headline: Review: ‘NOW.’ Uses Technology to Pair Dancers Thousands of Miles Apart
abstract: Eight performed this Pat Catterson work at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University — joined by nine dancers from around the world, via Skype.
lead_paragraph: If you have used Skype, you know the sound: a low-fi digitization of numbers being pressed on a touch-tone phone, followed by a burbly version of ringing. Even if you grew up before the Internet age, the sound is familiar enough, though if someone answers on the other end, and the connection is good, then not just the voice but also the video image of that person appears, wherever he or she might be in the world.

headline: Report Describes Lawyers’ Advice on Moving Suspect Funds Into U.S.
abstract: The report is the result of an undercover investigation by Global Witness, a nonprofit group that has been pushing for stricter money-laundering rules.
lead_paragraph: With attention growing on the use of shell companies in high-end real estate, an activist organization released a report Sunday night that said several New York real estate lawyers had been caught on camera providing advice on how to move suspect money into the United States.

headline: Unpublished Black History
abstract: Revealing moments in black history, with unpublished photos from The New York Times’s archives. We’ll add images daily in February.
lead_paragraph: Images from black history, drawn from old negatives, have long been buried in the yellowed envelopes and crowded bins of the New York Times archives.

headline: Microcephaly, Spotlighted by Zika Virus, Has Long Afflicted and Mystified
abstract: Each year, an estimated 25,000 babies in the United States receive a diagnosis of microcephaly, an abnormally small head, but prognoses are hard to predict.
lead_paragraph: The images pouring out of Brazil are haunting: struggling newborns with misshapen heads, cradled by mothers who desperately want to know whether their babies will ever walk or talk.

headline: Arnold Greenberg, Whose Manhattan Bookstore Fostered Wanderlust, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Greenberg left behind a law firm in favor of an independent bookstore, Complete Traveller, which he and his wife ran for more than three decades.
lead_paragraph: On the corner of 35th Street and Madison Avenue in Manhattan, in a small shop filled with shelves of books containing photographs and stories meant to entice readers to exotic locales, Arnold Greenberg found a place where his passions intersected.

headline: New Technologies Give Government Ample Means to Track Suspects, Study Finds
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Computer Security', 'Privacy', 'Terrorism', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Fears that encrypted communication will prevent agencies from tracking terrorists are overstated, according to a study that included current and former intelligence officials.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — For more than two years the F.B.I. and intelligence agencies have warned that encrypted communications are creating a “going dark” crisis that will keep them from tracking terrorists and kidnappers.

headline: Wine Here! A Football Bud Gets Competition
abstract: Wine sales have been steadily growing faster than beer sales, especially around Super Bowl time.
lead_paragraph: Beer and football may go together like wine and cheese. But lately more and more people seem be favoring a Bordeaux over a Bud Light.

headline: Beer Ads That Portray Women as Empowered Consumers, Not Eye Candy
abstract: Beer companies are rethinking the fraternity house imagery and sophomoric humor that long defined their advertising campaigns.
lead_paragraph: For years, one of the main criticisms of beer advertising was that it tended to either objectify women or disregard them entirely. Marketers seemed to be too busy trying to appeal to the young male audience they knew would consistently drink beer by the case to worry about anyone else.

headline: U.S. Broadens Fight Against ISIS With Attacks in Afghanistan
abstract: The operations followed President Obama’s decision to expand the authority of American commanders to attack a new branch of the militant group in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States has carried out at least a dozen operations — including commando raids and airstrikes — in the past three weeks against militants in Afghanistan aligned with the Islamic State, expanding the Obama administration’s military campaign against the terrorist group beyond Iraq and Syria.

headline: Ethanol Mandate, a Boon to Iowa Alone, Faces Rising Resistance
keywords: ['Ethanol', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Bioenergy and Biofuels', 'Corn', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Crop Controls and Subsidies', 'United States Economy']
abstract: A 2005 mandate requiring oil refiners to blend ethanol into gasoline has been a boondoggle for the rest of the country, and could face a congressional vote on its future.
lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa — Tim Recker has been growing corn in this state his whole life, and using his crops to make ethanol almost as long, at first by the jar for his trucks, now by the barrel for the nation. That is in large part because Congress in 2005 mandated that oil refiners blend ethanol into gasoline.

headline: Deal Restricts Tourist Helicopter Flights Over New York
abstract: Under the agreement, the number of helicopter flights will be halved by January 2017, and they will be banned from flying over Governors Island and Staten Island.
lead_paragraph: After decades of complaints about noise and air pollution from the tens of thousands of tourist helicopter flights that circle Manhattan each year, New York City announced a deal on Sunday that would cut their number in half by January 2017.

headline: Scott Gomez, a Onetime Rookie Star, Is Again an N.H.L. Prospect
abstract: Gomez, 36, who had 181 goals in his 1,066-game N.H.L. career, winning two Stanley Cups with the Devils, hopes to work his way up from the A.H.L.’s Hershey Bears.
lead_paragraph: HERSHEY, Pa. — Less than 21 hours after a game in Syracuse, and less than 17 hours after the team bus rolled back into town, Scott Gomez perched astride the boards at Giant Center, awaiting the first shift of the seventh American Hockey League game of his life.

headline: Oil Company Earnings, Trader’s ‘Flash Crash’ Hearing and the Jobs Report
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Automobiles', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: This week Exxon Mobil, BP and Royal Dutch Shell will report quarterly earnings, Navinder Singh Sarao is expected back in court and the Labor Department will release figures on hiring and unemployment.
lead_paragraph: Alphabet is expected to report earnings on Monday and, for the first time, to reveal financial data for each entity under its holding company structure — that includes the online ad unit Google, and the smart device maker Nest, among others.

headline: An Unwanted Circus Descends, and an Oregon Town Strives to Stay Kind
abstract: Journalists, protesters, officials and ideologues have swamped tiny Burns, Ore., and its residents have responded by offering couches, meals and coffee.
lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — Remote Western towns, in midwinter’s grip, definitely have some romance to them. But this one has become a circus tent: A giddy but tense crush of humanity has descended here in rural eastern Oregon, benefiting businesses and swamping them, filling bars, and making motel rooms unattainable amid a bizarre tide of guns, police, reporters and ideologues quoting (at length) from the United States Constitution.

headline: Warriors’ League of Their Own Needs Time: Four Months
abstract: After nearly falling to the woeful 76ers on Saturday night, Golden State appeared to be mortal, until a buzzer-beating 3-pointer flew in the face of the basketball gods.
lead_paragraph: Anything can happen, right? The extraordinary Golden State Warriors can be cruising to a victory over the N.B.A.’s worst team and, within 12 unforeseen basketball minutes, have to escape Philadelphia and the 7-41 76ers on a buzzer-beating 3-pointer by Harrison Barnes.

headline: Saudi Coalition in Yemen Announces Inquiry Into Bombings
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Civilian Casualties']
abstract: Responding to criticism of its bombings in Yemen, which rights groups have called war crimes, the Saudi-led military coalition there announced the formation of an investigative committee.
lead_paragraph: Responding to criticism of its rampant bombings in Yemen, including a toughly worded appraisal from a United Nations panel that was leaked last week, the Saudi-led military coalition fighting there announced on Sunday the formation of a “high-level independent committee” to investigate the bombardments, which rights groups have called war crimes.

headline: Initially Rebuffed, Bill de Blasio Quietly Canvasses in Iowa for Hillary Clinton
abstract: The mayor of New York City described the joy he took in the yeoman’s work of a campaign, walking down residential streets and speaking with voters directly.
lead_paragraph: INDIANOLA, Iowa — Back home, he oversees the lives of millions of New Yorkers. Here in the Midwest, he took pains to be just another volunteer, traipsing along residential streets and speaking with Iowans who knew little about him.

headline: Late Goal Gives U.S. Hope That 2016 Will Be a Brighter Year
abstract: The United States national team began rectifying the disappointment of last season by rallying for a 3-2 win over Iceland in an exhibition in Carson, Calif.
lead_paragraph: CARSON, Calif. — A new year means new hope, revised goals, a chance to reinvigorate the spirit. For the United States national team, it means an opportunity to erase the bad taste from a disappointing 2015.

headline: Donald Trump Delivers Flurry of Flattery in Iowa
abstract: True to form, Mr. Trump’s closing message to Iowa Republicans heading into Monday night’s caucuses has been unruly, inconsistent, and sometimes unpredictable.
lead_paragraph: COUNCIL BLUFFS, Iowa — Over the last few days, Donald J. Trump has proposed having Medicare negotiate lower prescription drug prices — a Democratic objective that Republicans hate — and, more characteristically of his party, has vowed to repeal the Affordable Care Act, which would leave millions of people without health insurance.

headline: Don’t Shoot the Messenger, Israel
abstract: Lashing out at critics will not resolve an untenable occupation.
lead_paragraph: United Nations — IN Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories, 2016 has begun much as 2015 ended — with unacceptable levels of violence and a polarized public discourse. That polarization showed itself in the halls of the United Nations last week when I pointed out a simple truth: History proves that people will always resist occupation.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Pacers at Hawks

lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — It’s a can’t-miss joke that Senator Bernie Sanders cannot stop telling.

headline: Koch Political Group Spent $400 Million in 2015, Officials Say

lead_paragraph: The political network overseen by Charles and David Koch spent $400 million in 2015 to fund political and philanthropic organizations, officials announced on Saturday at the Koch’s annual winter conference in California.

abstract: As New York City’s homeless population increases and temperatures drop, officials are worried about people illegally living in vacant properties and increasing the risk of fires.

Thick plumes of smoke filled her lungs as Ms. Diaz’s fears were confirmed: The abandoned house on her block was burning.

headline: Bernie’s Revolution vs. Hillary’s Getting Things Done
abstract: The Democratic candidates agree that policy needs to change. They disagree on how to make it happen.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders are locked in an intense, occasionally nasty, policy battle — a fight finally being put to its first voter test today in Iowa. One advocates a single-payer health care system (Mr. Sanders), the other is attacking his plan to make it a reality (Mrs. Clinton). One refuses to raise taxes on the middle class (Mrs. Clinton), the other is O.K. with doing so in order to fund certain programs (Mr. Sanders). Mrs. Clinton is hammering her opponent over his previous milquetoast support for gun control measures. Mr. Sanders claims Mrs. Clinton doesn’t go far enough on Wall Street reform.

headline: The Cornfield Crucible
abstract: This year, oddball Iowa is a must-win contest for presidential front-runners, especially the Republicans.
lead_paragraph: Small and mostly rural, overwhelmingly white and unusually religious, Iowa is not a microcosm of America. But it’s the undeniable birthplace of political success stories that few saw coming. From Jimmy Carter to Barack Obama, Iowa’s esoteric caucus system is a crucible where a long shot without much money and a lot of time to shake hands can make it onto the nation’s radar screen.

headline: The Irrationality of Natural Life Sentences
abstract: We can’t know the future. Condemning a person to be in prison until death ignores that fact.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been teaching philosophy for 15 years, and while I’ve had some very memorable experiences along the way, I knew early on that my current seminar would be unique. The course itself is on values, and each Monday for nearly three hours my students debate — in an often lively and engaging manner — issues ranging from the existence of universal moral truths to the permissibility of torture and the death penalty. In fact, a few weeks ago, there was a complaint about the level of noise coming from my classroom. The reason for the noise? The utilitarians were rather loudly arguing to the Kantians that sacrificing one of their classmates to prevent the Paris attacks would clearly have been justified.

headline: Hieronymus Bosch Is Credited With Work in Kansas City Museum
abstract: A 16th-century depiction of St. Anthony that had been attributed to the workshop of Bosch or a follower is now thought to be by the Dutch master’s hand.
lead_paragraph: ’S-HERTOGENBOSCH, the Netherlands — A small 16th-century oil on panel largely kept in storage at a Kansas City, Mo., museum is a work by the Dutch Renaissance master Hieronymus Bosch, researchers here said on Monday, a finding that, if accepted by other scholars, would add to the tiny list of about 25 recognized Bosch paintings in the world.

headline: It’s Been 10 Years. Would Clarence Thomas Like to Add Anything?

Unless something very surprising happens during the arguments that day, Justice Clarence Thomas will have gone 10 years without asking a question from the bench.

headline: Black America and the Class Divide
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Income Inequality', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The economic gap within the African-American community is one of the most important factors in the rise of Black Lives Matter, led by a new generation of college graduates and students.
lead_paragraph: In 1903, W. E. B. Du Bois, the leading scholar of the first half of the 20th century, defined the urgency of black social responsibility in his famous essay “The Talented Tenth” — 10 being the percentage of the African-American demographic needed to lead the race into an integrated, equal America. In “The Talented Tenth,” Du Bois called for “intelligent leadership” directed by “college-trained men” devoted to a “thorough understanding of the mass of Negroes and their problems” for the purpose of solving these problems, still so deeply entrenched a half century after the abolition of slavery.

headline: Janet Napolitano Reviews Peter Bergen’s ‘United States of Jihad’
abstract: A study seeks answers to why some ‘ordinary’ citizens become jihadists.
lead_paragraph: Who constitutes a homegrown jihadist, and what distinguishes the terrorist attack in San Bernardino from the mass murder at Sandy Hook Elementary School? In post-9/11 America, questions like these shape our national discourse on terrorism, law enforcement and public safety. Peter Bergen, CNN’s national security analyst and the author of four other books on terrorism, addresses these and other salient questions in his excellent new “United States of Jihad: Investigating America’s Homegrown Terrorists.” Bergen seeks to understand why some Americans choose to become jihadists, how our institutions have responded to terrorism and how American society has been changed by terrorist threats. Terrorism has long existed in this country — Bergen describes the 1970s as the “golden age” of terrorism in the United States — but the horrific attacks of Sept. 11 and the loss of nearly 3,000 lives on American soil were to earlier terrorist attacks as a tsunami is to a high tide. Just as a tsunami leaves a landscape forever altered once it retreats, so too has Sept. 11 fundamentally changed America. The difficulty Bergen faces in mapping and analyzing post-9/11 homegrown terrorism is the ever shifting, contemporaneous terrain of his subject — it’s a bit like writing a history of the 1960s while the Beatles are still singing. Nonetheless, Bergen’s book is the best one-volume treatment available on the current state of jihad in America.

headline: Everything About Everything: David Foster Wallace’s ‘Infinite Jest’ at 20
abstract: Two decades after it was published, Wallace’s novel still feels transcendentally, electrically alive.
lead_paragraph: [On this week’s Inside The New York Times Book Review podcast, Tom Bissell and the editor Michael Pietsch discuss “Infinite Jest.”]

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 1, 2016
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by commenting on what you see and why. A live discussion is offered that day from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: Updated: Feb. 5, 2016

headline: Our Man in Iowa: How the Iowa Caucuses Work
abstract: We sent our reporter Trip Gabriel to live in Iowa. Now it is caucuses day.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Good morning from Iowa, where it is finally showtime. At 7 p.m. here on Monday, Republican and Democratic caucuses will be called to order in 1,681 precincts around the state. It’s an arcane relic of neighbor-to-neighbor politics, but also an example of democracy at its grass-roots finest. This final Our Man in Iowa dispatch answers frequently asked questions on the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Benoît Violier’s Death Shines Light on High-Pressure Restaurant World
abstract: Mr. Violier ran the Restaurant de l’Hôtel de Ville in Switzerland, which was named the world’s best in December. The police said his death appeared to have been a suicide.
lead_paragraph: In the rarefied galaxy of restaurants that have received the Michelin guide’s highest honor, three stars, Benoît Violier’s, in Switzerland, was by one measure the most glittering.

headline: Finding a Drug for Healthy Aging
abstract: Researchers are seeking drugs that can slow the rate of aging and the development of the debilitating chronic ailments that typically accompany it.
lead_paragraph: Given their druthers, most people would opt for a long and healthy life. Few relish the idea of spending years, even decades, incapacitated by illness, dependent on caregivers and unable to enjoy the people, places and activities that make life worth living.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Donald Trump, Bernie Sanders, Syria
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start your day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Monday Briefing.
abstract: Here’s what you need to know to start the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know to start the day.

headline: Morning Agenda: Barclays and Credit Suisse to Settle ‘Dark Pool’ Inquiries
abstract: Puerto Rico Proposes Plan to Delay Debt Payments | Goldman’s Role as Lender in Short Sales
lead_paragraph: BARCLAYS AND CREDIT SUISSE TO SETTLE ‘DARK POOL’ INQUIRIES | Barclays and Credit Suisse will pay a combined $154.3 million to settle allegations that they misrepresented their private stock trading services,

headline: New York Today: Celebrating Black History
abstract: Black History Month, cloudy skies, and a house in Harlem.
lead_paragraph: Updated at 9:30 a.m.

headline: ScienceTake | Plants Can Count?
abstract: The Venus flytrap, a plant that eats insects, will clamp its leaves shut only after trigger hairs are tripped two times within about 20 seconds. Even without nerves, it counts electric impulses that go from cell to cell.
lead_paragraph: The Venus flytrap, a plant that eats insects, will clamp its leaves shut only after trigger hairs are tripped two times within about 20 seconds. Even without nerves, it counts electric impulses that go from cell to cell.

headline: A Tabletop Sanctuary
abstract: For Imam Khalid Latif, a chaplain of the New York Police Department, his dining table provides a haven.
lead_paragraph: Until six months ago, Imam Khalid Latif, a chaplain of the New York Police Department and the executive director of the Islamic Center at New York University, did not own a dining table.

headline: The Venus Flytrap, a Plant That Can Count
abstract: By wiring up the insect-eating plant, scientists found that it counted the electrical impulses that came from trigger hairs on its leafy jaws.
lead_paragraph: Carnivorous plants stir the imagination. You can find the results in science fiction novels (“The Day of the Triffids”), Broadway plays(“Little Shop of Horrors”) and in recent research that concludes that the Venus flytrap can count.

headline: Let the Voting Begin
abstract: After months of stump speeches, debates, fund-raisers and town-hall-style events, the candidates are finally ready to face voters in the nation’s first nominating contest, at the caucuses in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Monday night does not signify the end of the 2016 presidential campaign. But it does signify the end of the beginning, as Iowans head to their caucus sites to nominate their choice of candidate for the Democratic and Republican Parties.

headline: Does a Crack in a Carrot Spell Ruin for the Root Vegetable?
abstract: Growth cracks can originate during the growth period from uneven moisture. As to the safety of cracked carrots, common sense should be the rule.
lead_paragraph: Q. Why are some carrots split or deeply cracked, and why are more of these showing up in stores? Are they safe to eat?

headline: Italian-Iranian Hall of Mirrors
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Nudism and Nudity', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Art', 'Sculpture', 'Museums', 'Politics and Government', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: The West has not capitulated by hiding the Capitoline nudes. But Italy has again failed the test of seriousness.
lead_paragraph: Italy’s decision to cover up the nudes at the Capitoline Museum in deference to the sensibilities of the visiting Glasgow-educated Iranian president has been widely interpreted as final proof of the capitulation of Western civilization to theocratic Islam.

headline: Taliban Bombing Kills at Least 20 at Kabul Police Station
abstract: The new attack on the capital came as American officials gave a grim new estimate of Afghan casualties in last year’s fighting.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban suicide bomber struck near a Kabul police complex on Monday, killing at least 20 police officers and wounding 29 people, Afghan officials said, in the latest of a rapid-fire series of militant attacks on the capital this year.

headline: SAG Win for ‘Spotlight’ Sows Confusion in the Best Picture Race
abstract: As the guilds go with different top films, only Leonardo DiCaprio and Brie Larson have cemented their status as Oscar front-runners.
lead_paragraph: The Screen Actors Guild Awards were handed out over the weekend and managed in one fell swoop to both clarify and muddy the Oscars race.

headline: Cruise and Air News: Robots Onboard; Chefs Too
keywords: ['Cruises', 'Robots and Robotics', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: What you need to know if you’re on a trip or planning one soon, including a Lincoln Center cruise and a remake of Terminal 2 at Los Angeles International Airport.

headline: Iowa Caucuses: The Political Divides to Watch Out For
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: An explanation of the state’s demographic divides, and how that affects candidates’ chances.
lead_paragraph: Join us for live coverage of the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Exploitation of Endangered Species Feared as China Revisits Wildlife Law
keywords: ['Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A proposed revision makes explicit that endangered species are “natural resources” that can be legally bred in captivity for commercial purposes.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A proposed revision to China‘s Wildlife Protection Law is being criticized by conservationists who fear it could legitimize the commercial exploitation of endangered species, such as tigers, bears and pangolins.

headline: 1916: Zeppelin Raid Buries Victims
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A Zeppelin raid traps 29 victims in Paris in 1916.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Though Paris, with its customary gay courage, had dismissed Saturday’s Zeppelin raid by Sunday evening as one of the inevitable incidents of the present war, it was not until yesterday that the terror of the sky raider was lifted from twenty-nine persons who have just been rescued from the tomb of masonry that one of the bombs had sealed upon them. There were some apertures high up in the accidental prison and ladders were raised to these so that food and water could be lowered. It was only yesterday that the rescuers broke through the last barriers and liberated the captives. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 2, 1916

headline: Your Team Made the Super Bowl? Better Get a Flu Shot
abstract: Parties built around the big game can give you more than just heartburn, research shows.
lead_paragraph: If your home team is playing in the Super Bowl (looking at you, Denver Broncos and Carolina Panthers fans), the parties you attend could give you more than just heartburn, a hangover or temporary psychological discomfort.

headline: John Kerry Urges Syrian Factions Not to Squander U.N. Talks
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The major world powers — as well as regional actors that have fueled the war — have all given their blessings for talks to take place, but they want different things.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — In a forceful, videotaped message circulated on social media on Sunday, Secretary of State John Kerry urged the rival factions in Syria not to squander the opportunity to engage in United Nations-mediated talks that began haltingly on Friday in Geneva aimed at crafting a political settlement to the conflict.

headline: Prudential of Britain Hires New C.E.O. for Asset Management Business
abstract: Anne H. Richards, the chief investment officer of Aberdeen Asset Management, is expected to succeed Michael McLintock, who is retiring as chief executive of M&G Investments.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British insurer Prudential said on Monday that it had hired the chief investment officer of Aberdeen Asset Management to serve as the new top executive of its asset management business, M&G Investments.

headline: Online Lender Ezubao Took $7.6 Billion in Ponzi Scheme, China Says
abstract: The accusations cast a shadow over the country’s web-based finance industry, a lucrative sector that the authorities say is the subject of a growing number of fraud cases.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A Chinese online finance company bilked investors out of more than $7.6 billion, spent lavishly on gifts and salaries and buried the evidence, according to local authorities who described the operation as an enormous Ponzi scheme.

headline: G.E. to Phase Out CFL Bulbs
keywords: ['Electric Light Bulbs', 'Light-Emitting Diodes', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Compact Fluorescent Light Bulbs']
abstract: The compact fluorescent light bulb, once the undisputed energy-efficient alternative, is being overtaken by LEDs and will not be made or sold in the United States by G.E. by year’s end.
lead_paragraph: Just a few years ago, the compact fluorescent light was the go-to choice for customers seeking an inexpensive, energy-efficient replacement for the standard incandescent bulb. But as the light quality of LEDs improved and their cost plummeted, manufacturers and retailers began shifting their efforts in that direction.

headline: 1941: Nazis Gave World a Warning
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A book written by a German professor in 1932 had outlined the rise of the Nazis, in 1941.
lead_paragraph: Every success that Nazi Germany has had in Europe since the advent of Adolf Hitler was carefully planned as a rigid course of action by a German professor of geography, who in Brunswick, Germany, Sept. 2, 1932, grasped his pen in cold hate and urged defeated Germany to ‘‘take up the sword in both hands’’ against the enemy of the Reich, ‘‘smiting him hip and thigh till we split him in two from top to bottom.’’ The actual textbook apparently has been the relatively little known ‘‘Raum und Volk im Weltkriege,’’ which was published in the United States in 1934 as ‘‘Germany Prepares for War.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 2, 1941

headline: John Kasich and Chris Christie Face New Hampshire Elimination Round
abstract: The latest round of campaign finance filings revealed just how high the stakes are in New Hampshire for Gov. Chris Christie Christie of New Jersey and Gov. John Kasich of Ohio in the Republican presidential race.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. – Gov. John Kasich of Ohio and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey are locked in an increasingly bitter fight in New Hampshire. Both men have anchored their presidential campaigns in the state, holding dozens of town hall meetings and spending most of their money in an effort to seize momentum here.

headline: U.N. Rights Chief Urges Turkey to Investigate Shooting of Civilians
abstract: Two were said to have been killed when troops appeared to open fire on an unarmed group about 10 days ago. The wounded included a journalist who filmed the episode.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations’ top human rights official urged Turkey on Monday to investigate a report that the army shot unarmed civilians in the mainly Kurdish southeast, and expressed alarm at a crackdown on journalists and critics of the country’s government.

headline: More About Renewables
abstract: Joe Romm has the details.
lead_paragraph: I’ve learned a lot of what I know about energy economics from Joe Romm, and he has a post this morning that is, in effect, a primer on the background to today’s column. As I tried to convey, the news is amazingly good — we now have the technology to shift dramatically away from fossil fuels, at relatively low cost.

headline: Abbott to Acquire Alere, a Maker of Medical Diagnostics Tests
abstract: Alere, which makes point-of-care medical tests that can provide results in a matter of minutes, will enhance Abbott’s diagnostics business.
lead_paragraph: Abbott said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire Alere for an expected $5.8 billion to enhance its diagnostics business.

headline: Daily Report: More Earnings, Earnings, Earnings
abstract: The tech earnings season is hitting peak news this week with big reveals from Alphabet and Yahoo.
lead_paragraph: We are now getting to the newsiest part of the tech earnings cycle.

headline: Light Government Touch Lets China’s Hui Practice Islam in the Open
abstract: For the Muslims in the Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, there are fewer limitations on religion. “Life for the Hui is very good,” an imam said.
lead_paragraph: WUZHONG, China — As the call to prayer echoed off the high walls of the madrasa and into the surrounding village, dozens of boys, dressed in matching violet caps, poured out of their dorm rooms and headed to the mosque.

headline: Prediction Markets: Donald Trump’s Nomination Chances Better Than 50 Percent
abstract: Political prediction markets, where traders bet on the outcome of the election, give him a 51 percent chance of becoming the Republican nominee.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump is now more likely than not to win the Republican nomination.

headline: Manchester City, Set for a Banner Year, Hires Pep Guardiola
abstract: Although in second place in the Premier League under Manuel Pellegrini, City announced it had signed Guardiola, of Bayern Munich, to take over as manager next season.
lead_paragraph: Manchester City sits in second place in the Premier League, behind only the unlikely Leicester City. The team is also in the final of the League Cup and the last 16 of the F.A. Cup and the Champions League. In theory, it could win all four trophies this season.

headline: The Strip — 2015
keywords: ['Comic Books and Strips', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Cartoons about current affairs.
lead_paragraph: Cartoons about current affairs.

headline: Barclays Center in Brooklyn Becomes a Classroom
abstract: Whether it is Barclays or the old Ebbets Field, a stadium can bring tremendous changes to its neighborhood, as one class at Packer Collegiate Institute is learning.
lead_paragraph: It was hard to tell what the 19 ninth graders, seated in section 213 at Barclays Center in Brooklyn for a game between the New York Islanders and the Detroit Red Wings, were enjoying more: the action on the ice, or the long inflatable noisemakers in their hands. With each hit or shot came a cacophonous, joyous thumpathumpathumping.

headline: Strongholds for China’s Hui Muslims
abstract: Throughout Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region and Gansu Province, mosques soar, adolescents study the Quran and muezzin summon the faithful via loudspeakers.
lead_paragraph: Throughout Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region and Gansu Province, mosques soar, adolescents study the Quran and muezzin summon the faithful via loudspeakers.

headline: A Trove of Rarities in ‘Jazz Singers’ Exhibition at Library of Congress
abstract: “Jazz Singers” is to open at the Library of Congress on Feb. 11 and remain on view until July.
lead_paragraph: Video clips and artifacts connected to Billie Holiday, Ella Fitzgerald and Sarah Vaughan will be showcased at the Library of Congress this month as part of a new “Jazz Singers” exhibition, opening Feb. 11. The exhibition will pull from the library’s extensive archives and include rarely seen documents like Chet Baker’s suicide note, as well as contributions from the current singers Cecile McLorin Salvant and Esperanza Spalding, the bass player.

headline: 失业的缅甸大象
abstract: 为了治理森林退化，缅甸新上台的民主政府禁止原木出口。数千头长期为伐木业辛勤工作的大象却因此失业。
lead_paragraph: 为了治理森林退化，缅甸新上台的民主政府禁止原木出口。数千头长期为伐木业辛勤工作的大象却因此失业。

headline: Ahead of Iowa, Winners in Presidential Style
abstract: Donald Trump leads over all, but Chris Christie and Ted Cruz are tied with him in the subcategory of “presidential style.”
lead_paragraph: Just as the Iowa caucuses, the first official test of the 2016 presidential election, begin, and with the New Hampshire primary looming next week, a new study has been released that looks at the candidates and their appeal in a somewhat different light. To be specific: a fashion light.

headline: Zika Virus a Global Health Emergency, W.H.O. Says
abstract: In its decision, the World Health Organization highlighted the seriousness of the Zika outbreak, a mosquito-borne virus thought to cause birth defects that has exploded in Latin America, and gave countries powerful tools to fight it.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization declared the Zika virus and its suspected link to birth defects an international public health emergency on Monday, a rare move that signals the seriousness of the outbreak and gives countries new tools to fight it.

headline: Laura Carmichael Discusses Edith’s Evolution on ‘Downton Abbey’
abstract: Ms. Carmichael talks about her character’s bad luck, the problem with male editors and sisterly rivalry.
lead_paragraph: Lady Edith Crawley, the second Grantham sister, has had a miserable time through most of the six seasons of “Downton Abbey.” Always second fiddle to her sister Mary, Edith, played by Laura Carmichael, has been jilted at the altar, involved with a married man (his wife was in a mental institution), then left pregnant when he mysteriously disappeared. But in Seasons 5 and 6, Edith emerges from her chrysalis to become an independent woman about London town, running a magazine and finding her own voice and perhaps, if Julian Fellowes, the writer of the series, allows, romantic happiness, too.

headline: The Everlasting Power of the Bad Girl Haircut
abstract: Jane Fonda’s signature shag has incredible staying power but isn’t for everyone. There’s no hiding the rebelliousness it suggests.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘Hair had ruled me for many years,’’ Jane Fonda wrote in her autobiography, ‘‘My Life So Far.’’ The men in her life had historically preferred her hair long, blond and becomingly combed, but she grew restless. Fonda presented herself to the hairstylist Paul McGregor, instructed him to ‘‘Do something’’ and emerged a short time later with her honeyed shoulder-length curtain darkened and frayed into the cut that ‘‘Klute’’ made famous.

headline: 1886 | ‘My Poor Old Jumbo, Your Alice Weeps for You’
abstract: The death of Jumbo the elephant in 1885 and the arrival the following year of his “widow,” Alice, inspired some mammoth stories in The Times.
lead_paragraph: The death of a single rat was news in The New York Times on Jan. 26.

headline: Using a Mother’s Microbes to Protect Cesarean Babies
abstract: A new study shows that a mother’s beneficial microbes can be transferred, at least partially, from her vagina to her baby after a C-section.
lead_paragraph: The first germs to colonize a newborn delivered vaginally come almost exclusively from its mother. But the first to reach an infant born by cesarean section come mostly from the environment — particularly bacteria from inaccessible or less-scrubbed areas like lamps and walls, and skin cells from everyone else in the delivery room.

headline: Alcoa to Add 3 Directors, Heading Off a Board Fight
abstract: The agreement with Elliott Management, the activist hedge fund, comes as Alcoa prepares to divide itself into two.
lead_paragraph: Alcoa has headed off a potential board fight with the activist hedge fund Elliott Management, announcing on Monday that it will add three directors.

headline: Powerful Storm Kills Driver and Wreaks Havoc in California
abstract: Severe weather lashed San Diego and Los Angeles Counties. A driver was killed after fierce winds sent an 80-foot tree crashing onto her vehicle in San Diego, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A powerful storm that unleashed heavy rains and gale winds up to 85 miles an hour over the weekend also tore off rooftops, toppled trees and utility poles, and knocked out power to tens of thousands of customers in San Diego and Los Angeles, officials said.

headline: 12 Great Recipes for Right Now
abstract: Lamb chops tonight. For the rest of the week, cheesy pasta bake, chicory salad, chicken tagine and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Race on College Campuses
abstract: New York Times journalists, student activists and college administrators discussed race on college campuses on Feb. 4.
lead_paragraph: New York Times journalists, student activists and college administrators discussed race on college campuses on Feb. 4.

headline: A Dutch Designer Makes Her Name in Lights
abstract: The artist Sabine Marcelis’s neon and resin sculptures were the talk of Design Miami.
lead_paragraph: When the California Light and Space artists of the 1960s made Minimalist sculptures out of neon tubes and cast acrylic, they were appropriating what was then cutting-edge industrial technology. More than half a century later, the 30-year-old Dutch designer Sabine Marcelis is using those materials for what she sees as their incomparable visceral impact. ‘‘Neon is such a magical medium,’’ she says. ‘‘There’s still no true alternative to its presence and light quality.’’ Marcelis, whose résumé includes work for Céline and Stella McCartney, made a splash in December at Design Miami with her neon and resin ‘‘Dawn’’ light sculptures for the Victor Hunt gallery.

headline: How Wealth Plays Into Politics at a Personal Level
keywords: ['Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Research generally confirms what many voters perhaps always intuited: that wealth changes political leaders qualitatively.
lead_paragraph: The debate over widening inequality, and what to do about it, has gradually moved toward the center of the political agenda and fueled populist movements on the left and the right in many nations.

headline: Catch. No Catch. You Make the Call
abstract: Here are seven times this season that fans were baffled by a ruling. See if you can make the right call.
lead_paragraph: Here are seven times this season that fans were baffled by a ruling. See if you can make the right call.

headline: Spend the Money for the Good Boots, and Wear Them Forever
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Personal Finances', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: The cheaper, lower-quality item can be a bad deal if you’ll have to replace it several times before the more expensive, higher-quality one would wear out.
lead_paragraph: I like buying high-quality things. And for the longest time, I’ve had this sneaking suspicion that buying high-quality stuff, which perhaps initially was more expensive, actually saved me money in the long run. It wasn’t until very recently, though, that I noticed a strong argument in support of my hunch.

headline: Seven Marathons in Seven Days, Crossing Each Finish Line for Fellow Marines
abstract: Marine Corps Captain Calum Rammhe, a longtime marathon runner, ran seven marathons on seven continents in seven days to raise money for a charity that supports wounded Marines and their families. It also let him reflect on why running is more than a hobby for him.
lead_paragraph: Calum Ramm, a captain in the Marine Corps, has run many marathons in his day, but last week he set out on a far bigger challenge: running seven marathons on seven continents in just seven days as part of the World Marathon Challenge. Starting off deep in Antarctica on Jan. 23, he went on to complete marathons in Chile, Miami, Madrid, Morocco and Dubai before the finale in Sydney, Australia, on Friday. Only 15 athletes took part; those who finished ran 183.4 miles through snow, mountains, tropical heat and city streets.

headline: What’s a Catch? In the N.F.L., the Rule Seems Impossible to Grasp
abstract: Every week, it seems, at least one crucial pass play in the N.F.L. is scrutinized, reviewed via video and debated over whether it really was a catch.
lead_paragraph: The first completed forward pass in professional football came in 1906, when quarterback George Parratt, who was known as Peggy, threw to an end named Bullet Dan Riley for the Massillon Tigers, a team from Ohio. There were no reports of disputes over whether it really was a catch.

headline: What Is Marco Rubio After in Iowa?
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tea Party Movement', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How the Florida senator’s campaign is hoping to make the best of a likely third-place showing in the state’s caucus.
lead_paragraph: In the final days before today’s Iowa caucus, the campaign staff of the Republican presidential candidate Senator Marco Rubio worked furiously to quash a scurrilous story line about their candidate that had been circulating among the Washington commentariat. The damaging rumor in question was that Rubio — who for weeks has been considered Iowa’s likely third-place finisher, behind Ted Cruz and Donald Trump — was in fact closing in on Cruz and likely to place second.

headline: George Soros Donated Millions to Pro-Hillary Clinton Group in 2015
abstract: George Soros contributed $6 million in December to Priorities USA Action, a “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton’s presidential bid, and $8 million to the group in 2015.
lead_paragraph: George Soros, whose reputation for big-money giving has loomed larger than his actual checkbook in most recent election cycles, contributed $6 million in December to Priorities USA Action, a “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton’s presidential bid.

headline: Peru’s Possible Prison Presidency
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: A former general is running for the top job in April’s election even as he faces trial for the army’s 1988 assassination of a journalist.
lead_paragraph: Lima, Peru — In the 1980s, Hugo Bustíos was a photojournalist working in Ayacucho, a province in Peru that was then under martial law. The army was waging a brutal counterinsurgency campaign against the Maoist rebels known as Sendero Luminoso, or the Shining Path. Mr. Bustíos’s work as a reporter made him an inconvenient witness to atrocities committed by both sides, and he had received numerous death threats.

headline: Set to Start Dream Job, Reporter Dies at 32
abstract: Michael J. Feeney, 32, was about to start a new job at CNN but fell ill and abruptly died from complications from a staph infection.
lead_paragraph: A former reporter for The Daily News in New York, Michael J. Feeney, was about to start his dream job as an entertainment reporter with CNN when he became sick last week. On Sunday, Mr. Feeney died in a New Jersey hospital of complications from a staph infection in his kidneys, his mother, Reba Willis, said.

headline: Some Hunter-Gatherers Had a Taste for Tortoises, Study Says
keywords: ['Turtles and Tortoises', 'ARCHAEOLOGY AND ANTHROPOLOGY', 'Caves and Caverns']
abstract: In a cave near Tel Aviv, researchers found evidence of what the inhabitants ate more than 400,000 years ago.
lead_paragraph: More than 400,000 years ago, hunter-gatherers living in what is now Israel perked up a diet of game and vegetables with something unusual: tortoises.

headline: A Valentine’s Day Playlist From Elijah Wood’s D.J. Duo
abstract: Love-inspired tracks from the vinyl-spinning actor and his partner, Zach Cowie, who first met at a Rodarte party.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago, Zach Cowie and Elijah Wood met at a party thrown by the Rodarte designers, Kate and Laura Mulleavy. Cowie was the D.J., Wood was a guest, and the two bonded over obscure music — or as Cowie put it, “over a similar sense of adventure in our music consumption.” Soon after, they formed Wooden Wisdom, spinning all-vinyl, danceable ’70s psychedelic funk and garage mainly for their friends — and on occasion, at a venue near you.

headline: Google Artificial Intelligence Beats Expert at Go Game
abstract: This week we celebrate the victory of Google’s computer AI with a simple strategy challenge.
lead_paragraph: Tremendous news last week: Google announced that it had created a computer program that defeated a professional player at Go – an event that many thought was still a decade away.

headline: Exploring the Cuisine of Tokyo and Kanazawa
abstract: From Tokyo to Kanazawa on Japan’s northern coast, sampling the culinary wizardry of a new wave of creative chefs.
lead_paragraph: From Tokyo to Kanazawa on Japan’s northern coast, sampling the culinary wizardry of a new wave of creative chefs.

headline: How to Build a TimesMachine
abstract: At the beginning of this year, we expanded TimesMachine, our virtual microfilm reader — learn about how we tackled some technical challenges to do so.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of this year, we quietly expanded TimesMachine, our virtual microfilm reader, to include every issue of The New York Times published between 1981 and 2002. Prior to this expansion, TimesMachine contained every issue published between 1851 and 1980, which consisted of over 11 million articles spread out over approximately 2.5 million pages. The new expansion adds an additional 8,035 complete issues containing 1.4 million articles over 1.6 million pages.

headline: SFX Entertainment Declares Bankruptcy
abstract: The reorganization will take the company private, eliminate more than $300 million in debt and install a new chief executive to replace Robert F.X. Sillerman.
lead_paragraph: SFX Entertainment, the company created four years ago to capitalize on the popularity of dance music festivals, declared bankruptcy on Monday, after a troubled year in which the company’s founder abandoned a takeover bid and its stock plunged by more than 95 percent.

headline: African Union Says Crisis in South Sudan Is Worsening
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: A new, nine-page report blames government forces and rebels for the declining humanitarian situation, in which starvation, lack of government oversight and violence reign.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — A new report written for the African Union and made public on Monday presented an especially grim picture of South Sudan’s civil war, blaming government forces and rebels for the declining humanitarian situation in the world’s newest country.

headline: Women’s Views on Women Who Are Ovulating
abstract: In a study, women with higher estrogen levels found images of ovulating women to be more threatening.
lead_paragraph: Several studies suggest that men find women more attractive when they are in the ovulatory phase of their menstrual cycle.

headline: Pro-John Kasich ‘Super PAC’ Ad, Critical of Marco Rubio, Is Pulled
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Violence Against Women Act (1994)']
abstract: An ad by a pro-John Kasich “super PAC” criticized Marco Rubio for voting against the Violence Against Women Act, but a supporter of the bill, Senator Kelly Ayotte of New Hampshire, said she did not want the issue politicized, and the ad was pulled.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — A “super PAC” supporting Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio said it would take down an attack ad in New Hampshire after Senator Kelly Ayotte, the state’s popular Republican senator, criticized it as inappropriate and exploitative.

headline: Bernie Sanders and the Youth Vote
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Youth']
abstract: Bernie Sanders’s youthful fans are moved by his message, but are they fired up enough to turn out for him?
lead_paragraph: WATERLOO, Iowa — Bernie Sanders held a rock concert rally in Iowa this weekend, which seemed both fitting and unnecessary for a candidate whose every speech features cheering fans shouting requests for his greatest hits.

headline: A Guide to Mandarin Oranges
abstract: Some of the mandarin varieties available to U.S. consumers.
lead_paragraph: Some of the mandarin varieties available to U.S. consumers.

headline: Voter Who Confronted Ted Cruz on Obamacare Said He’s Surprised by the Attention
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: A Hillary Clinton supporter whose brother-in-law died shortly after he gained coverage under the Affordable Care Act said he got the idea to confront Senator Ted Cruz after hearing him speak in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Mike Valde attended a Ted Cruz speech, where the Texas senator delivered his standard presidential promise to repeal President Obama’s signature health care law.

headline: California’s Mandarin Industry
abstract: As the nation’s appetite for tangerines increases, California meets the demand.
lead_paragraph: As the nation’s appetite for tangerines increases, California meets the demand.

headline: Mandarin Oranges, Rising Stars of the Fruit Bowl
abstract: As sales boom, here’s help in finding the best of the fruit popularly known as tangerines.
lead_paragraph: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. — Along the Maricopa Highway at the southwestern end of the San Joaquin Valley, rimmed by hardscrabble hills and bobbing oil pumps, stretch miles of lush green groves bearing fluorescent mandarin oranges. Once home to cotton fields, this is now the epicenter of an epic agricultural boom that has industrialized a noble fruit and turned it into a rising star.

headline: Syria Talks Are Declared Open as Mediator Begins Shuttle Diplomacy
abstract: There have been no direct talks between the sides, but the United Nations mediator said he considered the negotiations officially started because he had conferred with each delegation.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Declaring the official beginning of the first Syria peace talks in two years, the United Nations mediator said Monday that they must show results to the country’s suffering civilians and he called on the outside powers that are helping drive the conflict to take steps to reduce the violence.

headline: Bluffer’s Guide to the Oscars: Best Supporting Actor
abstract: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.
lead_paragraph: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.

headline: Invitation to a Dialogue: Reclaim Reason in Politics
abstract: A political science professor says many voters today are “immune to evidence and rational argument.” Readers are invited to respond.

headline: Giving Sundance Movies a Second Chance
abstract: After the festival is over, its movies are often forgotten, but the website and app GoWatchIt can alert users when the films are released months later.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Many of the movies that played at this year’s Sundance Film Festival, which ended on Sunday, have already been forgotten. It’s harsh but true. Buzz comes and goes fast in the social media age.

headline: Temple of Dendur’s Lost Colors Brought to Life at the Met
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art’s MediaLab has installed a projector to show what this temple may have looked like in its original, polychromatic form.
lead_paragraph: As depicted in popular culture, ancient Egypt is awash with the color beige. A trip to the Metropolitan Museum of Art would seem to reflect that notion: The Temple of Dendur, with its weatherworn sandstone, could fit in naturally with the earth tones of “Aida” or “The Mummy.”

headline: ‘Grease: Live!’ Ratings Make Strong Case for TV Musicals
abstract: The Fox production was the second-most-viewed of the recent live TV musicals; next up for the network is “The Passion,” live from New Orleans, in March.
lead_paragraph: Live musicals on network television might be here to stay.

headline: Strategy of Alere Board Paid Off With Buyout by Abbott
abstract: The diligence of the board of Alere, a diagnostic tester, brought a chunky 51 percent premium in the $5.8 billion sale to Abbott, announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes a company’s directors get it right.

headline: From Iowa to N.H.: Updates
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Elections', 'Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Real-time news and analysis during and after Iowa caucuses, leading up to the New Hampshire primary.

headline: ‘Made at NYPL’ Features Robert Caro and Other Writers
keywords: ['Writing and Writers', 'Libraries and Librarians', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The New York Public Library is celebrating the authors who have spent time there writing or researching their works.
lead_paragraph: On the very day he arrived by ship in New York in January 1917, Leon Trotsky, who would become Lenin’s leading lieutenant in revolutionary Russia, was met by the editor Nikolai Bukharin. He dragged Trotsky across town to admire, the historian Orlando Figes wrote, “the most accessible major library in the world, open evenings and to anyone without any accreditation.”

headline: Megyn Kelly Will Appear on Post-Super Bowl Colbert Show
abstract: The Fox News host will join a lineup of guests that include Tina Fey, Will Ferrell and the comedy duo Key and Peele.
lead_paragraph: CBS announced on Monday that Stephen Colbert had added Megyn Kelly to his list of guests for a special edition of his show that will air in the valuable post-Super Bowl slot on Sunday night.

headline: Sacai’s Jewelry Collaboration With Sophie Bille Brahe
abstract: A 10-piece capsule collection of dangling earrings debuts today.
lead_paragraph: A 10-piece capsule collection of dangling earrings debuts today.

headline: In Williamsburg, Falafel in the Tel Aviv Style
abstract: Also, chocolates for the Lunar New Year and treats for the Super Bowl and Valentine’s Day.
lead_paragraph: For the new streetside kiosk attached to the 12 Chairs Cafe in Brooklyn, the chef, Shimon Maman, and his partners looked to Tel Aviv’s falafel stands. Pita bread comes with traditional stuffings like sabich (eggplant), kebabs, shakshuka and falafel, the last with fried potatoes in the sandwich. Mr. Maman said his fillings had “more finesse” than is typical in Israel. The stand is open from 9 a.m. to 4 p.m.; there is covered seating as well as takeout: The Kiosk, 12 Chairs Cafe, 342 Wythe Avenue (South Second Street), South Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 347-227-7077, 12chairscafe.com.

headline: A Yahoo Employee-Ranking System Favored by Marissa Mayer Is Challenged in Court
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Workplace Environment', 'Performance Evaluations (Labor)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A former Yahoo manager who lost his job filed suit in California on Monday, saying the system, which has been used to fire hundreds of employees, is discriminatory and violates the law.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — One of Marissa Mayer’s signature policies as chief executive of Yahoo has been the quarterly performance review, in which every employee at the company is ranked on a scale of 1 to 5. The ratings have been used to fire hundreds of employees since Ms. Mayer joined the company in mid-2012.

headline: Sacai’s Delicate — but Tough — New Jewelry Collaboration
abstract: The label teamed up with the jewelry designer Sophie Bille Brahe on a 10-piece capsule collection.
lead_paragraph: When the jewelry designer Sophie Bille Brahe first met Chitose Abe, the founder and designer of the ready-to-wear label Sacai, at Dover Street Market’s 10-year anniversary party in London in 2014, they instantly bonded. “I have always admired Chitose’s work and, when we met that night, she showed me she was wearing some of my jewelry,” Bille Brahe says. “The admiration, to my surprise and delight, was mutual.” Almost immediately, the two designers started talking about how they could work together. “We had the first conversation about a collaboration right then and there — and it became obvious that our styles were artistically compatible,” says Bille Brahe.

headline: China Is Latest Destination for Brazilian Stars
abstract: Last year, teams from China’s Super League bought the rights to the Brazilian league’s two best players, and the exodus is continuing, which some consider a worrisome trend.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — In this country’s top soccer league, the Brasileirão, team officials are used to the phone calls. They expect them. Agents and executives, middlemen and managers, all of them looking to make a deal in the game’s greatest shopping mall.

headline: Calvin Johnson: Bigger, Stronger, Faster and, Maybe Soon, Retired
abstract: Johnson, who is reportedly planning to retire, would immediately enter the discussion as one of the best young players to walk away, with per-game numbers that put him in elite company.
lead_paragraph: Nicknames have largely become a thing of the past in the sports world, but when Calvin Johnson arrived in the N.F.L., it was clear that he was going to be an exception. Called Megatron by his teammate Roy Williams, Johnson took on a larger-than-life persona as a wide receiver who was bigger, stronger and faster than anyone else on the field, not unlike the “Transformers” character that inspired the name.

headline: An Eating Disorder in People With Diabetes
abstract: Diabulimia occurs when people with Type 1 diabetes manipulate their insulin in order to purge calories, much as someone with bulimia might induce vomiting.
lead_paragraph: The first time she skipped an insulin dose, the 22-year-old said, it wasn’t planned. She was visiting her grandparents over a summer break from college and indulged in bags of potato chips and fistfuls of candy, but forgot to take the extra insulin that people with Type 1 diabetes, like her, require to keep their blood sugar levels in a normal range.

headline: Arrests in China over Finance Fraud
abstract: The founder and a partner of Ezubao, China’s largest online finance platform, described how they duped customers in what could be the biggest financial fraud case in the country’s history.
lead_paragraph: The founder and a partner of Ezubao, China’s largest online finance platform, described how they duped customers in what could be the biggest financial fraud case in the country’s history.

headline: Fire at Virginia Smokehouse Leaves Pork-to-Table Movement Reeling
abstract: A huge fire reduced Edwards Virginia Smokehouse to rubble, and the loss of its famed hams has had ripple effects far beyond the state.
lead_paragraph: SURRY, Va. — Sam Edwards learned the art of curing country hams growing up here on the banks of the James River, from his father and grandfather before him. They taught him the secrets of salt and hickory smoke, and how to know when the meat is just the right shade of mahogany, ready to be aged like fine bourbon or wine.

headline: Pulitzer Prize Party
keywords: ['Pulitzer Prizes', 'Writing and Writers', 'Photography', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The Insider looks at the 100th anniversary party for the Pulitzer Prize, which was attended by prizewinning Times staff writers, editors and photographers.
lead_paragraph: The Pulitzer Prizes were established a century ago, and soon after, The New York Times won its first, for articles about World War I.

headline: Complaint Against Yahoo
abstract: In a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., Gregory Anderson, an editor at Yahoo who was fired in November 2014, alleges that the company’s senior managers routinely manipulated the rating system to fire hundreds of people without just cause to achieve the company’s financial goals.
lead_paragraph: In a lawsuit filed in Federal District Court in San Jose, Calif., Gregory Anderson, an editor at Yahoo who was fired in November 2014, alleges that the company’s senior managers routinely manipulated the rating system to fire hundreds of people without just cause to achieve the company’s financial goals.

headline: Vibrant Culture of China’s Hui Muslims
abstract: Hui Muslims form a 1,200-year-old community in northern China and enjoy greater religious freedom than the Uighurs of Xinjiang.
lead_paragraph: Hui Muslims form a 1,200-year-old community in northern China and enjoy greater religious freedom than the Uighurs of Xinjiang.

headline: David Hart: Fall 2016
abstract: David Hart’s fall 2016 men’s collection.
lead_paragraph: David Hart’s fall 2016 men’s collection.

headline: Assessment of Flint Water Crisis May Hinge on Stupidity vs. Criminality
abstract: Because of state law, the Michigan investigation into the municipal water supply in Flint can range more broadly than the federal inquiry.
lead_paragraph: In the movie “The Big Short,” which is concerned with how the housing bubble led to the financial crisis in 2008, one of the characters tries to explain why no one at the banks was being held accountable. “Tell me the difference between stupid and illegal, and I’ll have my wife’s brother arrested,” he says.

headline: Boko Haram Raid in Nigeria Kills at Least 65
abstract: Militants descended Saturday evening on the small village of Dalori, where they unleashed a torrent of gunfire, set homes ablaze, blew up fleeing residents and abducted children.
lead_paragraph: KADUNA, Nigeria — It was a particularly brutal raid, the kind that had become rare in recent months. Dozens of homes were burned to the ground. Children were abducted and carried off into the bush. People seeking refuge under a familiar tree were blown up by a suicide bomber who had infiltrated their ranks.

headline: How Free Electricity Helped Dig $9 Billion Hole in Puerto Rico
keywords: ['Electric Light and Power', 'Local Government', 'Sales and Excise Taxes']
abstract: With Puerto Rico’s power authority $9 billion in debt and the commonwealth owing $72 billion, free electricity may end.
lead_paragraph: AGUADILLA, P.R. — To understand how Puerto Rico’s power authority has piled up $9 billion in debt, one need only visit this bustling city on the northwest coast.

headline: MoMA PS1 Names Winner of Summer Architecture Competition
abstract: Escobedo Solíz Studio, a partnership based in Mexico City, will transform the museum’s courtyard this summer.
lead_paragraph: Now in its 17th year, the Young Architects Program at MoMA PS1, an international competition to choose a designer to transform the museum’s courtyard in Long Island City, Queens, each summer, has previously seen structures with the ability to purify water; ones made from corn stalks and living roots; ones consisting mostly of bungee cords and others with cardboard columns that could grow herbs and dispense juice.

headline: C.D.C. Ends Chipotle Case With Illness Still a Mystery
abstract: The agency said investigators were unable to specify the food or ingredient responsible for the E. coli outbreaks that have sickened about 60 people in several states.
lead_paragraph: The E. coli outbreaks at Chipotle Mexican Grill restaurants in the United States appear to be over, but investigators have been unable to trace the cause of the sickness, federal authorities said on Monday.

headline: Turning an Out-of-Control Ship Away From France
abstract: Maritime officials said on Monday that a towline was attached to the Modern Express, a distressed cargo ship that was on course to collide with the coast of France.
lead_paragraph: Maritime officials said on Monday that a towline was attached to the Modern Express, a distressed cargo ship that was on course to collide with the coast of France.

headline: Operation Turns Tilting Cargo Ship From Collision Course With French Coast
abstract: The ship was headed from Gabon to a French port with 22 crew members when it began to list badly.
lead_paragraph: A listing, out-of-control cargo ship on a collision course with the French coast has been rotated away from danger, French maritime officials said on Monday.

headline: Killing of Pilot Highlights Tanzania’s Struggle With Poachers
abstract: Officials said they were closing in on the poachers who shot and killed a British helicopter pilot, in a country whose elephant population has declined drastically.
lead_paragraph: ARUSHA, Tanzania — Roger Gower, an experienced British helicopter pilot, was flying low over a wildlife reserve near the Serengeti National Park in Tanzania on Friday, searching for signs of poaching, when he spotted an elephant carcass. He circled back for a closer look.

headline: A Playlist Fit for a Harlem Renaissance Painter
abstract: What to listen to when raising a glass to Archibald Motley, with thanks to our Drink columnist’s cousin, Phil Schaap.
lead_paragraph: In my latest Drink column, I discuss how prominently and evocatively the culture of drink features in the paintings of the Harlem Renaissance artist Archibald Motley. Drinking might get some serious thematic competition from music, except that the two so frequently go together in Motley’s paintings, as in life.

headline: When Justice Is Unequal
keywords: ['Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Poverty', 'Minorities', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: A law professor writes that the criminal justice system “is stacked against you if you are poor.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Spirit of 2008
abstract: Eight years ago, Iowa marked Barack Obama’s first step toward a November victory. Today his historic legacy seems split between the two Democratic front-runners.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 2008, Iowa felt like the center of something big. I lived in Iowa City then, and I voted in the January caucus that turned out to be Barack Obama’s first step to victory. That night and throughout the campaign, the city seemed to buzz with emotion — with hope, yes, but also with joy. There was dancing in the streets of Iowa City the night Mr. Obama won the general election, and I’ve never seen such collective rejoicing before or since.

headline: The Times’s Endorsement of Hillary Clinton
abstract: Readers discuss Mrs. Clinton’s voting record, likability, character and electability.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Eckhaus Latta’s Latest Photo Shoot Breaks the Fourth Wall
abstract: The designers made “Smile” as part of the Hammer Museum’s third Los Angeles–centric biennial exhibition.
lead_paragraph: “Our practice is interesting to curators because it exists in both realms — art and fashion,” speculates Zoe Latta, the designer and half of the bicoastal label Eckhaus Latta. She and her co-designer, Mike Eckhaus, contributed to the latest iteration of MoMA PS1’s “Greater New York” survey and, last year, received a commission from the Hammer Museum ahead of its third Los Angeles–centric biennial exhibition, titled “Made in L.A. 2016: a, the, though, only,” which opens June 12.

headline: New Wearable Sensor Can Collect Data From Sweat
abstract: The device could help people monitor conditions like dehydration and fatigue in real time, one of the inventors said.
lead_paragraph: Wearable monitors measure heart rate, body temperature and other health indicators. For the first time, a flexible, wearable sensor can collect data about multiple chemicals in body sweat.

headline: Hal Prince Withdraws From ‘The Band’s Visit,’ and David Cromer Will Direct
abstract: Schedule conflicts are cited as Mr. Prince withdraws as the director of “The Band’s Visit.”
lead_paragraph: Hal Prince has dropped out of directing the Off Broadway musical “The Band’s Visit,” coming to the Linda Gross Theater later this year. He will be replaced by David Cromer, who directed the acclaimed 2009 Off Broadway production of “Our Town.”

headline: British Researcher Gets Permission to Edit Genes of Human Embryos
abstract: Researchers worldwide have been observing a voluntary moratorium on changes to DNA that could be passed down to subsequent generations.
lead_paragraph: A British researcher has received permission to use a powerful new genome editing technique on human embryos, even though researchers throughout the world are observing a voluntary moratorium on making changes to DNA that could be passed down to subsequent generations.

lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:
