lead_paragraph: Looks from Garciavelez Fall 2016 Collection.

headline: Give the Dead a Break
abstract: A reader writes that “we should airbrush out the foibles and inadequacies that exist in those who have left us,” at least for a while.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Both Parties Lost the White Middle Class
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The populism we’re seeing stems from the collision of whites who flourish in the global economy with those who don’t.
lead_paragraph: LONG after the dust settles in Iowa — and New Hampshire, and even the 2016 campaign itself — one question will remain: Why, after decades of supporting the liberal and conservative establishments, did the white middle-class abandon them? Wherever Donald J. Trump and Bernie Sanders end up, their candidacies represent a major shift in American politics. Since World War II our political culture has been organized around the needs, fears and aspirations of white middle-class voters in ways that also satisfied the interests of the rich and powerful. That’s no longer true.

headline: Review: Juilliard Orchestra Charts a Path to Babbitt at the Focus! Festival
abstract: The Juilliard Orchestra played Schoenberg, Brahms and Stravinsky as it brought a centennial celebration of Milton Babbitt to a close at Alice Tully Hall.
lead_paragraph: A basic command of psychology can be helpful in programming concert music — especially when it comes to the famously thorny Serialist compositions by Milton Babbitt. Perhaps the Juilliard School consulted a trauma expert in assembling Friday’s final concert in its weeklong Focus! celebration of Babbitt’s centennial, which was structured like a course of graduated-exposure therapy.

headline: Scenes From Sundance
abstract: The photographer Gus Powell captures the festival in all its glamour — and drudgery.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Gus Powell captures the festival in all its glamour — and drudgery.

headline: Chilly, and Boozy, Scenes From Sundance
abstract: The photographer Gus Powell shares photos that document this year’s film festival — in both its glamour and its drudgery.
lead_paragraph: The Sundance Film Festival, which officially concluded on Sunday, is full of top-shelf open bars, schmoozing and seven-figure deals in the Park City snow. It can also be a slog, with films starting at 8:30 in the morning and lasting until well past midnight. The New York City-based photographer Gus Powell, whose most recent book, “The Lonely Ones,” pairs quiet, everyday images hidden behind gatefolds with suggestive captions, set out to document his own personal Sundance experience — from his arrival in Park City all the way to his bleary-eyed trip home. See some of his favorite shots in the slideshow here.

headline: On Wikipedia, Donald Trump Reigns and Facts Are Open to Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: On any day, Mr. Trump’s entry usually attracts more views than those of his Republican rivals, and on some days, more than all of them combined.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz’s birthplace became a presidential campaign issue last month when Donald J. Trump added it to his tool belt of attacks.

headline: The Composer Carter Burwell and His Oscar Nod for ‘Carol’
abstract: Mr. Burwell talks about the mystery and risks of love, and how long it takes to compose a score.
lead_paragraph: There was much cheering when the composer Carter Burwell landed his first Oscar nomination this year for his score for Todd Haynes’s midcentury romance, “Carol.” A longtime collaborator with the Coen brothers – he has scored over a dozen of their films, including “Raising Arizona,” “The Big Lebowski” and “No Country For Old Men” – Mr. Burwell had long been thought overdue for academy recognition.

headline: Dada Masilo Turns Tchaikovsky on His Head in ‘Swan Lake’
abstract: Ms. Masilo uses a classic ballet to address homophobia and domestic violence in her native South Africa.
lead_paragraph: The Swan Queen enters the stage to the familiar harp ripples that signal the beginning of the tender Act II pas de deux of “Swan Lake.” Dressed in a white tutu and feathery headdress, she plunges her arms forward, wrists crossed, in a movement familiar to lovers of this ballet. But the familiarity ends there. Prince Siegfried is nowhere to be seen; this Swan Queen is barefoot and bald; and as Tchaikovsky’s plaintive violin melody begins, her movements incorporate balletic sweep and the grounded, hip-shaking, stamping notes of African dance.

headline: Review: Charles Lloyd & the Marvels Defy Easy Categories
abstract: Blues, folk, jazz and more came through in this quintet’s set at the Appel Room at Jazz at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: The jazz saxophonist Charles Lloyd’s new quintet has some effective signal-scrambling in it. That starts with its name, the Marvels, which sounds like a surf-rock instrumental band from around 1963.

headline: Senior U.S. Official Describes 2-Day Visit to Syria
abstract: Brett McGurk, President Obama’s envoy to the American-led coalition against the Islamic State, said he toured the border town of Kobani and met with coalition fighters.
lead_paragraph: ROME — President Obama’s envoy to the American-led coalition fighting the Islamic State said Monday that he had just completed a two-day weekend trip in Syria, the first known visit by a senior United States official since the coalition began airstrikes there in 2014.

headline: Airlines Use Wireless Networks to Replace the Seat-Back Catalog
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Wireless Communications', 'Shopping and Retail', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: The SkyMall catalog may be gone, but in-flight retailing is alive and well, via the wireless networks that give passengers access to social networks or entertainments.
lead_paragraph: Rose Wang, a frequent traveler, is willing to concede that she sort of misses the kitschy SkyMall catalog and its quirky roundup of gadgets, pet accessories and other oddities.

headline: Volkswagen Bank Profits May Be Endangered by Diesel Scandal
keywords: ['Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Diesel Power', 'Credit and Debt', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: Volkswagen Financial Services, the company’s in-house bank, has been an important element in VW’s rise to become the No. 2 carmaker in the world after Toyota.
lead_paragraph: Volkswagen is more than just a scandal-plagued automaker. It is also one of Europe’s largest banks, and its loan portfolio appears vulnerable to the emissions-cheating crisis that has engulfed the company.

headline: Iowa Caucuses: What to Know
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: While a win in Iowa does not always lead to the nomination, it often provides a significant boost to the top finishers and has the potential to reorder the dynamics of the race.
lead_paragraph: Join us for live coverage of the Iowa caucuses.

headline: A God of the Bullring Made Human
abstract: José Tomás has been considered a kind of savior amid the dwindling spectacle that is bullfighting, but on Sunday, in front of more than 45,000 fans in Mexico City, he brought the bull in too close.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — It was not long after the first trumpets on Sunday that José Tomás found himself in familiar territory: inches from the vicious horns of a fighting bull, so close they nearly brushed up against the pink silk of his traje de luces, or suit of lights.

headline: Studying the Heart of El Niño, Where Its Weather Begins
abstract: Over the Pacific, researchers dropped instrument packages in hope of better forecasting the effects of the phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: HONOLULU — A thousand miles south of Hawaii, the air at 45,000 feet above the equatorial Pacific was a shimmering gumbo of thick storm clouds and icy cirrus haze, all cooked up by the overheated waters below.

headline: Yankees’ Greg Bird Will Miss Season After Shoulder Surgery
abstract: Greg Bird, who shined in 157 at-bats last season, will have a procedure to repair a torn labrum in his right shoulder after initially injuring it last spring.
lead_paragraph: In only 157 at-bats in August and September, Greg Bird gave the Yankees something to dream about. His picturesque left-handed swing seemed so well suited to Yankee Stadium that many fans preferred him as the regular first baseman over Mark Teixeira, even though Teixeira had a strong season last year.

headline: Photos of the Day: Peru and Elsewhere
abstract: Peru and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Peru and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: At Museum of Mathematics, Meet 2 Beavers That’ll Never Meet
abstract: The museum’s newest exhibit uses beavers, train tracks and spinning turntables to illustrate a theorem.
lead_paragraph: The latest exhibit at the National Museum of Mathematics in Manhattan was supposed to have been put on display last fall, except it was not quite working.

headline: How to Foster an Elephant for Valentine’s Day
abstract: Animated video by the artist Hugo Guinness sheds light on the innocent families torn apart by poachers — and an organization working to protect them.
lead_paragraph: The British artist and Wes Anderson collaborator Hugo Guinness has a soft spot for animals. He has painted pooches, cats — and at least two bunnies (his daughter’s); designed a rhinoceros doodle for a Coach wallet in 2012; and embarked on a Google safari to sketch exotic toads, serpents and bears, which were compiled into a book released last year ($25, Dashwood Books). He was even the voice for the farmer Nathan Bunce in “Fantastic Mr. Fox.” And so it may come as no surprise that Guinness supports organizations that rescue innocent animals — like the David Sheldrick Wildlife Trust (DSWT), protector and rehabilitator of orphaned elephants and rhinos in Africa. With J.Crew, he illustrated a sold-out sweatshirt, whose entire proceeds were donated to DSWT. He also created line drawings for the above animated video in support of DSWT’s Orphans’ Project, through which anyone may foster an infant for just $50 per year — a very nice Valentine’s Day present, if you ask us.

headline: Alphabet, Google’s Parent Company, Grows Briskly to Close In on Apple
abstract: Revenue increased 24 percent in the most recent quarter, positioning the outfit formerly known as Google to become the world’s most valuable company.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street got its first glimpse of the financial details of a new conglomerate called Alphabet on Monday. Investors liked what they saw so much that the outfit formerly known as Google is poised to become the world’s most valuable company.

headline: Rihanna’s ‘Anti’ Sells Fewer Than 1,000 Copies in U.S., but Some Call It a Hit
abstract: The Tidal streaming service says the album is a hit, but it opened relatively low on the Billboard chart, which disqualifies album copies that are part of gratis promotions.
lead_paragraph: Just how popular is the new Rihanna album, “Anti”?

headline: CBS and NBC Will Split a Bigger Deal for Thursday N.F.L. Games
abstract: After two one-year deals with CBS for “Thursday Night Football” games, the N.F.L. announced a two-year deal with CBS and NBC worth an estimated $450 million annually.
lead_paragraph: After two one-year deals with CBS to televise eight “Thursday Night Football” games, the N.F.L. announced a two-year deal Monday with CBS and NBC worth an estimated $450 million annually.

headline: Obama Cleared Way for Today’s Outsider Candidates
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Celebrities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The ultimate anti-establishment White House candidate may be the one living there now, as the president’s success has emboldened candidates from both parties to try to follow his example.
lead_paragraph: Since outsider, anti-establishment White House candidates are all the rage, consider this one: scant executive experience, brief time in federal office, a bold if not arrogant willingness to challenge much more seasoned politicians, an aspirational platform with little track record to back it up, and a minority to boot.

headline: How One New Brand Is Reimagining the Men’s Suit
abstract: The three-year-old men’s wear label Abasi Rosborough made additions and subtractions to produce something that was appropriate for the workplace, but moved like activewear.
lead_paragraph: “When you’re starting a brand, you have to be a product of your own experiences,” says the designer Greg Rosborough. “You can’t fake being something else.” Along with his co-founder, Abdul Abasi, Rosborough has created Abasi Rosborough — a three-year-old men’s wear brand that is, in many ways, a product of both of their pasts.

headline: Regulators Aren’t Done With ‘Dark Pool’ Investigations
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Settlements with Barclays and Credit Suisse for misrepresenting private stock trading sites are not likely to be the last cases involving abuses in electronic trading.
lead_paragraph: Settlements by Barclays and Credit Suisse for misrepresenting their private stock trading sites to customers are unlikely to be the last as regulators continue to pursue abuses in electronic trading.

headline: Human Error Possible in Deadly ’15 Amtrak Crash, Documents Suggest
abstract: Reports released by the National Transportation Safety Board found no problems with the train, tracks or signals. Full findings are due in a few months.
lead_paragraph: Federal officials investigating an Amtrak derailment in Philadelphia last year left open the possibility on Monday that human error led to the crash as they released documents showing that no problems were found with the train or with the tracks and signals at the site of the accident.

headline: Creating a Family Website
abstract: You don’t have to be a full-fledged webmaster to share photos, videos and news with family and friends in your own private corner of the Internet.
lead_paragraph: Q. If I wanted to set up my own website where I can upload pictures and videos for my family and friends to see, where would I start? Obviously, I am not talking about a YouTube account, but something like a site with my own name. Is there an easy way to do this?

headline: Fashion and Design’s New Space-Age Sheen
abstract: Leather and snakeskin accessories and ultra-modern objects for the home are illuminated in lustrous shades of metallic.
lead_paragraph: Leather and snakeskin accessories and ultra-modern objects for the home are illuminated in lustrous shades of metallic.

headline: Feb. 1, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Peru, Afghanistan, Egypt and Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Peru, Afghanistan, Egypt and Lebanon.

headline: Bank Tellers, With Access to Accounts, Pose a Rising Security Risk
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Identity Theft']
abstract: Though cybertheft gets most of the publicity, retail-branch employees are tapping into customers’ personal information and their cash.
lead_paragraph: Bank robbers used to burst into banks brandishing guns and bearing notes demanding cash to the teller behind the window. Today, the thieves may be on the other side of the counter.

headline: First Freely Elected Parliament After Decades of Military Rule Opens in Myanmar
abstract: More than 100 of the new lawmakers are, like the democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, former political prisoners.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s first freely elected Parliament after half a century of military rule opened on Monday, a symbolic but critical milestone in the country’s fragile transition to democracy, and a moment long awaited by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the leader of the nation’s democracy movement.

headline: Review: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson,’ Seen This Time in Double Vision
abstract: This 10-part series, which has its debut on FX on Tuesday, focuses on the legal process and how racial attitudes affected it.
lead_paragraph: On June 12, 1994, Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald L. Goldman were brutally murdered outside Ms. Simpson’s Los Angeles home. In the trial that followed, argues “The People v. O. J. Simpson: American Crime Story,” our current social conflicts and media culture were born.

headline: Australia to Begin Monitoring for Zika Virus
abstract: Health officials in the northern part of Queensland and Papua New Guinea, to Australia’s north, have begun taking measures to guard against the virus.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Health officials in tropical far-north Queensland and Papua New Guinea, to Australia’s north, have begun monitoring for the mosquito-borne Zika virus, which was declared an international public health emergency on Monday by the World Health Organization.

headline: Review: Laura Secor’s ‘Children of Paradise: The Struggle for the Soul of Iran’
abstract: Ms. Secor’s book offers profiles of journalists, dissidents and activists who have stood up for their beliefs in the years since the Islamic Revolution in 1979.
lead_paragraph: Given Iran’s recent nuclear deal with the West, the lifting of economic sanctions and political maneuvering before this month’s parliamentary elections (in which hard-liners have tried to disqualify large numbers of moderates and reformists from running), Laura Secor’s new book about Iran since its 1979 Islamic Revolution could not be more timely.

headline: Review: ‘O Earth,’ a Riff on ‘Our Town’
abstract: Casey Llewellyn’s play, presented by the Foundry Theater, gives audiences a Grover’s Corners concerned with social changes.
lead_paragraph: The ghost light is on, planted at center stage, but if its job is to keep spirits away, it isn’t working. In “O, Earth,” Casey Llewellyn’s whimsical, politically impassioned riff on Thornton Wilder’s “Our Town,” phantasms are present, and at least one of them is angry.

headline: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Iowa, Zika, Black History Month
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Cosby Case Highlights a Rivalry Between Two Lawyers
abstract: A coming court hearing surrounding sexual assault charges against Bill Cosby is likely to pit a former district attorney in Montgomery County, Pa., against the county’s present district attorney.
lead_paragraph: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — When Bill Cosby arrives at the historic courthouse here on Tuesday to fight charges that he sexually assaulted a young woman 12 years ago, the key players at a pre-trial hearing may well be two men whose own rivalry has become part of the unfolding drama in Mr. Cosby’s criminal case.

headline: When Doctors Took ‘Family Planning’ Into Their Own Hands
abstract: A new documentary, “No Más Bebés,” examines a California hospital’s sterilizations of Mexican-American women in the early 1970s — and the women who filed suit in response.
lead_paragraph: Dolores Madrigal remembered being told that her sterilization could be reversed. Jovita Rivera and Georgina Hernández said they were bullied by doctors and nurses who declared their children burdens on California taxpayers. Melvina Hernandez did not find out that her tubes had been cut until four years after her son was born.

headline: ‘King Charles III’ Commands Its Strongest Broadway Week
abstract: The new play by Mike Bartlett ends its Broadway run on a financial high.
lead_paragraph: “King Charles III,” the critically acclaimed future history play imagining the British monarchy after Queen Elizabeth II, enjoyed its strongest week on Broadway before ending its run on Sunday.

headline: 9 Things to Do in the Bay Area During Super Bowl Week
abstract: Whether you are traveling to the Bay Area for Super Bowl activities or already live there, we have a few things to keep in mind.
lead_paragraph: We recently wrote about some of the special events happening in the San Francisco Bay Area for Super Bowl 50, with tips from The Times’s Benjamin Hoffman, who will be covering his seventh Super Bowl this week and who knows the area better than most.

headline: Canvassing for Bernie Sanders in Iowa
abstract: With just hours to go before the caucus doors closed on Monday, the National Nurses Union was still out combing the Des Moines streets for potential supporters for Senator Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: With just hours to go before the caucus doors closed on Monday, the National Nurses Union was still out combing the Des Moines streets for potential supporters for Senator Bernie Sanders.

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Hillary Clinton Leads in Fund-Raising From Lobbyists
abstract: Registered lobbyists raised more money for Hillary Clinton than for any other presidential candidate of either party during the three months ending in December, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission.
lead_paragraph: Registered lobbyists raised more money for the Democrat Hillary Clinton than for any other presidential candidate of either party during the three months ending in December, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission.

headline: Both Sides in Wildlife Refuge Protest Face Off in Oregon
abstract: Residents angry about the takeover of a federal wildlife refuge confronted antigovernment supporters in a nonviolent but emotional demonstration in Burns, Ore.
lead_paragraph: BURNS, Ore. — Local residents furious about the  armed occupation of a federal wildlife refuge   in eastern Oregon  faced off in force on Monday against antigovernment protesters who support the occupation, with both sides gathering outside the Harney County Courthouse here in a nonviolent but dramatic confrontation.

headline: Reverberations From a Rise in Mexico’s Murder Rate
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Longevity', 'Men and Boys']
abstract: Rising homicide rates are lowering a country’s average life expectancy.
lead_paragraph: Escalating homicide rates in Mexico are affecting the country’s average life expectancy.

headline: CWST: Fall 2016
abstract: The latest designs from Derek Buse and Joe Sadler.
lead_paragraph: The latest designs from Derek Buse and Joe Sadler.

headline: A.I.G. Plans to Streamline, but Not Divide, Itself
abstract: The activist shareholder Carl Icahn, who wants the company to break into three, says he’ll propose possible board members by the end of next week.
lead_paragraph: American International Group is sticking with a strategic plan that aims to streamline the company but falls far short of calls from activist shareholders like Carl C. Icahn to break into three.

headline: Economists Sharply Split Over Trade Deal Effects
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Economy']
abstract: It may be a political football for presidential candidates, but the liveliest debate recently about the Trans-Pacific Partnership is among blue-ribbon economists.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lawmakers and presidential candidates are having their say about the 12-nation Pacific Rim trade accord that is President Obama’s top economic priority in his final year in office. But lately the liveliest debate over the deal is among blue-ribbon economists.

headline: Fight Between 2 California Escapees Proved to Be Turning Point
abstract: Fugitives who had broken out of an Orange County jail argued over whether to kill a cabdriver they had kidnapped.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After five days on the run, two of the three inmates who had broken out of an Orange County jail came to blows as they argued over whether to kill a taxi driver they had kidnapped in Southern California and taken with them to San Jose.

headline: Uber Drivers in New York City Protest Fare Cuts
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Hundreds of Uber drivers gathered at the New York headquarters of the ride-sharing service to oppose fare cuts imposed last month, a move the company said lifts demand during slow winter months.
lead_paragraph: Uber drivers are commonly referred to as workers in the “on-demand” economy.

headline: Lucio Castro: Fall 2016
abstract: Lucio Castro’s fall show.
lead_paragraph: Lucio Castro’s fall show.

headline: At Berkeley, a New Digital Privacy Protest
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Privacy', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'ACADEMIC FREEDOM', 'Cyberwarfare and Defense']
abstract: A group of 11 professors at U.C. Berkeley have objected to a quietly installed cybersecurity program set up by the University of California system in response to a huge data breach last summer.
lead_paragraph: After hackers breached the computer network  of the U.C.L.A. medical center last summer, Janet Napolitano, president of the University of California, and her office moved to shore up security across the university system’s 10 campuses.

headline: $1 Billion Planned for Cancer ‘Moonshot’
abstract: Researchers said the Obama administration’s spending proposal was a comparatively small sum in a field in which major advances often take many billions to achieve.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration announced on Monday that it hoped to spend $1 billion to fund a cancer “moonshot” in search of a cure. But in the costly world of biological research, such a sum may be better described as a cancer slingshot, researchers said.

headline: Brooklyn Suicide Is Third Hanging in City Holding Cells Since May
keywords: ['Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Drunken and Reckless Driving', 'Police']
abstract: An autopsy found that Serge Duthely of Canarsie, who had been arrested on Sunday on a drunken-driving charge, had hanged himself with his T-shirt.
lead_paragraph: The death of a man in a Brooklyn police station house on Sunday was the third time since May that someone had hanged himself in a New York Police Department holding cell, the authorities said.

headline: Menacing Video Posted by Chechen Leader Alarms Critics of Putin in Russia
abstract: The video, which appeared to show a Russian opposition figure in the cross hairs of a sniper’s rifle, was removed from Instagram because it violated guidelines against threats or harassment, a spokeswoman said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Members of Russia’s political opposition reacted with fear and outrage on Monday after one of President Vladimir V. Putin’s most loyal and aggressive allies posted a menacing video online that appeared to show a Kremlin critic in the cross hairs of a sniper’s rifle.

headline: Scenes From Caucus Day
abstract: Before the voting began in Iowa, candidates and volunteers made their last-minute pitches.
lead_paragraph: Before the voting began in Iowa, candidates and volunteers made their last-minute pitches.

headline: Myron Beldock, Civil Rights Lawyer Who Fought for Lost Causes, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Beldock was known for defending and winning freedom for people who had been convicted and imprisoned, including the boxer Rubin “Hurricane” Carter and a defendant in the Central Park Jogger case.
lead_paragraph: Myron Beldock, a lawyer who championed seemingly lost criminal causes but won freedom for various wrongly convicted men, including the former boxer Rubin (Hurricane) Carter after he had served 19 years in prison for three murders in New Jersey, died on Monday at a hospice in Manhattan. He was 86.

headline: Camp Santanoni in the Winter
abstract: The compound in the Adirondacks, which offers peace, solitude and natural beauty, hosts a series of winter open houses every year.
lead_paragraph: The compound in the Adirondacks, which offers peace, solitude and natural beauty, hosts a series of winter open houses every year.

headline: In the Adirondacks, a Winter Trek Into the Gilded Age
abstract: Camp Santanoni, a sprawling compound, opens its buildings to visitors in the winter for only a few weekends, so long as they make the five-mile trip from the main road, often through snow.
lead_paragraph: NEWCOMB, N.Y. — For those willing to make a five-mile trek on snowshoes or cross-country skis, a historic winter wonderland can be found deep in the Adirondack woods.

headline: Some Heresy on Wall Street: Look Past the Quarter
keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Corporations', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Laurence D. Fink of BlackRock urged 500 chief executives in a letter to stop providing quarterly earnings estimates.
lead_paragraph: Most money managers clamor for companies to provide detailed guidance on their next quarter, down to the penny — but not the world’s largest investor.

headline: Closing Arguments Given in Key Voter Rights Trial
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Identification Devices', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)']
abstract: A North Carolina case has implications for what voting-related laws federal courts might allow states to pursue and enforce.
lead_paragraph: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C. — In the final session of a trial that could yield a crucial decision about a policy that has been disputed for years, a federal judge heard closing arguments on Monday about North Carolina’s voter identification law.

headline: Cory Schneider, Brodeur’s Successor, Is Helping the Devils Rebuild
abstract: Schneider, the team’s No. 1 goalie for a season and a half, has made it his mission to get the Devils, who have missed the playoffs in four of the past five years, to the postseason.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Cory and Jill Schneider have a 3-month-old son, Wyatt, and the family just moved into a house in Short Hills, N.J., with a backyard that Cory says is big enough for their 11-year-old sheepdog, Bella.

headline: India: 13 Swimmers Drown in Riptide
abstract: The bodies of 10 women and three men were recovered, and one student was still missing.
lead_paragraph: At least 13 college students drowned in the Arabian Sea on Monday after being swept away by a receding tide. A group of more than 100 students had visited a beach in the western state of Maharashtra and went for a swim after lunch, said J. P. Yadav, a Coast Guard official. The bodies of 10 women and three men were recovered, and six women were rescued, Mr. Yadav said. One student was still missing. Drownings took place in the same area in 2014 and last year, which prompted the authorities to post warnings.

headline: Iran: Khomeini’s Grandson Receives an Endorsement After Disqualification
abstract: Hassan Khomeini said he would appeal his disqualification to run for a seat on the council, which is empowered to choose the next supreme leader.
lead_paragraph: A grandson of Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, a reform-minded cleric who was disqualified last week from running for election to an important clerical council in Iran, received a significant endorsement on Monday from an influential former president, a possible indication that his candidacy might be revived. The grandson, Hassan Khomeini, 43, has said he would appeal his disqualification to run for a seat on the council, known as the Assembly of Experts, which is empowered to choose the next supreme leader. Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani, the former president and political veteran who was close to Mr. Khomeini’s grandfather, the founder of the Islamic Republic, was quoted in state media as saying that the vetters of candidates had no right to disqualify Mr. Khomeini.

headline: Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz Supporters Sought New Donors at Koch Conference
abstract: Top supporters of Senator Marco Rubio and Senator Ted Cruz held private meetings to sway potential new recruits at the annual winter conference hosted by Charles and David Koch, according to a participant.
lead_paragraph: Top supporters of Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas held private meetings to sway potential new recruits at the annual winter conference hosted by Charles and David Koch this weekend, according to a participant.

headline: U.S. Fortifying Europe’s East to Deter Putin
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama plans to increase the deployment of heavy weapons and other equipment to NATO countries in Central and Eastern Europe.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama plans to substantially increase the deployment of heavy weapons, armored vehicles and other equipment to NATO countries in Central and Eastern Europe, a move that administration officials said was aimed at deterring Russia from further aggression in the region.

headline: Iowa Entrance Polls
abstract: Surveys of Democratic voters entering the caucuses in locations throughout Iowa on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: Surveys of Democratic voters entering the caucuses in locations throughout Iowa on Monday evening.

headline: Iowa Entrance Polls
abstract: Surveys of Republican voters entering the caucuses in locations throughout Iowa on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: Surveys of Republican voters entering the caucuses in locations throughout Iowa on Monday evening.

headline: Concerns Over Social Media Link to Virginia Girl’s Killing
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Bullies']
abstract: The arrest of two Virginia Tech students in the abduction and murder of a 13-year-old girl who posted on a Facebook group called Teen Dating and Flirting has set off fresh concerns about the dangers of young people who seek liaisons on social media.
lead_paragraph: BLACKSBURG, Va. — The arrest of two Virginia Tech students in the abduction and murder of a 13-year-old girl who posted on a Facebook group called Teen Dating and Flirting — and showed a neighbor girl texts she said she had exchanged with an 18-year-old man — has set off new concerns about the dangers to young people who seek liaisons on social media.

headline: San Francisco Will Have U.S. Review Police Tactics
abstract: The mayor requested the review after police officers fatally shot an African-American man on a city street in December, sparking protests.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department announced Monday that it will conduct a sweeping review of the San Francisco Police Department, looking at everything from episodes involving the use of force to officer training and stops of civilians.

headline: Denise Duval, French Soprano and Poulenc Interpreter, Dies at 94
abstract: Ms. Duval, a foremost interpreter of Francis Poulenc’s works, was also known for her performances of compositions by other French masters.
lead_paragraph: Denise Duval, a French soprano best known as the cherished muse of her countryman Francis Poulenc, died on Jan. 25 in Bex, Switzerland. She was 94.

headline: Adjusting Medication May Prolong Levine’s Tenure at the Met
abstract: A visit to the conductor’s neurologist yielded a potential solution and an 11th-hour reprieve.
lead_paragraph: The stage was being set to announce the retirement of James Levine, the music director of the Metropolitan Opera since 1976, after his longstanding health woes seemed to worsen this season to the point that singers and musicians were having difficulty following his conducting.

headline: Organization Behind Grammys to Create Lobbying Group
abstract: The focus of the Grammy Fund will be lobbying Congress for fair compensation for creators of music.
lead_paragraph: For years, the music industry’s lobbying efforts have been hampered by factionalism, as different sides of the business competed to influence lawmakers. Now, with copyright and royalties issues taking center stage in the music world, the organization behind the Grammy Awards wants to unite the industry’s voice in Washington.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10, Episode 3: Mulder Rediscovers His Monster Mojo
abstract: After two sober episodes, “The X-Files” took a welcome comedic turn this week.
lead_paragraph: “Yeah, this is how I like my Mulder!” Scully, you took the words right out of my mouth.

headline: Making Choices in Iowa
abstract: Following a year of venting and anger, voters can only hope that the presidential campaign will now move toward issues and ideas.
lead_paragraph: After a long year of too much polling, posturing and propaganda, American voters are now at last making choices. The run-up to the Iowa caucuses, which took place on Monday night, shows it’s time to move beyond the emotional venting that has been broadly common to both parties, but could not have been more different in the particulars.

headline: After Retrial, Brooklyn Teenager Is Convicted in Fatal Shooting on Bus
abstract: A jury found Kahton Anderson, 15, guilty of second-degree murder in the death of Angel Rojas, who was struck by a bullet in 2014 that was intended for members of a rival gang.
lead_paragraph: A Brooklyn teenager who opened fire on a crowded New York City bus during a gang turf war two years ago, killing a 39-year-old immigrant who was an unintended target, was convicted of second-degree murder on Monday.

headline: Iowa’s Republican Caucus Results, Precinct by Precinct
abstract: Detailed results in the race for president.
lead_paragraph: Detailed results in the race for president.

headline: Iowa’s Democratic Caucus Results, Precinct by Precinct
abstract: Detailed results in the race for president.
lead_paragraph: Detailed results in the race for president.

headline: New Hampshire Offers Hope to Candidates Who Lagged in Iowa
abstract: Two Republican candidates, Chris Christie and John Kasich, could face virtual elimination if they fail to stand out in the New Hampshire primary next week.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Hours before the end of the Iowa caucuses on Monday night, three Republican candidates had already assembled in New Hampshire to rally their supporters. Anticipating disappointment in Iowa, the group — made up of current and former governors — has chosen to make a stand here instead.

headline: Howard Koslow Dies at 91; Artist Designed Stamps for 40 Years
abstract: Mr. Koslow was a painter and illustrator who for more than four decades designed many of the most recognizable stamps issued by the United States Postal Service.
lead_paragraph: Howard Koslow, a painter and illustrator who for more than four decades designed many of the most recognizable stamps issued by the United States Postal Service, including a 1994 series depicting famous blues and jazz musicians and 30 stamps depicting coastal lighthouses, died on Jan. 25 at his home in Toms River, N.J. He was 91.

headline: Supersonic Speed
abstract: Peter Collins expands our view of today’s crossword.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Look! Up in the SKY! It’s a FLOCK OF BIRDS! It’s a PLANE! It’s Paul MOLITOR, whom I did not know before today’s puzzle by Peter A. Collins. But apparently, Mr. MOLITOR can fly, because he’s up there above the HORIZON.

headline: Delayed New York City Report on Shelter Safety Violations Is Released
abstract: The report, which Mayor Bill de Blasio promised to release last May, documents longstanding problems in housing units rented as shelter space from private landlords.
lead_paragraph: Seeking to show progress in New York’s efforts to improve homeless shelters, Mayor Bill de Blasio released a new — and overdue — report on Monday that catalogs the number of safety violations at more than 600 sites used to house homeless people.

headline: Son of Ex-Aide to de Blasio’s Wife Is Arrested in Fatal Stabbing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Robberies and Thefts']
abstract: New Jersey officials said Khari Noerdlinger, the son of Rachel Noerdlinger, a former chief of staff to Chirlane McCray, stabbed a teenager who was taking part in an armed robbery.
lead_paragraph: The son of a former top aide to Mayor Bill de Blasio’s wife was arrested on Monday on charges that he fatally stabbed a 16-year-old suspect in an armed robbery attempt in New Jersey, according to law enforcement authorities.

headline: In Knoedler Art Fraud Trial, Expert Testimony on Fakes Weighs Heavily
abstract: Two art experts, including Mark Rothko’s son, Christopher, testified that the Knoedler gallery’s director misrepresented their opinions on works sold falsely as by artists like Rothko.
lead_paragraph: At its most basic, the Knoedler & Company fraud trial revolves around whether a once celebrated art gallery knowingly sold a forged Mark Rothko painting.

headline: Murray Louis, Choreographer With a Comic Flair, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Louis was notable for his quick directional shifts, tiny darting gestures and unexpected contrasts between rigidity and stillness.
lead_paragraph: Murray Louis, the son of a Brooklyn baker who won acclaim as a brilliantly nimble dancer and a quirky and often surprising choreographer, died on Monday at his home in New York City. He was 89.

headline: Scenes From Caucus Night
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The Republicans had an early victor in Iowa, while the Democrats tensely awaited results.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans had an early victor in Iowa, while the Democrats tensely awaited results.

headline: Ted Cruz Wins Republican Caucuses in Iowa
abstract: The victory by Senator Ted Cruz, powered by a surge of support from evangelical Christians, threw into question the depth of support for Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, powered by a surge of support from evangelical Christians, dealt a humbling loss to Donald J. Trump in the Iowa caucuses on Monday, throwing into question the depth of support for Mr. Trump’s unconventional candidacy.

headline: How to Understand Donald Trump’s Defeat in Iowa
abstract: A loss raises the possibility that his strength is at least partly an illusion.
lead_paragraph: For months, mainstream Republicans have hoped that Donald Trump’s support was a mirage — a combination of high name recognition, unsustainable news media coverage and support from irregular voters who might not show up in a primary.

headline: G.O.P. Caucus: ‘In About 20 Minutes This Place Is Going to Get Stupid’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: At a caucus site in Pella, Iowa, it was clear that the early arrivals included many first-time caucusgoers, with no unanimity about who they were supporting.
lead_paragraph: PELLA, Iowa — When Dan Spotten opened the doors to Pella High School shortly after 5 p.m. to allow voters from six Republican precincts to cast ballots in the Iowa caucuses, he was committed to running a tight ship.

headline: Martin O’Malley to Drop Out After Finish in Iowa Vote
abstract: Martin O’Malley, a former mayor of Baltimore and governor of Maryland, said Monday night that he would end his campaign for the Democratic nomination in the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Martin O’Malley, the former Democratic governor of Maryland, and Mike Huckabee, the former Republican governor of Arkansas, ended their presidential campaigns Monday night after disappointing finishes in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: So This Is the Humble Trump?
abstract: On Monday afternoon, Mr. Trump was proclaiming his impending victory in Iowa. That night, he was acting like he never expected to win.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, to borrow his own word, is unbelievable.

headline: In This School Cafeteria Caucus, the Lunch Lady Still Rules
abstract: Only a handful of Democrats showed up to caucus in Indianola Precinct 7 four years ago, as President Obama sought re-election. This year, however, the race was far more competitive.
lead_paragraph: INDIANOLA, Iowa — The brightly lit high school cafeteria began to fill up shortly before 6 p.m., and the menu board advertising hot dogs and turkey fritters was soon hidden by a campaign sign for Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. (An anti-bullying poster remained.)

headline: Temporary Agreement Reached in Custody Battle Over Picasso Bust
abstract: The two parties disputing the sculpture’s ownership have agreed that the statue will go to the Gagosian Gallery until the conflict is adjudicated.
lead_paragraph: The mystery of what will happen to Picasso’s 1931 plaster bust of his mistress and muse Marie-Thérèse Walter after the Museum of Modern Art’s blockbuster show closes on Sunday has been temporarily resolved.

headline: Polls Show Preferences and Priorities in Iowa
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: After months of campaigning, fierce debates and a blizzard of television commercials, polls showed how voters split among the presidential hopefuls when it came time to make a decision.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Senator Ted Cruz won support among evangelicals, very conservative voters and those who were seeking a candidate who shares their values. Donald J. Trump did well among first-time caucusgoers and those who want the next president to be from outside the political establishment. Senator Marco Rubio found support among voters who said the economy was the most important issue and those who thought it was most important to have a candidate who could win in November.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | novelty
abstract: This word has appeared in 291 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: novelty • \ˈnä-vəl-te\ • noun

headline: Little Separates Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton in Tight Race in Iowa
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The close vote means that Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders are likely to split Iowa’s share of delegates to the Democratic convention.
lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont were locked in an intensely tight race in the Iowa caucuses on Tuesday as Mrs. Clinton’s strong support among women and older voters was matched by the passionate liberal foot soldiers whom Mr. Sanders has been calling to political revolution.

headline: You Didn’t Win Iowa. Now What?
abstract: Advice for the election season’s first batch of also-rans.
lead_paragraph: It doesn’t feel good to be a loser. And on Monday night, in one way or another, a lot more candidates lost than won. For some of the candidates, losing in Iowa doesn’t matter as much; they’re hoping to find success somewhere down the twisting, breakneck ice luge that is the presidential primary season.

abstract: Efforts to move the military’s leave policies closer to those of the private sector could have a positive effect on civilian employees, too.

(The Navy last year changed its policy to give women 18 weeks of paid leave.) In addition to the change announced by Mr. Carter, which does not require legislative approval, the Pentagon intends to ask Congress to increase paid paternity leave to 14 days from 10 days.

headline: ‘The Black Presidency: Barack Obama and the Politics of Race in America,’ by Michael Eric Dyson
abstract: The president has not been able to pursue an agenda of racial justice.
lead_paragraph: What happens when the nation’s foremost voice on the race question is also its most confined and restrained? Michael Eric Dyson raises this question about President Obama in his latest book, “The Black Presidency: Barack Obama and the Politics of Race in America.” The book inspires one to raise similar questions about Dyson himself. For, while hardly restrained, Dyson appears noticeably boxed in by the limitations placed on celebrity race commentators in the Age of Obama.

headline: ‘The Vegetarian,’ by Han Kang
abstract: A South Korean woman’s sudden vegetarianism begins a parable both serene and violent.
lead_paragraph: Last August, Anne Rice posted a call to arms — on Facebook, of course — warning that political correctness was going to bring on literary end times: banned books, destroyed authors, “a new era of censorship.” “We must stand up for fiction as a place where transgressive behavior and ideas can be explored,” she proclaimed. “I think we have to be willing to stand up for the despised.” I, a fan of transgressive literature, could not pinpoint why I found her post to be so much more vexing than the usual battle cries of P.C.-paranoiacs. I finally had my answer after reading Han Kang’s novel “The Vegetarian”: What if “the despised” can stand up on their own?

headline: Fighting ‘Erasure’
abstract: Calling out the expunging of minorities’ struggles and achievements from the record is an attempt to restore what has been lost.
lead_paragraph: Efforts to force collective amnesia are as old as conquest. The Roman decree damnatio memoriae — ‘‘condemnation of memory’’ — punished individuals by destroying every trace of them from the city, down to chiseling faces off statues. It was considered a fate worse than execution. But there are subtler, everyday forms of banishing people from public life.

headline: How Chris Jackson Is Building a Black Literary Movement
abstract: One of the publishing industry’s only black editors is transmitting ideas from writers on the margins to the mainstream readers who need to hear them.
lead_paragraph: On an unnervingly balmy November day, the scene at Medgar Evers College in Brooklyn was restless and expectant. Ta-Nehisi Coates was scheduled to appear on campus for a discussion about his best-selling book, ‘‘Between the World and Me.’’ Evers has a student body that is over 80 percent black, and interest in the event was palpable. Outside, on Bedford Avenue, a diasporic survey of music — reggae, soca, R.&B., trap — flew out the windows of rusted sedans as a slow parade of students filed into the building: a group of young men in near-identical oxfords and knit ties; a woman in a knee-length camouflage hoodie, black tights and Timberland boots; kids wearing mohawks, flattops, cornrows and uncountable Afros.

headline: Bohemia’s Secret Spot for Cross-Country Skiing
abstract: The Jizera Mountains of Central Europe, unknown to many, offer fine Nordic trails.
lead_paragraph: The trail descended gently through a dense spruce forest, blanketed by snow from an overnight storm. It was bitterly cold, but the sky had cleared and the sun reflected dazzlingly off the frosted terrain. I rounded a corner on my cross-country skis and took in an impressive sight that emerged out of the rustic landscape like a vision from the Brothers Grimm: a meadow dominated by a castlelike dark-wood villa, with gabled windows, a central cupola and huge icicles dangling from the roof.

headline: 1916: Prince Yussuf Commits Suicide
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Prince Yussuf Izzettin is found dead in 1916.
lead_paragraph: CONSTANTINOPLE — Prince Yussuf was found dead by his servants at 7.30 a.m. in the Zingirli-Koyon Palaco. The veins of his left arm had been cut. The report issued after the autopsy states that Prince Yussuf committed suicide, and is signed by the most eminent physicians of Constantinople. Prince Yussuf Izzettin was thought to be neurasthenic, says the ‘‘Figaro,’’ but, though the message alleges suicide, his death gives some ground for speculation. It is noteworthy that Prince Yussuf has recently been spoken of as the leader of a movement opposed to German domination in Turkey. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 3, 1916
