headline: My Secret Policeman
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: In Egypt, if a National Security officer calls to ask you ‘to tea,’ it’s an invitation you can’t refuse.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — “Miss Mona, welcome home. The airport told us you’ve just returned from Vienna.”

headline: From Zegna to Saint Laurent, Fashion’s Rumor Mill Goes Into Overdrive
abstract: Whispers about the futures of a host of top designers are enough to make the head spin and they do a disservice to the industry.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another fevered round of fashion speculation. Rumors are popping up with the blinding frequency of paillettes on an Elie Saab dress. I’ve never seen it this way. It’s corrosive. So let’s take them out of the shadows where they breed.

headline: Corporate Bribery Cases and Fines Fell in 2015, Report Shows
keywords: ['Foreign Corrupt Practices Act (1977)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Corporations']
abstract: The decline was attributed to fewer cases of self-reporting, a smaller number of big settlements and a focus on more complicated cases.
lead_paragraph: The number of Foreign Corrupt Practices Act enforcement actions and financial penalties declined sharply last year, but the federal government has signaled that it plans to bolster its efforts in pursuing corporate bribery cases, according to a new report by the law firm Jones Day.

headline: From ‘Bold’ to ‘Bastard,’ Readers Debate Role of Working Women in India
abstract: Some say a recent Times article shows that the country has made great progress on women’s rights. Others say change can not happen without more models of courage.
lead_paragraph: India needs more “angry, bold, ‘real bastard’ women,” wrote a reader in California. Another argued that working women face more of a “glass ceiling” in the United States than in India.

headline: 1941: Pact Signed to Clear ‘Badlands’
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Shanghai agrees to clean up the city’s western “badlands” in 1941.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Because of the economic and political factors involved, considerable speculation has been aroused concerning the eventual effectiveness of an agreement signed yesterday [Feb. 1] by the heads of the Shanghai Municipal Council and the Chinese government of the city for the ostensible purpose of cleaning up the vice and lawlessness of the city’s western ‘‘badlands.’’ The agreement provides for creation of a special police force and provides that as soon as the special police unit undertakes its duties the gambling dens, opium places and similar enterprises shall be forbidden. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 3, 1941

headline: John Sununu Previews Attacks Donald Trump Will Face in New Hampshire
abstract: John H. Sununu, the former governor of New Hampshire who has been voicing increasing concern about what a Donald J. Trump victory in his state would mean for his party, twisted the knife after the billionaire’s second-place finish in the Iowa caucuses.
lead_paragraph: John H. Sununu, the former governor of New Hampshire who has been voicing increasing concern about what a Donald J. Trump victory in his state would mean for his party, twisted the knife after the billionaire’s second-place finish in the Iowa caucuses on Tuesday morning — and offered a preview of the attacks he is about to face.

headline: U.S. and Europe in ‘Safe Harbor’ Data Deal, but Legal Fight May Await
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Privacy', 'Social Media', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The agreement would let businesses like Google and Facebook continue to move personal data across the Atlantic, but European privacy officials may balk.
lead_paragraph: European officials on Tuesday agreed to a deal with the United States that would let Google, Amazon and thousands of other businesses continue moving people’s digital data, including social media posts and financial information, back and forth across the Atlantic.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Dutiful Slog
abstract: Her campaign declared victory in Iowa, but she has no reason to celebrate.
lead_paragraph: Late Monday, as the unfinished vote count suggested the slimmest of victories for Hillary Clinton, she stepped to a microphone, flashed an Oscar-worthy smile of triumph and told supporters that she was “breathing a big sigh of relief.”

headline: James Corden to Host Tony Awards
abstract: James Corden of “The Late Late Show” will host this year’s Tony Awards broadcast.
lead_paragraph: James Corden of “The Late Late Show” was named on Tuesday to host this year’s Tony Awards.

headline: When Is Criticism Unfair?
abstract: Leslie Jamison and Alice Gregory debate the boundaries of fair criticism.
lead_paragraph: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Leslie Jamison and Alice Gregory debate the boundaries of fair criticism.

headline: A Big Louisville Upset of U.N.C., at Least by Human Standards
abstract: While No. 2 North Carolina was ranked much higher than No. 19 Louisville in the men’s basketball polls entering Monday’s game, computer rankings and oddsmakers begged to differ.
lead_paragraph: The headlines Tuesday morning were clear: Something surprising had happened in college basketball the previous night.

headline: Chris Christie, 10th in Iowa, Tells New Hampshire Fans He Performed ‘as Expected’
abstract: “I’m in a peppy mood this morning,” said Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who has spent much of the last two months in New Hampshire and is counting on a big finish there in next week’s primary.
lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H. — Chris Christie on Tuesday morning did not seem like a man who had finished near the back of the pack with 1.8 percent of the vote in the Iowa caucuses the night before.

headline: Lincoln Center Season Includes Gianandrea Noseda and Christian  Gerhaher
abstract: Next season’s Great Performers series will run on and off from Oct. 28 through May 21, 2017.
lead_paragraph: Gianandrea Noseda leading the London Symphony Orchestra in the Verdi Requiem, the baritone Christian Gerhaher singing a program of Mahler lieder, and the pianist Jeremy Denk playing a recital of music from medieval to modern times will be among the highlights of next season’s Great Performers series at Lincoln Center, whose lineup was announced on Tuesday.

headline: Mauro Bigonzetti to Direct La Scala Ballet
abstract: Mauro Bigonzetti, an Italian choreographer who works in a contemporary ballet idiom, succeeds Makhar Vaziev.
lead_paragraph: Mauro Bigonzetti, an Italian choreographer with a substantial reputation in Europe and the United States, has been appointed director of La Scala Ballet, the company announced on Monday. He succeeds Makhar Vaziev, who will become the director of the Bolshoi Ballet on March 18.

headline: Magic Leap, an Augmented Reality Firm, Raises $793 Million
abstract: Magic Leap has drawn attention for attracting investors like Google, Fidelity Investments and Warner Brothers, although it has shown the public little about its products.
lead_paragraph: Magic Leap, a secretive augmented reality start-up based in Dania Beach, Fla., announced on Tuesday that it had raised a $793 million round of venture financing, valuing the company at $3.7 billion, excluding the new funds.

headline: Nahnatchka Khan on ‘Fresh Off the Boat,’ Chinese New Year and Michael Chang
abstract: Ms. Khan’s sitcom, about growing up Taiwanese-American in Florida, plans a Chinese New Year episode, the first on an American series.
lead_paragraph: Once mostly anonymous, the producers who oversee top television series have sometimes become as well known as the actors who star in them. On occasion, The New York Times will pose questions from readers (and some of our own) to notable show runners and post their responses.

headline: Prediction Markets’ Sudden New Favorite: Third-Place Rubio
abstract: The sharp, decisive shift suggests that markets believe that the early rounds of voting reveal a lot about the underlying state of this election.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz beat all comers in Monday’s Iowa caucuses. He also beat expectations. Yet according to political prediction markets, Marco Rubio was the night’s biggest winner. Mr. Rubio’s third-place showing led his political stock to soar, and markets now rate him as a strong favorite to win the G.O.P. nomination.

headline: The Russian Runway Raconteuse
abstract: The young Moscow-born designer behind the fashion-world darling A.W.A.K.E. is driven by a desire to spin tales.
lead_paragraph: In fashion this spring, there are no rules. Perhaps no young designer explored this idea more than Natalia Alaverdian, with her label, A.W.A.K.E. Each collection is meant to tell a story, built around an animal mascot. This season, her most surprising and fantastical yet, is ‘‘very much about Africa,’’ says the 34-year-old, who was born in Soviet Moscow, raised in Belgium and has also worked as a stylist, photographer and fashion director. ‘‘I had a vision of a zebra crossing her legs and smoking a cigarette,’’ an image she ended up putting in a slashed circle (so as not to promote smoking) and placing on a jacket sleeve, among other garments, to evoke the insignia of an African military general. Major stylists and fashion followers alike, including Kim and Kanye, have started requesting her clothes. Take note.

headline: “Takashi Murakami’s Superflat Collection: From Shohaku and Rosanjin to Anselm Kiefer”
abstract: The first public exhibition of Murakami’s vast personal art collection goes on view at the Yokohama Museum of Art in Japan through April 3, 2016.
lead_paragraph: The first public exhibition of Murakami’s vast personal art collection goes on view at the Yokohama Museum of Art in Japan through April 3, 2016.

headline: Nielsen Plays Catch-Up as Streaming Era Wreaks Havoc on TV Raters
keywords: ['Television', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Web-Original Programming', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Nielsen executives say that they have heard the complaints of TV and ad executives and are ready to track the many ways people consume media. But skeptics abound.
lead_paragraph: Dennis Cheatham said he felt as if he were receiving a message from the past last May when a package arrived in the mail from Nielsen asking him to participate in the survey that for decades has detailed the television viewing habits of Americans.

headline: The West Must Stop Giving Turkey a Free Pass
abstract: The United States and the European Union have deemed refugees and Syria more important than Turkish democracy. That’s a mistake.
lead_paragraph: Last month, more than 1,200 Turkish and foreign academics signed a petition calling attention to the continuing humanitarian crisis in many Kurdish-majority towns in southeastern Turkey, which are the site of fighting between the Turkish Army and the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or P.K.K. The petition decried the Army’s shelling of urban areas and the imposition of weekslong, 24-hour curfews, which have left many civilians unable to bury their dead or even obtain food. President Recep Tayyip Erdogan publicly denounced the signers as “so-called intellectuals” and “traitors.” Within days, antiterror police had detained and harassed dozens of the signatories.

headline: Iowa Caucus Night
abstract: The long battle for the candidates concluded on Monday night in the Hawkeye state.
lead_paragraph: The long battle for the candidates concluded on Monday night in the Hawkeye state.

headline: Storm Batters Nation’s Midsection With Snow and Lightning
abstract: The storm, packing blizzard-like conditions and lightning strikes, deposited several inches of snow in Colorado and Nebraska, and knocked out power to thousands of residents.
lead_paragraph: A storm packing blizzard-like conditions, as well as lightning strikes, was expected to deposit several inches of snow on the country’s midsection Tuesday.

headline: Submit Questions for Vince Gilligan and Peter Gould of ‘Better Call Saul’
abstract: The AMC series returns for its second season on Feb. 15.
lead_paragraph: Vince Gilligan and Peter Gould answered the questions here.

headline: Takashi Murakami on the Art of Collecting Art
abstract: As his personal collection goes on display at a Japanese museum, the artist describes what it’s like to be on the other side of the transaction.
lead_paragraph: As his personal collection goes on display at a Japanese museum, the artist describes what it’s like to be on the other side of the transaction.

headline: After a Massacre, San Bernardino Police Stare Down Crippling Cuts
abstract: A corps that responded heroically to the Dec. 2 terrorist attack is also savaged by rattletrap equipment, crushing workloads and sunken morale.
lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — Detective Ryan Wicks trained the headlights of his Ford Crown Victoria Police Interceptor on a young man spotted fleeing local gang members and climbed out of his car, a battered black-and-white cruiser of mid-2000s vintage. The odometer stood north of 95,000 miles. A rear fender was scarred by the belt buckles of hundreds of suspects who had been spread-eagled against it.

headline: 8 New Destination Hotels for 2016
abstract: Highly anticipated properties are scheduled to open in Phnom Penh; Lake Como, Italy; St. Kitts and Cape Town — and in Shanghai, Disney will have a Toy Story Hotel.
lead_paragraph: Hotel openings might seem like everyday events, but a handful come with more excitement and anticipation than the rest. They may be in a particularly notable building, bring a fresh concept to an already-popular destination or have the potential to attract travelers to a location they may not have thought of visiting. With these factors in mind, we turned to travel professionals who check out new properties for a living and picked eight names worth checking into in 2016 (excluded from the list below are hotels that are reopening after a renovation, as with the Ritz Paris).

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 10: Jane Swipes Right
abstract: Chapter 32 introduced some new romantic prospects for Jane, with mixed results.
lead_paragraph: About halfway through the second season of “Jane the Virgin,” the question of when Jane will actually lose her virginity is still up in the air. Beyond the original elevator pitch, Jane’s virginity has never been the point of the series, but it’s still an important lingering aspect of her life. This episode focuses more on the “who”: For a while it seemed like a choice between Michael and Rafael, but now could it be someone new?

headline: Benoit
abstract: A French bistro from Alain Ducasse in Midtown.
lead_paragraph: A French bistro from Alain Ducasse in Midtown.

headline: Benoit in Midtown Is the Bistro That Will Take You to Paris
abstract: The menu includes dishes outside the bistro canon made almost as well as those inside it.
lead_paragraph: Like many New Yorkers, I have convinced myself that a rickety fire escape platform is a terrace and that a segment of the Empire State Building’s antenna seen through a sliver of window constitutes a panoramic skyline view. The same capacity for wishful self-delusion must be what keeps us going to bistros that are nothing like anything in France.

headline: Utah Symphony Names New President
abstract: Paul Meecham, who has helped to restore fiscal stability at the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, will start in July.
lead_paragraph: The Utah Symphony, which has been steadily rebuilding its player ranks under the musical direction of Thierry Fischer, announced on Tuesday that it would soon be under new administrative leadership: It is hiring Paul Meecham, the president of the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, to be its next president.

headline: Butterflies for Ted Cruz, Determined Foe of Ethanol Mandates
keywords: ['Agriculture and Farming', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Butterflies and Moths', 'Corn', 'Environment', 'Ethanol', 'Fuel Efficiency', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Ted Cruz’s victory in Iowa may be a victory for butterflies, as well, if it ends political subservience to Big Corn.
lead_paragraph: No matter who prevails as the Republican presidential candidate and who wins the election next November, there may already be a big and enduring win out of this crazy race — for the environment, including ailing monarch butterflies. If butterflies had hands instead of wings, they’d be clapping for Senator Ted Cruz.

headline: Let the Moon Be Your Guide in Finding Five Planets
abstract: Learn a low-fi method for spotting five planets at once.
lead_paragraph: For the past two weeks, five of our solar system’s planets have paraded across the pre-dawn sky, visible to the naked eye, giving early-risers a rare visual treat. The show will continue into mid-February but as many a stargazer will attest to, distinguishing Mercury, Venus, Mars, Saturn and Jupiter amid the medley of twinkling dots can be tricky. There are a number of apps and computer programs that can help people track the quintet, but for those in need of a low-fi way to spot the planets, a recent NASA video offers the following advice: Look for the moon.

headline: Time for a Strategic Shift at UBS’s Investment Bank
abstract: After several quarters of more than 20 percent returns on equity, UBS’s broker-dealer business squeezed out a 4.4 percent return in the quarter that just ended.
lead_paragraph: Running an investment bank is a well-paid but sometimes frustrating business.

headline: Sarah Palin’s English
keywords: ['Grammar', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The elements of Mrs. Palin’s speech style on the campaign trail aren’t simple; they’re actually incredibly complicated.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Palin has been mocked a lot for the way she talks, especially in her strange and rambling endorsement speech for Donald Trump. But her speeches on the campaign trail aren’t simple; they are actually incredibly complicated.

headline: Some Iowa Delegates Awarded by Coin Toss
abstract: With the results so close in the Democratic caucuses in Iowa, some precincts used a coin toss to decide the winner of a spare delegate.
lead_paragraph: With the results so close in the Democratic caucuses in Iowa, some precincts used a coin toss to decide the winner of a spare delegate.

headline: Letitia James, New York Public Advocate, Sues Education Dept. Over Schools’ Disability Services
abstract: Ms. James said that because of a computer system’s shortcomings, children had been deprived of assistance and the city had lost out on Medicaid reimbursements.
lead_paragraph: Public Advocate Letitia James has sued the New York City Education Department, saying a $130 million computer system meant to track services for students with disabilities was a failure.

headline: Candidates, in New Hampshire, Hit the Ground Running
abstract: Ted Cruz. Marco Rubio. Donald Trump. Hillary Clinton. Bernie Sanders. Those not declaring victory in Iowa were predicting it in New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: Presidential candidates flew through the night to hit the New Hampshire campaign trail running on Tuesday morning, eager to capitalize on a race that has been reordered by surprising finishes in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Marrakesh’s New Super Souk
abstract: The Moroccan city’s most beloved boutique hotel, El Fenn, now has a carefully edited gift shop.
lead_paragraph: The boutique hotel El Fenn has long been a favorite of the fashion crowd for its glittery rooftop bar with views of the medina, and its one-of-a-kind rooms, decorated with hand-woven kilim blankets and plush, modern Berber carpets from the renowned rug seller Soufiane Zarib. Now, with its new, lushly appointed gift shop, admirers can take these home — plus browse a carefully edited selection of other goods from Morocco and beyond, including unusual vintage jewelry, ethereal clothing by the French designer Thierry Colson and dramatic leather caftans and djellabas, embellished with snakeskin and ostrich, by the American artist Paul Rowland, who spearheaded the store.

headline: Is a Cow a ‘Who’ or a ‘Which?’ Our Standards Editor Weighs In
abstract: The associate masthead editor for standards, Philip B. Corbett, considers the prickly, philosophical question.
lead_paragraph: Philip B. Corbett is the associate masthead editor for standards and oversees The Times’s style manual.

headline: A Memorable Fillet of Sole, With a Touch of Color
abstract: Bright, juicy, sweet and tart segments of blood orange contrast beautifully with the understated fish.
lead_paragraph: Fillet of sole is the perfect fish to cook for a romantic and elegant dinner for two.

headline: The Republican Establishment’s New Hampshire Playbook
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Here is a look at how Jeb Bush, Chris Christie, John Kasich and Marco Rubio hope to use the Granite State to reinvigorate their campaigns.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Welcome to New Hampshire, a state with a history of rebutting Iowa’s best-laid plans. Here, the Republicans’ four so-called establishment candidates — former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida — hope to emerge as a clear alternative to Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Donald J. Trump, who finished in the top two slots on Monday evening in Iowa. Mr. Rubio enters New Hampshire with the clear momentum, having finished third in Iowa and well ahead of his rivals. But the three governors still believe New Hampshire is their best shot to reinvigorate their campaigns.

headline: Joseph Abboud: Fall 2016
abstract: The first show following the designer’s return to his namesake brand (which he launched in 1987 and left in 2005.)
lead_paragraph: The first show following the designer’s return to his namesake brand (which he launched in 1987 and left in 2005.)

headline: Finding Common Political Ground on Poverty
abstract: In an unlikely meeting of the minds, scholars from the left and the right managed to craft a compelling set of recommendations, despite their differences.
lead_paragraph: If you have been paying any attention to America’s paralyzed politics, you are not going to believe this.

headline: Bahamas Mega-Resort Stands Empty, Casualty of Dispute With Chinese Partners
abstract: Thousands of Bahamians had been counting on the opening of the $3.5 billion Baha Mar, but the project is now in receivership.
lead_paragraph: NASSAU, the Bahamas — Trei Bethel had been looking for work in the Bahamas for about a year when he finally got a break: a coveted spot in a program that trained young Bahamians to work at Baha Mar, a $3.5 billion mega-resort nearing completion on Nassau’s white-sand Cable Beach.

headline: North Korea, Defying Warnings, Prepares to Launch Long-Range Rocket
keywords: ['Rocket Science and Propulsion', 'Satellites', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The United States and allied nations see such moves by the North as cover for developing an intercontinental ballistic missile that can deliver a nuclear bomb.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In a new dare to the United States and its allies, North Korea has notified the United Nations agency responsible for navigation safety that it is planning to launch a long-range rocket this month to put a satellite into orbit.

headline: George Miller to Lead Cannes Film Festival Jury
abstract: The festival said that the selection of the director of “Mad Max: Fury Road” should be seen as a “celebration of genre cinema.”
lead_paragraph: PARIS — George Miller, the director of “Mad Max: Fury Road,” will preside over the jury of this year’s Cannes Film Festival, the festival announced Tuesday. In a statement, it called his appointment “a no-holds-barred celebration of genre cinema.”

headline: ChemChina Is Close to a Deal to Buy Syngenta
abstract: If completed, an acquisition of Syngenta, a Swiss agricultural and chemical giant, would be the largest by a Chinese company of a foreign company.
lead_paragraph: China is on the verge of its biggest ever foreign deal — and another possible political storm.

headline: Duckie Brown: Fall 2016
abstract: Steven Cox and Daniel Silver’s fall designs.
lead_paragraph: Steven Cox and Daniel Silver’s fall designs.

headline: Zica Car Will Be Renamed, Tata Motors of India Says
abstract: The automaker, seeking to avoid an unfortunate association with the outbreak, will rename its vehicle.
lead_paragraph: When the Indian automaker Tata Motors unveiled the name of its curvaceous new hatchback late last year, it declared that the car would be the “the next big thing.” The name? Zica.

headline: Appetite for S.U.V.s Offers Upside in Slower Month for Auto Sales
abstract: While sales slipped from the torrid pace of last year, analysts said that average vehicle prices rose because of strong demand for higher-cost S.U.V.s.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Sales of new vehicles dropped in the United States in January from a year ago, partly because of the snowstorm that shut down dealerships across the East Coast.

headline: Another New Director for Tanztheater Wuppertal
abstract: Adolphe Binder’s appointment, which takes effect in May 2017, comes “at a time of change” for the Wuppertal ensemble, a statement said.
lead_paragraph: Adolphe Binder, the director of the GöteborgsOperan Danskompani, will become the new director of the Tanztheater Wuppertal in May 2017, the company announced on Monday. She will be the fourth director to run the Tanztheater Wuppertal, in Germany, since the death in 2009 of the choreographer Pina Bausch, who had taken over the company in 1973 and turned it into a world-famous ensemble and a repository for her potent form of dance theater.

headline: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Intensify Efforts in New Hampshire After Iowa Standoff
abstract: Final vote counts showed Mrs. Clinton narrowly beating Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, according to The Associated Press and other news organizations.
lead_paragraph: NASHUA, N.H. — Hillary Clinton is digging in for a tough fight against Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont in next week’s primary in New Hampshire, her advisers said Tuesday, trying to spark political momentum and fund-raising energy after only a razor-thin victory in the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Kossar’s Returns With Bagels and Bialys on the Lower East Side
abstract: Also, City Crab Shack offers Chesapeake Bay seafood; Lionsbeerstore has more than more than 350 beers; and Pizzeria Sirenetta moves in on the Upper West Side.
lead_paragraph: Kossar’s Bagels & Bialys In the bagel capital of the world, the bialy, the round, flattened roll with onions in the center, also gets its due. Evan Giniger and David Zablocki, who in 2013 bought the 80-year-old Kossar’s Bialys on the Lower East Side, closed it in September for renovations. The working bakery in the back is now enclosed in glass, and the storefront is no longer drab, newly decked out with subway tiles and white marble. And now you can order your bialy sliced and filled with cream cheese, peanut butter, hummus and even whitefish salad, which was never offered before. Kossar’s is also making its own cream cheeses, labeled (and trademarked) as Schmears, in flavors like lox, vegetable, horseradish and everything bagel. The bialys have gone on a flavor trip, too, with sun-dried tomato, olive and apple-cinnamon. There are also pletzls (onion flatbreads), challahs and babkas. Sandwiches like the Yenta, with whitefish salad and pastrami salmon, are available for the first time. (Opens Friday): 367 Grand Street (Essex Street), 212-473-4810, kossars.com.

headline: A Party to Open New York Men’s Fashion Week
abstract: Tyson Beckford, Victor Cruz and Matt Harvey celebrate the sophomore week devoted to men’s wear at a party held by the CFDA and Dockers.
lead_paragraph: Tyson Beckford, Victor Cruz and Matt Harvey celebrate the sophomore week devoted to men’s wear at a party held by the CFDA and Dockers.

headline: Josh Brolin Revels in the Role of Go-To Guy
abstract: The actor, whose newest film is “Hail, Caesar!,” finds himself in demand after a long dry spell.
lead_paragraph: “I should warn you,” Josh Brolin said, calling from North Carolina. “I’ve just come out of the woods after three and a half months, and I’m a little crazy.”

headline: Matt Harvey and Tyson Beckford Help Open New York Men’s Fashion Week
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', "Men's Fashion Week", 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The Mets pitcher and the model help celebrate the sophomore week devoted to men’s wear at a party held by the CFDA and Dockers.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, as much of the nation looked toward Iowa for hints of its political future, the insular world of men’s fashion took a moment to raise a glass and give a toast to, well, itself.

headline: David Boies’s Dual Roles at Theranos Set Up Conflict
abstract: Mr. Boies represents Theranos as its lawyer, but he also represents the company’s investors as a director, a situation that could become tricky.
lead_paragraph: Theranos is in trouble, and David Boies, a star lawyer, has placed himself at the heart of it, a decision that he may come to rue.

headline: Johnny Manziel’s Days With the Cleveland Browns Appear Numbered
abstract: The team issued a terse statement after Manziel’s latest off-the-field incident and said it would address his status on team when “permitted by league rules.”
lead_paragraph: The Cleveland Browns issued a terse response on Tuesday to quarterback Johnny Manziel’s latest incident, with a strong implication that his days as a Brown may be numbered.

headline: ‘Heisenberg’ Will Transfer to Broadway
abstract: Mary-Louise Parker and Denis Arndt will reprise their roles in this Simon Stephens’s drama when Manhattan Theater Club transfers its production of the show to Broadway this fall.
lead_paragraph: Mary-Louise Parker and Denis Arndt will reprise their roles in Simon Stephens’s drama “Heisenberg” when Manhattan Theater Club transfers its production of the show to Broadway this fall, the theater announced on Tuesday. The two-character play, which Manhattan Theater Club mounted last year Off Broadway, is to start previews at the company’s Samuel J. Friedman Theater on Sept. 30, with opening night scheduled for Oct. 13. Mark Brokaw will again direct.

headline: Review: In ‘Death of the Liberal Class,’ a Writer Tones Down His Anger
abstract: This play imagines what happens to an author after he tires of railing against the capitalist system.
lead_paragraph: “Death of the Liberal Class,” a muddle of a play by Robert Lyons at the New Ohio Theater, tries to find bigger themes in a male schlub’s midlife crisis. But that’s asking too much of the story’s irksome, inconsistent characters.

headline: Review: In ‘Madoff,’ What He Was Thinking
abstract: Richard Dreyfuss stars in this four-hour ABC mini-series is told from the perspective of Bernard L. Madoff, the mastermind behind America’s greatest Ponzi scheme.
lead_paragraph: Bernie didn’t fail us. We failed Bernie.

headline: Iowa As A Media Focal Point
abstract: Why a handful of votes end up ruling the narrative.
lead_paragraph: The outsized role the Iowa caucuses play in the nomination process is, as almost everyone acknowledges, sort of stupid. But where does it come from? The immediate answer is that it’s about the news media, which seize on the Iowa results and use them to tell narratives that can, in turn, have a huge impact on fundraising and later voting.

headline: Iowa Votes, and the World Weighs In
abstract: What do they make of the caucus results in Hong Kong? Egypt? And Mexico? (Donald Trump may want to skip these last two.)
lead_paragraph: As the results of the Iowa caucuses — Ted Cruz’s narrow but humbling triumph over Donald J. Trump and Marco Rubio in the crowded Republican field, and Hillary Clinton’s razor-thin victory over Bernie Sanders in the Democratic contest — emerged on Tuesday morning, so did reactions and analysis from reporters, commentators and observers around the world. Below is a sampling.

headline: Analyzing the Iowa Caucus Results
abstract: Readers discuss Ted Cruz’s victory over Donald Trump and the very tight Democratic contest.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Death of a Star Swiss Chef Underscores the Profession’s Stress
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Chefs', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Work-Life Balance']
abstract: The apparent suicide of Benoît Violier, at the top of his craft, has drawn attention to the mental-health challenges that can affect restaurant employees.
lead_paragraph: The story is starting to sound familiar. A chef at the pinnacle of the culinary world commits suicide.

headline: LVMH Posts $7.2 Billion Profit, Beating Analysts’ Expectations
abstract: The company’s annual profit rose 16 percent in 2015, despite shakiness in the global market for luxury personal goods.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — LVMH, the world’s largest luxury group by sales, recorded full year profit and revenue for 2015 that outpaced analysts’ expectations, despite a rocky global market.

headline: Public School: Fall 2016
abstract: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow’s latest designs.
lead_paragraph: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow’s latest designs.

headline: Obama and Paul Ryan Have Lunch, and Consider a Wary Truce
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Presidential Election of 2008']

lead_paragraph: MILFORD, N.H. — If people thought that his second-place finish in Iowa had discouraged Donald J. Trump or distracted him from his goal of winning the Republican presidential nomination, Mr. Trump made it clear Tuesday night that they were dead wrong.

headline: Rivals Look to New Hampshire for a Shot at Breaking Donald Trump’s Stride
abstract: The Republican establishment closes ranks around a smaller number of candidates, but can Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio build on their Iowa momentum?
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Emboldened by Donald J. Trump’s defeat in the Iowa caucuses, conservative leaders and rival candidates for the Republican presidential nomination began to challenge him aggressively in New Hampshire on Tuesday, aiming to cut into his wide lead here and perhaps even to embarrass him by denying him victory in a second consecutive state.

abstract: Documents released by a congressional panel show that Valeant Pharmaceuticals and Turing Pharmaceuticals, Mr. Shkreli’s former company, sometimes raised prices as much as fiftyfold.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli anticipated huge profits from raising the price of a decades-old drug for an infectious disease, belying any notion that helping patients was foremost in his mind, according to information released by congressional investigators on Tuesday.

headline: Taliban Gun Down 10-Year-Old Militia Hero in Afghanistan
abstract: The former child soldier, Wasil Ahmad, was killed near his family’s home less than six months after he had fought to end a Taliban siege and was publicly — and illegally — celebrated.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Afghan government declared Wasil Ahmad a hero for leading a militia’s defense against a Taliban siege last year, parading him in front of cameras in a borrowed police uniform too big for him. On Monday, the Taliban triumphantly announced that they had assassinated him with two bullets to the head.

lead_paragraph: I did an interview on NY1 about Bob Gordon’s Rise and Fall of U.S. Economic Growth. My segment starts at 9:11.

headline: Polls Were Way Off on Donald Trump. Here’s What It Means.
abstract: Republican strategists have hoped for months that Mr. Trump’s lead was an illusion. The size of the polling error suggests this could be the case.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump was at the top of each of the last 10 polls in Iowa, but his lead failed to hold up on caucus night Monday. In the end, his seven-point lead in polling averages amounted to a three-point loss to Ted Cruz.

headline: Podcast: Postgame Wrap-Up on the Iowa Caucus
abstract: The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, talks about the Iowa caucus results, the winners, losers and what’s ahead.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz wins. Hillary Clinton wins, by the thinnest of margins. Martin O’Malley is out. The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, is in Des Moines and joins us for a postgame wrap-up on the Iowa caucus.

headline: Zika Infection Transmitted by Sex Reported in Texas
abstract: Officials in Dallas reported that a patient with Zika virus was infected after having sex with an ill individual who had returned from a country where Zika was circulating.
lead_paragraph: A case of Zika virus infection transmitted by sex, rather than mosquito bite, was discovered in Texas on Tuesday, a development sure to complicate plans to contain a global epidemic.

headline: ChemChina’s Bid for Syngenta Leaves Monsanto in the Cold
abstract: Monsanto would probably need to sweeten its offer for Syngenta to overpower ChemChina’s.
lead_paragraph: The advance of the China National Chemical Corporation, a state-owned company, on Syngenta leaves Monsanto in a thorny spot.

headline: Men’s Wear Veteran Joseph Abboud Returns to the Runway
abstract: After a 15-year absence, the 65-year-old designer makes a new case for his look at men’s fashion week in New York.
lead_paragraph: David Bowie’s music was a staple of the men’s fashion shows that recently concluded in Europe, and it was back for the start of the men’s fashion week in New York as the first model made his way down the runway for Joseph Abboud.

headline: The Most Exacting Photographer in Downtown ’70s New York
abstract: A new exhibition celebrates the work of Peter Hujar, whose portraits of figures like Susan Sontag, Fran Lebowitz and Candy Darling have become iconic.
lead_paragraph: In the pages of T last September, the critic and novelist Edmund White asked, “Why can’t we stop talking about New York in the late 1970s?” This month, Paul Kasmin and Pace/MacGill galleries have teamed up to present an exhibition of two dozen photos from one of that period’s most celebrated photographers, the late Peter Hujar, whose archive also supplied the imagery for White’s piece. The show includes some of his most iconic images, including “Candy Darling on Her Deathbed,” here, and the portraits of Susan Sontag and Fran Lebowitz below that were also included alongside White’s article in T.

headline: 18 Elephants on a Plane: Move From Swaziland to U.S. Is Criticized
abstract: Three zoos formed a partnership to house the elephants, which were said to be threatened by habitat destruction and drought, but conservationists said the move imperiled the animals.
lead_paragraph: More than a dozen elephants from southern Africa are being moved to American zoos, a plan that critics say will imperil the animals.

headline: Iowa Caucus Coverage Draws Large Crowds on Cable
abstract: The three main cable news networks, Fox News, CNN and MSNBC, each attracted much larger audiences for their reports on the Iowa caucus than they did in 2012.
lead_paragraph: In an election season in which audiences for primary debates have shattered cable news records, the coverage of the Iowa caucus also achieved big numbers.

headline: Chinese-American Chefs Start a Culinary Conversation With the Past
abstract: From cookbooks and childhood memories, and through trial and error, some are determined to begin a new tradition with the food of their ancestors.
lead_paragraph: One was working as an accredited C.P.A. Another had just completed the requirements for a pre-med degree at the University of Chicago. Yet another, a junior employee at Morgan Stanley, walked down 75 flights in the World Trade Center’s South Tower and back into the family food business on Sept. 11, 2001.

headline: Changes at Brioni and Berluti Continue Designer Shuffle
abstract: The sudden shift in men’s wear mirrors the recent shake-up in women’s wear.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is experiencing another designer exodus.

headline: Australia Confirms 2 Cases of Zika Virus
abstract: The two people were probably infected on a trip to Haiti, health officials said, and they have recovered.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Health officials in Australia on Tuesday confirmed two cases of the Zika virus in residents who most likely were infected on a visit to Haiti, and the officials also warned pregnant women not to travel to areas where transmission rates are high, like the Caribbean.

headline: Comparing Rubio and Obama in Iowa
abstract: A selection of moments showing similarities between Marco Rubio’s speech on Monday night and Barack Obama’s speech in 2008 after he won the Iowa caucuses.
lead_paragraph: A selection of moments showing similarities between Marco Rubio’s speech on Monday night and Barack Obama’s speech in 2008 after he won the Iowa caucuses.

headline: Cue the New Sod: N.F.L. Plays Super Bowl on Its Own Turf
abstract: For about the past 25 years, the N.F.L. has replaced the entire field for Super Bowls played on natural grass, ensuring pristine conditions for the game.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Hours after the San Francisco 49ers beat the St. Louis Rams on Jan. 3 in the final game of the regular season here, a whole other team entered Levi’s Stadium for an urgent, curious ritual: to replace the entire field in time for the Super Bowl a month away.

headline: SXSW Sets Film Lineup With Western From Ti West
keywords: ['Movies', 'South by Southwest Music and Media Conference']
abstract: The South by Southwest festival will also screen a documentary about improv comedy titled “Thank You Del.”
lead_paragraph: Uber drivers, improv groups and vice principals are all in the mix at the next South by Southwest film festival in Austin, Tex. On Tuesday, organizers announced the majority of their feature lineup, this year including 89 world premieres.

headline: A Playful, French Take on a Classic Notebook
abstract: Vahram Muratyan, known for his “Paris versus New York” illustration, designed a series of notebooks for Smythson.
lead_paragraph: When Smythson approached the graphic artist Vahram Muratyan to design a set of notebooks — carte blanche — Muratyan ran with that freedom. “It occurred to me that I could take those words — those French phrases that we use in English — and place them above the different glasses, or characters,” the graphic artist says. “Carte blanche” didn’t ultimately make the cut, but there’s “je ne sais quoi,” “crème de la crème” and “touché” (and three more) etched onto fuchsia, orange and yellow covers. Muratyan, known for his “Paris versus New York: A Tally of Two Cities” blog-that-became-a-book, referred to his latest bridging of the cultural gap as a “soft and sweet French invasion. I wanted to drop a French guy into Smythson’s British history.”

headline: Francisco Flores, Tainted Ex-President of El Salvador, Dies at 56
abstract: Mr. Flores was facing charges of diverting $15 million in contributions for earthquake victims to his personal and political party accounts.
lead_paragraph: Francisco Flores, a former president of El Salvador who was facing charges of diverting $15 million in contributions for earthquake victims to his personal and political party accounts, died on Jan. 30 in San Salvador. He was 56.

lead_paragraph: Images of Blinn College, a junior college in Brenham, Tex., where Cam Newton played in 2009, after leaving Florida but before heading to Auburn and then the N.F.L.

headline: At Blinn College, Cam Newton Plotted a Return to the Big Time
abstract: Newton, the Panthers’ Super Bowl quarterback, transferred to Blinn College, in Brenham, Tex., to keep his football career going after leaving the University of Florida.
lead_paragraph: BRENHAM, Tex. — Before Cam Newton won the Heisman Trophy, before he was drafted first over all, before he led the Carolina Panthers to Super Bowl 50, he woke up to mooing. The bovine alarm clocks grazed in a pasture, since built over, situated a deep spiral from his first-floor residence in Building 5 of the College Park Apartments here.

headline: Obama Seeks More Than $1 Billion to Fight Opioid Abuse
keywords: ['Epidemics', 'Heroin', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Law and Legislation', 'State of the Union Message (US)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The administration said it would ask Congress for the money next year to help deal with a problem that has worsened during the president’s tenure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration said on Tuesday that it would ask Congress to spend an additional $1.1 billion next year to combat a growing epidemic of prescription painkiller and heroin abuse.

headline: Review: In ‘The Fugitives,’ Looking for His Muse in All the Wrong Places
abstract: Christopher Sorrentino’s latest novel centers on a Brooklyn writer who escapes to a small Michigan town to finish a long-overdue book and flee a messy personal life.
lead_paragraph: In his new novel, “The Fugitives,” Christopher Sorrentino grafts a halfhearted, Elmore Leonard-style casino heist plot onto what is fundamentally the mournful story of one man’s failures as a writer, a husband and a father. The result is something close to a disaster.

headline: ‘The Vegetarian,’ a Surreal South Korean Novel
abstract: Han Kang, highly regarded in her homeland, has broken through to English-speaking readers with a book that’s a decade old.
lead_paragraph: When Han Kang’s surreal, violent novel “The Vegetarian” was published in South Korea nearly a decade ago, literary critics found it baffling. The story stars an unhinged heroine who believes she’s turning into a tree, and features some of the strangest erotic passages in literature. (In one unforgettable scene, Ms. Han renders clichéd sexual metaphors about flowering plants and protruding pistils quite literally.)

headline: Robert Geller: Fall 2016
abstract: The latest fall looks.
lead_paragraph: The latest fall looks.

headline: After Suing Over Eggless Spread, Hellmann’s Introduces Its Own
abstract: In 2014, Unilever sued Hampton Creek, whose Just Mayo eggless spread has dented the market share of conventional mayonnaise brands.
lead_paragraph: If you can’t beat ’em, join ’em. Unilever, the global food and consumer products giant, said on Tuesday that it would begin selling an eggless sandwich spread.

headline: The Tiny London Shop Behind Some of the Very Best Libraries
abstract: London’s Heywood Hill curates impressive collections for discerning customers in 60 different countries — and specializes in the obscure.

headline: Pentagon Chief Calls for Spending Increase to Address Multiple Threats

abstract: Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said the United States no longer faced one threat at a time, but an array of opponents, as he previewed the Pentagon’s budget request for 2017.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Ashton B. Carter said Tuesday that the United States faced a “dramatically different” security environment than at any point in the past 25 years, arguing for an increase in military spending to confront an array of threats like the Islamic State and Russia.

keywords: ['Company Reports', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Facing investor demands for action, Yahoo said it would lay off workers and explore possibilities that include sale of some assets.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Yahoo is moving full speed ahead — in every direction.

headline: Gun Tests and Tears at Officer Peter Liang’s Trial in Killing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Several jurors handled the 9-millimeter pistol that Officer Liang used in the 2014 fatal shooting, seeking to determine how much force was needed to pull the trigger.
lead_paragraph: One by one, the jurors held the Glock 9-millimeter pistol that had belonged to Police Officer Peter Liang, from which a bullet ricocheted down a housing project stairwell and killed an unarmed man in November 2014.

headline: Virginia Girl Probably Died the Day She Vanished, Officials Say
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Social Media']
abstract: The “very preliminary” cause of death was announced Tuesday, and a second Virginia Tech student charged in the girl’s death now faces charges of helping commit the murder.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A 13-year-old Virginia girl was most likely stabbed to death by a Virginia Tech student on the day she disappeared, the authorities in Blacksburg, Va., said Tuesday, and a second university student — originally accused of helping dispose of the body — now faces charges of helping commit the murder.

headline: Muslim Conference Calls for Protection of Religious Minorities
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Yazidi (Religious Sect)', 'Religion and Belief']
abstract: The gathering in Morocco of muftis, theologians and scholars issued a declaration welcomed by many as a hopeful sign, though also seen with some skepticism.
lead_paragraph: MARRAKESH, Morocco — At a recent conference held by Muslim scholars to confront violence in the Islamic world, a representative of the Yazidi religious minority in Iraq and Syria said his people desperately needed protection from the Islamic State.

headline: Tech’s Track Record of Shake-Ups at the Top
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Mobile Commerce and Payments']
abstract: Yahoo and Twitter are just the latest tech companies shaping plans for major overhauls and management shake-ups. A look back at how Priceline, Amazon and eBay weathered turbulent times.
lead_paragraph: Ups and downs are nothing new in the fast-moving technology industry. And as soon as a company hits turbulence, calls for a management shake-up almost always follow.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Urban Meditation Destinations
abstract: Inspired by their own love of conscious quietude, a trio of women in Los Angeles and New York are bringing nirvana to the jaded masses.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by their own love of conscious quietude, a trio of women in Los Angeles and New York are bringing nirvana to the jaded masses.

headline: Kickstarter as a Path to Grammy Nominations, Far Beyond the Indie Scene
abstract: Kickstarter and other crowdfunding sites have become part of the standard financial circuit for musicians of all types, with releases edging closer to the mainstream.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, the Nashville Symphony was in austerity mode as it recovered from the financial crisis and a flood that caused $40 million in damage to its building. To help finance an album of works by the composer Joan Tower, the orchestra turned for the first time to a source more associated with indie rock than with classical music: Kickstarter.

headline: Bernie Sanders Heads to New Hampshire on Iowa Momentum
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Strategists will try to hold onto the Vermont senator’s advantage in his neighboring state, drawing more votes, money and buzz to the upstart campaign.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Senator Bernie Sanders, who came within half a percentage point of defeating Hillary Clinton in Iowa, will spend the next week trying to maintain a significant advantage in New Hampshire, where he has been leading in polls for months.

headline: Review: A New York Philharmonic Contact! Menu, With Esa-Pekka Salonen as Chef
abstract: This concert at National Sawdust in Brooklyn Included Mr. Salonen’s 1982 concoction “Floof,” as well as new-music compositions by Donatoni, Lutoslawski and Castiglioni.
lead_paragraph: Though he won’t be the next music director of the New York Philharmonic, Esa-Pekka Salonen isn’t leaving anytime soon: Named the orchestra’s composer in residence last year, he remains in that position through the 2017-18 season. He programmed and hosted the Philharmonic’s latest installment of its Contact! new-music series on Monday at National Sawdust in Williamsburg, a rare foray to Brooklyn by a Lincoln Center institution.

headline: Review: The Curtis Symphony Orchestra Dives Into Mahler and More
abstract: This orchestra performed Luciano Berio ‘s “Sinfonia,” Mahler’s First Symphony and Busoni’s “Berceuse Élégiaque” at Carnegie Hall
lead_paragraph: Luciano Berio’s groundbreaking “Sinfonia,” which helped pave the way for the freewheeling compositional styles now in vogue, is too seldom heard. So Ludovic Morlot’s stirring rendition with the Curtis Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening was most welcome.

headline: With the Return of Men’s Fashion Week to New York, Street Style Is Back
abstract: For a number of stylish guys heading to Day 1 of the biannual showcase, suits were all the rage.
lead_paragraph: For a number of stylish guys heading to Day 1 of the biannual showcase, suits were all the rage.

headline: New Western Wall Prayer Space Highlights Wider Divide Among Jews
keywords: ['Temple Mount (Jerusalem)', 'Women and Girls', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: Now the question is whether the new prayer space at the wall is a step toward more fundamental change or only a resolution to a localized problem.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It seemed a solution worthy of Solomon: create a permanent egalitarian prayer space at the Western Wall alongside the gender-segregated area that has been the subject of vitriolic protest.

headline: Leicester City Tops Liverpool, and Keeps On Dreaming of Title
abstract: Leicester City’s hot start was supposed to fade in September or October. Or maybe November. Or December. But it is February now and the club is still atop the Premier League.
lead_paragraph: LEICESTER, England — Three years ago this Thursday, a news conference was held at the University of Leicester to confirm that the remains discovered beneath a city parking lot in 2012 were those of King Richard III, one of the most vilified monarchs in history. The finding, which involved a glorious combination of science and serendipity, brought global attention to this city in England’s East Midlands, and when Richard’s remains were reburied inside the local Anglican cathedral last year, a steady stream of tourists followed, too.

headline: Chipotle Food-Safety Issues Drag Down Profits
abstract: The company said its profits fell 44 percent in the fourth quarter after outbreaks of food-borne illnesses linked to its restaurants in several states.
lead_paragraph: Chipotle Mexican Grill revealed on Tuesday that federal prosecutors had expanded their inquiry into the company’s multistate outbreaks of food-borne illnesses, further threatening sales that declined steeply by the end of last year.

headline: Visions of Oakland, Made of Cloth
abstract: Many facets of the California city — bits of its personality, its history and its social complexity — are captured in works by the African American Quilt Guild of Oakland.
lead_paragraph: Many facets of the California city — bits of its personality, its history and its social complexity — are captured in works by the African American Quilt Guild of Oakland.

headline: Quilts With a Sense of Place, Stitched in Oakland
abstract: Works by the African American Quilt Guild of Oakland, Calif., capture many facets of the city’s life, and the concerns of its artists.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — Wildfires were burning across California as Marion Coleman began “Firestorm,” her quilt about the flames that ravaged the Oakland and Berkeley Hills in 1991. It is an inferno captured in cloth: the blackened silhouettes of trees, engulfed in a blaze of intricate, swirling stitches.

headline: Fischli and Weiss: Anarchy at the Guggenheim
abstract: The first New York survey of the Swiss artists Peter Fischli and Davis Weiss is set to open this week.
lead_paragraph: In the art of the 20th century, comedy was tough to come by. Marcel Duchamp and his urinal were the original stand-up act, and Magritte was good for some laughs. But a long, dry stretch followed, through Abstract Expressionism and Minimalism, lightened up in the 1960s only by oddball wits like Ray Johnson and Lee Lozano.

headline: Review: In ‘Rams,’ Brothers at Odds Face a Shared Threat to Their Livelihood
abstract: The sources of the bad blood are never specified, but it trickles though Grimur Hakonarson’s new film, in some respects a familiar kind of Nordic comedy.
lead_paragraph: Even though they live in rural Iceland, thousands of miles from the Holy Land, and in a modern reality of computers and mechanized farm equipment, Gummi and Kiddi have a decidedly Old Testament vibe. It’s not just the untended beards and the well-tended sheep. The two men, who live on neighboring farms in a quiet valley, are feuding brothers, locked in a sibling rivalry that recalls Jacob and Esau or Cain and Abel. The sources of the bad blood are never specified, but it trickles though “Rams,” Grimur Hakonarson’s new film, like an icy stream.

headline: New Offensive by Assad’s Forces Overshadows Syria Peace Talks
abstract: Government bombing attacks around Homs and Aleppo were supported by intensive Russian airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A major offensive by Syrian government forces backed by intensive Russian airstrikes in and around the northern city of Aleppo on Tuesday cast a pall over United Nations efforts to draw government and opposition delegates assembled in Geneva into substantive peace talks.

headline: Uber Drivers and Others in the Gig Economy Take a Stand
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: As the online gig economy grows, workers are beginning to band together to secure what they see as fairer treatment from companies that make them feel more like employees than contractors.
lead_paragraph: Last September, Dallas-area drivers for UberBlack, the company’s high-end car service, received an email informing them that they would be expected to start picking up passengers on UberX, its low-cost option.

headline: Lady Gaga Will Sing the National Anthem at Super Bowl 50

lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl lineup has gained another diva: Lady Gaga will sing the national anthem on Sunday at Levi’s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif., the N.F.L. and CBS announced on Tuesday.

headline: Iowa Results Signal Long Nominating Contests for Both Parties
abstract: No candidate appears to have an easy path to win victories in the next two states, and insurgents have enough money to finance a strong offensive.
lead_paragraph: A pair of presidential primary battles that just days ago seemed to have heavy favorites now present the prospect of protracted and expensive contests for both parties, as the candidates who survived the Iowa caucuses surged on Tuesday toward the New Hampshire primary to be held next week.

headline: Opinión: En Perú, una campaña presidencial y un juicio por asesinato van de la mano
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: El General Daniel Urresti, candidato presidencial del partido gobernante, fue acusado el año pasado de haber ordenado el asesinato de un periodista.
lead_paragraph: LIMA, Perú — En los 80, Hugo Bustíos trabajaba como fotoperiodista en Ayacucho, una provincia peruana que entonces se regía por ley marcial. En esa época el ejército libraba una campaña brutal de contrainsurgencia para abatir a Sendero Luminoso. El trabajo de Bustíos como reportero lo convirtió en un testigo incómodo de las atrocidades cometidas por ambos bandos, y recibió numerosas amenazas de muerte.

headline: Spain: Socialist Aims to Form Coalition
abstract: King Felipe VI asked the leader of the Socialist party, Pedro Sánchez, to try to form a coalition government and break Spain’s political deadlock after inconclusive elections.
lead_paragraph: King Felipe VI on Tuesday asked the leader of the Socialist party, Pedro Sánchez, to try to form a coalition government and break Spain’s political deadlock after inconclusive elections in December. Last month, Spain’s acting prime minister, Mariano Rajoy, turned down the king’s offer, saying that he lacked sufficient support to form a government. Although Mr. Rajoy’s conservative Popular Party won the most votes in December, it lost its parliamentary majority. But Mr. Sánchez also faces an uphill struggle. He has been trying to persuade two emerging parties — Podemos and Citizens — to back him, even though the leaders of the two parties have recently ruled out working together. He also faces dissent within his own party to a coalition with Podemos. He has asked for one month to line up possible partners before seeking the endorsement of lawmakers. If he fails and no other leader is able to put together a viable government, new elections will have to be called.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Schenker, 49, is the president and a managing partner of ABS Partners Real Estate, a New York-based brokerage, management and consulting firm that also invests in commercial property, mainly office buildings. Mr. Schenker helped start ABS in 1999, along with Earle S. Altman, the chairman, whom he met while working at Helmsley Spear in his first job out of college.

His resignation comes amid calls for universities to be more transparent about sexual harassment in their science departments, where women account for only one-quarter of senior faculty jobs.

headline: California: Los Angeles Charges Gas Company in Leak
abstract: Los Angeles prosecutors have filed criminal misdemeanor charges against Southern California Gas Company for failing to report a huge natural gas leak that began in October.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles prosecutors have filed criminal misdemeanor charges against an energy company for failing to immediately report a natural gas leak that began in October and has forced thousands from their homes.  The Southern California Gas Company, which owns the leaking well that has pumped tons of natural gas into the air for more than three months, was charged with three counts of failing to report the release of hazardous materials from Oct. 23 to Oct. 26, and one count of discharging air contaminants, from Oct. 23 to the present. The company could face fines of up to $25,000 a day for each day that state regulators were not notified about the leak. Fines of $1,000 per day could also be applied for the pollution violation. Jackie Lacey, the Los Angeles district attorney, said that a criminal conviction would help “prevent similar public health threats in the future." Also Tuesday, Attorney General Kamala Harris joined a long list of parties suing the utility company over the leak.

headline: Moving Freely, and Photographing, in Marseille
abstract: Joan Liftin’s images are guided not by storytelling, but by freedom and movement, a driving force from her early years as a dancer.
lead_paragraph: From rooftops to railroad tracks, Joan Liftin seemed to be walking — and looking — everywhere in Marseille. She could look up to see the sunshine washing over street art. Below her, a puddle reflects a man in a suit. Underground, passengers wait for the Metro. Though she insists “there are no stories” in photography,” the images in her new book, “Marseille,” reflect that freedom of movement, which is no surprise: Her artistic spirit comes from modern dance.

headline: Social Media: Destroyer or Creator?
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: A man who helped set off the 2011 Tahrir Square uprising in Egypt has drawn some conclusions about “Facebook revolutions.”
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years we’ve been treated to a number of “Facebook revolutions,” from the Arab Spring to Occupy Wall Street to the squares of Istanbul, Kiev and Hong Kong, all fueled by social media. But once the smoke cleared, most of these revolutions failed to build any sustainable new political order, in part because as so many voices got amplified, consensus-building became impossible.

headline: Fighting the Zika Virus
abstract: The World Health Organization was right to declare the mosquito-borne disease an international public health emergency.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization and its director general, Dr. Margaret Chan, were right to declare the Zika virus an international public health emergency, even if its suspected link to severe birth defects has not been proved. The mosquito-borne disease is a serious threat: It is usually so mild as to be undetectable in adults, yet as it has exploded across South and Central America it has been followed by a surge in babies born with underdeveloped heads, a condition called microcephaly.

lead_paragraph: The New York City Ballet dancer and choreographer Troy Schumacher, 29, has been with the company since 2005. As a choreographer, he is known for ballet-meets-fashion collaborations with designers such as Thom Browne, and the team Marta Marques and Paulo Almeida of Marques’Almeida. His work with the design duo, in the ballet ‘Common Ground,’ is featured this month at Lincoln Center for the ballet company’s winter season. He offered a peek inside his closet.

headline: In Ecuador, the Frugal Traveler Tries Luxury

lead_paragraph: I was not surprised when applause broke out as the pilot touched down at the Quito airport, high in the Ecuadorean Andes. In five and a half years as the Frugal Traveler columnist, I’ve learned that cheering a safe arrival is a standard (and lovable) practice in some parts of the world.

headline: Roger Goodell’s Unstoppable Football Machine
abstract: For all the revelations about its brutality, pro football is more popular and profitable than ever. How the N.F.L. commissioner and a group of billionaire owners have kept the league on offense.
lead_paragraph: Everywhere you go at the National Football League’s corporate headquarters in Manhattan, a Park Avenue enclave that feels both futuristic and retro at the same time, you encounter ‘‘the Shield.’’ The star-studded, upside-down nipple with a football floating on top adorns the front doors; it is painted on walls, carved into trophies, printed on napkins and mouse pads, inlaid in silver on a conference table, etched into cuff links and iced onto cookies. All employees receive a Lucite Shield at the beginning of the season. Security guards in the lobby wear tiny Shield pins. The Shield is sacrosanct. It is a symbol of almost mystical power, and its display seems to be governed by some Constitution-like power. It stands for big notions, like ‘‘Respect,’’ ‘‘Resilience,’’ ‘‘Integrity’’ and ‘‘Responsibility to Team.’’ These words greet you in big letters on the glass entrance door.

headline: Gay Congregation Celebrates Its Identity With New Home in Manhattan

headline: ‘Paradise Now: The Story of American Utopianism,’ by Chris Jennings
abstract: A look at five utopian communities in 19th-century America.
lead_paragraph: By any measure, Ann Lee, the illiterate daughter of a Manchester blacksmith, led one of the most audacious and improbable lives of the 18th century. Born in 1736, she came of age in the fetid, soul-destroying crucible of English industrialization. But in religion, Lee discovered her native boldness and charisma. She became a prophet and, in 1774, led a small band of followers across the Atlantic. They became known as Shakers. And from a mean cabin in upstate New York they formed a society that would draw thousands into communal villages across much of the United States. Lee did not live to survey her realm. But her social conscience — forged in the bleak shadow of the Manchester mills — animated Shaker communities well into the 20th century.

headline: ‘In Europe’s Shadow,’ by Robert D. Kaplan
abstract: Kaplan looks to Romania’s past, then to the changes of recent decades.
lead_paragraph: Some 35 years ago, Robert D. Kaplan embarked on what this book portrays as an enduring love affair. The object of his affection and fascination is not a person, but a country: Romania. It is an obsession that has led him to plunge into the surrounding Balkans, and farther afield to contemplate Europe in all its historic complexity.

headline: Should Doctors-in-Training Work Fewer Hours?
abstract: Hospital care is a 24-hour-a-day enterprise, but the question of which doctor should be there — and how long he or she should already have been there — is among the most controversial and unsettled in medicine.
lead_paragraph: How many hours should medical residents work?

headline: Obama, in Mosque Visit, Denounces Anti-Muslim Bias

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Wednesday embraced Muslims in the United States as part of “one American family” and implicitly criticized the Republican presidential candidates in a warning to citizens to not be “bystanders to bigotry.”

abstract: President Obama will meet with Muslim leaders near Baltimore and speak out against hostility and discrimination against Islam.
lead_paragraph: President Obama will make his first visit to a mosque in the United States on Wednesday, traveling to a suburb of Baltimore to meet with Muslim leaders and to speak out against hostility and discrimination against Islam.

headline: Poll Watch: After Iowa, Terrain Looks More Challenging for Ted Cruz
abstract: Ted Cruz’s success in the Iowa caucuses on Monday was a victory for the Republican base, if not for the party establishment. But New Hampshire is typically a state where broadly palatable, general-election-friendly candidates can stake their hopes.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz’s success in the Iowa caucuses on Monday was a victory for the Republican base, if not for the party establishment. Looking ahead to New Hampshire, the terrain will be quite different.

headline: Should a Man Have Told His Mother-in-Law That She Was Dying?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Families and Family Life', 'Death and Dying', 'Dementia', 'Ethics (Personal)']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to make difficult decisions as a parent dies and when to share family secrets.
lead_paragraph: My mother-in-law died recently of cancer. She was 88 and had a full and good life. She did not have full-blown dementia, but she had a hard time retaining information — much of what she heard she forgot almost immediately. She had four daughters who did not tell her about her terminal situation; they merely said she was sick, though she asked what was wrong with her. She had never been religious, but I know even atheists sometimes turn to God near death. What were her children’s ethical responsibilities here — and, since they decided not tell their mother the truth, should I have? Name Withheld

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Puppies (a.k.a. Imitation Infants)
abstract: The final word on sleeping with dogs.
lead_paragraph: Emma writes: My boyfriend and I have been together for three years, and we have an 8-month-old puppy. We can’t agree whether she should be allowed to sleep in our bed. I believe she is a warm and welcome presence, while he believes that she disrupts our sleep.

headline: Danny Meyer Thinks Tipping Is Socialist
abstract: The restaurateur on why waiters will appreciate his new gratuity system, and what politicians can learn about hospitality.
lead_paragraph: Your restaurant group has been in the news recently because it is phasing out tipping. When is the last time you left a tip? On Saturday night. At a restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Taxi Use Patterns Can Tell Us How Good the Super Bowl and Halftime Show Were
abstract: The more exciting the game, the less taxi usage during the fourth quarter and the larger the postgame spike.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s TV ratings or avocado consumption, we’re inundated with ways to quantify the annual extravagance that is the Super Bowl. I would like to suggest another avenue of analysis: publicly available New York City taxi data.

headline: Ken Stabler, a Magnetic N.F.L. Star, Was Sapped of Spirit by C.T.E.
abstract: Stabler, a former Raiders quarterback known for his charisma, had high Stage 3 chronic traumatic encephalopathy when he died at 69 in July, researchers said.
lead_paragraph: Shortly before he died in July, the former N.F.L. quarterback Ken Stabler was rushed away by doctors, desperate to save him, in a Mississippi hospital. His longtime partner followed the scrum to the elevator, holding his hand. She told him that she loved him. Stabler said that he loved her, too.

headline: Journalist Who Sought Refuge in Thailand Is Said to Return to China
keywords: ['Extraordinary Rendition', 'Political Prisoners', 'Freedom of the Press', 'News and News Media']

lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — In the crowded New Hampshire primary, no candidate may shape the direction of the Republican presidential campaign more than the man who finished sixth in Iowa: Jeb Bush.

keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: “We didn’t have much of a ground game because I didn’t think I was going to be winning,” Donald J. Trump said of his campaign’s voter targeting operation for the Iowa caucuses. “That’s why I’m so honored to have come in second.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump acknowledged on Tuesday night that his voter turnout operation in Iowa was weak, despite boasts from his team for weeks of a secret plan to get his supporters to the polls.

keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Home Repairs and Improvements', 'Shopping and Retail']

lead_paragraph: Almost four years ago, the home improvement retailer Lowe’s set off a political storm in Quebec with a hostile bid for Rona, a Canadian chain headquartered in that province.

headline: What O.J. Simpson Taught Me About Being Black
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Decisions and Verdicts', 'Discrimination']
abstract: I was dismayed when my fellow blacks cheered the verdict. But I now realize that police brutality and unequal justice are central to black identity.
lead_paragraph: It is easy to forget how beloved a celebrity O. J. Simpson was in his time — Heisman Trophy winner, N.F.L. superstar, Hollywood actor and pitchman supreme. Until he was arrested in the brutal slayings of his ex-wife Nicole Brown Simpson and her friend Ronald L. Goldman, after a televised police chase that transfixed the nation, he seemed to have transcended his roots in San Francisco housing projects.

The fight threatened to derail the first energy bill in a decade.

headline: Lord Lucan, Missing Since 1974 Murder, Is Declared Dead (Again)
abstract: A London court issued a death certificate for the aristocrat, who disappeared after the killing of his family’s nanny. The decision allows his son to inherit the title.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — It was a case that riveted the world: In 1974, a dashing British aristocrat and army officer, known for his prowess at backgammon and bridge and his fondness for vodka martinis, powerboats and Aston Martin cars, vanished after the bludgeoned body of his children’s nanny was found in the basement of his family’s house in the affluent Belgravia area of London.

headline: Ireland Dissolves Parliament and Schedules Election
abstract: Prime Minister Enda Kenny is widely expected to be re-elected in a vote scheduled for Feb. 26, but his party may fall short of a majority.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ireland’s prime minister, Enda Kenny, announced on Wednesday that Parliament would be dissolved and a general election held on Feb. 26.

headline: How Politics Has Poisoned Islam
abstract: Since its earliest days, Islam has been used as a tool in power struggles. It’s time for that to change.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — We Muslims like to believe that ours is “a religion of peace,” but today Islam looks more like a religion of conflict and bloodshed. From the civil wars in Syria, Iraq and Yemen to internal tensions in Lebanon and Bahrain, to the dangerous rivalry between Iran and Saudi Arabia, the Middle East is plagued by intra-Muslim strife that seems to go back to the ancient Sunni-Shiite rivalry.

headline: Railing Against Graft, a Georgian Leads Calls for a Cleanup in Ukraine
abstract: Mikheil Saakashvili, the former president of Georgia, is making a political comeback in Ukraine at the forefront of a movement to strip oligarchs of their power.
lead_paragraph: KHARKIV, Ukraine — It was supposed to be a routine cabinet meeting for Ukraine’s Western-backed government. The interior minister, Arsen B. Avakov, a banker and businessman, was reading a prepared speech about privatizing state assets.

headline: Bonnie Raitt, Lucinda Williams and Loretta Lynn Are Rocking On and On
abstract: With new albums this spring, three of the longest-reigning queens of American music continue to belt it out.
lead_paragraph: The music industry may worship youth, but according to Bonnie Raitt, ‘‘in the fringe of the business, ageism isn’t as much of a thing.’’ Both Raitt, 66, who has a new record, ‘‘Dig in Deep,’’ out this month, and Lucinda Williams, 63, have remained prolific, to critical acclaim, since they rose to fame in the ’80s. That ‘‘shouldn’t be unusual,’’ says Williams, ‘‘but it is.’’ She fields a lot of questions about her continued success: ‘‘Basically, what they’re saying is, how come you haven’t fizzled out?’’ In fact, Williams feels like she’s in the prime of her career, a theory borne out by her 12th studio album, ‘‘The Ghosts of Highway 20,’’ also out this month, on which her famously ragged voice is rougher and more compelling than ever. A major influence on both Raitt and Williams is Loretta Lynn, who at 83 is releasing ‘‘Full Circle,’’ her first album since her 2004 collaboration with Jack White, in March. ‘‘As long as I’m on this earth,’’ she said recently, ‘‘I will try to be on top somewhere.’’
