headline: 1916: Plot to Kill China’s Ruler
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A conspiracy against China’s leader is discovered in 1916.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A conspiracy against Yuan-Shih-Kai has been discovered by the Court spies. At its head are the President’s secretary and high officials, among them being two Ministers and the Master of Ceremonies of the dethroned dynasty. The conspirators proposed to surround the palace with troops, to kill Yuan-Shih-Kai, to re-establish the Republic and to transmit the power to agents of the Yun-Nan Government, who have arrived in the capital. Five hundred persons, of whom many are well known, have been flung into prison. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 4, 1916

headline: G.M. Posts Record Profit of $9.7 Billion for 2015
abstract: The company said that its results in North America were the driving force behind its performance.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With American consumers buying new vehicles in record numbers, General Motors is raking in big profits and promising even better earnings in 2016. G.M., the nation’s largest automaker, said on Wednesday that it earned a profit of $9.7 billion in 2015 primarily because of its strong performance in its core North American market.

headline: Rand Paul Drops Out of Presidential Race
abstract: Some of Rand Paul’s crucial issues as a senator failed to animate donors and voters as he had expected.
lead_paragraph: Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky ended his presidential campaign Wednesday, after a disappointing fifth-place finish in the Iowa caucuses this week.

headline: Zegna Confirms Stefano Pilati’s Departure
abstract: The head of design for Ermenegildo Zegna Couture is the fourth designer in the past year to leave a job after only approximately three years.
lead_paragraph: The Milanese men’s wear brand Ermenegildo Zegna announced on Wednesday that it was parting ways with Stefano Pilati, the head of design for Ermenegildo Zegna Couture, confirming rumors that had been swirling since Monday and making it the third Italian men’s house to lose its designer in a week. The departure was characterized as being by mutual agreement.

headline: A Beachfront Home on Barbados

lead_paragraph: On the island’s west coast, the house, with three bedrooms and three and a half baths, is on the market for $3.5 million.

headline: Daily Report: Yahoo’s Multipronged Turnaround Strategy
abstract: Yahoo is opening itself up to all options — spinoff, sale, a simplification of its operations — in its quest to right itself.
lead_paragraph: For Yahoo, there is no simple way out of its current woes. So Yahoo’s solution is to look at all options.

headline: China Resists Harshly Punishing Those Responsible for Wrongful Convictions
abstract: While officials have become more transparent about such cases, punishment for those accused of falsifying evidence and using coercive techniques is often lax.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For two decades, Shang Aiyun waited for the day when the people responsible for convicting and executing her teenage son for a murder he did not commit would be held to account.

headline: Baghdad Hosts a ‘Marathon’ and Celebrates a Victory
abstract: Nearly 2,000 runners took part in the Baghdad International Marathon, the first one in as long as anyone could remember in the troubled Iraqi capital.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Naji Abdulamir used to run all over Baghdad but preferred the farmlands along the banks of the Tigris. Karim Aboud once ran for Saddam Hussein and has the gold watch and the newspaper clippings to prove it. Falih Naji ran for Iraq at a competition in India in 1982, and recalled, “There was no higher honor than representing your country.”

headline: Silencing Noisy Web Pages
abstract: The latest edition of the Safari browser makes it easy to mute unwanted audio blaring from open tabs.
lead_paragraph: Q. I often listen to music when browsing the web on my Mac but get annoyed when Safari starts blaring an advertisement or some other video — especially in another browser tab. Can I turn off the audio for just the browser?

headline: Dropbox May Not Be LeBron James, but It Is Still in the Game
abstract: As the markets for funding tech start-ups cool, companies like Dropbox, which once had a $10 billion valuation, are confronting their outsize dreams of yesteryear.
lead_paragraph: There are no obvious signs of distress at the lavish San Francisco headquarters of the cloud storage company Dropbox, where on any given day, its hallways bustle with upbeat, well-compensated tech workers enjoying the customary trappings of start-up life. Dropbox is not laying off workers or shrinking; it hired nearly 500 people last year, 75 since the start of this year, and it plans to soon move into a sprawling, custom-designed office building for which it has signed a long-term lease.

headline: In ChemChina’s Bid for Syngenta, One Adviser Stands Out
abstract: Gordon Dyal, an adviser on the blockbuster merger, is the latest star deal maker who landed a plum assignment independently of a former employer.
lead_paragraph: The China National Chemical Corporation’s $43 billion bid to buy Syngenta is enormous by many measures. But one of the lead advisers who helped put the deal together is just a one-man shop.

headline: Gambling on O’Neill: Forest Whitaker Makes His Broadway Debut in ‘Hughie’
abstract: The film and television actor stars in a storied one-act play at the Booth Theater, playing a down-on-his-luck gambler in 1928 Times Square.
lead_paragraph: The moment Forest Whitaker steps onto 42nd Street, the shouting begins.

headline: Maastricht Art Fair Widens Its Reach, to New York
abstract: Tefaf’s New York venture — essentially two new boutique shows — is an audacious move at a time when New York’s calendar has never been more crowded with high-end fairs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tefaf Maastricht, Europe’s biggest and most prestigious fair devoted to art, antiques and design, is expanding into New York.

headline: Below the Line: Editing ‘The Big Short’
abstract: Hank Corwin actually aimed for imperfect cuts as a way to help audiences connect emotionally with Adam McKay’s financial drama.
lead_paragraph: Energetic in its pacing and rule-breaking in its style, “The Big Short” keeps viewers on their toes. Characters break the fourth wall and stock footage is mixed with more traditional scenes to tell the story of the housing collapse, a drama both tragic and darkly funny. To assemble these ideas into a cohesive whole, the director Adam McKay brought in the editor Hank Corwin, who had worked with Oliver Stone and Terrence Malick.

headline: Whoopi Goldberg and Nathan Lane on Roster for Solo ‘White Rabbit Red Rabbit’ Performances
abstract: Several prominent New York actors will perform “White Rabbit Red Rabbit” unrehearsed and alone.
lead_paragraph: Several prominent New York actors have signed on to take part in an unusual theatrical exercise in which they will each separately perform the same unrehearsed play before a live audience over a series of weeks, without the benefit of either a director or a set.

headline: Letters From the White Terror
abstract: The following are excerpts of letters discovered in recent years written by prisoners of Taiwan’s political repression known as the White Terror. The prisoners were allowed to write letters to their families before they were executed.
lead_paragraph: The following are excerpts of letters discovered in recent years written by prisoners of Taiwan’s political repression known as the White Terror. The prisoners were allowed to write letters to their families before they were executed.

headline: 1941: A Crime Wave Hits Shanghai
keywords: ['ARSON', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Shanghai suffers from a wave of arson and murder in 1941.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Murder, arson, bombings and a double kidnapping occurred in Shanghai during the early morning hours today [Feb. 3]. A Chinese newspaper editor was assassinated, an attempt was made to burn a platform at the scene of a scheduled taxpayers’ meeting, grenades were thrown at two court buildings and an accountant and bookkeeper of The American Trading Company were abducted. The arson occurred at 3 a.m. when two Japanese drove a stolen taxicab to the speakers’ platform at the International Race Course, soaked the car in gasoline and set it afire. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 4, 1941

headline: Georgia’s Oldest Death Row Inmate Is Executed
abstract: Brandon Astor Jones, 72, was put to death for a 1979 murder after the United States Supreme Court declined to grant a stay of the execution.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s oldest death row inmate was executed early Wednesday after the United States Supreme Court declined to grant a stay of execution.

headline: New York Philharmonic Announces Its 175th-Anniversary Season
abstract: The Alan Gilbert era of the Philharmonic will draw to a close with a blaze of new music, intriguing juxtapositions and a semi-staged opera.
lead_paragraph: The Alan Gilbert era of the New York Philharmonic will draw to a close next season with a blaze of new music (seven premieres), intriguing juxtapositions (Schoenberg’s shattering “A Survivor From Warsaw” and Beethoven’s Ninth) and several other nods to hallmarks of his tenure as music director, including one last semi-staged opera: Wagner’s “Das Rheingold.”

headline: Taiwan Families Receive Goodbye Letters Decades After Executions
abstract: Letters from victims of political repression, uncovered in the past decade, offer comfort to relatives and a glimpse of Taiwan’s buried history.
lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — The month before he was executed, in April 1952, Guo Ching wrote letters to his mother, wife and children to say goodbye.

headline: Wells Fargo to Pay $1.2 Billion in Mortgage Settlement
abstract: The bank has been in talks with the government since 2012 over claims that it improperly classified some F.H.A. loans as qualifying for federal insurance.
lead_paragraph: Wells Fargo has agreed to pay $1.2 billion to put to rest claims that it engaged in reckless lending under a Federal Housing Administration program that left a government insurance fund to clean up the mess.

headline: Aspirin May Protect Against Staph Blood Infections
abstract: Taking a daily low-dose aspirin has been shown to protect against dying from a Staphylococcus aureus blood infection.
lead_paragraph: Taking a daily low-dose aspirin has been shown to reduce the risk for heart attack and stroke, and possibly the risk for certain cancers. Now researchers have found another possible benefit: protection against dying from a Staphylococcus aureus blood infection.

headline: David G. Hartwell, Literary-Minded Editor of Science Fiction, Dies at 74
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Science Fiction', 'Books and Literature', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: Mr. Hartwell brought a literary sensibility to genres like horror, fantasy and science fiction, working with authors like Frank Herbert and Philip K. Dick.
lead_paragraph: David G. Hartwell, an editor who brought a literary sensibility to genres like horror, fantasy and science fiction, working with Frank Herbert, Philip K. Dick and other notable authors, has died. He was 74.

headline: Great Midweek Recipes
abstract: For tonight, a no-recipe pasta dish. For the rest of the week, try spicy chicken wings, stir-fried green beans, roasted salmon and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Jacob Zuma, South African Leader, to Repay Part of Money Spent on His Home
abstract: The president has been dogged by reports about $23 million in public funds used to make extensive upgrades to his homestead.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The South African president, Jacob Zuma, agreed on Wednesday to repay the government part of the $23 million in public funds that were spent on lavish improvements to his home, in an attempt to defuse a controversy that has dogged his administration and the governing party, the African National Congress.

headline: A Liquor License Workaround: Fermented, Not Distilled
abstract: Restaurants and bars are serving up lower-alcohol substitutes to work around restrictive local laws or take advantage of their loopholes.
lead_paragraph: The cocktail menu at Chillbar, a brunch restaurant in Hollywood, Fla., has an extensive selection of drinks incorporating vodka, rum and tequila, including the best-selling Empress Chilltini, a martini-like concoction involving elderflower, lychee, basil and a generous slug of booze. What all of Chillbar’s drinks lack, though, are actual distilled spirits.

headline: Youth Tackle Program Is Being Eliminated in a Football Hotbed
abstract: Amid financial and safety concerns, the Boys & Girls Club of Marshall, Tex., voted to end its tackle program; the club will expand its popular flag football program.
lead_paragraph: There will be less tackle football in Marshall, Tex., once a football hotbed that competed for high school state championships, produced N.F.L. players like Y.A. Tittle and appeared in the book “Friday Night Lights.”

headline: What Anna Stubblefield Believed She Was Doing
abstract: Her letter to a judge answers some questions — and raises others.
lead_paragraph: In late December, Anna Stubblefield — a former chairwoman of the philosophy department at Rutgers University in Newark, mother of two and fervent activist for social justice — sat down to write a letter on narrow-ruled, legal-size paper. “Your Honor,” she began, “I write to ask for your mercy.”

headline: Bernie Sanders Says Yes to Debate With Hillary Clinton on Thursday Night
abstract: “You know that I have always wanted more debates, and Secretary Clinton in the beginning was not so interested in more debates,” Senator Bernie Sanders said. Thursday’s debate in Durham, N.H., will be hosted by MSNBC.
lead_paragraph: After some deliberation, Senator Bernie Sanders has agreed to face Hillary Clinton in an additional debate on Thursday night.

headline: An Expanding Universe of Space Apps
keywords: ['Mobile Applications', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Stars and Galaxies', 'Earth', 'Planets', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Photography']
abstract: While becoming an astronaut is out of reach for most of us, there are plenty of apps that can take your mind on a journey to the final frontier.
lead_paragraph: FROM the reusable rockets by SpaceX to the stunning photos of dim and distant Pluto, space is all over the news. While becoming an astronaut is out of reach for most of us, there are plenty of apps that can take your mind on a journey to the final frontier.

headline: Robert Durst Pleads Guilty in Gun Case, Setting Up Possible Murder Trial
abstract: The plea by Mr. Durst, the estranged scion of a New York City real estate family, allows him to be transferred to Los Angeles to face charges that he murdered a friend, Susan Berman.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Durst’s luck may be running out.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Cast Will Perform at the Grammys, via Satellite
abstract: Musical theater will return to the Grammy Awards for the first time since 2010.
lead_paragraph: In the latest trickle of news from the Grammy Awards, the organizers of the awards show announced on Wednesday that the cast of “Hamilton” will perform a number on the broadcast, live via satellite from the Richard Rodgers Theater in New York.

headline: How to Watch the Super Bowl When You Don’t Have Cable
keywords: ['Super Bowl', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Football']
abstract: A variety of easy — and legitimate — ways are now available for watching the biggest football game of the year.
lead_paragraph: THIS Super Bowl weekend, you can focus on making nachos and Buffalo wings and worry less about how to watch the big game. There will be more methods and devices than ever before to watch the Broncos and Panthers without cable — all headache-free, no sketchy workarounds required.

abstract: Mr. Varvatos’ fall looks.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Varvatos’ fall looks.

headline: Record Number of False Convictions Overturned in 2015
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A total of 149 defendants were cleared last year, 10 more than in 2014, according to a review by the National Registry of Exonerations.
lead_paragraph: A record 149 people in the United States were found in 2015 to have been falsely convicted of a crime, and of those, nearly four in 10 were exonerated of murder, according to a report released on Wednesday.

headline: Andrew Garfield to Star in ‘Angels in America’ at National Theater in London
abstract: The National Theater’s productions for coming seasons include “Angels in America” starring Andrew Garfield.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The National Theater here scrapped the tradition of announcing a single season at a time on Wednesday, naming an ambitious slate of productions that will run there through 2018.

headline: Bob Elliott, Half of the Deadpan Bob and Ray Comedy Team, Dies at 92
abstract: The comedian and his partner, Ray Goulding, specialized in low-key humor that debunked gasbags.
lead_paragraph: Bob Elliott, who as half of the comedy team Bob and Ray purveyed a distinctively low-key brand of humor on radio and television for more than 40 years, died on Tuesday at his home in Cundy’s Harbor, Me. He was 92.

headline: Hearty Sandwiches Are Dublin’s Answer to a Recession
abstract: A once-strapped economy coupled with a desire to dine out gives rise to less expensive but still creative options.
lead_paragraph: Most of the time, narrow Montague Street, a few blocks south of magnificent St. Stephen’s Green in Dublin, functions as a nondescript passage, allowing pedestrians a quick jaunt from the handsome red-brick Georgian townhouses of Harcourt Street to the motley restaurants and bars of Camden Street. But during the weekday lunchtime rush, the tiny brick-paved lane becomes a destination unto itself.

headline: How Not to Stop Bank Wrongdoing
keywords: ['Attorneys General', 'High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Securities and Commodities Violations']
abstract: Two banks will pay penalties in “dark pool” cases, but no individuals have been charged.
lead_paragraph: Another day, another legal settlement over bank wrongdoing that — we are asked to believe — occurred without any human being breaking the law.

headline: Review: In ‘Better Living Through Criticism,’ A.O. Scott Defends His Job
abstract: Mr. Scott, a chief film critic at The New York Times, tells how critics consider and conclude when it comes to the arts.

headline: Pussy Riot Video Mocks Russian Prosecutor Accused of Corruption
abstract: The Russian punk protest group sashayed back into the public debate with a sly rap video about corruption in the office of Prosecutor General Yuri Y. Chaika.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Wearing police uniforms and fishnet stockings, they whip hooded prisoners and waterboard them in their prison cells. The well-made-up women gleefully throw wads of cash into the air and flirt viciously with their viewers.

headline: German Cabinet Approves Measures Tightening Asylum Rules
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Sex Crimes', 'Law and Legislation', 'International Relations']
abstract: The measures, expected to be passed by Parliament, included a two-year ban on family reunifications and the exclusion of three North African countries from the asylum list.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The German cabinet took significant steps on Wednesday toward toughening asylum rules in the wake of the Cologne assaults, approving among other measures a two-year ban on family reunifications and excluding three North African countries from its asylum list.

headline: Cheap Oil Isn’t a Threat
abstract: The Natural Resources Defense Council writes that today’s low oil prices “pose little risk to the continued rapid scale-up of clean energy.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The World’s Most Dedicated All-Natural Perfumer
abstract: For Mandy Aftel, who creates custom scents with valuable and esoterically sourced materials, the ultimate luxury is a fleeting fragrance for one.
lead_paragraph: ‘‘OUR TIME IS MORE impoverished, aromatically, than it’s ever been in the past,’’ Mandy Aftel told me last April. We were sitting beneath a fig tree in her Berkeley backyard, at the edge of a rose garden whose flowers had been chosen specifically for their pungent fragrances. The obscenely vibrant blossoms spread to the edge of the property, stopping only at the fence that separates her yard from Chez Panisse, the famous California-cuisine-catalyzing restaurant. Aftel, 67, was sneezing a bit and struggling to speak through snags of dryness in her throat. ‘‘It makes me sad,’’ she said, referring to her spring cold. ‘‘I feel like I’m missing out on a lot of stuff.’’

headline: Editas Medicine and BeiGene Gain in Market Debuts
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering']
abstract: The two biotech companies’ initial public offerings are testing the waters after a recent sell-off in biotech.
lead_paragraph: After a volatile stock market kept initial public offerings of stock on the sidelines in January, two biotech companies are braving the waters.

headline: Souping Is the New Juicing
abstract: Soup cleanses promise an easier detox than a juice cleanse.
lead_paragraph: For the last few weeks, Vivienne Zhao, an investment banker who lives and works in Manhattan, has spent each Monday on a cleanse, consuming over the course of the day five liquid-based meals delivered in single-serve plastic containers.

headline: Surge of Zika Virus Has Brazilians Re-examining Strict Abortion Laws
abstract: Abortion rights activists are seizing on the crisis to push back against conservative lawmakers who want to toughen already stringent limits.
lead_paragraph: RECIFE, Brazil — The surging medical reports of babies being born with unusually small heads during the Zika epidemic in Brazil are igniting a fierce debate over the country’s abortion laws, which make the procedure illegal under most circumstances.

headline: Perry Ellis: Fall 2016
abstract: Fall designs from the label’s creative director Michael Maccari.
lead_paragraph: Fall designs from the label’s creative director Michael Maccari.

headline: Half A Loaf, Financial Reform Edition
abstract: Dodd-Frank is better than you think.
lead_paragraph: A lot of the debate over the Sanders insurgency hinges on whether you see Obama-era reforms as trivial, utterly inadequate to the problems, or as a half loaf that’s a lot better than none. (It also hinges on whether you believe that a Sanders candidacy could mobilize vast untapped wells of progressive sentiment, or whether you believe that he would be hit with a smear campaign like nothing you’ve seen before — except for what has already happened to Hillary Clinton, and is baked into her polling. You can guess what I think.)

headline: Top Chef Gave No Hint of Distress Before Apparent Suicide
abstract: Just days before he was found dead in his Swiss home, Benoît Violier expressed misgivings to a French newspaper but little more.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Just days before the star French-Swiss chef Benoît Violier was found dead at his home in Switzerland, after apparently shooting himself with his own gun, the soft-spoken 44-year-old chef gave little hint that he was troubled in his last interview.

headline: The Temptation of Co-Working Spaces
abstract: The number of such spaces has multiplied in recent years, especially in the Los Angeles area, where each profession and neighborhood seems to have its own.
lead_paragraph: Technology has upended where we work. The line between work and play has been blurred, and the difference between the office and home has all but disappeared.

headline: Scandinavian Style Comes to London
abstract: Our Legacy, a fashion label that offers good bang for the buck, opens a small shopping oasis on a side street in Soho. New York may be next.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish are coming! The Swedish are coming!

headline: Ted Cruz Finds Some Common Ground With Bernie Sanders
abstract: At a town-hall-style event in New Hampshire, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas identified Bernie Sanders as an unlikely kindred spirit while describing the failings of a “corrupt” Washington.
lead_paragraph: HENNIKER, N.H. — Ted Cruz is feeling the Bern. Sort of.

headline: When Donald Trump Doesn’t Win
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: His post-Iowa Twitter outbursts show what happens when he doesn’t get his way.
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible to predict when Donald Trump’s supporters will finally have enough of his bombast and bigotry, or when (if ever) he will decide to cancel the 2015-16 season of his reality-show campaign and go home. But if he does, we are getting a pretty good idea of how it will happen – with an epic outburst of petulance.

headline: On National Signing Day, College Football Recruits Have Starring Roles in a Carnival
abstract: Michigan, which put on a carefully orchestrated production featuring Derek Jeter and Tom Brady, claimed the commitment of Rashan Gary, the country’s top-ranked recruit.
lead_paragraph: Derek Jeter and Tom Brady showed up as promised in Ann Arbor, Mich. Wolverines Coach Jim Harbaugh, a onetime Michigan quarterback, tossed footballs into the crowd seated in a campus auditorium. Jim Leyland, the former Detroit Tigers manager, appeared onstage with the hip-hop group Migos. Did they dab? Dab they did.

headline: Verbatim: Chris Christie Foresees an Easy Time With Hillary Clinton
abstract: “I’ll beat her rear end on that stage and you know what? After I do, she’ll be relieved because she’ll just be worried I was going to serve her with a subpoena.” – Gov. Chris Christie, discussing Hillary Clinton at a campaign event in Lebanon, N.H.
lead_paragraph: – Gov. Chris Christie, discussing Hillary Clinton at a campaign event in Lebanon, N.H., on what will happen if the two become their parties’ nominees and debate each other.

headline: How El Salvador Acted Against the Zika Virus
abstract: El Salvador’s vice minister for health explains why his country advised women against becoming pregnant.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tara Parker-Pope: Living Well
abstract: The Times’s Well editor, Tara Parker-Pope, will discuss reinvention and health.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Times Insider Events — live programming for Times Insiders and their guests.

headline: Financing ChemChina’s Bold Play for Syngenta
abstract: The deal will call for a huge financing package both in Switzerland, where Syngenta is based, and in China.
lead_paragraph: Never mind Frankenfoods: The China National Chemical Corporation’s takeover of Syngenta will need Frankenfinancing.

headline: Bernie Sanders Cancels Rally Before Nighttime TV Appearance
abstract: Bernie Sanders’s campaign said he was canceling a rally Wednesday to give him more time to prepare for a town hall-style event on CNN later at night.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont canceled an event he had scheduled Wednesday before a televised town-hall-style event later at night.

headline: The Explorers Club Once Served Mammoth at a Meal. Or Did It?
keywords: ['Mammoths (Animals)', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)', 'Sloths (Animals)', 'Turtles and Tortoises', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Exploration and Explorers']
abstract: At a legendary dinner in 1951, the Explorers Club was said to have served its members mammoth, but DNA tests have revealed what the meat really was.
lead_paragraph: The story of the 1951 annual Explorers Club dinner is famous, at least among explorers, paleontologists and connoisseurs of exotic cuisine. In brief, mammoth was served.

headline: Understanding Zika
abstract: How dangerous is the virus and who is most at risk?
lead_paragraph: How dangerous is the virus and who is most at risk?

headline: Is Shame an Antidote to Addiction?
abstract: Doctors and a health writer take issue with a Sunday Review article calling for shame as a weapon in fighting addiction.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ramones Retrospective Coming to Queens Museum
abstract: The exhibition “Hey! Ho! Let’s Go: Ramones and the Birth of Punk” will examine the group’s influence on music and art.
lead_paragraph: As the Beatles are to Liverpool and Bruce Springsteen to Asbury Park, N.J., so are the Ramones to Queens, the polyglot New York borough that nurtured John William Cummings, Thomas Erdelyi, Douglas Glenn Colvin and Jeffrey Ross Hyman — otherwise known as Johnny, Tommy, Dee Dee and Joey Ramone, pioneers of the two-minute poppy punk song.

headline: Syria Talks Are Suspended
abstract: The United Nations mediator, Staffan de Mistura, announced that he was halting the talks until Feb. 25 because of a lack of progress.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations on Wednesday temporarily suspended the fledgling talks aimed at ending the war in Syria and called on the countries fueling the conflict to do more to yield results, as Syrian government forces sharply escalated an offensive on a strategic rebel-held city.

headline: Hillary Clinton Adopts ‘Fighter’ Theme in a Tough New Hampshire Battle
abstract: With a hard battle ahead in the New Hampshire primary, Hillary Clinton is using the “fight” theme as a central part of her campaign’s messaging.
lead_paragraph: DERRY, N.H. — The signs read, “Fighting for Us.” The new theme song is “Fight Song.” The documentary video shown at the beginning of her events is titled “Fighter.”

headline: After Iowa, Readers Debate Who Won and Who Lost
abstract: Times readers took to comments to unpack the outcome of the Iowa caucuses.
lead_paragraph: Lela Moore is a news assistant on The Times’s Community Desk.

headline: Index Ventures Closes on $550 Million Investment Fund
abstract: The fund is earmarked for early-stage investments in start-ups, part of the venture capital firm’s longer-term investment strategy.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The landscape for Silicon Valley may have become rockier over the last several months. But that has not stopped venture capital firms from raising new money to pour into start-ups.

headline: Move Up New York’s Primary
abstract: A New Yorker objects that since the state’s primary isn’t until April, “we are usually ignored by presidential candidates.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: France Seeks to Extend State of Emergency Despite Protests
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Search and Seizure', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The French government confirmed Wednesday that it would seek a second three-month extension of the state of emergency declared after the Paris attacks in November.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Despite widespread protests across the country in recent days, the French government confirmed on Wednesday that it would seek a three-month extension of the state of emergency it declared after the attacks in and around Paris that left 130 people dead in November.

headline: Court Ruling on Juveniles
abstract: A psychiatrist writes that the Supreme Court has again acknowledged that “children are not just little adults.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: A reader writes that special interests that push for laws limiting policy innovation at the local level contradict the framers’ intentions.

headline: Donald Trump Says Ted Cruz Stole Victory in Iowa Caucuses
abstract: After hinting at it for a day, Donald J. Trump on Wednesday bluntly accused Senator Ted Cruz of “stealing” his Iowa caucuses victory and demanded a do-over.
lead_paragraph: After hinting at it for a day, Donald J. Trump on Wednesday bluntly accused Senator Ted Cruz of “stealing” victory in the Iowa caucuses and demanded a do-over.

headline: Facts & Figures: America’s Voting Population Is More Diverse Than Ever
abstract: Thirty-one percent of those eligible to vote in November will be minorities, compared to 29 percent in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Eligible voters in the United States are a more diverse group than ever before, according to the Pew Research Center. Thirty-one percent of those eligible to vote this November will be members of a racial or ethnic minority group, compared to 29 percent in 2012.

headline: Brooklyn Gang Indictment
abstract: Eighteen reputed members of a subset of the Folk Nation gang called No Love City, based in Flatbush, Brooklyn, were responsible for a “wave of terror,” the Brooklyn district attorney said.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen reputed members of a subset of the Folk Nation gang called No Love City, based in Flatbush, Brooklyn, were responsible for a “wave of terror,” the Brooklyn district attorney said.

headline: The View From the Back Row in Paris
abstract: A neophyte witnesses the greatest spectacle in fashion — not just on Twitter and Instagram, but in person
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Photographers and film crews immediately swarmed a car as it glided in front of Place Vendôme on a Sunday night in late January, jostling to capture the beauty who stepped out. Bystanders craned to get a glimpse of a woman wearing a bright orange dress, cunningly engineered with provocative cutouts and bound with matching thin ropes, pulleys really, covering a few key bits. The word filtered through to the back of the hive that it was Rita Ora, the British pop star and fashion-show mainstay, and, crucially, someone clearly committed to working a dress.

headline: Brooklyn College Games Seem Like Family Outings (Because They Are)
abstract: Egzon and Pajtim Gjonbalaj play basketball for Brooklyn College, as did another brother and cousin, but the family’s presence extends well into the stands.
lead_paragraph: Since November, the Gjonbalaj family of Brooklyn has had at least a dozen reunions. Nearly all of them have taken place in New York City basketball gyms.

headline: Fashion Magazines Look to Familiar Faces for Cover Models
abstract: Celebrities like Taraji P. Henson and Reese Witherspoon can be seen on the front of a variety of publications in a year.
lead_paragraph: If you missed Taraji P. Henson on the cover of the February issue of Elle, don’t despair. You can sift through the stacks at the nail salon and find her on the cover of Allure, from last July. Or on the August cover of W. Or Glamour (October). Or Essence (November).

headline: Amit Singhal, an Influential Engineer at Google, Will Retire
abstract: Mr. Singhal, one of the earliest builders of Google’s computer system, said he would leave the parent company, Alphabet, on Feb. 26.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alphabet, the parent of Google, is losing one of its most influential engineers, but his successor’s background is indicative of how important artificial intelligence technology is becoming to the Silicon Valley company.

headline: Review: ‘The Most Incredible Thing’ Brings Hans Christian Andersen’s Fairy Tale to Life
abstract: The choreographer Justin Peck tells the story of a Creator aiming to win over a Princess by presenting her a clock that performs a marvel on each of the 12 hours.
lead_paragraph: In Hans Christian Andersen’s “The Most Incredible Thing” (1870), the usually impressive choreographer Justin Peck has chosen a story whose details he can’t tell clearly and whose overall point he makes hackneyed. Ingenuity shines forth here and there; and Mr. Peck occasionally reveals new aspects of skill. But this 43-minute piece proves a damp squib. Its many dances seem not central but peripheral.

headline: Rick Santorum Plans Announcement on His Candidacy
abstract: Former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania plans an announcement later Wednesday about his candidacy amid speculation that he is pulling out of the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: Former Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania plans two major announcements on Wednesday night about his candidacy amid speculation that he is pulling out of the race.

headline: Six Steps to Curb Materialism in Your Kids
abstract: A program helped teenagers learn to distinguish wants from needs.
lead_paragraph: Children are ever-changing beings, but when it comes to money and materialism, too many parents think that their older offspring are not malleable at all.

headline: 18 Gang Members, Accused of Terrorizing Brooklyn, Are Indicted
abstract: District Attorney Ken Thompson said the suspects, facing charges that include murder, were responsible for a wave of violence.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen members of a street gang responsible for a “wave of terror” in Brooklyn have been charged with violent crimes in a 76-count indictment, law enforcement officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Drone Captures View of a Devastated Syrian City
abstract: A video taken by a drone winding its way through the battered city of Homs contains haunting images of the destruction after five years of civil war.
lead_paragraph: A video taken by a drone winding its way through the battered city of Homs, Syria, has captured haunting images of the virtually complete destruction after five years of civil war.

headline: The Five Stages of Donald Trump’s Grief Over His Loss in Iowa
abstract: The billionaire businessman initially struck a magnanimous tone after losing the Iowa caucuses on Monday night. It didn’t last long.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is grieving.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger: Fall 2016
abstract: Mr. Hilfiger’s latest looks.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Hilfiger’s latest looks.

lead_paragraph: How about one of these days some fashion maverick makes a radically ironic move — sends out, say, a Lawrence Welk collection shown on models sporting toupees?

headline: Donald Trump Takes a Positive View of America in New Ad
abstract: Mr. Trump ditches talk of the dire state of America in favor of a more positive message in an ad featuring a diverse set of supporters embracing his plan to “Make America Great Again.”
lead_paragraph: Still licking his wounds from losing the Iowa caucuses, Donald J. Trump is rolling out a new advertisement that ditches his gloom and doom about the dire state of America in favor of a more positive message.

keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Immigration Detention', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'International Relations']

lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — The United Nations strongly rebuked Australia over its human rights record after the highest court here ruled on Wednesday against a challenge to Australia’s immigration policies.

headline: The Look: Kristen Wiig’s Sparkling Geometric Dress
abstract: The actress wore a Rosie Assoulin look encrusted with Swarovski crystals to last night’s “Zoolander 2” premiere.

headline: Bomb Suspected in Deadly Explosion on Somali Jet
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: The blast above the plane’s right wing on Tuesday sucked one passenger out, killing him, and injured two others. Shabab militants are suspected.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — American officials said Wednesday that an explosion on a Somali jetliner that punched a three-foot hole through its fuselage in midair and killed one passenger was most likely caused by a bomb.

headline: Review: In Gabriel Kahane’s ‘The Fiction Issue,’ Timelessness and Sept. 11
abstract: Mr. Kahane’s new album, with Brooklyn Rider, shows off his sophisticated breadth of style and reflects on collective tragedy.
lead_paragraph: “The Fiction Issue”

headline: A Way to Lock Lost Debit Cards, From a Big Bank
abstract: Bank of America is one of the first large national banks to offer the security feature, which works with a mobile phone.
lead_paragraph: Almost everyone with a bank account has encountered this situation: You return home after shopping, or dining out, and discover that your debit card is missing.

headline: Review: ‘Animals,’ an Animated Comedy From the Duplass Brothers
abstract: This HBO series imagines New York City’s critters — pigeons and bugs, police horses and alley cats — as neurotic hipsters.
lead_paragraph: Pizza Rat: great New Yorker or greatest New Yorker? Last September, the Internet embraced a video clip of a rat dragging the city’s finest populist comestible down a subway staircase. It was hilarious and disgusting, but for city folk, the identification went deeper. Here was a fellow prole, having battled New York City for an absurdly large prize, humping it home like a weary commuter. Pizza Rat was us.

headline: Bad Loans in China
abstract: Some analysts estimate that China’s troubled credit could exceed $5 trillion.
lead_paragraph: Some analysts estimate that China’s troubled credit could exceed $5 trillion.

abstract: Cadet’s fall show.
lead_paragraph: Cadet’s fall show.

headline: Toxic Loans Around the World Weigh on Global Growth
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: Bad debts have been a drag on economic activity ever since the financial crisis of 2008, but the threat appears to be rising, and China is the biggest source of worry.
lead_paragraph: Beneath the surface of the global financial system lurks a multitrillion-dollar problem that could sap the strength of large economies for years to come.

headline: Justin Peck’s “The Most Incredible Thing”
abstract: The choreographer’s new ballet was created in tandem with the artist Marcel Dzama and the composer Bryce Dessner.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer’s new ballet was created in tandem with the artist Marcel Dzama and the composer Bryce Dessner.

headline: Martin Shkreli Appears to Adopt a New Legal Strategy: Silence
abstract: Mr. Shkreli’s new defense lawyer, Benjamin Brafman, said he had advised his client, who faces securities fraud charges, to stop talking to the media and posting on Twitter.
lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli was back in federal court on Wednesday, and for a change the brash New York businessman, who is facing securities fraud charges, had little to say.

headline: Behind the Scenes at This Season’s Most-Talked-About New Ballet
abstract: “The Most Incredible Thing,” which premiered last night, was created by the wunderkind choreographer Justin Peck along with Marcel Dzama and Bryce Dessner.
lead_paragraph: Last night, backstage at Lincoln Center, an anthropomorphic “deadly sin” in a handmade horned wig competed for mirror space with a monk. It was the world premiere of Justin Peck’s first-ever narrative ballet, “The Most Incredible Thing,” a gorgeous and undulating adaptation of a short story by Hans Christian Andersen.

headline: So Long, Bloomingdale’s: A Man of Style Strikes Out on His Own
abstract: Josh Peskowitz, a street photographers’ favorite, is opening his own men’s wear store near Beverly Hills. “I’m putting myself on the line,” he said.
lead_paragraph: The gentleman in the vintage Japanese noragi work shirt and unstructured pinstriped suit, the one likely to be ringed with Mongolian prayer beads, is attracting attention, again.

headline: Fordham Prep Rattled by 2 Students’ Suicides
abstract: The all-boys Jesuit high school in the Bronx has marshaled resources to provide counseling to students and reassurance to parents after the teenagers jumped in front of trains.
lead_paragraph: Fordham Preparatory School, the all-boys Jesuit high school in the Bronx, has been stunned and shaken in recent weeks, as not one but two students have killed themselves, both by jumping in front of trains.

headline: Sumner Redstone Steps Down as CBS Chairman, Replaced by Leslie Moonves
abstract: A lawsuit challenging Mr. Redstone’s mental competence had raised questions among analysts and investors about his suitability for the job.
lead_paragraph: The 92-year-old media mogul Sumner M. Redstone has declared repeatedly over the years that he would never retire from his perch at the top of his $39 billion entertainment empire.

headline: A Men’s Brand That Finds Inspiration (and Models) on the Street
abstract: Daisuke Obana — the designer of the Japanese brand N. Hoolywood — discovers models for his show all over New York. T visited him in the studio.
lead_paragraph: Street casting models for runway shows is common practice these days for designers — but the Japanese men’s wear brand N. Hoolywood, which has been doing it for 15 years, has mastered it like an art form.

headline: In the Studio With N. Hoolywood
abstract: The designer Diaske Obana and the stylist Tsuyoshi Nimura search the streets of New York for five days and find over 100 people to audition for the show. T visited them during a fitting.
lead_paragraph: The designer Diaske Obana and the stylist Tsuyoshi Nimura search the streets of New York for five days and find over 100 people to audition for the show. T visited them during a fitting.

headline: Cross-Country Skiing in the Jizera Mountains
abstract: Nordic trails, virgin forests and a haunting history in Central Europe’s Jizera Mountains.
lead_paragraph: Nordic trails, virgin forests and a haunting history in Central Europe’s Jizera Mountains.

headline: Betty Woodman’s Cheery Ceramics Come to London
abstract: The artist’s work incorporates glazed earthenware vessels and painted canvases, to delight and maybe even, she hopes, make you a better person.
lead_paragraph: The bright-eyed, 85-year-old American artist Betty Woodman has been creating with clay for almost 70 years, since she took a one-off pottery class in high school. “I still have the naïve belief that having beautiful things around you might make you a better person,” she says. Fittingly, her work — on display beginning today at London’s Institute of Contemporary Art — depicts cheery and inviting interior scenes, composed of her glazed earthenware vessels among large acrylic canvases.

headline: 2nd Suspect Arrested in Killing of Brooklyn Couple
abstract: Jerry Maisonett was charged with second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon in connection with the deaths of Rosie Sanchez and Anderson Nunez, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A second suspect was arrested on Wednesday in a killing last month in Brooklyn in which a 15-year-old girl is accused of attacking her mother and her mother’s boyfriend, the police said.

headline: One Artist’s Fascination With a Giant Old Clamp
abstract: Shana Lutker shares a weathered C-clamp she once found on the side of the road — and hasn’t done much with since.
lead_paragraph: In this series for T, the writer and author of “Worn Stories,” Emily Spivack, interviews creative types about their most prized possessions.

headline: President Obama Finally Visits an American Mosque
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Mosques', 'Muslim-Americans', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Amid the anti-Muslim vitriol sweeping the nation, Mr. Obama assured his audience that “we are one American family.”
lead_paragraph: President Obama’s very first visit to a United States mosque did not happen until this week, in his final year in office. The fact that it had never happened before made the event remarkable and, sadly, a bit risky amid the anti-Muslim vitriol sweeping the nation. Mr. Obama made his purpose clear in arriving Wednesday at the Islamic Society of Baltimore. He simply wanted to say something positive about Muslim Americans and their numerous contributions as responsible citizens in the face of steady denunciations from Republican candidates in the presidential campaign.

headline: Airstrike at Yemen Cement Factory Said to Kill at Least 15
abstract: The bombing by Saudi-led forces of a factory north of Sana, the capital, killed civilian workers in nearby businesses and two military guards, local officials said.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — An airstrike by a military coalition led by Saudi Arabia hit a cement factory north of Sana, Yemen’s capital, on Wednesday evening, killing at least 15 people, including civilian workers in nearby businesses, according to local security and medical officials.

headline: Review: Dada Masilo’s ‘Swan Lake’ Offers Ill-Fated Love With a Twist
abstract: This South African choreographer’s reinterpretation of Tchaikovsky’s work combines bits of ballet and African dance with simple politics: against homophobia.
lead_paragraph: Even before the houselights go down, we hear familiar strains of Tchaikovsky’s “Swan Lake” at an unusually rapid tempo. After a while, swans appear, wearing the white tutus associated with the ballet, but half of them are male. All of them are black South Africans. They strike attitudes of ballet swans in a forceful, clipped fashion. They turn away from us, and as they flap their arms sinuously, they shake their tail feathers of tulle.

headline: Four Absurdist Filmmakers — and Friends — on One Screen
abstract: A new series at Lincoln Center celebrates a clique of young directors whose films pull from classical narratives, pop culture and art history.
lead_paragraph: The friends and filmmakers Gabriel Abrantes, Alexander Carver, Benjamin Crotty and Daniel Schmidt were brought together through serendipity — variously at school, through mutual friends and abroad — but it’s their shared aesthetic and sense of humor that have kept this creative quartet in conversation for the past decade. This February, the Film Society of Lincoln Center honors the foursome’s unique connection with a weeklong program dedicated to their avant-garde shorts and feature-length films. Aptly titled “Friends With Benefits,” the series will act as a mini-retrospective for their individual efforts, as well as their collaborative ones. (A trailer for the series premieres above.) Packaged thematically over seven days, the program will encompass almost 10 years’ worth of their gleefully unorthodox content in addition to the U.S. premiere of Crotty’s “Fort Buchanan,” a queer soap opera about a man trapped on a remote military base, waiting for his lover to return.

headline: Israeli Police Officer Is Killed in Attack by 3 Palestinians in Jerusalem
abstract: Another border police officer was wounded in the assault, carried out by men armed with automatic rifles, knives and pipe bombs, who were fatally shot by officers at the scene.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Three Palestinian men armed with automatic rifles, knives and pipe bombs attacked Israeli border police officers in East Jerusalem on Wednesday, killing one officer and wounding another. The three assailants were fatally shot by officers at the scene.

lead_paragraph: 케냐 투르카나 호숫가의 한 석호에서 일어난 사건이다. 때는 약 1만 년 전. 한 무리의 수렵채집인들이 다른 수렵채집인 무리를 공격하여 학살했다. 두개골이 부서지고 화살촉, 혹은 창촉이 박혔으며 그 외에 몇몇 치명적인 상처가 있는 시체를 남겼다.

headline: Topsy-Turvy Oscars Race May Gain Clarity in Directors Guild Awards
abstract: A look back at the ups and downs of this awards season as the Oscars loom with no clear front-runner for best picture.
lead_paragraph: Quick — name the best picture Oscar winner from two years ago, or from another two years before that. Cannot? Despair not. Some of the most lastingly resonant films have failed to land best picture Oscars, among them “Citizen Kane,” “Goodfellas” and “It’s a Wonderful Life.” Others, like “Some Like It Hot,” “Blade Runner” and “Thelma & Louise” did not even get best picture nominations, and the American Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences failed to nominate “His Girl Friday” for anything at all. All of which is to say that come Feb. 28, when this year’s Oscars are doled out, the ultimate winners might not, in the broad scheme of things, matter a ton.

headline: Dodge Chargers Recalled for Tire Jack Problem
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles']
abstract: Fiat Chrysler is recalling almost 505,000 2011-16 Dodge Chargers because the vehicle might fall off the jack when a tire is being changed.
lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler is recalling almost 505,000 2011-16 Dodge Chargers, including about 442,000 in the United States, because the vehicle might fall off the jack when a tire is being changed, the automaker said Wednesday. The problem is that the part of the vehicle’s body the jack is holding up could flex, allowing the vehicle to topple, said Eric Mayne, a Fiat Chrysler spokesman. Fiat Chrysler will supply owners with wheel chocks; the owner’s manual shows how they should be used. The automaker said it was aware of three minor injuries.

headline: In Silicon Valley, a Time-Honored Sport Looks to the Future

The leather ball has been stitched the same way for decades, and the chain gangs hold the first-down markers like crossing guards at a busy street corner. The players smash into one another in a way a fan from a century ago would recognize.

headline: Virginia: Under Scrutiny, Teen Dating Site Is Removed
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Social Media', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: Facebook has taken down from its site group called Teen Dating and Flirting, which stirred outrage over its sexually explicit content after the recent murder of a 13-year-old Virginia girl.
lead_paragraph: Facebook has taken down from its site a group called Teen Dating and Flirting, which stirred outrage over its sexually explicit content after the recent murder of a 13-year-old Virginia girl, a company spokeswoman said on Wednesday. The group burst into the spotlight this week after two Virginia Tech students were charged in the abduction and murder of the girl, Nicole Madison Lovell of Blacksburg, Va. The students — David Eisenhauer, 18, of Columbia, Md., and Natalie Marie Keepers, 19, of Laurel, Md. — are being held without bond. Nicole is believed to have met Mr. Eisenhauer through social media, though there has been no assertion that they connected on Facebook. But her brief comments on the page of the teen dating group, which had more than 18,000 members, drew attention to the group, prompting Facebook to investigate. The spokeswoman said the group violated Facebook’s published community standards, which ban, among other things, nude images, threats, bullying, harassment, and anything that promotes sexual exploitation.

headline: Iran: Former BBC Journalist Is Arrested
abstract: The former journalist, Bahman Daroshafaei, a dual citizen of Britain and Iran, was taken into custody for undisclosed reasons in Tehran, where he had been working as a translator.
lead_paragraph: A former journalist with the British Broadcasting Corporation’s Persian service was arrested in Iran on Wednesday, Iranian activists outside the country reported, just as Iran’s foreign minister embarked on a trip to Britain, the first such visit in more than a decade. The former journalist, Bahman Daroshafaei, a dual citizen of Britain and Iran, was taken into custody for undisclosed reasons in Tehran, where he had been working as a translator, according to an account on Iranwire, a news service founded by expatriate Iranian journalists. The arrest may have been intended by hard-line factions in Iran, which are suspicious of improved ties with the West, to embarrass Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif, who has been seeking greater engagement.

lead_paragraph: On social media and the web, commenters reacted to the news that former N.F.L. quarterback Ken Stabler’s brain had C.T.E, believed to be caused by repeated blows to the head.

headline: Democrats Tangle in New Hampshire Over Rights to ‘Progressive’ Label
abstract: The Democrats, in an increasingly testy battle for the presidential nomination, took part in a town-hall meeting in New Hampshire, where next week’s primary voting has gained in prominence after a close contest in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont clashed in heated terms over the meaning of progressivism in America on Wednesday, with her forced to defend positions that he argued are not in line with the liberal wing of the Democratic Party.

headline: Activity at North Korea Site Suggests Preparations for Rocket Launch
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Satellites', 'International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: More vehicles have been seen at a launch site near Pyongyang’s northwestern border with China, according to a United States website.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — Increased vehicle activity has been detected at North Korea’s rocket launch site near its northwestern border with China, which could be a sign of preparations for the launch Pyongyang said it would conduct this month, according to a United States website that monitors the North.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | viand

lead_paragraph: viand • \ˈvi-ənd\ • noun

headline: Mexico: Ex-Governor Detained by Spain Returns Home
abstract: The former governor, Humberto Moreira, spent a week in a Spanish jail on suspicion of money laundering last month and flew back to Mexico on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Humberto Moreira, a Mexican former governor who spent a week in a Spanish jail on suspicion of money laundering last month, flew back to Mexico on Wednesday. After Mr. Moreira was detained in Madrid on Jan. 15, the case against him crumbled. Judge Santiago Pedraz of Spain’s National Court rejected prosecutors’ arguments that Mr. Moreira had transferred 200,000 euros, or about $218,000, in illegitimate funds to Spain in 2013 and ordered his release. Mr. Moreira’s passport was initially withheld, but after prosecutors failed to appeal, it was returned on Tuesday and Mr. Moreira boarded an Aeromexico flight on Wednesday. Mr. Moreira, 49, is notorious for having increased the debt of his state, Coahuila, by 100 times while serving as its governor from 2005 to 2011 and concealing the loans.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
abstract: “Hoosiers,” airing this evening, may inspire enthusiasm for March Madness; if that’s not your thing, comedies abound, too.
lead_paragraph: The high school basketball film “Hoosiers” may inspire enthusiasm for the approaching N.C.A.A. tournament, and perhaps for the Indiana Hoosiers, who are leading the Big Ten. And if you aren’t much for comedies like “You, Me and the Apocalypse,” the avant-garde “Baskets,” starring Zach Galifianakis, may appeal.

headline: Playboy Puts On (Some) Clothes for Newly Redesigned Issue
abstract: The magazine still has plenty of semi-nude pictures, which feel more impromptu than posed, as well as long articles.
lead_paragraph: What is Playboy without naked women? It sounds a little bit like Car and Driver magazine without cars or drivers, and for readers who want only to gawk at the most intimate of female parts, it is just that. For everyone else, the makeover is subtler than you might expect. And frankly, the starkest changes have little to do with flesh.

lead_paragraph: Julian Assange — the founder of WikiLeaks who sought refuge in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden — has been arbitrarily detained in violation of international law, a United Nations human rights panel has concluded.

headline: Royal Dutch Shell’s Profit Down 56% on Slumping Oil Prices
abstract: Stock rises on a promise to maintain the dividend and prospects for the pending acquisition of the energy company BG Group.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Royal Dutch Shell became the latest big energy company to file a damage report on the impact of depressed oil prices, saying on Thursday that its adjusted profit fell 56 percent in the fourth quarter of 2015 compared to a year earlier.

headline: S.S. United States, Historic Ocean Liner of Trans-Atlantic Heyday, May Sail Again
keywords: ['Ships and Shipping', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The S.S. United States, which still holds the speed record for an Atlantic crossing, may be refitted into a luxury travel option by Crystal Cruises.
lead_paragraph: The S.S. United States has just been tossed a life preserver.

headline: Cuban-American Exile Up North
abstract: A new show, “The Cuban-Americans,” examines the lives of Cuban transplants living in New Jersey and New York.
lead_paragraph: Despite Chris Matthews’s dismissive characterization of Senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio as “two Cuban guys,” the fact that they placed first and third in the Iowa caucuses is a milestone in Cuban-American history. In the more than half-century since Cubans went into exile and remade their lives in the United States, they have transformed cities like Miami and attained success in business and industry.

headline: A City Council Raise That Raises Questions
abstract: There are good reasons for a pay increase, but there are also good reasons for taking the time to explain why such a large raise is needed.
lead_paragraph: The New York City Council is looking to vote itself a hefty pay raise. This is always a delicate issue for politicians sensitive about irritating their employer, the taxpaying public. The vote is scheduled for Friday, conveniently timed to disappear into the Saturday news abyss.

headline: An Unpaid Debt to Afghan Interpreters
abstract: Thousands of Afghans may be disqualified from moving to the United States as a result of an unfair change to the application process.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Congress made a change to the rules of a resettlement program for Afghan interpreters who risked their lives by working for the American government. To be eligible for an American visa, applicants would have to demonstrate that they had worked for the United States for at least two years, rather than one. There was no reason to think the new requirement would affect the roughly 10,300 people who already had pending applications.

headline: White America’s ‘Broken Heart’
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Minorities', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The urgency of inequality as an issue is really about how some white Americans are now experiencing what many minorities here have long experienced.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, at the Corinthian Baptist Church in Des Moines, former President Bill Clinton, looking frail and sounding faint, stumped for his wife, working through her qualifications with a husband’s devotion and a Svengali’s facility.

headline: 2 Questions for Bernie Sanders
abstract: An admirer could use some reassurance.
lead_paragraph: When Bernie Sanders won election as mayor of Burlington, Vt., in 1981, I called his office to see if there was a story there about a socialist elected official. I was interning at The Washington Post (I didn’t mention the intern part!) and spoke at length to some assistant who answered the phone in the mayor’s office.

headline: The Plausibility of Ted Cruz
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why can’t the Iowa winner get any respect?
lead_paragraph: It’s rare for a politician to be overshadowed in victory, and even rarer when that victory is actually an upset. But Ted Cruz managed that trick in Iowa: Despite pulling out a victory when almost everyone expected Donald J. Trump to win, he found himself overshadowed twice in the coverage that followed— first by Trump’s unexpected flop, and second by Marco Rubio’s unexpectedly strong third-place finish.

headline: The Supreme Court vs. the President
abstract: The Supreme Court has abandoned judicial restraint to challenge the president’s authority and discretion.
lead_paragraph: Hard-wired into the Supreme Court’s DNA is the notion that the court doesn’t reach out to decide a constitutional issue if it can resolve a case by interpreting a statute. “The court will not anticipate a question of constitutional law in advance of the necessity of deciding it,” is how Justice Louis D. Brandeis expressed this principle of judicial restraint 80 years ago in a concurring opinion to which the court often makes reference.

headline: And Now, the Marco Memo
abstract: He’s still giving much the same speech but not the same stances.
lead_paragraph: Here we are, in the Marco Rubio Moment.

headline: When State Control Damages a City
abstract: The crisis in Flint raises serious questions about how and when state-appointed emergency managers should intervene.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, officials from Michigan and the federal Environmental Protection Agency were called before a House committee to explain how they let the drinking water in Flint become poisoned by lead. Also testifying before the committee was a mother of four whose tap water has been so contaminated since early 2015 that her family has had to use bottled water for drinking and cooking and has often showered at friends’ homes outside the city.

headline: Clinton's Email Habits: Careless or Criminal?
abstract: What does the latest news about Secretary Clinton's emails mean, and based on what we know so far, was her behavior criminal?

headline: Rubio’s Call for No Capital Gains Tax Is a Break With the G.O.P.
abstract: A once-fringe idea is going mainstream this year courtesy of Senator Marco Rubio in the Republican race.
lead_paragraph: When Steve Forbes ran for president in 1996 on a plan that called for no taxes on dividends and capital gains, Mitt Romney, then a private citizen, took out a full-page ad in The Boston Globe attacking his proposal as plutocratic.

headline: Credit Suisse Takes Big Loss on Write-Down in 4th Quarter
abstract: As part of a restructuring, the Swiss bank said it had taken a good-will charge of 3.8 billion francs as it reassessed the value of its investment unit.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Credit Suisse reported a multibillion-dollar loss in the fourth quarter on Thursday — far more than analysts had expected and its largest in seven years — as turbulent markets and a substantial charge associated with its restructuring weighed on its results.

headline: News Q’s | Rivals Look to New Hampshire for a Shot at Breaking Donald Trump’s Stride
abstract: How have conservative leaders and rival candidates for the Republican presidential nomination begun to challenge Donald J. Trump aggressively after his defeat in the Iowa caucuses?
lead_paragraph: The following lesson activities are based on the article “Rivals Look to New Hampshire for a Shot at Breaking Donald Trump’s Stride.”

headline: With This Tattoo, I Thee Wed
abstract: In a quest to convey the permanence of their marriages, some couples are having their wedding rings tattooed on.
lead_paragraph: Valentine’s Day often finds couples speaking of love and lasting commitment. Some have concluded (for better or worse) that there is no finer way to celebrate eternal love than by showcasing it on one’s ring finger with a tattoo.

headline: Judd Apatow Reads ‘At the Hospital, an Interlude of Clarity’
abstract: The comedic filmmaker reads an essay about a date that only got better after an E.R. visit.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the fourth episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, brought to you by The New York Times and WBUR. This week, you’ll hear the filmmaker/producer/screenwriter/comedian Judd Apatow (“Trainwreck,” “Girls,” “Knocked Up,” “The 40-Year-Old Virgin” and “Superbad,” to name just a few) read a 2014 Modern Love essay by Brian Gittis titled “At the Hospital, an Interlude of Clarity.”

headline: Birmingham Symphony Names Mirga Grazinyte-Tyla, Rising Star, as Its Next Conductor
abstract: In a field where women are rare as maestros, Ms.Grazinyte-Tyla also stands out for her originality and upbeat rapport with musicians.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to discovering conducting talent, few ensembles boast a track record like that of the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra in England. It has been a springboard for the careers of Simon Rattle, the chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic, and Andris Nelsons, the music director of both the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Leipzig Gewandhaus Orchestra.

headline: When Ling-Ling and Hsing Hsing Arrived in the U.S.
abstract: In rapprochement with Washington, Mao Zedong’s government sent over two pandas, which President Nixon decided would live in the National Zoo.
lead_paragraph: The foreign guests had traveled a great distance to reach Washington, stopping in Honolulu on the way and finally disembarking under heavy security. On April 16, 1972, they were welcomed to the United States by the country’s first lady, Pat Nixon.

headline: A Hudson Heights Co-op With a View
abstract: Nicolas Gérard wanted a spacious one-bedroom co-op and a reasonable commute to work.
lead_paragraph: Before he moved to New York four years ago, Nicolas Gérard lived in Togo in West Africa, having been posted there by the United Nations. In Lomé, the capital city, he and a colleague shared a rented house with a yard and a swimming pool.

headline: Congresswoman’s Long Quest: Bringing Pandas to New York
abstract: After terrorist attacks, the financial crisis and natural disasters, Representative Carolyn B. Maloney believes the city could benefit from hosting the animals from China.
lead_paragraph: It is an obsession that has taken her to the other side of the world, one that has turned casual conversations into arm-twisting negotiations, and innocuous radio chitchat into a stealth attack on the mayor of New York.

headline: Our Man in New Hampshire: Weathering the Elements for Ted Cruz
abstract: With less than a week before the primary, many voters have already made up their minds. But that does not stop them from waiting for their candidates, even in the rain.
lead_paragraph: GOFFSTOWN, N.H. — If you think finding street parking in Manhattan is tough, try hunting for a spot on Main Street in a New Hampshire suburb when Ted Cruz has come to town.

headline: As Syria Talks Fizzle, ‘War Has No Meaning Anymore’
abstract: Much in Geneva this week was like the last round of Syria peace talks there two years ago. But something fundamental had changed: There was, on both sides, grim resignation.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Four Syrian rebel commanders huddled in a knot, all broad shoulders and shiny gray suits, surveying the hotel lounge. Gigantic portraits of Jim Morrison and Jimi Hendrix gazed down at the carpet, a checkerboard of faux zebra-hide in squares of orange and magenta. On a low sofa, a couple snuggled to the sounds of Amy Winehouse.

headline: Chris Christie and Jeb Bush Team Up on a Mutual Target: Marco Rubio
abstract: Members of the Bush and Christie campaigns have communicated about their shared desire to halt Marco Rubio’s rise in the polls, Republican operatives say.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Frustrated and flailing as his candidacy threatens to slip away, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey is embarking on a scalding effort over the next week to discredit Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, the man he blames for undermining his campaign and whose ascendancy he deeply resents.

abstract: Do your parents encourage you to find joy in your work? Do they emphasize experimentation, or rule-following? What about your teachers? Do you tend to pursue things because you are motivated to do them, or because your parents or teachers want you to?

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Lead', 'Water', 'Water Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: The drinking water may have exposed tens of thousands of people to lead and other toxic chemicals. But few see a way to pick up and move someplace safe.

lead_paragraph: Martin Shkreli’s grilling by Congress on Thursday proved to be the spectacle that many had long anticipated.

headline: Sleep Problems Tied to Type 2 Diabetes
abstract: Trouble falling or staying asleep, sleeping less than six hours a night, snoring, apnea and shift work were linked to an increased risk of diabetes in women.
lead_paragraph: Women with sleeping difficulties are at increased risk for Type 2 diabetes, researchers report.

headline: Living With Cancer: A Woman Like Me
abstract: The film “A Woman Like Me” explores the roles played by temperament, spirituality and art as two vigorous women attempt to reconcile themselves to a terminal prognosis.
lead_paragraph: We commonly assume that cancer afflicts the aging or aged, but approximately 16 percent of breast cancer deaths involve women under the age of 50. How can or should an alarming death sentence be confronted in midlife? The personal challenges posed by incurable disease unfold in an absorbing documentary about movie-making, “A Woman Like Me,” which opened in New York in October and became available on Netflix this January.

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Growth across the European Union will be slower than previously estimated this year and next as the world economy shifts into a lower gear and European leaders wrangle over how to handle an influx of refugees, officials warned on Thursday.
