headline: Syria Aid Pledges From Rich Countries Reach $10 Billion
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'International Relations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Britain, Germany and the United States, among other countries, made new pledges to help refugees and others affected by the civil war.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — With no end in sight to Syria’s five-year-old civil war, rich nations pledged more than $10 billion on Thursday to help the millions of people who have been displaced by the conflict and to prepare for new waves of refugees expected this year.

headline: Michael Kors: Fall 2016
abstract: Mr. Kors’ fall looks.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Kors’ fall looks.

headline: There Is No One to Inaugurate Yet, but Festivities Must Still Be Prepared
abstract: Congress took the first steps toward planning the party for the next president and vice president, as the House formally adopted a resolution establishing a Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies.
lead_paragraph: Who cares who wins the presidential election? New Hampshire may have yet to get its say, but someone is going to get elected. And that means someone will be inaugurated.

headline: Europe’s Huddled Masses
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A digital migration of epic proportions is underway. But America is nowhere to be seen on the refugee crisis.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From London to Athens, Europe is questioned. Some people, mainly refugees from Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan, are dying to get into the European Union. Many British conservatives are fighting to get out of it. Others, including President Vladimir Putin of Russia, plot to undermine it. Yet others are bored by it: The 20th century and the strategic imperatives behind NATO and the European Union seem far away to wired millennials.

headline: Germany Arrests Algerian Suspected of Planning Terrorist Attack
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The Berlin police said the man, 35, had been detained at a refugee shelter as hundreds of officers carried out raids across three states.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — An Algerian man suspected of training with Islamic State terrorists in Syria and of planning an attack in Germany was taken into custody at a refugee shelter in North Rhine-Westphalia early Thursday as hundreds of police officers carried out raids in three German states, the police said.

headline: North Korea Launches Newest Offensive: Cigarette Butts
abstract: Balloons sent by the North carried not just leaflets declaring South Korea’s leader a “filthy president,” but also a payload of actual filth.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea likes to call South Korea a land of “political filth” and its leaders, including President Park Geun-hye, “human trash.” Now, apparently to highlight its contempt, it has begun sending balloons into the South with an unusual payload, the police here said on Thursday: cigarette butts.

headline: Iowa Follows Sanders and Clinton Into Final Debate Before New Hampshire
abstract: The close race in Iowa has added fuel to the steadily growing fire between the campaigns of Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont. In the final Democratic debate before the New Hampshire primary, that fire is bound to burn bright.
lead_paragraph: Just as the Democratic presidential primary race has hit a newly contentious note, Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Sanders will take the stage at a debate that neither originally wanted.

headline: Xi Jinping Assuming New Status as China’s ‘Core’ Leader
abstract: The term evokes a stature not recognized since Deng Xiaoping and suggests that President Xi’s steely quest for dominance is not over.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China’s president, Xi Jinping, has already grasped more power more quickly than his two recent predecessors, and he has shown a taste for audacious decisions and a loathing for dissent. But a new push to praise him as China’s “core” leader, a term resonant with the formidable stature once held by Deng Xiaoping, suggests that his steely quest for dominance is not over.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: William Blake’s Grave
abstract: In a London cemetery, the poet’s spirit feels abundantly alive.
lead_paragraph: Please suspend your disbelief: Long ago, when I was feverish with pneumonia, a lamb with the face of the poet and artist William Blake appeared in my room and implored me not to lie down. His advice might have saved my life. But somehow, I never visited Blake’s grave to thank him until last August.

headline: A Hint of Danger in the Forest
keywords: ['Pigs', 'Wilderness Areas', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'ANIMALS']
abstract: An encounter with a wild boar momentarily realigns our relationship to nature in a time of mass extinction.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, I walked through an English forest with an old friend who told me there was something living in it that I had never seen before. Intrigued, I stood with him by a barbed-wire fence running across leaf ­litter dappled with sunlight. It was very quiet — just the sifting of a faint breeze through the trees and a robin singing from a holly bush. My friend whistled, called, then whistled again, and I felt a flicker of recognition as a dark shape flitted between trees about 60 or 70 yards away and then ran toward us. It was a wild boar. I’ve seen images of them all my life: razor-backed beasts on ancient vases, in illustrations in medieval manuscripts, slumped in front of men with rifles in old trophy photographs. And now here one was, called into the real world.

headline: Review: Michael Jackson, Before He Was King
abstract: Spike Lee’s documentary, “Michael Jackson’s Journey From Motown to Off the Wall,” about Jackson’s development as a solo artist, has its TV debut on Showtime on Friday.
lead_paragraph: When you think of Spike Lee as a director of documentaries, you probably think of “4 Little Girls” and “When the Levees Broke,” his somber, anguished accounts of assaults on black communities. But the majority of his nonfiction work has been in a lighter and more celebratory vein — music and comedy concert films, music videos, profiles of athletes like Kobe Bryant and Jim Brown.

headline: The Privilege of Wild Food
abstract: Cooking cod cakes, and giving thanks for line-caught fish.
lead_paragraph: It was dawn in big swells, Block Island rising a few miles to the southwest, and a group of sport fishermen were standing pressed against the stern rails of a large charter boat, drifting on the tide. This was the Jenglo, 46 feet, with a huge, sweeping flare of a bow, out of Orient Point on Long Island. The men had steamed three hours in winter darkness to reach this spot, some of them growing sick in the motion, others smoking silently or drinking coffee, staring out into the heave of the sea. There were rods in their hands, heavy sinkers attached to them, two hooks each above them, baited with clam bellies.

headline: ‘Zoolander 2’ Creates a Model-Slash-Juggernaut
abstract: With the help of a vast social media network, the fashion world embraces the sequel to the film that poked fun at this image-driven industry.
lead_paragraph: As “Zoolander 2” begins on the streets of Rome with a chase scene straight out of the “Mission: Impossible” movies, Derek Zoolander — once a really, really ridiculously good-looking three-time male model of the year and still an incredibly poor speller — is nowhere to be found.

headline: When Your Baby Won’t Eat
abstract: Our daughter started life on a feeding tube. Then we tried to wean her off it — and began to understand the complexity of how children relate to food.
lead_paragraph: Violet looked perfectly normal, but she had been slowly suffocating for at least a week, and we had no idea. Violet seemed like an ordinary newborn: From birth, she cried when she was hungry, slept when she was full. When awake, she stared at us intensely; when she slept, she slept a lot — one night, for nine hours. When the time she spent breast-feeding went from 45 minutes to 20, then 10, then five, I thought the two of us were getting better at it. We weren’t. And the purplish tinge to her lips, hands and feet didn’t mean she was chilly. Violet’s heart was failing.

headline: Seduced by Tuscany in Winter
abstract: Cozy coffee bars, pasta shops, even a boar hunt are among the cold-­weather pleasures of the off-season by the sea.
lead_paragraph: Something was lacking on the Tuscan coast.

headline: Willie Wood Made the Most Memorable Play of Super Bowl I. He Has No Recollection.
abstract: Wood’s interception of a pass by Chiefs quarterback Len Dawson helped the Packers win the title. In the five decades since, Wood’s and Dawson’s lives have taken divergent paths.
lead_paragraph: The Green Bay Packers’ agile, lissome safety, Willie Wood, snatched the wobbly pass thrown by the Kansas City Chiefs’ quarterback, Len Dawson, and zigzagged to the doorstep of the Chiefs’ end zone, setting up an easy Packers touchdown. Green Bay never looked back in a 25-point rout of Kansas City in the first Super Bowl.

headline: Benjamin Millepied to Step Down From Paris Opera Ballet
abstract: Mr. Millepied said that he had decided to focus on his own choreography and to return to Los Angeles, where he still directs the L.A. Dance Project.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Benjamin Millepied, the choreographer and former New York City Ballet dancer who brought an aura of glamour and intense news media visibility to the 335-year-old Paris Opera Ballet as its director of dance, said on Thursday that he was resigning after just over a year in the position.

headline: The N.F.L.’s Next Play: Address Brain Trauma or Fade Away
abstract: The doctor who took a stand decades ago against boxing argues that the N.F.L. must acknowledge the high risk of brain injury.
lead_paragraph: IN late 1982, I was watching the heavyweight championship fight between Larry Holmes and Randall Cobb, known as Tex, on television. Even though I was a longtime fan of pretty much every sport, I was appalled by the ceaseless violence that the referee permitted to be inflicted on Cobb. As a pathologist who had autopsied hundreds of people, I knew the kind of damage the fight could be causing. I wasn’t the only one horrified by the spectacle: Howard Cosell, who was calling the fight, asked, “I wonder if that referee understands that he is constructing an advertisement for the abolition of the very sport that he’s a part of?”

headline: Sisterhood, Beyond the Script
abstract: Actresses in several shows, including “Hamilton” and “Fiddler on the Roof,” demonstrate the power of real-life bonding in conveying authenticity.
lead_paragraph: At the start of rehearsals for the Broadway revival of “Fiddler on the Roof” last fall, it quickly became clear that the three actresses playing Tevye’s eldest daughters were inseparable. Observing them huddled together in a corner in their black rehearsal clothes, the musical’s director, Bartlett Sher, labeled them “the coven.”

headline: Cory Booker: By the Book
abstract: The U.S. senator says that while the difficult process of writing his own book, “United,” “didn’t ultimately break me, there were times I wanted to yell, times when I pounded my desk.”
lead_paragraph: The U.S. senator says that while the difficult process of writing his own book, “United,” “didn’t ultimately break me, there were times I wanted to yell, times when I pounded my desk.”

headline: GPS Mix-Up Brings Wrong Turn, and Celebrity, to an American in Iceland
abstract: Noel Santillan, a 28-year-old from New Jersey, typed the wrong address for his hotel and spent six hours on the road before realizing: This isn’t Reykjavik.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When Noel Santillan typed the word Laugarvegur instead of Laugavegur into his rental car’s GPS, the New Jersey resident couldn’t have imagined that the extra “r” would make him something of a celebrity in Iceland.

headline: Can’t Leave That Latin Sound
abstract: A Manhattanite hops in the car to get out of town, but then realizes he can’t live without the beat coming from La Mega.

headline: New York Times Co. Announces Newsroomwide Strategy Review
abstract: The company highlighted digital growth in the fourth quarter but said revenue was flat because of its declining print business.
lead_paragraph: Buoyed by strong digital growth and cost savings, The New York Times Company reported on Thursday an increase in quarterly profit but said revenue was flat as its print business continued to decline. The earnings report came on the same day that a sweeping examination of the newsroom, which will include identifying further areas for cost reductions, was announced.

headline: High-Speed Traders in Britain Subject to New Accountability Rules
keywords: ['High-Frequency and Flash Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Financial Conduct Authority said certification rules would apply to wholesale banking activities, including high-frequency and algorithmic traders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — British regulators said on Thursday that people engaged in high-frequency or algorithmic trading would be subject to newly completed rules intended to bring more accountability to the financial industry.

headline: A Brisk Swim Across Martha’s Vineyard
abstract: For no particular reason other than the romance of the idea, the writer and T’s deputy editor Hanya Yanagihara traversed the entire island’s mostly polite — and at times, dark — waters.
lead_paragraph: For no particular reason other than the romance of the idea, the writer and T’s deputy editor Hanya Yanagihara traversed the entire island’s mostly polite — and at times, dark — waters.

headline: Matt LeBlanc to Join ‘Top Gear’
abstract: The “Friends” actor will become the first American to co-host the BBC’s popular car-themed show.
lead_paragraph: The actor Matt LeBlanc will join the cast of the BBC’s car-themed show “Top Gear,” a popular program known for its on-air antics — as well as its high-profile staffing changes.

headline: 1941: U.S. Bars Boy, Then Relents
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: U.S. bars nine-year-old Scot who arrived alone in New York in 1941.
lead_paragraph: Michael Storrie, nine-year-old Scot, who arrived alone on Monday in New York in search of refuge, stood dry-eyed yesterday before a special board of inquiry at Ellis Island and heard himself ordered excluded from the United States for lack of proper entry papers. His unblinking acceptance of the blow moved the board to arrange an appeal and an immediate parole. Michael, whose father is in Lisbon on a war mission and whose mother is doing war work in Bermuda, was to have been the guest of Mr. and Mrs. George C. McIntosh at Clifton Springs, Va., for the duration of the war, but he did not have a card of identification and American visa. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 5, 1941

headline: Going Green, For Real
abstract: Solar and wind dominate new capacity.
lead_paragraph: I wrote earlier this week about prospects for a renewables revolution; right on schedule, Bloomberg reports, A Renewables Revolution Is Toppling the Dominance of Fossil Fuels in U.S. Power. It turns out that solar and wind accounted for two-thirds of the generation capacity added last year.

headline: Reinstalling Windows 10
abstract: Even if you upgraded to Windows 10 by downloading the software free on your PC, you can still reinstall the whole operating system if needed.
lead_paragraph: Q. The Windows 10 upgrade is a free download for Windows 7 and Windows 8.1 machines, but it doesn’t seem to have its own serial number and obviously didn’t come with an installation DVD. What happens if I need to reformat my hard drive and reinstall the operating system? How do I reactivate Windows?

headline: Daily Report: The Mystery of Amazon’s Bookstores
keywords: ['Book Trade and Publishing', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Shopping Centers and Malls', 'Social Media']

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Torture', 'Missing Persons', 'International Relations']

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Four months ago, Giulio Regeni, an Italian doctoral candidate at Cambridge University, arrived in Cairo to improve his Arabic and conduct research among the city’s street vendors.

keywords: ['Dancing', 'Theater', 'Encores! Great American Musicals in Concert (Series)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']

lead_paragraph: The Challenge: A healthy 67-year-old man develops an annoying little cough that, over the course of a week, worsens and nearly takes his breath away. Can you figure out why?

headline: Fabio Luisi’s Future Looks Bright, Wherever It Is

lead_paragraph: After a long day rehearsing Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut” at the Metropolitan Opera, the conductor Fabio Luisi stepped nimbly around the studio overlooking Central Park where he plies his side trade: making perfume. He proffered samples of ingredients like jasmine, bergamot and ambergris, and gave sniffs of his own recipes.

headline: Picasso in Custody Battle Was Intended for Sale to Leon D. Black
abstract: In an ongoing legal battle, a court filing Wednesday by Pelham Holdings names the secret buyer Larry Gagosian was going to sell the bust to.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s Carriage-Horse Plan Falters in City Council

headline: Chris Christie Faults Marco Rubio’s Abortion Position, and Misrepresents It

headline: Disappointed With Europe, Thousands of Iraqi Migrants Return Home
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Many of the Iraqis who joined Syrians, Africans and Afghans in the great migrant wave to Europe last year with expectations of quick success are now turning around.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Night after night, Mohammed al-Jabiry tossed and turned in his bed at a refugee center in Finland, comparing life in Europe with life in Baghdad. After many sleepless nights, he decided to come home.

headline: Fashion Industry Scrambles to Find a Use for Snapchat
abstract: Lured by the attention garnered by the likes of Gigi Hadid, Kylie Jenner and DJ Khaled, big brands have clamored to build a presence on the messaging app.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Here’s a question: What do looks from the catwalks at New York Men’s Fashion Week, a video of Gigi Hadid singing a duet with Taylor Swift and the latest cover of the annual Hollywood issue of Vanity Fair have in common?

headline: 1966: Photos Show Pebbles on Moon
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The moon is photographed from its surface for the first time in 1966.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — For the first time in history, a man-made object today [Feb. 4] photographed the moon from the lunar surface itself. Luna-9, the Soviet rocket that made the first soft landing on the moon, televised its pictures back to the earth. The Soviet Union declined to make them public, but England’s Jodrell Bank radiotelescope observatory intercepted the Russian signals and developed them into ‘‘sensational’’ pictures. So fine was the detail that features only a few inches long were visible, British scientists said. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 5, 1966

headline: A Key Divide Between Clinton and Sanders Supporters: Income
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Presidential Election of 2008', 'Primaries and Caucuses']

lead_paragraph: At first glance, Bernie Sanders’s voters in Iowa this week looked a lot like Barack Obama’s from 2008. Both were strongest among young, independent-leaning, liberal men.

headline: 2 Israelis Sentenced in 2014 Murder of Palestinian Teenager
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Palestinians', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Jews and Judaism']
abstract: One was given life in prison for a crime that prompted deep soul-searching in Israel and contributed to the Gaza war that same year.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — It was a case that shocked Israel and the world: the brutal murder of a Palestinian teenager named Muhammad Abu Khdeir, 16. He was abducted on July 2, 2014, beaten, choked and then burned to death.

headline: New York City Takes Steps to Better Fight Suits Against Police
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The Police Department has created a 40-member legal unit to uncover evidence to fight lawsuits, and the city’s Law Department has hired 30 lawyers to try more cases in court.
lead_paragraph: When New York City paid $5,000 last year to settle a lawsuit by a man who was shot in the leg by police officers after he had threatened them with a machete, outrage came from all corners: police unions, newspaper editorials and even Mayor Bill de Blasio, who condemned the deal struck by his own Law Department.

headline: John Kasich Needs a Big Showing in New Hampshire, but He’s Not Sweating It
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio needs big numbers in Tuesday’s New Hampshire primary to keep his campaign going, but is keeping to his relaxed, take-it-or-leave-it demeanor on the trail.
lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.H. — Gov. John Kasich desperately needs a strong showing here, and he has done his darnedest to make it happen, crisscrossing the state to hold 96 town-hall meetings, by his count.

headline: Donald Trump Ad Suggests He Has a Rainbow Coalition of Support
abstract: Uncharacteristically, Mr. Trump gives nearly half his 30-second commercial over to the voices of other people, including some who are not native English speakers.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s first advertisement since the Iowa caucuses lets a diverse group of “Voters Speak.”

headline: Power Struggle at Viacom as New Leader Is Named

lead_paragraph: With the ailing 92-year-old Sumner M. Redstone in his final act as a media titan, the two rivals jousting over the future of his $40 billion entertainment empire repeatedly crisscrossed the country in the last several months to visit his mansion in a gated Beverly Hills enclave.

headline: Luke Kuechly Turns Pick-Six Into a Common Occurrence
abstract: Kuechly, the Panthers linebacker, returned an interception for a touchdown in both of his playoff games this season; only two players have had more in their career.
lead_paragraph: Few plays are more exciting in football than the interception return for a touchdown, the pick-six. For one team, 6 points come out of nowhere; for the other, hope turns to despair.

headline: Wentworth Miller on Captain Cold’s Evolution and His Own, and on ‘DC’s Legends of Tomorrow’
abstract: The actor talks about his career and personal path, including plans for a “Prison Break” sequel, his battle with depression and coming out as gay three years ago.
lead_paragraph: Some characters die hard. For some TV viewers, Wentworth Miller will forever be Michael J. Scofield of “Prison Break,” a structural engineer determined to spring his brother, Lincoln Burrows (Dominic Purcell), from a penitentiary with the help of blueprints tattooed on his own upper body.

headline: Sexual Harassment in the Sciences: Readers React on Social Media
abstract: An article by The New York Times about Jason Lieb, a University of Chicago professor who stepped down amid a sexual harassment scandal, ignited a heated debate on social media.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Amy Harmon reported that a prominent professor at the University of Chicago had stepped down in response to accusations of sexual harassment. The article ignited a heated discussion on Twitter, with some readers sharing their experiences of harassment in the science field.

headline: ‘It’s Genital Genocide’
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Female Genital Mutilation', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Leyla was subject to female genital mutilation as a girl in Somalia. Now living in England, she’s a prominent advocate to end the practice.
lead_paragraph: Like many young girls, Leyla Hussein didn’t learn that she was going to have to undergo female genital mutilation until the day she was cut. She was born in Somalia and raised in Saudi Arabia and Italy but moved back to her homeland, where cutting is common, at age seven. “It was actually my next door neighbor’s daughter that told me when I realized there was a big party taking place in the house,” Leyla says. “She was telling me part of my vagina was going to be taken away. While she’s explaining I could hear this screaming inside of the house, which was my sister being cut.”

headline: If There Is a Recession in 2016, This Is How It Will Happen
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Credit and Debt', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Interest Rates']
abstract: Tumult in emerging markets and the commodities sectors could create both real and psychological hits to an economy that is already growing sluggishly.
lead_paragraph: More and more news headlines and stock market analysts’ reports have started predicting, or at least insinuating, that a recession could be near in the United States.

headline: How Ted Cruz Sees the World
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Global Warming', 'Native Americans', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Terrorism']

headline: Who Is Benjamin Millepied and Why Is He Leaving the Paris Ballet?
abstract: The choreographer is returning to Los Angeles with his wife, Natalie Portman, after just over a year leading the Paris Opera Ballet. Here’s a quick look at his career and the company.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer is returning to Los Angeles with his wife, Natalie Portman, after just over a year leading the Paris Opera Ballet. Here’s a quick look at his career and the company.

headline: To Strengthen the Carolina Panthers, Coach Ron Rivera Loosens His Grip
abstract: A self-regulated curfew is entirely fitting with the ethos of the team, which appears to have old-style leaders but takes an unconventional approach to most things, including play-calling.
lead_paragraph: SAN JOSE, Calif. — Thirty years ago, when Carolina Coach Ron Rivera played in the Super Bowl, his coach was Mike Ditka, a man known as Iron Mike. Rivera was a linebacker, and today he remains a large, imposing man with an aura of steely authority.

headline: Valtellinas Are No Longer Hiding in the Hills
abstract: The nebbiolo-based wine from Lombardy is experiencing a rebirth in interest, including a look from the Times tasting panel.
lead_paragraph: Way up in the foothills of the Alps, about as far north as you can go in the Lombardy region of Italy without hitting Switzerland, a series of terraced vineyards hug the hillsides overlooking the river Adda. With the majestic snowcapped massif to the north, the narrow river valley to the south and centuries-old castles crowning hilltops for good measure, this wine zone, Valtellina, is strikingly beautiful.

headline: D.C. Crime Bill Would Pay People to Avoid Committing Crimes
abstract: The payment model, based on a program in California, is just one part of a larger bill focused on reducing crime.
lead_paragraph: Avoid criminal activity for a chance to earn $9,000?

headline: The Detailed, Rich and Mysterious Work of Jan van Eyck
abstract: The 15th-century van Eyck diptych in a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art may have begun as the outer wings of a triptych.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago I made a long-imagined pilgrimage to Ghent, Belgium, to see at last one of the signal achievements in Western painting: Jan van Eyck’s altarpiece for St. Bavo’s Cathedral, painted in 1432. Its dozen panels (one a copy of a stolen portion) depict Jesus, Mary and John the Baptist above a green field in which angels kneel before a shining lamb, all done with an intense realism made possible through the new technology of oil paint.

headline: The New Generation of Nomadic Chefs
abstract: It used to be that owning a restaurant was every young chef’s dream. No longer.
lead_paragraph: These days, instead of pledging themselves to a respected restaurant (preferably Michelin-starred) and working their way up, some ambitious young chefs are going out on their own after only a few months at a renowned kitchen. They’re not opening restaurants of their own, however, but instead bouncing from place to place — a trend that’s coincided with the flourishing of restaurant takeovers and pop-up events.

headline: Bernie Sanders Gets Backing From Former N.A.A.C.P. Chief and a Nevada Union
abstract: Benjamin T. Jealous, a former N.A.A.C.P. president, endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders on Thursday, as did an electrical workers’ union in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: A former N.A.A.C.P. president is expected to endorse Bernie Sanders on Friday, in a move that could enhance the Vermont senator’s support among black voters across the country.

headline: For Filmmaker, Game’s Danger Trumps Thrill
keywords: ['Football', 'Television', 'Movies', 'Sports Injuries', 'Concussions', 'Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: Bob Carmichael, 68, once thought he’d rather die than not play football. Then he became one of the earliest voices to question the game’s place in America.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — In the mid-1970s, Bob Carmichael was a fast-rising man at NFL Films, a lieutenant in the young empire that was the National Football League. A former major-college football player, he helped produce those gloriously rich tapestries of athleticism; the long, slow spirals set against azure skies; the leaping, twisting grabs by receivers; and the thunderous hits.

headline: A Valentine’s Day Dinner You Can Make at Home
abstract: Our fearless food editor advises home cooks on gender stereotypes, an easy steak dinner and how to stock a beginner’s kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Have questions about recipes, cooking and food? My job is to answer them. Ask me anything: foodeditor@nytimes.com.

headline: Who Are the True Heirs of Zionism?
abstract: Israel is moving away from the vision of its largely secular founders.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — ZIONISM was never the gentlest of ideologies. The return of the Jewish people to their biblical homeland and the resumption of Jewish sovereignty there have always carried within them the displacement of those already living on the land.

headline: In Australia, a New Tactic in Battle Against Zika Virus: Mosquito Breeding
abstract: Residents in parts of Queensland are taking part in trials to breed mosquitoes from eggs injected with a bacteria that blocks the pests from carrying diseases like Zika and dengue.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Early next week, Michelle Littman plans to take a small cardboard noodle box, with some twine for a handle, into an overgrown part of her tropical suburban garden and do something rather counterintuitive — breed mosquitoes.

headline: New York State to Offer Free Zika Testing to Pregnant Travelers
abstract: The state will offer tests to all pregnant women who have been to a country affected by the Zika epidemic, regardless of whether they show symptoms, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday announced that New York State would offer free testing to all pregnant women who had traveled to a country experiencing a Zika outbreak, regardless of whether they were showing symptoms.

headline: On Stellar Rays Expands Its Lower East Side Universe

lead_paragraph: Candice Madey is arguably one of the art world’s Lower East Side pioneers, having first opened her gallery, On Stellar Rays, on Orchard Street in 2008. Five years later, she moved to her current second-floor space at 1 Rivington Street, and now she is expanding into that building’s storefront on the Bowery, as well as into its lower level.

headline: Poke Bowls Around Manhattan
abstract: A Hawaiian favorite says aloha to New York.
lead_paragraph: A Hawaiian favorite says aloha to New York.

headline: After Queens Slashing, Many Questions and a Young Life Upended
abstract: An unknown assailant sneaked up behind Jia Jia Liang, 16, a Chinese exchange student, in December and sliced her with a box cutter.
lead_paragraph: Two scars now mark the left side of Jia Jia Liang’s young face. One begins at the top of her cheekbone under her eye and runs in a surgically precise line to her jawline. The second begins closer to her ear and runs to her jaw. As they traverse her cheek, they are as parallel and orderly as train tracks.

keywords: ['Falsification of Data', 'Surgery and Surgeons', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Transplants']

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In an effort to diversify leadership in the upper ranks of the N.F.L., Commissioner Roger Goodell said on Thursday that the league would now require at least one woman be interviewed for any executive position openings in the league office.

headline: Young Democrats Flock to Bernie Sanders, Spurning Hillary Clinton’s Polish and Poise
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Youth', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Colleges and Universities']

headline: DNA Study of First Ancient African Genome Flawed, Researchers Report
abstract: When other researchers studied the 4,500-year-old-genome, they discovered that the conclusion that much of Africa has Eurasian ancestry was incorrect.
lead_paragraph: When scientists first started to figure out how to extract DNA from ancient skeletons, their success was met with astonishment. One minute, scientists were fishing Richard III’s genes from his royal bones, and the next they were showing off DNA retrieved from 500-year-old Incan mummies.

headline: An Artist and a Poet Contemplate Race
abstract: Using graphite and ink, the artist George Condo captures the tension of Rachel Zucker’s poem.
lead_paragraph: For T’s ongoing series, the painter and sculptor George Condo interpreted a poem by Rachel Zucker, the author of five books of poetry.

headline: The Lives and Lies of a Professional Impostor
abstract: “Jeremy Wilson,” now at Rikers Island facing fraud charges, has used dozens of aliases as a professor, a commando, numerous executives and an Irishman, among other cons.
lead_paragraph: He strolled into the police station in Chelsea on Jan. 4 wearing a Harvard sweatshirt, a “Wounded Warrior” cap and military dog tags dangling from his neck. He said he was Jeremiah Asimov-Beckingham, a veteran of Afghanistan, wounded in combat, now working as an executive for an airline. He had come to the station to pick up his car.

headline: Marco Rubio Supporters Move to Poach Donors From His Rivals

lead_paragraph: Supporters of Marco Rubio are inviting hundreds of current and potential Rubio donors to a strategy meeting in New York inmid-February, hoping to capitalize on a potential strong finish in the New Hampshire primary to poach donors.

headline: Credit Suisse’s Painful Turnaround Is Falling Short

headline: Valentine’s Day Etiquette: How to Handle Tricky Situations
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', "Valentine's Day", 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: Also: teaching Valentine etiquette to a second grader; an age-old question from a new man on the market; and finishing second to a race.
lead_paragraph: I am living a gender-stereotype reversal and am embarrassed about it. Here goes: I love my girlfriend of two months, and she treats me really well. But she is not demonstrative. She never volunteers an “I love you,” but I can tell she does by her loving ways. (Also, when I ask her if she loves me, she says yes.) But sometimes, I sense her pulling away for short periods. Should I say something about this as Valentine’s Day approaches?

headline: Legal Marijuana Sales Hit $5.4 Billion in 2015, Report Says
abstract: Marijuana is getting more respect as legal sales rose from $4.6 billion in 2014, according to a report by two analysis and investment firms.

headline: U.N. Peacekeepers Accused of Rape in Central African Republic

headline: 10 Indian Soldiers Feared Dead in Avalanche on Himalayan Glacier

headline: Ex-Prosecutor’s Job: Flag N.F.L. Players
abstract: When players are accused of crimes, Lisa Friel, who worked in the Manhattan district attorney’s office for 28 years, investigates potential code-of-conduct violations for the league.
lead_paragraph: A shortstop for the Colorado Rockies is charged with grabbing his wife by the throat and shoving her into a hotel’s sliding glass door. headline: Yasiin Bey Arrest Gives World Passport Visibility

lead_paragraph: There is a point at which you may find yourself so at odds with your country — over its policies, its people or other matters — that you no longer want to be a citizen. Which passport should you travel under if you leave? One group has created a solution for such a scenario: the World Passport, which doesn’t explicitly label you as a citizen of any nation.

headline: At Live Ideas Festival, a Twist on an Arab Dance and Scenes From Gaza
abstract: The festival at New York Live Arts features “Badke,” by the Belgian company Les Ballets C de la B, and “Archive,” by the Israeli choreographer Arkadi Zaides.
lead_paragraph: Every wedding has its communal dance. (In the United States, often, it’s the moves to “Y.M.C.A.”) In many Arab countries, it’s dabke, a twisting, weaving follow-the-leader line dance comprising small stomps, low kicks and clasped hands. It can be slow and contained, or rousing and athletic. That tradition anchors “Badke,” a work by the much-admired Belgian company Les Ballets C de la B that is part of the Live Ideas festival at New York Live Arts, focusing this year on the Middle East and North Africa. “Badke” developed over several years in workshops in the West Bank city of Ramallah and includes 10 Palestinian performers; the title’s scrambled letters suggest a familiar ritual with a twist (Thursday, Feb. 11, through Saturday, Feb. 13). On Tuesday and Wednesday, Arkadi Zaides, one of the few Israeli choreographers explicitly grappling with politics in his work, presents “Archive,” featuring film footage from Gaza. On Saturday, the creators of both shows sit down to discuss the role of art in a seemingly interminable conflict. (212-924-0077, newyorklivearts.org.)

abstract: I should be used to strangers bending and twisting my military service to suit their needs. But I’m not.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Donald J. Trump removed himself from the Republican debate last week and threw a huge public relations party for himself, he did what many politicians before him have done: He cynically used United States military veterans to elevate his own political standing. His alt-rally, called a “Special Event to Benefit Veterans Organizations,” held in Des Moines, was the type of circus we’ve come to expect from the former reality TV star turned politician.

headline: Tobias Lindholm Narrates a Scene From ‘A War’

lead_paragraph: The drama “A War” (opening Feb. 12) looks at the Danish military’s involvement in the war in Afghanistan and a moral conflict one commander has in the midst of it. The film is from Tobias Lindholm and is the follow-up to “A Hijacking,” his procedural that looked at the takeover of a Danish cargo ship by pirates. “A War” has received an Oscar nomination for best foreign language film. In this scene, snipers observe, and try to take down, a Taliban fighter who is transporting an improvised explosive device. In a recent interview, Mr. Lindholm discussed the scene and the research that went into his film. Here are excerpts from that conversation.

keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Sixty-two percent of Americans say the government doesn’t do enough for the middle class. Republican candidates should pay attention.
lead_paragraph: It can be hard to discern what most Americans want from the federal government when some of the loudest candidates are trying to win votes by promising to build continent-sized walls and carpet bombing neighborhoods in the Middle East. That’s why a Pew Research Center report published Thursday is so important: Sixty-two percent of the people Pew surveyed said the government is not doing enough for the middle class.

abstract: Based on a book by Nicholas Sparks, the film stars Teresa Palmer and Benjamin Walker as a pair who fall in love amid rain-soaked trysts and ocean sunsets.
lead_paragraph: “The Choice” is the 11th film to ooze from the syrupy scribblings of Nicholas Sparks, who informs us in the publicity notes that he considers it to be “even more memorable and profound” than his 1996 sobfest, “The Notebook” (filmed in 2004). Clearly his talent for emotional manipulation far exceeds his humility.

headline: Review: In ‘Washer/Dryer,’ a Marriage Goes Through the Spin Cycle
abstract: In this play by Nandita Shenoy, the only thing that stands in the way of blissful living is a co-op that a wife refuses to give up.
lead_paragraph: Sonya and Michael weren’t planning on a wedding when they got that Groupon deal for a trip to Las Vegas. But at the hotel, she asked for the honeymoon suite, and he took it as a hint. Now they’re back in New York, married, and he’s moving into her studio on the Upper East Side.

headline: Health Care Signups Exceed Hopes, With 4 Million Newcomers to Federal Marketplace
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid']
abstract: About 12.7 million people signed up for health coverage under the Affordable Care Act or had their coverage renewed in the third annual open enrollment season.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — About 12.7 million people signed up for health insurance under the Affordable Care Act or had their coverage automatically renewed in the third annual open enrollment season, the Obama administration said Thursday.

headline: Review: In ‘The Wedge Horse,’ Family, Tragedy and Candy
abstract: Siblings try to decide how to honor the memory of their brother, who died on Sept. 11, in Nick Gandiello’s affecting if overwrought drama.
lead_paragraph: Convenience store snacks and the reverberations of a national tragedy are fodder for “The Wedge Horse,” Nick Gandiello’s affecting if overwrought drama for Fault Line Theater. During the winter of 2003, Maddy (Ali Rose Dachis), her brother Bobby (Charlie Thurston) and their friend Los (Jorge Eliézar Chacón) meet on a decrepit Long Island Railroad platform to discuss Sour Patch Kids, life and fate.

headline: Review: In Company XIV’s ‘Snow White,’ the Evil Queen Lands a Racy Gig
abstract: Blending dance and music in a burlesque style, the production features a leering queen, cavorting henchmen, an ambitious Snow White, dwarf puppets and sex toys.
lead_paragraph: Her name may not be in the title, but Company XIV’s “Snow White” is all about the Queen. In this production, which had its debut at the Minetta Lane Theater on Wednesday, the Queen is played with relish by the actor-dancer Laura Careless, who has the kind of wicked smile that suggests fangs. That leer goes well both with her Marie Antoinette outfit and with the lingerie that’s exposed as she’s stripped by her mirror-bearing henchmen, who wear fishnets on their legs and jeweled ball gags in their mouths.

headline: Review: ‘Eisenstein in Guanajuato’ Explores 10 Days That Changed a Filmmaker’s Life and Work
abstract: This comedic fantasy from Peter Greenaway about Sergei Eisenstein’s trip to Mexico in the 1930s quotes Eisenstein at length, while imagining a scandalous personal life.
lead_paragraph: Sex and death, or in the elevated language of the British director Peter Greenaway, “Eros and Thanatos,” walk hand in hand in “Eisenstein in Guanajuato.” This comedic fantasy from Mr. Greenaway about the seminal Russian filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein’s trip to Mexico in the early 1930s quotes Eisenstein at length, while imagining a scandalous personal life, about which little is known. Referring to his classic film “October: Ten Days That Shook the World,” Eisenstein calls this working vacation “the 10 days that shook Eisenstein.”

headline: A Very Different Kind of Immersive Art Installation
abstract: The pieces in teamLab’s “Living Digital Space and Future Parks,” in Menlo Park, involve light, sound, video, digital sequences and virtual-reality environments.
lead_paragraph: There’s an old phrase in Japanese, Toudai moto kurashi, which translates to “the lighthouse does not shine on its base” — that is, you can see everything around you except what’s closest. It’s a useful saying to keep in mind as, this week, the Japanese tech-art collective teamLab unveils its largest installation to date: 20 works inside 20,000 square feet. As the inaugural exhibition for Pace’s newly minted Art+Technology program, housed in the gallery’s Menlo Park space, it places tech-based art directly in the heart of Silicon Valley — to completely surprising effect. “We respect Silicon Valley exceedingly, but, as things are happening all the time, we aren’t paying it a lot of attention,” says Toshiyuki Inoko, the collective’s founder. “TeamLab wants to contribute to mankind through a different role than Silicon Valley.” The exhibition, titled “Living Digital Space and Future Parks,” aims to be a disruptor — and not in the tech-jargon sense, but rather more literally. “We want to think about a new way for art to be,” Inoko says. “Not just works of art, but including everything: space, viewers, even the market.”

headline: Review: ’Utility,’ a Woman’s Dance With Despair
abstract: The play, by Emily Schwend, is a domestic drama about a young mother raising three children on the low wages of her shift-work jobs.
lead_paragraph: Around her ragged little East Texas home, Amber does just about everything that needs doing. Barely past 30, raising three young kids on the paltry wages of her pair of shift-work jobs, she is exhausted by the constant scramble. In this weakened state, she lets her husband, Chris, a serial cheater, wheedle her into giving him another chance.

headline: At One Modeling Agency, Nonconformity Is Key
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Men and Boys', 'Models (Professional)', "Men's Fashion Week", 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The Düsseldorf-based Tomorrow Is Another Day has launched dozens of careers and now represents several popular male models.
lead_paragraph: For Eva Gödel, the owner and founder of Düsseldorf-based model agency Tomorrow Is Another Day, model-scouting is more than just a job. “The thing is, I’m always looking everywhere,” she says. “In the middle of the shopping street, I can stand there for eight hours and just look. The more people, the better for me. Some of my best boys I found when I was driving in my car!”

lead_paragraph: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

headline: Poor Jeb!
keywords: ['Debates (Political)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: His exit from the race would be no loss — except for one thing.
lead_paragraph: Jeb Bush is getting desperate.

headline: Review: ‘West of Eden’ — Hollywood Not-So-Confidential
abstract: In an oral history, Jean Stein chronicles the bad behavior — and worse — of an old ruling class.
lead_paragraph: In 1971, Edie Sedgwick, the subject of Jean Stein’s last book, died in Santa Barbara of an overdose of alcohol and barbiturates. That same year, Jennifer Jones, one of the principal figures in Ms. Stein’s new “West of Eden,” staged a theatrical suicide attempt by walking into the ocean in Malibu, with good reason to expect she would be rescued. She was. She lived until 2009, surviving a troubled daughter, an even more unhinged son and two very rich husbands, David O. Selznick and Norton Simon. Even when running out of money, she insisted on spending $500 a month to have her sheets pressed.

headline: Review: Craig Finn and a Bleak Vision of America at the Appel Room
abstract: Mr. Finn’s American Songbook concert on Wednesday evening was dominated by songs from his gloomy “Faith in the Future” album.
lead_paragraph: “Certain songs, they get so scratched into our souls.” That line from “Certain Songs,” the opening number in Craig Finn’s American Songbook concert at the Appel Room on Wednesday evening, wonderfully describes how pop songs take hold of you without your even realizing it. Whenever you hear them, they transport you back in time (in this case to 1977 and the moment of Billy Joel’s “Only the Good Die Young” and Meat Loaf’s “Paradise by the Dashboard Light”).

headline: Review: In ‘Fort Buchanan,’ Making Love and War
abstract: Benjamin Crotty’s film, set at a French fort, follows a young woman, her two fathers and all the amorous military spouses and lovers around them.
lead_paragraph: “Fort Buchanan,” a witty and eccentric debut feature from the filmmaker Benjamin Crotty, who was raised in the United States but is based in France, seems to have been born of an inspired mix-up, as if someone had hired the postcolonialist director Claire Denis (“Beau Travail”) to shoot an episode of “M*A*S*H.”

headline: Review: ‘Hex’ Explores Shape-Shifting and Transference
abstract: The dance duo robbinschilds, created by Sonya Robbins and Layla Childs, expands for this work, in which dance movements are passed among different bodies.
lead_paragraph: Can collaboration be seen as a feminist platform? The dance duo robbinschilds — formed in 2003 by Sonya Robbins and Layla Childs — is giving that idea a shot by branching out, choreographically speaking, to include six dancers in the creation of “Hex,” the pair’s latest work. It’s a female collective, but is it feminist? In the end, the fight against artistic hierarchy is more noble than effective. Topping the lengthy list of what “Hex” is missing is a point of view.

headline: Review: ‘Pride and Prejudice and Zombies’; More Tea, Dear?
abstract: In this undead ravishing of the Jane Austen novel, Elizabeth Bennet must deal with creatures much, much worse than Mr. Darcy.
lead_paragraph: As it turns out, fighting zombies does nothing to improve on the original Elizabeth Bennet, Jane Austen’s heroine from “Pride and Prejudice.” In “Pride and Prejudice and Zombies,” a character claiming to be Elizabeth Bennet (Lily James), wields swords and other deadly blades, fires guns and occasionally flashes a leg in order to stomp on a zombie head. Battling the undead keeps her, friends and family safe from the flesh-eating hordes, but the character has been so radically transformed from Austen’s that Elizabeth already feels like a goner.

headline: Review: Seeking Common Ground in ‘Chatting With the Tea Party’
abstract: Mr. Orloff, in this play, seeks to humanize members of a group dismissed by his friends and characterized as loudmouth reactionaries.
lead_paragraph: Rich Orloff calls his “Chatting With the Tea Party” a “documentary-style play,” but it’s also a personal-journey play, which is what saves it from being either too dry or too smarmy.

headline: End of the Road May Be Near for Side Mirrors
abstract: Many automakers are demonstrating video systems that replace side mirrors with cameras, but it may take drivers some time to get used to them.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE engineers dreamed of eliminating drivers in cars, they imagined eliminating the side mirrors. The protuberances are ugly, create aerodynamic drag, and their associated blind spots are the bane of parking-challenged drivers everywhere.

headline: Review: ‘The Pack’ Pits a Family Against Vicious Wild Dogs
abstract: Nick Robertson’s Australian film, set on a remote sheep farm in the Outback, is in some ways reminiscent of “Cujo,” but offers far less plot.
lead_paragraph: Filmmakers have known since at least 1983 that it takes more than snarling dogs to make a decent snarling-dog horror movie. That’s the year that “Cujo,” the film version of Stephen King’s novel, came out, and in addition to the fearsome title character, a deranged St. Bernard, it had a disintegrating marriage, a boy who was afraid of monsters, and more to help add interest.

headline: Dog Collars Continue to Fetch Top Dollar
abstract: A silver collar made in 1883 for a Scotch collie named Help is estimated to sell for $2,500 to $3,500 at Bonhams on Feb. 17.
lead_paragraph: Dog collars, whether circlets made of precious metal or spiked leather straps, can yield insights into socioeconomic history and family tragedies. This year collars with poignant back stories are surfacing at museums and on the market.

headline: Senator Rob Portman to Oppose Pacific Trade Pact
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The announcement by Mr. Portman, a former trade ambassador to President George W. Bush, illustrates the congressional headwinds facing the 12-nation trade accord.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a clear sign of the trouble facing President Obama’s trade pact with Pacific Rim nations, one of the most influential congressional Republicans on trade issues announced on Thursday that he would oppose it unless significant changes were made.

headline: Super Bowl Halftime History: It’s Been a Long Time Since Those Sousaphones
abstract: The Super Bowl’s halftime show has changed, really changed. A brief history, from Grambling State’s marching band to Beyoncé and Coldplay.
lead_paragraph: During the 2015 Super Bowl halftime show, 118.5 million viewers watched Katy Perry ride onto the field on a giant metallic lion, change costumes three times and soar above the crowd as fireworks bombarded the sky. But it wasn’t always this way: Over the past 50 years, the break between halves of the N.F.L.’s championship game has transformed from a showcase for college sousaphonists into a global marketing opportunity for pop superstars. This is how a 12-minute pause on the field evolved into a barometer of American pop culture in a dozen pivotal performances.

headline: Review: In ‘Tumbledown,’ a Book Is the Third Party in a Love Triangle
abstract: Rebecca Hall plays the young grieving widow of an acclaimed indie-folk singer and Jason Sudeikis his brash biographer in this dramedy directed by Sean Mewshaw.
lead_paragraph: When Hannah (Rebecca Hall) is introduced in “Tumbledown,” roaming her rustic Maine cabin and working at a typewriter next to her two dogs, you half expect the scene to turn into a coffee commercial (maybe right after the canine reaction shot). The dawdling city-country dramedy that follows could have used the caffeine for its slack story of love after grief.

headline: Marco Rubio ‘Super PAC’ Taunts Jeb Bush for Poor Showing
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Advertising', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: In an attempt to grab the moderate Republican vote, the ad, calling Mr. Bush “Not the Answer,” describes Mr. Bush’s well-financed, yet sagging campaign.
lead_paragraph: With negative ads being lobbed at their candidate from all sides, the “super PAC” supporting Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, Conservative Solutions PAC, is broadcasting a spot calling Jeb Bush “Not the Answer.”

headline: Under Pressure, F.D.A. Adds Measures on Opioid Abuse
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'OxyContin (Drug)', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Naloxone (Drug)']
abstract: Dr. Robert Califf, the acting commissioner, acknowledged the broader concern from Congress as the agency had come under fire for continuing to approve opioids.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from Congress to take action amid a worsening opioid epidemic, the Food and Drug Administration on Thursday announced several measures aimed at dealing with abuse.

headline: ‘Vikings,’ Here to Set the Record Straight
abstract: This exhibition presents archaeological objects aimed at shedding new light and correcting misconceptions about Scandinavia’s ancient seafarers.
lead_paragraph: The new “Vikings” exhibition at Discovery Times Square is, in a sense, built around something that isn’t there.

headline: Review: ‘Southbound’ Tells Five Horror Tales, All Set on a Desolate Highway
abstract: This anthology film, by the directors Roxanne Benjamin, David Bruckner, Patrick Horvath and the collective Radio Silence, presents characters who need to escape (and can’t).
lead_paragraph: “Southbound” is something you don’t see much anymore: an anthology horror film. Its five segments do what they’re supposed to do — unsettle you — but as a bonus, they also leave you wanting more. These are fragments more than complete stories, and the incompleteness is its own kind of creepiness.

headline: Review: In ‘I Knew Her Well,’ Stefania Sandrelli Reaches for la Dolce Vita
abstract: In this restored 1965 film from the writer-director Antonio Pietrangeli, a would-be starlet fitfully ascends the social stratum.
lead_paragraph: In the opening shot of this newly restored 1965 Italian film, the camera moves snakelike across a deserted, litter-strewn beach, finally resting on a beautiful woman, sunbathing and asleep, a droning transistor radio next to her head. This shot is arguably a distillation of the writer-director Antonio Pietrangeli’s entire picture, but the subsequent 113 minutes are very much worth sticking around for.

headline: Three Shows Celebrate Hiro
abstract: The fashion photographer is the subject of retrospectives this season in London, New York and Boston.
lead_paragraph: The fashion photographer is the subject of retrospectives this season in London, New York and Boston.

headline: Indelible Images From a Fashion Photography Icon
abstract: Three separate retrospectives this season, in New York, London and Boston, celebrate the five-decade career of Hiro.
lead_paragraph: Throughout his five-decade (and counting) career, the fashion photographer Hiro has shot everything from surrealist still lifes to album covers — creating a vast, wide-ranging archive of work that’s big enough to support three (!) retrospectives this season. (Two shows of his work are now on view in Boston and London; another opens later this month in New York at Pace/MacGill.)

headline: For Children Listings for Feb. 5-11
abstract: The firefly is very lonely. The caterpillar is very hungry. The sea horse is very swollen. (He happens to be, if you’ll pardon the expression, very pregnant.) But the children? They’re just very happy.
lead_paragraph: The firefly is very lonely. The caterpillar is very hungry. The sea horse is very swollen. (He happens to be, if you’ll pardon the expression, very pregnant.) But the children? They’re just very happy.

headline: U.N. Report Accuses Rwanda of Training Rebels to Oust Burundian Leader
abstract: The report said investigators had spoken with 18 Burundian rebels who claimed to have been trained inside Rwanda.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — A confidential United Nations report that became public this week accused the Rwandan government of secretly training rebels to overthrow the president of Burundi, a country rapidly sliding toward chaos.

lead_paragraph: The retired New York Times sportswriters Dave Anderson and Frank Litsky look back at some memories of covering the N.F.L.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘4th Man Out,’ a Film About Friendship and Coming Out
abstract: Adam, a mechanic in his 20s who has recently come out, tries dating apps with the encouragement of his three lifelong buddies.
lead_paragraph: In this tender, funny, but none too daring film, Adam, a regular guy who works as a mechanic in his little hometown, comes out on his 24th birthday. After a night of serious partying, he shares the news with his three lifelong buddies, who are completely gobsmacked.

headline: ‘Laura Poitras: Astro Noise’ Examines Surveillance and the New Normal
keywords: ['Art', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'September 11 (2001)', 'Classified Information and State Secrets']
abstract: The Whitney offers an engrossing solo show by an artist best known for films documenting surveillance and the post-Sept. 11 “war on terror.”
lead_paragraph: Political art has changed over the past 50 years. Unlike the protest art of an earlier era, much of the most interesting new work feels slippery and evasive, as if reluctant to speak its mind. In part, this is a reflection of different, though not necessarily evolved, thinking. We’ve abandoned old beliefs in utopias, in visions — some would say hallucinations — of a society built on absolute good for all, in which art plays a declaratively positive role. The 1960s counterculture, even at its most anarchic, was based on such beliefs and visions. And that counterculture is long gone.

headline: Confidential United Nations Report on Burundi
abstract: A leaked document accuses the Rwandan government of secretly training rebels to overthrow the president of Burundi.
lead_paragraph: A leaked document accuses the Rwandan government of secretly training rebels to overthrow the president of Burundi.

headline: Review: ‘The Club’ Sees the World Through the Eyes of Damaged Souls
abstract: Pablo Larraín’s film brings the viewer into an uncomfortable state of intimacy with disgraced priests who are perpetrators of hideous crimes.
lead_paragraph: Tom McCarthy’s “Spotlight,” deservedly nominated for a bunch of Oscars, examines evil from the outside, shining a beam of journalistic illumination at the abuse and corruption that festered within the Roman Catholic hierarchy for decades. “The Club,” the latest feature from the Chilean writer-director Pablo Larraín, looks at the same issue from the inside out, bringing the viewer into an uncomfortable state of intimacy with the perpetrators of hideous crimes.

headline: Watch Live: Iowa Caucuses
abstract: Check out the scenes for Republicans and Democrats, as voters gather for the first time in the 2016 presidential election.
lead_paragraph: Check out the scenes for Republicans and Democrats, as voters gather for the first time in the 2016 presidential election.

headline: Review: ‘Misconduct’ Stars Josh Duhamel and Anthony Hopkins in a Tale of Corporate Evil
abstract: This action thriller, the directorial debut of Shintaro Shimosawa, also features Al Pacino as a lawyer caught in a power struggle with a corrupt pharmaceutical executive.
lead_paragraph: On paper, it sounds juicy: “An ambitious lawyer (Josh Duhamel) finds himself caught in a power struggle between a corrupt pharmaceutical executive (Anthony Hopkins) and his firm’s senior partner (Al Pacino). When the case takes a deadly turn, he must race to uncover the truth before he loses everything.”

headline: 101 Years Ago: ‘The Birth of a Nation’ Had its First Screenings
abstract: D.­W. Griffith’s film had instantly anointed him king of the movies, but from its first screenings it also had drawn considerable protest.
lead_paragraph: We can’t undo history, but we can mess with how the Internet sees it. Try Googling “The Birth of a Nation,” for example. Since its lauded premiere at the Sundance Film Festival last week, this new movie by Nate Parker has burned up the search engines, going head-to-head with that old racist cinematic masterpiece by D. W. Griffith from 1915. Which is exactly the kind of refocusing of history’s lens that Mr. Parker intended when he wrote, directed and starred in a slave-rebellion story, snatching the identical title from Griffith.

headline: Peter Fischli and David Weiss Playfully Poke High-Culture Pieties
abstract: In an exhibition at the Guggenheim, these two Swiss artists (Mr. Weiss died in 2012) upend high culture with their sculptures, photographs and movies.
lead_paragraph: In his classic tome “Homo Ludens: A Study of the Play-Element in Culture,” the Dutch historian Johan Huizinga declared that “genuine, pure play is one of the main bases of civilization.” If that’s true, then the art-making team of Fischli and Weiss — Peter Fischli (born in 1952) and David Weiss (1946–2012) — have been among the contemporary world’s eminently civilizing influences. Few other artists have been more infectiously playful than this Swiss duo, as visitors to the Guggenheim Museum will be delighted to find in  “Peter Fischli David Weiss: How to Work Better.”

headline: A Word With: Raquelin Mendieta
abstract: The performance artist Ana Mendieta died in 1985, but her older sister, Raquelin, discusses why a cache of films she made is now being exhibited.
lead_paragraph: When the Cuban-born artist Ana Mendieta died in 1985 at the age of 36 after falling from her apartment window in Greenwich Village (her husband, the sculptor Carl Andre, was  acquitted of her murder), she left behind an unruly body of work whose sweep belied the number of years she had to make it.

headline: Questions on Speeches to Goldman Sachs Vex Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: With rivals pouncing on her ties to corporate America, experts say Mrs. Clinton needs to justify accepting speaking fees as high as $225,000. And quickly.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Here’s how we analyzed the fifth Democratic debate in real time, and our live fact checks.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s campaign has started emailing supporters asking them to flood New Hampshire as volunteers.

headline: Aiding Peyton Manning’s Return: Tiring, but Not Thankless
abstract: Jordan Taylor, a rookie on the Broncos’ scout team, became Peyton Manning’s personal practice partner as the quarterback recuperated from an injury.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — About two hours before kickoff Sunday, one of the most important members of the Denver Broncos will walk onto the field at Levi’s Stadium to prepare for the Super Bowl. He plans to run for a bit, and catch 50 to 75 passes. After finishing his pregame routine, he will retreat to the locker room, cool down and change.

headline: ‘Anri Sala: Answer Me’ Offers Symphonic Experience From Floor to Floor
abstract: A three-floor solo exhibition at the New Museum features audio and video installations by the Albanian video artist.
lead_paragraph: Certain artworks imprint themselves on the brain. “Dammi i Colori,” a 2003 video by the Albanian artist Anri Sala, seems permanently lodged in mine. I first saw it at the Venice Biennale that year, mesmerized by this D.I.Y. documentary’s effortless argument for the necessity of art and its potential as balm for a traumatized city.

headline: Three Big Art Shows Are Opening in New York This Week
abstract: Laura Poitras gets her first solo museum show at the Whitney, plus major exhibitions at the Guggenheim and the New Museum.
lead_paragraph: Laura Poitras gets her first solo museum show at the Whitney, plus major exhibitions at the Guggenheim and the New Museum.

headline: Maurice White, Founder and Leader of Earth, Wind & Fire, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. White and his band were award-winning hit makers for much of the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Maurice White, the founder and leader of Earth, Wind & Fire, whose genre-defying music made it one of the most successful bands of the 1970s, has died at his home in Los Angeles. He was 74.

headline: Bill Seeks to Limit Use of Arbitration to Avoid Courts
keywords: ['ARBITRATION, CONCILIATION AND MEDIATION', 'Consumer Protection', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A Senate bill would prevent civil rights cases, employment disputes and other critical lawsuits from being forced into arbitration, a process often stacked against consumers.
lead_paragraph: Two leading Senate Democrats introduced a bill Thursday that would strictly limit the use of arbitration, a process used to resolve legal disputes that is often stacked against consumers.

headline: Donald Trump’s Ground Game Questioned After Iowa Showing
abstract: Mr. Trump’s campaign definitely has a lot of volunteers, but it appears to lack the basics of a good field organization with the ability to identify, target and turn out voters.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — David Carney, a veteran Republican strategist here, has received six phone calls at his Hancock, N.H., home from Donald J. Trump’s campaign the last few days. But five came after the Trump volunteers were told that the occupants were backing another candidate: Mr. Carney’s wife is Carly Fiorina’s campaign director in the state.

headline: Carly Fiorina Excluded From Final Republican Debate Before New Hampshire Primary
abstract: Though Republican candidates past and present had been arguing for Mrs. Fiorina to be included, she did not meet the polling standards set by ABC News, the host of the debate on Saturday. The debate will feature Donald J. Trump, Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush, John Kasich, Chris Christie, and Ben Carson.
lead_paragraph: The debate lineup is set, the podium alignment announced, and Carly Fiorina is still not added to the debate stage.

headline: Fifth Democratic Debate: Analysis
abstract: We analyzed the fifth Democratic debate, the last before the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, in real time.

headline: Washington: Brothers Charged in Murders at a Homeless Camp
abstract: Three brothers, ages 13, 16 and 17, were charged with first-degree murder on Thursday in the killings last month of two people at a homeless encampment in Seattle.
lead_paragraph: Three brothers, ages 13, 16 and 17, were charged with first-degree murder on Thursday in the killings last month of two people at a homeless encampment in Seattle. Prosecutors said the boys, also homeless, had intended to steal drugs and money. Three other people were wounded. The brothers James Taafulisia, 17, and Jerome K. Taafulisia, 16, were charged as adults, King County Prosecuting Attorney Daniel T. Satterberg said. The 13-year-old will be tried as a juvenile, and if convicted, could be held only until he is 21.

headline: Unicef Report Finds Female Genital Cutting to Be Common in Indonesia
keywords: ['Female Genital Mutilation', 'Women and Girls', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: A study by the agency found that the practice, long known as a ritual in Africa and parts of the Middle East, included almost half the women of Indonesia.
lead_paragraph: Female genital cutting has always been seen as an ancient ritual practiced in Africa and to a lesser extent in the Middle East, but a new global assessment documents for the first time that it is widespread in one of the most populous countries in Asia: Indonesia, where almost half the women are estimated to have undergone it.

headline: Marco Rubio Sees Bounce in Latest New Hampshire Poll
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: A new survey of New Hampshire voters confirmed that Senator Marco Rubio has quickly become the candidate to beat in the state’s primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, N.H. — One of the most respected surveys of New Hampshire voters confirmed on Thursday that Senator Marco Rubio of Florida has quickly become the candidate to beat in the state’s primary on Tuesday, a sudden rise that has reordered the Republican primary race and unnerved his rivals.

headline: Mary Fiumara, Mother in Indelible Prince Spaghetti Ad, Dies at 88
abstract: Mrs. Fiumara played the devoted mother who shouted “Anthony! Anthony!” from her apartment window in a commercial for Prince spaghetti that ran for 13 years.
lead_paragraph: From Juliet to Alice Kramden, women have communed from their upper-story windows, but few ever reached a wider audience with as mundane a message as Mary Fiumara.

headline: C.D.C. Issues Zika Advisory for Pregnant Women and Sex Partners
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Sex', 'Condoms', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention urged pregnant women whose male partners have spent time in a Zika-affected country to abstain from sex or use condoms during their pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: Pregnant women whose male sexual partners have spent time in a country with confirmed transmissions of the Zika virus should either abstain from sex or use condoms during intercourse for the duration of their pregnancy, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has announced.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Lays Out Vision for New York in State of the City Address
keywords: ['State of the City Message (NYC)', 'Transit Systems', 'Carriages', 'Cable Cars and Trams', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The mayor adapted his liberal ambitions to a broad range of projects aimed at the everyday dangers and inconveniences of New York City life.
lead_paragraph: Speaking of power-washed streets free of graffiti and new infrastructure projects along the waterfront, Mayor Bill de Blasio on Thursday laid out a vision of New York that would gleam from pavement to rooftop, while renewing his pledge to create a more equal city without diminishing its quality of life.

headline: Video Review: The BMW X5 xDrive40e, a Hybrid for the Future
abstract: The fuel savings may not offset the cost at today’s prices, but this well-engineered and smooth-driving S.U.V requires no other sacrifices of its owner.
lead_paragraph: INEXPENSIVE gasoline has fueled sales of the crossovers and sport utility vehicles that Americans love. That’s good for the automakers’ bottom line, but it also presents a challenge as fuel economy standards get stricter.

headline: 2 New York City Police Officers Are Shot in the Bronx
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: The officers were struck in the Bronx at a housing project, and one was seriously wounded, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Two New York City police officers patrolling a public housing complex in the Bronx were shot Thursday night by a gunman who fled into an apartment and killed himself, the police said. The officers were in stable condition and alert late Thursday.

headline: A Mishandled Concussion Leads to a Review of Protocol
abstract: St. Louis quarterback Case Keenum was not taken out of a game despite being disoriented after he was knocked to the ground.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The N.F.L. said it may change its concussion protocol after coaches and officials mishandled St. Louis Rams quarterback Case Keenum, who was not removed from a game despite being disoriented after being knocked to the ground.

headline: Deal Shows Investors Are Willing to Make a Blind Bet on Uber
abstract: The institutional investors will not receive financial details about Uber or direct equity in the company.
lead_paragraph: A deal about to close on Wall Street illustrates just how much some investors are willing to give up to gain a piece of the hottest start-up.

headline: Emails Reveal Early Suspicions of a Flint Link to Legionnaires’ Disease
abstract: Emails indicate that county health officials were concerned last March about a wave of Legionnaires’ cases, and were at the time raising the possibility of a link to the Flint River.
lead_paragraph: Michigan state officials were aware of an increase in Legionnaires’ disease cases and a possible tie to Flint’s troubled water supply at least 10 months before Gov. Rick Snyder informed the public of the situation last month, newly obtained emails show.

headline: What You Missed in the Debate
abstract: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton faced off in their first one-on-one debate before New Hampshire’s primary on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed the fifth Democratic debate in real time, and our live fact checks.

headline: Citi Field and Yankee Stadium Could Become Off Limits to Smokeless Tobacco
keywords: ['Smoking and Tobacco', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Baseball', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A New York City Council member is set to introduce a bill that that would ban smokeless tobacco from public arenas in the five boroughs.
lead_paragraph: Quietly during the 2015 baseball season, Major League Baseball and the players’ union jointly hired Dr. Michael Steinberg, the director of the Rutgers University tobacco-dependence program, to serve as a consultant to the sport. If any player or other club employee wanted to quit using smokeless tobacco, Dr. Steinberg was available to develop a confidential treatment plan.

headline: Everyone Loses if Britain Exits the E.U.
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: A British exit would deal a serious blow to a European Union already battered by an economic crisis and an immigration crisis.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of a British exit from the European Union has been around for a long time. Britain never fully warmed to the idea of the European Union, and the “euroskeptics” clamoring to get out give the impression that nothing the union could offer would sway them.

headline: Government Forces, Backed by Russian Jets, Advance in Syria
abstract: The government’s recent gains have diminished pressure on President Bashar al-Assad to compromise in negotiations.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — Syrian government forces supported by heavy Russian airstrikes advanced in the country’s north on Thursday, nearly surrounding rebels in the city of Aleppo and displacing thousands of civilians.

headline: A Waterfront Route to Serve the Poor, Not Just the Wealthy
keywords: ['Cable Cars and Trams', 'Gentrification', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: A planned streetcar line running from Brooklyn to Queens would provide a lifeline for a stretch of real estate that is starved of transit options.
lead_paragraph: Bill de Blasio has promised to undo one of history’s great blunders.

headline: Elation and Skepticism Over Proposal for Streetcars in Brooklyn and Queens
abstract: Some residents agree that a 16-mile streetcar line running through the neighborhoods would ease commutes, but it would also mean having to live through several years of construction.
lead_paragraph: It is a frustrating conundrum of commuting in the boroughs of New York City outside Manhattan: A destination in Brooklyn or Queens might be just a few miles away, but getting there by public transportation can be a trek. It might involve long walks, long bus rides or, quite possibly, a swing through Manhattan by train.

headline: Construction Worker, 62, Dies in Fall From East Harlem Building
abstract: The police said Konstantinos Potamousis, who worked for a company in Astoria, Queens, was replacing roof gutters on the six-story building on East 107th Street.
lead_paragraph: A construction worker was killed on Thursday after falling from a building undergoing repair work in Manhattan, the police said.

keywords: ['Foreign Aid', 'Drug Cartels', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The Colombian government is expected to sign a final peace agreement with FARC guerrillas by March 23, bringing an end to the longest civil war in Latin America.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama welcomed President Juan Manuel Santos of Colombia to the White House on Thursday for a buoyant celebration of the $10 billion, 15-year American effort to help Colombia vanquish its violent drug cartels and end its festering guerrilla war.
