headline: Alice Denham, Who Kissed and Told About Literary New York, Dies at 89
abstract: In “Sleeping With Bad Boys,” Ms. Denham, a former Playboy centerfold, chronicled her years of literary striving and sexual adventure.
lead_paragraph: Alice Denham, a writer and former Playboy centerfold who left a vivid chronicle of her literary and sexual adventures in her 2006 memoir, “Sleeping With Bad Boys: A Juicy Tell-All of Literary New York in the Fifties and Sixties,” died on Jan. 27 at her home in Manhattan. She was 89.

lead_paragraph: In a case that echoes the Takata airbag recalls, automakers including Honda and Fiat Chrysler will recall about five million vehicles worldwide to fix a defect in an airbag component known for years but left unaddressed.

headline: Review: A Whirlwind of Delicious Gossip in ‘Sense & Sensibility’
abstract: Bedlam theater company’s version of the Jane Austen novel expands and magnifies Austen’s delicate comic worldview without cracking a single teacup.
lead_paragraph: Pray do not be alarmed, gentle readers, but I am here to tell you that Jane Austen has been pumped full of helium. Now you might think that the injection of such an alien element would warp, if not altogether explode, that fabled “little bit (two inches wide) of ivory” on which Austen said she worked.

headline: Sleuths Connect Them
abstract: A welcome entry into our solving weekend by MaryLou Guizzo.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — This one by MaryLou Guizzo, in my opinion, was a great puzzle painted in sparkling, broad brushstrokes. It kept me guessing, it sometimes zigged when I zagged, but I had a fabulous time solving it. On a Friday, you could say, we are the sleuths and it is our job to connect the DOTS.

headline: My Take on Tonight’s Democratic Presidential Debate
abstract: The big winner in Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders’s first one-on-one debate? It was the voters.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders dueled tonight in the fifth Democratic presidential debate, and here’s my play-by-play commentary. And no, this isn’t a column or even a formal blog post; it’s simply an assortment of my tweets during the debate. Think of it as journalism on the fly — here goes!

headline: Public Housing Agencies Seek More Time to Enact Smoking Ban
abstract: Officials with the federal Department of Housing and Urban Development said they have received more than 1,000 comments about the proposed ban.
lead_paragraph: Public housing agencies are asking for more time and resources to put in effect a proposed federal ban on smoking that would affect nearly one million households nationwide.

headline: Knicks Erase 27-Point Deficit Before Rally Falters
abstract: After a flirtation with .500, the Knicks had their most unfortunate loss of the season and find themselves losing ground a week ahead of the All-Star break.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN HILLS, Mich. — Robin Lopez was less than an hour removed from the Knicks’ most deflating loss of the season, and he took the long view. The Knicks had toyed with the basketball gods by filling the first half with putrid basketball, and they ultimately got what they deserved when the Detroit Pistons escaped Thursday night with a 111-105 victory.

lead_paragraph: Having held positions at Ralph Lauren, Gap and J. Crew, Todd Snyder knows his American sportswear. See his Fall looks.

lead_paragraph: DURHAM, N.H. — In a caustic debate on Thursday night, Hillary Clinton accused Senator Bernie Sanders of leveling “attacks by insinuation and innuendo” against her integrity and her credentials as a progressive by portraying her as beholden to wealthy interests and corporations.

headline: High Rate of Problem Drinking Reported Among Lawyers
abstract: One in three practicing lawyers are problem drinkers, and 28 percent suffer from depression, according to a study of nearly 13,000 licensed lawyers in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers struggle with substance abuse, particularly drinking, and with depression and anxiety more commonly than some other professionals, according to a new study conducted by the American Bar Association together with the Hazelden Betty Ford Foundation.

headline: David Mirra, BMX Bike Star, Dies in an Apparent Suicide

headline: ‘You Got to Get Out of Bed and Vote,’ Donald Trump Tells New Hampshire Crowd
abstract: Mr. Trump, whose outsized confidence has been a hallmark of his presidential campaign, seemed to change tacks, imploring a crowd of several hundred supporters not to be complacent in the run-up to Tuesday’s primary.
lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, N.H. — Donald J. Trump, whose outsized confidence has been a hallmark of his presidential campaign, implored a crowd of several hundred supporters here on Thursday night not to be complacent in the run-up to Tuesday’s primary. “Don’t think we are going to win,” Mr. Trump, who came in second to Senator Ted Cruz of Texas in the Iowa Caucuses this week, warned the crowd.

headline: Who Won the Debate? Critics Are as Split as the Candidates
abstract: The consensus was that the first one-on-one debate between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders was the most feisty, yet substantive, encounter to date.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont debated one-on-one for the first time Thursday night, and the consensus among commentators and critics was that it was the most feisty, yet substantive, encounter to date. Most agreed that Mr. Sanders and Mrs. Clinton each won out on their respective strengths — Wall Street reform and foreign policy — with views divided on a true victor.

lead_paragraph: In perhaps the biggest shake-up of the fashion show system since ready-to-wear took to the catwalk, Burberry announced on Friday that after the women’s wear season that begins in New York next week, it would move to a see-now/buy-now collection model.

headline: Robert Frank, Valuing the Image Over the Object
abstract: A new show of Robert Frank’s work showcases hundreds of images in a new — and transient — way.
lead_paragraph: When the current Robert Frank exhibit at New York University closes next week, it’s really closing: The images will be handed over to photo students who will, in a private ceremony, draw on them or sculpt them into some creation of their choosing. Then they will destroy them.

headline: A Ruling in Alexander Litvinenko’s Poisoning, but No Justice
abstract: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of the former K.G.B. officer who was poisoned in London, is pushing for sanctions against members of the Kremlin elite.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Days after a British public inquiry linked President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to the fatal poisoning of her husband, Marina Litvinenko visited a cherished corner of Highgate Cemetery here.

headline: Reading Rock Star Obituaries
abstract: You look for a pattern — years of debauchery finally catching up with them? — and realize simply that a rock star can have a very ordinary ending.
lead_paragraph: They pass away with regularity now, frozen in provocative poses of youthful eternity. Gone in the last month are David Bowie, age 69, Glenn Frey, 67, and Paul Kantner, 74, musicians who lifted hearts, pushed boundaries, had it all and then had nothing that could hold off the inevitable.

headline: Who Hates Obamacare?
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Left-wing attacks on an imperfect program could undermine progressives’ interests.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz had a teachable moment in Iowa, although he himself will learn nothing from it. A voter told Mr. Cruz the story of his brother-in-law, a barber who had never been able to afford health insurance. He finally got insurance thanks to Obamacare — and discovered that it was too late. He had terminal cancer, and nothing could be done.

headline: A Question of Moral Radicalism
abstract: Stories of extreme do-gooders are both inspiring and unnerving. So how altruistic must one be?
lead_paragraph: At the National Prayer Breakfast, President Obama told the story of a group of Americans who were captured by the Nazis during World War II. The head of the German prison camp gave an order that the Jewish soldiers step forward. An American master sergeant, Roddie Edmonds, ordered all of his men to step forward. The Nazi held a gun to the sergeant’s head and said, “These can’t all be Jewish.” The sergeant replied, “We are all Jews.” Rather than execute all of the men, the Nazi backed down.

headline: A Streetcar Ride to New York’s Future
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Transit Systems', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Cable Cars and Trams']
abstract: The mayor’s enticing proposal must show itself to be worth the cost and not merely serve as a convenience for the affluent.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s proposal to build a streetcar line connecting 16 miles of neighborhoods along the booming East River waterfront of Brooklyn and Queens presents an eye-catching, ambitious exercise in what the mayor terms “equity and innovation.” Equity for local residents who feel marooned from the city’s subway system, and innovation in reviving the streetcar as a modern feature to serve a fast-growing waterfront.

headline: ‘Dreamers’ on the Front Lines of the 2016 Race
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Editorial Observer']

lead_paragraph: During the 2012 presidential race, Erika Andiola, an undocumented immigrant from Mexico, chased Mitt Romney, the Republican nominee, across the country, challenging his suggestion that America should become so inhospitable to people like her that she would self-deport.

abstract: How can fans enjoy watching a game that helps ruin players' lives?

abstract: The steel maker said its results were hurt by lower prices — depressed by cheap Chinese exports — and by write-offs in the company’s large mining business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a sign of severe distress in global steel making, ArcelorMittal said on Friday that it lost nearly $8 billion last year, and that it planned to seek $3 billion in new capital from shareholders to shore up its finances.

lead_paragraph: A slew of high-end, high-profile rental buildings are poised to open across Manhattan and Brooklyn this year, adding more than 8,000 units at a pace not seen in years, and in the process, redefining what rental housing in the city can be.

headline: Our Man in New Hampshire: The Exit of Martin O’Malley
abstract: The former Democratic governor of Maryland had planned to compete in the state, but his withdrawal from the race left his supporters seeking alternatives.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — A cardboard cutout of the candidate stood against the wall, below a not-yet-erased whiteboard showing his schedule. Leftover campaign signs littered the floor. A paperback of a strategist’s memoir of Gary Hart’s 1984 presidential campaign lay on a desk.

headline: Homeless Young People of New York, Overlooked and Underserved
abstract: As the city prepares for an annual census of the homeless population, some groups are trying to make sure people in their late teens or early 20s are not missed.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of homeless young people are in plain sight every day in New York City.

headline: 5 Notable Quotes From Mayor Bill de Blasio’s State of the City Speech
abstract: The mayor’s speech did not convey an overarching theme in service of a single policy initiative as much as it offered proposals that the city could do largely on its own.
lead_paragraph: Here are five notable quotes from Mayor Bill de Blasio’s State of the City address on Thursday, with explanations of their significance.

headline: The Bumpy Rise of a Young Bull Rider
abstract: Cooper Davis is a husband and father at age 21. And he has one of the most dangerous jobs in the world.
lead_paragraph: For two long evenings and one long day in late January, Kaitlyn Davis sat high in the stands of Chesapeake Energy Arena in Oklahoma City, tucked in with her 8-month-old son, Mackston, his stuffed toy bull and a large Louis Vuitton leather carryall packed with baby supplies. “Story of my life,” Ms. Davis said, noting the Vuitton bag and the toy bull.

headline: Capitol Portraits, a Perk of Access, Become a Symbol of Excess Instead
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Art', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Capitol Building (Washington, DC)']
abstract: Taxpayer-funded paintings of congressional members on display in the Capitol are seen by some as windows on United States history. Now, they’re also banned.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a corridor just a few feet from the floor of the United States Senate hangs a 19th-century oil painting of Henry Clay, the dexterous and venerated Kentucky lawmaker. He is portrayed with his hands folded and his lips pursed with slight impatience, as if, like his greatest admirer, Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, he longs to escape formality and get back to the business of legislating.

headline: The Town of Colma, Where San Francisco’s Dead Live
abstract: The town has 1,600 living residents and about 1.5 million dead ones — many of whom, like the 49ers, left San Francisco for greener pastures to the south.
lead_paragraph: COLMA, Calif. — While the Super Bowl will be played at Levi’s Stadium, and thousands of news media members who descended on the Bay Area this week were based at the Moscone Center, Levi Strauss lay inside a marble crypt in one of this tiny town’s 17 cemeteries, and George Moscone lay under the grass in another.

abstract: “I was introduced to all sorts of people, but there was one girl in a dress who was cute, loudmouthed, and doing magic tricks.”
lead_paragraph: As a preschooler, Zoe Reiches announced to her family that she planned to build an orphanage in Africa when she grew up. During high school, at 16, she actually did help build a school in a Mayan village in Belize.

headline: 5 Czechs Who Were Missing in Lebanon Arrive Home
abstract: The joyful response to their return has been tempered by revelations that Prague seems to have freed two terrorism suspects to secure their release.

The two-story, four-bedroom house sat on a one-acre lot in a 1970s-era subdivision that defines a kind of rustic suburbia. The back of the property was wooded, and there were still several farms nearby, some with fairly large herds of cattle.

He started the Toronto-based company with his high school friend, Sidney Robinson, with the idea of offering biking trips for students around Europe.

headline: What You Get When You Mix Chickens, China and Climate Change
abstract: The pathogens that frighten me most are novel strains of avian influenza.
lead_paragraph: IT was a gray, damp January afternoon a few years back when I visited the Jiangfeng wholesale poultry market on the outskirts of Guangzhou, in the southern Chinese province of Guangdong. With its bleak wire enclosures and grid of cement paths, the place had the feel of a neglected 1970s-era urban zoo. And despite the comparatively narrow range of species there — chickens, geese, ducks, quails and partridges, mostly, with a smattering of rabbits and one large slumbering hog — it smelled like one, too. As I walked around, watched suspiciously by the market’s handsome young security guards, a slimy mix of bird droppings and decomposing feathers slowly crept up the heels of my clogs.

headline: 1916: French Planes Retaliate

lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Dropping ten bombs a minute, the French aeroplane squadron which scourged the Strumitza valley near Petritch, occupied by the Bulgarian forces, killed or wounded 1,000 soldiers in less than half an hour. Details of the raid, which was made on Wednesday as a reprisal against the Zeppelin attack on Paris a week ago, have just been made public, following the gathering of information concerning the damage inflicted.

headline: Target Margin Theater Takes On Eugene O’Neill
abstract: The company begins a two-season project devoted to the writer, starting with “Drunken With What,” which excavates “Mourning Becomes Electra.”
lead_paragraph: Weighing in at three plays, 15 acts and six hours of Freud-meets-Aeschylus doom and gloom, Eugene O’Neill’s “Mourning Becomes Electra” (1931) is heavy lifting for even the most muscular artists. But the Target Margin Theater, known for radically reinventing classic behemoths, is not about to be daunted by a little excess weight. (Last year, it hoisted the dense literary conundrums of Gertrude Stein.) The company begins a two-season project devoted to O’Neill with a series of works that excavate and abstract the unwieldy “Electra” under the title “Drunken With What” at the Abrons Arts Center. As the name suggests, the lines between the muse and the bottle in O’Neill’s work will be considered, though in separate, cocktail-size gulps instead of a marathon binge. David Herskovits, Target Margin’s founder and artistic director, presides as spiritual bartender and mixologist. (Starting Thursday, Feb. 11, Abrons Arts Center, 866-811-4111, targetmargin.org.)

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Roz Chast’s memoir of her parents’ deaths is one of several nuanced considerations of family and mortality on the hardcover graphics list.
lead_paragraph: The Cartoonist’s Elegy: Between romance novels and mysteries, love and death have long ruled the fiction lists. But they’re increasingly common in hardcover graphics as well: On this week’s list, nuanced considerations of family and mortality turn up in Adrian Tomine’s story collection “Killing and Dying” (No. 8 after 17 weeks); Tom Hart’s memoir “Rosalie Lightning,” about the death of his 1-year-old daughter (No. 6 after three weeks); and — the book that arguably paved the way in this regard — Roz Chast’s memoir of her parents’ deaths, “Can’t We Talk About Something More Pleasant?” (No. 4 after 91 weeks). Chast’s memoir was chosen as one of the Book Review’s 10 Best Books in 2014, when we wrote that “cartoons, it turns out, are ­tailor-made for the absurdities of old age, illness and dementia.” But the book is equally moving as an account of Chast’s relationship with her parents — in particular her difficult, complicated mother. “I’ve been aware of issues with my mother since I was a little kid,” Chast told me recently via email. “The book didn’t really help me come to terms with them. There are certain things that don’t work out in life, and writing a book is an interesting way to look at those things and think about them. And I’m aware it could have been much, much worse. She had a lot of wonderful qualities: She was strong-willed and very smart. I’ve been told by her former students that she was the best teacher they ever had. But being a mom, which to me is a combination of strength but also flexibility — sometimes a lot of flexibility — was something that didn’t really interest her.”

headline: This Video Game Will Break Your Heart
abstract: “That Dragon, Cancer” is a memoir of a 5-year-old dying of cancer. It’s shattering and important.
lead_paragraph: The “extra life” was a fixture of early video games, a reward for skilled players that was imbued with the language of reincarnation. Players would not say they earned additional time to play, or a bonus turn, upon reaching a certain score. They were bestowed an extra life, a new chance at existence.

headline: ‘Infinite Jest’ at 20
abstract: When David Foster Wallace’s novel was first published, critics called it everything from “tedious” to “uproarious.”
lead_paragraph: When his “Infinite Jest” came out 20 years ago, David Foster Wallace felt some anxiety about how his fully stuffed novel would be received. In an interview on the radio show “Bookworm” at the time, Wallace said: “This is the great nightmare, when you’re doing something long and hard, is you’re terrified that it will be perceived as gratuitously hard and difficult, that this is some avant-garde-for-its-own-sake sort of exercise.”

headline: Ask the Experts Your Parenting Questions
abstract: Times journalists and experts will answer your questions on family matters.
lead_paragraph: We’re expanding the Ask Well feature to include questions about family and raising children. You ask, and New York Times experts do the research to answer the most popular or intriguing questions. Do the risks of Zika virus trump the risk of using DEET on very young children? Will a toddler who eats only “white” foods be malnourished? Is there any way to prevent teen acne?

headline: Sports Sharpen the Presidential Image
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Athletics and Sports', 'Presidents and Presidency (US)']
abstract: Presidents and those who aspire to the job have a long history of using their sports participation to enhance their political profiles.
lead_paragraph: Asked what Bernie Sanders was “like as a kid brother,” his brother, Larry, recalled on CNN last month that he was “a very good athlete.” Responding to a question by Chris Cuomo about this comment in last month’s CNN’s Democratic Town Forum, Senator Sanders said that his elementary school in Brooklyn won the borough championship, and that he was “a very good long-distance runner” and “captain of my cross-country team.”

headline: Super Recipes for the Super Bowl
abstract: Loaded nachos, spicy chicken wings and queso fundido for the Super Bowl, with project cooking and brunch ideas for the weekend.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: ‘Beasts and Children,’ by Amy Parker
abstract: Animals provide metaphors in these linked stories.
lead_paragraph: “The White Elephant,” the capacious first story in Amy Parker’s engaging linked collection, “Beasts and Children,” tracks the disintegration of 10-year-old Cissy Bowman’s family. The dusty mounted heads — bison, caribou, moose — in her father’s trophy room haunt the story with their unsettling eyes. “Most stories bear as little relation to reality as Daddy’s trophies do to the warm and living animal,” Cissy’s mother warns her daughters — and the reader. “An animal looks back at you, but a trophy’s gaze never offers anything but a distorted and diminished reflection of your face.”

headline: C. D. Wright’s ‘The Poet, the Lion’
abstract: Wright’s book offers brief takes on poems and poetics.
lead_paragraph: Some critics of poetry are judges, separating good from bad. Some are kindergarten teachers, gentle in correction, indiscriminate in praise. Some delight in the takedown. Others love books you need them to explain. Some compose manifestoes, declaring the ends of stylistic eras. I myself hereby declare the era of declaring eras over is over.

headline: ‘The Big Red Book of Modern Chinese Literature,’ Edited by Yunte Huang
abstract: An anthology of 20th-century Chinese literature asserts the primacy of politics but still allows the purely creative sensibility to shine.
lead_paragraph: In 1906, while studying medicine in Japan, a young Chinese man called Zhou Shuren was shown a slide depicting a scene from the Russo-Japanese War of 1904-5, which was partly fought on Chinese territory. It showed a crowd of Chinese watching while one of their compatriots was beheaded by the Japanese, accused of being a Russian spy. “They were all strong fellows but appeared completely apathetic,” Zhou recalled. “After this film I felt that medical science was not so important after all. The people of a weak and backward country, however strong and healthy they may be, can only serve to be made examples of, or to witness such futile spectacles. . . . The most important thing, therefore, was to change their spirit, and since at that time I felt that literature was the best means to this end, I determined to promote a literary movement.”

headline: ‘Dream Cities,’ by Wade Graham
abstract: The ideas and structures that created today’s cities, and the architects and planners who implemented them.
lead_paragraph: Thomas More’s “Utopia,” which appeared 500 years ago, in 1516, may have changed the world. But few of its readers, I suspect, have read the whole thing. Impatient to get to “the good part” — More’s fanciful description of his mythical island republic — they understandably skip over its garrulous prelude, a dialogue in an Ant­werp garden with the sailor who reputedly discovered Utopia. They shouldn’t, for in many ways this is the most brilliant part of the book.

headline: Joe R. Lansdale’s ‘Honky Tonk Samurai,’ and More
abstract: Lansdale’s latest includes excessive violence, raunchy language, adolescent clowning, and characters named Weasel and Booger.
lead_paragraph: Let’s make a list of the dubious delights that await you in HONKY TONK SAMURAI (Mulholland, $26), the latest outing for Joe R. Lansdale’s perpetual bad boys, Hap Collins and Leonard Pine. There’s excessive violence (eye-gouging and such), to be sure, as well as raunchy language, sexist attitudes, tasteless humor, adolescent clowning around and general vulgarity. Not to mention characters named Weasel and Booger.

headline: Group Portraits
abstract: New books include Daniel Oppenheimer’s “Exit Right: The People Who Left the Left and ­Reshaped the American Century.”
lead_paragraph: EXIT RIGHT The People Who Left the Left and ­Reshaped the American CenturyBy Daniel Oppenheimer 403 pp. Simon & Schuster, $28.

headline: ‘The Darkening Trapeze: Last Poems,’ by Larry Levis
abstract: Poems of social conscience and personal abandon.
lead_paragraph: Larry Levis is so much identified with the rhetoric of elegiac poetry — his choice of subjects, from beauty to hopelessness; his position as a poet of the San ­Joaquin Valley; his reputation since his death by heart attack in 1996 at the age of 49 — that it can be easy to forget how extraordinarily tender he was. And his tenderness can cause you to overlook his social conscience. I say this (in the spirit of disclosure) as a writer who, like many in my generation, counts Levis’s poetry as an influence.

headline: Laura Secor’s ‘Children of Paradise: The Struggle for the Soul of Iran’
abstract: An American journalist traces how reformists evolved from earlier supporters of the clerical regime.
lead_paragraph: In the mid-1980s, a few years after Iran became the world’s first modern revolutionary theocracy, two charismatic intellectuals and their followers conducted a long-running feud over metaphysics in the country’s newspapers and lecture halls. One of the intellectuals, Laura ­Secor writes in “Children of Paradise,” an engrossing but narrowly focused history of the Iranian reform movement, was Abdolkarim Soroush, a champion of the ­Austrian-British philosopher of science and open-society advocate Karl Popper. Farsi translations of Popper’s works were flying off the shelves. But they were being savaged in the press by devotees of Soroush’s rival, Ahmad Fardid, who espoused the views of Martin Heidegger. Many hard-liners in the Islamic Republic were attracted to Heidegger, the midcentury German thinker tainted by his ties to Nazism, as a counter to Western scientific rationalism’s claims to universalism. “Because both philosophers were associated with the ruling regime, their debates were fully aired before the public,” Secor says. “Iranian intellectuals, perhaps thrilling to the aura of purpose, often describe the battle as a war by proxy between Heidegger and Popper.”

headline: ‘Francis Bacon in Your Blood: A Memoir,’ by Michael Peppiatt
abstract: Peppiatt’s remembrance of the painter Francis Bacon is neither tribute nor apologia.
lead_paragraph: When Michael Peppiatt, at 21, met Francis Bacon, the 53-year-old artist was already all artifice, well spoken when well rehearsed, his bistro doctrines applauded by clinking glasses. Peppiatt, having taken over a student arts journal at Cambridge, had shown up in London’s Soho. It was 1963, and Peppiatt laid claim to but a tenuous introduction to the renowned painter he sought. At the bar of the French House, the youth was handled by the photographer John Deakin, who loudly advised: “My dear, you should consider that the maestro you mention has as of late become so famous that she no longer talks to the flotsam and jetsam. . . . I fear she wouldn’t even consider meeting a mere student like you!”

headline: Darryl Pinckney’s ‘Black Deutschland’
abstract: In Pinckney’s novel, a young man from Chicago with an addiction problem flees to Berlin, hoping to escape his hometown’s suffocating racism and homophobia.
lead_paragraph: “It doesn’t always start with a suitcase. Sometimes things begin with the wrong book.” Thus opens Darryl Pinckney’s haunting second novel, “Black Deutschland.” The “wrong book” in question is Christopher Isherwood’s “Berlin Stories,” the literary source for the musical “Cabaret,” and inspiration for Pinckney’s protagonist to seek refuge in what became the unofficial capital of the Cold War. It’s the early 1980s, and Jed, a young man from Chicago with an addiction problem, is trying to flee his hometown’s suffocating racism and homophobia by expatriating himself to Berlin, a city he hopes will accept him and his desires as it did Isherwood’s a half-century earlier.

keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: The halt of an official investigation has not quieted questions over how hundreds of millions of dollars ended up in the accounts of Prime Minister Najib Razak.
lead_paragraph: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia — After Malaysia’s attorney general cleared Prime Minister Najib Razak of corruption charges involving hundreds of millions of dollars that ended up in his bank accounts, Mr. Najib issued a statement of his own.

headline: Tianjin Explosions Were Result of Mismanagement, China Finds
abstract: Citing dereliction of duty, Chinese cabinet officials vowed to punish 123 government workers in connection with the blasts in August, which killed 165 people.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The blasts that killed 165 people at one of China’s busiest seaports last year were a result of a culture of mismanagement at a chemical warehouse and lax oversight by regulators, according to a government investigation whose results were released Friday.

abstract: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, claimed a ‘significant victory’ after a United Nations panel ruled that he had been detained arbitrarily and should be compensated.
lead_paragraph: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, claimed a ‘significant victory’ after a United Nations panel ruled that he had been detained arbitrarily and should be compensated.

headline: Bernie Sanders’s Kibbutz Found. Surprise: It’s Socialist.
abstract: It was no secret that the Democratic presidential candidate spent time on an Israeli kibbutz in the 1960s. Until now, however, the name was not known.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Senator Bernie Sanders volunteered on an Israeli kibbutz in the 1960s, but he has always been vague about the specific location. Now, the mystery about the Democratic presidential candidate’s past appears to have been solved, in the archives of the Israeli newspaper Haaretz.

headline: Why Your Portfolio Needs Plenty of Stocks, Whatever Your Age
abstract: Most investment counselors tell people to reduce holdings of common stock as they get older, but that advice is poor, a former chief economist writes.
lead_paragraph: WHEN I went to work on Wall Street in 1972, it was an article of faith that older investors should own less common stock than young ones. One rule of thumb suggested that your equity exposure should equal 100 percent minus your age: 70 percent for a 30-year-old, for example, but just 35 percent for someone who is 65.

lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is taking some heat for taking a snow day four days before the New Hampshire primary.

headline: At a San Francisco Restaurant, a Taste of Brittany
abstract: Dominique Crenn’s newest venture, Petit Crenn, pays homage to the simple dishes prepared by her mother and grandmother at their home near the coast in western Brittany.
lead_paragraph: In 2011, Dominique Crenn opened her first restaurant, Atelier Crenn, in the Cow Hollow neighborhood of San Francisco. Within two years, its enchantingly artistic cuisine earned two Michelin stars, making Ms. Crenn the first female chef in the United States to hold the honor. A piece of artwork in Atelier Crenn’s kitchen — a girl holding two star-shaped balloons while a third floats tantalizingly overhead — hinted at her dream of an even larger constellation.

abstract: The Dean Hotel is a tasteful, reasonably priced crash pad for those who want to be in the heart of the night life district.
lead_paragraph: Doubles start at 116 euros, about $119 at $1.05 to the euro.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Alison Bechdel
abstract: The cartoonist shares the titles she’d most want with her on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the cartoonist Alison Bechdel, winner of the 2014 MacArthur “Genius” Award and creator of the Bechdel test, which measures gender bias in film. She is also the author of the autobiographical graphic novel “Fun Home,” which was adapted into the Tony-winning musical of the same name. She shares her list exclusively with T.

lead_paragraph: HAVERHILL, N.H. — In a kitchen where tin pails and rustic kitchen tools hung from the ceiling beams, Glen Putnam pointed to the old box television atop a refrigerator that throughout his life has brought him the latest about Bernie Sanders.

lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark shows you how to make peppermint patties with a cookie crust.

lead_paragraph: We are a family of mint lovers, from the herbs on the deck to the tea in the cabinet to an entire drawer full of Altoids and Tic Tacs.

lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — At every turn in his improbably rapid rise, Ding Ning, 34, went to great efforts to convey the image of strong government backing for his Internet financing business.

abstract: More designer chatter, a Burberry change-up and Cindy’s short retirement.
lead_paragraph: Hello, does anyone work here?

lead_paragraph: A hungry sea lion pup wandered off the beach and into a fancy seaside San Diego restaurant Thursday morning, took one of the best seats in the house and peered out the window at the waves as if preparing to order a big plate of sardines.

lead_paragraph: This spring, the bygone garment is now the star attraction.

headline: Sick and Tired of ‘God Bless America’
keywords: ['Religion and Belief', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Atheism', 'Christians and Christianity', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Secular voters must demand candidates who reflect their values.
lead_paragraph: THE population of nonreligious Americans — including atheists, agnostics and those who call themselves “nothing in particular” — stands at an all-time high this election year. Americans who say religion is not important in their lives and who do not belong to a religious group, according to the Pew Research Center, have risen in numbers from an estimated 21 million in 2008 to more than 36 million now.

headline: The Big Problem With High Health Care Deductibles
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Economy', 'Medicare']
abstract: Research shows higher deductibles reduce spending, but it does not show that they lead workers to compare prices or make wise choices on where to cut.
lead_paragraph: When Bernie Sanders released his long-awaited health care plan last month, it was light on the details. But it did include one major, crowd-pleasing promise: Under his Medicare-for-all proposal, no American would ever have to pay a deductible or co-payment to receive health care again.

headline: Why the Film Academy’s Diversity Push Is Tougher Than It Thinks
keywords: ['Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Movies', 'Minorities', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Gender', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Asian-Americans']
abstract: The Motion Picture Academy wants to double its minority membership and achieve gender parity. A close look at its largest group, the actors branch, shows how far it has to go.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Roughly 87 percent are white. About 58 percent are male. As many as two-thirds are at least 60 years old.

keywords: ['Cellular Telephones', 'Television', 'Personal Finances', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Cable Television', 'Consumer Protection', 'Wireless Communications']
abstract: When calling cable and phone providers to negotiate better deals, employees of BillFixers impersonate their clients. Whatever the ethics of this approach, their negotiating tactics have much to teach.
lead_paragraph: BRENTWOOD, Tenn. — Cable companies and mobile phone service providers now offer so many deals, options, add-ons and doodads that the sheer number of potential pricing plans can boggle the mind. Chances are, you’re paying too much. Chances are, most everyone is.

lead_paragraph: Match the besotted, thwarted, inappropriate or (more rarely) happy character with his or her beloved.

lead_paragraph: A police hunt for a Missouri couple wanted for a series of abductions and robberies across the South ended early Friday on the Florida Panhandle in a barrage of gunfire that left one of the suspects dead.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syrian government and allied forces pressed their most significant advance in months on Friday, sending insurgents scrambling and tens of thousands of civilians fleeing toward the border with Turkey.

headline: A Valentine’s Day Reading List
abstract: This classic literature encourages us to embrace the broadest, least judgmental and most generous definition of love. Test your knowledge.
lead_paragraph: If, as Shakespeare informs us in “A Midsummer Night’s Dream,” the course of true love never did run smooth, often that road seems even rougher in literature than in life. Some of the world’s most celebrated masterpieces are populated by vivid, beautifully drawn characters whose romantic disappointments and satisfactions I’ve enjoyed talking about, with my students, in the literature classes I’ve taught over the years.

headline: Parties Close Out New York Men’s Fashion Week
keywords: ["Men's Fashion Week", 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Parties (Social)', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Todd Snyder and Rochambeau celebrated their shows on the final night of the men’s wear season.
lead_paragraph: One month, four countries, two continents and a ton of shows later, the fall 2016 men’s wear season had finally come to a close. But first, a drink.

headline: Social Practice Degrees Take Art to a Communal Level
abstract: For this M.F.A., hold the paint. These artists are learning communication, organization and negotiation.
lead_paragraph: Carmen Papalia’s M.F.A. project doesn’t look much like art. For “Blind Field Shuttle,” he led his classmates across the Portland State campus in Oregon on an eyes-closed walking tour, single file, each with a hand on the shoulder of the person in front.

headline: Create Your Own Language, for Credit
abstract: HBO’s “Game of Thrones” turns constructed language into a hit.

headline: Learning to Live Small (in a Dumpster)
abstract: Huston-Tillotson University in Austin, Tex., has set a curriculum around a trash bin.
lead_paragraph: How to get students thinking about their environmental footprints?

headline: Who Needs Advanced Math? Not Everybody
abstract: Andrew Hacker of Queens College on the importance of “adult arithmetic.” Algebra, he’s not so keen on.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Hacker has taught political science at Queens College, City University of New York, for nearly 45 years, plus quantitative reasoning for the last three. Not one to decelerate, at 86 he is doing nothing less than taking on the mathosphere, where, he admits, he has few fans. His experimental course requires no geometry, algebra or calculus; instead, he teaches facility with numbers. He calls it adult arithmetic, and it involves statistics, analytic thinking and rigorous computation. Further challenging convention, his new book, “The Math Myth and Other STEM Delusions,” published next month, argues against the requirement that all high school students take a full menu of math.

headline: Wood Shop Enters the Age of High-Tech
abstract: The D.I.Y. movement — to get students creating, be it for fun, for art or for entrepreneurship — is booming. There’s even a MOOC on how to teach tinkering.
lead_paragraph: You remember wood shop. You made that swan-shaped planter your parents pretended to like. And then you moved on.

headline: The Sheltering Campus: Why College Is Not Home
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Youth', 'Parenting', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: Universities have given in to the implicit notion that they should be a haven. But are they hindering their students’ development?
lead_paragraph: Erika Christakis used to teach a course at Yale titled “The Concept of the Problem Child,” a discussion of child development and socialization in a historical and modern context. The course was a seminar of 20 participants, and it was popular; she had planned extra sessions this semester to accommodate the hundreds of interested students.

headline: Are You There, Teenagers? A Newsletter Aims for Your Inbox
keywords: ['Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Women and Girls', 'E-Mail', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Millennial Generation', 'Newsletters']
abstract: Two former editors from Teen Vogue and Nylon have started an email newsletter for teenage girls focused on news and networking. But will they read it?
lead_paragraph: There is perhaps no creature more vulnerable to scrutiny — or capable of fiercely scrutinizing others — than the teenage girl.

headline: Maurice White, a Voyager Who Traveled Countless Musical Paths
abstract: The founder of Earth, Wind & Fire created hits that were marvels of pop fusion.
lead_paragraph: Maurice White, the boundless funk voyager and smooth-soul maestro who died this week at 74, was one of music’s most gifted alchemists of style. The floor-shaking hits he created with Earth, Wind & Fire were more than marvels of pop fusion — though with their precision blend of urbane jazz, Afrofuturist R&B and fluorescent disco, they were surely that. Mr. White, who had formative experience in the vanguard of African-American art music, brought the full spectrum of those interests to the table as a tunesmith, bandleader, producer and singer. His music was populist and positivist even as it arced toward a stratospheric level of harmonic and rhythmic sophistication.

headline: Review: ‘Broadway & the Bard’ Serves Delicious Combos
abstract: Len Cariou pairs Shakespeare’s monologues and sonnets with songs from musicals in a solo show at the Lion Theater.
lead_paragraph: Shakespeare and Broadway have had a relationship quite a bit more intimate than a handshake over the years, but the two have perhaps never met with quite the coziness that they do in “Broadway & the Bard,” an odd but enjoyable solo show, starring the stage veteran Len Cariou, that juxtaposes monologues and sonnets with songs from musicals.

headline: In a Slovenian Cave, Hoping for a Batch of Baby ‘Dragons’
abstract: To see the olms in Postojna Cave, you’ll need to take an underground train. But you might be rewarded with a glimpse of their crystal clear eggs.
lead_paragraph: Creatures resembling dragons dwell deep within the caves of Slovenia. And now with the help of biologists, a new brood is set to hatch at an unusual aquarium, accessible by underground train.

headline: Fantasy Sites Are Dealt New Rebuff by Citigroup
abstract: Citigroup said it would begin blocking New Yorkers’ debit and credit card payments at the two largest sites, FanDuel and DraftKings.
lead_paragraph: Already under a growing legal and legislative assault, the daily fantasy sports industry was dealt a new blow Friday when Citigroup said it would begin blocking New Yorkers’ debit and credit card payments at the two largest sites, FanDuel and DraftKings.

headline: Readers Respond: ‘Infinite Jest’ at 20
abstract: Commenters illustrate the starkly divided reception of David Foster Wallace’s ambitious novel.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 200 readers commented on Tom Bissell’s essay commemorating the 20th anniversary of David Foster Wallace’s novel “Infinite Jest.” The reactions illustrated the divisive nature of the 1,076-page book. When it was first published, critics called it everything from “tedious” to “uproarious.” Some readers consider it a big-hearted postmodern masterpiece, while others find it a pretentious slog.

headline: Bernie Sanders to Do ‘S.N.L.,’ With Larry David Hosting
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders plans to travel to New York this weekend to appear on “Saturday Night Live,” interrupting his campaign in New Hampshire for some national television exposure, according to a senior campaign official.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont plans to travel to New York this weekend to appear on “Saturday Night Live,” interrupting his campaign in New Hampshire for some national television exposure, according to a senior campaign official.

headline: After the Super Bowl, Death Wish Coffee Might Need Its Own Brew to Keep Up
abstract: Thanks to its rabid, and presumably well-caffeinated, fan base, the small company in upstate New York won a 30-second advertisement spot during the game Sunday.
lead_paragraph: ROUND LAKE, N.Y. — There’s no question that Death Wish Coffee, a pirate-flag-adorned brand from upstate New York, is strong, like really strong, like linebacker-strong, like Super Bowl-hype strong, but is it the strongest coffee in the world?

headline: Louisville Men’s Basketball Team Will Skip Postseason as a Scandal Swirls
abstract: Louisville announced the decision amid an N.C.A.A. investigation into a woman’s claim that she had provided strippers and prostitutes for some recruits and their fathers.
lead_paragraph: Louisville is voluntarily withholding its men’s basketball team from this season’s Atlantic Coast Conference and N.C.A.A. tournaments, as the N.C.A.A. investigates a scandal in which a former basketball employee is accused of having purchased strippers and prostitutes for some recruits and their fathers from 2010 to 2014.

abstract: A reader calls for major corporate tax reform to help the jobless and small businesses.

headline: Belgium to Double Spending on Police and Intelligence
abstract: The plan seeks to address criticism aired in the wake of the attacks in Paris, but its emphasis on monitoring immigrant areas has proved controversial.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Belgian government announced police and intelligence changes on Friday intended to address criticism of its failure to properly monitor or arrest the Islamic State-inspired extremists who used the country to plot the Nov. 13 attacks in Paris.

headline: One More Thing for U.S. Women’s Soccer Team to Worry About
abstract: Olympic and sports federation officials have reacted to the Zika virus threat at the Rio Games in such an unhurried way that some view it as tone deafness.
lead_paragraph: The biggest challenge for Olympic and health officials in combating the Zika virus before the Rio Games may be the popular and far-flung sport of soccer, which will be played across Brazil.

headline: A Coconut Palm’s Allure
abstract: A reader writes, “The coconut palm in our front yard was my best childhood friend.”

headline: It’s Time to Talk About Taxing Oil
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Taxation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama’s proposed tax on oil production probably won’t make it through Congress. But it’s important nonetheless.
lead_paragraph: By the standards of the old adage “politics is the art of the possible” President Obama’s proposal to levy a $10 per barrel fee on oil production and imports is not very politic. But it is very good policy.

headline: Pat Haden Stepping Down as U.S.C. Athletic Director
abstract: Haden, a former Trojans quarterback, helped stabilize Southern California’s football program after N.C.A.A. sanctions.
lead_paragraph: Pat Haden, who won two national championships as a quarterback at Southern California before returning nearly four decades later to preside over an athletic department mired in pay-for-play-related sanctions, will step down as the Trojans’ athletic director in June, the university president, C.L. Max Nikias, announced Friday.

headline: The Critics Still Win
abstract: A researcher finds that the opinion of professional critics matters more than that of “super audience reviewers.”

headline: The Way Ted Cruz Won in Iowa Suggests Trouble Ahead
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Evangelical Movement', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: He excelled among “very conservative” voters, but that group thins out as primary season rolls on.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz kept his hopes alive with a come-from-behind victory in the Iowa caucuses this week. But the way he won raises serious questions about his chances later on.

headline: Twitter Steps Up Efforts to Thwart Terrorists’ Tweets
abstract: The company said it had suspended 125,000 accounts associated with extremism since mid-2015 and was accelerating its review of users suspected of spreading terrorism.
lead_paragraph: For years, Twitter has positioned itself as a “global town square” that is open to discourse from all. And for years, extremist groups like the Islamic State have taken advantage of that stance, using Twitter as a place to spread their messages.

abstract: The president of Catholics for Choice says the virus has highlighted another crisis: the lack of abortion rights in Latin America.

headline: Las Vegas Review-Journal Names New Top Editor of Paper
abstract: The appointment of J. Keith Moyer as editor in chief comes not long after The Las Vegas Review-Journal was bought by Sheldon Adelson, one of the richest men in America.
lead_paragraph: The Las Vegas Review-Journal said on Friday that it had appointed a new editor, several weeks after the newspaper was bought by the billionaire casino magnate and Republican donor Sheldon Adelson under controversial circumstances.

headline: Snarky Puppy: A House Built on Solid Funk
abstract: The jazz-fusion band Snarky Puppy is the most visible of a crop of young bands building on a foundation of funk, rock, hip-hop and electronic music.
lead_paragraph: “I know you’re all wondering why I called you together,” David Crosby said to peals of laughter as he sat down. Mr. Crosby, the crinkly folk-rock eminence, had come to Lil’ Frankie’s in the East Village for dinner with a half-dozen members of the group he once hailed on Twitter as “quite possibly the most advanced band in the world ... certainly the best I’ve heard/seen.”

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: David Foster Wallace’s ‘Infinite Jest’
abstract: Michael Pietsch and Tom Bissell discuss Wallace’s novel on its 20th anniversary, and Chris Jennings discusses “Paradise Now: The Story of American Utopianism.”

headline: BlackBerry Lays Off 200, Pointing to Shift Away from Phones
abstract: The Canadian company’s chief executive has said in the past that he wants to maintain the company’s phone business. That is, if it is not a money loser.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — In what appears to be part of its retrenchment from making phones, BlackBerry said on Friday that it has laid off 200 workers at its head office in Ontario and at an office in Florida.

headline: When a Public Family Is Publicly Attacked
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Discrimination', 'Hate Crimes', 'Parenting']
abstract: A well-known blogger’s children become the target of abuse on Twitter. Should she stop sharing their family stories?
lead_paragraph: When a blogger uses her multiracial family to make a public point, racist attacks may be inevitable. Is she right to take that risk — and to make that choice for her children?

headline: Luxury Condos on Brooklyn’s Fourth Avenue
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: Sales are about to begin at the Baltic, an 11-story condominium rising on the corner of Baltic Street and Fourth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Carlo A. Scissura, the president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, has a grand vision for the borough’s Fourth Avenue, which for decades was a dreary boulevard where you were more likely to get your tires replaced or buy a cheap mattress than eat a fine meal or find a luxury apartment.

headline: Australia Reacts to U.N. Decision on Julian Assange
abstract: The foreign minister, Julie Bishop, said she was seeking legal advice after a United Nations panel found that Mr. Assange, an Australian, has been detained in violation of international law.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Julie Bishop, Australia’s foreign minister, has sought legal advice on the implications of a United Nations decision on Friday that the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange, an Australian, has been unlawfully held by Sweden and Britain for more than five years.

headline: Big Ticket | 46 East 81st Street
abstract: A five-story, 20-foot-wide brick townhouse at 46 East 81st Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, sold for $16 million and was one of the runner-up sales of the week in the city.
lead_paragraph: A five-story, 20-foot-wide brick townhouse at 46 East 81st Street, between Madison and Park Avenues, sold for $16 million and was one of the runner-up sales of the week in the city.

abstract: A BlackRock founder sold his meticulously renovated co-op apartment at 101 Central Park West.
lead_paragraph: One of the founders of the behemoth asset management company BlackRock sold his fully renovated apartment at the white-glove co-op 101 Central Park West for $35,336,000, a transaction that was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: In Iowa, Voting Science at Work
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Research', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Voting and Voters', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: How to increase turnout (and maybe how not to).
lead_paragraph: OF the two winners of the Iowa caucuses, who’s the better behavioral scientist, Ted Cruz or Hillary Clinton? To judge from their campaigns’ respective “get out the vote” efforts, both politicians seem to have studied up on recent research in the field.

headline: Ted Cruz’s Campaign Spread False Report in Iowa That Ben Carson Was Quitting Race
abstract: The Carson campaign, which has angrily accused Mr. Cruz of dirty tricks, escalated the feud on Friday by using the audio recording of the message left by Cruz supporters in a fund-raising email.
lead_paragraph: As Iowa Republicans headed to the caucuses on Monday night, Senator Ted Cruz’s campaign left recorded messages for supporters with “breaking news” that Ben Carson would drop out of the race, and told them to “inform any Carson caucus-goers of this news and urge them to caucus for Ted instead.”

headline: Feb. 5, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Japan and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Turkey, Japan and the United States.

headline: French Spelling Changes, 26 Years in the Making, Cause a Fracas
abstract: Textbook publishers have embraced spelling and accent changes approved in 1990, and French-speaking traditionalists are venting anger at a perceived attack on culture and history.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In France, the land of Molière, questions of language are so sacred that every Thursday the “immortals,” the guardians of the French language at the Académie Française, meet to discuss — among other things — proposed changes to the institution’s vaunted dictionary.

headline: Puerto Rican Officials Warn Congress of Major Defaults Without Restructuring
keywords: ['Government Bonds', 'Credit and Debt', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Officials want lawmakers to help them bind holdout creditors to a restructuring plan that would cover $49 billion of debt that is backed by taxes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Puerto Rico and its top advisers made their case in Washington on Friday for a law that would allow broad restructuring of the island’s multibillion-dollar debt, saying that if Congress did not act soon, major defaults were likely this spring.

headline: Donald Trump Gets Snowed Out
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Snow and Snowstorms']
abstract: Other travelers braved the snow in New Hampshire on Friday. Why not Mr. Trump?
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — “Donald Trump Takes N.H. by Storm,” said CNN.

headline: For Deon Cole, the Comedy Keeps Him Busy
abstract: Mr. Cole moved seamlessly from writing for “Conan” to stealing scenes in “black-ish.” Now he’s playing a detective on a TBS police procedural spoof.
lead_paragraph: Seriously funny — that’s how Deon Cole thinks of himself these days. But it’s not like his ego has run amok or anything.

headline: Review: Recalling the Man in ‘Jim: The James Foley Story’
abstract: The documentary, which airs on HBO on Saturday night, focuses on the American freelance journalist who was beheaded by ISIS in August 2014.
lead_paragraph: If some Americans had not registered just how brutal the Islamic State was before August 2014, the group’s videotaped beheading of James Foley that month certainly drove the point home. Mr. Foley, 40, a freelance American journalist, became a symbol of sorts, evidence that the Islamic State, also known as ISIS or ISIL, was an unscrupulous enemy that could not be ignored.

headline: New Albums From Infamous Stringdusters, Trixie Whitley and Others
abstract: Also: Dori Freeman, Sunflower Bean and the Lavender Flu.
lead_paragraph: LADIES AND GENTLEMEN

headline: Syndicated, in Brooklyn, Offers Movies, Munchies and Breakups on the Menu
abstract: This new dining and film-going spot offers the romantic comedies “Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind” (2004) and “Forgetting Sarah Marshall” (2008).
lead_paragraph: At Syndicated, a new restaurant, bar and cinema at 40 Bogart Street in Bushwick, Brooklyn, Tim Chung is certainly bringing a likable quirkiness to the task of curating the film selections. Themed double features often fill the Friday and Saturday slots, and the Feb. 12 and 13 pairing comes under the heading “Erasing Your Ex?”

headline: Samantha Bee Takes Her Place on Late Night
abstract: This former correspondent for “The Daily Show” will become the only woman currently hosting a late-night satire program.
lead_paragraph: Samantha Bee fumed for a few minutes in September, when Vanity Fair published an article on late-night television and placed a portrait of 10 hosts — all men, including Stephen Colbert, John Oliver, Conan O’Brien and Trevor Noah — on its cover. Then she asked a co-worker to insert an image of her as a tattooed centaur shooting laser beams from her eyes into the portrait. She tweeted it with a single word: “BETTER.”

headline: 21st-Century Music Rises on Three Stages
abstract: The new-music ensemble Contemporaneous focuses on female composers at Pioneer Works, and Glenn Kotche joins So Percussion at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Wintry sounds predominate in “Laws of Nature,” a concert on Thursday, Feb. 11, at Pioneer Works in Red Hook, Brooklyn, featuring the lively new-music ensemble Contemporaneous. The program focuses on female composers and includes new and recent works by Fjóla Evans, Anna Thorvaldsdottir and Kate Moore, as well as the premiere of an arrangement of Joanna Newsom’s heartbreaking song “Sawdust and Diamonds.” (718-596-3001, pioneerworks.org.) More 21st-century music is on offer the same evening from the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center at the Kaplan Penthouse, in a salute to the New Mexico summer festival Music from Angel Fire. The Opus One Piano Quartet plays works by Lowell Liebermann, Steven Stucky, Marc Neikrug and Roberto Sierra. (212-875-5788, chambermusicsociety.org.)

headline: Paul Bley’s Legacy, Invoked in Tribute
abstract: This influential jazz pianist, who died last month at 83, is recalled, directly and otherwise, in two concerts this week.
lead_paragraph: Paul Bley, who died a few days into the new year, at 83, was a jazz pianist of enigmatic intention and restive yet soulful composure. A catalyst behind the transition from bebop to free jazz, he broadened the realm of possibility for his instrument, deeply influencing generations of improvising pianists. One of them, Keith Jarrett, performs a solo concert on Tuesday, Feb. 9, at Carnegie Hall, and it seems reasonable to assume that the music will unfold, on some level, as a tribute. (carnegiehall.org.)

headline: Olivo Barbieri’s Serendipitous Choreography on the Adriatic
abstract: The Italian artist photographed random groups of people standing in shallow water. This is his sixth solo exhibition at the Yancey Richardson Gallery.
lead_paragraph: The Italian artist Olivo Barbieri is known for his photographs investigating human behavior in relation to the natural majesty of waterfalls and mountain ranges. Now he has turned his attention to the Italian coastline of the Adriatic Sea.

headline: The Stakes in the Democratic Race
abstract: Readers discuss who is more electable and whose policies are better.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: The Latest Jobs Report Cuts Both Ways
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Minimum Wage', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: The Fed will have to wait for February’s report to get a clearer sense of what’s going on.
lead_paragraph: The employment report for January, released on Friday, plays into the old joke about economists: “Give me a one-handed economist,” President Harry Truman once said. “All my economists say ‘on the one hand….on the other.’”

headline: Review: ‘The Gambler,’ Dostoyevsky With Laughs
abstract: Glyn Maxwell’s stage adaptation, produced by Phoenix Theater Ensemble, focuses on a hapless tutor and a general with money problems.
lead_paragraph: Scroll through your mental list of gifted comic writers, and Dostoyevsky probably doesn’t make the cut. But he was a funny guy, and his wisecracking novella “The Gambler,” published in 1866, is a case in point. Even the inevitable descent into torment and ruin is peppered with laughter.

headline: Review: A Schubert Song Cycle and Moods It Inspired
abstract: The baritone Roderick Williams, the pianist Susie Allan and the actress Jenny Agutter combined for a performance of “Schwanengesang” and poetry at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: Schubert already knew he was dying when, during his final three months of life, in 1828, he composed three piano sonatas, the “Shepherd on the Rock” trio, the String Quintet in C and 14 songs that were later published together under the heading “Schwanengesang” (“Swan Song”). Unlike his other song cycles, like “Winterreise,” there isn’t a dramatic or narrative thread to “Schwanengesang,” though one was provided on Thursday in a thoughtfully conceived program by the baritone Roderick Williams, the pianist Susie Allan and the actress Jenny Agutter.

headline: Review: Aventura Sighs Goodbye, as Women Squeal
abstract: The Bronx band, which brought the Dominican music bachata to a worldwide audience, honors Washington Heights, which was an early Aventura stronghold.
lead_paragraph: A high-voiced heartthrob and songwriter leads his band to Top 10 albums and arenas, goes solo and headlines his own stadium shows. Then he rejoins his former bandmates for a final set of performances together. It’s the story of Michael Jackson and the Jacksons. It’s also the story of Romeo Santos and Aventura, a band formed in the Bronx in the 1990s that brought bachata, music from the Dominican Republic, to listeners worldwide.

headline: Pentagon Releases Small Portion of Photos From Detainee Abuse Cases
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Detainees', 'Torture', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The Pentagon on Friday released 198 photographs from detainee abuse investigations in the Afghanistan and Iraq wars, while blocking the release of 1,800 more.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon on Friday released 198 photographs from detainee abuse investigations in the Afghanistan and Iraq wars. The pictures, taken more than a decade ago during the Bush administration, consist largely of close-up views of scrapes and bruises on detainees’ bodies.

headline: ‘Cyanotypes: Photography’s Blue Period‘
abstract: Cyanotype, a 19th-century photographic printing process, is making a resurgence, notably in an exhibition at the Worcester Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: Cyanotype, a 19th-century photographic printing process, is making a resurgence, notably in an exhibition at the Worcester Art Museum.

headline: Review: ‘Regression’: Memory Isn’t All It’s Cracked Up to Be
abstract: The film, directed by Alejandro Amenábar and starring Emma Watson and Ethan Hawke, finds a detective investigating a child abuse case.
lead_paragraph: In the late 1990s and early 2000s Alejandro Amenábar directed two of the most striking and dynamic genre movies of the time, 1997’s knotty and terrifying virtual-reality/time travel tale “Abre los Ojos” (“Open Your Eyes”) and 2001’s innovative but in many respects gratifyingly old-fashioned ghost story “The Others.”

headline: Cyanotype, Photography’s Blue Period, Is Making a Comeback
abstract: A 19th-century photographic printing process is making a resurgence, notably in a show at the Worcester Art Museum in Worcester, Mass.
lead_paragraph: The Phoenix artist Annie Lopez wanted to stand out among her contemporary peers. Instead of trying to invent something utterly new, she has been turning to a 174-year-old photographic printing process — cyanotypes, once used for copying architectural drawings — and giving it her own distinctive twist.

headline: Marco Rubio Is Endorsed by The Las Vegas-Review, Owned by Sheldon Adelson
abstract: Mr. Rubio’s endorsement by Nevada’s largest newspaper could play a key role in his efforts to win the state caucuses on Feb. 23 and the Republican presidential nomination.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida won the endorsement on Friday of The Las Vegas-Review, Nevada’s largest newspaper, an important boost in a state that could play a key role in his efforts to win the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Argentina Reaches Debt Deal With 2 Hedge Funds
abstract: Montreux Partners and Dart Management have agreed to take an offer made by the South American nation.
lead_paragraph: Argentina has offered to pay $6.5 billion to a group of hedge funds holding bonds it defaulted on 14 years ago in a historic effort by the nation to put a bitter legal battle behind it.

headline: In Rome, a Grand Welcome for 2 Long-Deceased Saints
abstract: The bodies of Padre Pio and Padre Leopoldo, their corpses enclosed in glass boxes, were paraded through the city for the Vatican’s Jubilee celebration.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Along the broad boulevard leading to St. Peter’s Square, the faithful pressed forward. Nuns pointed cellphone cameras. Others stood on tiptoes, trying to catch a glimpse. Squadrons of police officers restrained the crowds and blocked traffic, as motorists could do little except step out of their cars and watch the show.

headline: Candidates Make Rounds in New Hampshire Before Primary
abstract: The state’s voters got a closer look at the Republican and Democratic candidates as a prelude to Tuesday’s events.
lead_paragraph: The state’s voters got a closer look at the Republican and Democratic candidates as a prelude to Tuesday’s events.

headline: City History, and Vantages, Often Overlooked
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Music', 'Jazz', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Remembering Manhattan’s role as the nation’s first capital, paying tribute to an unsung composer and enjoying bird’s-eye views of the skyline.
lead_paragraph: “America begins in New York,” Kenneth T. Jackson, the Columbia University professor and editor of the Encyclopedia of New York City, likes to say. Now comes the journalist and author Fergus M. Bordewich to engagingly revive the forgotten story of the nearly 18 months that New York was the nation’s first capital in “The First Congress: How James Madison, George Washington and a Group of Extraordinary Men Invented the Government” (Simon & Schuster, $30).

lead_paragraph: When used as intended, Tinder, the mobile dating application, can provide many things: actual dating, long-term relationships, casual sex, new friends, mindless entertainment or validation that at least the occasional stranger finds you minimally attractive.

headline: The Praying Mantis, a Friend and Foe of New York City Gardens
abstract: The frothy, walnut-size blobs attached to shrubs this time of the year belong to mantises, the camouflaged insects who are subject of many urban myths.
lead_paragraph: Perplexed urbanites might suspect that the frothy, walnut-size blobs attached to shrubs, fence posts and grass stems this time of year are insect-related. But not many guess that these are the egg masses of praying mantises.

lead_paragraph: When ship manifests and immigration rosters fail to produce an aha moment in the popular PBS genealogy whodunit, “Finding Your Roots,” the show’s host, Henry Louis Gates Jr., often has a sleuth card up his sleeve. Go to the DNA. Buried in our genes lie clues to origin stories — or, anyway, the basis for tidy pie charts diagraming blood quantum.

headline: Supporters Gather at Funeral for Oregon Protester
abstract: Some protesters have sought to turn LaVoy Finicum into a folk hero, and his family has questioned the circumstances of his shooting by the authorities.
lead_paragraph: KANAB, Utah — The mourners and sympathizers came from across the West on Friday, in pickups flying American flags, to attend the funeral here of LaVoy Finicum, the one member of a band of armed protesters in Princeton, Ore., who was killed last week after a car chase with the authorities.

lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazilian scientists said Friday that they had detected the presence of the Zika virus in samples of human saliva and urine, a first for Brazil.

headline: Pleading the Case to Get Parking Tickets Dismissed
abstract: Brian LaRoche spends his working days contesting parking tickets in New York City on behalf of clients, some of whom amass hundreds of tickets in a week.
lead_paragraph: Two cigarettes into his brief afternoon break, Brian LaRoche, 35, glanced at a parking ticket on a Verizon van parked on John Street in Lower Manhattan, and offered his assessment.

lead_paragraph: Polygon Elite, founded and led by Sergei Maslikhov, offers lessons in the ancient Russian martial art known as Systema Rukopashnii Boi.

headline: Teaching a Medieval Russian Martial Art in a Flatiron Basement
abstract: At Polygon Elite, Sergei Maslikhov teaches the millennium-old Systema Rukopashnii Boi, a type of hand-to-hand combat that stresses survival over elegance.
lead_paragraph: The desert boot of the instructor weighed heavily on the sternum of a student lying on a thin layer of industrial carpeting. In this low-slung and windowless room, five others were on the ground, awaiting their turn under the boot of their teacher, Sergei Maslikhov. The man under his heel grimaced but bore Mr. Maslikhov’s weight stoically.

lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The furor surrounding the death of an Italian student whose body was discovered Wednesday on an Egyptian roadside grew Friday as Italian investigators flew to Cairo to help find his killers, and it emerged that the young man had secretly written from Egypt for a left-wing Italian newspaper.

headline: An Old Cathedral and a Daily Aperitivo
abstract: In NoLIta, one can pray in the Basilica of St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral and have a drink at Emporio down the block.
lead_paragraph: On any given weekend, NoLIta’s tastefully curated boutiques are brimming with avid shoppers. Over on the Bowery, the New Museum draws contemporary art lovers. Seekers of spiritual atonement — or the merely curious — slip into the Basilica of St. Patrick’s Old Cathedral, a historic sanctuary on the corner of Mott and Prince Streets.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The contrast between the improving health of the labor market and the weakness of other economic indicators poses a challenging quandary for the Federal Reserve.

headline: Eight Boldly Striped Bags for Spring
abstract: Formally ladylike shapes get a burst of energy from the sportiest of patterns.
lead_paragraph: Formally ladylike shapes get a burst of energy from the sportiest of patterns.

headline: How Val DiFebo, C.E.O. of Deutsch NY, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The ad agency executive, who lives in Queens, relaxes with her family and does her best to unplug, but she’s never completely off the radar.
lead_paragraph: When huge numbers of Americans sit down to watch the Super Bowl and its high-profile ads this weekend, Val DiFebo will have had a hand in some of what they see. Ms. DiFebo, 54, is the chief executive of the ad agency Deutsch NY, whose parent company has delivered well-remembered spots, including one with a chorus of dogs barking the “Imperial March” from “Star Wars,” to past Super Bowls. For this year’s big game, look for Deutsch’s Taco Bell spot. A Bronx native, Ms. DiFebo lives in Douglaston, Queens, a waterfront community between Bayside and Little Neck, with her husband, J. Dixon Byrne, 64, an actor; their son, Bryan, 11; and their Yorkshire terrier, Murphy.

headline: Former N.A.A.C.P. President Endorses Bernie Sanders
abstract: Benjamin T. Jealous also vowed to increase support for Mr. Sanders among black voters in South Carolina, a crucial primary state, as well as across the country.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin T. Jealous, a prominent black leader and former N.A.A.C.P. president, endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont for president on Friday and vowed to increase his support among black voters in South Carolina, a crucial primary state, as well as across the country.

headline: Montclair Bread Company Has Sunday Treats All Week Long

headline: The Republican Refusal to Aid Flint
abstract: The city’s residents need support now and a long-term commitment for help in decades to come.
lead_paragraph: The water crisis in Flint, Mich., has elicited a lot more hand-wringing and apologies than concrete actions to provide for the needs of children and adults whose health may be damaged by water from pipes that are leaching lead into taps all over the city. The state government, whose officials caused this crisis, has been loath to commit substantial funds to long-term needs, and Congress, under the control of Republicans, is finding excuses not to rescue this poverty-stricken, majority-black city of nearly 100,000 people.

headline: The Sincerest Form of Flattery
abstract: Hillary Clinton picks up some of the progressive stances, and style, of Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: “Immature poets imitate; mature poets steal,” T. S. Eliot said, meaning that the best poets seek to improve on lasting ideas. It would seem that the Democratic presidential primary’s mature poet is Hillary Clinton, who has been adopting the progressive words, and style, of her rival Bernie Sanders. The Vermont senator’s longstanding call for revolution against a system rigged against the poor and middle class resonates with young Democrats who jam convention halls to hear his booming, Brooklyn-accented voice. Some Democrats say it’s great that Mr. Sanders is nudging Mrs. Clinton to the left. Others say she’s merely parroting the race’s true progressive.

I had lived there for nearly a decade but was so broke from student loans and other indulgences (like paying rent) that I convinced myself I had no choice but to move to the Midwest. The plan worked. I spent several years in Lincoln, Neb., got out of debt, and then moved to Los Angeles, where I lived for another 13 years.

headline: In Defense of Funny Diagrams (Wonkish)
abstract: You’ll have to pry my pencil out of my cold, dead hands.
lead_paragraph: Brad DeLong asks a question about which of the various funny diagrams economists love should be taught in Econ 101. I say production possibilities yes, Edgeworth box no — which, strange to say, is how we deal with this issue in Krugman/Wells. But students who go on to major in economics should be exposed to the box — and those who go on to grad school really, really need to have seen it, and in general need more simple general-equilibrium analysis than, as far as I can tell, many of them get these days.
