lead_paragraph: Fiat Chrysler Automobiles is recalling almost 505,000 2011-16 Dodge Chargers, including about 442,000 in the United States, because the vehicle might fall off the jack when a tire is being changed, according to a report by the automaker posted on Saturday on the website of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

headline: Jeb Bush Supporter’s  Debate Advice: ‘Throw That Punch’
abstract: A Jeb Bush supporter references a decades-old boxing match to encourage the former Florida governor to deliver a knock out punch to Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, N.H. — The man who stood at Jeb Bush’s rally here Saturday morning had not a question but a comment.

headline: Pakistan’s Hand in the Rise of International Jihad
abstract: Sunni extremists are being recruited and trained to fight in conflicts abroad.
lead_paragraph: TUNIS — PRESIDENT ASHRAF GHANI of Afghanistan has warned in several recent interviews that unless peace talks with Pakistan and the Taliban produce results in the next few months, his country may not survive 2016. Afghanistan is barely standing, he says, after the Taliban onslaught last year, which led to the highest casualties among civilians and security forces since 2001.

headline: Jeb Bush Will ‘Protect America,’ Says Big Brother George W.
abstract: The former president says Mr. Bush’s “good heart and strong backbone” will unite the country and the world in the fight against terrorism.

headline: House Fires in the Bronx Kill Two People
abstract: An older woman and a young man died on Saturday morning in two separate fires that broke out just hours and blocks apart in the Parkchester neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: A young entrepreneur with dreams of opening a business and an older immigrant described as a neighborhood matriarch were killed early Saturday in separate house fires that broke out just blocks apart in the Bronx, officials said.

headline: Adam Grant, a Workplace Magician, Reveals His Secrets
abstract: The professor and author of “Originals: How Non-Conformists Move the World” says we all have original ideas, but most of us don’t act on them.
lead_paragraph: Before becoming the youngest tenured professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 2011, when he was 29, Adam Grant was a professional magician.

headline: Vanguard, a Champion of Low Fees, Faces a Peculiar Tax Challenge
abstract: A whistle-blower claims that the mutual fund group, which is ultimately owned by investors in its funds, should have to account for profits it could have earned if it had charged higher fees.
lead_paragraph: Vanguard may have committed a sin while pursuing a virtue.

headline: We Have a Win-a-Trip Winner!
abstract: Must be something in the Notre Dame water! For the second time, a Notre Dame student has won my annual win-a-trip contest.
lead_paragraph: Must be something in the Notre Dame water! For the second time, a Notre Dame student has won my annual win-a-trip contest, in which I take a student with me on a reporting trip to the developing world. The winner this year is Cassidy McDonald, a junior from Madison, Wis., who is majoring in marketing and minoring in journalism. She has worked for CBS News and Wisconsin State Journal, where one of her leads sparked a subreddit page: “I love you, Cassidy McDonald.” And that lede? Here goes: “Wisconsin cheesemakers found their whey Friday at the American Cheese Society Competition in Providence, Rhode Island, where they did better than gouda — they did grate.”

headline: Queens, One of a Kind
abstract: After moving to Astoria in 2012, Bryan Formhals began photographing homes, intersections and trains in the area, elements that he says lend to the borough’s unique landscape.
lead_paragraph: After moving to Astoria in 2012, Bryan Formhals began photographing homes, intersections and trains in the area, elements that he says lend to the borough’s unique landscape.

headline: A Journey Through Queens With the Photographer Bryan Formhals
abstract: After moving to Astoria in 2012, the landscape photographer Bryan Formhals set out to create a visual vocabulary of Queens as a way to convey the borough’s uniqueness.
lead_paragraph: Take the residential loft aesthetic: open space, clean lines, flat surfaces, an impersonal industrial voice. Apply it to the great urban outdoors. Now you have the borough of Queens, as seen through the lens of the landscape photographer Bryan Formhals, 39, who has been shooting the borough since he moved to Astoria from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, in 2012. “The landscape reminded me of when I was living in Los Angeles,” said Mr. Formhals, a Minnesota native who lived on the West Coast before moving to Brooklyn in 2009. “With the elevated trains and the two airports, you have the sense of people traveling through the air over Queens, and even on the ground there’s an element of people on the move. It felt very contemporary, even more so than Brooklyn. It felt like a city on the verge.”

headline: Revaluing Family Treasures for the Taxman
keywords: ['Appraisals and Valuation (Property)', 'Inheritance and Estate Taxes', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: The appraisal of expensive collectibles like vintage racecars and fine art is increasingly at issue as tax authorities take a closer look at valuations.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, a bright red 1957 Ferrari rolled onto a stage in Paris and sold for 32 million euros, or about $35.8 million, making it, by some measures, the most expensive car ever sold at auction.

headline: Rafael Bosch: Sweets as Strength Training
abstract: As a candy maker for Hillside Candy, Mr. Bosch, 22, regularly lifts 145-pound batches of soon-to-be treats.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Bosch,22, is a candy maker at Hillside Candy in Hillside, N.J.

headline: At the Performing Arts Center in Purchase, a Debut for Dawn Upshaw
abstract: Ms. Upshaw will be the soloist in Osvaldo Golijov’s “Three Songs for Soprano and Orchestra,” her first performance with the Westchester Philharmonic.
lead_paragraph: Scrambling to fulfill a commission that would mark the Minnesota Orchestra’s 100th anniversary, the composer Osvaldo Golijov came up with a plan: Combine three of his chamber pieces into a single orchestral work and recruit the soprano Dawn Upshaw, who had debuted the pieces, to be his soloist.

headline: Taking Stock of a Fixer-Upper in ‘The Substance of Bliss’
abstract: Talk of ceiling tiles leads to questions about failings that may have led to a child’s drug addiction in a new play at New Jersey Repertory Company.
lead_paragraph: A modest patch of suburban hell is surveyed in Tony Glazer’s new play, “The Substance of Bliss,” which is having its world premiere production at New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch.

headline: Free Ticket to Super Bowl 50? No, Thanks, He’ll Watch at Home
abstract: Mayor Jamie L. Matthews of Santa Clara may be the only mayor to host the Super Bowl and yet have no interest in attending the game that will be played in his city.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Jamie L. Matthews may be the only mayor in the United States to host the Super Bowl and yet have no interest in attending the game that will be played in his city.

headline: Cuomo Moves Against Therapy That Claims to Make Gay Children Straight
abstract: Andrew M. Cuomo on Saturday announced a series of measures intended to eliminate so-called conversion therapy, which he called “a hateful and fundamentally flawed practice.”
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York on Saturday announced a series of measures intended to eliminate so-called conversion therapy, a practice that claims the ability to reverse same-sex attraction in some people but that has been widely discredited by scientists and criticized by gay-rights groups.

headline: Electability
abstract: I’m not a political scientist, man, but I do read them.
lead_paragraph: If you are still on the fence in the Democratic primary, or still persuadable, you should know that Vox interviewed a number of political scientists about the electability of Bernie Sanders, and got responses ranging from warnings about a steep uphill climb to predictions of a McGovern-Nixon style blowout defeat. And all of them dismiss current polls as meaningless.

headline: Antics Aside, Terrell Owens Stands Out for His Achievements
abstract: Owens, who failed to gain election on his first time on the Pro Football Hall of Fame ballot, is often met with a great deal of vitriol, despite his dominance as a wide receiver.
lead_paragraph: As Sunday’s Super Bowl approached, Cam Newton defended the antics of the Carolina Panthers by pointing out that an N.F.L. play usually lasts for only four to six seconds and saying that anyone looking to judge him or his team should focus on what they do during that time, rather than being distracted by the irrelevant things that happen between plays.

headline: At the Heckscher Museum, a Celebration of ‘Men at Work’
abstract: The exhibition, of art from the museum’s permanent collection, takes a look at subjects immersed in physical, mental and spiritual activities.
lead_paragraph: On the face of it, a painting of some of the founding fathers laboring over the Declaration of Independence would seem to have little in common with the image of a drink-swilling, red-nosed court jester before he starts his on-command tomfoolery.

headline: Iran Panel Reverses Disqualification of Election Candidates
abstract: Iran’s reformist faction has tried to flood the vetting committee, known as the Guardian Council, with candidates, hoping that enough would slip through for their faction to win a majority in Parliament.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — An Iranian vetting committee on Saturday reversed a decision to disqualify more than 1,500 candidates who had registered to run in parliamentary elections scheduled for Feb. 26. It is unclear how many of the newly approved candidates are considered to be reformists, who are opposed by Iranian hard-liners.

headline: On the Mound: Observant. At Bat: Ultra-Orthodox.
abstract: At Playhouse Park in West Hartford, a staging of Chaim Potok’s “The Chosen” shows that things are not always as they seem.
lead_paragraph: You know you’re in for something out of the ordinary from the get-go. There are plenty of plays that begin with a narrator addressing the audience directly, but at “The Chosen,” the current offering at Playhouse on Park in West Hartford, we are being addressed in Hebrew. If the title rings a bell, it should — the play is adapted from Chaim Potok’s popular 1967 novel of the same name. The narrator is quick to rescue the non-Hebrew speakers in attendance, for, like all good memory-play narrators, he wants us to hear his story. This one is about growing up in a Jewish neighborhood in Brooklyn in the 1940s, with news of the war in Europe and Big Band music on the soundtrack of daily life.

headline: Not Just a Death, a System Failure
abstract: My mother’s death was so wrenching that I applied to medical school to help change the way people die in America.
lead_paragraph: On the day before my mother died, she gave my father a list of demands. He wrote them on the back of an envelope and showed them to me as he left the intensive care unit. There, in his clear block handwriting, it read:

headline: Give Up Your Data to Cure Disease
keywords: ['Electronic Health Records', 'Privacy', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Computer Security', 'Research']
abstract: Our privacy concerns are standing in the way of medical advances.
lead_paragraph: HOW far would you go to protect your health records? Your privacy matters, of course, but consider this: Mass data can inform medicine like nothing else and save countless lives, including, perhaps, your own.

headline: Gordon Ballard
abstract: An energy executive on space, Arctic and oil exploration, the smell of spinning vinyl and an exhausting movie.
lead_paragraph: Gordon Ballard is executive director of the International Association of Oil & Gas Producers, whose members produce more than half of the world’s oil and more than a third of its gas.

headline: Holding Sentencing Reform Hostage
keywords: ['Mandatory Sentencing', 'Editorials', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Law and Legislation', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Congress could pass the most significant criminal justice reform in a generation — if only some members would stop putting up hurdles.
lead_paragraph: An opportunity to pass the most significant federal criminal justice reform in a generation may be slipping away — despite the tireless efforts of many top Republicans and Democrats in Congress, as well as a rare exhortation from President Obama during last month’s State of the Union address.

headline: Ted Cruz Won’t Be Denied
abstract: As Republicans ganged up on Trump and Rubio, did they let the senator from Texas slither by?
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — ANOTHER Ted Cruz rally, another Ted Cruz rant about the media’s failure to give him his due. I endured one in the tiny town of Weare, N.H., on Thursday afternoon and had two thoughts.

headline: Hillary Battles Bernie Sanders, Chick Magnet
abstract: Can she recapture her young idealism?
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — HILLARY CLINTON first grabbed the national spotlight 47 years ago as an idealistic young feminist, chiding the paternalistic establishment in her Wellesley commencement speech.

headline: The Last of the Bushes
abstract: In Jeb Bush’s floundering, there are echoes of his father’s fate.
lead_paragraph: GEORGE H. W. BUSH was the first politician I ever disliked. I was 12, my parents were loyal Democrats, and every night we’d watch the news, cheer for whatever Bill Clinton was saying on the trail, and then glower at the screen when Peter Jennings went to Brit Hume, then the White House correspondent, for an update on what the incumbent president was up to.

headline: America Is Flint
keywords: ['Lead', 'Water', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Water Pollution', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']

keywords: ['ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'SAT (College Admission Test)', 'ACT (Examination)', 'Anxiety and Stress']
abstract: A Harvard report that promotes “meaningful” community service misses the point.
lead_paragraph: THE college admission process is always stressful, often unfair and may well reward the wrong values. But the recommendations released last month by a Harvard Graduate School of Education project called Making Caring Common will only make things worse.

headline: Sweetheart, Get Me Readers
keywords: ['Public Editor (Times Column)', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media']
abstract: The goal of The Times’s new Express Team is to help reposition the paper in a changing information landscape. Some readers are uneasy.
lead_paragraph: With a new TV mini-series debuting last week, everybody was talking about O.J. Simpson, the football star who fell from grace. The Times wanted in — so editors and writers quickly developed a list-like article that compiled the paper’s original coverage of the 1990s murder case, and offered it to readers on Facebook and other social media platforms.

headline: Don’t Break Up the Banks. They’re Not Our Real Problem.
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Economy', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Income Inequality', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: A protagonist of “The Big Short” argues that the attention paid to the banks distracts us from the real economic challenge we face: income inequality.
lead_paragraph: IN the movie “The Big Short,” Steve Carell plays a slightly altered version of me. In real life, I am a portfolio manager and financial services analyst who over a 25-year career has, at times, been highly critical of bank behavior.

keywords: ['Obesity', 'Women and Girls', 'English Language', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Weight']
abstract: A radical idea: You can love your body, even without losing weight.

headline: Football, So Beautiful for Fans, Scars Players With Dementia
abstract: With each concussion, the evidence mounts that football’s C.T.E. problem is steadily undermining the joy of the game.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday evening marks the 50th playing of the Super Bowl, which began as a far simpler interleague rivalry and evolved into a national feast day for football fans to binge on the balletic action before giant television screens and worship the game across nacho bowls. Memory for detail, so important to sports fans, will be on display as viewers recall the exploits in Super Bowls past of Joe Namath and so many other gifted athletes.

headline: Congress Starts to Get Serious About Online Privacy
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Search and Seizure', 'Computers and the Internet', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Privacy']
abstract: New legislation would update a 1986 law to reflect how people use the Internet today.
lead_paragraph: Congress could soon vote on a bill that would require law enforcement agencies to get a search warrant from a judge to obtain emails, photographs and other documents Americans have stored online. This important legislation would update the law to reflect how people use the Internet today.

headline: Iranian Commander Dismisses Saudi Role in Syria
abstract: Maj. Gen. Mohammad Ali Jafari, the leader of Iran’s Revolutionary Guards Corps, ridiculed the notion of Saudi Arabia’s intervening in the Syrian civil war, saying the kingdom lacked “the courage to do it.”
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — A top Iranian commander reacted with ridicule to Saudi Arabia’s suggestion that it was prepared to take part in ground operations in Syria, saying Saturday that the kingdom would not dare send troops there.

headline: Knicks Scuffle, Regress and Look Inward as Losses Mount
abstract: As the losses pile up, the pressure is growing on the players and especially Coach Derek Fisher to keep the Knicks relevant this season.
lead_paragraph: The message from Coach Derek Fisher was much the same after another loss. Competed hard. Difficult opponent. Missed opportunities.

headline: Economists Against the Draft

abstract: Amid a debate over whether women should register for the draft, some economists call for an end to the system entirely.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Defense Department’s decision to let women serve in every part of the military has left just one major distinction between the roles of men and women: Men are required to sign up for the draft when they turn 18. Women are not.

abstract: Readers discuss a letter writer’s call to “reclaim the place of reason in our political life.”
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss a letter urging Americans to try to bridge the political divide and “reclaim the place of reason in our political life.”

headline: Cavaliers Try to Push Pace, but Change Is Slow
abstract: A closer look at the numbers reveals that the transition from David Blatt to Tyronn Lue has not exactly been a paradigm shift in style for the slow-footed franchise.
lead_paragraph: When Tyronn Lue took over as the coach of the Cleveland Cavaliers last month, he raised eyebrows by questioning the conditioning of his players and openly wondering if they could keep up with his vision for the team.

headline: Rejected Campaign Buttons
abstract: Some campaign swag that didn’t make the cut.
lead_paragraph: Some campaign swag that didn’t make the cut.

headline: How a Medical Mystery in Brazil Led Doctors to Zika
abstract: A sudden, sharp increase in babies with “no foreheads and very strange heads” was baffling doctors in Brazil. That set off a search for answers that led to a little-known pathogen, the Zika virus.
lead_paragraph: Something strange was happening last August in the maternity wards of Recife, a seaside city perched on Brazil’s easternmost tip, where the country juts into the Atlantic.

headline: What 74 Years of Crossword History Says About the Language We Use
abstract: The world may have become more globalized, but the venerable puzzle now relies less on international words and place names.

headline: John L. Tishman, Builder Who Shaped American Skylines, Dies at 90
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Building (Construction)', 'World Trade Center (Manhattan, NY)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Buildings (Structures)']
abstract: Mr. Tishman’s company oversaw the construction of the John Hancock Center in Chicago and the twin towers of the World Trade Center in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: John L. Tishman, a master builder of the 20th century whose Tishman Realty and Construction Company transformed the skylines of Chicago, Detroit, Los Angeles and New York, died on Saturday at his home in Bedford, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: Review: Raga Indian Cuisine in Croton-on-Hudson
abstract: The restaurant, which opened in Croton-on-Hudson in October, offers a variety of offerings from the Indian subcontinent.
lead_paragraph: In October, Raga Indian Cuisine began operating in a bright little shopping strip on Croton-on-Hudson’s Maple Street. The décor is simple, and the design touches left by the previous occupant, a Spanish restaurant, like an Iberian wrought iron gate under a bricked archway, also work well for Raga.

headline: Review: At Wölffer Kitchen in Sag Harbor, a Winemaker Puts Food First
abstract: A restaurant from the owners of Wölffer Estate Vineyard pairs Mediterranean flavors with fresh ingredients from the East End.
lead_paragraph: On an island practically teeming with vineyards, it was only a matter of time before a winery-owned restaurant sprang up on the East End. In July, Wölffer Estate Vineyard opened Wölffer Kitchen on Main Street in Sag Harbor.

headline: Federal Judge Orders Abortion Foes Not to Release Secretly Filmed Videos
abstract: The ruling marked the second major setback in recent weeks for the anti-abortion group, the Center for Medical Progress.
lead_paragraph: In a sharp rebuke, a federal judge on Friday issued a preliminary injunction ordering abortion opponents not to release videos they had secretly made at meetings of abortion providers, and he added that the opponents’ claims that such organizations were illegally selling fetal tissue were baseless.

headline: Priest Abuse Victim Is Suspended From Vatican Panel
abstract: A high-profile Vatican commission on the prevention of child sexual abuse voted on Saturday to temporarily suspend one of its members.
lead_paragraph: ROME — A high-profile Vatican commission on the prevention of child sexual abuse voted on Saturday to temporarily suspend one of its members, an outspoken victim of clerical abuse who accused the church of failing to deliver on its promises of reform and accountability.

headline: Amanda Kessel, Top College Player Out of Action Since Sochi, Returns
abstract: Kessel, the 2013 Patty Kazmaier Award winner as college hockey’s top female player, had not played since the gold medal game of the Sochi Olympics.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — On the second shift of her first hockey game in almost two years, University of Minnesota right wing Amanda Kessel collided twice with North Dakota players and fell to the ice. Both times, she picked herself up and jumped back into the play.

headline: Review: Local and Fresh Without the Pretense at Mill Street Bar & Table
abstract: Chef Geoff Lazlo, who has worked in prestigious restaurants from California to Manhattan, builds a daily menu that varies based on the local produce.
lead_paragraph: Though he embraces the use of local sources, Geoff Lazlo, managing partner and the executive chef of Mill Street Bar & Table in Greenwich, likes to keep things simple. So he doesn’t overwhelm diners with information, à la the waitress in “Portlandia,” about the provenance of each and every item on his menu.

headline: As Rubio Waffles, Two Floridians in the House Seek Bipartisan Climate Solutions
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Two Floridians in Congress, a Republican and a Democrat, create a House caucus to explore policy options on climate change.
lead_paragraph: Given Florida’s special vulnerability to rising seas and other consequences of human-driven global warming (which I first wrote about in 1988), it’s not surprising that one of the first efforts to break the partisan impasse in the House around this issue has come from two lawmakers from the south end of that state — Republican Representative Carlos Curbelo and Representative Ted Deutch, a Democrat.

headline: Airlines Reap Record Profits, and Passengers Get Peanuts
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Discount Selling']
abstract: Despite the cost savings to airlines from plummeting oil prices, airfares on the biggest domestic carriers have hardly budged.
lead_paragraph: Helped by falling oil prices, airlines are reporting record profits, but for many passengers this sudden bonanza has meant little more than extra bags of free peanuts and pretzels.

headline: Beyoncé Releases Surprise Single ‘Formation’ Ahead of Super Bowl Performance
abstract: The new video was announced on the singer’s Instagram and website Saturday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé is not coming to the Super Bowl empty-handed. A day before her planned performance at Sunday’s game, the singer released a new single, “Formation,” along with a music video that invokes Hurricane Katrina and black pride (“I like my negro nose with Jackson 5 nostrils,” she sings.

headline: Rep. Chris Gibson, a Republican, Explores a Run for New York Governor in ’18
abstract: The 51-year-old congressman will file paperwork on Monday to form a committee that would allow him to raise money for a possible campaign against Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: United States Representative Chris Gibson, a Republican from upstate New York who has become a sharp critic of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, said he plans to create a committee to prepare for a potential run for governor in 2018.

headline: Chinese Zookeepers on the Year of the Monkey
abstract: Two zookeepers, Zhang Hui and Bu Haixia, discussed their monkeys, what’s different about the Year of the Monkey and whether the monkeys care about it.
lead_paragraph: China is home to a wide range of monkeys and other primates, but with the wild ones largely in remote or mountainous areas, zoos offer the best chance for many Chinese to see some up close in this Chinese Year of the Monkey. In anticipation of especially large crowds in coming days, the Nanjing Hongshang Forest Zoo, in the eastern province of Jiangsu, is celebrating the start of the Lunar New Year on Monday with a week of educational events about their primates, some of which are endangered and under special protection. Several of the animals are being shown to the public for the first time.

headline: Adding Insult
abstract: Alan Arbesfeld hurls insults at us. Also, apparently the Super Bowl is this weekend.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — The Super Bowl is definitely this weekend. You might have thought that it was last weekend, but I can tell you with great confidence that it was not. So let’s all just move on and chat about the puzzle so you can watch some football and enjoy all of the amazing Super Bowl snacks you prepared.

headline: Officials Seek Cause of Fatal Crane Crash in Lower Manhattan
abstract: Investigators in New York City continued to examine the wreckage, and crews were starting to cut the tangle of metal into almost three dozen smaller chunks to be carted away.
lead_paragraph: The long metal necks dotting the New York skyline have become familiar symbols of the city’s development rush in recent years. But as one of those cranes lay crumpled on a narrow Lower Manhattan street, toppled after a deadly collapse on Friday, the image of the machine took on a jarringly different meaning.

headline: Miriam Cedarbaum, U.S. Judge, Dies at 86; Sentenced Martha Stewart
abstract: Judge Cedarbuam oversaw thousands of cases since 1986, including the 2004 trial of Martha Stewart that brought wide public attention.
lead_paragraph: Miriam Goldman Cedarbaum, a federal judge in Manhattan who presided over the trial that sent the domesticity expert Martha Stewart to prison for lying to the government about her sale of stock in a friend’s company, died on Friday at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. She was 86. Her son Daniel confirmed her death.

headline: Eighth G.O.P. Debate: Analysis
abstract: We analyzed the eighth Republican debate, the last before the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday, in real time.

headline: Guantánamo Prisoner Sent Home to Morocco Remains in Legal Limbo
abstract: Younis Shokuri feared being repatriated to Morocco, and his lawyers said they were assured there was a deal between the U.S. and Moroccan governments. Yet he remains in custody in his native country.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Younis Shokuri, a Moroccan detainee at the Guantánamo Bay prison, said he feared being repatriated to his native country. But the Moroccan government told the United States that it would probably release him without charges 72 hours after any transfer. So last September, Mr. Shokuri went home — reluctantly, but voluntarily.

headline: El Salvador Arrests Ex-Military Officers in 1989 Jesuit Killings
abstract: Officials said they would continue raids that have so far netted four of the 16 men being sought in connection with the murders of six priests and two others.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Breaking years of inaction over one of the most emblematic cases from El Salvador’s brutal civil war, Salvadoran police have begun to arrest former military officers who are accused in the killings of six Jesuit priests, a housekeeper and her teenage daughter.

headline: Prison Official in Washington State Resigns Over Early-Release Error
abstract: The official, Dan Pacholke, resigned amid a political dispute over a computer coding error that allowed an estimated 3,000 inmates to be released early over 13 years.
lead_paragraph: The top corrections official in Washington State resigned on Saturday amid a political dispute over a computer coding error that allowed an estimated 3,000 inmates to be released early over 13 years.

headline: What You Missed in the Debate
abstract: With three days until the New Hampshire primary, the Republican candidates faced off. Here are the highlights.

headline: Frank Finlay, 89, Is Dead; Was Iago to Olivier’s Othello
abstract: Mr. Finlay, an English actor, was often cast as a rogue or villain and was nominated for an Academy Award for his role in the 1965 film version of “Othello.”
lead_paragraph: Frank Finlay, an Academy Award-nominated English actor known for his screen appearances as Iago in “Othello” and Porthos in “The Three Musketeers,” died on Jan. 30 at his home in Weybridge, England. He was 89.

headline: Yale Educator Recounts ‘Painful Experience’ of Halloween Email Furor
abstract: Erika Christakis, a former lecturer at Yale, spoke for the first time in an interview about her experience as an unwitting target over campus protests against racial insensitivity.
lead_paragraph: NEW HAVEN — Dodging 5-year-olds at the Calvin Hill Day Care Center here, Erika Christakis admired how the teachers celebrated free play as a route to intellectual inquiry, listened to children rather than preaching and stood back to let them find their own way.

headline: The Vote for Bankruptcy Reform that Haunts Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Campaign Finance', 'Bankruptcies']
abstract: The Bernie Sanders campaign has leaned on years-old criticism by Elizabeth Warren, the Massachusetts Democrat, to link Mrs. Clinton to Wall Street.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — As Hillary Clinton fights off intense criticism over her ties to Wall Street, a central question has gone unanswered: Has she ever taken any action that favored the financial industry?

headline: Kunduz Residents Live in Fear of Taliban’s Return
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)']
abstract: Four months after the Taliban overtook Kunduz for two weeks, Afghan forces remain overstretched, and residents worry that the return of the insurgents is inevitable.

headline: Cam Newton Reserves Coveted Souvenir for Young Panthers Fans

headline: Beyoncé in ‘Formation’: Entertainer, Activist, Both?
keywords: ['Music', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Super Bowl']
abstract: In one of her most political videos yet, the singer comments on police brutality and black financial power, one day before taking the Super Bowl stage.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon, Beyoncé released “Formation,” her first new song since 2014, on Tidal and YouTube in advance of her Sunday appearance at the Super Bowl 50 halftime show at Levi’s Stadium in Santa Clara, Calif. The song’s subject is familiar Beyoncé self-affirmation, and the video is among the most politically direct work she’s done in her career, with implicit commentary on police brutality, Hurricane Katrina and black financial power. Jon Caramanica, a pop music critic for The New York Times, Wesley Morris, The Times’s critic at large, and Jenna Wortham, a staff writer for The New York Times Magazine, discussed the song’s sound, the video’s look and the way that Beyoncé increasingly blends the aesthetic and the political. Here are excerpts from their conversation:

Chris Christie of New Jersey. Voters also saw a more muted Senator Ted Cruz, and a Jeb Bush who seemed finally to have found his footing on the debate stage. For Donald J. Trump, the leader in state polls, Saturday night’s affair was one in which he largely stayed above the fray, while delivering some crisp attacks without getting rattled. headline: They’ve Seen It All
abstract: The retired New York Times sportswriters Dave Anderson and Frank Litsky share Super Bowl insights gained over five decades.
lead_paragraph: The Super Bowl has now been around for half a century, which means there are not many journalists who can say they were there at the beginning and have seen every game that followed. But Dave Anderson and Frank Litsky, longtime members of the New York Times sports department who are now retired, can make that claim. The two sat down last week to reflect on how the Super Bowl came about and how it became enormously popular through the decades, with television ratings soaring, Roman numerals crowding together and players like Joe Namath making a name for themselves forever.

abstract: The authorities said that 117 people were believed buried in the ruins of a 17-story apartment tower, and faint cries could be heard beneath the rubble.

headline: Learning to Walk in a Homeless Shelter
abstract: My daughter took her first steps in a homeless shelter. In some ways, I did, too.
lead_paragraph: My daughter learned to walk in a homeless shelter. We had one week left there until we reached the 90-day maximum stay in the shelter system in Port Townsend, Wash., and had grown used to our street, with its five little brown cabins on the edge of town. Our cabin was on the end and had two bedrooms with two twin beds. We had a stand-up shower, a table and a small couch that was covered with a sheet.

headline: 1966: House Passes Cold-War G.I. Bill of Rights
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: New provisions for Vietnam veterans are passed by the House of Representatives in 1966.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House today [Feb. 7] unanimously passed a new GI Bill of Rights for veterans of Vietnam and the cold war of the last ten years. It provides aid for education, home loans and other benefits. The bill, with a first-year price tag of $335 million and a five-year estimated cost of $2.1 billion, was expected to be approved quickly by the Senate, which passed its own more expensive version of the bill last year.

headline: Net Neutrality Again Puts F.C.C. General Counsel at Center Stage
abstract: Jonathan Sallet has had a hand in divisive debates in Washington, and he will draw more attention as decisions are made on net neutrality and the Time Warner Cable-Charter merger.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Every day for one month last fall, Jonathan Sallet, the general counsel at the Federal Communications Commission, sneaked into a small, windowless office at the agency, its location undisclosed except to senior staff.

headline: The Republicans in New Hampshire, Angry and Afraid
abstract: The candidates who debated on Saturday repeated their warnings about immigration, and unfortunately one of the less extreme candidates, Marco Rubio, stumbled at the event.
lead_paragraph: Fear and hatred stalked the Republican debate on Saturday night, aimed at every available target, including, as starkly as ever, the immigrant threat.

headline: Chinese Animal Trainers Looking for Respect in the Year of the Monkey
keywords: ['Lunar New Year', 'Monkeys and Apes', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare']
abstract: The tradition of performing monkeys has fallen on hard times in China, but trainers hope their animal’s turn on the Chinese zodiac cycle will improve business.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The performing monkey masters of Xinye County have been praying at their Monkey King shrine that the Lunar New Year, bringing in the Year of the Monkey on Monday, will also bring back good times for their disappearing vocation.

headline: Performance Monkeys in the Year of the Monkey
abstract: The tradition of performing monkeys has fallen on hard times in China, but trainers hope the new year will bring them and their animals more respect.
lead_paragraph: The tradition of performing monkeys has fallen on hard times in China, but trainers hope the new year will bring them and their animals more respect.

headline: Charges Against Correction Officer
abstract: Nicole Bartley, a correction officer at Rikers Island, was charged with having sex with an inmate whom she said she had fallen in love with.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Bartley, a correction officer at Rikers Island, was charged with having sex with an inmate whom she said she had fallen in love with.

headline: Review: Janis Ian, Singer of ‘At Seventeen,’ Now at 64 and in Solo Concert
abstract: “At Seventeen” may have been a long time ago, but Ms. Ian imbues it with the same power and emotion today.
lead_paragraph: Has there ever been a major pop hit more brutally self-lacerating than Janis Ian’s confessional song “At Seventeen,” in which she used the words “ugly duckling girls like me” to describe the misery of not being a high-school golden girl? The wounds of adolescent rejection and cruelty may eventually heal, but they leave scars.

headline: Review: Jeffrey E. Stern’s ‘The Last Thousand’ Explores the Mission of a Struggling Afghan School
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Education (K-12)', 'Women and Girls', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Hazaras (Ethnic Group)']
abstract: Moral tension animates this portrait of Marefat, a progressive school for girls and boys of the Hazara minority that is endangered by the withdrawal of American troops.
lead_paragraph: In February 2013, Barack Obama promised that the United States would withdraw half its troops from Afghanistan over the course of the year. It was a popular decision. This was, after all, part of what he’d been elected to do.

headline: Credit Suisse C.E.O. Asks for a Cut in His Bonus
abstract: The executive, Tidjane Thiam, asked the board for a “significant reduction” in his bonus after the bank reported a multibillion-dollar quarterly loss.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Tidjane Thiam, the chief executive of Credit Suisse, has asked the company’s board to reduce his bonus, days after the Swiss bank reported a multibillion-dollar loss in the fourth quarter.

headline: Cartoon: Heng on Military Intervention in Myanmar
abstract: The democracy movement of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is negotiating with Myanmar’s military over the composition of the next government.
lead_paragraph: The democracy movement of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi is negotiating with Myanmar’s military over the composition of the next government.

headline: ‘Custom Melodies,’ Time Capsules in Song, at Chinatown Soup
abstract: Grey Gersten, who interviews people and creates songs just for them, played his compositions on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The crinkled papers pinned across the small Chinatown gallery’s walls bore the official tone of citizenship applications. They were covered in check boxes, signatures, blue-stamp notarizations and titled “Custom Melodies Form CM-0027.” But they also contained scrawled drawings and questions: “Do you know your limits yet?” “Most recent Google query?” and “Were you ever involved with the occult?”

headline: Tagore Translation Deemed Racy Is Pulled From Stores in China
abstract: As the nation celebrates the 155th anniversary of the poet’s birth with a translation of his works, another tome, by Feng Teng, has caused a furor.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Nearly 75 years after his death, Rabindranath Tagore, the Bengali poet and Nobel laureate, still has a huge following in Asia. Outside India and Bangladesh, perhaps nowhere is his legacy more alive than in China, where his works have been part of the middle-school curriculum for decades.

headline: Review: Zurich Ballet’s ‘Swan Lake’ Looks to a Classic Version From Long Ago
abstract: Alexei Ratmansky’s production, with the Zurich Ballet and Milan’s La Scala Ballet, restores elements of an 1895 production at St. Petersburg’s Mariinsky Theater.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — The lake with swan-maidens on its bank at night, the swan hunt that leads Prince Siegfried to discover doomed love, the heroine Odette and her evil replica, Odile: “Swan Lake” often feels like the world’s most familiar ballet. Yet Alexei Ratmansky’s new Zurich Ballet production, which had its premiere on Saturday at the Zurich Opera House, shows just how far all other “Swan Lakes” have come adrift.

headline: Review: In ‘Homegrown,’ the Potential Terrorist Isn’t a World Away
abstract: The HBO documentary “Homegrown: The Counter-Terror Dilemma” is about jihadist terrorism in the United States.
lead_paragraph: “Homegrown,” Greg Barker’s new documentary on jihadist terrorism in the United States, beginning on HBO on Monday night, is a thoughtful, multidimensional exploration of a subject that often provokes hysteria.

headline: Review: ‘The Grand Parade’ Romps Through the 20th Century
abstract: This performance presents seminal events and issues of the period, but leaves many others untouched.
lead_paragraph: MONTCLAIR, N.J. — Hey, it’s Kaiser Wilhelm and the influenza pandemic! Also, the Russian Revolution, the Charleston and Harry Houdini. This cavalcade of figures and emblems constitutes just a few minutes of Double Edge Theater’s “The Grand Parade (of the 20th Century),” a highly imagistic and somewhat cryptic sprint through 100 years of popular and political culture, offered by Peak Performances at Montclair State University here.

headline: Review: Benjamin Millepied’s ‘La Nuit S’Achève’ at Paris Opera Ballet
abstract: A day after the company announced that Mr. Millepied would be leaving, it performed the premiere of his choreographed sextet set to a Beethoven Sonata.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Cries of “Merci!” and “Bravo!” erupted from the audience on Friday night when Benjamin Millepied took a bow along with the dancers of the Paris Opera Ballet after a performance at the Palais Garnier. It was a closely watched moment: Just a day earlier the opera had announced that Mr. Millepied would be leaving as director of dance in July and be succeeded by Aurélie Dupont, a retired company étoile. (Not everyone agreed with the shout-outs: “Ridiculous!” a French audience member commented at intermission.)

headline: Italian Student’s Brutal Killing May Be Issue in Egypt-U.S. Meetings
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'International Relations', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Torture']
abstract: Diplomatic visits come amid pressure by Italy for Egypt to find the killers of an Italian doctoral candidate, Giulio Regeni, whose badly beaten body was found in Cairo.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Diplomatic meetings in Cairo and Washington this week are likely to further focus international attention on the death of an Italian graduate student whose badly beaten body was found in Cairo last week.

headline: Review: Gemma Bond Dance Presents ‘Harvest’
abstract: The American Ballet Theater corps member had her first full evening of choreography at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: As a dancer with American Ballet Theater, Gemma Bond is the kind of corps member who can distinguish herself in solo opportunities. Much rarer for a ballerina, though, is the side career she has been developing as a choreographer. At Danspace Project from Thursday through Sunday, she presented her first evening of work.

headline: Grammys Tend to Focus on Heroics in Singling Out the Jazz Solo
abstract: A Grammyish solo, by and large, is a framed event, a bravura spot-lit performance, a physical display. But jazz is about context and collaboration.
lead_paragraph: A friend who edits a monthly jazz magazine tells me that nearly 5,000 new jazz records were sent in his direction last year. That’s not all of the new jazz albums made around the world in 2015, but a decent percentage of them.

headline: Iñárritu Wins Top Prize at Directors Guild Awards
abstract: Mr. Iñárritu was honored for his work on “The Revenant.”
lead_paragraph: Alejandro G. Iñárritu took home the top prize at the Directors Guild of America awards for the second year in a row. After being honored last year for “Birdman,” Mr. Iñárritu won the outstanding directorial achievement award on Saturday for “The Revenant,” becoming the first director to win in back-to-back years.

headline: Review: In ‘Une Éducation Manquée,’ Opera Lafayette Executes a Simple Plot
abstract: This 1879 Chabrier operetta, presented as a satire of the French education system, requires a great suspension of disbelief from contemporary audiences.
lead_paragraph: The ambitious Washington-based Opera Lafayette has, over two decades, taken on many challenging assignments. This season alone, it opened with Vivaldi’s partially lost “Catone in Utica,” and it closes in the spring with “Opera and the French Revolution,” an amalgam of dramatic scenes by Jean-Paul-Égide Martini, Luigi Cherubini and Antonio Sacchini.

headline: Tabloid Twosomes
abstract: The return of Paolo Pasco.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — An amusing start to our solving week, with phrases that contain pairs of the word IT. Solving was easy, but the revealer — the tabloid phrase “IT COUPLES” — kept its secret from me until nearly the end.

headline: ‘Serial’ Subject’s Bid for New Trial Angers Dead Woman’s Family
abstract: A judge in Baltimore last week began reviewing whether Hae Min Lee’s former boyfriend, who was convicted of killing her, should receive a new trial.
lead_paragraph: The family of Hae Min Lee, whose former boyfriend is seeking a retrial 16 years after he was convicted of killing her, broke its silence on Sunday.

headline: NJPAC Announces Classical Season
abstract: Renée Fleming will headline the 2016-17 classical season at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.
lead_paragraph: Renée Fleming will headline the 2016-17 classical season at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark in a lineup that also includes visits from prominent European orchestras.

headline: West Bank Settlers’ Listings on Airbnb Draw Palestinian Anger
abstract: Settlers are renting homes on Airbnb, but the Palestinian Authority condemned the website for not mentioning that the settlements are considered illegal by most of the world.
lead_paragraph: HAVAT GILAD, West Bank — The “studio house” offered recently for $111 a night on Airbnb  is a breeze-block building slightly apart from its neighbors in this illegal settler outpost deep in the occupied West Bank. There are several rooms, sparely furnished and not completely finished, and a lot of junk outside, including empty ammunition crates used for storage. The views over the hills are of a Palestinian village, Farata, and another hilltop Israeli settlement, Ramat Gilad.

headline: Connecticut Faces Lawsuit Over Ebola Quarantine Policies
abstract: Plaintiffs who were put under quarantine in 2014 planned to file a class-action lawsuit alleging the state violated their rights with unnecessary detentions.
lead_paragraph: Law students working with Yale’s legal services organization planned to file a class-action lawsuit in Federal District Court on Monday against Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut and the state’s acting and former health commissioners on behalf of residents affected by Connecticut’s Ebola quarantine policies, including two who were Yale graduate students.

headline: How Julian Assange Is Destroying WikiLeaks
abstract: The website’s founder is letting his anti-democratic ideology undermine the goals of his most famous project.
lead_paragraph: Hamburg, Germany — LAST week a United Nations panel ruled that Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks who has been living in the Ecuadorean Embassy in London to avoid extradition to Sweden, had been arbitrarily detained, and called for his immediate release. Though Mr. Assange says he will remain in the embassy, the ruling was hailed by his legions of supporters, who saw it as a rare instance of justice for a man they believe has been persecuted for exposing government secrets.

headline: Knoedler Gallery Director Settles Lawsuit Over Fake Rothko
abstract: Ann Freedman settled with Domenico and Eleanore De Sole for an undisclosed amount. The case against the gallery is expected to continue.
lead_paragraph: Ann Freedman, long a leading New York gallerist, and a couple who accused her in a federal lawsuit of fraudulently selling them a fake Rothko painting for $8.3 million settled their lawsuit on Sunday.

headline: The Next Battle
abstract: With Iowa and its caucuses behind them, the presidential candidates took their campaigns to New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: With Iowa and its caucuses behind them, the presidential candidates took their campaigns to New Hampshire.

headline: New York Parking Alert: Alternate-Side Rules Suspended on Monday
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Lunar New Year']
abstract: The regulations will be suspended because of the Asian Lunar New Year.
lead_paragraph: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday. Other regulations will remain in effect.

headline: Lawyer for Plaintiffs Suing G.M. Steps Up Criticism of Another
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Liability for Products']
abstract: Lance Cooper, a lawyer who helped bring a deadly switch defect to light, says a lead lawyer for the plaintiffs is putting his own financial interests ahead of the case.
lead_paragraph: The infighting among lawyers for the plaintiffs suing General Motors over a flawed ignition switch intensified after one who helped uncover the defect sharpened his attacks against another who is heading the case.

headline: Bridgewater Executives Deny Report of Rift at the Hedge Fund
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Pensions and Retirement Plans', 'Sovereign Wealth Funds']
abstract: Ray Dalio, the founder, said Bridgewater Associates was continually assessing the responsibilities of executives including Greg Jensen, the co-C.E.O.
lead_paragraph: For Ray Dalio, the billionaire founder of the world’s biggest hedge fund, Bridgewater Associates, transparency is a core principle.

headline: Geneva, a City of Diplomacy, Brims With Totems of Peace and War
keywords: ['International Relations', 'Monuments and Memorials (Structures)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Humanitarian Aid']
abstract: The site of stalled talks on the war in Syria is filled with artistic reminders of the city’s role in trying to save humanity from itself.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — If you walk down the sloping green lawns of the Palais des Nations, you will see 193 blocks of stone, one for each of the nation states recognized by the United Nations, arranged like the infinity symbol, with an extra loop.

headline: Lawsuit Filed by Chicago Police Officer Robert Rialmo
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Officer Rialmo’s lawsuit was a counterclaim to a wrongful death case brought weeks ago by Quintonio LeGrier’s estate, a black 19-year-old who was fatally shot by Mr. Rialmo on Dec. 26.
lead_paragraph: Officer Rialmo’s lawsuit was a counterclaim to a wrongful death case brought weeks ago by Quintonio LeGrier’s estate, a black 19-year-old who was fatally shot by Mr. Rialmo on Dec. 26.

headline: Chicago Officer, Citing Emotional Trauma, Sues Estate of Teenager He Fatally Shot
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The police officer who fatally shot Quintonio LeGrier, a black 19-year-old and an unarmed bystander, is seeking more than $10 million for “extreme emotional trauma.”
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The Chicago police officer who fatally shot a black 19-year-old and an unarmed bystander in December has filed a lawsuit seeking more than $10 million in damages from the teenager’s estate, an unusual legal approach based on a claim that the young man’s actions leading up to the gunfire were “atrocious” and have caused the officer “extreme emotional trauma.”

headline: Draft Registration for Women Would Stir a Sleepy Government Agency
keywords: ['Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Women and Girls', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The change, recently advocated by military officials and lawmakers, could be the most significant for the Selective Service System in decades.
lead_paragraph: ARLINGTON, Va. — Once a month, in a windowless office near the Pentagon, specially trained federal employees roll two lottery machines out of a closet to practice something the government has not had to do in more than 40 years: selecting young Americans for the military draft.

headline: No Corrections: February 8, 2016
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, February 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: De Blasio Announces New Safety Measures After Fatal Crane Collapse
abstract: Starting Monday, crawler cranes are required to stop operating when forecasts or readings for steady wind speeds reach 20 miles per hour or higher or gusts of at least 30 m.p.h.
lead_paragraph: Two days after a 38-year-old man was killed by a crawler crane that collapsed onto a Lower Manhattan street as workers tried to secure it against accelerating winds, Mayor Bill de Blasio said New York City was lowering the wind-speed threshold at which such equipment must be shut down.

headline: In Flint, Hillary Clinton Prods Congress and Calls Response to Crisis ‘Immoral’
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Lead', 'Water', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Water Pollution', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: In a visit 48 hours before the New Hampshire primary begins, Mrs. Clinton implored Congress to pass a bill that would deliver $600 million in aid to Michigan.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — In the midst of a public health emergency over lead-tainted water, Hillary Clinton, speaking at a black church here on Sunday, implored Congress to pass a bill that would deliver aid, calling the city’s contaminated water supply and the delayed response to it “not merely unacceptable or wrong” but also “immoral.”

headline: Oilers’ Connor McDavid Scores a Goal, but the Islanders Do Him Seven Better
abstract: Kyle Okposo had a hat trick as the Islanders spoiled the New York City debut of McDavid, Edmonton’s dazzling rookie, with an 8-1 rout.
lead_paragraph: The wizardry of Connor McDavid finally reached New York City with the Edmonton Oilers’ visit to Brooklyn on Sunday.

headline: ‘The Good Wife’ Is Ending, CBS Announces in Super Bowl Ad
abstract: Only nine more episodes to go.
lead_paragraph: CBS dropped a surprise on fans of “The Good Wife” Sunday night when it announced, during a Super Bowl commercial, that the show’s current season would also be its last.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 8, 2016.
lead_paragraph: "There’s a special place in hell for women who don’t help each other!”

headline: For Peyton Manning, the Setting Is Perfect for a Curtain Call
abstract: Imagine this: Manning, who this season has been coy about whether he will retire, acknowledges that 18 seasons of being an N.F.L. quarterback are more than enough.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — Here’s a perfect ending for Peyton Manning. Or even an imperfect one.

headline: Pet Food Pantries Offer Relief to Animal Owners Struggling With Bills
keywords: ['Pets', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Food Banks and Pantries']
abstract: The pantries have sprung up across the country to help people who view their pets as family, and spend their last dollars on a can of Purina.
lead_paragraph: Cookie flirted with the man at the front counter with the swagger of a born charmer. She tilted her head, fixed him with a knowing look, and leaned forward on two meaty paws.

headline: Ego, Envy or Airtime? Joe Scarborough’s Unusual Spat With Marco Rubio
abstract: An email offers a raw glimpse into an unusual spat involving the host of an MSNBC morning show and a presidential candidate who refuses to appear on it.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — The message from a top producer at MSNBC was blunt: Joe Scarborough, the host of “Morning Joe” on MSNBC, was displeased that Senator Marco Rubio of Florida repeatedly appeared on rival cable news shows but kept rebuffing invitations to appear on his program.

headline: New Hampshire’s First 9 Voters See Spotlight Slip Away
abstract: The dearth of candidate visits to Dixville Notch is one more way in which New Hampshire’s first-in-the-nation primary is seeing some of its cherished grass-roots traditions shaken up.
lead_paragraph: DIXVILLE NOTCH, N.H. — The barely discernible township here has, since 1960, paired its wilderness with outsize political symbolism: Every four years, residents have slipped into voting booths at midnight to cast what they say are the first presidential primary votes in the nation.

headline: How Sea Walls Around Hoboken Might Have Stopped Hurricane Sandy’s Floods
abstract: Staunch opposition has emerged in Hoboken to a $230-million plan to prevent flooding. A model of flows from Hurricane Sandy in 2012 by the Stevens Institute of Technology shows how strategically placed sea walls might work.
lead_paragraph: Staunch opposition has emerged in Hoboken to a $230-million plan to prevent flooding. A model of flows from Hurricane Sandy in 2012 by the Stevens Institute of Technology shows how strategically placed sea walls might work.

headline: Plan to Flood-Proof Hoboken Runs Into a Wall
abstract: After the devastation of Hurricane Sandy, leaders vowed to protect the New Jersey city. But some say plans for walls in the city would ruin its character.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — Every time a powerful nor’easter or tropical storm threatens New York, residents of this small city on the New Jersey bank of the Hudson River start having flashbacks to the devastating inundation they endured when Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012.

headline: Ted Cruz, in New List of Endorsements, Includes Lawmaker Who Didn’t Endorse Him
abstract: Mr. Cruz announced on Sunday the endorsements of six state representatives who had previously supported Rand Paul. At least one representative was surprised to see his name.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Ted Cruz announced on Sunday the endorsements of six state representatives who had previously supported Rand Paul.

headline: Rikers Officer Is Accused of Having Sex With an Inmate
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Officer Nicole Bartley, 30, who also faces drug charges, said she planned to bring marijuana in to the jail as a favor to the inmate, Dasmond Loveless.
lead_paragraph: A correction officer at Rikers Island was arrested on Saturday after being accused of having sexual relations in a jailhouse closet with an inmate as well as possessing marijuana.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Season 6, Episode 6: Does Lady Mary Have a Heart?
abstract: The estate opens its doors to the likes of us. And Carson cannot be satisfied — at least not at home with his new wife.

headline: Bill Clinton Unleashes Stinging Attack on Bernie Sanders
abstract: Addressing supporters in New Hampshire, he portrayed his wife’s opponent for the Democratic nomination as hypocritical, dishonest and “hermetically sealed.”
lead_paragraph: MILFORD, N.H. — Bill Clinton uncorked an extended attack on Senator Bernie Sanders on Sunday, harshly criticizing Mr. Sanders and his supporters for what he described as inaccurate and “sexist” attacks on Hillary Clinton.

headline: Review: It’s Coldplay, Starring Beyoncé, at Super Bowl Halftime Show
abstract: Beyoncé and Bruno Mars, two of the last three years’ headliners, were brought in as reinforcements to provide a much-needed assist to Chris Martin’s band.
lead_paragraph: Everything that could be said about the choice of Coldplay to headline the halftime show at Super Bowl 50 was said by the band members themselves Sunday evening — not with their mouths, but with their outfits.

headline: More Than a River Separates Bernie Sanders’s State From Primary’s
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders is from Vermont, and though Hillary Clinton’s campaign says he will have an advantage in neighboring New Hampshire, the states are not as similar as they appear.
lead_paragraph: HANOVER, N.H. — Hillary Clinton’s campaign maintains that Senator Bernie Sanders could win New Hampshire’s primary on Tuesday because he comes from neighboring Vermont. As Bill Clinton told NBC News: “Nobody from a state bordering New Hampshire has ever lost a Democratic primary to a non-incumbent president.”

headline: Broncos Win Super Bowl 50 as Defense Swarms Panthers
abstract: Led by Von Miller, the Broncos’ stingy defense carried Peyton Manning to his second Super Bowl victory and gave Denver its first title since 1999.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — An anticipated showdown between an old-style quarterback and his new-age counterpart — not to mention two top-seeded teams — degenerated into a morass of poor throws, dropped passes and horrible pass protection, with a combined six turnovers and 18 penalties.

headline: Super Bowl Ads Play It Safe, Sticking to the Script
abstract: Though some commercials were more serious and socially conscious, many advertisers dusted off their well-worn playbooks and went for laughs.
lead_paragraph: Advertisers dusted off their well-worn playbooks for Super Bowl 50, deploying a combination of humor, celebrities and plenty of animals in their annual appeal for the attention of the game’s more than 100 million viewers.

headline: Retreat Favored by Republicans Makes Obama Feel at Home, Too
abstract: President Obama has used the Sunnylands estate to confer with heads of state, but also as a place to unwind with old friends.
lead_paragraph: President Obama has used the Sunnylands estate to confer with heads of state, but also as a place to unwind with old friends.

headline: Obama Revives the Republican Glory Years of Sunnylands Estate
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Golf']
abstract: The lush California estate where President Obama plans to welcome Asian leaders next week — and maybe play some golf — has historically been a Republican retreat.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama spends his Christmas holidays in an oceanfront rental house on the windward side of Oahu. But Hawaii has never really staked a claim to being the home of the western White House. That status increasingly belongs to Sunnylands, the lush estate in Rancho Mirage, Calif., where Mr. Obama plans to welcome leaders from 10 Southeast Asian nations for a summit meeting next Monday.

headline: A Super Bowl Reunion 35 Years After Iran Hostages’ American Homecoming
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Football', 'Super Bowl', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: At a hotel in West Point, one of the 52 Americans taken hostage in Iran in 1979 and relatives of others gathered to watch the Super Bowl.
lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — As Lady Gaga sang “The Star-Spangled Banner” before Super Bowl 50 kicked off on Sunday, Don Cooke walked into the lounge of the Thayer Hotel on the grounds of the United States Military Academy here and put his hat over his heart.

headline: Federal Specialist to Inspect Elevated Radiation at Indian Point
abstract: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is sending its specialist to join the investigation of radioactive groundwater at the power plant, about 45 miles north of Midtown Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission is sending a radiation-protection specialist to New York this week to inspect the Indian Point nuclear power plant after state officials found evidence of a surge in radiation levels in groundwater there, a spokesman for the federal agency said on Sunday.

headline: ‘Billions’ Episode 4: The Harmless Sociopaths
abstract: Bobby’s as rich as can be, but even he doesn’t have everything he wants.
lead_paragraph: Andrew Bird’s “Oh No,” the catchy little song that opens and closes “Short Squeeze,” seems at first like an ironic counterpoint to the action, a cute harmony of whistling and acoustic guitar set against footage of Mick Danzig, a portfolio manager, drunkenly blasting away at deer with a semiautomatic at 4:42 a.m.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | wanderlust
abstract: This word has appeared in 69 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: wanderlust •\ˈwän-dər-ˌləst\• noun

headline: Student Question | Should Students Expect College to Be Like Home?
abstract: What challenges and opportunities appear when college students keep their families involved in their campus life?
lead_paragraph: How often do the college students you know communicate with their families? How much do the students share about their academic pursuits, social lives and post-college goals with their families?

headline: An Illustrated Look at Super Bowl 50
abstract: The illustrator Bob Eckstein once again took in the big game with pen in hand.
lead_paragraph: The illustrator Bob Eckstein once again took in the big game with pen in hand.

headline: Missing From the Big Picture, a Tighter Focus on Peyton Manning
abstract: It became a game of greatly diminished expectations, and Peyton Manning’s diminished skills as a passer. It did not make for a game bursting with life or producing a stirring broadcast.
lead_paragraph: With nine minutes left in Super Bowl 50, CBS’s Jim Nantz offered evidence that the game was anything but a golden evocation of the N.F.L.’s Big Game.

headline: Once Again, Fuzzy N.F.L. Catch Rule Impacts Outcome
abstract: In a season in which the toughest question for the N.F.L. to answer — on the field, at least — was “Was that a catch?,” perhaps the biggest play of the Super Bowl involved such a vexing and controversial query.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — In a season in which the toughest question for the N.F.L. to answer — on the field, at least — was “Was that a catch?,” it was appropriate that what might be considered the biggest play of the Super Bowl on Sunday involved such a vexing and controversial query.

headline: Super Bowl M.V.P. Von Miller, No. 2 in 2011 Draft, Comes Out on Top of No. 1
abstract: The Panthers selected quarterback Cam Newton first over all five years ago, and right behind him the Broncos chose Von Miller, who became the most valuable player of Super Bowl 50 by bedeviling Newton.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — With the first pick in the 2011 N.F.L. draft, the Carolina Panthers drafted Cam Newton. Picking second, the Denver Broncos chose Von Miller.

headline: What to Watch Monday
abstract: “Waking Ned Devine” is new on Amazon, and George Clooney and Quentin Tarantino battle vampires in “From Dusk Till Dawn” on Syfy.
lead_paragraph: “Waking Ned Devine,” the underrated Irish comedy, is new on Amazon. “Alien” merits another viewing no matter how recently you’ve seen it. Jean-Paul Sartre wrote in “Nausea” that 3 p.m. is both too early and too late to do anything, but that was before “From Dusk Till Dawn” was on television.

headline: Cam Newton’s Season of Superlatives Ends in Disappointment
abstract: Newton led the Panthers to a 15-1 record in the regular season on the way to winning the league’s Most Valuable Player Award. But then he faced the Denver Broncos’ exceptionally powerful defense.
lead_paragraph: SANTA CLARA, Calif. — About halfway through the first quarter, with the Carolina Panthers backed up on their own 15-yard line, Denver Broncos linebacker Von Miller made a beeline for quarterback Cam Newton.

headline: Seahawks’ Marshawn Lynch Points Toward Retirement
abstract: With reports circulating that Lynch, a Seattle running back, was considering retiring, he posted a photo on Twitter of two green cleats hanging up.
lead_paragraph: With reports circulating that Seattle Seahawks running back Marshawn Lynch was considering retiring, Lynch appeared to settle the speculation Sunday evening, posting a photo on Twitter of two green cleats hanging up.

headline: Nickname? Just Call Broncos’ Defense One of the Best Ever

headline: The Last Word on James Dean and Dennis Stock

Dennis himself was the subject of “The Articulate Image,” my video about his half-century career as a Magnum photographer. We recorded 20 hours of interviews about his amazing journeys and stories, and his James Dean story was something I knew by heart.

headline: The Time-Loop Party
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republican candidates keep repeating their canned policy statements, despite evidence that these prescriptions have failed in the real world.
lead_paragraph: By now everyone who follows politics knows about Marco Rubio’s software-glitch performance in Saturday’s Republican debate. (I’d say broken-record performance, but that would be showing my age.) Not only did he respond to a challenge from Chris Christie about his lack of achievements by repeating, verbatim, the same line from his stump speech he had used a moment earlier; when Mr. Christie mocked his canned delivery, he repeated the same line yet again.

headline: What Is the Self? It Depends
abstract: When it comes to our relationship to the world, there is an East-West divide. But it can be bridged.
lead_paragraph: I recently took my self to a gathering of a dozen selves to discuss the idea of self, East and West. This created a strange dissonance between the theoretical premise of the meeting and the empirical reality. The people seated around the table seemed very obviously all to be the same kinds of beings, yet they kept telling one another how differently they conceived the self. Stark differences between theoretical selves were completely indiscernible in ordinary human interaction.

lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — BRAZIL is in a state of crisis. Since October, there have been more than 4,000 suspected cases of babies born with a neurological syndrome associated with the Zika virus. The Health Ministry has suggested that women avoid pregnancy until the epidemic has passed or more is known about it.

Five months passed before the city told pregnant women and children not to drink the water, and shut down taps and fountains in schools.

headline: America’s Syrian Shame
abstract: Putin’s policy is hard to distinguish from Obama’s. America’s capitulation is complete, with appalling results.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Putin policy in Syria is clear enough as the encirclement of rebel-held Aleppo proceeds and tens of thousands more Syrians flee toward the Turkish border. It is to entrench the brutal government of Bashar al-Assad by controlling the useful part of Syrian territory, bomb the moderate opposition into submission, block any possibility of Western-instigated regime change, use diplomatic blah-blah in Geneva as cover for changing the facts on the ground and, maybe fifth or sixth down the list, strengthen the Syrian Army to the point it may one day confront the murderous jihadist stronghold of the Islamic State.

headline: ‘The Good Death,’ ‘When Breath Becomes Air’ and More
abstract: Five books explore the way we are shaped by our knowledge of mortality.
lead_paragraph: Death goes in and out of fashion. The topic lingers behind euphemisms for a few years, and then someone calls it forth again: Elisabeth Kübler-Ross with her disciplined “On Death and Dying” in 1969; Susan Sontag with her angry but profound “Illness as Metaphor” in 1978 and the empathetic follow-up “AIDS and Its Metaphors,” in 1988; Derek Humphry, implausibly, with his suicide handbook “Final Exit” in 1991; Sherwin Nuland with his magisterial “How We Die” in 1993; more recently, Joan Didion with her agonizingly precise “The Year of Magical Thinking” in 2005; and Atul Gawande with his humane “Being Mortal” in 2014. Each of these books argues, one way or another, for a continuum between life and its conclusion. The gloss of youthful vitality can persuade us that life is for the living, but life is also for the dying, and repudiating that ultimate punctuation escalates our anxiety and deprives us of final dignity. Time and again, we must clarify our individual and collective beliefs about how the last chapter changes the rest of the narrative. “Or not to be” is not in fact a question.

headline: Song of Inexperience
abstract: For E. M. Forster, sex became symbolic of all in human existence that one could feel but not express.
lead_paragraph: It has often been my experience that rereading a book that was important to me at earlier times in life is something like lying on the analyst’s couch. The narrative I have had by heart for years is suddenly called into alarming question. It seems that I’ve misremembered quite a lot about this or that character or this or that plot turn — they met here in New York, I was so sure it was Rome; the time was 1870, I thought it was 1900; and the mother did what to the protagonist? Yet the world still drops away while I’m reading and I can’t help marveling, “If I got this wrong, and this and this wrong, how come the book still has me in its grip?”

headline: Opening Up About Depression
keywords: ['Depression (Mental)', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: As much as I understand that illness is illness, whether mental or physical, and that there’s a greater openness about depression now than a generation ago, I still feel shame about my depression.
lead_paragraph: I have slogged through a number of difficult situations in recent months, among them the ongoing crises of my elderly parents’ illnesses and the suicide of a friend. I never lost my appetite nor burst into tears, and I didn’t suffer from any of the other typical symptoms of depression. Maybe I was more irritable than usual, a bit more prone to snap. And yes, I buried myself in my work. But I didn’t think I’d tripped down into the rabbit hole of depression.

The officer had gone searching for the bullet, he said. Over the ringing in his ears, he could hear someone wailing. He ran down the stairs. On the fifth-floor landing, a man lay sprawled in blood.

headline: Perversity in a Bottle
abstract: A new fragrance line from a perfume historian brings back the sexiest scents.
lead_paragraph: The perfume historian Barbara Herman insists she is ‘‘not a nostalgist.’’ Still, she found herself lamenting the fact that the more animalic, “erotic” fragrances she prefers (she collects vintage perfumes, like Lanvin’s My Sin and Robert Piguet’s Baghari, from as far back as the turn of the 20th century) went out of favor in the 1990s, for reasons of style and animal rights. (Some of the ingredients were invasively obtained.) And so she decided to bring them back. For the first collection in her new line, Eris, she collaborated with the renowned French perfumer Antoine Lie. Each perfume in La Belle et la Bête, which uses only synthetics for the animal notes, is ‘‘a collision between the animal and the floral.’’ Of the more provocative, funky notes, she says, ‘‘It’s not just shock value. It makes you rethink your sense of smell.’’
