headline: The Unexpected Sequence
lead_paragraph: 恭禧发财! Today we welcome the Year of the Monkey with a mischievous challenge suggested by Sunil Singh, a math consultant with Scolab, an education technology laboratory in Montreal. The best puzzles — including crosswords, of course — will often contain a bit of purposeful misdirection, and Sunil has offered up a challenge that’s beyond tricky. Fortunately, he promises to help us out with few hints (left as comments) if needed.

headline: Exploring the Desert Landscape of Namibia
abstract: A seven-day journey by four women through a surreal landscape yields awe-inspiring sights, and hard-won lessons.
lead_paragraph: A seven-day journey by four women through a surreal landscape yields awe-inspiring sights, and hard-won lessons.

headline: Flash-Free Video in 2016
abstract: Read about how we turned off Flash support for VHS, the New York Times video player.
lead_paragraph: At the beginning of this year, we officially turned off Flash support for VHS, the New York Times video player. We now use HTML5 video technology for all video playback on desktop and mobile web browsers. Flash was a very powerful and popular technology in its day but it has waned over the years as browsers have embraced the open standard of HTML5. Throughout the second half of 2015, Chrome, Firefox and Safari also began blocking the Flash plugin from automatically loading content unless users gave their permission. In order to continue providing a quality video experience for our viewers, switching exclusively to HTML5 video became necessary.

headline: Russia Announces Surprise Military Drills in South
abstract: The Defense Ministry ordered troops in the southern region on full combat readiness, a move that appeared intended to unnerve neighbors.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia’s Defense Ministry announced a surprise military exercise on Monday that ordered troops garrisoned throughout the nation’s southern region to full combat readiness, a move that appeared intended to unnerve neighbors.

headline: Marco Rubio’s Lighter Side
keywords: ['Football', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Super Bowl', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: His performance at a Super Bowl party on Sunday could not have been more different from his embarrassing showing at Saturday’s debate.
lead_paragraph: “Marco Roboto” was nowhere in sight.

headline: Californians Fight Over Whether Coast Should Be Rugged or Refined
abstract: The effort to oust the executive director of the California Coastal Commission, one of the most powerful governmental groups in the nation, has created a firestorm.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — It has been one of the most powerful governmental agencies in the nation, with sweeping powers to determine what gets built, or does not get built, on the 1,100 miles of cliffs, mountains and beaches along the Pacific Ocean, one of the country’s great destinations.

headline: The Many Frenemies of Ted Cruz
abstract: During the Republican primary campaign so far, the Texas senator has been famously disliked by his rivals — but also indispensable to them.
lead_paragraph: One evening at a hotel bar in Des Moines shortly before the Iowa caucus, a top strategist for the campaign of Senator Ted Cruz looked up from his adult beverage, allowed himself an amused smile and observed, “We probably have had more frenemies than anyone else in the field.”

headline: A Party on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown
abstract: How a bad night for Marco Rubio might pitch the Republican primary into chaos.
lead_paragraph: Right up until Saturday night, it appeared that the race for the Republican nomination was about to rationalize itself along the lines that many people, myself included, had expected for a while. Marco Rubio, coming off his strong third in Iowa, had bounced up into the mid-teens in a bunch of New Hampshire polls. This bounce suggested that he was poised to be — as in Iowa — the candidate of late deciders, leaving him with at least the strong second place finish that he needed to put Jeb Bush and Chris Christie on life support, and possibly more if Donald Trump dramatically underperformed his polls. The party establishment, such as it is, was showing signs of deciding on Rubio, the rest of the field was being winnowed, and a Trump-Ted Cruz-Rubio three-way race — assuming no Trump collapse — seemed like it could be upon us within weeks.

headline: A Firestorm Over Gloria Steinem and Madeleine Albright
abstract: Readers young and old react to comments by Ms. Steinem and Ms. Albright directed at young women.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: In Hospitals, Smoke-Free Doesn’t Mean Abuse-Free
keywords: ['Addiction (Psychology)', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'Smoking and Tobacco']
abstract: Hospitals can make substance abusers well and sick at the same time.
lead_paragraph: The substance user and the hospital are bound by the most ambivalent of relationships. Heavy users — of tobacco, alcohol or harder drugs — see far more of the wards than the average citizen and, it is safe to say, like them even less.

headline: Sanctions Lifted, American Tourists Head to Iran
abstract: Drawing comparisons to interest in Cuba trips, tour operators say that Iran is fast becoming a popular destination for Americans.
lead_paragraph: The lifting of sanctions on Iran last month has resulted in a surge of bookings, tour operators say, many from Americans undeterred by a State Department warning laying out the risks of taking trips there.

headline: Michael Brick, Former Times Reporter, Dies at 41
abstract: Mr. Brick helped cover the collapse of Enron, the aftermath of Hurricane Katrina and offbeat sports for The Times.
lead_paragraph: Michael Brick, a former reporter for The New York Times who covered crime in New York, education in Texas and extreme sports nationwide, died on Monday in Austin, Tex. He was 41.

headline: Ring of Elephant Poachers Broken Up by Tanzanian Authorities
abstract: An inquiry into a British pilot’s death led to nine arrests — including a conservation intelligence officer — on charges of poaching elephants for their ivory.
lead_paragraph: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania — An investigation into the death of a British helicopter pilot who was looking for poachers near Serengeti National Park has uncovered a criminal poaching ring led by a rogue intelligence officer, the Tanzanian authorities said on Monday.

headline: 4 Manhattan Bars That Set the Mood for Romance
abstract: Meaghan Dorman sets an amorous tone at Dear Irving, the Bennett, and two locations of the Raines Law Room.
lead_paragraph: The Raines Law Room, a well-upholstered, low-lit underground speakeasy in the Flatiron district, seems engineered for intimacy. Cushioned alcoves can be shielded from prying eyes by floor-to-ceiling curtains. Call buttons, a common fixture in taverns a century ago, are at every booth and table, allowing a guest to summon service without breaking the mood.

headline: Syrians Desperate to Escape What U.N. Calls ‘Extermination’ by Government
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A new United Nations report accuses the government of President Bashar al-Assad of “inhuman actions” against Syrian civilians.
lead_paragraph: KILIS, Turkey — Tens of thousands of Syrians who were running for their lives piled up near the border crossing with Turkey here on Monday. They were fleeing a crushing wave of Russian airstrikes and government ground forces advancing toward the frontier in a developing rout of insurgent forces north of Aleppo, Syria’s largest city.

headline: Elizabeth Dee Gallery Is Moving to Harlem
abstract: The gallery’s move from Chelsea is the latest sign of Harlem’s growth as a gallery district.
lead_paragraph: It is still a long way from being the new Chelsea, or the new Lower East Side, or even the new Brooklyn. But Harlem is starting to gain speed as a new gallery district. The Elizabeth Dee Gallery, which has operated in Chelsea for 15 years and has represented sought-after artists like Ryan Trecartin, Adrian Piper and the collective Leo Gabin, announced that it is moving to a new space on Fifth Avenue between East 125th and East 126th Streets in May.

headline: Donald Trump’s Colorful Encounter With a Hometown Reporter
abstract: Donald Trump bumped into Marcia Kramer, a well-known New York TV reporter, in an encounter that brought a dash of the New York media world to New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Donald J. Trump has brought his oh-so-New York swagger to New Hampshire, and some other Big Apple personalities have followed close behind, bringing their own tabloid touch to the tradition-bound first primary state.

headline: Part of John Kasich’s Problem: Liberals Like Him
abstract: The ability to appeal to Democrats and to work with them is seen by many conservatives as a liability.
lead_paragraph: Our readers seem to like John Kasich. Liberal pundits and editorial board writers in New Hampshire tend to like him, too. Liberals and moderates in New Hampshire, who are plentiful and who are allowed to vote in the primary of their choosing if they are not registered with a party, also seem to have a soft spot for him.

headline: HSBC Case Tests Transparency of Deferred Prosecution Agreements
abstract: A judge’s order to release secret documents raises questions about how much involvement courts should have over settlements related to corporate wrongdoing.
lead_paragraph: Abraham Lincoln once said, “Let the people know the facts and the country will be safe.” Whether that view applies to disclosure of a corporate monitor’s report about HSBC’s response to money laundering problems that resulted in a deferred prosecution agreement in 2012 is the focus of a dispute between the Justice Department and Judge John Gleeson of the Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

headline: East Meets West in a One-of-a-Kind Cartier Pendant
abstract: Art Deco geometry mingles with Indian exoticism in an opal and sapphire necklace from the French jeweler.
lead_paragraph: The jeweled panther may be the most recognizable symbol of Cartier, but the historic French house has always nurtured a subtler, more abstract side as well. Louis Cartier, who traveled to India and the Far East in the early 1900s, strove to combine the streamlined geometry of Art Deco with the lush motifs of Asia. Cartier’s chief designer (and Louis’s purported lover) Jeanne Toussaint often expressed that East-meets-West aesthetic in dangling necklaces made with unexpected stones; Cecil Beaton likened them to rosaries. This one-of-a-kind piece evokes those early masterworks. A gold chain adorned with black lacquer chevrons and diamonds cradles an Ethiopian white opal of nearly 16 carats, from which a rare green sapphire leads to the pendant’s decadent drop — a honeycomb of gold and jewels punctuated by a pear-shaped imperial topaz. Not as dangerous as a jungle cat, perhaps, but just as beguiling.

headline: The New Shape of Women’s Tailoring
abstract: Of-the-moment garment construction upends clean, unfinished hemlines with slits and unexpected proportions.
lead_paragraph: Of-the-moment garment construction upends clean, unfinished hemlines with slits and unexpected proportions.

headline: Larchmont Takes a Breather From Building
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Zoning', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: A developer’s plan to tear down a grand old home and build four in its place helped inspire the village in Westchester County to press pause on new construction.
lead_paragraph: LARCHMONT, N.Y. — The yard signs began appearing in November, only a few at first, lodging in lush lawns, flower beds budding in the unseasonable warmth, and on picket fences and stone walls. They quickly began to spread across this compact village on Long Island Sound, in front of grand Victorians and Tudors and simple (yet seven-figure) Cape Cods and split-levels.

headline: JPMorgan Backs Geithner’s Investments With Warburg Pincus
abstract: Timothy Geithner, the president of Warburg Pincus and former Treasury secretary, arranged a line of credit with JPMorgan Chase to invest in the firm’s funds.
lead_paragraph: Timothy F. Geithner has joined fellow Warburg Pincus partners in securing financing to make personal investments in the private equity firm’s funds.

headline: 7 Trends From a Month of Men’s Fashion Shows
abstract: Cuddly? Check. Military? Got that, too. A quick guide to the latest looks in men’s wear.
lead_paragraph: Cuddly? Check. Military? Got that, too. A quick guide to the latest looks in men’s wear.

headline: Experience Science: Count Birds From Your Backyard
abstract: Thousands of bird-watchers are expected to join the Great Backyard Bird Count, an annual avian census used to create a massive online database.
lead_paragraph: Bird-watchers worldwide will flock to parks and backyards this Presidents’ Day weekend to record the winter whereabouts of millions of birds.

headline: For Some Cord Cutters, Streaming Super Bowl Was a Nonstarter
abstract: Users complained that a CBS Sports app cut out while they were trying to watch the big game.
lead_paragraph: Watching the Super Bowl over the weekend turned out to be a not-so-superb experience for some owners of streaming devices like the Apple TV and Google’s Chromecast.

headline: Review: ‘The Girl in the Red Coat,’ an Abduction Story Told in Two Voices
abstract: Kate Hamer’s debut novel about an 8-year-old girl who is taken captive is narrated from the perspective of the girl and her despairing mother.
lead_paragraph: The title of Kate Hamer’s gripping debut novel, “The Girl in the Red Coat,” immediately recalls the explosion of similarly titled books and movies, from Stieg Larsson’s “The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo” and its sequels, to “The Girl on the Train” to “Gone Girl,” “The Good Girl,” “The Danish Girl” and “The Girl With a Clock for a Heart.”

headline: The Renewable Fuel Standard
abstract: The National Biodiesel Board says the standard is working, “diversifying a fuel supply dangerously reliant on fossil fuels.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lending Her Ears to an M.I.T. Experiment
abstract: A writer begs a researcher to let her find out where in her brain the music-specific pathway resides, subjecting herself to a barrage of sounds.
lead_paragraph: I’m not claustrophobic or fidgety. I love music, though I’m not a musician. For all the times I had written about neuroscience studies that rely on the brain-mapping technique called functional magnetic resonance imaging, or F.M.R.I., I had never seen a scan performed. This was my chance.

headline: New Ways Into the Brain’s ‘Music Room’
abstract: M.I.T. researchers have devised a radical approach to brain imaging that reveals what past studies missed about neural responses to music.
lead_paragraph: Whether to enliven a commute, relax in the evening or drown out the buzz of a neighbor’s recreational drone, Americans listen to music nearly four hours a day. In international surveys, people consistently rank music as one of life’s supreme sources of pleasure and emotional power. We marry to music, graduate to music, mourn to music. Every culture ever studied has been found to make music, and among the oldest artistic objects known are slender flutes carved from mammoth bone some 43,000 years ago — 24,000 years before the cave paintings of Lascaux.

headline: Argentine Offer Opens the Way for a Debt Settlement
abstract: Argentina’s offer of a 25 percent discount on its bonds could be the best deal possible for holdout creditors.
lead_paragraph: Real money may finally be on the table in Argentina.

headline: Concord Cake Returns to West Side
keywords: ['Bakeries and Baked Products', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Cakes', 'Korean Food (Cuisine)', 'Hamburgers']
abstract: Also, a book on Korean food in New York; sweet scents of chocolate; a sleek Italian pot; and ground prime rib for burgers.
lead_paragraph: The demise of Soutine Bakery on the Upper West Side three years ago left chocolate lovers without its signature confection, the ultimate dacquoise, mousse layered with crisp meringue collapsing into a creamy pillow at the touch of a fork. The cake, originally called Concorde, was created in 1969 by the French chef Gaston Lenôtre for the debut of the supersonic jet that year. Gadi Peleg, an owner of Breads Bakery, grew up in the neighborhood and is one of those who missed Soutine’s version. Now, with the blessing of Madge Rosenberg, who owned Soutine, Mr. Peleg and his partner, the baker Uri Scheft, have brought back the cake, now called Concord, at the new branch of their bakery across from Lincoln Center. The bright, airy store also sells breads, other pastries, salads and sandwiches and has outdoor seating: Concord cake, $38, or $12 for the mini, Breads Bakery, 1890 Broadway (63rd Street), 212-633-2253, breadsbakery.com.

headline: Chesapeake Energy Plagued by Plunging Shares
abstract: Shares of the beleaguered oil producer fell to as low as $1.51 on Monday after a trade publication reported that the company had hired restructuring lawyers.
lead_paragraph: The pain for Chesapeake Energy began early on Monday, as its stock began to tumble. And kept falling.

headline: “In the Seed We Have the Universe”
abstract: The art and meditation space Inner Fields hosted a plant-themed drawing night on Saturday — participants drew both real plants and a “plant spirit” embodied by a ballet dancer.
lead_paragraph: The art and meditation space Inner Fields hosted a plant-themed drawing night on Saturday — participants drew both real plants and a “plant spirit” embodied by a ballet dancer.

headline: A Nature-Inspired Drawing Event — With a Dance Twist
abstract: For a plant-themed evening at the new Prospect Heights art and meditation space Inner Fields, 10 participants sketched dead flowers and a live ballerina.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night in Prospect Heights, the artist Elaine Su-Hui hosted “In the Seed We Have the Universe,” the first figure drawing event at Inner Fields, a new shoebox-sized art space she designed to give people a place to connect with nature. Most of the 10 who came had no formal drawing training, but they all plopped down on cushions to silently draw portraits of the “plant spirit”: the classically trained ballet dancer Leah Mulartrick, who expressed the plant’s life cycle with sprightly dance moves.

headline: Donald Trump Denies Saying What He Said About John McCain
abstract: Donald J. Trump denied calling Senator John McCain a loser. But he did say it, in reference to Mr. McCain’s loss to Barack Obama in the 2008 presidential race.
lead_paragraph: LONDONDERRY, N.H. — There have been several indications recently that Donald J. Trump is trying to temper his language and tone in the final days before the New Hampshire primary. One came Monday morning, when Mr. Trump insisted he had never called Senator John McCain, the self-described maverick who won the state’s primary twice, a “loser.”

headline: New Hampshire Voters Hear Candidates’ Final Appeals Before Primary
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Snow and Snowstorms']
abstract: As the snow fell, the Republican and Democratic candidates carried on, with at least one front-runner wondering how the weather would affect turnout.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — A rambunctious herd of presidential candidates dashed across a snowy New Hampshire on Monday, making last-ditch efforts to persuade undecided voters on the eve of the nation’s first primary election, the outcome of which could bring a dose of clarity to a campaign that has become surprisingly muddled.

headline: Ganging Up Against Cancer
abstract: A reader urges “the scientific community to collaborate for the greater good.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Obama Will Seek $11 Billion for Homeless Families
keywords: ['Homeless Persons', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Affordable Housing', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: While homelessness among veterans has decreased, family homelessness has proved more persistent as wages fail to keep pace with skyrocketing housing costs in many cities, including New York.
lead_paragraph: After making progress in reducing homelessness among veterans, the Obama administration is turning to the larger and more complicated challenge of homelessness among families with young children.

headline: Moving Data From Europe
abstract: The Future of Privacy Forum says E.U. regulators’ efforts to threaten data transfers to the U.S. are the wrong way to press for surveillance reforms.

headline: Star Brothers Are Apparently the Latest to Defect From Cuba
abstract: The star Cuban infielder Yulieski Gourriel and his younger brother were apparently trying for careers in Major League Baseball.
lead_paragraph: When a delegation of major leaguers made a goodwill visit to Cuba in December, they were welcomed by a 22-year-old budding star of the island’s domestic league, Lourdes Gourriel Jr. Dressed in aviator sunglasses and white high-tops, he looked the part of a big leaguer but was awestruck by introductions to Clayton Kershaw and Miguel Cabrera.

headline: A Diverse Pixar Crew Grabs an Oscar Nomination
abstract: “Sanjay’s Super Team,” an animated short directed by the Indian-American Sanjay Patel, was produced by a woman and made by an ethnically broad crew.
lead_paragraph: Amid the controversy over the all-white slate of acting nominees for this year’s Oscars, “Sanjay’s Super Team,” a candidate for best animated short, embodies the kind of inclusive filmmaking that many critics say the motion picture academy should recognize more often. The film — directed by Sanjay Patel, an Indian-American who grew up in California; produced by a woman; and made by an ethnically diverse crew — shares a highly personal tale that resonates with many audiences: the clash between a tradition-minded immigrant father and his more assimilated son.

headline: Chris Christie Says Race Is ‘Wide Open’ Heading Into Primary
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie, invigorated after his performance in Saturday night’s debate, declared the Republican race to be “wide open” on Monday as he hopes for a better-than-expected finish in Tuesday’s primary.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, invigorated after his performance in Saturday night’s debate, declared the Republican race to be “wide open” on Monday as he hopes for a better-than-expected finish in the New Hampshire primary on Tuesday.

headline: Bernie Sanders and the V.A.
abstract: Readers discuss Senator Bernie Sanders’s response to complaints about health care for veterans.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: De Blasio’s Streetcar Plan
abstract: A reader fantasizes about a politician’s admission that he has no idea how much a project will eventually cost.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Humans Are Spreading Deadly Bee Virus, Study Says
abstract: Researchers say that the trade and movement of honeybee colonies have caused deformed wing virus to travel all over the world.
lead_paragraph: The deformed wing virus is decimating bee populations worldwide, and it is spreading because of human trade and the transport of bees, a new study reports.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Attitude Toward Wall Street Is Subjective
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Capital Gains Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Depending on how your brain processes information, Mrs. Clinton is deep in the pocket of Wall Street, or she has a smart plan to rein in its excesses.
lead_paragraph: About a year ago, there was a viral debate over the color of a dress. Was it white and gold? Or blue and black? The answer seemed like it must be objective — something is either blue or it isn’t — but in fact was subjective. The answer depended on how your brain processed the image and how it subconsciously subtracted either the blue or gold to account for the implicit effects of daylight.

headline: Portraits of an Older Michelangelo Indicate He Had Arthritic Hands
abstract: The master probably had osteoarthritis, but his commitment to art may have kept his hands functional until his death in 1564, according to doctors.
lead_paragraph: Michelangelo probably had osteoarthritis, but his commitment to art may have kept his hands functional until his death in 1564. Those are the conclusions drawn by doctors who studied three portraits of Michelangelo from ages 60 to 65 by other artists. The paintings show that the small joints of his left hand were affected by noninflammatory degenerative changes, yet earlier portrayals show no such deformity. “Continuous and intense work could have helped Michelangelo to keep the use of his hands for as long as possible,” said Davide Lazzeri, a specialist in plastic reconstructive and aesthetic surgery at the Villa Salaria Clinic in Rome and an author of a report in The Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine.

headline: Hackers Get Employee Records at Justice and Homeland Security Depts.
abstract: The breach appeared to be by an intruder who impersonated a government employee, but officials said there was no indication that sensitive information had been stolen.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the latest cyberattack targeting the federal government, an intruder gained access to information for thousands of employees at the Justice Department and the Department of Homeland Security, but officials said Monday that there was no indication that sensitive information had been stolen.

headline: Foreign Policy Questions Push Bernie Sanders Out of Comfort Zone
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Mr. Sanders, running against a former secretary of state, has for months replied to questions about counterterrorism by returning to more familiar turf: income inequality.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont was asked on Sunday about the North Korean missile launch that took place while he was appearing the previous night on “Saturday Night Live,” and he answered without once discussing how he would contain or confront the renegade nuclear state, or persuade China to control its ally.

headline: Rangers Keep Rolling as Captain Sits Out
abstract: The Rangers prevailed without their sidelined captain for the team’s first win in three games this season against the Devils.
lead_paragraph: Defenseman Ryan McDonagh, the Rangers’ captain, missed his first game of the season Monday with a concussion. His team soldiered through, winning its third straight game with a lift from a stoic defenseman who had broken his right thumb only six days earlier.

headline: Taliban Suicide Bomber Kills at Least 3 in Northern Afghanistan
abstract: Explosives were detonated near an Afghan National Army minibus in Mazar-i-Sharif, which had until lately seemed almost immune to violence seen in other parts of Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Taliban suicide bomber killed at least three people on Monday and wounded 18 more in the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif, officials said.

headline: An American Football Fan in Paris
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Football', 'Mobile Applications', 'Super Bowl', 'Television', 'Television Sets and Media Devices', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Vending Machines']
abstract: The time difference means watching the Super Bowl on Monday — and blocking out who won until then.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — When my wife and I woke up on Monday morning, all our computers, cell phones and other devices were down and we studiously ignored the blinking voicemail light. And when I turned on the iPad, I covered it with a magazine to see only the “slide to unlock” line at the bottom, then swish! directly to the Game Pass app. Cast that onto the TV screen, and a sigh of relief. We’d done it again.

headline: Iranian News Channel Suspends 2 Executives in Sexual Harassment Case
keywords: ['Sexual Harassment', 'Television', 'News and News Media', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: A prominent newscaster on Iran’s state-run English-language news channel recorded an explicit conversation in which one of the men asked her for sex.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Press TV, Iran’s state-run, English language news channel, suspended two executives on Monday after a prominent newscaster said she had endured years of sexual harassment from them.

headline: Rihanna Rebounds in Second Week on the Charts, and ‘Anti’ Takes No. 1
abstract: After opening at No. 27, Rihanna’s eighth album sold 124,000 copies in its first full week of release and leaped to the top of the Billboard 200.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Rihanna’s starting position on the Billboard chart took a painful hit, with her long-anticipated new album, “Anti” (Roc Nation), reaching just No. 27. But on the latest chart, after accounting for the album’s first full week of sales, “Anti” sailed straight to No. 1, with 124,000 copies sold and 14.2 million streams in the United States, according to Nielsen.

headline: Gregg Feinstein, 54, Dies; Head of Mergers at Houlihan Lokey
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Mr. Feinstein was one of the rare bankers who publicly advised shareholder activists on their campaigns for change at corporations.
lead_paragraph: Gregg Feinstein, the head of mergers and acquisitions in the United States for the investment bank Houlihan Lokey and an adviser to shareholder activists, has died. He was 54.

headline: Bill Clinton Has a Few Thoughts About the Meaning of ‘Establishment’
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The former president criticized Senator Bernie Sanders for dismissing many Hillary Clinton supporters as being members of the “establishment.”
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. – A day after Bill Clinton attacked Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on multiple fronts, the former president refined his critiques by zeroing in on the senator’s habit of dismissing Democratic leaders and liberals who disagree with him as “part of some mythical establishment.”

headline: Study Links Sleeplessness and False Confessions
abstract: Research subjects who were kept awake were much more likely to admit to something they did not do than those who slept.
lead_paragraph: Sleep deprivation may lead individuals to confess to crimes they did not commit, new research suggests.

headline: Cockroaches: Indestructible, and Instructive to Robot Makers
abstract: The pests could offer a new model for devices that crawl through rubble to look for survivors or gather information after disasters, scientists say.
lead_paragraph: Humans may never be able to exterminate cockroaches, but they may be able to learn something from them.

headline: Bills’ LeSean McCoy Said to Be Involved in Assault That Left Two Police Officers Injured
abstract: McCoy and a former San Diego Chargers player, Curtis Brinkley, were reportedly involved in a dispute at a Philadelphia club.
lead_paragraph: LeSean McCoy, the Buffalo Bills running back who led the N.F.L. in rushing in 2013, was under investigation after a weekend assault in Philadelphia sent two off-duty police officers to the hospital with injuries, according to local news media reports.

headline: ScienceTake | Building a Rescue Roach
abstract: Cockroaches move so well through small spaces that they make good models for robots to find survivors in collapsed buildings.
lead_paragraph: Cockroaches move so well through small spaces that they make good models for robots to find survivors in collapsed buildings.

headline: Post-Super Bowl ‘Late Show’ Draws 21.1 Million Viewers
abstract: It was the biggest audience ever for the show and for its host, Stephen Colbert, and it will be hard for him or any other late-night host to hit viewership numbers like that again.
lead_paragraph: Stephen Colbert’s special post-Super Bowl broadcast of “The Late Show” drew 21.1 million viewers on Sunday night, the first time a late-night host was given the time slot after the game.

abstract: Despite intensifying criticism from the Clinton campaign, the Sanders team is sticking with what it considers a winning message about waging a political revolution against a rigged economy.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, NH — The Sanders campaign seems to almost feel bad for Hillary Clinton.

lead_paragraph: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.

lead_paragraph: After a bruising campaign, the results in the presidential primaries in New Hampshire were decisive.

headline: For Chris Christie, Success on Tuesday Is a Moving Target
abstract: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, knowing the fate of his campaign could rest on New Hampshire, could not say what level of support he would need to stay in the race.
lead_paragraph: HAMPSTEAD, N.H. — Chris Christie knows Tuesday is a big day that could very well decide the fate of his presidential campaign. But in the final hours before the primary here, he is resisting saying specifically what would make the day a success.

headline: How to Vote in the New Hampshire Primary
abstract: A Republican National Committee member from New Hampshire, Steve Duprey, explains how residents of the state can vote in the Republican and Democratic primaries.
lead_paragraph: A Republican National Committee member from New Hampshire, Steve Duprey, explains how residents of the state can vote in the Republican and Democratic primaries.

headline: Suit Against Knoedler Gallery Over Fake Rothko Continues After a Settlement

headline: A Unisex Clothing Line Inspired by the Construction of Buildings
abstract: Aaron Jacobson, creator and designer of the two-year-old line Faan, was originally trained as an architect.
lead_paragraph: Seated at a table overlooking 8th Avenue in the New York Times cafeteria, the fashion designer — and formally trained architect — Aaron Jacobson admits that he’s slightly distracted by the view. But he returns to focus on the given topic, his unisex clothing line, Faan, saying, “I don’t really see good design as having gender. The gender-neutral thing was never explicitly meant as a political statement; it happened naturally, from the beginning. I’m not drawn to a red-carpet gown; I’m drawn to the proportions and shapes and construction details that you see every day,” here, he gestures toward the window, “and to me, my clothes are sexy because they’re thoughtful.”

headline: Hard Money Men
abstract: Has anyone actually listened to Kasich on economics?
lead_paragraph: So what will happen in NH tomorrow? I have no idea. We must dispel with this notion that anyone has the slightest idea what they are doing. However, there seems to be a real possibility for one thing that seemed unlikely before the RubiOS bug manifested itself: that John Kasich will come in second on the Republican side.

headline: Beyoncé’s Halftime Show Inspires Ridiculous Criticism
keywords: ['Discrimination', 'Football', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Music', 'National Anthems', 'Olympic Games', 'Olympic Games (1968)', 'Police', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Rock Music', 'Super Bowl']

lead_paragraph: What do Beyoncé, Tommie Smith and John Carlos have in common? They all managed to get the white political establishment to sputter in outrage by daring to celebrate their identity and mention – gasp – racial politics at a public event.

headline: A Beloved Childhood Lemon Tart Recipe, Courtesy of agnès b.
abstract: A tarte au citron made from the designer’s late mother’s recipe will be available throughout this month at Maman’s West Broadway location.
lead_paragraph: Now, thanks to a limited offer at the Maman bakery and café in New York, you can have a taste of agnès b.’s childhood. When the French fashion designer was young, she would often watch her late mother make a version of tarte au citron that, to her, beat out the versions found in French pâtisseries. Her mother would cover the dough with beans so it wouldn’t curl up, baking it until it was golden and crunchy. Then, she added the filling — a mixture of lemon, egg yolks, sugar and flour — returned the pastry to the oven and let it sit for 15 minutes, topping it with beaten egg whites. She gave it a sprinkling of lemon zest for an extra kick of citrus. “I think it’s much better because they often make it with not enough lemon, and too creamy,” she says. “But this recipe from my mother, it must be an old recipe, but it’s very good. You must use pure lemon with nothing on the skin.”

headline: Tunisian Town Simmers With Unrest Over Lack of Jobs and Investment
abstract: In a country where nearly a third of young people are unemployed, the jobless in Kasserine have occupied part of the governor’s office and declared a hunger strike.
lead_paragraph: KASSERINE, Tunisia — After graduating from college and still not being able to find a job, Ridha Yahyaoui protested with 78 other graduates in a sit-in two years ago. Most were eventually given public-sector positions, but Mr. Yahyaoui was left out.

headline: Bush and Clinton Campaigns Show the Downside of Dynasties
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The flip side to the advantages of being a dynastic candidate: You often have to compete with more natural politicians who got to the top on their own.
lead_paragraph: Why have Jeb Bush and Hillary Clinton struggled so much during this campaign? It might seem as if the public is weary of Bushes and Clintons and has turned against dynastic politics, but voters don’t usually punish politicians for being members of political families. Becoming a long-term member of the House of Representatives, for example, substantially increases the odds that a relative will also serve in Congress.

lead_paragraph: Michael R. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, confirmed in an interview with The Financial Times that he was actively weighing an independent campaign for president in 2016.

lead_paragraph: BOSTON — For thousands of college hopefuls, the stressful college admissions season is about to become even more fraught. The College Board, which makes the SAT, is rolling out a new test — its biggest redesign in a decade, and one of the most substantial ever.

headline: ‘Voter-Shaming’ Mailer That Made Noise in Iowa Shows Up in New Hampshire
abstract: A voter-turnout tactic employed by Ted Cruz’s presidential campaign in Iowa is cropping up in New Hampshire, by way of an organization about which few public details are available.
lead_paragraph: A controversial voter-turnout tactic employed by Senator Ted Cruz’s presidential campaign in Iowa is cropping up in New Hampshire, this time by way of a mysterious organization about which few public details are available.

headline: Reporting on Zika When You Have Zika
abstract: Trying to distinguish caution from panic, thermometer in hand.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot we don’t know about the Zika virus, but there’s one thing I’m sure of: I had it last month. I got to Haiti in early January, a few days before the first cases were confirmed in the country’s capital, Port-au-Prince. Two weeks later, my wife started developing symptoms. A blood test confirmed she had the disease. By then, I was experiencing the same symptoms: the low-grade fever, then a mild rash covering my face and chest, pinkish eyes, and when those cleared up, stiff fingers and toes that plumped up like sausages.

lead_paragraph: TAINAN, Taiwan — Long before a 17-story condominium complex was ever built across the street from his family home in the early 1990s, Yang Yumin used to play on the site as a boy.

headline: Turban-Wearing Sikh American Actor Is Barred From Aeroméxico

lead_paragraph: An American actor and designer said he was barred from boarding a plane in Mexico on Monday for a flight home to New York because he refused to remove his turban during a security check.

headline: Review: In ‘Untapped,’ Percussive Sass From RAW Dance Company
abstract: The Australian ensemble’s show at the New Victory Theater sets out to amuse, deploying eye-catching moves in routine after routine.
lead_paragraph: If a show’s success can be measured by the number of happily shrieking children in the audience, then “Untapped!” was a big hit on Friday night at the New Victory Theater. The perky percussive dance production, performed by the RAW Dance Company of Brisbane, Australia, brings together five tap dancers, a beatboxer and three musicians — on bass, guitar and drums — for one relentlessly energetic hour intent on engaging distractible minds.

headline: Richard P. Von Herzen, Explorer of Earth’s Undersea Furnaces, Dies at 85
abstract: Dr. Von Herzen, an oceanographer, uncovered thousands of miles of interconnected volcanoes where the planet’s oceanic plates pull apart and ooze molten rock.
lead_paragraph: Richard P. Von Herzen, an explorer who found that the icy depths of the deep sea concealed vast regions of simmering heat, helping to confirm the scientific view of the Earth’s crust as continuously in motion, died on Jan. 28 in Portola Valley, Calif. He was 85.

headline: Review: Jon Kinzel’s ‘Atlantic Terminus,’ in Which Dance and Visual Art Converge
abstract: In a residency at Invisible Dog in Brooklyn, the choreographer explores creative intersections with the help of guest artists.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Jon Kinzel paced around the Invisible Dog, a vast Brooklyn arts center, before planting himself in front of a wall onto which he drew a maze of shapes. It was already covered with his artwork — drawings, collages and paintings from the past 25 years. In another corner of the space, a woman, only partly visible, reclined on her back in a tent while knitting. A table covered with art supplies hinted at how Mr. Kinzel, an accomplished choreographer, is currently spending his days — making art, making dances and discovering where the two forms meet.

headline: Review: Ashley Fure Highlighted in a Composer Portrait at Columbia
abstract: This composer’s work, including “Something to Hunt,” was performed at the university’s Miller Theater.

lead_paragraph: If Cyrano had been a lesbian United States Army veteran with a blog — well, Ginger Lazarus’s “Burning” finishes that sentence in the admirable Resonance Ensemble  production at the Theater at St. Clement’s.

headline: Review: ‘Here We Go Again,’ a Tradition of Teenage Moms
abstract: A new series on TV One follows two women who became mothers at 16, and their concerns for a daughter in the newest generation.
lead_paragraph: It sure was a long time ago that “I Love Lucy” scriptwriters were forbidden to use the word “pregnant.” Nowadays, not only has pregnancy been employed as a plotline in every imaginable way — planned, unintended, surrogate, etc. — but television also has an entire universe of reality shows on the subject, so many that “Saturday Night Live” once mocked MTV as “Maternity TV.”

headline: Alwin Nikolais’s Influence on Dance Is Resurrected
abstract: A program at the Joyce Theater is meant to remind viewers of this choreographer’s multimedia mindset and his impact.
lead_paragraph: Before Pilobolus, before Momix, before Mummenchantz, there was Alwin Nikolais, the great magician of 20th-century dance. Nikolais (1910-1993) created shape-shifting, otherworldly visual wonders through original experiments with bodies, space, light and sound, and his work was hugely popular and influential from the 1950s until the 1990s. Today, however, it’s not well known to general audiences. But Tuesday through Sunday, a program of four pieces, spanning his long career, comes to the Joyce Theater.

headline: Bad Shape of Knicks Starts With the Triangle

lead_paragraph: The happiest man in America is — or should be, at least — Steve Kerr. We don’t really know how close he actually came to accepting an offer from Phil Jackson in May 2014 to coach the Knicks — only that Kerr had understandable reservations about becoming the frontman, or fall guy, for the newly minted Team Triangle before an offer he couldn’t refuse from the Golden State Warriors made it a moot point.

headline: Rihanna’s ‘Anti’ Is the Record You Make When You Don’t Need to Sell Records
abstract: The old economics of selling albums are collapsing. With ‘Anti,’ Rihanna has taken that fact as an invitation to make any music she wants.
lead_paragraph: As its name suggests, “Anti,” the new studio album from pop singer Rihanna (and this week’s No. 1 on Billboard’s album charts), is unlike any of the records that preceded it. For as long as she has been a star, Rihanna’s career has functioned as a perfectly oiled pop machine: Her first record dropped in 2005, when she was 17, and she has churned out a new album each subsequent year for the entire decade since, collecting multiplatinum sales, eight Grammys and 24 nominations in the process. Her success doubled, then tripled and quadrupled; the assembly-line model turned her into a perfectly produced product, ready for consumption.

Yet he’s hoping to “try it again and explain what I was trying to say the first time.”

headline: Artur Fischer, Inventor With More Patents Than Edison, Dies at 96

While airstrikes can help achieve short-term military objectives, he told reporters, “they do not, on their own, achieve long-term stability.”

headline: Donald Trump Tries a Town Hall Event, and It’s a Hit
abstract: Such traditional events have been few and far between for Mr. Trump, but for roughly an hour on Monday he capably handled one in Londonderry.
lead_paragraph: LONDONDERRY, N.H. — Donald J. Trump’s version of a town hall event throughout most of the campaign has been to have audience members shout questions at one of his mega-rallies. Traditional town hall events, which voters in the early states have historically demanded of candidates, have been few and far between.

headline: Sam Spence, Who Set the Fierce Dance of the N.F.L. to Music in Film, Dies at 88
abstract: Spence’s compositions were used to set the mood for NFL Films, and he was the last survivor of the four men credited with popularizing the football highlight genre.
lead_paragraph: Sam Spence, a prolific composer for NFL Films who marshaled sawing strings, rattling drums, pounding timpani, resonant horns, twittering woodwinds and blaring trumpets to create a signature soundtrack for the quasi martial enterprise known as pro football, died on Saturday, the day before the Super Bowl, in Lewisville, Tex. He was 88 and had lived for most of his adult life in Munich, Germany.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10, Episode 4: Back in the Day
abstract: An emotional episode whose two halves don’t exactly line up.
lead_paragraph: “Back in the day,” both the concept and the actual phrase, are prominent in this episode of “The X-Files.” So let’s begin there. Back in the day, Scully’s mother was her rock. She supported her choice to leave behind a medical career and pursue her work in the F.B.I. and on the X-Files. And she never pushed Mulder away, even when his exploits repeatedly put her daughter in peril. Back in the day, Mrs. Scully was about the only person who called Mulder Fox. Back in the day, Mrs. Scully lost her husband (Season 1, “Beyond the Sea,” which is also beyond creepy), and her other daughter, Melissa (Season 3, “Paper Clip”).

headline: The Trump Brand, Win or Lose
abstract: What happens if a business built on victory falters?
lead_paragraph: BRIAN CONNELLY, a computer consultant in Landrum, S.C., has owned the domain name loser.com for more than 20 years. He has primarily used it as a private joke and to poke fun at Kanye West. But in December, after Donald J. Trump called for barring Muslims from entering the United States, Mr. Connelly started redirecting loser.com visitors to the Wikipedia page for Mr. Trump. Last week, after Mr. Trump placed second in the Iowa caucuses, Mr. Connelly was pleased to see a significant uptick in traffic to his site. “It was a little bit of karmic justice,” he said.

headline: Evidence of Prisoner Abuse, Still Hidden
keywords: ['September 11 (2001)', 'Torture', 'Detainees', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Photography', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Editorials']
abstract: Allowing the Pentagon to indefinitely block the release of photos that document prisoner abuse in Iraq and Afghanistan is unjustifiable.
lead_paragraph: Responding to a lawsuit, the Department of Defense last week released 198 photos that added little to our understanding of the shameful period after the Sept. 11 attacks during which American troops systematically abused detainees. If the military has its way, the period will be largely forgotten. The Pentagon continues to fight the release of roughly 1,800 photos gathered as part of criminal investigations into allegations of prisoner mistreatment by American troops in Iraq and Afghanistan.

headline: When Addiction Has a White Face
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Heroin', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine', 'Addiction (Psychology)']
abstract: For African-Americans, today’s softer stance on addiction looks painfully different from the crack era.
lead_paragraph: WHEN crack hit America in the mid-1980s, for African-Americans, to borrow from Ta-Nehisi Coates, civilization fell. Crack embodied instant and fatal addiction; we saw endless images of thin, ravaged bodies, always black, as though from a famined land. And always those desperate, cracked lips. Our hearts broke learning the words “crack baby.”

abstract: In a new book, Yan Xuetong of Tsinghua University calls on China to forge military partnerships abroad and build a more humane society at home.
lead_paragraph: Yan Xuetong, the director of the Institute of International Relations at Tsinghua University in Beijing, argues for a more assertive foreign policy for China in his latest book, “The Transition of World Power: Political Leadership and Strategic Competition.” In the book, which the Chinese state news media has reviewed favorably, he advocates what he calls moral realism as a rising China challenges the United States for world leadership. This approach would combine a greater emphasis on forging military partnerships abroad while building a more humane society at home.

headline: Chirlane McCray and the Limits of First-Ladyship
abstract: What two years in Gracie Mansion have meant for a woman who aspired to be the “voice for the forgotten voices.”
lead_paragraph: The first time I had lunch with Chirlane McCray at Gracie Mansion, I was distracted by the wallpaper. This was just about a year after her husband, Bill de Blasio, was sworn in as mayor of New York. In a breathlessly short period, McCray had gone from being a poet, wife and mother, with a job writing ad copy for a neighborhood hospital, to being first lady of New York City with a day-to-day schedule that could consist of everything from reading books to kindergartners in a classroom in East New York to exchanging pleasantries with Catherine, the Duchess of Cambridge.

headline: Natalia Vodianova Shares Her Beauty Routine
abstract: What she has learned from modeling, and why she doesn’t do yoga.
lead_paragraph: The model Natalia Vodianova, 33, is known for her Cinderella story: She went from selling fruit in her native Nizhny Novgorod in Russia to scaling the heights of the fashion world. A luxury-campaign favorite — she is currently the face of Calvin Klein Euphoria perfume — Ms. Vodianova has also become a philanthropist, founding the Naked Heart Foundation, which supports Russian families raising children with special needs, and hosting the organization’s annual Fund Fair, to be held this year in London on Feb. 20.

headline: ‘Forty Rooms,’ by Olga Grushin
abstract: In Grushin’s novel, a woman who dreams of being a poet wrestles with compromise and heartbreak.
lead_paragraph: The structure of Olga Grushin’s original new novel, “Forty Rooms,” is ingeniously simple. Over several decades, we follow the Russian-born narrator ­— an aspiring poet turned American housewife — into the 40 rooms that represent the topography of a privileged, middle-class woman’s life. We are taken from the “stuffy and bright” Moscow apartment bathroom — the first place to “emerge from the haze of nonbeing” when the protagonist is not yet 5 — to the suburban America entrance hall from which she will finally depart. And along the way, we come of age with the person whom we know, tellingly, only as Mrs. Caldwell. Or perhaps I should say, we come of ages with Mrs. Caldwell, because as any woman in her fifth decade or beyond can attest, most of us come of age in many stages: as daughter, as wife, as mother, as . . . you get the idea. It is a mark of the author’s skill that, while sweeping us along in Mrs. Caldwell’s particular narrative, Grushin indirectly challenges the reader to reflect on her own history; to come up with the labels that contribute to her own identity — writer, sister, for example — and to name the rooms in which she has come to her own realizations.

Several companies offer excursions on the scooters; with most, tourists ride as passengers while the driver is their guide, but a few tours give visitors the chance to drive the bikes themselves.

headline: It’s in America’s DNA to Be ‘Divisive’
keywords: ['English Language', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Debates (Political)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: The label used to mean the subject was worth arguing about. Now, in pop culture, sports and politics, it’s a conversation-ender.
lead_paragraph: Let’s face it: There are some things we just can’t face. Life’s too short. Somebody’s too sensitive. And the subject — whatever it is, although lately it’s been whatever — is too third-rail dangerous. Border walls, charter schools, closing Guantánamo, global warming, that Al Jazeera documentary claiming Peyton Manning used performance-enhancing drugs, Hillary Clinton, #OscarsSoWhite: Why bring any of this up? Why bring it up now? It’s too fraught, too . . . divisive.

headline: Singapore’s Artistic Experiment
abstract: This island republic’s ambition to be the art capital of Southeast Asia could be hard to reconcile with its conservative social mores.
lead_paragraph: Singapore — Wandering through the spectacular new National Gallery here, it’s easy to discern Singapore’s urge not just to showcase the best of its art, but to educate its visitors. Among the exhibitions are a solo show of works by Tang Da Wu and a lavish display of paintings by Chua Ek Kay, hugely important local artists who remain little known outside Southeast Asia. Then there is an entire floor dedicated to an exhibition titled “Siapa Nama Kamu?” (“What Is Your Name?”), which traces the history and identity of Singapore from its origins as a British colony to a modern cosmopolitan city-state.

headline: Uruguay’s Quiet Democratic Miracle
abstract: If ‘South America’ summons images of political turmoil, populist tyrants, religious mania and epic corruption, think again.
lead_paragraph: Montevideo, Uruguay — “Because here nobody is better than anybody else.” The phrase, one of this small South American country’s most cherished sayings, dates back to the 19th century and is often repeated by its thinkers, presidents and everyday citizens. As a simple expression of the democratic spirit, it sums up how Uruguayans feel about their homeland.

headline: Ukraine and the West Need Each Other
abstract: Despite Putin’s threats, the West should keep its promises of closer ties.
lead_paragraph: Kiev, Ukraine — After centuries of nearly continuous foreign control, we Ukrainians achieved our independence from the Soviet Union 25 years ago, in 1991. In 2005, after a fraudulent election brought Viktor Yanukovych into power, our Orange Revolution helped defeat him. And this month, we mark two years since Maidan — the Revolution of Dignity — when we overthrew kleptocratic rule by Mr. Yanukovych a second time. For Ukrainians, it seems the new Ukraine is never here; it’s always coming.

headline: Reviving the Art of David Jones
abstract: A retrospective reveals the range of the remarkable British artist and poet.
lead_paragraph: CHICHESTER, England — The British artist, poet and critic David Jones was something of a prodigy. In 1909, at age 14, he won a place at Camberwell College of Arts and Crafts in London, where his first teacher held his work up as an example to older students, saying: “Look at that, you see, Jones leaves everything out except the magic.”

Rather, it was the one for the new Quicken Loans “Rocket Mortgage,” which aims to make it easier to get a mortgage using a mobile device.

headline: Lighting That Lets Spring Shine in
abstract: The designer Lindsey Adelman’s wall-spanning fixture — reminiscent of a cherry tree branch in bloom — is an organic wonder.
lead_paragraph: Winter drapes the limbs of cherry trees with shimmery icicles, but by early spring, pale blooms will push forth. The American designer Lindsey Adelman evokes both these seasons in her latest lighting fixture, the Cherry Bomb Fringe, created for the design gallery Nilufar in Milan. The fixture’s tubular brass branches can climb walls (or a ceiling, if you wish) and can be customized in various sizes. Its graceful metal arms — punctuated by gold-leaf handblown glass globes — drip with hundreds of slender brass chains that sparkle in the reflected light like sun on ice, or as summer days grow long and languid, like links of Spanish moss tumbling over outstretched boughs.

lead_paragraph: The floor exercise in gymnastics is all about the tumbling, right? Sure, in between the runs the gymnast shows off her balance or does balletlike moves, but that’s just a moment for athletes and fans to catch their breath.

headline: The Possibility of More: High School Senior Chases the ‘Aha!’ Moment
abstract: High school senior Rachel Abbe finds that solving crossword puzzles enables her to learn things that class time does not provide.
lead_paragraph: SPECIAL POST — For Rachel Abbe, a high school senior from Westchester, N.Y., the ticket to relief from the intense pressure of college preparation and midterm exams lay in a stack of blank New York Times crosswords on a stand near the school librarian’s desk. Moments when she did not have to focus on vocabulary words she’d never seen or drill math problems were precious and few, but just a few feet away sat a chance to take a break and do something productive at the same time. Eventually, taking that deep dive into the hobby of crossword solving affected her so much that she wrote her college application essay — a prime piece of mental real estate for any college-bound teenager — on why she solves.

headline: Review: Samantha Bee’s Fierce, Fiery Feminism Anchors ‘Full Frontal’
abstract: The comedian’s new weekly show, which began on Monday, could free her from chasing the 24-hour news cycle, and she is one of few female comics in a boys’ club.
lead_paragraph: In the cold open of “Full Frontal With Samantha Bee,” her new weekly show Mondays on TBS, Ms. Bee addressed the elephant in the man cave.

lead_paragraph: The Swedish actress Alicia Vikander has been the It Girl of this awards season, not least because of the one-two-punch performances she delivered in 2015, first as the seductive humanoid Ava in “Ex Machina” and then as Gerda Wegener, the devoted wife of Eddie Redmayne’s pioneering transgender character, Lili Elbe, in “The Danish Girl.” She’s won nominations and awards for both, and is the projected front-runner for the best supporting actress Oscar for her work in “The Danish Girl.”

headline: ‘Jane the Virgin’ Season 2, Episode 11: Teacher Crush
abstract: Jane has inappropriate thoughts about her adviser.
lead_paragraph: This week’s “Jane the Virgin” is all about self-reflection and re-evaluation. Two of the Villanueva women — Jane and Xiomara — each find themselves at confusing points in their lives, forcing them to re-evaluate priorities, career goals and even a promise made at age 10. Getting older, whether you’re in your twenties or about to hit 40, occasionally means looking back on what you once thought was important and coming to terms with the fact that things shift: maybe you wanted kids, and now you don’t; maybe you once put everyone else first and now you want to focus more on making yourself happy.

headline: ISIS, in a First, Says It Was Behind Attack in Syrian Capital

headline: 1941: British Fleet Rains on Genoa
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: British forces wreak havoc on the Italian port of Genoa in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Warships of the British Mediterranean fleet swept into the Gulf of Genoa at dawn this morning [Feb. 9] and poured more than 300 tons of shells into the Italian naval base and other military targets in that area. The bombardment was carried out in conjunction with an attack launched from the 22,000-ton aircraft carrier Ark Royal, whose planes dropped several tons of bombs and a large number of incendiaries. One plane was the only loss suffered by the British force, while the damage done to the enemy was inestimable. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 10, 1941

headline: Obama’s Last Budget, and Last Budget Battle With Congress

headline: ‘Valley of the Dolls,’ by the Numbers
abstract: The pop culture classic remains as gleefully salacious as ever — even as it turns 50.
lead_paragraph: When the actress Jacqueline Susann was diagnosed with breast cancer in 1962, she made a deal with God: She would settle for 10 more years of life. . . if she could become the world’s most popular writer. In the 12 years that followed, she became just that: the first novelist to achieve three consecutive New York Times No. 1 best sellers, and one of the richest self-made women in America. Her first novel, ‘‘Valley of the Dolls,’’ remains a pop-culture touchstone: a gleefully salacious story of friendship, sex, backstabbing and pills (or ‘‘dolls’’) that won famous fans and detractors alike. (Susann, who died in 1974, made hundreds of appearances to support the novel and is credited with inventing the modern book tour.) Now celebrating its 50th anniversary, the tawdry tale of Anne Welles, Jennifer North and Neely O’Hara hasn’t lost its punch. Here, a look at the vital stats behind one of the most talked-about books of all time.

headline: Bonds on the Run

She learned English while young (she was raised in Rhode Island) and in it has written four authoritative works of fiction, including “Interpreter of Maladies” (1999), for which she won a Pulitzer Prize.

headline: Salvation Burger in Turtle Bay Joins the Family
abstract: Also, Freud offers Austrian fare; Gentilly travels to New Orleans; and Bark has closed.
lead_paragraph: Salvation Burger April Bloomfield and Ken Friedman, who started the Salvation brand with tacos, now welcome burgers and hot dogs into the tent. “I love burgers and I take pride in cooking them, but I always wanted to grind my own meat and make all the other stuff,” Ms. Bloomfield said as she layered two flattened patties with house-made “processed” cheese that is based mostly on English Cheddar. There’s also a steak burger seared over wood, a vegetable burger that oozes beet juice and a homemade hot dog. The beef, raised upstate, is butchered in house. The restaurant is spacious and handsome, with an open kitchen, curtained booths, waiter service and a collection of bovine tchotchkes. Milkshakes, spiked or not, and creamy pies ramp up the calorie count: (Opens Wednesday): 230 East 51st Street, 646-277-2900, salvationburger.com.

When opinions about his acting abilities hit their nadir, around the time he won a Razzie for worst actor of the century in 2000, he half-agreed with his harshest detractors.

headline: That Wasn’t a Meteorite That Killed a Man in India, NASA Says
abstract: A “land-based” explosion was the likely cause, not an object from space, which would have been a first of sorts in recorded history.
lead_paragraph: The news reported by Indian newspapers and picked up by many outlets around the world was startling: A bus driver was killed and three people were injured after a meteorite hit a college campus on Saturday. If true, it would have been the first scientifically confirmed report in history of someone being killed by a meteorite impact.

headline: A Victory for Voting Rights in Maryland
keywords: ['Ex-Convicts', 'Probation and Parole', 'State Legislatures', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: The state legislature has passed a bill that will restore voting rights to nearly 40,000 people with felony convictions.
lead_paragraph: The state laws that will bar nearly six million people with felony convictions from voting in this year’s presidential election are the shame of the democratic world. Virtually all disenfranchised Americans would be free to vote were they citizens of countries like Australia, Spain, France, Ireland or Germany. Indeed, many nations around the world view voting rights as so fundamental to citizenship that they bring the ballot box right into prison.

It also seems to have led to surprising progress in the movement to curb female genital mutilation in the poor West African country.

headline: A Lingerie Brand That Aims for Comfort — and Inclusivity
abstract: Just in time for Valentine’s Day, Lonely Lingerie introduces new styles and sizes.
lead_paragraph: The best bra holds the right fit, shape and lift with delicate balance; often it’s as much about what’s refused as what’s offered. That’s the idea behind Lonely Lingerie, the New Zealand-based label founded by Helene Morris in 2009. “We don’t do padding,” she says. “We don’t do push-up. For us, it’s a natural aesthetic. It’s still really supportive, but it’s supremely comfortable.”

headline: A Forceful Voice in Defense of Israel’s Image Abroad
abstract: Gilad Erdan, a rising star in the conservative Likud Party, has a lot on his mind, much of it concerned with waning international support for Israel.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Gilad Erdan is one of the rising stars of the conservative Likud Party: a 45-year-old former yeshiva student, a lawyer and an adviser to two prime ministers, Ariel Sharon and Benjamin Netanyahu. For the March 2015 elections, he was No. 2 on the party list, just after Mr. Netanyahu, whom he now serves as minister of public security, strategic affairs and public diplomacy. But only after Mr. Erdan played hardball and refused initial offers.

Like television spec scripts being submitted to a network for development consideration, these were headed to Ralph Lauren for approval.

lead_paragraph: Infants infected with the Zika virus may be born not only with unusually small heads, but also with eye abnormalities that threaten vision, researchers reported on Tuesday in the journal JAMA Ophthalmology.

headline: Corporate Inversions Aren’t the Half of It
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Shelters', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: The bigger benefit to corporations fleeing American tax bills — and the bigger loss to American taxpayers — is a maneuver called earnings stripping.
lead_paragraph: If you thought there was a problem with inversions — deals that allow American companies to relocate their headquarters to lower their tax bills — wait until you hear about the real secret to avoiding corporate taxes. It’s called earnings stripping, and it is a technique that the Obama administration has so far failed to stop.

Clapper, warned Tuesday that North Korea had expanded its production of weapons-grade nuclear fuel, making clear that the Obama administration now regarded the reclusive government in Pyongyang, rather than Iran, as the world’s most worrisome nuclear threat.

headline: Peter Liang Aimed Before Firing Shot That Killed Akai Gurley, Prosecution Says
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The shooting in a Brooklyn stairwell was not accidental, an assistant district attorney said in closing arguments at the police officer’s manslaughter trial.
lead_paragraph: In closing arguments on Tuesday at the manslaughter trial of a New York City police officer charged in the shooting of an unarmed man, the prosecution presented a new argument to jurors: The officer did not mistakenly fire a bullet that ricocheted off a wall and killed Akai Gurley, who was walking down the stairs of a Brooklyn housing project, as the defense has argued.

headline: Haiti: Drought Worsens Food Crisis, U.N. Agency Says
abstract: More than 1.5 million Haitians are threatened with malnutrition — double the number of six months ago — because of a three-year-old drought.
lead_paragraph: More than 1.5 million Haitians are threatened with malnutrition — double the number of six months ago — because of a three-year-old drought that has been worsened by the global El Niño weather phenomenon, the anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said Tuesday. The agency, the World Food Program, classified these people as the “severely food insecure” subset of 3.6 million Haitians who are facing food insecurity — lack of access to a reliable and affordable food supply. It also said that up to 70 percent of the crops in some areas of Haiti, the Western Hemisphere’s poorest country, had been lost this past year. Wendy Bigham, the agency’s deputy director in Haiti, said that without rain for the 2016 spring season, many farmers would lose their fourth consecutive harvest. Agriculture employs half the working population in Haiti, and 75 percent of the people live on less than $2 a day.

headline: Martin Brodeur’s No. 30 Is Raised to Rafters as Devils Honor 3-Time Cup Champion

headline: Republican Budget Tantrum
abstract: It’s a new low when the chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees won’t even hold hearings with the White House budget director.
lead_paragraph: By law, dating back to 1921, the president of the United States must submit an annual budget request to Congress. On Tuesday, President Obama submitted his eighth and final budget. And like all presidential budgets, it is a statement of values and priorities, a blueprint for turning ideas into policies, a map of where the president wants to lead the country.

headline: Russia: Putin Opponent Is Attacked After Veiled Threat
abstract: Mikhail M. Kasyanov, a leading figure in the political opposition was attacked late Tuesday in Moscow by a dozen or so men who placed a cake on his head.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail M. Kasyanov, a leading figure in the political opposition whose image the leader of Chechnya, Ramzan A. Kadyrov, menacingly posted online in the cross hairs of a sniper rifle this month, was attacked late Tuesday in Moscow by a dozen or so men who placed a cake on his head at a restaurant. Mr. Kasyanov told the Interfax news agency that men “of a non-Slavic nationality,” a common euphemism here for Chechens, set upon him in a Moscow restaurant, yelled death threats, smeared the cake on his head and then left. Mr. Kasyanov served as prime minister during President Vladimir V. Putin’s first term before joining the opposition.

headline: Always, Sometimes, Never

headline: ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’ Episode 2: The Chase
abstract: O.J. goes on the run and one of the most famous car chases ever ensues.
lead_paragraph: This episode opens with two crucial questions: The Los Angeles County District Attorney Gil Garcetti wonders “How does a murder suspect disappear from a house full of people?,” and Robert Shapiro wants to know, “Who the hell signs a suicide note with a happy face?” The entirety of “The Run of His Life” (the episode takes its name from the Jeffrey Toobin book on which the series is based) is about the manhunt for O.J., the infamous Ford Bronco chase and the nonstop news coverage of both.

headline: David Schwimmer on Playing a Kardashian in ‘The People v. O.J. Simpson’

lead_paragraph: David Schwimmer and O. J. Simpson were moving in opposite directions in 1994, with the actor growing famous as part of a new hit sitcom, “Friends,” as the former football star’s life fell apart on national television.

headline: As Donald Trump Wins, Mainstream G.O.P. Is Left to Muddle On

lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Republican leaders had aimed to bring a swift and orderly resolution to the party’s presidential primaries, avoiding a long and costly fight that could stretch well into the spring.

headline: What About Ted Cruz?
abstract: The prospect of a general election between candidates whom leaders and strategists in both parties see as losers is more than an idle fantasy.

headline: DraftKings-ESPN Deal Ends
abstract: DraftKings was released from its sponsorship deal with the cable network.
lead_paragraph: DraftKings has been released from its sponsorship deal with ESPN, another indication of the mounting pressure on daily fantasy sports operators. According to an executive familiar with the dealings between the companies, DraftKings asked out of its agreement, and ESPN granted the request. Last year, ESPN backed out of a proposed deal to invest about $250 million for a 20 percent stake in DraftKings because ESPN’s parent company, the Walt Disney Company, did not want to be involved in an industry that it felt was too close to gambling. Along with FanDuel, DraftKings is waging an expensive legal fight against the determination in states like New York, Illinois and Texas that daily fantasy games violate their laws.

headline: Primary Exit Polls Show Terror Fears Aided Trump and Young Voters Helped Sanders
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Youth', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Terrorism', 'Voting and Voters']

lead_paragraph: Two-thirds of New Hampshire Republican primary voters agree with Donald J. Trump’s proposal to temporarily bar Muslims from entering the United States. And they overwhelmingly express fear of another terrorist attack.

But the results also tell much about the electorate and the challenges the contenders face going forward.

headline: The Environmental Legacy of the Steel City
abstract: A group of photographers documenting environmental issues around air quality control in Pittsburgh hopes their images will spur others to action.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Lynn Johnson grew up in Pittsburgh, a city famed for its industry and attendant air pollution. She still recalls how her father would take a spare white shirt to work every day, as his collar would become discolored by noon. While the Steel City has given way to more tech-driven jobs, in the 21st century its air quality still ranks among the worst in the country, according to the American Lung Association.

headline: The Many Mideast Solutions
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Palestinians']
abstract: Our presidential candidates can retire their platitudes about standing with Israeli and Sunni Arab allies.

My question is: (A) Do you care? (B) What are you going to do about it? And (C) how important is it to you?”

keywords: ['Cable Cars and Trams', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Transit Systems', 'Subways', 'Parking']
abstract: A line that actually improves quality of life for New Yorkers must be fast, frequent and reliable.
lead_paragraph: SIXTY years ago, the last trolley jangled down the streets of Brooklyn, the end of an era for what was once the most common mode of transportation for urban Americans. Now streetcars are making a comeback nationwide. In the past decade, new lines have started running in eight cities; nearly a dozen more will be under construction this year.

abstract: Just a few years ago the Queens neighborhood was mostly filled with industrial buildings; today it’s a pleasant place to live, with large luxury towers rising in the neighborhood.

But Mr. Lavaia, 42, had heard that the area, then still mostly filled with industrial buildings, was a good investment and, with more residential development underway, would soon become a more pleasant place to live.

Many also will wind up sidelined by injury. But a new study suggests that being light on your feet could keep most runners healthy.

headline: Why Students Lie, and Why We Fall for It
abstract: All kids lie, the writer Maria Konnikova says. It’s a part of growing up, testing limits and adjusting to social expectations and norms.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been a teacher, primarily of middle and high school English and Latin, for a long while now, and in that time I’ve been conned a thousand times. Now, I love my students. They are some of the most kind, giving and earnest children I know. And yet they have cheated, forged notes and lied to me. While I’ve usually been able to get at the truth behind my students’ deceit, I have to admit I have a few unsolved cases filed away in my desk drawer.

headline: ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ Is Headed to Broadway
abstract: The producer Scott Rudin has acquired stage rights for Harper Lee’s novel and has hired Aaron Sorkin to adapt the story. Bartlett Sher will direct.
lead_paragraph: Over the past 55 years, Harper Lee’s “To Kill a Mockingbird” has racked up pretty much every accolade imaginable. It won the Pulitzer Prize and was adapted into an Academy Award-winning film starring Gregory Peck. The book became a commercial blockbuster that sold more than 40 million copies, a staple on school curriculums, and an enduring moral parable about a young girl’s coming of age in an unjust world.

headline: Paul Ryan’s Budget Strategy Collides With Conservatives’ Demands

lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill. — President Obama on Wednesday came to the place where he began his historic campaign for the White House nine years ago to the day, to reckon with perhaps his presidency’s greatest failure: his unfulfilled promise to lift American politics above toxic partisan divisions.

headline: To Reduce the Risk of Alzheimer’s, Eat Fish
abstract: Among carriers of the gene that increases Alzheimer’s risk, a study found a benefit from eating seafood at least once a week.
lead_paragraph: Eating seafood is linked to a reduced risk of dementia-associated brain changes in people who carry the ApoE4 gene variation, which increases the risk for Alzheimer’s disease. Eating seafood was not linked to similar changes in those who carried other forms of the ApoE gene.
