headline: Letter of Recommendation: The Beekeeper Joke
abstract: I can tell most jokes just fine. Somehow, though, the funniest joke in the world (as I insist it is) escapes my efforts.
lead_paragraph: The funniest joke in the world, as I insist it is, proceeds like many others: two guys meeting on the street; the presentation of a problem; the suggestion of a remedy; and then, of course, the unex­pected consequence. Most jokes like this depend on some sort of misunderstanding. ‘‘Madam, your son has got his foot stuck in my daughter’s commode!’’ — like that. But this one’s not like that. The standard model is just confusion. You can see where things went wrong; just back it up and you’re O.K. The world’s the same again. That’s part of the fun.

headline: The Living Artist
abstract: In spaces intimate and public, LaToya Ruby Frazier reveals ongoing life in the steelworking ‘‘ghost town’’ of Braddock, Pa.
lead_paragraph: If you look down toward the river from the upper section of Braddock Avenue, you see a landscape entirely altered by heavy industry. The Edgar Thomson Steelworks was Andrew Carnegie’s first mill. With the other mills in the area now shut down, it is also his last. The industrial landscape on which it sits is interrupted by plumes of smoke and looks blasted and forlorn, like a medieval battlefield or futuristic dystopia. And right next to the mill, to the west and north, is the town of Braddock proper, a grid of single-family homes and empty plots, only a few miles away from downtown Pittsburgh.

headline: A New Look and Feel for Bits
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: We are bidding farewell to the Bits blog, though not to the journalism that has sustained it.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a decade, one way The New York Times has shared the story of the technology industry and its impact on our lives has been through a blog called Bits. Today we are bidding farewell to the blog, though not to the journalism that has sustained it.

headline: Is It Selfish for a Gay Couple to Have Kids via Surrogacy?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Surrogate Motherhood', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Education (K-12)', 'Volunteers and Community Service', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on deciding against adoption, and advocating for students in court.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I are gay and are exploring the possibility of having children using an egg donor and a surrogate mother. Sometimes when we mention this in conversation, people ask us, in a chiding tone, Why don’t you adopt? They often then argue that with so many children in need of good homes, it would be ethically superior for us to adopt, instead of spending a small fortune so we can have children to whom we are genetically tied. In addition, there are ethical issues related to paying women for their eggs or paying women to carry our children as surrogates. Are we acting unethically — or at the least selfishly or self-indulgently — in pursuing biological children instead of adopting orphans who could benefit from what (we like to think) would be a good home? David Lat, New York

headline: Pee-wee’s Big Comeback
abstract: After disappearing for nearly three decades, Paul Reubens’s subversive alter ego returns — and seems more radical than ever.
lead_paragraph: Paul Reubens wanted to show me his favorite Walgreens. I had asked to visit a place of personal significance, and although he has lived and worked in Los Angeles since the 1970s, he didn’t plot some dutiful trip down memory lane — a spin past the old headquarters of the Groundlings, the pioneering improv troupe where he created Pee-wee Herman, his indelible comic alter-ego; through the Burbank soundstages where he filmed much of ‘‘Pee-wee’s Big Adventure,’’ the hit 1985 film that made him a star; up to his Hollywood Hills home, where he keeps an elaborate cactus garden and a stockpile of curios and tchotchkes. Instead, he proposed a pilgrimage to the Walgreens West Coast flagship. I laughed, but he wasn’t kidding. A 23,500-square-foot behemoth at the corner of Sunset and Vine, the store is kitted out to the point of preposterousness with, among other things, a sushi bar, a supermarket, a florist, a warren of frozen-yogurt kiosks and a sidewalk cafe. As we entered, an employee handed out cups of sparkling wine. ‘‘I love it here,’’ Reubens said.

headline: Chasing Redfish Off the South Texas Gulf Coast
abstract: Among sport fish, redfish strike a near perfect balance between challenge and reward.
lead_paragraph: Rick Hartman had just navigated a pair of husband-and-wife anglers to a pretty little stretch of sapphire-colored water along the scruffy sand-grass shoreline of the Lower Laguna Madre, off the South Texas Gulf Coast. Normally when a redfish guide pulls a skiff into an area he wants to explore, fish bolt from it, at least until the guide cuts the motor and begins poling. But when Mr. Hartman steered his craft into this spot, he told me when I called him to ask about a trip to the little-known but beloved angling destination, reds were everywhere, “circling, tailing, in the middle of the water, just offshore.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on ‘The West Wing’ Super Fan
abstract: You can’t make us watch it.
lead_paragraph: Talee writes: I love ‘‘The West Wing.’’ The pace and erudition of the show, plus Aaron Sorkin’s dialogue, have me addicted. I try to persuade everyone I know to watch it, but three of my best friends won’t give in. What can I do?

headline: $1,300,000 Homes in Connecticut, Iowa and Pennsylvania
abstract: This week’s properties include a 1796 house in Connecticut and contemporaries in Iowa and Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: ROXBURY, CONN.

headline: After New Hampshire, Hillary Clinton Struggles to Find Her Footing
abstract: Many people close to Mrs. Clinton, including her husband, believed the state would serve as a lifeline, but instead, Senator Bernie Sanders won.
lead_paragraph: HOOKSETT, N.H. — After her unexpected victory in the New Hampshire primary in 2008, Hillary Clinton said she “found my own voice.” She left New Hampshire on Tuesday night, after a double-digit defeat, still searching for it.

headline: 1916: Preparing to Lay a Pacific Cable
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The United States prepares to lay an underwater cable to Hawaii in 1916.
lead_paragraph: As the Herald predicted a few days ago the Senate has to-day appropriated $25,000 in the Naval Bill for the taking of soundings between San Francisco, Canton and Honolulu, for the purpose of determining the practicability of laying a Pacific cable. The proposition was adopted with the understanding that it does not commit the Government in any way to lay a cable. The Hawaiian Government has granted the exclusive right for fifteen years to any company connecting the islands with America by cable. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 11, 1916

headline: As Syria Devolves Further, Allies Criticize American Policy
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said support for Kurdish militants fighting the Islamic State had helped turn the region into “a sea of blood.”
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Allies of the United States sharply criticized the Obama administration’s Syria policy on Wednesday, when the outgoing foreign minister of France called it “ambiguous” and the president of Turkey said American inaction had allowed the region to descend into a blood bath.

headline: Tempelhof Airport, Once a Lifeline for Berliners, Reprises Role for Refugees
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'Cold War Era', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Americans used the airport to run the airlift that saved West Berlin from a Soviet blockade. It is now becoming Germany’s largest refugee center.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Prussians once paraded on the grounds that are now Tempelhof. Then, in the 1930s, the architect Ernst Sagebiel took what was a modest airfield and conceived the site as a gigantic entrance to Hitler’s new Germany.

headline: Why ‘Diverse TV’ Matters: It’s Better TV. Discuss.
keywords: ['Television', 'Web-Original Programming', 'Minorities', 'Women and Girls', 'Movies', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: As TV embraces diversity, characters become more like us, and shows get better. The critics Wesley Morris and James Poniewozik of The Times discuss.
lead_paragraph: “Ladies and gentlemen, welcome to diverse TV.” So said Idris Elba at the Screen Actors Guild Awards last month. It was a reference, of course, to the furor over the Oscars’ all-white acting nominees. But Mr. Elba, who won awards that night for film and TV performances, was probably also aware that in the debate over whose stories get told on the screen, it’s the small one that seems to have the edge as the more inclusive medium.

headline: A House With Two Pools in Provence
abstract: Built in 2006 with the look of a traditional farmhouse, the six-bedroom home is on the market for $3.9 million.
lead_paragraph: Built in 2006 with the look of a traditional farmhouse, the six-bedroom home is on the market for $3.9 million.

headline: House Hunting in ... France
abstract: A favorable exchange rate, low interest rates and a drop in property prices are making real estate in France an attractive investment for foreigners.
lead_paragraph: A HOUSE WITH TWO POOLS IN PROVENCE

headline: Asahi Group Offers to Buy Peroni and Grolsch for $2.9 Billion
keywords: ['Beer', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The deal would be the latest effort by Anheuser-Busch InBev to sell parts of SABMiller as it hopes to convince regulators to approve their merger.
lead_paragraph: Asahi Group Holdings of Japan said on Wednesday that it had made a binding offer to buy the beer brands Peroni and Grolsch, as well as certain European operations of SABMiller, for 2.55 billion euros, or about $2.9 billion.

headline: The End of the Merkel Era
abstract: Germany’s recent period of centrism and moderation is over. Who knows what comes next?
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — THE next few weeks will most likely determine the future of Germany’s approach to the refugee crisis — and perhaps the future of the country itself.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Challenge: Peddling Pragmatism
abstract: Presidential candidates often run on a promise of change, which is appealing even when it’s not very realistic.
lead_paragraph: Political campaigns are supposed to promise hope and change, but Hillary Clinton is not offering enough of either — one of the most important reasons that she barely won Iowa and lost by a wide margin to Bernie Sanders in New Hampshire.

headline: How a Debate Misstep Sent Marco Rubio Tumbling in New Hampshire
abstract: Mr. Rubio’s campaign, once surging, is now grappling with the weaknesses of a strategy constructed around the political talents of the candidate.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Everything, it seemed, was breaking Marco Rubio’s way.

headline: Paris Opera Ballet Opts for Silence Over Benjamin Millepied’s Resignation
abstract: At the announcement of the 335-year-old company’s 2016-17 program, officials refused to discuss Mr. Millepied’s brief tenure as director of dance.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — About 200 journalists packed into the gilded Rotonde du Glacier in the Palais Garnier here on Wednesday for the Paris Opera’s announcement of its 2016-17 season. But those who attended in hopes of learning more about the unexpected news that the director of dance, Benjamin Millepied, had decided to step down after barely 15 months in the post were left disappointed.

headline: Behind the Makeup and Costumes of ‘Mad Max: Fury Road’
abstract: The film’s Oscar-nominated designers explain how they created Furiosa’s look. Step 1: Eliminate the feminine.
lead_paragraph: Working on “Mad Max: Fury Road” was a lot like working on a carnival; a traditional script was nowhere to be found. Or so it seemed to Lesley Vanderwalt, who oversaw the movie’s Oscar-nominated hair and makeup.

headline: 1941: Britain Breaks With Rumania
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain breaks off ties with Romania in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Great Britain today [Feb. 11] broke off diplomatic relations with Rumania, charging that her territory was being used by Germany as a military base. The action followed close on the heels of Prime Minister Winston Churchill’s radio speech last night, in which he asserted that forward units of the German air force had penetrated Bulgaria from Rumania. Official circles here emphasized that the government’s action must not be assumed to mean that the Royal Air Force immediately would bomb Rumanian oil fields, now reported completely in German hands, but they admitted that it put the government in a position to do so ‘‘if we feel like it.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 11, 1941

headline: Who’s Favored to Win the Super Bowl Next Year? Them Again
abstract: The team widely favored to win Super Bowl LI is not the reigning champion, Denver, or even the Carolina Panthers but — once again — the New England Patriots.
lead_paragraph: Super Bowl 50 is barely in the books, but it is certainly not too soon to start thinking about Super Bowl LI.

headline: Taylor Stanley, the Calmest Dancer at Lincoln Center
abstract: At 24, Mr. Stanley is appearing in Justin Peck’s “The Most Incredible Thing” and talking about dance, humility and his dog.
lead_paragraph: As the Creator in Justin Peck’s latest work, “The Most Incredible Thing,” the New York City Ballet soloist Taylor Stanley invents a clock, which is smashed by a Destroyer but magically comes back to life. Eventually, the Creator brings peace to the kingdom and wins the hand of the Princess.

headline: During Primary Season, Gratitude to President Obama
abstract: Readers discuss the man and his presidency.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Mitsuko Uchida and the Cleveland Orchestra Play Mozart
abstract: Ms. Uchida will conduct from the keyboard on Valentine’s Day at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The pianist Mitsuko Uchida has long been associated with Mozart, a composer she performs with elegance, clarity and a crystalline touch, the melodic lines unfolding with operatic warmth. At 7 p.m. on Sunday, she offers a Valentine’s Day treat, conducting the Cleveland Orchestra from the keyboard. Ms. Uchida performed the Mozart concertos with this superb ensemble while artist in residence there from 2002 to 2007, and their continuing recording collaboration has produced several excellent Mozart discs on the Decca Classics label.

headline: Maxwell, an Elusive Soul Man, Steps Out
abstract: The R&B singer headlines two area shows this week, at Barclays Center in Brooklyn and Prudential Center in Newark.
lead_paragraph: The R&B songwriter Maxwell, one of the neo-soul pioneers of the 1990s, moves at a pace all his own. Back in 2009, he released his fourth album, “BLACKsummers’night,” a 37-minute set of slowly undulating, structurally adventurous, jazz-infused songs that zoomed into the Top 10 and won Grammy Awards. He said at the time that it was the beginning of a trilogy. The next two segments still haven’t appeared, though last year Maxwell hinted that a new album would be released this winter.

headline: ‘Major Crimes,’ With Ambition
abstract: This TNT police drama returns on Monday with a five-episode arc.
lead_paragraph: Since it was spun off from “The Closer” in 2012, TNT’s “Major Crimes” has become a solid if somewhat unadventurous procedural. When it returns from its winter break on Monday, Feb. 15, however, it gets considerably more ambitious: Instead of serving up a crime of the week, it begins a five-episode arc rooted in a single crime that touches both hot-button real-life issues and a long-dormant murder investigation.

headline: John Kasich, No. 2 in New Hampshire, Turns to an Uncertain South Carolina
abstract: The Ohio governor savored his come-from-behind finish on Tuesday, but the road ahead for his presidential campaign remains arduous and uphill.
lead_paragraph: MANCHESTER, N.H. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio savored his come-from-behind, second-place finish in the New Hampshire Republican primary on Tuesday night as if it were an outright victory.

headline: Florist-Friendly Marketplaces Help Local Flower Shops Hang On
abstract: National merchants like 1-800-Flowers and FTD.com take more than 25 percent of a sale, squeezing local florists. But start-ups are challenging that model.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, florists across the country will send out millions of Valentine’s Day bouquets filled with roses, carnations, tulips and other blooming symbols of love. And some will lose money on almost every single sale.

headline: Easy Midweek Recipes
abstract: Recipes for winter tomatoes, a no-recipe taco dinner and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: North Korea’s Rocket Launch Frays Ties Between South Korea and China
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The prospect of a new era in relations fell apart this week when South Korea said it was seeking to deploy an American missile defense system on its territory.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — When China’s leader, Xi Jinping, visited America’s firm ally South Korea in 2014, it seemed to be the beginning of a promising courtship.

headline: The Year of the Angry Voter
abstract: We seem to be mistaking politicians’ hissy fits for righteous wrath.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been having a hard time understanding the mood of the country. I turn on the television, and I see a land where to be a citizen means to specialize in the venting of spleen.

headline: Knoedler Gallery and Collectors Settle Case Over Fake Rothko
abstract: The collectors had sought $25 million in damages, accusing the defunct gallery and its former president of participating in a “racketeering scheme.”
lead_paragraph: A lawsuit against Knoedler & Co., a once celebrated New York art gallery accused of selling a fake Rothko painting to a pair of collectors for $8.3 million, ended in a settlement on Wednesday, just as the gallery’s former owner and its president were preparing to testify in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

headline: Ayatollah Khomeini’s Grandson Is Disqualified From Elections
abstract: Hassan Khomeini, 43, is among thousands barred from running for Parliament and for the Assembly of Experts, which selects the supreme leader.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — After months of political maneuvering, the scion of the powerful Khomeini family and the projected figurehead of Iran’s ailing reform movement was definitively barred Wednesday from participating in parliamentary elections this month, the semiofficial news agency ILNA reported.

headline: Woman and 2 Daughters Fatally Stabbed at Staten Island Motel
abstract: The police said they were searching for a man who knew the woman and her three daughters, who were stabbed at a motel used to house homeless families.
lead_paragraph: The man lingered in the hall of a Staten Island motel that has become a bleak way station for people plunged into homelessness. Finally, he entered one of the rooms. Four minutes later, he was gone, a gruesome, wrenching scene left behind.

headline: Cooper Hewitt’s Triennial Asks: What Makes Something Beautiful?
abstract: At the design museum, designers from around the globe will explore ideas of beauty.
lead_paragraph: Beauty can be a bad word in design, connoting ornament, surface and, that most suspect attribute, pleasure. These are three of the reasons that Ellen Lupton, the senior curator of contemporary design at the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum, and Andrea Lipps, an assistant curator there, embraced beauty as the title of the museum’s Triennial, opening Friday.

headline: New Writer, Same Goal: Exploring the World on a Budget
abstract: Seth Kugel hands the cheap-travel reins to Lucas Peterson, but not before the two trade some touring tips and tricks.
lead_paragraph: Last week marked the final Frugal Traveler column for Seth Kugel, who has been bargain hunting and globe jumping for us for almost six years. Next week, he passes the baton to Lucas Peterson. In preparation for the handoff, the new columnist interviewed the outgoing one to find out how cheap travel opens up a new world and about the time he got jumped.

headline: As Bernie Sanders Makes History, Jews Wonder What It Means
abstract: Mr. Sanders is the first Jewish candidate in U.S. history to win a presidential primary. Some Jews celebrated. Others had mixed feelings.
lead_paragraph: But is it good for the Jews?

headline: Afghan Policeman, Shot After Firing on NATO Soldiers, Dies of Wounds
keywords: ['Attacks on Police', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The policeman, who had been guarding a ministry, opened fire on coalition troops, who fired back and fatally wounded him, the Afghan government said.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — An Afghan policeman shot by a NATO coalition soldier has died of his wounds after apparently conducting an insider attack, the government said on Wednesday.

headline: Burger King to Add Hot Dogs to the Grill
abstract: The hamburger chain is looking to use the kitchen equipment and condiments it already has and offer more variety on its menu.
lead_paragraph: Burger King is going to the dogs — hot dogs, that is.

headline: 12 Nigella Lawson Recipes for Valentine’s Day
abstract: Romantic main courses and chocolate recipes for Feb. 14.
lead_paragraph: Romantic main courses and chocolate recipes for Feb. 14.

headline: Brazilians Shrug Off Zika Fears to Revel in Carnival Fun
abstract: Many Brazilians feel they have more important things to worry about, including soaring unemployment, a plummeting currency and a corruption scandal.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — From a mosquito’s point of view, the sweaty, minimally clothed multitudes thronging the streets of this northeastern city on Monday night must have looked especially delectable.

headline: Before Donald Trump, There Was Jan Brewer
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Arizona Immigration Law (SB 1070)']
abstract: The former Arizona governor showed that G.O.P. voters could be drawn to a tough immigration stance and moderation on taxes and spending.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s rise from joke candidate to likely Republican nominee surprised all the supposed experts, including me. But 2,000 miles from Washington, in the southwestern American desert, we should have seen an early warning.

headline: Future and Young Thug, Atlanta’s Hip-Hop Workaholics, Go Their Own Ways
abstract: Two new albums show that if Young Thug is the city’s most influential eccentric, Future is now the voice of the establishment.
lead_paragraph: A few days ago, the Atlanta rapper Young Thug released the video for “F Cancer (Boosie),” a song from his new EP, “I’m Up” (300/Atlantic). It is, like many of the videos he has a hand in conceptualizing, a fascinating dash of medium-fi, madhouse cinema.

headline: A Rough Ride for Tech Stocks, and It’s Not Over
abstract: As Twitter reports quarterly earnings, the tech sector braces for more fallout.
lead_paragraph: It has been a rough year for tech stocks. Yes, even rougher than it has been for most everyone else on Wall Street (though a few energy companies might dispute that claim).

headline: Making Corrections in the Gmail Address Book
abstract: When your Google Contacts list becomes outdated or in need of correction, you can update the entries as needed.
lead_paragraph: Q. When I’m sending a Gmail message in my web browser, I’ve noticed that the email addresses for certain people have completely wrong, outdated or unrelated names connected to them. How can I correct this?

headline: Sikh American Actor Flies Home to New York Wearing His Turban
abstract: The actor, Waris Ahluwalia, was not allowed to board a plane in Mexico City on Monday because he refused to remove his religious head covering.
lead_paragraph: A well-known Sikh American actor, Waris Ahluwalia, who was not allowed to board an airplane in Mexico City because he refused to remove his turban during a security check, flew home to the United States on Wednesday, ending a two-day standoff with Aeroméxico.

headline: By Hiring Lisa M. Borders, W.N.B.A. Gets a Leader Who Follows the Game
abstract: Borders, a former Atlanta City Council president who calls herself a “raving fan” of the Atlanta Dream, takes over a league that is struggling with attendance.
lead_paragraph: Lisa M. Borders, who was named the W.N.B.A. president Wednesday, describes herself as a “raving fan” of the Atlanta Dream, the franchise she helped attract when she was president of the local City Council.

headline: Bookshelf: Black History
abstract: New picture books tell both well-known and neglected stories from centuries of African-American life.
lead_paragraph: New picture books tell both well-known and neglected stories from centuries of African-American life.

headline: Supreme Court’s Blow to Emissions Efforts May Imperil Paris Climate Accord
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Coal', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Polluters like China and India may balk at following through on the Paris Agreement on cutting emissions if the United States fails to carry out strong policies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s surprise decision Tuesday to halt the carrying out of President Obama’s climate change regulation could weaken or even imperil the international global warming accord reached with great ceremony in Paris less than two months ago, climate diplomats say.

headline: Deficit Threatens Stability of University of California, Berkeley, Official Says
abstract: The chancellor said cuts and new revenue were needed to address the $150 million deficit, or 6 percent of Berkeley’s $2.4 billion budget.
lead_paragraph: The chancellor of the University of California, Berkeley, said Wednesday that the university had a “substantial and growing” deficit that could threaten its long-term stability and that it needed to reduce expenses and raise revenues to maintain its position as a premier public institution.

headline: Gov. Christie, Headed Home to New Jersey, Stalls Commute
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: “Governor Christie is booked on this flight but he hasn’t shown up yet.”
lead_paragraph: The television at Gate B25 in Boston’s Logan Airport blared a CNN story on Wednesday: “Sources: Christie to meet with aides on future.” Then, “Sources expect Christie to formally suspend bid.”

headline: Newspaper Adviser Is Fired After Students’ Scoop Roils Maryland Campus
abstract: The faculty adviser to the student paper at Mount St. Mary’s was dismissed after the university president was quoted likening struggling students to bunnies who should be drowned.
lead_paragraph: When student reporters at Mount St. Mary’s University, a small Catholic institution in Maryland, published an article in January that quoted the university’s president likening struggling freshmen to bunnies that should be drowned, they knew it might get a big reaction.

headline: Sofia Coppola to Make Opera Debut in Rome
abstract: Her staging of Verdi’s “La Traviata,” a collaboration with the fashion designer Valentino, will open on May 24.
lead_paragraph: In a coup for the struggling Rome Opera, the film director Sofia Coppola will make her operatic debut there, the company announced this week. Her staging of Verdi’s “La Traviata,” a collaboration with the fashion designer Valentino Garavani and his workshop, will open on May 24 and run through June 30.

headline: The Real Jobless Rate Is 42 Percent? Donald Trump Has a Point, Sort Of
keywords: ['Unemployment', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: That number works, but only if you count retirees, college students and stay-at-home parents.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump seems quite certain that the real unemployment rate is higher than the 4.9 percent that the Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported it to be. A lot higher.

headline: In Italy, a Top Club Stands Alone in Supporting Women’s Soccer
abstract: Unlike other countries like England, Spain, France and Germany, Italy has only one top-division men’s club, Fiorentina, that operates a women’s team.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, Italy — In England, many top soccer clubs, including Arsenal, Chelsea, Manchester City and Liverpool, operate a women’s team alongside their more famous men’s team. In Spain, teams like Barcelona, Athletic Bilbao, Atlético Madrid and Espanyol do the same. In France, the top-division clubs Paris St.-Germain, Lyon, Montpelier and St.-Étienne also field professional women’s teams while in Germany the group includes Bayern Munich, Wolfsburg, Bayer Leverkusen and Hoffenheim.

headline: With Storm Over, Some Humor on Anthem of the Seas
abstract: A comedy show on the Anthem of the Seas cruise ship lets passengers laugh at the turbulent weather that had been so frightening two nights before.
lead_paragraph: The voyage of Anthem of the Seas was cut short after sailing through a strong winter storm that produced hurricane-force winds. Here is Brett Michael Dykes’s original firsthand account.

headline: Take Two: Scarlett Johansson and Michèle Lamy
abstract: Scarlett Johansson and Michèle Lamy try some new products.
lead_paragraph: Scarlett Johansson and Michèle Lamy try some new products.

headline: Assisted Suicide Study Questions Its Use for Mentally Ill
keywords: ['Euthanasia and Assisted Suicide', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Law and Legislation', 'Research']
abstract: Researchers who looked at doctor-assisted deaths in the Netherlands found that some patients had declined treatment that might have helped.
lead_paragraph: A new study of doctor-assisted death for people with mental disorders raises questions about the practice, finding that in more than half of approved cases, people declined treatment that could have helped, and that many cited loneliness as an important reason for wanting to die. The study, of cases in the Netherlands, should raise concerns for other countries debating where to draw the line when it comes to people’s right to die, experts said.

headline: The Coolest Pins to Customize Your Denim
keywords: ['Jewels and Jewelry', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shopping and Retail']
abstract: Fifty-one pins you should put on your jacket now.
lead_paragraph: “We lack intimacy.”

headline: 1-Year-Old Girl Fatally Shot in Her Crib in Compton
abstract: The police said the fatal shot traveled through the door of a garage where her family lived. The authorities say the shooting may be gang-related.
lead_paragraph: A 1-year-old girl was resting in her crib, surrounded by family members inside a converted garage in Compton, Calif., when a bullet came through the garage door and struck her in the head, leaving her mortally wounded.

headline: Eiko Steps Away From One Dance Partner, to Take on Many More
abstract: Half of the duo Eiko and Koma is performing in public spaces around the world as part of new project.
lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, it was Eiko and Koma. But two years ago, after Koma injured his ankle, Eiko, the other half of the husband-and-wife dance duo — treasured for their stark, startlingly slow excavations of stillness and shape while time gradually passes — struck out on her own. The pair are likely to perform together in the future, but for now, Eiko is consumed with a solo project that has transformed her career.

headline: Brutal Romanian Prison Warden, 90, Loses Appeal of 20-Year Sentence
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Political Prisoners']
abstract: The Communist-era commander of a notorious prison, convicted of murder and crimes against humanity, must start serving his term immediately.
lead_paragraph: BUCHAREST, Romania — The highest court in Romania upheld a 20-year prison term on Wednesday for a 90-year-old former warden from the country’s repressive Communist past who had overseen brutal treatment of prisoners, including routine beatings and starvation.

headline: Traditionalists Rebuffed as Parliament Turns the Page on Parchment
keywords: ['Archives and Records', 'Paper and Pulp', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Legislatures and Parliaments']
abstract: For nearly 1,000 years, acts of British Parliament have been recorded on calfskin parchment. Now, the House of Lords is switching to paper.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — For centuries, acts of Parliament and other important documents have been inscribed on vellum, a parchment made from calfskin. Magna Carta, which King John signed 800 years ago last year, was written on vellum. So was the Domesday Book compiled in 1086, 20 years after William the Conqueror sailed across the English Channel.

headline: Deutsche Bank’s Opaque Balance Sheet Clouds Its Position
abstract: A close look at the German lender’s capital position implies that a nervousness among investors is overdone.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank’s vast and opaque balance sheet is holding it back. Media reports that the German lender was considering buying back senior debt to strengthen its balance sheet sent its shares – and those of European peers – soaring on Wednesday. But Deutsche’s shares are still down 35 percent since early January.

headline: A Multifront Republican Battle in South Carolina
abstract: Heading to the state’s primaries, the G.O.P. candidates chasing Donald J. Trump are trying to show strength.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — Donald J. Trump’s rivals for the Republican presidential nomination dug in Wednesday for a hard fight in the South Carolina primary, where Mr. Trump will seek to gain a clear upper hand in the 2016 race after his smashing victory in New Hampshire.

headline: Big City Book Club
abstract: Matthew Thomas’s “We Are Not Ourselves,” a multi-generational saga of Irish immigrant life in New York, was the subject of an online discussion on Feb. 11, 2016.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Thomas’s “We Are Not Ourselves,” a multi-generational saga of Irish immigrant life in New York, was the subject of an online discussion on Feb. 11, 2016.

headline: When Women Fire Back, Are They ‘Ferocious’? When Is a Critic a Scold?
abstract: Some readers see gender bias in language choice in The Times.
lead_paragraph: Last week, The Times prominently displayed an analysis piece which explored the matter of sexist language and speech in the presidential campaign. Through interviews and other research, it showed how negative words such as “shrill” or “shouting” have been applied to Hillary Clinton, but not to her male rivals.

headline: Chris Christie Drops Out of Presidential Race After New Hampshire Flop
abstract: The governor of New Jersey said on Facebook that he was ending his presidential campaign, a day after he came in a disappointing sixth in the primary.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, a once-commanding figure in the Republican Party who struggled to attract support for his presidential campaign but unsettled the race with his strident attacks on Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, ended his run for the White House on Wednesday.

headline: Coaching Stars to Avoid a ‘Racist Against Whites’ Moment
keywords: ['Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Public Relations and Publicity', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Movies', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Discrimination', 'Celebrities', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Last year, the biggest things Oscar nominees had to worry about were questions about fashion; this year, diversity is the hot topic.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this awards season, at a ceremony for one of Hollywood’s guild prizes, a prominent filmmaker who does not have a dog in the fight mulled over whether to chat with the media. After seeking the advice of a friend, who replied, “Not unless you want to talk about diversity,” the filmmaker stood down.

headline: Department of Justice Sues Ferguson, Which Reversed Course on Agreement
keywords: ['Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: City leaders rejected a deal to overhaul the police force, setting up a court fight over excessive policing in a city that came to symbolize it.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Department of Justice filed a civil rights lawsuit against Ferguson, Mo., on Wednesday, less than a day after the city rejected an agreement to overhaul its beleaguered criminal justice system and address allegations of widespread abuses by its police department.

headline: Ex-Los Angeles Sheriff, Lee Baca, Pleads Guilty to Lying in Corruption Inquiry
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Lee Baca, who oversaw over a jail system where inmates were found to have been routinely tortured, had denied that such problems were rampant.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Lee Baca, the former Los Angeles County sheriff who resigned in 2014 amid a growing corruption scandal in his department, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to making false statements to the federal authorities who were investigating the jail system he oversaw.

headline: Candy, Fit for a Valentine’s Day Sleepover
abstract: The former lingerie designer Maayan Zilberman’s new confectionery project, Sweet Saba, will pop up at the Standard — just in time for the holiday.
lead_paragraph: If anyone knows about gifting for Valentine’s Day, it’s the lingerie-designer-turned-candy-maker Maayan Zilberman. Her former fashion line, the Lake and Stars, blurred underwear with outerwear; her new project, Sweet Saba, delights in the mix-up between sculpture and candy. “It was a very seamless shift,” the sharply manicured Zilberman says of her new endeavor. “Candy, like lingerie, has its biggest market around Christmas and Valentine’s. I think if you have the same sensibility and the same customer, it’s just like saying you have a new dish on the menu.”

headline: What’s the Deal With Cruz and Kids?
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Cruz’s latest ad features a Donald Trump action figure destroying a doll house as children chant “eminent domain.” For real.
lead_paragraph: Is there any limit to Senator Ted Cruz’s willingness to exploit small children – his own and now others – in embarrassing and peculiar ways to further his bid for the Republican presidential nomination? Based on his latest TV ad, “Playing Trump,” which features three kids playing with a Donald Trump doll and robotically mouthing Cruz campaign talking points, the answer is clearly “No.”

headline: Drug Traffickers Turn to New Type of Courier: Seniors
abstract: Seniors who have been deceived have unknowingly tried to carry drugs into nearly a dozen foreign countries, the Department of Homeland Security said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In what law enforcement officials describe as a new front in international smuggling, global traffickers and cartels are increasingly turning to a new source for couriers to smuggle drugs across international borders: vulnerable American older adults.

headline: Autopsy Shows the N.H.L.’s Todd Ewen Did Not Have C.T.E.
keywords: ['Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy', 'Hockey, Ice', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts', 'Concussions']
abstract: The results surprised researchers and Ewen’s widow because he was a hockey enforcer who displayed symptoms of the brain disease before he killed himself.
lead_paragraph: When the former N.H.L. enforcer Todd Ewen died in September, reportedly of a self-inflicted gunshot, his brain was sent to researchers. Years of memory loss and undiagnosed depression led to speculation that Ewen, 49, had chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a degenerative brain disease caused by repeated blows to the head.

headline: Marco Rubio Is Robotic, but Not Out of It
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Donald Trump has been rewarded for his aversion to even a nanosecond of scripted political contrivance. His fellow candidates should take notes.
lead_paragraph: Don’t blame message discipline for Marco Rubio’s lightning-fast collapse from triumphant in Iowa to disappointed in New Hampshire. Even his opponents chalked up the I, Robot routine in Saturday’s debate to message discipline. But that’s a smear against one of the most effective tools any candidate has in his campaign arsenal. Mr. Rubio stumbled because he took the practice to an absurd extreme.

headline: Sales and Deals for Fashion Week and Valentine’s Day
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', "Valentine's Day", 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Lyst and Uber are teaming up, Diesel presents Nicola Formichetti’s new retail concept, and more.
lead_paragraph: Didn’t manage to score tickets to Yeezy Season 3? Cheer up: There are many more ways to take part in the fashion week festivities. On Thursday from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m., the e-commerce aggregator Lyst will team up with Uber on a giveaway celebrating the diversity of New York style. Enter the code FINDNYFW in the app for the chance to request a goody bag filled with items shoppable on Lyst (like, say, an oh-so-downtown Maiyet geometric block scarf) tailored to the neighborhood you’re in.

headline: The Landscape After New Hampshire
abstract: A sampling of the reaction to the results of the New Hampshire primary.

headline: The Republican Mess
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With no establishment candidate emerging at the moment, Trump and Cruz have the only clear paths to the nomination.
lead_paragraph: In 1996, Pat Buchanan — running as a populist, a protectionist, an outsider — won three of the first four Republican primary season contests, taking caucuses in Louisiana and Alaska, finishing a close second in Iowa, and then winning New Hampshire outright.

headline: An Exhibition That Proves Video Games Can Be Art
abstract: “The Game Worlds of Jason Rohrer,” in Boston, is the first major museum retrospective dedicated to a game designer’s work.
lead_paragraph: In April 2010, a brouhaha erupted in the gaming community that still reverberates today: The film critic Roger Ebert had opined that video games could never truly be counted as art. “Let me just say that no video gamer now living will survive long enough to experience the medium as an art form,” he wrote on his blog. But three months later, in an erudite follow-up titled “Okay, Kids, Play on My Lawn,” he recanted. Great works of art, he speculated, “could instruct me about life, love, disease and death, principles and morality, humor and tragedy.” Ebert admitted that he hadn’t spent enough time with video games to know if they could, indeed, evoke these feelings. “I don’t know if they can be inspired to transcend themselves,” he wrote. “Perhaps they can. How can I say?”

headline: Carly Fiorina Drops Out of Republican Presidential Race
abstract: Ms. Fiorina had poor showings in both New Hampshire and Iowa, as her message of corporate experience failed to win over voters.
lead_paragraph: Carly Fiorina, 61, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, suspended her presidential campaign Wednesday, announcing her decisions on social media after poor showings in the New Hampshire and Iowa nominating contests.

headline: A Rap Video With a Side of 3D-Printed Jewelry
abstract: The jewelry line Holy Faya and KillASon partnered on “The Black Crook,” an edit of which appears here.
lead_paragraph: In June 2014, the industrial designer Célia Elmasu and the multidisciplinary artist Nelly Zagury — longtime friends and intermittent collaborators — made a pact over Skype. “I said, ‘If I quit my day job, you quit yours. I quit; you quit,’” Elmasu, now 29, remembers. “Nelly said, ‘O.K., I’ll quit,’ and I asked, ‘You sure?’ And that started it all.” Zagury, 28, chimes in, “Our initial idea was two parts: a hip-hop musical and doing crazy props.” A year and a half later, the French-born, Brooklyn-based duo has created “the first 3D-printed music video.” Elmasu and Zagury’s jewelry brand, Holy Faya, regularly worn onstage by FKA twigs, is a fortuitous byproduct.

headline: G.M. Recalls Trucks Because of Brake Pedal Issue
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Automobiles']
abstract: About 478,000 Chevrolet Silverados, GMC Sierras and Chevy Tahoes are recalled to fix a nut that can loosen and allow the brake pedal to fall off.
lead_paragraph: General Motors is recalling about 478,000 trucks, including almost 427,000 in the United States, because the brake pedal could fall off, the automaker said on Wednesday.

headline: Experts Study Zika’s Path From First Outbreak in Pacific
abstract: The virus, which has been around in Asia for decades, first hit hard on Yap Island, and spread across the Pacific, with a huge outbreak now in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Yap Island, a speck of land in the Western Pacific best known for using huge stone discs as currency, was facing a medical mystery.

headline: Times Reporter: ‘I Would Never Cut a Deal Like That’
abstract: Mark Landler responds to a reader query about a troubling practice, calling it ‘a serious breach of journalistic ethics.’
lead_paragraph: Here’s an ugly term: Transactional journalism — also known as a quid pro quo.

lead_paragraph: A work crew pulled up to the northwest corner of West End Avenue and 101st Street on Wednesday morning and approached an oblong glass box that looked so anachronistic that a passer-by might have wondered if it simply had dropped out of the sky.

lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The defense ministers from all 28 NATO countries approved a plan on Wednesday to enhance the alliance’s military presence in Central and Eastern Europe, part of its expanding efforts to deter Russian aggression, according to NATO’s secretary general, Jens Stoltenberg.

lead_paragraph: Marc Andreessen, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist and board member of the social network Facebook, has long been one of its vocal supporters. On Wednesday, Facebook did not welcome that support.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It appears that Google has persuaded federal regulators that — in some situations at least — the Tin Man has a heart.

lead_paragraph: Days after the Giants’ season ended, the owner John K. Mara declared the roster undertalented and soberly put the onus for rebuilding the team on General Manager Jerry Reese.

keywords: ['Parties (Social)', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Lunar New Year', 'Fashion and Apparel']

headline: Mine Kills Civilians as Fighting Heats Up in Eastern Ukraine
abstract: A minivan trying to bypass traffic at a checkpoint near Donetsk tripped a land mine, killing four occupants. It was unclear which side had planted the mine.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Fighting that had been quiet for several months between Russia-backed insurgents and government forces has picked up in eastern Ukraine, punctuated by regular artillery shelling, the use of land mines and other tactics that have put civilians at risk.

headline: Twitter User Growth Stalls, and the Chief Pledges to Make Fixes
abstract: The problem, Twitter said, is that the service is still not always intuitive to use, and it comes with quirks that newcomers find difficult to grasp.
lead_paragraph: When Jack Dorsey returned last year as chief executive of Twitter, the social media company he co-founded, he had a mandate: Right a sinking ship.

headline: How a Junk-Food-Obsessed Instagram Chef Does Valentine’s Day
abstract: Christine Flynn, recently outed as the creator of the fictional Chef Jacques La Merde account, shares her very refined plating tips — using unconventionally commercial ingredients.
lead_paragraph: Everything about the Instagram celebrity chef Jacques La Merde is a little bit off. First, the faceless Instagrammer attracted thousands of followers (currently, 122,000), many of whom assumed La Merde was a man. But a recent episode of “Top Chef” revealed the account is run by the Toronto-based chef Christine Flynn. Many also assumed that La Merde was poking fun at the food world with an integration of Bugles and Drumsticks into daintily composed plates, mimicking complex dishes that might come out of Noma or Eleven Madison Park’s kitchens. In actuality, Flynn’s elaborate experiments in plating culture were exactly that — experiments. “I wasn’t allowed to eat junk food growing up,” she says.

headline: Streamlining the Universal Remote Device
keywords: ['Television Sets and Media Devices', 'Mobile Applications', 'Smartphones', 'Remote Control Systems']
abstract: Many so-called universal remotes are hard to set up, and bury important commands in a remote screen’s submenus.
lead_paragraph: IF you’re of a certain age, you may recall what you had to do to watch television: You turned the set on.

headline: The Portland of Portugal
abstract: Porto was once one of the country’s richest towns, known for its artisanry. These days, it’s reemerging as a food and design hub, proving that austerity isn’t the death of creativity.
lead_paragraph: In Portugal’s second most populous city, medieval townhouses stack up beside the Douro River like Legos, and churches wear their blue-and-white azulejo tiles outside as well as in. Settled by the Romans, and famous for its port wines, which became a favored export to England via the 1703 Methuen Treaty, Porto was a lucky beneficiary of its country’s vast, centuries-spanning empire — look to the Baroque, blinding-gilt interior of the Church of São Francisco for evidence. Its riverside location made it an important industrial center in the 1700s and 1800s.

headline: MetLife Makes Its Case Against ‘Too Big to Fail’ Label
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Insurance', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: A federal judge questions whether an oversight council has systems in place to both gather evidence and fairly judge financial firms.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The “too big to fail” label is finally having its day in court.

headline: Review: On ‘Those Who Can’t,’ Stalking the Halls of Lower Education
abstract: The new comedy on TruTV is set in a high school and features the three-man Denver troupe Grawlix. The show goes for the gross and raunchy.
lead_paragraph: At this rate, by the end of the decade every comedy troupe in North America will have its own television series about misbehaving educators.

headline: At the Grammy Awards, a History of Old-Guard Resistance to Change
abstract: Reflecting on a strain of bias against the young and against mainstream hits.
lead_paragraph: The slate of best new artist nominees at the 2011 Grammy Awards was the most stacked in recent memory: Justin Bieber, a teen heartthrob who would go on to become the only relevant solo male pop star of the 2010s so far; Drake, at the beginning of his quest to fully meld hip-hop and R&B; Mumford & Sons, a band that delivered roots rock with arena muscle; and Florence & the Machine, glam art-rock innovators.

headline: Review: A Cabinet of Curiosities at the Joyce
abstract: The Ririe-Woodbury Dance Company performs four quirky pieces by the choreographer Alwin Nikolais.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer Alwin Nikolais came to modern dance late after studying piano and working in scenic design, puppetry and acting. Looking back now, it makes sense. Nikolais, who died in 1993, was ahead of his time in his vision of theater as a place where sound, light and movement work in concert to give birth to jewel-like spectacles. He was long accused of dehumanizing dance; yes, there can be shapes instead of bodies and masks instead of faces, but there’s no denying the heart in his choreography, however peculiar, playful or grisly it is.

headline: Some Auto Insurance Premiums Penalize Home Renters, Study Finds
keywords: ['Automobile Insurance and Liability', 'Personal Finances', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: Consumers pay about 7 percent more for annual premiums if they rent their home rather than own it, even if they have stellar driving records.
lead_paragraph: What does owning a home have to do with car insurance? Quite a bit, when it comes to the rates consumers pay for auto coverage, a new analysis finds.

headline: Versace Through the Years
abstract: Donatella Versace is the one designer who has consistently challenged the paradox of power and sex — and she’s done it with a laugh, a cigarette and a billion dollar business.
lead_paragraph: Donatella Versace is the one designer who has consistently challenged the paradox of power and sex — and she’s done it with a laugh, a cigarette and a billion dollar business.

headline: Stakes in Nevada Rise for Hillary Clinton as Caucuses Near
abstract: After his defeat of Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday, Bernie Sanders will have a chance to prove himself in a state as racially diverse as Iowa and New Hampshire are not.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The Democratic presidential caucuses in Nevada were supposed to be an afterthought: lost in the shadows of high-profile battles in Iowa and New Hampshire, and fought in a state far off in the West where voters have a long, warm history with Bill and Hillary Clinton.

headline: Mylan in $7.2 Billion Deal for Meda, a Swedish Drug Maker
abstract: Mylan is buying greater exposure to over-the-counter products, which represent 40 percent of Meda’s product sales, and an entry into emerging markets.
lead_paragraph: After several attempts a few years ago to acquire Meda, a Swedish drug maker, Mylan finally found the price to solidify a deal: $7.2 billion.

headline: In the Pop-Up Kitchen With Albert Adrià
abstract: The Catalan chef brought T into the Domino kitchen, at the Café Royal hotel, to test recipes for his forthcoming 50 Days event.
lead_paragraph: The Catalan chef brought T into the Domino kitchen, at the Café Royal hotel, to test recipes for his forthcoming 50 Days event.

headline: A Preview of Chef Albert Adrià’s Much-Anticipated London Pop-Up
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Pop-Up Stores and Restaurants', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: Beginning Friday, he will serve a prix fixe Catalan-inspired dinner at the Café Royal Hotel — for 50 days.
lead_paragraph: This Friday, the beloved Catalan chef Albert Adrià (who is, of course, Ferran Adrià’s little brother) will cook in London for the first time with a pop-up at the Café Royal hotel. Unlike the five diverse restaurants he runs in Barcelona — which range from a perpetually sold-out avant-garde tapas bar called Tickets, to Hoja Santa, a modern Mexican table that was just awarded a star in the 2016 Michelin guide to Spain — the two-month-long pop-up will serve a prix fixe menu devised entirely by him.

headline: Fox News Draws 4.2 Million Viewers for New Hampshire Primary Coverage
abstract: It was the second-biggest audience for primary or caucus coverage, after the contest in Iowa last week, which sent 4.5 million viewers to Fox News.
lead_paragraph: Fox News drew 4.2 million viewers for Tuesday night’s coverage of the New Hampshire primary, the second-highest viewership for primary or caucus night coverage for any cable network dating to 2000. It was the highest rating for coverage of the New Hampshire primary for any cable network going back those 16 years.

headline: Better Call Roberto: Alagna Steps In to ‘Manon Lescaut’
abstract: The tenor replaces Jonas Kaufmann in the Metropolitan Opera’s new production to star with the soprano Kristine Opolais.
lead_paragraph: The tenor Roberto Alagna was sleeping the morning after singing “Pagliacci” at the Metropolitan Opera last month when the company’s general manager, Peter Gelb, telephoned with a potential crisis on his hands. Jonas Kaufmann, one of the biggest stars in opera, had just withdrawn from a coming new production of Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut.” Would Mr. Alagna step in?

headline: Asahi’s Beer Buy: Trying to Escape Demographic Destiny
abstract: Asahi of Japan may be paying high for three so-so beer brands with the aim of increasing sales outside its aging and stagnant home market.
lead_paragraph: Anheuser-Busch InBev is getting the better of Asahi of Japan on three middling beer brands. While the $2.9 billion price tag is a bit lower than expected, the Japanese brewer’s acquisition of Peroni, Grolsch and Meantime clocks in at what may be some 25 times one measure of operating profit. The deal is only justifiable under the demographic logic of the buyer’s shrinking home country.

headline: AmfAR Gala to Honor Harvey Weinstein
abstract: The annual fund-raising gala for AIDS research is the unofficial kickoff to New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: The producer Harvey Weinstein is being honored Wednesday night at the annual amfAR gala, which serves as the unofficial kickoff to New York Fashion Week. Charli XCX and Icona Pop will perform — they collaborated on the 2012 hit “I Love It” — and a charity auction will take place during dinner. Last year, the event raised $2.25 million for AIDS research. Previous honorees include Bill Clinton, Elizabeth Taylor, Diane von Furstenberg and Elton John. More information can be found at amfar.org.

headline: Education May Cut Dementia Risk, Study Finds
abstract: Researchers say people with at least a high school education and healthier lifestyles are aiding a decline in new cases, or staving off dementia longer.
lead_paragraph: The risk of developing dementia is decreasing for people with at least a high school education, according to an important new study that suggests that changes in lifestyle and improvements in physical health can help prevent or delay cognitive decline.

headline: Review: New York Philharmonic’s Chinese New Year, From Breezy to Languid
abstract: Tan Dun’s “Nu Shu: The Secret Songs of Women” and Li Huanzhi’s “Spring Festival Overture” were on the holiday program at David Geffen Hall.
lead_paragraph: Hidden messages conveyed in an ancient, enigmatic language are the subject of Tan Dun’s “Nu Shu: The Secret Songs of Women,” which capped the New York Philharmonic’s Chinese New Year celebration at David Geffen Hall on Tuesday. This languid, melancholy work for solo harp, orchestra and what its composer calls “micro films” is the result of Mr. Tan’s own field research into a nearly extinct language and calligraphy used for 700 years by women from a village in his native Hunan province.

headline: Benjamin Millepied Opens Up on Leaving Paris Opera Ballet

lead_paragraph: PARIS — “No questions?” Stéphane Lissner, the general director of the Paris Opera, asked the 200 or so journalists assembled on Wednesday morning for the announcement of the Opera’s 2016-17 season. There was the briefest pause. “Well, thank you,” he said, leaving the podium immediately with the music director Philippe Jordan and the director of dance, Benjamin Millepied.

headline: Three Ways to Quit a Campaign
abstract: The art of dropping out.
lead_paragraph: This is the time when candidates who never had a shot at the Republican nomination but were hanging in through New Hampshire drop out of the race. Or as they say, “suspend” their campaigns – a term of art coined in the last few cycles so that they can go on raising money even though they are not actually running anymore.

headline: Behind the Scenes With Six of Fashion Week’s Emerging Designers
abstract: Young talent from around the world convene for the Vfiles Runway competition in New York. T visited them before the show.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this week, six young designers from around the world convened in an empty retail space in SoHo to prepare their debut collections at New York Fashion Week. They were the winners of the sixth Vfiles Runway competition — which will be held tonight at Spring Studios — and have come from Italy, Switzerland, Ukraine, Holland and India. More than a few of them are in New York for the first time.

headline: SolarCity and Other Rooftop Providers Face a Cloudier Future
keywords: ['Solar Energy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power']
abstract: Losses at rooftop solar companies have mounted as some states have withdrawn their support, and cheap natural gas isn’t helping matters.
lead_paragraph: Just two years ago, SolarCity and other rooftop solar providers were Wall Street darlings, and prospects for growth were flying high, as enthusiasm for solar power was seemingly boundless.

headline: Young Bombers Kill 58 at Nigerian Camp for Those Fleeing Boko Haram
abstract: The episode at the Dikwa camp follows a pattern of attacks that the group has carried out since the military began operations against the militants.
lead_paragraph: MAIDUGURI, Nigeria — When three girls showed up Monday at a camp for people who had fled the militant group Boko Haram, they were welcomed and offered a place to sleep.

headline: Stop Bernie-Splaining to Black Voters
abstract: History and experience have burned into the black American psyche a functional pragmatism whose existence doesn’t depend on others’ approval.
lead_paragraph: Now that Iowa and New Hampshire are vanishing in the rearview mirror, the Democratic contests shift more West and South — beginning with Nevada and South Carolina, states that have significantly more Hispanic or black voters, respectively, who at this point disproportionately favor Hillary Clinton to Bernie Sanders.

headline: Yemen: Airstrike Kills Family in Capital
keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Two television journalists and their three children died when an airstrike by the military coalition led by Saudi Arabia hit their house in Sana.
lead_paragraph: Two television journalists were killed late Tuesday, along with their three children, when an airstrike carried out by the military coalition led by Saudi Arabia hit their house in Sana, the capital, witnesses said. The journalists, Suaad Hujaira, 30, and her husband, Muneer Alhakami, 37, worked for Yemen TV, a state channel controlled by Yemen’s Houthi rebels and critical of the Saudis’ military intervention in Yemen. The coalition, which has been fighting the Houthis since March, has been accused of killing hundreds of civilians in airstrikes that are often indiscriminate, human rights groups say. Mr. Alhakami and Ms. Hujaira’s house was in a residential neighborhood in Sana, far from any obvious military target, residents said.

headline: Man Convicted of Killing 3 Brooklyn Merchants in 2012
abstract: Salvatore Perrone, of Staten Island, was found guilty in a series of apparently random attacks that had shopkeepers on alert for months.
lead_paragraph: A traveling clothing salesman was convicted on Wednesday of fatally shooting three merchants in Brooklyn, a series of apparently random attacks in 2012 that had shopkeepers on alert for months.

headline: Twitter, to Save Itself, Must Scale Back World-Swallowing Ambitions
abstract: A more prosperous and promising future for Twitter may be as a private company or as a smaller division of a tech or media giant.
lead_paragraph: Twitter is the world’s most important social network.

headline: Cuomo’s Proposal Seeks Confidentiality for Minors With H.I.V.
abstract: The governor’s office said that the plan would help remedy situations in which teenagers cannot seek H.I.V. treatment without parental consent.
lead_paragraph: Among the recent patients at the Children’s Hospital at Montefiore in the Bronx was a 17-year-old with H.I.V. who put off his treatment until he turned 18, because he was worried his parents would kick him out and not pay for his medications if they found out about his status. At SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, doctors wanted to prescribe Truvada, the preventive H.I.V. pill, to a 16-year-old girl who was dating a man who was H.I.V. positive. But she did not receive it because she could not qualify for state assistance to pay for it.

headline: Russian Intervention in Syrian War Has Sharply Reduced U.S. Options
abstract: Russian military action has changed the shape of a conflict that had effectively been stalemated for years, and suddenly, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his allies have momentum.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — For months now the United States has insisted there can be no military solution to the Syrian civil war, only a political accord between President Bashar al-Assad and the fractured, divided opposition groups that have been trying to topple him.

headline: Security Fears Hang Over African Marathons
abstract: The marathon circuit in Africa has expanded in recent years to countries like Senegal, Nigeria, Ivory Coast and Gabon, despite concerns over potential terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Samba Faye’s training for Sunday’s inaugural marathon here includes runs along Dakar’s scenic coastal road, where there has been a noticeable increase in armed security at upscale hotels and shopping areas after recent terrorist attacks in Burkina Faso and Mali.

headline: Where Campaigns Go to Die
abstract: The Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primaries are the first tests presidential hopefuls face every four years, and for a lot of candidates, it’s the beginning and the end.
lead_paragraph: The Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primaries are the first tests presidential hopefuls face every four years, and for a lot of candidates, it’s the beginning and the end.

headline: Technology Manager Gets 3 Years’ Probation in CityTime Scheme
abstract: Carl Bell, who took $6 million in bribes while working on the CityTime payroll project, avoided prison after testifying at his accomplices’ trails.
lead_paragraph: It was one of the biggest frauds ever carried out against the City of New York, and a blot on former Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg’s reputation for managerial and technological savvy. On Wednesday, the criminal prosecutions spawned by the case, involving a computerized payroll system called CityTime, reached a quiet denouement when a federal judge in Manhattan sentenced a computer specialist at the center of the scheme to three years’ probation.

headline: Judge Refuses to Grant Mistrial in Akai Gurley Case
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: Lawyers for Officer Peter Liang, who is accused of fatally shooting Mr. Gurley in 2014, said the prosecution had introduced an “inflammatory” new theory at the last minute.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers defending a New York City police officer accused of killing an unarmed man inside a Brooklyn housing project sought on Wednesday to have the case declared a mistrial, arguing that a last-minute theory introduced by prosecutors was “inflammatory.”

headline: Canada: Another Human Foot Washes Ashore
abstract: The foot was found by a hiker on Vancouver Island’s Botanical Beach and was the 13th to wash up on British Columbia’s shoreline since 2007.
lead_paragraph: The British Columbia Coroners Service said Wednesday that it had opened an investigation after a human foot washed up on the province’s shoreline, the 13th since 2007. Like most of the other cases, the current one involves a foot wearing a running shoe. It was found by a hiker on Vancouver Island’s Botanical Beach on Sunday. The coroner’s office said the foot became detached from the body because of “prolonged immersion in water.” The style of the running shoe that was found was first sold in North American stores in March 2013, indicating that the death occurred sometime after that date. The coroner’s office confirmed that 10 of the 12 feet in earlier cases came from seven people who have been identified. It said that foul play was not evident in the other cases.

headline: Pennsylvania to Start Impeachment Proceedings for Attorney General
abstract: The impeachment vote by the State House and an effort to oust her by the State Senate were the latest turn in an eye-popping drama involving Attorney General Kathleen Kane.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURG, Pa. — The Pennsylvania House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to begin impeachment proceedings against Attorney General Kathleen Kane, who survived a separate attempt by Senate Republicans to oust her using an arcane constitutional procedure not invoked here since 1891.

headline: Did the Supreme Court Just Kill the Paris Climate Deal? Maybe. We Explain.
abstract: Answers to questions about the court’s decision to temporarily block the Obama administration’s effort to regulate emissions from coal-fired power plants.
lead_paragraph: Answers to questions about the court’s decision to temporarily block the Obama administration’s effort to regulate emissions from coal-fired power plants.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | The Plunge
abstract: Dakota Fanning reads the essay “Celebrating the Upside of an Emotional Plunge,” about a teenager who finds love after a 100-foot fall.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to the fifth episode of Modern Love: The Podcast, brought to you by The New York Times and WBUR. This week, you’ll hear the actress Dakota Fanning read a 2013 Modern Love essay by Natalie Lindeman titled “Celebrating the Upside of an Emotional Plunge,” about a teenager who finds the silver lining (and love) after falling 100 feet into one the country’s steepest canyons.

headline: Dweller on the Upper Mississippi
abstract: In which Zhouqin Burnikel fools me twice.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — As a person who is fairly visual, I like to imagine that when I come across a particularly tough crossword clue, a question mark appears above my head until my brain deciphers the answer. As soon as I figure out the answer, that question mark is replaced by an energy-saving and eco-friendly light bulb. I should probably cut down on the video games.

headline: F.B.I. Agents Encircle Holdouts at Oregon Standoff
abstract: The occupiers said they would turn themselves in, and Cliven Bundy, the cattleman whose sons were among the occupation’s leaders, was arrested.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — F.B.I. agents moved in on Wednesday night to encircle the last four holdouts at a federal wildlife refuge in eastern Oregon that has been occupied since early January by armed antigovernment militants.

headline: Two Maryland Deputies Are Killed in Panera Bread Shooting
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Attacks on Police']
abstract: The suspect, who was killed in the exchange of gunfire and had two outstanding warrants, was identified as David Brian Evans.
lead_paragraph: Two sheriff’s deputies were killed Wednesday in a shooting that started at a restaurant in a shopping center in Abingdon, Md., and ended near an apartment complex, the authorities said. The suspect was also killed in the exchange of gunfire.

headline: Police See Possible Hate Crime in Stabbing of Jewish Man in Brooklyn
abstract: The 25-year-old man, who was wearing traditional Hasidic clothing, sustained a collapsed lung after being attacked in the Crown Heights neighborhood, officials said.
lead_paragraph: A 25-year-old Jewish man dressed in Hasidic clothing was stabbed in the back on Wednesday as he walked along a street in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn, and his assailant was being sought in what the police were investigating as a possible hate crime, officials said.

headline: 캄보디아에서 만난 북한의 엘리트 예술 작품
abstract: 캄보디아에 있는 앙코르 파노라마 박물관은 북한 최고의 예술가 수백 명이 속해 있는 평양 만수대 창작사가 맡은 가장 야심 찬 해외 프로젝트다.
lead_paragraph: 캄보디아, 시엠립 — 입구에서 관람객을 맞는 거대한 벽화 속 미소를 띤 석상은 캄보디아 앙코르 유적지 옆에 새로 문을 연 앙코르 파노라마 박물관 내부의 어마어마한 규모와 웅장함에 비하면 그저 맛보기에 불과하다.

headline: New York City to Review a Nuisance Law That Has Led to Evictions
abstract: A little-known, difficult to counter legal practice raises questions over aggressive policing and judicial oversight in which some residents have been forced from their homes.
lead_paragraph: The Police Department will review the circumstances under which it forces people from their homes using New York City’s nuisance-abatement law, a legal weapon that has been used for decades to shut down drug dens, brothels and other criminal operations, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Donald Trump Takes Aim at Ted Cruz Again
abstract: The latest ad comes as the G.O.P. presidential candidates prepare to square off in South Carolina on Feb. 20, after splitting the first two contests.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump released an ad Wednesday attacking Senator Ted Cruz of Texas as the two prepare to square off in South Carolina, after splitting the first two Republican nominating contests.

headline: Nets Look to Turn the Page on Misery. Maybe Next Week.
abstract: Entering the All-Star break, the Nets are trying a more up-tempo style as they look to rebuild again, but the result was the same against the Grizzlies.
lead_paragraph: The Nets were 1.3 seconds away from their 40th loss of the season Monday when Joe Johnson banked in a 3-pointer as time expired to defeat the Denver Nuggets. The thrill of victory — a rare sight inside Barclays Center this season — sent the owner Mikhail D. Prokhorov (also a rarity inside the arena) out of his luxury-box seat, arms extended high in the air as he hollered and celebrated.

headline: Gov. Rick Snyder Asks Michigan Lawmakers for More Aid for Flint
abstract: The request did not include funds to replace all of the city’s lead service lines, which have been delivering tainted tap water.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan asked state lawmakers on Wednesday to approve $195 million more in aid for Flint, where tainted water has caused health problems and prompted calls to rapidly fix the city’s crumbling infrastructure. But the governor’s request did not include funds to replace every lead service line in the city, as Flint’s mayor has insisted is necessary.

headline: Kanye West’s Yeezy Season 3 Extravaganza
abstract: Mr. West debuted his Yeezy Season 3 fashion collection and his new album, “The Life of Pablo,” at Madison Square Garden.

headline: El Chapo Could Be Tried in Brooklyn Court for Drug Trafficking, Official Says
abstract: Although the drug trafficker Joaquín Guzmán Loera has been indicted in several American cities, he would face trial in Brooklyn if Mexico agrees to extradite him, a law enforcement official said.
lead_paragraph: If Mexico agrees to extradite the notorious drug trafficker known as El Chapo to the United States, he would be tried in federal court in Brooklyn, a law enforcement official said on Wednesday.

headline: No Serious Injuries After Bus Carrying Argentine Soccer Team Crashes
abstract: Players from a top Argentine soccer team received emergency treatment after their bus crashed and overturned in Venezuela following a match in the Copa Libertadores.
lead_paragraph: Players from a top Argentine soccer team received emergency treatment after their bus crashed and overturned in Venezuela following a match in the Copa Libertadores, South America’s premier club tournament. Huracán, a team from Buenos Aires, defeated Caracas F.C. on Tuesday night to secure a berth in the Copa’s second round. But on the way back to the airport, the brakes on the team’s bus failed, club officials said. The bus flipped, and several players and members of the club’s staff were hurt, although none of the injuries appeared serious.

headline: Federal Grand Jury Begins Hearing Evidence in Eric Garner Case
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Jury System', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Prosecutors presented evidence in the death of Mr. Garner, who died after being placed in a chokehold by a police officer. A Staten Island grand jury declined to indict the officer in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors began presenting evidence on Wednesday to a grand jury in Brooklyn in the death of Eric Garner, an unarmed black man who died after being placed in a chokehold by a white police officer in Staten Island in July 2014, according to a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Firing Leads to Questions on California Coast’s Future

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The decision by the powerful commission that controls development along California’s coastline to fire its executive director threw the agency into turmoil Thursday, raising questions about why it acted and the future of the state’s 1,100 miles of coastal land.

headline: Berlin Film Festival Includes a Focus on Immigration and Refugees
abstract: “Hail, Caesar” will open the event, but films with weightier subject matter are on the agenda. Meryl Streep is presiding over the Berlinale.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The 66th annual Berlin International Film Festival opens Thursday with the European premiere of the Coen brothers’ latest caper, “Hail, Caesar.” But the Berlinale has always been the most engagé of the world’s film festivals and this year’s selection also reflects some of the weightier issues in Europe today: immigration and refugees.

headline: Outrage Over an Italian Student’s Murder in Egypt
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Torture', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The United States and other allies must call on Egypt to put an end to the climate that allows such abuses to flourish.
lead_paragraph: Italy is in an uproar over the torture and murder in Egypt of Giulio Regeni, a 28-year-old Italian doctoral student at Cambridge University who disappeared in Cairo on Jan. 25 and whose half-naked, battered body was found in a ditch Feb. 3, hours after Italian officials appealed directly to President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt for help in locating the missing student.

headline: Hillary, Bernie and History
abstract: Democratic women are voting their ages in the nominating contests.
lead_paragraph: It’s a sad time for Hillary Clinton’s fans. Well, I guess that’s obvious, since she got clobbered in New Hampshire. But it’s the way she went down that was particularly painful. Bernie Sanders got more than half the women’s vote, mainly because younger women raced off to his corner in droves.

headline: All Praise the Women of Menopause
abstract: We have the First Communion, the bat mitzvah, the Sweet 16. Where are the rituals to celebrate the milestones of the other half of life?
lead_paragraph: For some women, menopause is no big deal. Some say they barely notice it. My mother, long ago, described her menopause this way: “My periods just started gettin’ lighter and lighter, and my harmones  settled down, and then one day … pfft! It was over.”
