lead_paragraph: The betting markets now say that the most likely Republican nominee for president is a man who mocks women, insults Latinos, endorses war crimes like torture, denounces party icons and favors barring people from the United States based on their religion.

headline: The Court Blocks Efforts to Slow Climate Change
abstract: The Republican justices just raised serious questions about America’s ability to deliver on its international pledge to lower emissions.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s extraordinary decision on Tuesday to temporarily block the Obama administration’s effort to combat global warming by regulating emissions from power plants was deeply disturbing on two fronts.

headline: Let’s End the Peril of a Nuclear Winter
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'United States International Relations', 'Cold War Era']
abstract: More than 30 years after the perils of a nuclear winter were first described by scientists, we still have enough nuclear weapons to alter the climate.
lead_paragraph: IN the early 1980s, American and Russian scientists working together outlined a stark vision of the Cold War future. In a battle between the two superpowers, smoke from fires ignited by nuclear explosions would be so dense that it would block out the sun, turning the earth cold, dark and dry, killing plants and preventing agriculture for at least a year.

abstract: The system of showing clothes on a runway, then selling them in stores six months later, seems increasingly irrelevant in the age of social media.
lead_paragraph: The first big show of New York Fashion Week will not take place in a traditional space. It is not even on the traditional schedule, which lists roughly 150 shows stretching from Thursday morning to next Thursday night.

headline: Tracing the Bishops’ Culpability in the Child Abuse Scandal
abstract: The pope must hold prelates accountable for cover-ups and also prod action from a panel he appointed to develop policies to avert child sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis’ commission on the clergy’s sexual violation of children had a timely private screening in Rome last week of “Spotlight,” the Oscar-nominated film about the pedophilia scandal in Boston. The film offers the Vatican, if it will listen, an emphatic lesson in accountability. It dramatizes the decision by The Boston Globe to do more than enumerate the scope of the scandal by reporting on cases involving scores of abusive priests. The scandal was tracked up the church hierarchy to Cardinal Bernard Law, who eventually had to resign his leadership when the news media, not the church, documented his role as a protector of abusive priests.

headline: The Road to the Top of the World
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Winter (Season)', 'Road Trips']
abstract: A remote town in the Arctic Circle known for caribou, northern lights and frigid winters feels like Canada’s last frontier. A highway being built there could change all that.
lead_paragraph: In the Arctic, roads are magical. They appear in the fall and melt in the spring. Others, buckled by permafrost, undulate in the snow. Many are invisible to the naked eye — caribou migration routes that exist only by instinct. During the sunless, frigid winter, the Arctic Ocean becomes one vast road for polar bears and snowmobiles.

headline: A Doctor in the Neighborhood
abstract: There aren’t any guidelines about how to behave when I run into a patient while I’m walking the dog in a ratty T-shirt or standing in line at the grocery store.
lead_paragraph: One of the main premises of health care reform is that everybody needs to have a primary care doctor, ideally in the community. I happen to live right near my clinic, so I often see many of my patients on the street. This can be good or bad. There have been innumerable times when a meeting on the street has added an important element to medical care — reminders of missed visits, lost prescriptions, continuing issues that would not have otherwise made it to my office.

headline: For 12 Photographers, an Anxious Gaze on Israel and the West Bank
abstract: “This Place,” at the Brooklyn Museum, examines the “radical otherness” of a tortured and complex land.
lead_paragraph: For 25 years, Frédéric Brenner traveled the world, finding Jews to photograph. In every place he went, whether it was a singles weekend in the Catskills or an ancient stone dwelling in Yemen, he sought to uncover a buried trace of his own past. “What had been silenced and ignored by my family, I had to excavate,” he said during a visit to New York last month.

headline: At Kichin in Brooklyn, Korean Fried Chicken and Mighty Rice Balls
abstract: The chef Bryan Moon opened the mostly Korean takeout shop under the Marcy Avenue subway stop in November with his older brother Mike.
lead_paragraph: Unpeel the wax paper and there is a fat, charred wedge of rice, prickly with bacon shards, its nori sleeve puckered from a bout on the grill. At the center is treasure: smoked Cheddar and a soft-boiled quail egg, ready to spill.

abstract: Mylan’s $7.2 Billion Deal for Swedish Drug Maker | U.S. and Europe Reach Agreement on Derivatives | MetLife Argues Against Being Too Big to Fail
lead_paragraph: DOLLAR WEAKENS ON FED CAUTION | Janet L. Yellen sounded more worried about the nation’s economy on Wednesday than she did at her last public appearance in December,Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times.

headline: New York Today: Where to Eat Alone
abstract: Thursday: Dining solo, Fashion Week begins, and a “cute” Valentine gift.
lead_paragraph: Good morning on this teeth-chattering Thursday.

headline: Total, French Oil Giant, Tries to Weather Plummeting Prices
abstract: The company’s adjusted profits fell less than analysts had expected, on the strength of cost-cutting and its refining and chemicals business.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a period of sharply lower oil prices, the French company Total fared better in the fourth quarter than some of its peers, reporting adjusted net income on Thursday that beat analyst expectations.

headline: School Bus Crash in Western France Kills 6 Students
abstract: The bus and a heavy truck collided at 7:15 a.m. in Rochefort, as the two vehicles passed each other on the road.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Six students were killed in western France on Thursday morning when their school bus and a heavy truck collided, officials said.

headline: Trial of Reinhold Hanning, Ex-Auschwitz Guard, Opens in Germany
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The 94-year-old former Nazi is charged with being an accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people who died at the camp in Poland.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Reinhold Hanning, a 94-year-old former Nazi charged with being an accessory to the murder of at least 170,000 people who perished at a concentration camp in Poland, refused to make any statements as his trial opened on Thursday in Germany, even as a survivor directly urged him to break his silence.

headline: Kentucky Ex-Governor Aims to Halt Rollback of Obamacare Changes
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: The state, already a test case for the embrace of Obama’s health care law, now stands to become one for attempts to undo it by the current governor.
lead_paragraph: The former governor who made Kentucky a national leader in health care expansion under the Affordable Care Act is moving to protect that legacy from his successor, who has set out to dismantle parts of it.

headline: Danielle Steel: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “Blue” says Alex Haley was her mentor. “We both wrote late at night, and when my phone rang at 3 a.m., I always knew it was him, making sure I was working.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “Blue” says Alex Haley was her mentor. “We both wrote late at night, and when my phone rang at 3 a.m., I always knew it was him, making sure I was working.”

headline: Three Pantry Staples With the Power to Transform
abstract: Olives, capers and chiles: a troika of flavorful ingredients that no wintertime kitchen can do without.
lead_paragraph: The world brims with noteworthy threes. There are the primary colors, the legs on a stool. There are thesis, antithesis, synthesis; Roosevelt, Churchill and Stalin at Yalta. There are the love triangles of Helen of Troy, of Anna Karenina — and of most of us, at some time in our own epic journeys. There were three Magi, bearing gold, frankincense and myrrh. But in daily life, where our needs are physical as often as intellectual and spiritual, no trinity is more useful than the gastronomic trinity of olives, capers and dried chiles. Each has a forcefulness belied by its small size, and together they can sit on a pantry shelf, waiting to be called on — which makes them as indispensable, on a small scale, as Ahab’s (three) mates aboard the Pequod and decidedly more successful at their aim.

headline: The Killing of Warren Weinstein
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'United States International Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: After the American aid worker was abducted in Pakistan, his family undertook a delicate negotiation in hopes of securing his release. But then they got word that he had died — in a United States drone strike.
lead_paragraph: As soon as Alisa Weinstein answered her cellphone last April and heard her sister Jen’s voice, she sensed what was coming. ‘‘It’s been confirmed,’’ Jen said. Alisa stood motionless at the foot of her bed in her tiny San Francisco apartment; just a moment before, she was getting ready for work as a researcher at Uber. She knew what her sister meant: The government was now certain that their father, Warren, was dead, executed by his jihadi captors. She felt herself ‘‘crumpling,’’ she remembers, but quickly ‘‘went into automaton mode.’’ She told Jen that she didn’t want any details. She didn’t want to think about how he had been killed.

headline: Review: In ‘Zoolander 2,’ All Is Still Vanity
abstract: Ben Stiller’s Derek Zoolander, 15 years later, is forever pursing his lips, striking poses and practicing his telekinetic blue-steel glare.
lead_paragraph: If you took away the extravagantly gaudy trappings of the overproduced, chaotic, not very funny comic circus that is “Zoolander 2,” you would still have a surefire basic concept. Derek Zoolander (Ben Stiller), an airhead model forever pursing his lips, striking poses and practicing his telekinetic blue-steel glare in the mirror, is a Chaplinesque Everyman in a delusional bubble. The prevalence of outrageous male vanity was the dirty little secret in the first “Zoolander” that lent the film its satirical bite. In the 15 years that have passed since then, it is anything but a secret in a world of competing buff, preening dandies.

headline: Review: ‘Deadpool,’ a Sardonic Supervillain on a Kill Mission
abstract: This eager-to-please comic-book movie, starring Ryan Reynolds and directed by Tim Miller, is the latest entry in the Marvel universe.
lead_paragraph: Jokes and bullets are tossed like confetti in “Deadpool,” a feverishly eager-to-please comic-book movie about a supervillain who suits up like a superhero. In uniform, the title character, an ordinary mercenary turned freakishly powerful mercenary, may look a little like Spider-Man, at least to the comic-book agnostic. But Deadpool is far more psychotic than heroic, which he cheerfully establishes by painting the screen red with one kill after another. He points, shoots, jokes (repeat), often while cracking wise right into the camera.

headline: What Caused This Otherwise Healthy Retiree’s Debilitating Cough?
abstract: His chest pain, combined with his hacking cough, suggested that he had pneumonia. But there was no sign of infection. So what was it?
lead_paragraph: His chest pain, combined with his hacking cough, suggested that he had pneumonia. But there was no sign of infection. So what was it?

headline: On Java, a Creative Explosion in an Ancient City
abstract: The last sultanate in Indonesia has emerged as one of the world’s most vibrant centers of artistic innovation and risk-taking.
lead_paragraph: After the tropical thunder rolls across south Java comes the rain, and each drop has a character. Some sweep across the bamboo roof in high-pitched volleys, and some plop into the puddles one by one, luminous, like silver. Others hit the dried banana leaves with a solid, resonant thunk.

headline: North Korea to Freeze South’s Assets at Kaesong Industrial Park
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Assets, Frozen', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Nuclear Tests', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'International Relations']
abstract: The North issued a blizzard of retaliatory actions after South Korea said it would close the park.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Thursday that it would freeze all South Korean assets at a joint industrial complex the South shut down to retaliate for a recent nuclear test and a rocket launch by the North.

headline: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts Quarterly Profit Jumps 53%
abstract: The private equity firm’s profit came to 8 cents a share after taxes, missing analysts’ estimates of 27 cents a share.
lead_paragraph: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Thursday that its fourth-quarter after-tax profit rose 53 percent despite a quarter of tumult in the stock market.

headline: First Draft Focus: Throwback Thursday — The More Things Change
abstract: Michael McNerney, 5, tired of waiting for his mother to mark her ballot in the New Hampshire primary, peeps out of a voting booth in Goffstown on March 11, 1952.

headline: NATO Will Send Ships to Aegean Sea to Deter Human Trafficking
abstract: The alliance’s secretary general said surveillance of the Turkey-Syria border would also be enhanced to monitor the activities of smugglers.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — With more than a million migrants having reached Europe in the last year and many more on the way, NATO stepped into the crisis for the first time on Thursday, saying it would deploy ships to the Aegean Sea in an attempt to stop smugglers.

headline: Taiwanese City Moves Against Builder’s Holdings After Earthquake
abstract: Tainan has told local government agencies to monitor the 30 real estate holdings to prevent their sale in the event the victims’ families want to sue.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The city government of Tainan in southwestern Taiwan announced Thursday night that it had identified at least 30 real estate holdings across the island belonging to the developer of an apartment complex that collapsed in an earthquake last Saturday, and had told local government agencies to monitor the holdings to prevent their sale.

headline: HSBC Rescinds Pay Freeze for 2016 but Keeps Hiring Ban in Place
abstract: The lender, which has been trying to cut costs by $5 billion annually, said it would fund pay increases from its bonus pool.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — HSBC has changed course on its decision to freeze pay this year.

headline: Joel Grey, a Broadway Eminence, Comes of Age at 83
abstract: Mr. Grey won an Oscar and a Tony for his role in “Cabaret.” Now, in a new memoir, he talks about his years in showbiz — and in the closet.
lead_paragraph: The view of the Hudson River from Joel Grey’s apartment on West Street is enchanting, even on a murky day, with a drizzle of rain fogging the long wall of high windows. But during a recent interview Mr. Grey rarely looked in that direction. He was focused instead on his new memoir, “Master of Ceremonies,” published by Flatiron Books this month.

headline: Dorothy Parker at the Movies
abstract: Two strangers walking out of the film “45 Years” both felt that it called to mind Dorothy Parker’s poem “Mortal Enemy.”
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: British Police Chief Says Sexual Abuse Complaints May Face More Skepticism
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: After embarrassing revelations related to child abuse inquiries, the authorities may no longer be encouraged to believe every complaint, he said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — After months of embarrassing revelations that the police had failed to challenge dubious claims of child sexual abuse committed by prominent Britons, the head of Scotland Yard announced on Thursday that the authorities might no longer be encouraged to believe every complaint.

headline: Steve Kerr Leads Warriors’ Chase of a Record He Helped Set
abstract: The Golden State Warriors are 48-4 and on pace to win more games than any other N.B.A. team ever, including the 1995-96 Chicago Bulls, which Kerr graced as a bench player.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — If Steve Kerr were any more muted on Wednesday night, he would have been a chromatic gray on the color wheel. His Golden State Warriors had just handed the host Suns a 112-104 setback to maintain their edge over the 1995-96 Chicago Bulls in the season-long race for the grand prize of immortality. The reigning N.B.A. champion Warriors had notched victory No. 48 in their 52nd game. Twenty years ago, the Bulls started 48-5 on their way to a record 72-win regular season.

headline: Two Cooks, Two Kitchens, Two Organizing Plans
abstract: Do different cooks need different approaches to organizing the kitchen?
lead_paragraph: My kitchen wasn’t awful. Many nights, the clutter on the counter was arranged quite neatly. Most of the cabinets closed. We could cook in it, and did, with joy.

headline: Delivery Start-Ups Face Road Bumps in Quest to Capture Untapped Market
abstract: Entrepreneurs and investors are discovering how complicated it can be to create a profitable delivery service.
lead_paragraph: DoorDash, one of a multitude of start-ups with a mobile app that lets people order and get food sent to their doorsteps, relies on contract drivers like Brian Navarro to make the deliveries. The problem is that workers like Mr. Navarro don’t always stick around.

headline: Don’t Forget Darfur
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: A reckless new military offensive by the Sudanese regime threatens another humanitarian disaster in the region.
lead_paragraph: Northampton, Mass. — Darfur may have dropped out of international headlines, but that does not mean the region enjoys peace. Far from it. A renewed escalation of violence by the Sudanese government against non-Arab ethnic groups threatens to compound a humanitarian disaster that, according to United Nations estimates, over the past 13 years displaced more than 2.7 million people in Darfur and an additional 380,000 refugees to eastern Chad.

headline: Why Twitter Is Like a Deli With Good Pastrami
abstract: A deli makes a great pastrami sandwich, but only sells them within a five-block radius. Likewise, when Twitter doesn’t draw new users, it can’t sell more ads.
lead_paragraph: Twitter’s earnings on Wednesday were by no means a surprise. The company’s revenues were still going up over the last three months of 2015, but the number of people who use it stopped growing.

headline: At Least 49 Inmates Killed in Mexican Prison Riot
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: A fight between two gangs turned into a deadly riot in an overcrowded, dated penitentiary in the northern city of Monterrey.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The fight took less than an hour. At the end of it, at least 49 followers of two rival gang leaders lay dead, stabbed and beaten to death in an overcrowded, aging prison in the northern city of Monterrey.

headline: Grayson Fund Brochure
abstract: A document dated June 2013 details the capabilities that it says Representative Alan Grayson brings to the hedge fund he continued to run despite his return to Congress.
lead_paragraph: A document dated June 2013 details the capabilities that it says Representative Alan Grayson brings to the hedge fund he continued to run despite his return to Congress.

abstract: Email correspondence from June 2015 between Representative Alan Grayson and his campaign manager at the time involves concern among his staff about the political damage Mr. Grayson’s hedge fund could cause his Senate bid.
lead_paragraph: Email correspondence from June 2015 between Representative Alan Grayson and his campaign manager at the time involves concern among his staff about the political damage Mr. Grayson’s hedge fund could cause his Senate bid.

headline: Alan Grayson’s Double Life: Congressman and Hedge Fund Manager
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Documents show how Mr. Grayson’s work as a hedge fund manager at times interfered with his other duties as a U.S. lawmaker.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The hedge fund manager boasted that he had traveled to “every country” in the world, studying overseas stock markets as he fine-tuned an investment strategy to capitalize on global companies’ suffering because of economic or political turmoil.

headline: Using Older Hardware With Windows 10
abstract: If you rely on a certain printer or scanner connected to your computer, check to see if the device is compatible with Windows 10 before you upgrade.
lead_paragraph: Q. Will the installation of Microsoft’s Windows 10 require me to install different drivers for my scanner and printer?

headline: U.S. Voters Strike Back Against Political Status Quo
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Campaign Finance', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: The New Hampshire primary victories of Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump are rooted in decades of failure by politicians to improve American lives.
lead_paragraph: A backlash has been building gradually among American voters for years against “stagflation,” “the middle-class squeeze,” cross-border trade deals and Wall Street bailouts.

headline: Morgan Stanley to Pay $3.2 Billion Over Flawed Mortgage Bonds
abstract: The bank was expected to pay $2.6 billion, but it was pushed to offer more in the settlement. Much of the additional money is going to New York State.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley will pay $3.2 billion to strike a settlement with state and federal authorities over the Wall Street firm’s creation of mortgage-backed bonds before the financial crisis.

headline: Lincoln Center Hall of Fame Names First Inductees
abstract: The freshman class includes Louis Armstrong, Plácido Domingo, Yo-Yo Ma, Audra McDonald, Leontyne Price and Harold Prince.
lead_paragraph: There is no hall yet, but Lincoln Center’s nascent performing arts hall of fame now has the fame part down. It announced Thursday that its first class of inductees would include Louis Armstrong, Plácido Domingo, Yo-Yo Ma, Audra McDonald, Leontyne Price and Harold Prince.

headline: 1916: Shake-Up in Wilson Cabinet
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Resignations shake up the Wilson administration in 1916.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — With the resignation of Mr. Lindley M. Garrison, the Secretary of War, and of Mr. Henry Breckinridge, the Assistant Secretary of War, and with the submarine outlook worse than at any time since the war began, the Administration is rocked to its very foundations.

headline: Indian Soldier Rescued After Siachen Avalanche Dies
abstract: He was buried for five days under 35 feet of ice on the Siachen Glacier, where Indian and Pakistani troops face one another at high elevations.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — An Indian infantryman whose unlikely survival in an avalanche touched off celebrations across the country died Thursday morning at a military hospital in New Delhi.

headline: ‘Wall of Love’ Commemorates Paris Attacks
abstract: In an effort to heal their neighborhood, residents of the 10th Arrondissement invited street and graffiti artists to paint on a blocklong wall near two cafes that were attacked.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to heal their neighborhood, residents of the 10th Arrondissement invited street and graffiti artists to paint on a blocklong wall near two cafes that were attacked.

headline: Hispanic Group Backs Harry Reid’s Chosen Successor in Nevada
abstract: The Latino Victory Fund and one of its more famous representatives, the actress Eva Longoria, endorsed Catherine Cortez Masto, Nevada’s former attorney general. She is the chosen successor of Senator Harry Reid, who is retiring.
lead_paragraph: The Latino Victory Fund, a Democratic-leaning group looking to elect Hispanics to higher office, made its first Senate endorsement on Thursday in a crucial swing state where the 2016 presidential race is moving toward — Nevada.

headline: What Two Black Holes Colliding Sounds Like
abstract: These chirps are gravitational waves converted to audible sounds. The faint thump matches the gravitational waves’ frequencies. The louder chirp is a higher frequency better suited to human ears.
lead_paragraph: These chirps are gravitational waves converted to audible sounds. The faint thump matches the gravitational waves’ frequencies. The louder chirp is a higher frequency better suited to human ears.

headline: LIGO Hears Gravitational Waves Einstein Predicted
abstract: About a hundred years ago, Einstein predicted the existence of gravitational waves, but until now, they were undetectable.
lead_paragraph: About a hundred years ago, Einstein predicted the existence of gravitational waves, but until now, they were undetectable.

headline: Gravitational Waves Detected, Confirming Einstein’s Theory
abstract: Scientists say they heard the faint chirp of two black holes colliding a billion light-years away, fulfilling Einstein’s general theory of relativity.
lead_paragraph: A team of scientists announced on Thursday that they had heard and recorded the sound of two black holes colliding a billion light-years away, a fleeting chirp that fulfilled the last prediction of Einstein’s general theory of relativity.

headline: 1941: War Looms Over Bulgaria
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: War looms over Bulgaria in 1941.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA — Bulgarian statesmen are watching, powerless to alter the course of events, as the spectre of war looms ever larger over their country. In diplomatic quarters here it is regarded as only a matter of days, or at best weeks before Bulgaria, like so many other small countries of Europe, becomes involved in the world conflict. There are few people in Bulgaria who do not fervently desire peace. But if Fuehrer Adolf Hitler has decided to move this way — and it is widely believed that he has — there will be no choice between war and peace. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 12, 1941

headline: Oscar’s Heart May Be in Hollywood, but His Accent Is British
abstract: Fully half of this year’s acting nominees come from Commonwealth countries.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — “The movies themselves seem passé in California now,” Christopher Rand wrote in “Los Angeles: The Ultimate City,” published in 1967. Brushing aside Hollywood in a single paragraph, he added that “the heart and soul of the movie business seems simply to have left L.A., mainly for foreign countries.”

headline: New York Police Are Using Covert Cellphone Trackers, Civil Liberties Group Says
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: Documents released Thursday show how the department used the surveillance technology while avoiding public debate or review of its constitutionality.
lead_paragraph: Covert cellphone tracking devices, which have proliferated in law enforcement agencies across the nation, have been used by the New York Police Department on at least 1,000 occasions since 2008 in the course of investigating rapes, murders and other crimes, as well as in searches for missing people, according to documents obtained by the New York Civil Liberties Union.

headline: Below the Line: A Daily Ordeal in the Makeup Chair
abstract: The star of “The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared” spent 4½ hours a day being transformed. The designers explain how.
lead_paragraph: “Mad Max: Fury Road.” “The Revenant.” “The 100-Year-Old Man Who Climbed Out the Window and Disappeared.” One of these films may not be quite like the others. Perhaps little-known here, the Swedish film “The 100-Year-Old Man” was a hit in its home country and is in contention alongside the other films for the best hair and makeup Oscar.

headline: James Woods Clears Hurdle in Effort to Unmask Twitter User
abstract: A judge declined this week to put an end to Mr. Woods’s case against an anonymous user that Twitter has refused to identify.
lead_paragraph: To those who spend enough time on the Internet, anonymous attacks come with the territory, like mosquito bites in the tropics. But some bites have serious consequences.

headline: Oregon Standoff Ends as Last Militant Surrenders
abstract: Forty days after the occupation of Malheur National Wildlife Refuge by antigovernment protesters began, the last four holdouts gave themselves up.
lead_paragraph: PRINCETON, Ore. — They implored the last holdout in the armed occupation of a wildlife refuge here to think about the Holy Spirit. They explained that the First Amendment was about freedom of speech and the Second was about the right to bear arms, and said that they were in that order for a reason. They asked him what he thought Jesus would have done in his situation.

headline: Cleveland Drops Attempt to Collect $500 From Tamir Rice Family
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Apologies', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The city said a bill had been automatically generated seeking payment for the medical costs of the 12-year-old who was shot dead by police in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 15 months after a Cleveland police officer fatally shot Tamir Rice, 12, while the boy was playing with a pellet gun near a recreation area, a document appeared online showing that the city was suing to collect $500 for his “last dying expense” — the cost of his emergency medical treatment.

headline: The San Pedro la Laguna Finals
abstract: Although soccer remains Guatemala’s top sport, San Pedro la Laguna has embraced basketball, which has a link to the Mayans.
lead_paragraph: Although soccer remains Guatemala’s top sport, San Pedro la Laguna has embraced basketball, which has a link to the Mayans.

headline: Guatemalan Athletes Are Dribbling, and Not Only With Their Feet
abstract: Although soccer remains the country’s top sport, an increasing number of people are avid players and fans of basketball, which has a link to the Mayans.
lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO LA LAGUNA, Guatemala — The gleaming artificial-turf soccer stadium in the hills above this picturesque town, tucked along the southwest shores of volcano-ringed Lake Atitlán, may be a paean to a soccer-loving culture.

headline: Bruce Springsteen Autobiography ‘Born to Run’ Set for September
abstract: Named for his career-defining 1975 album, the book will cover the “poetry, danger and darkness” of Mr. Springsteen’s New Jersey childhood and his drive to become a musician.
lead_paragraph: Bruce Springsteen is not out of new material just yet.

headline: Eleven Models — From All Over — to Watch This Season
abstract: On the first day of New York Fashion Week and the fall/winter 2016 shows, T and the casting director Arianna Pradarelli pick the runway’s most exciting new faces — some making their debuts, others a few seasons in.
lead_paragraph: On the first day of New York Fashion Week and the fall/winter 2016 shows, T and the casting director Arianna Pradarelli pick the runway’s most exciting new faces — some making their debuts, others a few seasons in.

headline: Vince Gilligan and Peter Gould on ‘Better Call Saul,’ Bob Odenkirk and Fan Tattoos
abstract: The AMC drama returns for its second season on Feb. 15.
lead_paragraph: Once mostly anonymous, the producers who oversee top television series have sometimes become as well known as the actors who star in them. On occasion, The Times will pose questions from readers (and pose some of our own) to notable show runners, and post their responses.

headline: Readers Respond to Redesigned, and Wordier, SAT
keywords: ['SAT (College Admission Test)', 'Reading and Writing Skills (Education)', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Mathematics']
abstract: Most readers support a move to harder reading passages and wordier math problems, saying it will better screen which students are ready for college.
lead_paragraph: Is it unfair to some students that the redesigned SAT, being rolled out next month, will include longer and harder reading passages and wordier math problems than before? Anemona Hartocollis’s article on the topic drew more than 900 responses from readers.

headline: Carmakers Retreat From Quirky Designs as Millennials Embrace Mainstream
abstract: Automakers like Toyota are pulling back from the boxy wagons and jellybean-shape city cars they were using to attract Gen X buyers.
lead_paragraph: It was not too long ago that automakers were tripping over themselves in pursuit of younger buyers, offering boxy wagons and small, jellybean-shape city cars. The Scion xB, the Honda Element, the Nissan Cube: All were funky departures for Generation X from the dowdy minivans of their parents.

headline: Katy Perry on Grammy Parties, a New Album and Keeping Calm Online
abstract: Ms. Perry talks about hosting an event for “creators,” the Super Bowl halftime show and watching the Grammys in her pajamas.
lead_paragraph: For the first time in eight years, Katy Perry is not attending the Grammy Awards. But she is planning a party.

headline: Donald Trump Announces Endorsements, but Doesn’t Name Them
abstract: Donald J. Trump announced that “dozens of Georgia officials” have endorsed him, but he only named four of them.
lead_paragraph: Rolling out endorsements from elected officials is a ritual of presidential campaigns, a sign a candidate is embraced by party leadership. Donald J. Trump added a twist on Thursday by announcing that “dozens of Georgia officials” endorse him, but only naming four of them.

headline: Nigeria Vexed by Boko Haram’s Use of Women as Suicide Bombers
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Three girls sent by Boko Haram this week to attack a camp for those seeking to escape violence revealed a weakness in defenses against the militants.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — Of all the mysteries surrounding Boko Haram, the marauding militant jihadist group that has terrorized Nigeria and its neighbors, the use of women and girls as suicide bombers is among the most vexing.

headline: Defending a Video Game Designer
abstract: Also: taking direction on sitting down in a crowd; artfully saying no to generous cash gifts; and declining a obvious invitation to baby sit.
lead_paragraph: My sweet, smart and responsible husband makes video games for a living. It is a controversial industry. Upon hearing his profession, many people begin long, angry monologues about how much they disapprove of his work. Their manners and politeness tend to evaporate. Is there a way to politely acknowledge these people’s feelings while exiting the conversations quickly?

headline: Video Review: With the RC F, Lexus Abandons Its Beige Image
abstract: Its 5-liter V8 provides plenty of oomph and growl. To find 467 horsepower and 389 pound-feet of torque under the hood of a Lexus is heartening.
lead_paragraph: When talk turns to high performance in cars, Lexus seldom springs to mind. Yes, it has built the passionate IS F sedan. Who wouldn’t want an LFA supercar? Still, Lexus hasn’t attracted the kind of attention that BMW M, Cadillac V and Mercedes AMG cars have.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Backing From Black Democrats in Congress
abstract: The political arm of the Congressional Black Caucus endorsed Hillary Clinton in what has become a tight race for the Democratic presidential nomination, providing an institutional boost as she battles with Senator Bernie Sanders for the support of black voters.
lead_paragraph: The political arm of the Congressional Black Caucus endorsed Hillary Clinton on Thursday in what has become a tight race for the Democratic presidential nomination, providing an institutional boost as she battles with Senator Bernie Sanders for the support of black voters.

headline: 5 Arrested in Connection With East Village Gas Explosion
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Explosions (Accidental)', 'East Village Explosion (March 2015)', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Landlords']
abstract: Four of those arrested were charged with manslaughter in the blast on Second Avenue last year that killed two and reduced three buildings to rubble.
lead_paragraph: The gas explosion that killed two people and destroyed three buildings last spring in the East Village was a catastrophic consequence of a scheme by a landlord who had installed an illegal gas line and hid the setup from inspectors, all in a bid to hold onto tenants and their high rents, prosecutors said on Thursday.

headline: Adriana Lima, Candice Swanepoel and Karlie Kloss Transform Into Marvel Superheroes
abstract: Garage Magazine reimagines five supermodels in its new issue.
lead_paragraph: Supermodels have gotten supermakeovers.

headline: Mark Rylance, Onstage Again in ‘Nice Fish’
abstract: Mr. Rylance heads to St. Ann’s Warehouse in a production about two men ice-fishing and pondering big questions.
lead_paragraph: Accepting a 2008 Tony Award for his hilarious performance in “Boeing Boeing,” Mark Rylance offered some curious advice in his speech: “When you are in town, wearing some kind of uniform is helpful, policeman, priest, etc.,” he began. The perplexing speech was actually a poem by the Minnesota poet Louis Jenkins; Mr. Rylance used another in 2011. “Unlike flying or astral projection, walking through walls is a totally earth-related craft,” he began, accepting a Tony for his performance as the hedonistic Johnny (Rooster) Byron in Jez Butterworth’s “Jerusalem.”

headline: Melissa Mark-Viverito, Council Speaker, Vows to Pursue New Criminal Justice Reforms
keywords: ['State of the City Message (NYC)', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Ms. Mark-Viverito’s proposals, aimed at shrinking New York’s jail population, included the creation of a commission to be led by the state’s former chief judge, Jonathan Lippman.
lead_paragraph: The speaker of the New York City Council, Melissa Mark-Viverito, vowed on Thursday to pursue a new round of criminal justice reforms aimed at shrinking the jail population to such a degree that officials could eventually contemplate shuttering the city’s scandal-plagued jail complex on Rikers Island.

headline: The Boston Modern Orchestra Project Fought Bloat — and Won
abstract: The group has become one of the most artistically valuable in the country for its support of new and neglected music.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Cast your eye over the orchestral landscape, and the big picture could be seen as one of institutional malaise: deficits, labor strife, cowardly programming. All of which makes it imperative to celebrate those ensembles that, through luck, skill and diligence, pull off what the symphonic behemoths too rarely achieve: diverse repertoire and financial equilibrium.

headline: Did You Get Tickets? Beyoncé, Adele and Other Big Tours Unleash Emotional Storm
abstract: The dance of joy and rage on social media begins anew with every big tour, as the concert-ticket market swells with fans and scalpers armed with bots.
lead_paragraph: General ticket sales for Beyoncé’s “Formation” world tour don’t open until next week, but advance sales have provided a taste of what to expect: lots of emotion — good and bad — pouring out on social media.

headline: Saint Laurent in Los Angeles
abstract: The fashion house Saint Laurent presented its collection in L.A. to a crowd of celebrities.
lead_paragraph: The fashion house Saint Laurent presented its collection in L.A. to a crowd of celebrities.

headline: Donald Trump’s Campaign Pulls a Negative Ad on Ted Cruz
abstract: Donald J. Trump’s campaign has ceased running a new negative ad against Senator Ted Cruz in South Carolina, a sign that the candidate may be emphasizing a more positive tone at this point in the battle in that state.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Donald J. Trump’s campaign started running a negative ad in South Carolina against Senator Ted Cruz that was searing, describing the winner of the Iowa Republican caucuses as a fake and a “Washington insider.”

headline: ‘Marcel Broodthaers,’ a Knot of Riddles in a MoMA Retrospective
abstract: This woozily perplexing exhibition gives New York its first-time full exposure to one of Europe’s most influential 20th-century poet-artists.
lead_paragraph: “I’m no good at anything. I am 40 years old.” So wrote the Belgian poet Marcel Broodthaers, who up until 1964, had been supporting himself, barely, as a bookseller and photojournalist (lots of pictures of the Brussels World’s Fair), while making short, strange films and publishing avant-garde poetry.

headline: No ‘P’ in Arabic Means No Palestine, Israeli Lawmaker Says
abstract: Anat Berko, a lawmaker from the governing Likud Party, drew ridicule after saying in a parliamentary debate that Palestine was a “borrowed term.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — One of the many things that divides Israelis and Palestinians is the letter P.

headline: The Grammys: What Makes an Album of the Year?
abstract: When Arcade Fire won in 2011 — and shocked nearly everyone, including the band — the award went to music that was new and worthy, not hit-driven.
lead_paragraph: Long-shot wins, unscripted moments and strange celebrity interactions are among the best reasons to watch awards shows like the Grammys, which are on CBS on Monday. The album of the year category is where they turn up surprisingly often.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Seeking Black Vote, Cites ‘Systemic Racism’
abstract: Mrs. Clinton has generally done well among African-American voters, and is turning her attention on them as tries to fend off Bernie Sanders.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton’s campaign released an ad Wednesday focusing on a “broken” criminal justice system, as she seeks to consolidate support among the African-American communities in South Carolina ahead of the Democratic primary there.

headline: A Lair That Houses 400 Pairs of Sunglasses
abstract: The architect Rafael de Cárdenas’s first commission of the year, the U.S. flagship for the Korean eyewear brand Gentle Monster, opens today.
lead_paragraph: In discussing his latest commission, the first U.S. flagship for Gentle Monster, opening today, Rafael de Cárdenas mentions the Korean eyewear brand’s molar-encrusted styles as a symbol of its irreverence: “The glasses are … they really … some have teeth on them,” he says. “Gentle Monster wanted the store to be very disruptive.”

headline: The New Power Dressing
abstract: Forget the gray suit — the new dress code is anything you want it to be.
lead_paragraph: I have a working definition of power, which came to me in an anecdote about Prince. One night at the end of last summer, according to someone who was there, Prince, the elusive chanteur, went to a concert in New York. Twenty minutes into the show, he decided he wanted McDonald’s French fries. Fifteen minutes after that, McDonald’s French fries were served to him on a white china plate. He ate standing up. Power like that has no uniform.

headline: Don’t Blame Pakistan for ISIS
abstract: A Pakistani Embassy official objects to an article that suggested that his country played a role in the rise of ISIS.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ancient War in Japan, Followed by a Renaissance
abstract: Nearly 50 superb examples of Buddhist art from the Kamakura period at Asia Society.
lead_paragraph: The Kamakura period in Japan (1185-1333) was a time of social and political disaster, with warrior clans from across the country lined up, for the first time, against imperial forces. During the resulting civil war, the unthinkable happened: The Buddhist temples in the ancient city of Nara were destroyed.

headline: ‘For Claude Shannon’ Brings Brainy Dance to the Kitchen
abstract: This work by Liz Santoro and Pierre Godard is part of a multigenre series.
lead_paragraph: What happens when a student of neuroscience and a former quantitative analyst make a dance? Liz Santoro, a choreographer who studied neuroscience at Harvard, and Pierre Godard, a theater technician and director with a background in applied mathematics, have been collaborating for five years, and their minds work well together. Their 2014 work “Relative Collider,” for three ultraprecise dancers (Ms. Santoro included), revealed tightly structured systems of movement and text governed by codes not easily deciphered. The work’s inscrutability was its strength.

headline: Ignore the GPS. That Ocean Is Not a Road.
keywords: ['Global Positioning System', 'Brain', 'Maps', 'Memory', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Navigation', 'Roads and Traffic', 'Research']
abstract: Dependence on navigation technology is eroding our cognitive map of the world around us.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Noel Santillan, an American tourist in Iceland, directed the GPS unit in his rental car to guide him from Keflavik International Airport to a hotel in nearby Reykjavik. Many hours and more than 250 icy miles later, he pulled over in Siglufjordur, a fishing village on the outskirts of the Arctic Circle. Mr. Santillan, a 28-year-old retail marketer from New Jersey, became an unlikely celebrity after Icelandic news media trumpeted his accidental excursion.

headline: In ‘Sunset Song,’ a Hard Life Amid Cruel Beauty
abstract: This melancholy movie by the British director Terence Davies opens the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s Film Comment Selects series.
lead_paragraph: As in most films by the British director Terence Davies, there is a sorrowful stillness at the heart of “Sunset Song,” the opening-night selection of the Film Society of Lincoln Center’s annual series Film Comment Selects, on Wednesday, Feb. 17. This screen adaptation of the Scottish author Lewis Grassic Gibbon’s 1932 novel is aligned with Mr. Davies’s somber, semi-autobiographical reveries about his lonely childhood and adolescence in grim, post-World War II London.

headline: Mavis Staples No Longer Wants to Make You Cry
abstract: Her new solo album, “Livin’ on a High Note,” includes material by songwriters half her age, including Neko Case, Nick Cave and Justin Vernon.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Awards and mementos fill the walls of Mavis Staples’s apartment in a high-rise on the South Shore here. Next to a window with a long view over a choppy Lake Michigan on a rainy, windy February afternoon, there was the platinum single of the indelible 1972 Staple Singers hit “I’ll Take You There.” There was a tambourine with Prince’s trademark glyph, a souvenir of the two solo albums he produced for her on his Paisley Park label. There was a photo of Ms. Staples with the Obama family, autographed by the president with thanks for a “magical evening” when she performed at the White House for a PBS soul-music special. And on a small table sits “my one Grammy,” Ms. Staples said, for her 2010 album “You Are Not Alone.”

headline: What Travelers Need to Know About Zika and Dengue
abstract: Essential information for areas like the Caribbean and Hawaii affected by Zika or dengue, from the use of mosquito repellent to refunds on airfare and hotels.
lead_paragraph: Outbreaks of the mosquito-borne diseases Zika and dengue aren’t slowing down: The Zika virus continues to spread throughout the Caribbean and Brazil, and the mayor of Hawaii County, Billy Kenoi,  declared a state of emergency on the Big Island on Monday in response to the increasing number of dengue cases there. Here is what you need to know if you are contemplating or already have plans to travel to a destination affected by either disease.

headline: Scanning Borders, Israel Surveys New Reality of Tunnels and Terror
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Palestinians', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Border Barriers']
abstract: It is more clear than ever that nonstate actors with sophisticated weapons and technology have replaced the threat to Israel from regular Arab armies.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT HERMON, Golan Heights — Israel’s military commanders are rethinking their concept of border security as they watch the reality of what is happening on the other side changing in front of their eyes.

abstract: BCBG’s fall collection.
lead_paragraph: BCBG’s fall collection.

headline: Brock Collection: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Looks from the latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the latest collection.

headline: Karlie Kloss, Blake Lively and Jay Z at amfAR’s Fashion Week Kickoff
abstract: amfAR honors Harvey Weinstein at its annual gala before New York Fashion Week; 2 Chainz and MADE hosts trap-house themed bash at Milk Studios.
lead_paragraph: amfAR honors Harvey Weinstein at its annual gala before New York Fashion Week; 2 Chainz and MADE hosts trap-house themed bash at Milk Studios.

headline: Disney Unit Cited in Harrison Ford Accident During ‘Star Wars’ Filming
abstract: The British Health and Safety Executive charged Foodles Productions with safety breaches related to an accident in which Mr. Ford’s leg was broken.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the British equivalent of fines levied by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration, a Disney subsidiary was charged on Thursday with four safety breaches on the Pinewood Studios set of “Star Wars: The Force Awakens.”

headline: 36 Hours in Houston
abstract: America’s youngest city offers a potpourri pot of cuisines, quirky shops and art with both global and local reach.
lead_paragraph: America’s youngest city offers a potpourri pot of cuisines, quirky shops and art with both global and local reach.

headline: Why It Won’t Be Easy or Cheap to Fix Flint’s Water Crisis
abstract: Four months after admitting the problem, officials in Michigan are scrambling to work with local leaders to form a plan to undo the damage.
lead_paragraph: Updated Feb. 17

headline: A Parasite, Leopards, and a Primate’s Fear and Survival
abstract: The parasite Toxoplasma gondii may affect the behavior of chimpanzees — and possibly other primates — toward a natural predator, a study finds.
lead_paragraph: Many of our primate ancestors probably ended up in the bellies of big cats. How else to explain bite marks on the bones of ancient hominins, the apparent gnawing of leopards or other African felines?

headline: Indictment in East Village Gas Explosion
abstract: Five people were arrested in connection with a blast on Second Avenue last year that killed two men; four of those arrested were charged with involuntary manslaughter.
lead_paragraph: Five people were arrested in connection with a blast on Second Avenue last year that killed two men; four of those arrested were charged with involuntary manslaughter.

headline: How to Watch the Democratic Debate in Milwaukee
abstract: Thursday night’s Democratic debate from Milwaukee is available on a number of platforms, including PBS and CNN.
lead_paragraph: Here’s our coverage of the sixth Democratic debate, and our live fact checks.

headline: Improving Startup Time in the NYTimes Android App
abstract: Here’s how we improved startup time for our Android application.
lead_paragraph: Improving application startup and load time has been a priority for The New York Times Android development team, and we’re not alone. As device manufacturers continue to offer faster and more fluid experiences, users expect their native apps to be faster still.

headline: Syria’s ‘Lost Generation’
abstract: A reader writes, “What is needed is a strategy that transcends humanitarian aid” to include sustainability in neighboring countries, like Jordan.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Six Killed in Shooting Rampage in Saudi Arabia
abstract: The attacker opened fire in a building in southern Saudi Arabia. The Interior Ministry described it as a “criminal” act and suggested it was unrelated to terrorism.
lead_paragraph: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia — An assailant shot and killed six employees inside an education administration building in southern Saudi Arabia on Thursday, the Saudi Interior Ministry said.

headline: Electric Daisy Carnival Announces 2016 Citi Field Lineup
abstract: David Guetta, Afrojack and Zedd will be among the more than 60 performers in Queens on May 14 and 15.
lead_paragraph: David Guetta, Afrojack, Zedd, Kaskade, DJ Snake, Dillon Francis and Eric Prydz will be among the more than 60 performers at Electric Daisy Carnival, the electronic music festival that will be held at Citi Field in Queens on May 14 and 15, the event’s organizers announced on Thursday.

headline: Gimmicky Crossword Clues
abstract: A longtime puzzle solver objects to more puns and pop culture references, which she views as “a dumbing down of the puzzle.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Reader Idea | Reading ‘Macbeth’ Through the Lens of Ferguson
abstract: As a way to engage a class of academically at-risk students in “Macbeth” and the essential question “Why do we trust?,” students first thought about the question as it applies to the death of Michael Brown.
lead_paragraph: Whom do we trust, and why?

headline: Federal Reserve Won’t Backpedal on Interest Rates, Janet Yellen Says
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Ms. Yellen, the Fed chairwoman, told senators that the Fed planned to raise rates gradually, as concerns persist about the economy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve and financial markets are having a difference of opinion.

headline: Pandora Is Said to Have Held Talks About Selling Itself
keywords: ['Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: Pandora, whose stock has fallen more than 60 percent since October, is said to be working with Morgan Stanley to meet with potential buyers.
lead_paragraph: Pandora Media, the largest Internet radio service, has held discussions about selling the company, according to people briefed on the talks.

headline: The Nuances of Mendoza
abstract: A growing number of Argentine producers are trying to move beyond traditionally fruity wines to explore the subtleties of the region’s terroir.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of Argentine producers are trying to move beyond traditionally fruity wines to explore the subtleties of the region’s terroir.

headline: To Move Beyond Malbec, Look Below the Surface
abstract: In the Mendoza region of Argentina, winemakers are using soil pits partly to educate visitors, but also to educate themselves.
lead_paragraph: TUNUYÁN, Argentina — The view from Bodega Catena Zapata’s Adrianna Vineyard, almost 5,000 feet high in the Uco Valley south of Mendoza, is nothing short of magnificent.

headline: When Family Fortunes Beget Vicious Power Struggles
abstract: The drama playing out around Sumner Redstone is the latest in a string of succession battles fought among the wealthiest of the 1 percent.
lead_paragraph: Consider the plight of Shari Redstone, the daughter of the billionaire media mogul Sumner Redstone.

headline: John Kasich Says ‘Negative’ Tone of Jeb Bush’s Campaign Could Hurt Family Name
abstract: The Ohio governor said Mr. Bush was risking tarnishing his family’s name by “trashing people” on the campaign trail.
lead_paragraph: PAWLEYS ISLAND, S.C. — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, edging toward more direct confrontation with former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, said on Thursday that Mr. Bush was risking tarnishing the Bush family name because of the negative tone of his campaign.

headline: At Creatures of the Wind, Lips Speak the Loudest
abstract: Burgundy lips with bright red gloss dominated the look at the fall/winter 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: “When girls feel really confident and just want to use one beauty trick — the lip is the beauty trick,” explained Creatures of the Wind’s lead makeup artist, Mark Carrasquillo, backstage at the fall/winter 2016 show. To his point, he outlined models’ lips with a deep burgundy lip liner (NARS Velvet Lip Liner in Belle Mare) followed by a coat of similarly hued semi-matte lipstick (NARS Audacious Lipstick in Bette, Ingrid or Charlotte are all good options). And then he added something extra: two brighter red glosses, which he dabbed and blended out from the center of the bottom lip for a painted-on look.

headline: The Woman Bridging the Divide Between Art and Poetry
abstract: With her cerebral and charmingly lo-fi installations and videos, Heather Phillipson is leading the way toward a new emotional expressiveness in contemporary art.
lead_paragraph: With her cerebral and charmingly lo-fi installations and videos, Heather Phillipson is leading the way toward a new emotional expressiveness in contemporary art.

headline: Mylan’s New Deal May Not Be the One Shareholders Wanted
abstract: The drug maker Mylan, which rejected one offer and was itself rebuffed on another, may be overpaying for the Swedish company Meda.
lead_paragraph: Mylan, the generic and specialty drug company, finally has a deal — but probably not the one its shareholders would have preferred. Three months after its rival Perrigo refused its hostile $26 billion offer, Mylan agreed to buy Sweden’s Meda for $7.2 billion.

headline: François Hollande Brings In Green Party Politicians in Cabinet Shuffle
abstract: The minor shake-up by the French leader also included the appointment of former Prime Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault as foreign minister, replacing Laurent Fabius, who stepped down Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France appointed a former prime minister and several politicians from so-called Green parties to his government on Thursday in a minor cabinet shuffle that is expected to be his last before the presidential election next year.

headline: Wall St. Whistle-Blowers, Often Scorned, Get New Support
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Whistle-Blowers']
abstract: Bank Whistleblowers United, an advocacy group, aims to improve the status of Wall Street whistle-blowers and change the way Wall Street is regulated.
lead_paragraph: Becoming a whistle-blower by reporting wrongdoing on Wall Street or in a federal agency that regulates Wall Street takes lots of guts. And a strong argument can be made that whistle-blowers should be celebrated and rewarded for their courage.

headline: The Only Mideast Solution: Two States
abstract: The president of J Street understands Thomas L. Friedman’s despair but says we must not give up and declare the peace process dead.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Creatures of the Wind: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters’s fall looks
lead_paragraph: Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters’s fall looks

headline: Barneys Returns to Chelsea — With Malin+Goetz
keywords: ['Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Perfumes and Fragrances']
abstract: The apothecary label developed a new fragrance to celebrate the luxury retailer’s reopening of its original Seventh Avenue location.
lead_paragraph: Almost 20 years after closing its original flagship store on Seventh Avenue in Chelsea in 1997, Barneys New York will reopen on Monday in the same storied location. To celebrate its homecoming, the luxury retailer has collaborated with various brands on exclusive limited-edition items — including Malin+Goetz’s newest Bergamot fragrance. “We felt it was really a unique request, in the sense that this was the first national retailer we had, I had worked there, and this scent was something that’s been in our brand all this time, and now has an opportunity to take on life in a different form,” explained Matthew Malin, who together with his partner (in business and in life), Andrew Goetz, also happens to be a longtime Chelsea resident.

headline: A Busy Person’s Guide to Staying Sane and in Shape
abstract: Taryn Toomey, a beloved fitness and emotional coach, teaches us how to keep it together this Fashion Week — and always.
lead_paragraph: Taryn Toomey’s 75-minute class — a category-defying blend of bootcamp, yoga and emotional catharsis — is the not-so-secret weapon of New York City’s fiterati, including Naomi Watts and Christy Turlington. Toomey began offering classes (invitation by word-of-mouth) in her TriBeCa building’s basement in 2011; she officially debuted “the class” (lowercase, because it’s more down-to-earth than “The Class”) in 2013. Sessions, in which Toomey helps followers rid themselves of “the sludge” (emotional and physical) and instructs them to “change the way your mind talks to your body,” sold out for weeks. The Class With Taryn Toomey, as it’s called, now has eight teachers. Later this month, Toomey will debut a fine jewelry line and open an outpost in Los Angeles.

headline: Michele Fiore, a Nevada Assemblywoman, Finds Unlikely Role at Oregon Standoff’s End
abstract: A candidate for Congress known for fighting claims of government encroachment talked her way into a tense negotiation with the occupiers.
lead_paragraph: A Nevada state lawmaker whose political life has been largely animated by concerns over individual liberty and gun rights emerged as an unlikely figure in negotiating the final stage of the standoff in eastern Oregon on Thursday.

headline: Science Teachers’ Grasp of Climate Change Is Found Lacking
abstract: A survey of 1,500 teachers in the United States found that on average they spend just one to two hours on average over the course of an academic year.
lead_paragraph: Most science teachers in the United States spend some time on climate change in their courses, but their insufficient grasp of the science as well as political factors “may hinder effective teaching,” according to a nationwide survey of the profession.

headline: Death Toll From War in Syria Now 470,000, Group Finds
abstract: A report by the Syrian Center for Policy Research said life expectancy in Syria had dropped 14 years and put the war’s economic cost at $255 billion.
lead_paragraph: GAZIANTEP, Turkey — As waves of heavy Russian airstrikes edged closer to the Turkish border on Thursday, a Syrian research group issued a report saying the impact of five years of war in Syria has been more devastating than already thought.

headline: Review: ‘Vinyl’ Resurrects the ’70s Music Industry, Amid Proto-Punk Squalor
abstract: Bobby Cannavale stars as the cocaine-snorting head of a foundering record label in this new HBO series, with a pilot directed by Martin Scorsese.
lead_paragraph: There are moments throughout the two-hour premiere of HBO’s pop-music drama “Vinyl” on Sunday night that will make you sit up and say, oh, yeah, Martin Scorsese directed this.

headline: Defending Europe Against Russia
abstract: Readers discuss a defense proposal to quadruple U.S. military spending in Europe, to $3.4 billion.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Tylenol During Pregnancy Tied to Asthma in Children
abstract: Taking Tylenol (acetaminophen) during pregnancy is associated with a slight increase in the risk for asthma in offspring, a new study has found.
lead_paragraph: Taking Tylenol (acetaminophen) during pregnancy is associated with a slight increase in the risk for asthma in offspring, a new study has found.

headline: Scientists Chirp Excitedly for LIGO, Gravitational Waves and Einstein
keywords: ['Gravitation and Gravity', 'Social Media', 'Physics', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Black Holes (Space)']
abstract: Before a big physics announcement, scientists took to social media to share their best imitations of two black holes colliding.
lead_paragraph: How do you celebrate a major discovery in physics and astronomy that could change the shape of scientific inquiry for the next century? Many scientists active on social media did it by chirping.

headline: The Supreme Court and Climate Change Politics
abstract: Two readers chastise the Supreme Court, saying its blocking of new coal plant rules was based on partisan politics.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Paris's Five Best Dishes, According to Chefs
abstract: T asked five of the City of Light’s culinary stars, who are each participating in this weekend’s second annual Taste of Paris food festival at the Grand Palais, to share their favorite things to eat right now.
lead_paragraph: T asked five of the City of Light’s culinary stars, who are each participating in this weekend’s second annual Taste of Paris food festival at the Grand Palais, to share their favorite things to eat right now.

headline: Unlikely Peacemaker, Michele Fiore, Helps End Oregon Standoff
abstract: Michele Fiore, a conservative Republican Nevada assembly member, emerged as the calm mediator in the final hours of an occupation of an Oregon wildlife refuge.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — She has embraced, with a smile and a flourish of diamonds, the imagery of guns, glitter and a hard-edge Western femininity. She drew criticism for appearing to endorse violence against Syrian refugees and for referring to a black lawmaker as “colored.” Her Christmas card last year showed nearly every family member, right down to a small child in glasses, with a firearm in hand or strapped to a hip.

headline: Top Chris Christie Donor, Kenneth Langone, Throws Support Behind John Kasich
abstract: Kenneth G. Langone, the billionaire co-founder of Home Depot who was a leading Christie supporter, has thrown his support behind John Kasich, the Kasich campaign said Thursday.
lead_paragraph: NORTH MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Kenneth G. Langone, the billionaire co-founder of Home Depot who was a leading supporter of Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, has thrown his support behind Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, the Kasich campaign said Thursday.

headline: Facts & Figures: Is Our Economy Fair?
abstract: A majority of Americans say no, but responses vary widely by income and political affiliation.
lead_paragraph: Sixty-five percent of Americans say the nation’s economic system “unfairly favors powerful interests,” according to a survey by the Pew Research Center. But Americans’ feelings about the economy vary a great deal by political affiliation and income.

headline: Ex-Priest Is Arrested in 1960 Killing of Texas Beauty Queen
abstract: The arrest of John Feit, now 83, came about in part because the relatives of Irene Garza, 25, never gave up on the case.
lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — She had a disarming combination of beauty and intelligence and, in her short life, amassed a collection of accomplishments and firsts: first Hispanic twirler at a majority-Anglo high school on the Texas-Mexico border, first in her family to go to college, homecoming queen and, in 1958, Miss All South Texas Sweetheart.

headline: Sushil Koirala, Ex-Premier of Nepal Who Fought for Democracy, Dies at 77
abstract: As prime minister, Mr. Koirala last year presided over the adoption of Nepal’s first democratic Constitution written by an elected assembly.
lead_paragraph: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Sushil Koirala, who as the prime minister of Nepal was an important force behind the adoption in September of the country’s first democratic Constitution drafted by an elected assembly, died here on Tuesday. He was 77.

headline: A Gun Dealer Talks Straight About Guns
keywords: ['Gun Control', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: Gun owners should be treated as engaged consumers who don’t want to lose their ability to purchase guns quickly and easily, not as participants in a modern morality play.
lead_paragraph: Nicholas Kristof’s call for a “new strategy” to combat gun violence is both necessary and compelling, but the solutions he advances — in particular changing how gun control advocates explain and justify their positions to gun owners — I think need a different approach.

headline: Donyell Marshall, a Holder of the 3-Point Record, Waits for It to Fall
abstract: In today’s N.B.A., the record for made 3-pointers in a game, 12, shared by Marshall and Kobe Bryant, could be broken any day, but it has survived since 2003.
lead_paragraph: There is no N.B.A. record that would seem to be more fragile than the one for most 3-point field goals made in a regular-season game. It has to fall, sooner rather than later, according to the less famous of the record’s co-holders.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Syria and More — Photos of the Day
lead_paragraph: Syria and More — Photos of the Day

headline: How The Times Named ‘Nollywood’
abstract: Norimitsu Onishi describes how a comment he made in conversation with an editor in 2002 lived on to describe an emerging cinema powerhouse in Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: Norimitsu Onishi is chief of The New York Times’s southern Africa bureau, based in Johannesburg. He previously covered Southeast Asia, Japan and the Korean Peninsula, and West Africa for The Times.

headline: Oregon Standoff Ends in Time to Prepare Malheur Refuge for Avian Occupiers
keywords: ['Animal Migration', 'Federal Lands', 'WESTERN STATES (US)', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: With the last armed occupiers in handcuffs, the abused Malheur wildlife refuge in Oregon can be prepared for the spring bird occupation.
lead_paragraph: The #OregonStandoff is over. It was heartening to learn today that the patient, but determined strategy of federal and local law enforcement officials worked, with three of the anti-government trespassers at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge walking out to be arrested and the last holdout coaxed to surrender after hours of YouTube-streamed discussion with the FBI and supporters. Get the details from The Times and Oregon Live.

headline: Public Housing, Private Donors
abstract: The de Blasio administration is supporting a nonprofit, the Fund for Public Housing, seeking donations to help the New York City Housing Authority.
lead_paragraph: Late last fall, Rasmia Kirmani-Frye, a lapsed doctoral student in urban policy and an executive at the New York City Housing Authority, gave a talk in Chicago, floating the notion that public housing, as if it were a museum or a prep school, should present itself as a philanthropic cause.

headline: After New Hampshire, Readers Debate Winners and Losers
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Times readers weigh in on the results from the primary.
lead_paragraph: Lela Moore is a news assistant on The Times’s Community Desk.

headline: Review: ‘Surface Tension,’ Inspired by the Met’s Percussive Collection
abstract: Third Coast Percussion performed the piece, composed by Donnacha Dennehy, with instruments like an Irish frame drum and a marimba.
lead_paragraph: Works for drums can be rich in rhythm and timbre, but are often harmonically less interesting because of the pitch limitations of the instrument. But a new piece by the Irish composer Donnacha Dennehy, given its New York premiere at the Metropolitan Museum of Art by Third Coast Percussion on Wednesday, proved an exception.

headline: Review: ‘Already Tomorrow in Hong Kong,’ a Meet-Cute Romance
abstract: Written and directed by Emily Ting, this film tells of two Americans who run into each other on the streets of a glittering city.
lead_paragraph: Stories don’t come much thinner than the one in “Already Tomorrow in Hong Kong,” a will-they-or-won’t-they romance that invests a lot in the attractiveness of that city.

headline: Jim Webb Decides Against an Independent White House Run
abstract: The former Virginia senator, who dropped out of the race for the Democratic nomination last year, cited a lack of money for forgoing a third-party bid for the presidency.
lead_paragraph: After months of mulling an independent run for president, Jim Webb is putting his White House hopes to rest.

headline: Hispanic Celebrities Denounce Donald Trump and G.O.P. Field
abstract: In an open letter, the group accused Mr. Trump and other leading Republican candidates of “capitalizing on negative stereotypes” about Latinos to galvanize the party’s base.
lead_paragraph: A group of Hispanic celebrities have signed an open letter denouncing Donald J. Trump and many of the Republican presidential candidates for “capitalizing on negative stereotypes” about Latinos to galvanize the party’s base.

headline: Object: Diving Below the Ice
abstract: This short film follows a diver on a search below the ice.
lead_paragraph: This short film follows a diver on a search below the ice.

headline: Object: Diving Below the Ice
abstract: What could the diver be searching for in the frigid depths?
lead_paragraph: I grew up in Poland watching my father dive professionally. To me, the most fascinating part of the endeavor was the moment when a diver surfaces. When you dive, descending underwater, you become disoriented. Your adrenaline kicks in. You have the sense that you can go deeper and even deeper still. But before you can do that, you have to know how to stop, and how to keep the pressure safe — only then can you continue. When a diver descends in the water, where there’s only one way out, he is crossing a line, entering a world in which he is entirely reliant on his own resources. So when the diver finally emerges, the relief is almost palpable.

headline: Airbnb Purged New York Listings to Create a Rosier Portrait, Report Says
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: An independent report says the site “misled the media and the public” by deleting over 1,000 listings to show that its hosts obeyed the city’s rules.
lead_paragraph: In December, Airbnb released a trove of data that showed about 95 percent of its hosts in New York City were playing by the rules. But an independent report released Wednesday cast a shadow on that rosy picture, claiming that the company “misled the media and the public” by removing more than 1,000 listings from its site in November before making available the data.

headline: Feb. 11, 2016 — Photos of the Day
abstract: Photos from Syria, Mexico, China and South Korea.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Mexico, China and South Korea.

headline: New Ted Cruz Ad Mocks Marco Rubio as ‘Just a Pretty Face’
keywords: ['Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration']
abstract: An ad Mr. Cruz is running in South Carolina humorously hammers Mr. Rubio for having been in the “Gang of Eight” that made a bipartisan immigration deal.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas is focusing much of his presidential campaign’s negative advertising on Senator Marco Rubio of Florida. In this ad, titled “Conservatives Anonymous,” Mr. Cruz suggests his Republican rival is nothing more than a pretty face. (The Cruz campaign pulled this ad from air on Thursday after reports surfaced that an actress in the ad had been in soft core pornography films.)

headline: Review: In ‘Bad Hurt,’ a Staten Island Family Struggles
abstract: This drama, set in 1999, features post-traumatic stress disorder and other problems that are not easily solved.
lead_paragraph: “Bad Hurt,” a family drama set on Staten Island in 1999 — its opening montage features a distant view of the World Trade Center over a Springsteen-inflected singer musing on how “talk is cheap” — is a sincere, in some respects conscientiously crafted, and almost relentlessly glum movie.

headline: George W. Bush to Campaign for Brother Jeb in South Carolina
abstract: Jeb Bush’s team made official what has long been an open secret — that former President George W. Bush will hit the campaign trail Monday with his younger brother in North Charleston, S.C.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — W. stands for winner — at least that’s what Jeb Bush’s campaign is hoping.

abstract: A look inside the couple’s East London apartment and studio.
lead_paragraph: A look inside the couple’s East London apartment and studio.

headline: At Home With Martino Gamper, Who Gives Unwanted Objects New Life as Furniture
abstract: In the commune-esque home of the Italian designer and his wife, the artist Francis Upritchard, the colorful trappings of life and work are uniquely integrated.
lead_paragraph: In the commune-esque home of the Italian designer and his wife, the artist Francis Upritchard, the colorful trappings of life and work are uniquely integrated.

headline: Gillian Jacobs, a Neurotic ‘Community’ Favorite, Finds ‘Love’
abstract: The actresss brings her skewed worldview and withering zingers to a new Netflix comedy produced by Judd Apatow.
lead_paragraph: Gillian Jacobs knows how to deliver a withering zinger. She did it as Britta Perry, the self-absorbed hipster with grand delusions on NBC’s “Community.” She did it as Mimi Rose Howard, the self-serious performance artist naïf on HBO’s “Girls.” She even did it in lingerie, in “Choke,” a 2008 adaptation of a Chuck Palahniuk novel, in which she played Cherry Daiquiri, a stripper with a sardonic smirk.

headline: Merrill Ashley Is in Focus at the Dance on Camera Festival
keywords: ['Dancing', 'Dance on Camera Festival', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: “The Dance Goodbye,” a documentary in this festival, looks at Ms. Ashley’s life after she retired from New York City Ballet as a principal.
lead_paragraph: Merrill Ashley was in her kitchen cooking when she found herself rocking her hips, ever so gently, from side to side. This was in 2001, after the first of two hip replacements.

headline: South Sudan Leader Appears to Take Major Step to End Conflict
abstract: President Salva Kiir said he was reappointing his rival as first vice president, an important condition of a deal to end more than two years of war.
lead_paragraph: The president of South Sudan appeared to take a major step on Thursday toward ending a disastrous civil war that began more than two years ago in the young African nation — reappointing his political rival as first vice president.
