headline: Uber Agrees to Settle Class-Action Suit Over Safety Claims
abstract: Uber must pay roughly 25 million riders across the United States and reword the language around the fee that the company charges for each ride.
lead_paragraph: Uber has agreed to pay $28.5 million to settle a class-action lawsuit that took issue with the company’s claims that its driver background checks were “industry leading.”

headline: Oprah Made Me Eat It
abstract: There are differences between bread and bread — and between celebrity spokeswomen and regular folks striving to fit into jeans.
lead_paragraph: I drank the Weight Watchers sugar-free Kool-Aid a few years ago, and as I never tire of telling people, I lost 26 pounds, which of course makes me better than you.

headline: A.I.G. Will Give Board Seats to 2 Activists Who Want a Breakup
abstract: The agreement ends nearly four months of bitter debate pitting Carl Icahn and John Paulson against A.I.G., which has resisted calls to break apart.
lead_paragraph: Two billionaire investors who have been agitating for the breakup of American International Group, the giant insurer, have gotten seats at the table.

headline: Review: ‘Glassland,’ the Brittle Territory of Love and Addiction
abstract: Alcohol is a dependable friend for a woman (Toni Collette) who has been abandoned and disappointed by life and has let others down in turn.
lead_paragraph: In “Glassland,” Toni Collette’s portrayal of an embittered Irish woman drinking herself to death in her shabby home on the outskirts of Dublin, is one of the most unsparing screen depictions of extreme alcoholism that I can remember. For much of its running time, the movie gazes unblinkingly into an abyss of poverty and hopelessness. And the environment created by the writer and director Gerard Barrett and the cinematographer Piers McGrail looks as drab and forbidding as any ’60s British kitchen-sink drama.

headline: Eric Foner Wins Historical Society Book Prize
keywords: ['Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Books and Literature', 'Underground Railroad (19th Century)']
abstract: Mr. Foner is being honored for his book “Gateway to Freedom: The Hidden History of the Underground Railroad.”
lead_paragraph: Eric Foner, the much-decorated Columbia University historian, will take on the title American Historian Laureate in April when the New-York Historical Society presents him with its annual American History Book Prize for “Gateway to Freedom: The Hidden History of the Underground Railroad.”

headline: Finding Beauty in the Darkness
abstract: Einstein’s “ripples” should matter to everyone — not just physicists.
lead_paragraph: WITH presidential primaries in full steam, with the country wrapped up in concern about the economy, immigration and terrorism, one might wonder why we should care about the news of a minuscule jiggle produced by an event in a far corner of the universe.

headline: Speedskater Is Poised to Upend Rule of Sports’ Highest Court
abstract: Claudia Pechstein, Germany’s most decorated Winter Olympian, has challenged the fairness of the Court of Arbitration for Sport in a German court, and a ruling next month could drastically alter how justice is meted out in the sports arena.
lead_paragraph: The Court of Arbitration for Sport has for decades served as the final arbiter on sports disputes throughout the world, ruling on thousands of cases ranging from trifling to momentous. The court enabled Oscar Pistorius to run against able-bodied athletes, upheld the cyclist Floyd Landis’s doping suspension and prevented Luis Suárez from overturning his suspension from soccer for biting an opponent at the 2014 World Cup.

headline: Chappatte on Colliding Political Black Holes
abstract: A team of physicists recorded the sound of two black holes colliding a billion light-years away, fulfilling a 100-year-old Einstein prophecy.
lead_paragraph: A team of physicists recorded the sound of two black holes colliding a billion light-years away, fulfilling a 100-year-old Einstein prophecy.

headline: BalletX Flaunts Its Seriously Absurd Style
abstract: The dance company presented the premiere of Trey McIntyre’s “Big Ones” and works by Matthew Neenan and Yin Yue at the Wilma Theater in Philadelphia
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Wacky, eccentric and fabulous, Trey McIntyre’s “Big Ones” — most of it set to Amy Winehouse songs — is so peculiar that the audience at its world premiere on Wednesday night didn’t laugh once. Well, how in the world do you respond to a work in which the 10 dancers — dressed in tunics and hot pants of dark brown leather — start by solemnly donning bonnets with two-foot-tall vertically pointing ears, like those of hares? And those crazy bonnets, laced under the chin, stay (with two brief exceptions) on those heads throughout.

headline: Review: In ‘Cabin Fever,’ the Flesh-Eating Virus Strikes Again
abstract: The director Travis Z. remakes Eli Roth’s 2002 film about vacationing post-adolescents who fall victim to a viral nightmare.
lead_paragraph: Remakes happen, and that’s not always a bad thing. The 1941 film “The Maltese Falcon,” beloved by pop culture mavens the world over, was in fact the third celluloid adaptation of the Dashiell Hammett novel over the course of a mere 10 years. That little bit of data, however, proves more and more an anomaly as the years go by.

lead_paragraph: In the horror film “The Witch,” opening Feb. 19, a 17th-century New England family is haunted by evil. It is the first feature from Robert Eggers, who won the directing prize at the 2015 Sundance Film Festival for the movie.

headline: Silence Is Golden for the Firearms Industry
abstract: A coming regulation on gun silencers has inspired a rush to buy them.
lead_paragraph: Over the years of the Obama administration, panicky fears and unfounded rumors among gun owners have caused the sale and hoarding of firearms to soar, despite the fact that gun rights have generally been extended, not tightened, on the state level at least. Now an actual policy change from the Department of Justice is approaching that has set off the latest firearms bonanza. This one a run on silencers: the extensions, so sinister in noir movies, that attach to gun barrels to limit some of the noise.

headline: Giacomo Tachis, Who Brought French Influence to Italian Wine, Dies at 82
abstract: Mr. Tachis, an oenologist by training, helped develop top-quality wines that used French grape varieties, an approach that proved transformative for the world of Italian wine.
lead_paragraph: Giacomo Tachis, who transformed Italian winemaking in the 1960s and ’70s with a series of innovative, French-influenced red wines from the Chianti region that became known as Super Tuscans, died on Saturday at his home in San Casciano in Val di Pesa, Tuscany. He was 82.

headline: Review: ‘Touched With Fire,’ a Love Story Between Two Bipolar Poets
abstract: Katie Holmes and Luke Kirby play bright, high-strung artists struggling with depression in this film by Paul Dalio.
lead_paragraph: Is there anything wrong with being a euphoric visionary artist? That question cuts to the essence of “Touched With Fire,” Paul Dalio’s extraordinarily sensitive, nonjudgmental exploration of bipolar disorder and creativity. When Marco (Luke Kirby) and Carla (Katie Holmes), poets with the condition also known as manic depression, meet at a group-therapy session in a mental hospital, their emotional combustion undercuts any available treatment.

headline: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week
abstract: Art in review, from Times critics.
lead_paragraph: Art in review, from Times critics.

headline: Review: In ‘Mountains May Depart,’ Jia Zhangke Shows a Changing China
abstract: The film, which begins in 1999, shows changes in personal relationships and in the country itself.
lead_paragraph: Three times in “Mountains May Depart,” the latest from the transformative Chinese director Jia Zhangke, people stand near a river that weaves through the landscape like a snake. In the first instance, three friends light fireworks that send out modest sparks. In the second, only two return to the river, where they ignite a bundle of dynamite. By the third trip, only one of the original three remains, everyone’s life having changed as profoundly as China, a cataclysm that’s expressed by a series of rapid explosions in the river, suggesting a drowning world.

headline: Your Thursday Evening Briefing: Bernie Sanders, Oregon, Einstein
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘How to Be Single’ Is Another Lonely-Hearts Adaptation
abstract: This adventure, which stars Dakota Johnson, flops even with Leslie Mann and Rebel Wilson hard at work being funny.
lead_paragraph: In “How to Be Single,” an innocent post-collegiate newcomer to New York named Alice disappears down a rabbit hole of deadening life lessons and half-baked screenwriting. Christian Ditter’s film adaptation of Liz Tuccillo’s quasi-advice book was written by the people (Abby Kohn and Marc Silverstein) behind a past February lonely-hearts adaptation, “He’s Just Not That Into You.” This reheated “Sex and the City” adventure flops, even with Leslie Mann and Rebel Wilson hard at work being funny.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: ‘A War’ Tracks a Conflict from Battle Zone to Court
abstract: In this Danish film by Tobias Lindholm, an Oscar nominee for best foreign-language film, a commander faces trial after ordering an attack on civilians in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The motion-picture battle cries of heroism and machismo don’t ring out in the Academy Award nominee “A War,” Tobias Lindholm’s 21st-century Danish variation on the conflict film. Instead, the perils of peacekeeping are the foremost concerns for a commander, Claus, and his troops, in a methodical movie that pivots from the backwaters of Afghanistan to a courtroom in Denmark.

headline: His Star Faded, Chris Christie Faces the Challenge of a More Modest Political Stage
abstract: Mr. Christie must now cram his vast political ambitions back into a space the size of New Jersey, and reimmerse himself in the humdrum functions of his office.
lead_paragraph: With his star power and influence diminished after a desultory performance on the presidential campaign trail, Gov. Chris Christie has returned to New Jersey to tend to a state he had at times abandoned during his run.

headline: Review: ‘Fitoor’ Enlists Dickens to Tell a Hindi Love Story
abstract: Based on “Great Expectations,” the film, directed by Abhishek Kapoor, is more Bollywood than Charles Dickens.
lead_paragraph: Based, sometimes loosely, sometimes carelessly, sometimes pointlessly, on “Great Expectations,” the Hindi movie “Fitoor” is at all times more Bollywood than Dickens. The Urdu word “fitoor” means “madness,” as in madly in love, so it’s no surprise that the movie, directed by Abhishek Kapoor (“Rock On!!”), focuses on the love story.

headline: Review: God and Devil Gamble on a Soul in ‘Cabin in the Sky’
abstract: The all-black musical, originally from 1940, is resurrected in City Center’s Encores! series.
lead_paragraph: The Devil and the Lord fight a war by proxy for the soul of a sweet but feckless fellow in “Cabin in the Sky,” an all-black musical from 1940 that kicks off the Encores! season at City Center. A central mission of this beloved series, now more than two decades old, is resurrecting musicals whose scores still shine even as their books have faded into irrelevance. This production — musically vibrant, dramatically a dud — for better and worse offers a prime example of the genre.

headline: She Painted Marie Antoinette (and Escaped the Guillotine)
abstract: Elisabeth Louise Vigée Le Brun made the rich look beautiful, before and after the French Revolution. Now she has a show of her own at the Met.
lead_paragraph: Official portraiture took a hit last week, at least in the United States. Congress just renewed its 2014 prohibition on spending public money on the portraits of politicians that by long tradition have graced the walls of the United States Capitol. Members of Congress and the executive branch must continue to pay for the images by which they want to be remembered.

headline: Review: John Lloyd Young, Stepping Out With Oldies Beyond the Four Seasons’
abstract: Mr. Young, a Tony winner as the original Frankie Vallie in “Jersey Boys,” has broadened his musical horizons in his fourth engagement at Café Carlyle.
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t until I watched the singer John Lloyd Young pour his heart out on Wednesday evening at Café Carlyle that I realized how much I have missed hearing the once-ubiquitous wail of a brokenhearted Romeo on the radio.

headline: Benjamin Clementine Performs at Rough Trade
abstract: The English singer and songwriter, who won the Mercury Prize in 2015, in one of his four shows in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Benjamin Clementine had a canny way to focus the audience’s attention when he performed at Rough Trade NYC on Wednesday night, his first of four New York City shows through March 1. Alone at a baby grand piano, he played low, slow, quiet single notes, barely audible, like the tolling of a distant bell, until the room was entirely hushed. And it stayed that way, except for applause and a fond group singalong, throughout a set of songs that gave introspection a heroic scale. The tunes moved between near-silence and operatic projection, between desolation and rage, between meditation and rhythmic drive, and between humility and hard-won pride.

headline: Review: In ‘Dog Run Moon,’ Men So Lonesome, They Could Cry
abstract: In Callan Wink’s book of short stories, the young men tend to live in trailers and work desultory jobs as the women they love are planning to run off.
lead_paragraph: In Yasmina Reza’s play “God of Carnage” (2006), a woman comments on the diminishment of the modern man. “Men are so wedded to their gadgets,” she says. “It belittles them. It takes away all of their authority.” She adds, “A man ought to give the impression that he’s alone.”

headline: Saint Laurent’s High-Voltage Glamour Woos a Rock ’n’ Roll Crowd
abstract: If you were a celebrity, you were at Hedi Slimane’s Saint Laurent show at the Palladium in Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — Lady Gaga wriggled free of a crowd that all but engulfed her at the Hollywood Palladium Wednesday night, pausing just long enough to blow a virtual kiss in Hedi Slimane’s direction.

headline: A Word With: Irving Azoff, a Hard-Charging Artists’ Manager
abstract: The combative manager of the Eagles, Steely Dan, Van Halen and others talks about the music business as he prepares to receive an industry award.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the music business, an artist’s personal manager is usually a behind-the-scenes figure, the negotiator and taskmaster unseen by the general public.

headline: Valentine’s Day Is a Laughing Matter at Q.E.D. and More Complex at Bookforum
abstract: Bookforum hosts its annual salute to St. Valentine with tales of misadventures in love, and Q.E.D. offers stand-up and sketch comedy.
lead_paragraph: The Miser once made the mistake of scheduling a second date on Valentine’s Day. An attempt to keep things casual and minimize expectations instead turned into a horrifying glimpse at an unhappy domestic future. The evening didn’t make for a lasting relationship, but it later provided good material for a cautionary tale.

headline: Valentines, Vengeful and Comic, Through an Antique Lens
abstract: The fad for the “vinegar valentine” is mostly forgotten, but The Times recorded it in a handful of articles.
lead_paragraph: Anonymous social mockery was not born on the Internet. One of its earlier daddies, as it happens, was naughty Cupid: in the 19th century, valentines were as likely to taunt and scorn as they were to declare passion or puppy love.

headline: Half a Townhouse on Gramercy Park
abstract: An impeccably designed four-bedroom triplex condominium in a 26-foot-wide mansion overlooking the park enters the market for $16.25 million.
lead_paragraph: An impeccably designed four-bedroom triplex condominium in a 26-foot-wide mansion overlooking Gramercy Park is about to enter the market for $16.25 million.

headline: Exclusive | 22 Gramercy Park South
abstract: An impeccably designed four-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath triplex condominium in a 26-foot-wide mansion is about to enter the market.
lead_paragraph: An impeccably designed four-bedroom, five-and-a-half-bath triplex condominium in a 26-foot-wide mansion is about to enter the market.

headline: Cooper Hewitt Triennial Offers a Bold Look at ‘Beauty’
abstract: With more than 250 works by 63 designers from around the world, “Beauty” is a mixed, visually cacophonous bag.
lead_paragraph: This year’s version of the Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum’s always interesting Design Triennial boldly ventures to tackle one of the most controversial topics in today’s visual culture. With more than 250 works by 63 designers from around the world in a jam-packed, two-floor show, “Beauty”  is a mixed, visually cacophonous bag in terms of quality. But whether or not everything in it qualifies as incontrovertibly beautiful, it’s an exciting opportunity to meditate on the perennially confounding questions: What is beauty? And what is it good for?

headline: Movie Review: ‘Zoolander 2’
abstract: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Zoolander 2.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Stephen Holden reviews “Zoolander 2.”

headline: An Adam Pendleton Exhibition Will Open in New Orleans
abstract: The city’s Contemporary Arts Center is devoting all three floors of its galleries to the show, “Adam Pendleton: Becoming Imperceptible.”
lead_paragraph: The conceptual artist Adam Pendleton has not made work that specifically references Hurricane Katrina.

headline: Chris Christie and the Bridges He Burned
abstract: The New Jersey governor’s strategy to run as a moderate problem-solver was doomed by scandals at home.
lead_paragraph: In the weeks before his re-election as governor of New Jersey in 2013, Chris Christie avoided campaigning for Republican legislators in his state. Instead, he aggressively courted endorsements from elected Democrats, racking up dozens. His office emailed YouTube videos to the press in which Mr. Christie and the president of the state Senate, a Democrat, heaped praise on each other. His plan was to win big in this blue state, setting up a future White House run as a bipartisan Republican who could actually get elected in a general election.

headline: Movie Review: ‘Mountains May Depart’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Mountains May Depart.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “Mountains May Depart.”

headline: Donald Trump Criticizes Pope Francis as ‘Very Political’ for Mexico Trip
abstract: In an interview with the Fox Business Network, the Republican presidential candidate suggested that Pope Francis was serving as a pawn of the Mexican government.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has a message for Pope Francis ahead of the pope’s trip to pray with migrants along the Mexican border: You don’t get it.

headline: The Period Room as Reconstruction Site
abstract: Many institutions, including the Minneapolis Institute of Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, are rethinking their period rooms.
lead_paragraph: Museumgoers most likely presume that period rooms remain static, but many are being overhauled. Major institutions are upgrading furnishings, adding technological and musical flourishes, and exploring the lives of the forgotten artisans and patrons who made the original décor possible.

headline: Where to Go in Manila
abstract: Escolta, once the Philippines’ version of Fifth Avenue, is being revived by young artists and historic preservationists.
lead_paragraph: Escolta, once the Philippines’ version of Fifth Avenue, is being revived by young artists and historic preservationists.

headline: U.S. and Russia Announce Plan for Humanitarian Aid and a Cease-Fire in Syria
keywords: ['Humanitarian Aid', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Relief would be sent to besieged cities within days, and a “cessation of hostilities” would go into effect in a week, American and Russian officials announced.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Secretary of State John Kerry and his Russian counterpart, Sergey V. Lavrov, announced that they had agreed on the delivery over the next few days of desperately needed aid to besieged Syrian cities, to be followed by a “cessation of hostilities” within a week on the way to a more formal cease-fire.

headline: Senate Sends Sweeping Trade Enforcement Bill to Obama
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Currency', 'Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'United States Economy']

Zuma, pledged in a state of the nation address on Thursday to revive the country’s economy and cut excessive spending. headline: A Chance to Halt the Brutality in Syria
abstract: An agreement to allow the delivery of humanitarian aid offers at least a glimmer of hope after the relentless attacks by Russia in support of the Syrian regime.

B. King. And the filmmaker Marjorie Sturm unravels the con behind the writer known as JT LeRoy.

headline: Who Won the Debate? Critics Say Hillary Clinton Shone
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders returned to familiar ground Thursday, grappling over Wall Street, health care and the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders returned to familiar ground on Thursday night, grappling over Wall Street, health care and the criminal justice system just two days after Mr. Sanders’s commanding victory in the New Hampshire primary. After heated clashes in their most recent meetings, this debate had a more subdued and even scholarly tone, with detailed discussions about Henry Kissinger, Franklin D. Roosevelt and President Obama’s legacy. In the aftermath, many commentators and critics felt that Mr. Sanders held his own on domestic affairs, but that Mrs. Clinton outshined him on foreign policy and scored some points by cornering him as a single-issue candidate.

headline: Hillary Clinton Is Calm, Cool and Effective
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Recovering from her loss in New Hampshire, Mrs. Clinton projected confidence as she debated Bernie Sanders, challenging him on issues beyond income inequality.
lead_paragraph: Facing off against Senator Bernie Sanders on Thursday night, Hillary Clinton did not comport herself like someone who had just suffered a landslide loss in New Hampshire. She did not raise her voice or express anger. She did not demonize Mr. Sanders or suggest he would be a dangerous choice for Democrats. She remained calm as he pungently sought to highlight their differences.

headline: Francis’s Visit to Mexico Comes as Country Struggles With Many Ills

Battles have literally been fought between church and state, while anticlerical laws stayed on the books until just a couple of decades ago.

headline: On the Edge on Staten Island
abstract: When Christine Osinski moved to Staten Island in the 1980s, she found the long-overlooked borough with a tough edge gave her a sense of freedom and distance from Manhattan.

headline: How Far Left Has America Moved?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: We could be looking at a presidential contest with no real conservative choice.
lead_paragraph: FROM the earliest days of Barack Obama’s presidency, a comforting assumption developed among much of the center-right political world. The thinking went like this: President Obama was far more liberal than the majority of the country. But given his extraordinary political talents, the fatigue of the George W. Bush years, the economic crisis and the excitement of electing the first African-American president, the country picked him not because of his ideology but in spite of it.

headline: Livin’ Bernie Sanders’s Danish Dream
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Youth', 'Taxation', 'United States Economy', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: His policies would give several of our systems northern European characteristics, including some that could surprise some of his supporters.
lead_paragraph: American capitalism has always been distinct from continental European capitalism. We’ve had more entrepreneurial creativity but less security. Our system has favored higher living standards for consumers while theirs has favored stability for employees and producers.

headline: On Economic Stupidity
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Economy', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Inflation (Economics)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Many of the presidential wannabes haven’t learned much about economic risks in the past eight years.
lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton’s 1992 campaign famously focused on “the economy, stupid.” But macroeconomic policy — what to do about recessions — has been largely absent from this year’s election discussion.

headline: Ferguson Turns Its Back on Justice
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Police', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Discrimination', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: The city is now facing a lawsuit from the Justice Department for rejecting a negotiated plan to overhaul its racist policing.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department’s Civil Rights Division took a necessary step on Wednesday when it sued Ferguson, Mo., for rejecting a painstakingly negotiated plan for overhauling the city’s racist policing. The City Council vote to unilaterally amend the plan reflects bad faith by lawmakers who have now made it clear that they cannot be trusted to bring an unbiased, constitutional criminal justice system to this troubled city.

headline: Karl Rove Bamboozles the I.R.S.
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Political Action Committees', 'Campaign Finance']
abstract: Trying to portray sheer check-writing power as a “social welfare” benefit insults honest taxpayers.
lead_paragraph: In a farcical abuse of common sense and the American taxpayer, the Internal Revenue Service has granted Crossroads GPS, the dark-money machine of Karl Rove, the Republicans’ guru of attack politics, status as a tax-exempt “social welfare” organization. This means it can keep its deep-pocketed campaign donors secret. The ludicrous I.R.S. finding that the group is not primarily what it so obviously is — a strident G.O.P. operation that should be required to name its donors — is essentially a license for it to run amok in the current federal election cycle with anonymous, unlimited donations.

headline: Day One of the New President
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: From violating the Geneva Convention to kicking millions off health care, a hefty list of promises from the most likely Republican nominees.
lead_paragraph: It was a lot of fun watching Chris Christie pants Senator Marco Rubio and steal his lunch money, causing the Marcobot to break down — a murder-suicide, it seems to be. And what fan of Lincolnesque elocution didn’t enjoy Donald Trump calling Ted Cruz a girlie man, while belittling Jeb Bush for needing his mommy. Great stuff from the Granite State.

headline: A Republican Crime Proposal That Democrats Should Back
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Corporations', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Requiring proof of a “guilty mind” can benefit corporate executives. But it will also help poor people and racial minorities targeted by the police.
lead_paragraph: THESE days, it’s practically unheard-of for those on the left to embrace ideas promoted by the likes of the Koch brothers and the conservative Heritage Foundation. But it would be a shame if partisan distrust kept Democrats from supporting a proposal favored by the right: a measure that would bolster the idea that a criminal conviction should require proof of what lawyers call “mens rea” — literally, a guilty mind. That’s because it can be harnessed to aid some of those who are especially ill treated by the criminal justice system: the poor and racial minorities.

headline: Q. and A.: Zha Jianying on Remembering the Cultural Revolution
abstract: Ms. Zha, who wrote an introduction to the harrowing Chinese memoir “The Cowshed,” said it rekindled the nightmarish memories from her own childhood.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Nearly 20 years after the appearance in China of one of the most shocking first-person narratives of the Cultural Revolution, “The Cowshed: Memories of the Chinese Cultural Revolution,” The New York Review of Books has published the book in English. Written by Ji Xianlin, the account appears with a new introduction by Zha Jianying, a writer and media critic based in New York. Mr. Ji, who was a distinguished professor of languages at Peking University, offers a rare and harrowing description of life as a prisoner of the Red Guards. The title refers to the flimsy structures with dank floors and reed mats where victims of the Red Guards at the university, including Mr. Ji, were kept.

headline: Police Report and Charges Involving Alan Pean
abstract: Alan Pean drove himself to St. Joseph Medical Center in Houston seeking treatment for mental health distress. During an altercation in his room with two off-duty police officers working as security guards, he was stunned with a Taser and shot in the chest, then charged with assault and reckless driving. Here are legal documents and the police report, redacted by the Police Department.

headline: Eagles Take to South African Agriculture
abstract: A community of Verreaux’s eagles is faring better in a landscape of farms than a similar group in a more remote region.
lead_paragraph: An eagle population in South Africa is thriving despite its situation in an agricultural landscape, according to a new paper in The Condor: Ornithological Applications. The birds are Verreaux’s eagles, predators in decline in southern Africa. Surprisingly, a community in the heavily farmed Sandveld region is healthier than one in the nearby, less developed Cederberg Mountains. The researchers speculate that the agricultural terrain may be easier for eagles to navigate and that their prey may be more diverse. The researchers said that potential threats, like the development of wind turbines, should be monitored.

headline: How to Survive Falling Through the Ice
abstract: Control your breathing. Work on your flutter kick.

Giesbrecht first fell through the ice as a child while hunting with his father. Later, he did so again repeatedly, to demonstrate certain principles of human thermoregulation. It was shocking every time.

headline: A Terrible, Happy Accident in Rio
abstract: A series of unfortunate events ends with an upside.
lead_paragraph: We were in a taxi riding back to Ipanema from my great-aunt’s funeral in Caju. My grandmother was in the front, with my aunt, my grandmother’s friend and me in the back seat. A few weeks earlier, I fell from a ladder and broke my sacrum, so I was supposed to be on bed rest, but I was very close to the aunt who passed away and decided to go to the funeral anyway.

The volume was spotty, but nobody complained.

headline: When the Hospital Fires the Bullet
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Guards', 'Security and Warning Systems', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Stun Guns']

lead_paragraph: When doctors and nurses arrived at Room 834 just after 11 a.m., a college student admitted to the hospital hours earlier lay motionless on the floor, breathing shallowly, a sheet draped over his body. A Houston police officer with a cut on his head was being helped onto a stretcher, while another hovered over the student.

headline: One Patient’s Story: ‘That’s a Kill Shot’
abstract: “This American Life,” in a partnership with The New York Times, tells the story of one family caught in the dangerous crossover of mental health treatment and security in American hospitals.
lead_paragraph: Last August, Alan Pean, a 26-year-old college student with suspected bipolar disorder, was shot in an encounter with two off-duty police officers working as security guards at the Houston hospital where he had come for help. The near-fatal incident illuminates what can happen when mental illness, medicine and weapons — increasingly deployed by medical centers across the country — intersect. We’re telling the story in collaboration with WBEZ Chicago’s This American Life, so in addition to reading the article, you can hear Alan and his family reflect on his ordeal.

headline: 1891: A Heart-Rending Account of the Massacre at Wounded Knee
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune: Sioux leaders in 1891 told of the indiscriminate killing of Native Americans by American soldiers.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 29, 1890, American soldiers killed men, women and children on the Pine Ridge reservation in South Dakota. Two Sioux leaders, Turning Hawk and American Horse, spoke of the massacre’s horrors at a conference in Washington D.C. in 1891. Below is an excerpt from their account that appeared in the European edition of The New York Herald:

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Ties to Henry Kissinger Come Back to Haunt Her
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders questioned Hillary Clinton’s foreign policy judgment in the Democratic presidential debate, specifically pointing to her friendship with Henry A. Kissinger, a secretary of state who served under Republicans.
lead_paragraph: When Hillary Clinton was secretary of state, she relied on Henry A. Kissinger’s counsel. He would send her “astute observations about foreign leaders” and “written reports on his travels.” She would joke with him that smartphones would have made his covert Cold War trip to Beijing impossible.

headline: The Political Economy of Interest Rates Revisited
abstract: Bankers influence, too much, but don’t rule.
lead_paragraph: A few months back there was a debate over the sources of pressure on the Fed to raise rates; part of what drove that debate was the clear division between Fed insiders, like Stan Fischer, who seemed eager to raise rates, and outsiders, like Larry Summers and myself, who were strenuously against a rate hike. What was odd about that debate was that there was little if any obvious difference in economic ideology between the two sides. So what made Keynesian central bankers much more inclined to raise rates, much less receptive to the argument that risks are asymmetric — waiting a bit too long is no big deal, moving too soon can be a disaster — than their colleagues/counterparts/former students outside the system?

headline: Emmett Till and Tamir Rice, Sons of the Great Migration
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Lynching', 'Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: African-Americans still haven’t found the freedom they left the South for 100 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Atlanta — IN winter 1916, several hundred black families from the Selma, Ala., Cotton Belt began quietly defecting from the Jim Crow South, with its night rides and hanging trees, some confiding to The Chicago Defender in February that the “treatment doesn’t warrant staying.” It was the start of the Great Migration, a leaderless revolution that would incite six million black refugees over six decades to seek asylum within the borders of their own country.

headline: Wim Wenders’s High Plains Grifter

lead_paragraph: In “The American Friend” (1977), the German director Wim Wenders, then 31, composed an ode to ambivalence. Mr. Wenders’s first commercial feature, after a half-dozen art films, was both enthralled and appalled by Hollywood; made in three countries (and three languages), it feels precisely placed yet essentially placeless, celebrating even as it deplores a new-minted environment of soulless high-rises and empty airports.

abstract: The accounts are intended to be a simpler, less expensive way for families to save money for members with disabilities.
lead_paragraph: Families that have members with disabilities are eagerly awaiting the debut this year of tax-free savings accounts that will help them set aside money for short- and long-term needs.

headline: Review: ‘The Room,’ a Pinter Play That Won’t Be Onstage for Long
abstract: The Wooster Group’s production of Harold Pinter’s first play seems doomed not to be seen after Sunday.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Harold Pinter was a young actor when he wrote “The Room,” dashing it off over a mere handful of days. It was his first play, and the career that followed its 1957 premiere ensured its status as a precious thing — the beginning of all that was to come.

headline: Disparity in Life Spans of the Rich and the Poor Is Growing
abstract: Despite advances in medicine, a longevity gap that has long favored wealthy Americans has more than doubled since the 1970s, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Experts have long known that rich people generally live longer than poor people. But a growing body of data shows a more disturbing pattern: Despite big advances in medicine, technology and education, the longevity gap between high-income and low-income Americans has been widening sharply.

headline: How to Pinch Pennies in the Right Places
keywords: ['Consumer Behavior', 'Savings', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Personal Finances', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Economics (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: When it comes to spending and saving, our bank accounts will be healthier if we stop looking at relative values and start looking at absolute dollars.
lead_paragraph: I try to be frugal. But my instincts as a consumer are mistaken. Behavioral economics suggests that I’m often frugal in the wrong way and that you may be, too.

headline: This Winter’s Polar Vortex, from Afar and Up Close
abstract: A close-focus and space view of the deep chill finally settling in over the Northeast, for a short while.
lead_paragraph: After walking our dog along the banks of the Hudson River this morning in single-digit temperatures, I went online to put the first deep freeze of our winter here in the Northeast into broader context. (Yes, it is the dread polar vortex.)

lead_paragraph: Kanye West and Taylor Swift just can’t quit each other.

headline: Dean Smith’s Shadow Looms Over U.N.C. as It Struggles With a Scandal’s Fallout
abstract: Emotions on campus are still raw from the revelation that athletes’ grades were inflated by fake classes — a scandal that has besmirched Smith’s cherished Carolina Way.
lead_paragraph: CHAPEL HILL, N.C. — I hadn’t realized when I came here this week that Sunday marked the first anniversary of Dean Smith’s death. But I was quickly reminded; the front page of the University of North Carolina student newspaper, The Daily Tar Heel, featured a photograph of Smith, the legendary former U.N.C. men’s basketball coach, along with an article that was less about his 879 wins and two national championships than about “the lives he touched and the impact he left.”

headline: Why I Can’t Learn to Love Donald Trump
keywords: ['Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Reality Television', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Creative destruction isn’t worth accelerating a trend toward Caesarism.
lead_paragraph: I concluded this week’s Campaign Stops column, written amid near-total Republican disarray, by wondering if reform-minded and populist-friendly conservatives should stop rooting against Donald Trump and hoping for a successful co-optation of the legitimate portions of his message, and instead just accept that the Trump phenomenon is going to carry all before it in this cycle — welcoming it as one part creative destruction, one part judgment issued from on high.

headline: Snapchat Bets Big on Quick-Fire Approach to Campaign Coverage
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'Instant Messaging']
abstract: The popular app aims to give its millions of users a chance to experience the daily tumult of the long primary season — in lively 10-second snippets.
lead_paragraph: BEDFORD, N.H. — Standing toward the back of the room at a Jeb Bush campaign rally here last week, Peter Hamby, the head of news at Snapchat, carried no notebook, pen or laptop.

abstract: A look at the different approaches of each singer and their new music.
lead_paragraph: Listen to this week’s podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher| Audioboom

abstract: Acceptance speeches would be accompanied by names crawling across the bottom of the screen. The nominees have to submit their lists in advance.
lead_paragraph: Could Oscar winners deliver their acceptance speeches with … emoticons?!

headline: Élan, David Waltuck’s Flatiron Restaurant, Will Close
abstract: The former chef at Chanterelle opened the two-starred place less than two years ago.
lead_paragraph: When David Waltuck returned to the kitchen about a year and a half ago with a new restaurant, Élan, and his famous seafood sausage on the menu, those who knew him from his days at the pioneering downtown restaurant Chanterelle cheered.

headline: Private Pinacotheque de Paris Museum to Close
abstract: The private museum, founded by the curator and art historian Marc Restellini, will close its doors indefinitely on Monday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Pinacothèque de Paris, a private museum founded by the curator and art historian Marc Restellini, will close its doors indefinitely on Monday, the institution said Friday.

abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

headline: The Rise and Fall of the Unicorn
abstract: Many unicorns, start-ups with billion-dollar valuations, have a shiny veneer of revenue growth but lack a competitive advantage for long-term value.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy G. Philips is a general partner at Spark Capital.

headline: In Syria, Skepticism That Cease-Fire Will Stop Fighting
abstract: To many, the deal hammered out in Munich overnight seemed like just another irrelevant set of words dictated by diplomats in a foreign capital.
lead_paragraph: KILIS, Turkey — The morning after the United States and Russia agreed on a cease-fire plan for Syria’s nearly five-year-old war, a dozen Syrians huddled at the border gate here on Friday delivered a unanimous verdict. Asked if the bombing would stop, they jerked their heads up and back in unison: Syrian for “No way.”

headline: Art Scene Heats Up in Downtown Los Angeles
abstract: A party circuit has emerged, following the crush of new galleries in the Arts District and neighboring Boyle Heights.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A glittery film premiere this was not.

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Bret Easton Ellis
abstract: The writer shares the titles he’d most want with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the writer and T contributor Bret Easton Ellis, who shares his list exclusively with T.

keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: A generation gap is emerging over the importance of electing a woman to the White House. We invite you to share your opinion. The Times may follow up with you.
lead_paragraph: A generation gap is emerging over the importance of electing a woman to the White House. We invite you to share your opinion. The Times may follow up with you.

headline: A Trip to Vietnam Inspires Tender Pork Ribs
abstract: The meat is first bathed in a fragrant marinade with traditional Vietnamese seasonings, then braised slowly, and browned at the end.
lead_paragraph: I love pork ribs, but when it comes to how best to cook them, I don’t necessarily take the expected approach.

headline: ‘Both the Democrats and Republicans Want Radical Change’:  Readers on the New Hampshire Primary
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Readers dissected the influence of gender, generation and political agenda on the primary, in response to recent columns and editorials.
lead_paragraph: Readers dissected the influence of gender, generation and political agenda in response to recent columns and editorials about Senator Bernie Sanders’s lopsided victory over former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton in the New Hampshire primary.

headline: Hillary Clinton Sharpens Focus After Democratic Debate Tussles
abstract: Before a mostly black audience, Hillary Clinton made clear that she intends to run in this state’s primary by effectively seeking President Obama’s third term.
lead_paragraph: DENMARK, S.C. — Hillary Clinton forcefully attacked Senator Bernie Sanders before a heavily black audience Friday, highlighting his criticism of President Obama, the Affordable Care Act and for what she suggested was a single-minded focus on economic fairness at the expense of racial justice.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Adam Grant’s “Originals,” No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list, overlaps with Malcolm Gladwell’s “Outliers” in substance as well as style.
lead_paragraph: Prophets of Doom: Some authors so thoroughly dominate their genre that rivals may want to invoke the Sherman Antitrust Act. Malcolm Gladwell, for instance, is the king of pithily titled, sociologically inflected narrative nonfiction with a vaguely entrepreneurial self-help feel; his “Outliers” has spent 208 weeks on the paperback nonfiction list and is currently No. 7 on the monthly business list. So it seems almost cheeky that the Wharton School professor Adam Grant has settled, for his latest addition to the field, on the pithy title “Originals.” Grant’s book, which debuts at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list — and comes with a front-cover endorsement from Gladwell — overlaps with “Outliers” in substance as well as style: Both propose to explain why some people rise above their peers to change the world. (Gladwell emphasizes practice; Grant, passion and nonconformity.) Readers of the Book Review may be particularly interested in one study Grant cites, in which a psychologist gave subjects an actual New York Times book review, modified to make it either extremely positive or extremely negative, then asked them to rate the critic’s intelligence. “Which version makes the reviewer sound smarter?” Grant asks. “People rated the critical reviewer as 14 percent more intelligent, and having 16 percent greater literary expertise, than the complimentary reviewer. People think an amateur can appreciate art, but it takes a professional to critique it.” Or, as the original researcher put it, “Prophets of doom and gloom appear wise and insightful, while positive statements are seen as having a naïve ‘Pollyanna’ quality.”

headline: John Kasich Says He, Too, Made Big Money in Speaking Fees
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio brought up his profitable speechmaking, for doing very little work, without any prompting while speaking at Francis Marion University in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, S.C. — Hillary Clinton isn’t the only presidential candidate who found paid speeches to be a lucrative source of income after leaving public office.

headline: Death Becomes Them
abstract: For fictional characters, paradoxically, dying is often the best method of never really fading away.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t want to achieve immortality through my work,” Woody Allen once said. “I want to achieve it through not dying.” One sympathizes. But for fictional characters, paradoxically, dying is often the best method of never really fading away. In this week’s issue, we look at a variety of books, both fiction and nonfiction, about the subjects of love and death.

headline: ‘Salt to the Sea,’ by Ruta Sepetys
abstract: This young adult novel set in the closing days of World War II is based on a real-life maritime disaster.
lead_paragraph: A group of teenage refugees meet on the road in the chaotic countryside of East Prussia in winter 1945. The Nazi Reich is collapsing all around them, and they, like hundreds of thousands, are fleeing the wrathful Soviet advance. They are trapped between their German conquerors and their terrifying Russian “liberators.” Their story is told through the ­voices of Joana, a pretty Lithuanian nurse; Florian, a Prussian with a mysterious letter of passage from a high-ranking Nazi officer; and Emilia, an idealistic but damaged Polish girl in a pink knit cap. Thrown together, struggling to survive, they at first hardly trust one another enough even to exchange names, and so they often just use epithets: “the knight,” “the nurse,” “the Polish girl,” “the wandering boy,” “the shoe poet.” (The last, an old cobbler, gets his name from his philosophy: “The shoes always tell the story.”) Each has secrets — the galling histories that haunt anyone who has lived through war, flight and deprivation.

headline: ‘The Borden Murders,’ by Sarah Miller
abstract: The curious case and sensational trial of Lizzie Borden, maligned innocent or ax murderer.
lead_paragraph: Lizzie Borden took an ax,Gave her mother forty whacks.When she saw what she had done,She gave her father forty-one.

headline: ‘The Heart,’ by Maylis de Kerangal
abstract: The ordeals of organ donation after a teenager’s accident.
lead_paragraph: We open this novel with the understanding that there will be death. It is a certainty. A story about a heart transplant is impossible without this inevitable equation: One body must give, and one must receive. From the first line of the French writer Maylis de Kerangal’s layered, meditative novel, we know that 19-year-old ­Simon Limbres will lose his heart.

headline: ‘Jakob’s Colors,’ by Lindsay Hawdon
abstract: Memory fuels a boy’s passage through wartime Austria.
lead_paragraph: After World War II, even as West Germany began to pay reparations to Jewish death camp survivors, one of its ministries denied the very basis of a collateral holocaust, arguing that the Nazis had persecuted the European Roma “not for any racial reason” but because of their “asocial and criminal record.” In fact, the murder of up to half a million Roma in camps like Auschwitz-Birkenau and Treblinka is comparable to the Shoah on every level except that of scale. Yet the atrocity has never received comparable attention and acknowledgment.

headline: $18.87 Million for a Greenwich Village Penthouse
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: A duplex at Greenwich Lane, with ample outdoor space, was the sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A former wife of the South African hotel magnate Sol Kerzner paid $18,867,059.42 for a duplex penthouse at the Greenwich Lane, a nearly blocklong condominium complex rising at the site of the former St. Vincent’s Hospital campus in Greenwich Village. The transaction was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city property records.

headline: ‘The Photographer’s Wife,’ by Suzanne Joinson
abstract: An artist’s troubles trace to her childhood in 1920s Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: Despite its title, Suzanne Joinson’s dreamlike second novel belongs not to ­Eleanora Rasul, the British wife of an Arab photographer, but to a complex, willful and sometimes off-putting woman named Prudence Ashton. First encountered in 1920 as a lonely 11-year-old trapped in the Holy Land by her father’s government job, Prue is allowed to wander the desert with her own Kodak. There she runs into Willie, the shellshocked aviator her father has hired to survey Jerusalem and help modernize the city — that is, to make it more like London, with tidy public parks and signs of Arab habitation removed.

headline: ‘Flight of Dreams,’ by Ariel Lawhon
abstract: Lawhon novelizes the last, fatal flight of the Hindenburg, and the private lives of its passengers.
lead_paragraph: On its doomed flight in early May of 1937, the silver-skinned zeppelin Hindenburg sailed 600 feet above the earth, from Frankfurt, Germany, to Lakehurst, N.J. Traveling at just under 80 miles an hour, carrying 97 passengers and crew, it would take four days on its trans-Atlantic voyage.

headline: Romance
abstract: New books by Eloisa James, Vanessa North, Mingmei Yip, Joshilyn Jackson and Karen Marie Moning.
lead_paragraph: MY AMERICAN DUCHESSBy Eloisa James Avon. Cloth, 389 pp., $25.99; paper, 422 pp., $7.99.

headline: Review: An Intense yet Pastoral Mahler, Cowbells Included
abstract: Semyon Bychkov conducts the New York Philharmonic in a performance of Mahler’s Sixth Symphony.
lead_paragraph: Mahler’s Sixth Symphony, which Semyon Bychkov is conducting with the New York Philharmonic at David Geffen Hall this week, achieves a remarkable synthesis of Classical structure and Romantic freedom. In the opening performance, on Thursday night, Mr. Bychkov gave full scope to those conflicting impulses.

headline: Awakening the Bowery’s Ghosts
abstract: In a city perpetually rebuilding itself, who controls the remnants below ground, and who shapes the story that will be told about what has been found?
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in October 2013, as work at a construction site in Chinatown was winding down for the day, an amateur historian known for his renegade research tactics, Adam Woodward, slipped through an open gate wearing a suit and tie. After nosing around in the pit, which was to accommodate the foundation for a 22-story luxury hotel, he sounded the alarm, a Paul Revere of the Bowery.

headline: Gibney Dance Announces Premiere and Expansion for 25th Anniversary
abstract: The troupe announced that Gina Gibney will present a new evening-length work in November and run a capital campaign to finance additions at the Agnes Varis Performing Arts Center.
lead_paragraph: New and restaged works by Gina Gibney, the founder and artistic director of Gibney Dance, are planned for the company’s 25th anniversary celebration, along with a 10,000-square-foot expansion of its home.

headline: New York City History, as Told by 50 Bowery
abstract: The address in Lower Manhattan has been a lodestone for the cultural, political and demographic changes of the city.
lead_paragraph: The address in Lower Manhattan has been a lodestone for the cultural, political and demographic changes of the city.

headline: Bookshelf: At Home in the Cold
abstract: New picture books include “One Day on Our Blue Planet . . . in the Antarctic” and “Shh! Bears Sleeping.”
lead_paragraph: New picture books include “One Day on Our Blue Planet . . . in the Antarctic” and “Shh! Bears Sleeping.”

headline: ‘The Man Without a Shadow,’ by Joyce Carol Oates
abstract: In Oates’s latest, a scientist falls for her test subject, a man with a compromised memory.
lead_paragraph: Joyce Carol Oates’s latest novel makes for uncomfortable reading. Even before the narrative begins, a hint of disquiet creeps in with the epigraph: “The annihilation is not the terror. The journey is the terror.” Forget the explicit reference to terror; a clammier sort of eeriness settles on the reader who pauses to research the identity of the epigraph’s supposed source, Elihu Hoopes, who turns out to be the “man without a shadow” of the title. To enter these pages is to enter a world of smoke and mirrors, rendered all the more insidious by the realization that this purports to be a world of objective truth, a world of scientific inquiry.

headline: ‘Tender,’ by Belinda McKeon
abstract: An Irish college student has adjustment issues after finding that the man she adores is gay.
lead_paragraph: Dark spirits inform the frantic heart at the center of “Tender,” Belinda ­McKeon’s second novel and a dead-on account of youthful obsession. Catherine Reilly is desperately in love with James Flynn. That James is gay seems no impediment to Catherine, and as their relationship grows ever more essential to her, she appropriates a line from Ted Hughes, a seducer-poet so powerfully attractive to women as to have made one throw up on sight of him: “What happens in the heart simply happens.”

headline: ‘I’m Glad About You,’ by Theresa Rebeck
abstract: A sympathetic romp through the terrains of love, regret and, not least, Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Theresa Rebeck’s tale of two star-crossed Midwesterners passed my screen test with flying colors. You know the one — you have a little pocket of time (15 minutes in the eye doctor’s waiting room, three minutes while waiting for the coffee to perk), and you have a choice: You can check your phone or dip into a book. When you pick the book, you know you’re reading a winner. “I’m Glad About You” is one of these novels — and not because my Instagram feed is all avocado toast, all the time.

headline: ‘The High Mountains of Portugal,’ by Yann Martel
abstract: Three men in different eras search the Iberian countryside for a thing they may never find.
lead_paragraph: A great void rises in Yann Martel’s new novel, and for the three men who act as the loose tethers of its three interwoven stories, the means of filling that void lies deep in the northern stretches of the Iberian countryside, among the scrubland and the stones. Spreading its action over the course of the 20th century, “The High Mountains of Portugal” probes the tender center of grief: Each of its three sections follows the fallout that results from the death of a man’s wife.

headline: ‘Where My Heart Used to Beat,’ by Sebastian Faulks
abstract: A self-destructing veteran finally confronts his memories and the mystery of his father’s death.
lead_paragraph: Sebastian Faulks’s latest novel explores the burden of Britain’s participation in the 20th century’s two major wars, as embodied in the experiences of Robert Hendricks, a psychiatrist and writer whose father died under murky circumstances during World War I and who is himself a lovelorn veteran of World War II. Readers of Faulks’s fiction, most notably of the loose trilogy formed by “Birdsong,” “The Girl at the Lion d’Or” and “Charlotte Gray,” know that his wartime plots tend to involve men and women finding and losing each other. Faulks’s appeal and popularity come from his confident balancing of historically accurate detail with ardent, even over-the-top sympathy for passionate private lives.

headline: ‘Alive, Alive Oh!’ by Diana Athill
abstract: Athill reports on her life at 98 with a still vibrant spirit.
lead_paragraph: The title of Diana Athill’s 2009 memoir, “Somewhere Towards the End,” published when she was 91, acknowledged in her no-fuss, charming way that her final hours were drawing nigh. “Somewhere” was presumably a last glance backward at her romances with married men in her frequent role as “the Other Woman,” coupled with observations about caretaking her mother in her final days and insights on a variety of topics, from faith to fashion, from the perspective of “advanced old age.” Athill, a longtime London book editor, concluded her elegant narrative by musing on possibilities for her deathbed quotation, admitting, “Foolish though it may be, I have to confess that I still hope the occasion on which I have to say it does not come very soon.”

headline: ‘Pax,’ by Sara Pennypacker
abstract: Forced to separate, a boy and his pet fox (for whom the author translates) go on adventures of discovery and maturation.
lead_paragraph: Foxes are fable animals: Their fur carries the electric charge of literary history. As with cats, their faces suggest they have no need of us, and in literature they have all the power that goes with independence. There are the foxes in Machiavelli’s “The Prince” (“One must therefore be a fox to recognize traps. . . . ”) and Jean de La Fontaine’s verses, and there’s Disney’s Robin Hood, matinee idol that he was. For me the most memorable literary fox until now has been the baby fox in Ted Hughes’s poem “Epiphany” — a distilled ball of “mannerless energy” and “old smell,” and a test of the poet’s ability to bend his life and marriage to fit the presence of something so wild and destructive, and so beautiful. Pax, the eponymous fox of Sara Pennypacker’s new novel, is built on the model of Hughes’s cub, half wild and half domesticated, a galvanic presence fit to join the ranks of fiction’s great foxes.

headline: ‘The Red Hat,’ ‘The Story of Snowflake and Inkdrop’ and More
abstract: Four picture books follow the many courses of love, from first meetings to the pain of separation.
lead_paragraph: Adults lug around a five-piece Samsonite luggage set of love and intimacy issues, but most small children have none, or at the most, a carry-on. They are unencumbered by personal history, commitment issues or self-doubt.

headline: Six Perfumers Describe the One They Love, Through Smell
abstract: In honor of Valentine’s Day, the creators of D.S. & Durga, Maison Louis Marie, Coqui Coqui, MCMC and Nasomatto fragrances share their favorite scents.
lead_paragraph: In honor of Valentine’s Day, T asked six great perfumers to describe the one they love — through smell — and how this has impacted their work.

headline: ‘The Narrow Door,’ by Paul Lisicky
abstract: A memoir illuminates two momentous relationships.
lead_paragraph: How well do we know the ones we love? Not as well as we think. Not as well as we do when we lose them, to death or loss of love, and can see at last even what we never wanted to see. Paul Lisicky, in his new memoir, “The Narrow Door,” describes losing his old friend, the novelist Denise Gess, and his husband, the acclaimed poet and memoirist Mark Doty, within a year of each other: Gess to cancer, at the age of 57, and Doty to another man.

headline: ‘Weathering,’ by Lucy Wood
abstract: The beauty and humanity of a daughter’s remembrance drive this debut novel.
lead_paragraph: “She made marmalade cake and soup with carrots and ginger; trying to replace the smell of damp with cooking smells. But still: damp shoes, damp clothes, the dank smell of river. The leak in the hall splitting the ceiling like the crust of a loaf.” The snowed-in feeling of Lucy Wood’s captivating debut novel, “Weathering,” comes from such descriptions of the house Ada has inherited upon her mother’s death, to which she has brought her young daughter, Pepper. This dampness so pervades the book that it almost swells the pages, and the imagery typifies Wood’s wonderful and energetic style, all the way down to the smallest detail: “She found a silty smudge, like a handprint, on the outside of the kitchen window and a small pile of stones on the front steps.” Lest you settle down too comfortably in this winter cabin of a novel: The handprint is that of her dead mother, Pearl.

headline: How Cold Is It? Too Cold for an Ice Fest
abstract: With wind chill temperatures headed below zero, the keepers of Central Park decided to cancel Saturday’s ice-sculpture celebration.
lead_paragraph: The timing seemed perfect.

headline: The Sexual Misery of the Arab World
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Sex', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Abstinence (Sexual)', 'Muslim Veiling', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: We act as though sex doesn’t exist, and yet it determines everything that’s unspoken. Sex is everywhere. Especially after death.
lead_paragraph: ORAN, Algeria — AFTER Tahrir came Cologne. After the square came sex. The Arab revolutions of 2011 aroused enthusiasm at first, but passions have since waned. Those movements have come to look imperfect, even ugly: For one thing, they have failed to touch ideas, culture, religion or social norms, especially the norms relating to sex. Revolution doesn’t mean modernity.

headline: La misère sexuelle du monde arabe
abstract: On fait comme si le sexe n’existait pas, mais il conditionne tous les non-dits. Le sexe est partout. Et surtout après la mort.
lead_paragraph: ORAN, Algérie — Après Tahrir, Cologne. Après le square, le sexe. Les révolutions arabes de 2011 avaient enthousiasmé les opinions, mais depuis la passion est retombée. On a fini par découvrir à ces mouvements des imperfections, des laideurs. Par exemple, ils auront à peine touché aux idées, à la culture, à la religion ou aux codes sociaux, surtout ceux se rapportant au sexe. Révolution ne veut pas dire modernité.

headline: Founded for the Poor, Mass General Looks to the Wealthy
abstract: The 205-year-old Boston hospital plans to open a concierge medical practice in the summer.
lead_paragraph: Can a hospital founded more than 200 years ago to treat the poor also adopt a form of medicine some criticize as health care for the rich?

headline: A Partner in DDC Furniture on Living With the Elements
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings']
abstract: Babak Hakakian, a partner in a high-end furniture business, Domus Design Collection, lives near Madison Square Park with his wife and two children.
lead_paragraph: “The Universe” is what Babak Hakakian calls the long white-lacquer-and-glass hallway that runs from the front door of his loft to the living area overlooking Madison Square Park. Lined with his art collection, it is illuminated by four crystal-and-nickel Galaxy chandeliers designed by Jan Pauwels. “I wanted the concept to really shine through,” he explained.

headline: What I Love | Babak Hakakian
keywords: ['Interior Design and Furnishings', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Babak Hakakian, a partner in DDC, a high-end contemporary furniture business, practices the design he preaches at home.

headline: Legacy of Officer Peter Liang’s Conviction Is Hard to Define
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: While some said the manslaughter conviction of Officer Liang was a long-overdue response to broader demands for law enforcement accountability, the details of the case made its larger meaning elusive.
lead_paragraph: A police officer opened the door to a stairwell in a Brooklyn housing project, sidearm in hand, and squeezed the trigger. The gun, in its brutal simplicity, did exactly what it was designed to do. Far more complicated was how the racially charged atmosphere — in New York City and across the country — in which the shooting occurred might shape the legacy of what amounted to an accident in the dark.

But on Friday morning, an embarrassing stain on the nation was erased. After 869 days, Norway finally has an ambassador.

headline: A Failed Auction? Might Be Nice.
abstract: Investors in Deutsche Bank should look very carefully at the bank’s offer to buy back 5 billion euros of its senior unsecured bonds.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank is making investors an offer they should refuse. The German bank on Friday offered to buy back 5 billion euros of its senior unsecured bonds, after a week in which its shares went on a roller-coaster ride. A big takeup would generate more capital for Deutsche, but it could also imply a lack of confidence in the bank’s solvency. Given the potential for bond prices to snap back, it may be better for investors to sit on the sidelines.

lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Pope Francis on Friday became the first pontiff to ever meet a patriarch of the Russian Orthodox Church, as the two Christian leaders set aside centuries of division in a historic encounter that was held in an unlikely setting: a room at the Havana airport.

headline: PAC Is Backing Donald Trump, Despite Campaign’s Policy
abstract: TrumPAC is soliciting low-dollar contributions that will go directly to Donald J, Trump, even though he has said he doesn’t want super PAC support and has made turning down large donations a staple of his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, the fund-raising email from TrumPAC could confuse a recipient. The solicitation that went out this week from what has been described in news media accounts as a “super PAC,” meaning it is barred from coordinating with the campaign, urges people to make a contribution of $5 that will “go straight to Donald Trump — we’ll eat all the processing costs so he gets 100 percent and YOU will show up on his F.E.C. report!”

headline: Review: ‘Badke,’ a Contemporary Spin on an Arabic Folk Dance
abstract: Inspired by the dabke, a popular Arabic dance, this production is more than a folk dance, both to its credit and its detriment.
lead_paragraph: “Badke” begins in the dark, where signs of life are heard, not seen. But neither the setting nor the subject matter leaves you unaware for long. As the stage reverberates with the sound of punctuated stomps, claps and the occasional whoop, the lights slowly illuminate the scene: 10 dancers with their backs to us hopping in sync. Who doesn’t love a good folk dance?

headline: A Word With: John Oliver, ‘Competing Against People Sleeping’
abstract: The host of “Last Week tonight” on HBO talks about the 2016 presidential election, late-night television and carpool karaoke with Adele.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, John Oliver returns with the third season of “Last Week Tonight” on HBO, joining a late-night comedy landscape that is arguably more competitive than it’s ever been. With only so many viewers to go around, who can make the best Donald Trump joke, who can fill the void left by Jon Stewart and who can produce a segment that goes viral are all vital questions.

headline: Review: In ‘11.22.63,’ an Appointment in Dallas
abstract: In Hulu’s adaptation of the Stephen King novel, a character played by James Franco goes back in time to try to prevent the assassination of J.F.K.
lead_paragraph: The streaming service Hulu needs a big score to keep pace with Netflix, and it has placed its faith in a couple of relatively sure things: Stephen King and the 1960s. The result, “11.22.63,” which begins Monday, is a capable adaptation of Mr. King’s 2011 best seller, appealing enough to snag a general audience and yet different enough from the book to give hard-core King fans plenty to grouse about.

headline: Madeleine Albright: My Undiplomatic Moment
abstract: I should know better than to tell a group of women to go to hell. But the sentiment behind my statement is true: Women need to help one another.

headline: James Levine Cancels Philadelphia Concerts
abstract: The orchestra said in a statement that “the physical demands of travel, rehearsal and concert performance would be detrimental to his current medical treatment.”
lead_paragraph: James Levine, the longtime Metropolitan Opera music director whose health struggles recently brought him to the verge of retirement from that position, has canceled a series of concerts with the Philadelphia Orchestra next week. Mr. Levine, 72, who has Parkinson’s disease, has been modifying his medication levels in an attempt to ease his condition, and the orchestra said in a statement that “the physical demands of travel, rehearsal and concert performance would be detrimental to his current medical treatment.”

headline: Why People Are Confused About What Experts Really Think

headline: Lady of the Valley: Jane Ormsby Gore’s Home
abstract: The English decorator has lived a life so wild and full that it almost reads as fiction. This chapter takes place in the Welsh countryside, in the poetic home she’s made for herself there.

headline: Mets Pitcher Jenrry Mejia Is First Major Leaguer to Get Lifetime Ban for Doping
abstract: Mejia, a reliever, received the punishment after testing positive for a performance-enhancing drug for the third time. This is the first time M.L.B. has delivered such a punishment.
lead_paragraph: In what can be debated as an extraordinary feat of either stick-to-it-iveness or poor judgment — or perhaps both — a professional baseball player has failed a doping test for a third time, resulting in a lifetime ban from Major League Baseball. It is the first time baseball has handed down the most severe punishment under its antidoping program.

headline: Surge in Medicare Advantage Sign-Ups Confounds Expectations
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicare', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Medicaid', 'Federal Budget (US)']
abstract: The government-subsidized plans for older Americans were forecast to wither in the face of cuts under the Affordable Care Act. Instead, they have thrived.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Five years into Medicare spending cuts that were supposed to devastate private Medicare options for older Americans, enrollment in private insurance plans through Medicare has shot up by more than 50 percent, confounding experts and partisans alike and providing possible lessons for the Affordable Care Act’s insurance exchanges.

headline: Hola, Cuba! It’s Hollywood Calling
abstract: Americans are now allowed to shoot scripted movies and shows in Cuba for the first time in half a century. But some filmmakers in Havana are worried.
lead_paragraph: During a shoot for the Showtime comedy series “House of Lies” last month, Don Cheadle sat outside a cafe in Old Havana, puffing on a fat cigar and clinking glasses with three compadres.

abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in New York.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in New York.

headline: A Remedial Lesson in Republican History
keywords: ['Budgets and Budgeting', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: When Republicans refused to hold hearings on the president’s budget, they broke with their own party’s roots.
lead_paragraph: When key Republicans refused earlier this month to schedule hearings with the White House budget director on the president’s new budget, the move was widely and correctly seen as churlish and childish.

headline: Adi Rukun, Neither Silent Nor Intimidated
abstract: Mr. Rukun, the Indonesian subject of “The Look of Silence,” says he used the director, Joshua Oppenheimer, “to expose the terrible ongoing effects of the genocide.”
lead_paragraph: There was a getaway car waiting outside. His family kept bags packed, ready to flee. And a fixer was on standby at the airport, waiting to book last-minute tickets if the need for escape should arise. Those precautions, among others, were taken by the filmmakers of the Oscar-nominated documentary “The Look of Silence” to ensure that its subject, Adi Rukun, remained safe during production.

headline: Harry Reid Says Alan Grayson Should Drop Senate Bid
keywords: ['Conflicts of Interest', 'Hedge Funds', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The Senate Democratic leader said the actions of Mr. Grayson, a Florida congressman and hedge fund manager, “disgrace the halls of Congress.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic leader, on Friday called for Representative Alan Grayson to drop his bid for the Senate, saying Mr. Grayson’s actions as a hedge fund manager “aren’t just disgraceful to the Democratic Party; they disgrace the halls of Congress.”

headline: Apple and Dr. Dre Are Said to Be Planning an Original TV Show
abstract: The show, “Vital Signs,” will be offered through the Apple TV streaming video device, a person with knowledge of the matter said.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple is working on an original television show with Dr. Dre, the co-founder of Beats Music and an Apple executive, according to a person with knowledge of the project.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Political Advertising', 'Debates (Political)', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Party leaders had hoped some of the most provocative speech would have subsided by now, but the battle lines on the issue have only deepened.
lead_paragraph: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — The Republican presidential race has erupted in an incendiary new round of attacks over immigration, laying the groundwork in South Carolina for a monthslong fight that is likely to amplify hard-line talk about border security and migrants before a national audience.

headline: 36 Preguntas para enamorarse de cualquier persona

headline: Porn Star From a Pulled Ted Cruz Ad Is the Chatter at Bob Jones University
abstract: At a prominent evangelical university, Senator Ted Cruz was asked about his campaign’s use of a porn star in an attack ad.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — In a corner of Bob Jones University, the evangelical institution where presidential candidates have long gathered to highlight their faith, Senator Ted Cruz stared into the cameras to answer the question that had almost certainly never been posed inside these halls.

headline: Prepare for ‘Guerrilla Warfare’ With Zika-Carrying Mosquitoes, Experts Warn
abstract: To combat the mosquito that carries the Zika virus, experts say the United States will need a “guerrilla warfare house-to-house method” of control.
lead_paragraph: SAVANNAH, Ga. — It was standing room only at the annual conference of the American Mosquito Control Association this week.

headline: A Valentine’s Date Idea for Astronomy-Loving Early Birds
keywords: ['Space and Astronomy', 'Planets', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: It’s still possible to take advantage of the narrowing window of opportunity to see five planets align.
lead_paragraph: Those who are looking for an unusual Valentine’s Day activity may want to take advantage of the narrowing window of opportunity to see five planets align. This time-lapse video, captured on Jan. 28, gives a sense of what is possible for those who rise very early — or stay up very late.
