abstract: Fans of fashion and music discussed what they're wearing, how much they love Kanye and how they managed to get tickets.
lead_paragraph: Fans of fashion and music discussed what they're wearing, how much they love Kanye and how they managed to get tickets.

headline: Maryland University Reinstates Two Faculty Members Amid Outcry
abstract: The president of Mount St. Mary’s reinstated a student newspaper adviser and another professor who had been critical of the president’s views.
lead_paragraph: The president of Mount St. Mary’s University in Maryland has reinstated two professors who were fired this week for what the administration called disloyalty, after the dismissals were widely denounced by advocates of academic and journalistic freedom and led to a faculty vote demanding his resignation.

headline: Anxiety Rises in Mexico as the Peso Tumbles
abstract: The Mexican currency has fallen more than 30 percent against the dollar over the past year, and past collapses have led to deep recessions.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — The voluble talk-show host Andrea Legarreta broke from her routine of celebrity chatter and household tips recently to give her television viewers an impromptu lesson in global economics and the Mexican peso.

headline: How Ute Lemper, German Chanteuse, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: She doesn’t emit the vibe of an Upper West Side mom, but on Sundays, when she’s not presenting cabaret classics by Kurt Weill, Édith Piaf and Jacques Brel, she’s just that.
lead_paragraph: With her sultry stage persona and “sharp vocal claws,” as a review in The New York Times put it, the German chanteuse Ute Lemper doesn’t project the vibe of an Upper West Side mom. But on Sundays — when she’s not presenting cabaret classics by Kurt Weill or her latest song cycle, “The 9 Secrets,” a setting of Paulo Coelho’s “Manuscripts Found in Accra” — she’s just that. “The rock-solid foundation of my life is my family, and I enjoy very much being with my kids and seeing them happy,” Ms. Lemper said, adding, “It’s only onstage that I am the glamorous lady.” Ms. Lemper, 52, lives in two apartments on different floors of a West 76th Street building with her husband, the percussionist and producer Todd Turkisher, 56; their children, Julian, 10, and Jonas, 4; and, when they are home from college, her two children from a previous marriage, Max, 21, and Stella, 19.

headline: Tommy Kelly, Who Played a Hollywood Tom Sawyer, Dies at 90
abstract: A Bronx boy picked by David O. Selznick to star in “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer,” Mr. Kelly later left the movies for a career in education.
lead_paragraph: If you were a producer casting “The Adventures of Tom Sawyer,” that enduring study of small-town, Middle American life, where would you be least likely to look for your star?

abstract: Here is the second day: Diane Kruger talks Oscars, Wes Gordon shows on Instagram, Adam Selman reveals a darker side and more.
lead_paragraph: We’ll be bringing you highlights from the shows, from the extravaganzas to the scrappy upstarts.

abstract: Tunes for turmoil.

abstract: حاضرٌ غائبٌ هو الجنس، لا بل حاضرٌ ومؤثّرٌ في كلّ ما لا يذكر. الجنس في كلّ مكان، حضوره طاغٍ، خاصّة بعد الموت.

headline: Strange Fascinations in a Kitsch Hideaway
abstract: A bar in Chinatown is a ramshackle retreat full of psychedelic charm.
lead_paragraph: A bar in Chinatown is a ramshackle retreat full of psychedelic charm.

headline: At a Chinatown Bar, Libations Sipped by the Light of Disco Balls
abstract: Once known as the “Bloody Bucket” for its history of crime, the lounge has reemerged in recent years as a bar full of psychedelic, ramshackle charm.
lead_paragraph: Trung Trang sat in his favorite booth at 169 Bar on East Broadway with his friend Allison Clark on a Saturday night last month. It was the night of the season’s first blizzard, and though Ms. Clark lived nearby, he had braved the trip to Chinatown from South Williamsburg, on foot. He was ready for a drink. A hodgepodge of disco balls, lasers and lanterns threw seizure-inducing hues of yellow, magenta and green onto their faces.

headline: Drew Lewis, Transportation Secretary During Air Controllers’ Strike, Dies at 84
abstract: Mr. Lewis, who was also an executive known for rescuing failing companies, put together a temporary system to keep planes in the air during the 1981 strike.
lead_paragraph: Drew Lewis, who as transportation secretary under Ronald Reagan in the early 1980s led contract negotiations with the air traffic controllers’ union and, when many of its members went on strike, put together a temporary system to keep planes in the air, died on Wednesday in Prescott, Ariz. He was 84.

headline: Two-Thirds of the World Faces Severe Water Shortages
abstract: The scarcity can lead to crop failure and low crop yields, which could cause food price increases, famine and widespread starvation.
lead_paragraph: About four billion people, or two-thirds of the world’s population, face severe water shortages during at least one month every year, far more than was previously thought, according to Arjen Y. Hoekstra, a professor of water management at the University of Twente in the Netherlands.

headline: Recalling the Past Lives of an East Village Bathhouse
abstract: Readers shared stories about the slow evolution of the 124-year-old Russian and Turkish Baths, where the atmosphere has long been “live and let live.”
lead_paragraph: A recent article about the Russian and Turkish Baths, a 124-year-old bathhouse on East 10th Street that thrives despite competition from more luxurious spots like Spa Castle, examined the baths’ odd business arrangement: For more than two decades, the two owners have split the business, operating it on alternate weeks.

headline: Leading a 21st-Century ‘21’ Club
abstract: Teddy Suric, the general manager of the Midtown restaurant, has increased its business by dropping the sport coat requirement and adding live music.
lead_paragraph: The venerable “21” Club on West 52nd Street is famous — notorious, even — for its speakeasy heritage and its history of well-known, well-lubricated regulars.

headline: Teatum Jones Wins the International Woolmark Prize
abstract: The British label was chosen from six finalists.
lead_paragraph: In 1954, two fashion world up-and-comers were honored by the International Wool Secretariat for their work in women’s wear. Karl Lagerfeld, 21 at the time, won a prize for coats, and Yves Saint Laurent, 18, was rewarded for dress design. The designers Hubert de Givenchy and Pierre Balmain were among the judges bestowing the honors.

headline: Take Me to the Pilot
keywords: ['Helmets', 'Vietnam War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Aircraft Carriers']
abstract: One of the notable items below decks at the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum is a Vietnam-era helmet worn by an aviation machinist in 1967.
lead_paragraph: There’s no mistaking the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum among the recreational boats, yachts and water taxis anchored at the piers along the Hudson River’s Manhattan docks. It’s the aircraft carrier next to the space shuttle and the submarine.

headline: Cosby Appeal Filed to Prevent Sexual Assault Case Prosecution
abstract: Mr. Cosby and his lawyers defended their appeal by saying that a previous prosecutor said he would never pursue the charge against the entertainer.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s lawyers on Friday appealed a decision made by a judge in a Pennsylvania court last week that allowed prosecutors to proceed with a criminal sexual assault case against him.

headline: At Yonkers Brewing Company, Beer Steeped in Local Pride
abstract: In the city where the gangster Dutch Schultz once owned a brewery, there is a new kind of brewer in town.
lead_paragraph: Until about a year ago, the name most associated with beer in Yonkers was probably that of the notorious racketeer Dutch Schultz, whose criminal domain once included a brewery in the city.

headline: Jake Page, Editor Who Made Science Accessible, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Page worked for book publishers and Smithsonian magazine and wrote books on several areas of science, natural history and the American Indian.
lead_paragraph: Jake Page, an editor and columnist at Smithsonian magazine who brought the wonders of science to a general audience in dozens of books, and who channeled his interest in the Indians of the American Southwest into a series of popular mystery novels, died on Wednesday at his home in Lyons, Colo. He was 80.

headline: New Donald Trump Ad Highlights Father of Teenager Killed by Illegal Immigrant
keywords: ['Gangs', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Jamiel Shaw’s son was killed in Los Angeles in 2008 by an illegal immigrant who prosecutors said mistook him for a gang member.
lead_paragraph: Abandoning a plan to run strictly positive ads in South Carolina, Donald J. Trump’s campaign released one that focused on the 2008 murder of a black teenage athlete in Los Angeles by an illegal immigrant.

headline: Review: Beneath the Rafters of the Barn, Steak and Seafood
abstract: At the Barn, a new restaurant in Granby, Conn., the chef describes a fondness for cooking “a little bit of everything.”
lead_paragraph: Entering a new restaurant, you react to certain details semiconsciously, décor features that skew your affections one way or another. The first thing I noticed at the Barn was the colored lights. Backlit areas glowed pink, yellow or green; a wooden lattice enclosed false marble panels that were lighted a luminous aqua from within. Wild, Gorgon-like chandeliers glimmered blue and yellow overhead. There was a vaguely disco-like quality to it all. Uh-oh, I thought.

headline: Georgia: State to Pay Transgender Inmate
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Georgia has agreed to pay a settlement to Ashley Diamond, the transgender woman who sued officials last year for failing to provide her necessary medical treatment.
lead_paragraph: The State Department of Corrections has agreed to pay a settlement of more than $250,000 to Ashley Diamond, the transgender woman who sued officials last year for failing to provide her necessary medical treatment and safekeeping during her incarceration. Ms. Diamond, a nonviolent offender who was housed in male prisons until her release in August, alleged that she was raped multiple times and that she was denied hormone therapy until the Department of Justice intervened in her case and The New York Times wrote about it. As result of her federal lawsuit, Georgia changed its approach to transgender inmates and dozens have started receiving hormones, the Southern Poverty Law Center said Friday.

headline: Review: The Stockton Inn, After a Revamp, Adopts a Modern Menu
abstract: After buying the business in 2012, the owner shut the banquet and hotel business to focus on the restaurant and tavern, following with a renovation.

headline: Michigan: Snyder Will Testify on Poisoned Water
abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder will testify before a congressional committee on the water crisis in Flint, he said.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder will testify before a congressional committee on the water crisis in Flint, he said on Friday. In a statement, Mr. Snyder, left, said that he had asked Representative Jason Chaffetz of Utah, chairman of the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, for the “opportunity” to speak about the lead contamination that occurred in the Flint water supply in 2014 and 2015. Mr. Chaffetz has not set a date for the hearing, but said that six other witnesses were invited. They include Susan Hedman, a former regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency who resigned last week; Darnell Earley, a former emergency manager of Flint; Dayne Walling, a former mayor of Flint; and Gina McCarthy, the E.P.A. administrator. The witnesses “will shed light on many of our remaining questions and help us propose reforms to the authorizing committees,” Mr. Chaffetz said in a statement.

headline: Syria Truce Deal Makes Aid a Political Tool, Critics Say
abstract: Access to aid is enshrined in international law. But in Syria, humanitarian groups say, it is used as leverage in battle and negotiations.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Leaders of humanitarian aid organizations have, over the last few months, repeatedly implored the warring parties in Syria and their backers not to use the delivery of food and medicine as a bargaining chip in their negotiations about war and peace.

headline: Review: At ToA, a Family’s Latest Foray Into Asian Fusion
abstract: ToA Asian Fusion, the newest restaurant owned by members of the Chen family, is found in an attractive storefront in Suffolk County.
lead_paragraph: Last September, ToA Asian Fusion became one of the newest fusion restaurants — and there are many from which to choose — to open on Long Island. Located opposite the Paramount theater in Huntington, it is owned by members of the Chen family, who also own MoCA Asian Bistro in Woodbury, Hewlett and Forest Hills, Queens, and MoCA Express in Inwood.

headline: Brian Moynihan, Bank of America Chief, Got 23% Pay Raise in 2015
abstract: Brian Moynihan’s pay rose to $16 million, 23 percent larger than in 2014, as the big bank generated higher profits and put its mortgage problems squarely behind it.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America gave its chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, a pay package last year that was 23 percent larger than in 2014, as the big bank generated higher profits and put its mortgage problems squarely behind it.

headline: Art and Ceremony Intertwine at Hosftra University African Exhibit
abstract: The Hofstra University Museum is showcasing works from 25 sub-Saharan cultures, emphasizing the cultural context and diversity of traditional art.
lead_paragraph: While doing research for the exhibition “Africa: Sub-Saharan Diversity” at Hofstra University Museum, its curator, Karen T. Albert, wondered about the identification of one major object.

headline: Bill Richardson Aids Effort to Free Student Held in North Korea
abstract: The former New Mexico governor, who has helped negotiate the release of Americans imprisoned by Pyongyang, was assisting in the case of Otto Warmbier.
lead_paragraph: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio has asked former Gov. Bill Richardson of New Mexico, a veteran diplomat and North Korea troubleshooter, to help in the effort to free an Ohioan arrested by the North Korean authorities six weeks ago, Mr. Kasich’s spokesman said Friday.

headline: While You Were Sleeping, They Made Art
abstract: “Insomnia,” at the Pelham Art Center, displays nearly 100 works by 12 artists who find themselves awake at odd hours.
lead_paragraph: It was 3 a.m. and Alexandra Rutsch Brock couldn’t sleep. She was scrolling through her Facebook news feed when she was struck by an image of an abstract painting posted by Julia Schwartz. “I fell in love with it,” Ms. Brock said.

headline: Review: In ‘Nureyev’s Eyes,’ a Bond Between a Painter and a Dancer
abstract: The play, at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, depicts the friendship between Jamie Wyeth and Rudolf Nureyev.
lead_paragraph: An unlikely but real friendship that developed between Rudolf Nureyev, the legendary Russian dancer, and Jamie Wyeth, the American realist painter, is imaginatively dramatized by David Rush in “Nureyev’s Eyes,” his two-character play at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick.

headline: Texas Panel Calls for an End to Criminal IDs via Bite Mark
keywords: ['Forensic Science', 'Teeth and Dentistry', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'DNA (Deoxyribonucleic Acid)']
abstract: The recommendation by the influential Texas Forensic Science Commission is not legally binding, but is likely to carry great weight.
lead_paragraph: An influential scientific commission in Texas called Friday for a halt in the use of bite-mark identifications in criminal trials, concluding that the validity of the technique has not been scientifically established.

headline: ‘The Moors’ at Yale Rep: Flights of Fancy and Tales of Deceit
abstract: From the stuff of dreams, “The Moors” at Yale Rep, a new comedy, is a play of deceit and revelations.
lead_paragraph: A mastiff and a hen came to me in my sleep the other night, visitors from the play I had just seen in New Haven. I wonder if the writer Jen Silverman has had the same experience, because her inspired new play, “The Moors,” rolls out like the stuff of dreams, with telling passages heightened by surrealistic flights of fancy — including that mastiff and hen in an archetypally pleasing, you-really-ought-to-see-this parable.

headline: Stranded at the Border
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: For Syrians fleeing airstrikes in Aleppo Province and hoping to find refuge in Turkey, it remains to be seen what the recent cease-fire agreement means. Most of them are still stuck at the border.
lead_paragraph: For Syrians fleeing airstrikes in Aleppo Province and hoping to find refuge in Turkey, it remains to be seen what the recent cease-fire agreement means. Most of them are still stuck at the border.

headline: American Marathoners Can Reach the Olympics One Way: Going the Distance
abstract: While most countries determine their Olympic running teams through a committee, U.S.A. Track & Field chooses its team solely through the top three finishers of the Olympic marathon trials.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — America’s top runners will gather on Saturday for the highest-stakes long-distance event in the nation: the Olympic marathon trials.

headline: Creations That Capture Our Imaginations
abstract: While today’s investment on infrastructure seems to prioritize repair, there are inspiring works to restore our faith in the power of great projects.
lead_paragraph: While today’s investment on infrastructure seems to prioritize repair, there are inspiring works to restore our faith in the power of great projects.

headline: Many Asians Express Dismay and Frustration After Liang Verdict
keywords: ['Asian-Americans', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: In Asian enclaves of New York, residents objected to the guilty verdict of Officer Peter Liang, saying that he was a scapegoat because of his race.
lead_paragraph: As the jury read the verdict — guilty — in the manslaughter trial of a New York City police officer whose gunshot into the stairwell of a public-housing building killed an unarmed man, the officer, Peter Liang, crumpled in his seat in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, his face falling into his hands.

headline: What Happened to the Great Urban Design Projects?
abstract: American infrastructure should be about awe. Instead, it’s deferred home maintenance on a massive scale.
lead_paragraph: On any given day, painters are repainting some part of the [Golden Gate] bridge. They use 10,000 gallons of paint a year. It is crazy that people repaint a bridge all year … The Golden Gate Bridge, which is orange, is the best-known and best-loved bridge in the world. It is best known because it is bold and courageous and unusual and even strange. It is best loved because it is bold and courageous and unusual and even strange.

headline: In Little-Man Era, Four Big Men Will Test Their Skills
abstract: This N.B.A. All-Star weekend, Anthony Davis, Draymond Green and two others will compete in the Skills Challenge, a head-to-head obstacle course that tests skills traditionally belonging to guards.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of the N.B.A., big men ruled the league. Giants with names like Mikan, Russell and Chamberlain dominated the paint, leaving smaller players to scrap for tougher shots outside.

headline: John Kasich Has Kinds Words for Chris Christie, but No Talk of Endorsement
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio offered kind words for Mr. Christie on Friday, but said he had not asked him for an endorsement.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — After winning over one of Gov. Chris Christie’s leading supporters, Gov. John Kasich of Ohio offered kind words for Mr. Christie on Friday, but said he had not asked him for an endorsement.

headline: Indie Bookstores Are Back, With a Passion
abstract: The neighborhood literary hangout, once struggling, appears to be winning over young readers who enjoy the face-to-face social experience of shopping for “real books.”
lead_paragraph: The decades of trauma suffered by independent neighborhood bookstores — damage from bargain megastores, the ascension of the e-book and Amazon’s flash delivery of cut-rate reading — hardly hindered Chris Doeblin’s search for the right place to open his fourth independent bookstore in Manhattan.

headline: With a Slur for Ted Cruz, Donald Trump Further Splits Voters
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s opponents hope his latest provocation may be too much for well-mannered voters in heavily evangelical Christian South Carolina to bear.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — Donald J. Trump has defied conservative orthodoxy on policy, shunned traditional politicking and even insulted prisoners of war and the disabled, sacrosanct constituencies that other candidates would no more slur than they would accept a bag of cash with cameras rolling.

headline: Another Season Gone Awry Hangs Over Carmelo Anthony, the All-Star
abstract: The N.B.A. All-Star weekend seems to mean more to Anthony than it does to most, largely because the Knicks torpedoed their slim playoff hopes by losing 10 of their last 11 games.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Carmelo Anthony, surrounded by many of his closest friends ahead of yet another appearance in the All-Star Game, said he was doing his best to forget about his full-time job, at least for a few fun-filled days.

headline: F.E.C. Tells Sanders Campaign That Some Donors May Have Given Too Much
abstract: The Federal Election Commission has asked the Sanders campaign to re-examine contributions from more than a hundred donors who appear to have given more than the legally permissible amount.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Election Commission has asked the presidential campaign of Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont to re-examine contributions from more than a hundred donors who appear to have given more than the legally permissible amount.

headline: Republicans, Widows and Porn
abstract: The level of rancor among the remaining Republican candidates is pretty stupendous.
lead_paragraph: You can’t possibly say it’s been a bad week when Ted Cruz has a problem with a soft-core porn actress.

headline: When Conditions Become Terrifying, an Elite Contest Can Proceed
abstract: Nic Lamb of Santa Cruz won the $30,000 first prize at the Titans of Mavericks in Half Moon Bay, Calif., a surfing competition that isn’t held if the waves aren’t sufficiently threatening.
lead_paragraph: HALF MOON BAY, Calif. — The veteran big-wave surfer Ken Collins thought he was going to drown. Safely alive a few minutes later, standing on a small dock with gauze stuffed into a left ear that had a ruptured drum, he was out of the Titans of Mavericks.

headline: Takata Discarded Evidence of Airbag Ruptures as Early as 2000
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Falsification of Data', 'Engineering and Engineers']
abstract: A former Takata airbag engineer testified that the company’s airbags began rupturing in internal testing as many as 16 years ago.
lead_paragraph: JACKSONVILLE, Fla. — As the safety crisis surrounding Takata’s airbags that are prone to rupture has mushroomed, the Japanese auto supplier has insisted that the propellant in its airbags is safe.

headline: Sophie Theallet: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Ms. Theallet presents her fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Theallet presents her fall collection.

headline: Last Militants Who Occupied Oregon Wildlife Refuge Appear in Federal Court
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Federal Lands', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: The first hearing for the final holdouts at the Malheur Federal Wildlife Refuge, who walked out peacefully on Thursday after 40 days of occupation.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — The standoff at a remote federal wildlife refuge that pitted armed militants against law enforcement officials began its next chapter in a federal courtroom here on Friday, a day after the final occupiers of the refuge surrendered. But the tough talk and the posturing about the government’s powers to oppress — the occupation group’s main ideological thread — continued in the street outside the courthouse, undiminished but now in a new setting.

headline: Prisoners Exonerated, Prosecutors Exposed
abstract: More people were exonerated of crimes in 2015 than ever before, revealing a criminal justice system rife with error, incompetence and misconduct.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, 149 people convicted of crimes large and small — from capital murder to burglary — were exonerated. It is the highest yearly total since this grim form of record-keeping began, in 1989.

headline: Mrs. Clinton’s Mixed Immigration Message
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Debates (Political)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration']
abstract: Showing full support for a bill that would ensure legal support for children at the border would help to clarify the candidate’s view.
lead_paragraph: In Thursday night’s Democratic debate, Hillary Clinton defended her past statements that Central American migrant children needed to be sent home from the border to “send a message” to other families: Don’t come.

headline: Glenwood Management, Developer Cited in Corruption Cases, Settles Disability Lawsuit
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Disabilities', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Glenwood Management agreed to make alterations at three high-rise apartment complexes in Manhattan after being accused of Fair Housing Act violations.
lead_paragraph: Glenwood Management, a politically influential developer of luxury high-rise apartment buildings in Manhattan that figured in two recent public corruption trials, has agreed to settle a civil rights lawsuit that claimed three of its residential complexes violated the Fair Housing Act’s requirements for people with disabilities.

headline: Monse: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia, alumni of Oscar de la Renta, present their second collection.
lead_paragraph: Laura Kim and Fernando Garcia, alumni of Oscar de la Renta, present their second collection.

headline: Dealing With Space and Time
abstract: Friday fun with Peter Wentz.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This one by Peter Wentz was a fun solve and not terribly difficult, although I did jump around quite a bit to fill everything in.

headline: Earth, Wind & Fire’s Musical Reintegration
abstract: Maurice White should be remembered as the crossover artist who defied the music industry’s focus on white audiences only.
lead_paragraph: THIS past weekend, radio stations across the country honored Maurice White, a founder of, singer for and driving force behind the band Earth, Wind & Fire, who died on Feb. 4, by playing marathons of his music. On Sunday, Mr. White and his band will be awarded the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award, joining musicians like Frank Sinatra, Ella Fitzgerald, Johnny Cash and the Beatles.

headline: U.S. Plans to Resume Commercial Flights to Cuba This Year
abstract: An agreement to be completed next week will allow American carriers to offer 20 flights per day to Havana and dozens more to other Cuban cities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration on Tuesday plans to complete an agreement with Cuba that will allow scheduled commercial flights to resume this year between the United States and the island nation for the first time in more than 50 years.

headline: Head of Sweden’s Karolinska Institute Quits Over Transplant Scandal
abstract: Anders Hamsten said he could no longer lead the the institute after accusations of medical misconduct against a former professor there.
lead_paragraph: The top administrator of one of Europe’s leading medical universities resigned on Friday, becoming the latest casualty of a scandal involving a prominent surgeon in the field of regenerative medicine.

headline: Ah, Spring! What Could Go Wrong?
abstract: As pitchers and catchers report to Florida and Arizona, here is the column nobody wants to read: a doomsday scenario, just below the cheery surface, that could thwart each team’s high hopes.
lead_paragraph: The best part of spring training, which opens for most teams by the end of this week, is the optimism. Every team’s best-case scenario is still in play. Whatever jersey a player wears, he can slip it on with pride and channel his inner Lloyd Christmas, the naïve dreamer from “Dumb and Dumber.”

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 13, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “In the wake of unfortunately so many deaths of unarmed black men, some cops gotta hang. The sentiment in the Asian community is: It’s easier to hang an Asian, because Asians, they don’t speak up.”

headline: Experts Discuss the Success Academy Video
abstract: A group of scholars shared their thoughts on effective teaching methods after watching a video of a teacher reacting to a student’s math mistake.
lead_paragraph: A group of scholars shared their thoughts on effective teaching methods after watching a video of a teacher reacting to a student’s math mistake.

headline: Prostitute Found in Long Island Marsh in 2011 May Have Been Murdered, Pathologist Says
abstract: A new autopsy suggests that Shannan Gilbert, whose remains were found on a stretch of beach within miles of 10 other bodies, may have been strangled.
lead_paragraph: Shannan Gilbert had been missing for more than a year and a half when her remains were found in 2011 on Jones Beach Island, N.Y., in a marsh off an oceanside highway. Police officials in Suffolk County suspected at the time that Ms. Gilbert, 24, had drowned, and an autopsy by the county medical examiner left the cause of death undetermined.

headline: Syrian War Could Turn on the Battle for Aleppo
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Syrian government forces and their allies are besieging the rebel-held section of Aleppo to starve the rebels into submission.
lead_paragraph: Russia is bombing rebel-held areas in Syria at a furious pace. That is giving the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, the upper hand. Meanwhile, critics accuse the United States of dithering.

headline: Readers Respond to Video of Success Academy Teacher’s Frustration With Student
abstract: The more than 1,800 comments ranged from support for tough love to reflections on the readers’ own education and the discipline they received.
lead_paragraph: “Didn’t Rutgers University fire its basketball coach for similar behavior?”

headline: On the Verge of Victory, the Rangers Let One Slip Away
abstract: The Kings scored the tying goal with 30 seconds left in regulation, then pulled out the victory in overtime.
lead_paragraph: A clash between the Rangers and the Los Angeles Kings stirs emotions for both squads.

headline: Yankees Settle With Closer Aroldis Chapman
abstract: The Yankees avoided arbitration with the newly acquired closer Aroldis Chapman and agreed to a one-year, $11.325 million contract. Chapman made $8.05 million last season, when he was 4-4 with 33 saves in 36 chances for the Cincinnati Reds.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees avoided arbitration with the newly acquired closer Aroldis Chapman and agreed to a one-year, $11.325 million contract. Chapman made $8.05 million last season, when he was 4-4 with 33 saves in 36 chances for the Cincinnati Reds.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: “Furious 7” says farewell to Paul Walker. “Meru” follows climbers up a blade of granite. And Rebecca Hall and Jason Sudeikis spar in “Tumbledown.”
lead_paragraph: The “Fast &” franchise goes airborne — and says farewell to Paul Walker — in “Furious 7.” “Meru” follows some fearless types up a stomach-turning blade of granite in the Himalayas. And Rebecca Hall and Jason Sudeikis spar alongside a couple of cute dogs in “Tumbledown.”

headline: North Korea Cancels Investigation Into Abductions of Japanese Citizens
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Embargoes and Sanctions']
abstract: The North halted its inquiry into the fate of Japanese said to have been kidnapped decades ago, retaliating for new sanctions imposed by Tokyo.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has announced a halt to an investigation into the fate of Japanese citizens said to have been abducted by its agents decades ago, retaliating for sanctions Japan imposed this week after the North’s latest rocket launching.

headline: John Dickerson, Molded by News Legends, Hones His Skills at CBS
abstract: Mr. Dickerson, the host of “Face the Nation,” could face his biggest audience yet when he moderates the Republican debate in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the standards of Sunday morning news shows, the handoff of the anchor’s position on “Face the Nation” on CBS was really quite peaceful.

headline: Constant Tide of Migrants at Sea, and at Turkish Cemetery
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Cemeteries', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Increased patrols and cold weather have done little to dissuade refugees fleeing war, and those who drown and are unclaimed are each given numbers and buried.
lead_paragraph: IZMIR, Turkey — City workers shoveled dirt over the two coffins, one at a time, as an imam, in plaintive and meditative tones, sang prayers in Arabic.

headline: Gearing Up for the Cloud, AT&T Tells Its Workers: Adapt, or Else
keywords: ['Cloud Computing', 'Vocational Training', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Work-Life Balance', 'E-Learning', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Colleges and Universities']

lead_paragraph: DALLAS — Thirty-four years ago, Kevin Stephenson got his younger brother, Randall, a job with the telephone company.

headline: Fashion Week: Saturday Is Church Day for Alexander Wang
abstract: Day 3 highlights include Rebecca Minkoff’s shop-from-the-runway pieces, Erykah Badu styling the Pyer Moss show, and Alexander Wang at St. Bartholomew’s Church on Park Avenue.
lead_paragraph: Remember “Saturday”? That mythical day to sleep in, loll over coffee, maybe take in a movie? Try again next week. It’s New York Fashion Week, and the parade continues apace. Weekend or not, there’s a full day of shows ahead.

headline: The House D.J. of the Bernie Sanders Campaign
abstract: Mel Sandico, a.k.a. D.J. Mel, has joined the traveling Bernie Sanders campaign as the music mix master of election night.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.H. — Standing between a wall of retracted wooden bleachers and his turntables, Mel Sandico, a.k.a. Mel Cavaricci, a.k.a. D.J. Mel, looked up to survey the crowd filing into Senator Bernie Sanders’s New Hampshire victory party last Tuesday night.

headline: The New Celebrity Power Move: Keeping Secrets
abstract: In the age of social media, celebrities like Beyoncé, Taylor Swift and David Bowie realized the value of maintaining a sense of mystery.
lead_paragraph: The announcement of David Bowie’s death on Jan. 11 dealt a double blow. First was its finality. Then came the realization that barely anybody knew he had been sick, including an old ally like Brian Eno, with whom he had traded emails a week before.

headline: What Is Paul Rudnick Doing Writing Young Adult Fiction?
abstract: A sophisticated and successful 58-year-old without children or a close relationship with a niece or nephew tackles teen life.
lead_paragraph: It didn’t take much to persuade Paul Rudnick to step inside P.S. 3 the other day to watch parents waiting to take their children home. After all, the gleefully transgressive humorist, who regularly launches little satirical missiles in The New Yorker, was about to publish his second young-adult novel. Observing a school pickup in his West Village neighborhood could be construed not so much as stalking as research, and also a good way to start this interview.

headline: Peggy Siegal Through the Years
abstract: Peggy Siegal, the omnipresent New York film publicist and event planner, remains Hollywood’s secret weapon in New York.
lead_paragraph: Peggy Siegal, the omnipresent New York film publicist and event planner, remains Hollywood’s secret weapon in New York.

headline: Peggy Siegal, Best Hostess in a Supporting Role
abstract: For 30 years, especially during Oscars season, the power publicist Peggy Siegal has played matchmaker between Hollywood moguls and New York taste makers.
lead_paragraph: Hunched over her saumon marine, Peggy Siegal, the omnipresent New York film publicist and event planner, was sitting between Oliver Stone and Anne Hearst at the Manhattan restaurant La Grenouille last October, talking about the night she tried to ascend to the throne of England.

headline: China’s Exodus of Capital
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: As the economy stumbles, individuals and companies are pulling money out of China en masse, leaving the government scrambling to limit the outflows.
lead_paragraph: As the economy stumbles, individuals and companies are pulling money out of China en masse, leaving the government scrambling to limit the outflows.

headline: Chinese Start to Lose Confidence in Their Currency
abstract: An exodus of capital, in which companies and individuals are moving money outside China, is casting doubt on the nation’s economic prospects.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As the Chinese economy stumbles, wealthy families are increasingly trying to move large sums of money out of the country, worried that the value of the currency will fall and their savings will be worth less.

headline: Rescue Efforts End in Taiwanese City Struck by Quake
abstract: Search crews on Saturday pulled the last of 114 bodies from the site of a 17-story complex that collapsed in the Feb. 6 quake in the city of Tainan.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Rescue efforts ended on Saturday at the site of a 17-story apartment complex in Tainan, in southwestern Taiwan that collapsed in an earthquake a week earlier, as search crews pulled the last of 114 bodies from the rubble.

headline: 1941: Germany Reported to Send Art to U.S. for Sale
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Nazis are said to be trying to find buyers for 14 world-famous works to bolster their dollar balances in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Fourteen world-famous paintings, having a total value of more than £2,000,000 ($8,000,000), are on their way from Germany to the United States by way of Siberia and the Pacific to be sold to bolster the Nazis’ dollar balances, the British Ministry of Economic Warfare said today [Feb. 12].

abstract: Decades of research suggest the space program is not a good comparison for cancer research.
lead_paragraph: Can we agree to stop calling it the cancer moonshot?

headline: Royal Caribbean’s ‘Smartship’ Avoids a Titanic Situation
abstract: Aboard Royal Caribbean’s flashy new megaship, awe gives way to fear as Anthem of the Seas meets up with a winter storm and its hurricane-force winds.
lead_paragraph: “It’s the most technologically advanced cruise ship in the world,” the Royal Caribbean sales agent told me over the phone when I booked a trip aboard the Anthem of the Seas, the cruise line’s flashy new megaship, reported to be the third-largest cruise vessel ever built. “It’s what we call a ‘smartship.’ ”

headline: AT&T’s History of Invention and Breakups
abstract: AT&T, once known informally as Ma Bell, is a storied American brand that goes back under a succession of names to the late 19th century, after Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone.
lead_paragraph: AT&T, once known informally as Ma Bell, is a storied American brand that goes back under a succession of names to the late 19th century, after Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone.

abstract: Bad news for Twitter and Google, and Facebook plans to connect to the world.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: In Met’s ‘Manon Lescaut,’ Classic Love Story Gets Noir Twist
abstract: The tenor Roberto Alagna, called at the last minute by the Metropolitan Opera, gave an ardent, impassioned performance as des Grieux, a student unlucky in love.
lead_paragraph: With courage, determination and a healthy measure of ambition, the tenor Roberto Alagna rescued the Metropolitan Opera’s new production of Puccini’s “Manon Lescaut,” which opened on Friday night. The production was thrown into crisis last month when Jonas Kaufmann, the most sought-after tenor in opera, withdrew from the entire run because of an illness he did not specify. Hoping to line up a star tenor replacement as des Grieux, the Met’s general manager Peter Gelb turned to Mr. Alagna, who had never sung the role. With just 16 days to prepare a major Puccini part for an important new production, Mr. Alagna, who had been appearing in “Pagliacci” at the Met, agreed to take it on.

headline: Falling Asleep to Grenades: Mexicans Tell Pope How They Live
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Corruption (Institutional)']
abstract: Before Pope Francis’s arrival in Mexico, we asked readers there to tell us what he should know about their lives. We received more than 500 responses on Facebook.
lead_paragraph: A young mother living in one of Mexico’s most violent states said she had gone to sleep with the sound of grenades and guns outside her home. Another woman, in Mexico City, wrote that kidnappings had become so commonplace, they are spoken of like the weather. Many others complained about living under a corrupt government.

headline: Jason Wu Takes On Red Velvet
abstract: The designer’s fall/winter collection featured subtle plays on texture, from wool and lace to swingy beaded fringe.
lead_paragraph: The designer’s fall/winter collection featured subtle plays on texture, from wool and lace to swingy beaded fringe.

headline: John Kasich Recalls Parents’ Death in Appeal to Religious Voters
abstract: A shift in tone for the Ohio governor as he takes his campaign to the evangelical-heavy South.
lead_paragraph: ORANGEBURG, S.C. — About 15 minutes into his stump speech at a barbecue restaurant here on Friday, Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio turned to discuss “the glue that keeps us all together.”

keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Elderly', 'Cooperatives', 'Home Appliances', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Rent Control and Stabilization']

lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

lead_paragraph: The designer Becca McCharen presented athleticwear, lingerie and dresses — some of which lit up.

headline: Taliban, Using Humvees Stolen From Army, Attack Check Post
abstract: Four Afghan policemen and two soldiers were killed in the attack in Helmand Province, and eight others were wounded.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — In an attack using a tactic long feared by Afghan officials, Taliban suicide bombers riding in two stolen Afghan Army Humvees clashed with security forces on Saturday in southern Helmand Province, killing six security personnel at a checkpoint, Afghan officials said.

headline: Even in Impersonations, Donald Trump Likes What He Sees of Himself
abstract: Mr. Trump has taken note of his copycats, and made it clear he believes that imitation is the sincerest form of flattery: “They’ve got, certainly, plenty of material, that’s for sure.”
lead_paragraph: There is only one Donald J. Trump, and yet as he has continued his campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, there has been a groundswell of would-be Donald Trumps — who are imitating him for laughs.

headline: Francis Admonishes Bishops in Mexico to ‘Begin Anew’
abstract: Speaking at Mexico City’s majestic Metropolitan Cathedral, the pope spared no criticism as he painted an almost biblical picture of a church seduced by power and money.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In a stinging rebuke to Mexico‘s church hierarchy, Pope Francis on Saturday told bishops that they had lost their way in “gossip” and “intrigue,” and challenged them to “begin anew” and tend to the church’s worshipers.

headline: After Stormy Royal Caribbean Cruise, Seeking Answers
abstract: The Coast Guard is examining the cruise ship that sailed into 120 m.p.h. winds, and a Florida senator has said that there should also be an investigation.
lead_paragraph: Royal Caribbean’s Anthem of the Seas vessel returned earlier than scheduled to its port of origin, Cape Liberty, N.J., on Wednesday evening after facing 120 m.p.h. winds on Sunday off Cape Hatteras, N.C. The cruise ship departed last Saturday and was on its way to a port call in Port Canaveral, Fla., as part of a seven-day trip to the Bahamas when it ran into the storm.

headline: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Saturday, Feb. 13
abstract: Scenes from Chromat, Jason Wu’s beauty look, inside the Monse studio and more.
lead_paragraph: 1. The Chromat show was lit — in the truest sense, with certain garments incorporating wirelessly triggered lights. “It’s all body-based,” said the designer Becca McCharen of her fall/winter 2016 collection. “We’re definitely interested in presenting the body in new juxtapositions.” For sportswear, dresses and underpinnings, she took inspiration from conceptual artists like Dan Flavin and Robert Irwin. See more scenes from Friday’s shows.

keywords: ['Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Workplace Hazards and Violations', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Workplace Environment']
abstract: A waitress at Hooters who was fired for swearing at the winner of a contest she believed to be rigged won her case before the National Labor Relations Board.
lead_paragraph: Little did the managers of a Hooters restaurant realize that a bikini contest they sponsored in 2013 would end up testing the limits of labor law.

headline: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
abstract: Puns and Anagrams with Mel Taub.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Solving a Puns and Anagrams puzzle feels, to me at least, kind of like cheating on a diet after a full week of eating only healthy food. It’s not that the daily crosswords aren’t fun, because they are. But PandAs feel more like the doughnuts of the puzzle world. They’re light, they’re entertaining and they sometimes have a sugary glaze and sprinkles on top. [Just … no. — Ed.]

headline: Rihanna on Her New See-Through, Stiletto-Heeled Puma Collection: ‘I Tried to Push the Envelope a Little Bit’
abstract: Rihanna answers questions about her first full fashion collection.
lead_paragraph: “I’m on cloud nine,” said Rihanna, the pop star turned brand ambassador and women’s creative director of Puma, after her first fashion show for the label. An hour earlier, her first full collection, a street-inspired, Japanophile departure from Puma’s usual sport-ready performance wear, had come down an L.E.D. runway to a crowd that included Naomi Campbell, Chris Rock, Travis Scott, Foxy Brown and Young Thug.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: A Tired View Of Newton And His Role

headline: Small Gifts to Bernie Sanders Challenge Hillary Clinton Fund-Raising Model
abstract: The pursuit of campaign financing highlights another stark contrast between the two major Democratic candidates.
lead_paragraph: In the back of a Concord, N.H., school gymnasium, as Bernie Sanders gave a triumphant speech after winning the New Hampshire Democratic primary, Kenneth Pennington stood staring at his smartphone, watching the numbers climb. Mr. Pennington, 24, the campaign’s digital director, saw thousands of people cramming onto the Sanders website at once, frantically trying to donate to his campaign. In one minute alone, 2,689 people had donated an average of $34.

headline: Rihanna Brings Smoke, Mirrors and Transparent Tops to Wall Street For Her First Puma Collection
abstract: In her first full collection for Puma she sent out looks that reflected the shapes and styles she likes to wear herself.
lead_paragraph: Trees, stark and faux in black and white, grew out of the floor and into a ceiling tiled with mirrors. At 23 Wall Street, the former House of Morgan had been converted into a forest from a digital-age fever dream — the Black Forest, one might almost say, since the stage had been set by Puma, the German sportswear behemoth, for the showing of its new collection designed by the pop idol Rihanna.

headline: Dividends, Wall Street’s Battered Status Symbol
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Personal Finances', 'Corporations', 'United States Economy', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Companies are cutting their once sacrosanct dividends, leaving investors to determine whether they’re just being prudent or may be in serious trouble.
lead_paragraph: Coca-Cola pays steady dividends. It has done so since 1920. In fact, it has increased dividends in each of the last 50 years.

headline: Mark Dunkerley: Where You Can See Airplanes and the Aloha Spirit

headline: Henry Kissinger: Sage or Pariah?
abstract: After Thursday's Hillary Clinton-Bernie Sanders debate, the former diplomat returns to the spotlight.

headline: A Monthly Gift That Keeps on Not Giving
abstract: Subscribers to Campbox, a subscription service for monthly boxes of camping gear, says it either didn’t deliver or didn’t deliver much.
lead_paragraph: The Haggler does not go camping, nor does he hike. He should probably claim that he is too busy protecting consumers to engage in an activity as frivolous as tromping through the woods and gaping at trees. But it is simpler than that. He doesn’t like the woods. He figures that his ancestors spent a lot of time in the woods wishing that they lived somewhere else. Like a city.

headline: AT&T’s Strategy Is One Part Innovation, One Part Inspiration
abstract: The company is using plans for super-high-speed 5G technology and an executive’s poignant life story as a way to assuage worries about its future.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — AT&T is pulling out the stops to persuade people about futuristic plans for its network — and itself. Sometimes that means pushing new technology, and sometimes it means that executives show a little vulnerability, something rare in corporate America.

headline: Catholic Leaders Say Zika Doesn’t Change Ban on Contraception
keywords: ['Zika Virus', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'ABORTION', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: After a period of saying little, bishops in Latin America are beginning to speak up and reassert the church’s opposition to birth control and abortion.
lead_paragraph: As the Zika virus spreads in Latin America, Catholic leaders are warning women against using contraceptives or having abortions, even as health officials in some countries are advising women not to get pregnant because of the risk of birth defects.

headline: The Commute of the Future? Ford Is Working on It
keywords: ['Commuting', 'Mobile Applications', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Research', 'Transit Systems', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs']
abstract: The design firm Ideo, which helped design the computer mouse, has been enlisted by Ford to shadow commuters and see how they get where they’re going: by car, bus, foot or Uber.
lead_paragraph: On a brisk October day in Chicago, a few employees from the design firm Ideo left their office and headed to Knife & Tine, a restaurant about four miles away. The goal, besides lunch, was to complete the journey within 45 minutes, on a budget of just $10 for the whole group, all while carrying bulky shopping bags.

lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — With Florida’s March 15 primary looming, Donald J. Trump drew another of his massive crowds Friday night in Tampa, where he boasted of his résumé as a developer and job creator in Florida.

headline: Scenes From Last Night’s Dazed x Calvin Klein Party
abstract: At the event celebrating the Dazed 100, many guests chose not to check their voluptuous furs.
lead_paragraph: Last night, as polar gusts persisted outside, the Calvin Klein and Dazed party — a celebration for the magazine’s 100 pop culture disruptors — raged in Bushwick. Inside, projectors bathed two rooms in gray (one wall showed a triptych of black and white video footage featuring the Dazed 100 recipients; on another, their names flashed at a spastic clip).

headline: War, Disease and Scandals Test Soccer Chief in Sierra Leone
abstract: Isha Johansen, the president of Sierra Leone’s soccer association, is one of just a handful of women in the world to have held such a post.
lead_paragraph: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone — For the last two and a half years, Isha Johansen has been throwing punches, both real and metaphorical, as the president of Sierra Leone’s soccer association, one of just a handful of women in the world to have ever held such a post.

headline: What to Look For in the Republican Debate
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Debates (Political)', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The departure of Gov. Chris Christie, whose debate performance one week ago blunted the momentum of Senator Marco Rubio, creates a different dynamic.
lead_paragraph: Join us for our coverage of the Republican debate.

headline: Suno: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, the finalists in the 2012 Vogue/CFDA fund, present their fall designs.
lead_paragraph: Max Osterweis and Erin Beatty, the finalists in the 2012 Vogue/CFDA fund, present their fall designs.

headline: Facing Allies’ Doubt, John Kerry Voices Confidence in Syria Cease-Fire
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Kerry, the secretary of state, promised on Saturday to help close off the routes migrants are taking to Europe and warned Russia that its military efforts in Syria to support President Bashar al-Assad would ultimately fail.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — Secretary of State John Kerry, facing both anger and skepticism from European allies about the willingness of the United States to intervene more deeply in the Syrian civil war, promised on Saturday to help close off the routes migrants were taking to Europe and warned Russia that its military effort to prop up President Bashar al-Assad of Syria would ultimately fail.

headline: Jets Will No Longer Get a Free Ride on Carbon Emissions
abstract: A U.N. agency has finally proposed the first binding limits on aircraft emissions.
lead_paragraph: It has been almost 50 years since the federal government began setting standards for automobile emissions. It is also about a half-century since the introduction of wide-body jets set off a runaway expansion of the aviation industry. About 3.8 billion people are expected to fly this year, 50 times as many as 50 years ago — making planes the fastest-growing source of carbon dioxide emissions, although they have faced none of the limits set on cars or trucks. That is, until last week, when the International Civil Aviation Organization, a United Nations agency, finally proposed the first binding limits on aircraft emissions.

headline: The Orphaned ’90s
keywords: ['Presidents and Presidency (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Nineteen Hundred Nineties']
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s campaign is struggling with liberals who don’t have any nostalgia for her husband’s era.
lead_paragraph: IN one theory of Hillary Clinton’s candidacy, before political reality intruded, she was going to have the best of two worlds.

headline: How We View Obesity
abstract: “We are more than the size clothing we wear,” writes one reader in this debate about whether “fat is bad.”
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss Americans’ obsession with weight and prejudices against “fat” people.

headline: Narcissism Is Increasing. So You’re Not So Special.
abstract: In the Greek myth, Narcissus falls in love with his reflection. Sure sounds like Instagram.
lead_paragraph: MY teenage son recently informed me that there is an Internet quiz to test oneself for narcissism. His friend had just taken it. “How did it turn out?” I asked. “He says he did great!” my son responded. “He got the maximum score!”

headline: When Hillary Clinton Killed Feminism
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights", 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: And she had help, as prominent feminists hypocritically joined the defense of Bill as he lied about his affair with an intern.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE Clinton campaign is shellshocked over the wholesale rejection of Hillary by young women, younger versions of herself who do not relate to her.

headline: Are You a Toxic Waste Disposal Site?
keywords: ['Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Lead', 'Chemicals', 'Children and Childhood', 'Poisoning and Poisons', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Inadequately regulated industrial companies surround us with chemicals that our bodies absorb.
lead_paragraph: EVEN if you’re not in Flint, Mich., there are toxic chemicals in your home. For that matter, in you.

headline: Fixing Our Broken Water Systems
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Infrastructure (Public Works)', 'Water Pollution', 'Lead', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Water']
abstract: The country has invested far too little in its public works, as governments at all levels have become obsessed with cutting spending.
lead_paragraph: Underneath America’s streets lies a network of pipes that is supposed to bring clean water into homes, schools and businesses. But the news of lead poisoning in Flint, Mich., and the emergence of similar problems in Sebring, Ohio, and other cities have revealed a shocking truth: Some of these systems are so old and poorly maintained that they have become a major hazard to human health.

headline: Time to Take North Korea Seriously
abstract: China should be using its leverage to steer North Korea toward a less hostile course.
lead_paragraph: Since the first of the year, North Korea has conducted another nuclear weapons test and launched a satellite on a rocket. Both acts further advance North Korea’s quest to acquire the ability to fire a nuclear-armed missile against another country, while serving as a reminder of the world’s lamentable failure to shut the program down.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Look
abstract: Shown here is the look that defined 2015: ankle boots, a long stretch of leg, a flowerlike blossom top and a fur pompom at the peak of knitted hats.
lead_paragraph: There’s an exhilaration to the opening of an international fashion season. The designer with the highest antennae will create, through clothes, the mirror image of our time. A look that defines a generation usually takes seven years to become visible. The rare exception: Christian Dior’s 1947 New Look, which arrived like a thunderclap. Shown here is the look that defined 2015: ankle boots, a long stretch of leg, a flowerlike blossom top and a fur pompom at the peak of knitted hats. Outside of this uniform, there were straws in the wind, above. Will shaping return to fashion through a cinched waist, a sculpted coat, a flared skirt? Or will it be an inflated silhouette, where the air between the cloth and the wearer creates the silhouette?

headline: Death, the Prosperity Gospel and Me
abstract: Some Christians believe God rewards the faithful. So why did I get Stage 4 cancer?
lead_paragraph: Durham, N.C. — ON a Thursday morning a few months ago, I got a call from my doctor’s assistant telling me that I have Stage 4 cancer. The stomach cramps I was suffering from were not caused by a faulty gallbladder, but by a massive tumor.

headline: Can Health Care Providers Afford to Be Ready for Disaster?
keywords: ['Disasters and Emergencies', 'Medicine and Health', 'Nursing Homes', 'Hospitals', 'Hurricane Katrina (2005)', 'Hurricane Sandy (2012)']
abstract: Many critical medical facilities are minimally prepared for disasters.
lead_paragraph: MORE than 200 people died in hospitals and nursing homes in Louisiana after Hurricane Katrina in 2005, leading to widespread agreement that health care preparedness in the United States needed dramatic improvement. One hospital, Memorial Medical Center, was so undone that two desperate doctors later said that they hastened the deaths of patients who had waited days in the heat for rescue.

headline: Amid Tension, Met and James Levine Mull Last Bow
abstract: How and when Mr. Levine will step down as music director after four decades is the question of the moment at the Metropolitan Opera.
lead_paragraph: The question of when and how to say farewell to a leader is one that bedevils all kinds of institutions, from Viacom, where the aging chairman Sumner M. Redstone recently stepped down under pressure, to the Denver Broncos, who will soon have to decide whether to ease out their quarterback, Peyton Manning, if he does not retire willingly.

headline: Not Their Mother’s Candidate
abstract: The­ generational battle over who women should vote for goes back to the right to vote.
lead_paragraph: If, as we’ve all now heard, “there’s a special place in hell for women who don’t help each other,” then a room on the Upper East Side of Manhattan has long been a piece of feminist heaven. It’s the room that Gloria Steinem provided for years in her apartment as a residence for young women she mentored and encouraged and learned from.

headline: Nikki Silva
abstract: A radio and podcast producer creator on living on a commune and the joys of gift wrapping.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Silva is one half of the Peabody Award-winning Kitchen Sisters, creators of documentary-style programming for public radio and for podcasts.

headline: How New York Made Pre-K a Success
abstract: The city smartly targeted all 4-year-olds, not just those from poor families.
lead_paragraph: BORSCHT isn’t found on most prekindergarten menus, but it’s what the cooks were dishing up for the 35 children at Ira’s Daycare in Briarwood, Queens, on a recent school day. Many families in this neighborhood are Russian émigrés for whom borscht is a staple, but children from half a dozen countries, including a contingent from Bangladesh, are also enrolled here.

headline: The Love Story Primary
abstract: Yes, political romances are our business.
lead_paragraph: MY mom, Fran, is wise and warm and helpful in many ways, but she’s never been great at dispensing pithy nuggets of life wisdom. One year, for a Mother’s Day feature, a magazine editor asked me to tell her the best piece of advice my mother ever gave me. All I could come up with was, “Don’t pick it.”

headline: At U.S. Olympic Trials, Two Marathoners Use Teamwork to Become Teammates
abstract: Amy Cragg won the women’s race in sweltering Los Angeles with a boost from her training partner, Shalane Flanagan, who finished third. Galen Rupp, a first-time marathoner, won the men’s race.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — At the United States Olympic marathon trials on Saturday, the runners confirmed that women are far stronger when they stay in formation.

headline: Britain Aims to Strengthen North’s Cities
abstract: Under a “Northern Powerhouse” plan, the government has pledged to build more roads and railways, invest in technology and research hubs, and even appeal to China’s development bank for funds.
lead_paragraph: LIVERPOOL, England — London churns out so much wealth that its annual economic output is equal to Saudi Arabia’s. No other city in Britain comes close.

abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Hillary Clinton Emails Released by State Department
abstract: Three emails released by the State Department from Hillary Clinton’s private account were now considered “secret,” the government’s second-highest classification.
lead_paragraph: Three emails released by the State Department from Hillary Clinton’s private account were now considered “secret,” the government’s second-highest classification.

headline: More Hillary Clinton Emails Released, Including 3 Now ‘Secret’
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: In the State Department’s latest batch of 551 emails from the personal server of Hillary Clinton, 84 contained information that has now been deemed classified.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The State Department released 551 more emails from the personal server of Hillary Clinton on Saturday, including 84 with some or all of the messages blocked out because they contained information that has now been deemed classified. Three of those are classified “secret.”

headline: Mets’ Jenrry Mejia Is Said to Deny Doping Claims
abstract: Héctor Gómez, who described himself on Twitter as the sports editor at a Dominican radio station, posted a few quotations he attributed to Mejia, the Mets pitcher suspended for life.
lead_paragraph: Each time Mets pitcher Jenrry Mejia has tested positive for performance-enhancing drugs, he has declined to discuss the results or has maintained his innocence. Even after his third failed test in less than a year, which was announced Friday and resulted in a lifetime ban from Major League Baseball, Mejia appears to be sticking to the message that he has not used P.E.D.s.

headline: Bernie Sanders Tells Volunteers in Reno to Expect Victory in Nevada
abstract: Bernie Sanders is hoping a win in Nevada will convince voters nationwide that he can garner support from a more diverse electorate than in Iowa and New Hampshire.
lead_paragraph: RENO, Nev. — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont told hundreds of volunteers gathered here on Saturday that his strong showings in Iowa and New Hampshire were not flukes.

headline: Man Arrested in Fatal Stabbing of Staten Island Woman and Her 2 Daughters
abstract: The man, Michael Sykes, was arrested without incident in a public-housing project in Woodside, Queens on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The suspect wanted in the stabbing at a Staten Island motel that left a homeless woman and two of her daughters dead was arrested and charged with murder on Saturday, the police said.

headline: Antonin Scalia, Justice on the Supreme Court, Dies at 79
abstract: Justice Scalia, whose legal theories, vivid writing and outsize personality made him a conservative leader, was found dead on Saturday in Texas.
lead_paragraph: Justice Antonin Scalia, whose transformative legal theories, vivid writing and outsize personality made him a leader of a conservative intellectual renaissance in his three decades on the Supreme Court, was found dead on Saturday at a resort in West Texas. He was 79.

headline: New Study Finds Persistent Peril from Urban Coal Soot in China and Indoor Smoke in India
keywords: ['Air Pollution', 'Coal', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: In Chinese cities and India’s rural households, millions remain at risk from power plant pollution and smoky cooking and heating fires.
lead_paragraph: The latest report on the “global burden of disease” finds air pollution caused the premature deaths of 5.5 million people in 2013, with China just ahead of India in deaths and the two countries together accounting for more than half the global total. The findings were released Friday by scientists at the University of British Columbia and discussed today at the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, in Washington.

headline: Caught Between Costly Alternatives, Ferguson Residents Worry About Its Fate
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Local Government', 'Budgets and Budgeting', 'Bankruptcies']
abstract: Ferguson, Mo., which challenged parts of a pact to overhaul its police and court system, faces a lengthy, costly legal battle now that the Department of Justice has filed a civil rights suit against the municipality.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — When the City Council took the defiant gamble last week of challenging parts of an agreement it had negotiated with the federal government to overhaul its Police Department and courts, it argued that the costs of the deal would drive the city into bankruptcy.

headline: The Death of Justice Scalia: Reactions and Analysis
abstract: Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia died on Saturday at a resort in Texas. His death quickly set off debate over a new nomination, with prominent Republicans calling for the next president to make a nomination. President Obama said he would nominate a new justice despite objections.

headline: All You Need
abstract: All we need, from MaryLou Guizzo.
lead_paragraph: “Nothing you can know that isn’t knownNothing you can see that isn’t shownNowhere you can be that isn’t where you’re meant to beIt’s easy …” — The Beatles, “All You Need Is Love”

headline: A Tour of Rwanda, From Jungle to City
abstract: An eight-day tour, departing from Kigali, features a trek into the jungle to view mountain gorillas.
lead_paragraph: Rwanda, Jungle to City Gondwana Ecotours, founded by Jared Sternberg in 2013 when he was a law student at Tulane, has added Rwanda to its list of destinations. A highlight of the eight-day tour, departing from Kigali, is a trek into the jungle to view mountain gorillas, who live in a tropical rain forest in the Virunga Mountains. Guests also will have the chance to track chimpanzee and golden monkeys with a conservationist.

headline: Russian Orthodox Church Blocks Funeral for Last of Romanov Remains
abstract: Despite mountains of evidence, the church says it doesn’t believe the remains are those of the last czar and his family.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Ever since the remains of the last czar, Nicholas II, and most of his family were exhumed 25 years ago from a dirt road in the Urals, investigators, historians and surviving members of the Romanov dynasty have anticipated the day when all the murdered royals would be laid to rest.

headline: Erykah Badu’s Styling Debut
abstract: The R&B singer worked closely with the designer Kerby Jean-Raymond on his label Pyer Moss’s fall/winter show, which was presented this afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The R&B singer worked closely with the designer Kerby Jean-Raymond on his label Pyer Moss’s fall/winter show, which was presented this afternoon.

headline: At Pyer Moss, Erykah Badu Makes Her Styling Debut
abstract: The R&B singer worked closely with the label’s designer, Kerby Jean-Raymond, on the show he presented at Milk Studios this afternoon.
lead_paragraph: For over a year, the men’s wear designer Kerby Jean-Raymond, of Pyer Moss, had his sights set on collaborating with the R&B singer Erykah Badu. She and Jean-Raymond eventually met through a mutual friend and embarked on a partnership that would mark a first for Badu: her styling debut. And this morning, when Badu arrived at his studio — wearing platform Teva sandals, an oversize denim tunic and a black chauffeur hat embellished with handmade pins reading “Acid” and “LSD” — she greeted Jean-Raymond like an old friend.

headline: Jordan Struggles Under a Wave of Syrian Refugees
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Jordan’s leaders face appeals from an overwhelmed public and from European nations urging them to stop the Syrians from heading to the West.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — King Abdullah II made his people an extraordinary promise last week: For every job the government offered Syrian refugees, it would create five jobs for Jordanians.

lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of words will flow in the coming days on the significance of the life and death of Supreme Court Justice Antonin Scalia at a Texas resort. Adam Liptak leads Times coverage here.

keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Treason and Sedition', 'Terrorism', 'Colleges and Universities']

lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The police have arrested the president of a student union here on a complaint of sedition, a news agency reported, the latest controversy to hit one of the country’s highly politicized universities.

abstract: Justice Antonin Scalia was a leader of the Supreme Court’s conservative wing and the longest serving member of the current court.

lead_paragraph: Punk-rock, mini bucket bags with grommets popped up at Alexander Wang — the ultimate cool girl accessory.

headline: At Alexander Wang, Blunt Bangs and Minimal Makeup
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: For the fall/winter 2016 show, models were meant to look “like they’ve been up all night partying."
lead_paragraph: As a continuation of last season’s theme, the beauty looks at Alexander Wang’s fall/winter 2016 show honed in on model’s individuality. For makeup, Diane Kendal gave each one a minimal look inspired by youth culture’s adoption of high fashion. Youthful, but worn-in nonetheless — “like they’ve been up all night partying,” she said. (A similar theme to last season’s Marc Jacobs look, too.) The main focus was on eyes: Kendal filled lids in with chocolatey brown shadow (NARS Dark Angel Velvet Shadow Stick) up to the contour. She then diffused the shadow around the entire eye area with moisturizer, using just her fingers, and finished them off with a touch of lip balm for a subtle sheen.

headline: Battle Begins Over Naming Next Justice
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday immediately set off a partisan battle over a vacancy that could reshape the Supreme Court for years to come, as Senate Republicans called on President Obama to let his successor fill the seat.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday set off an immediate partisan battle over a vacancy that could reshape the Supreme Court for years to come, as President Obama vowed to nominate a successor and Senate Republicans called on him to let the next president fill the seat.

headline: Kristaps Porzingis Quick to Make a Believer of Team World’s Coach
abstract: Ettore Messina, who had limited exposure to the Knicks rookie Kristaps Porzingis, got a front-row seat to witness his talent during Friday’s Rising Stars Challenge.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Ettore Messina, an assistant coach with the San Antonio Spurs, was only vaguely familiar with Kristaps Porzingis until this weekend. Messina, of course, had coached against Porzingis in two games this season, both wins for the Spurs. But Friday was their first meaty opportunity to get to know each other.

headline: Donald Trump Will Be G.O.P. Nominee, Students’ Mock Convention Says
abstract: Washington and Lee University’s mock convention has correctly predicted the nominee of the party not in the White House in 19 of 25 attempts.
lead_paragraph: LEXINGTON, Va. — A gymnasium full of college students here on Saturday did what a former Republican Party chairman, a former vice president and a former speaker of the House who addressed their mock convention would not: predict the Republican nominee for president.

headline: Adam Silver Aims to Reduce Excessive Fouling
abstract: The strategy of fouling poor free-throw shooters to slow offenses has prolonged games and exasperated fans. Commissioner Silver said that there appears to be a growing sense that the fouling ought to be curbed.
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Commissioner Adam Silver said Saturday that his personal views on the so-called Hack-a-Shaq tactic used by N.B.A. coaches had evolved.

abstract: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida blasted Donald J. Trump for insulting the Bush family and ridiculed the idea that Mr. Trump could be commander in chief.
lead_paragraph: Former Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida blasted Donald J. Trump for insulting the Bush family and ridiculed the idea that Mr. Trump could be commander in chief during a contentious and sometimes nasty Republican presidential debate in Greenville, S.C., on Saturday, a week before a crucial primary in the state.

headline: The Legendary Photographer Who Inspired a Fall Collection
abstract: Guests at Rodebjer’s runway show tonight will receive a zine created in homage to Mary Ellen Mark.
lead_paragraph: The designer Carin Rodebjer has always preferred facts to fiction. “I love people and their stories, and I always find the most interesting stories in real life. Since I was a kid, I was reading biographies and watching documentaries,” she says. “I tend to navigate towards other artists who work with reality in some way.”

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia’s Supreme Court Legacy
abstract: Justice Scalia left a huge imprint on this court. Now the Senate must allow President Obama to fill that seat.
lead_paragraph: Justice Antonin Scalia, who died on Saturday at the age of 79, served on the Supreme Court for 30 years and made as big a mark on the court and on American law and politics as some of the chief justices under whom he served. It took about 10 minutes after the announcement of his death for the right wing to start screaming that the Senate should not confirm a replacement while President Obama is in office.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, February 14, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It has been 80 years since an election-year vacancy has been filled and the politics of the court has changed drastically since those days.”

headline: Obama to Nominate Scalia Replacement Over Republicans’ Objections
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: With Democrats and the independents who caucus with them holding 46 seats in the Senate, President Obama faces a challenge in getting to the simple majority needed to confirm a nominee.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama said Saturday that he planned to submit a nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court, rebuffing Republicans who have called for him to leave the choice to the next president.

lead_paragraph: A woman and a boy were critically injured in a fire in an apartment at a public-housing project in Harlem, according to the Fire Department.
