abstract: Hillary Clinton called Senator Mitch McConnell’s statement that the next president, not President Obama, should appoint a successor to Justice Scalia “disappointing” and “totally out of step with our history and our constitutional principle.”
lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton called Senator Mitch McConnell’s statement that the next president, not President Obama, should appoint a successor to Justice Scalia “disappointing” and “totally out of step with our history and our constitutional principle.”

headline: Bernie Sanders Relies on Supporters for Ad About Unity
abstract: A spot submitted by supporters, and chosen in an effort overseen by Mr. Sanders’s wife, features portraits of a diverse array of people and a call to bring America together.
lead_paragraph: After letting Simon and Garfunkel speak for him in one ad, Senator Bernie Sanders has turned over his latest to his supporters, several of whom created a 60-second spot titled “Together.”

headline: Antonin Scalia, Conservative Legal Giant
abstract: For his intellect and influence, he will be remembered as the most important Supreme Court justice of his era.
lead_paragraph: Antonin Scalia, dead unexpectedly this weekend at 79, was not the most politically powerful justice during his three decades on the Supreme Court. That distinction belonged to the court’s two swing votes, Sandra Day O’Connor and then Anthony M. Kennedy, respectively the philosopher queen and king of our fraying republican order.

headline: Hillary Clinton, Shifting Line of Attack, Paints Bernie Sanders as a One-Issue Candidate
abstract: Mrs. Clinton said Senator Sanders had focused on Wall Street instead of issues that would do more to improve the lives of Americans.
lead_paragraph: HENDERSON, Nev. — Hillary Clinton set out on Saturday to blunt one of Bernie Sanders’s most potent arguments against her, attacking the Vermont senator as a one-note rival whose relentless focus on Wall Street excess and exorbitant political spending would do little to improve the lives of Americans.

headline: Texas Ranch Where Scalia Died Is Rugged Oasis for the Famous
abstract: The Cibolo Creek Ranch, a 30-000-acre spread north of the Mexico border in the Chinati Mountains, is a confidential vacation spot for public figures.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The closest community to the West Texas resort where Justice Antonin Scalia died is barely even a place anymore: It is a virtual ghost town where perhaps only a dozen people still live. And when a silver hearse drove across the rocks outside the Cibolo Creek Ranch on Saturday, it was from a funeral home at least an hour away.

headline: Scalia’s Supreme Court Seat and the Next Frontier in Political Hardball
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Constitution (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The fight over his seat is likely to be long, and to pose tough questions about the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: It takes no feat of imagination to guess how the debate about replacing Justice Antonin Scalia, who died unexpectedly on Saturday, will take shape. Within a couple of hours of news of his death, Mitch McConnell, the Senate majority leader, joined by fellow Republicans like Ted Cruz, said that Justice Scalia’s seat on the United States Supreme Court should remain vacant until after the November presidential election.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Altuzarra’s who is credited for reinventing the women’s coat in 2012, presents his fall looks.

headline: How Long Does It Take to Confirm a Supreme Court Nominee?
abstract: Republicans and Democrats are arguing over whether President Obama, whose term expires in 342 days, should try to fill Justice Antonin Scalia’s seat.
lead_paragraph: Republicans and Democrats are arguing over whether President Obama, whose term expires in 342 days, should try to fill Justice Antonin Scalia’s seat.

headline: Republican Candidates Unite Against Obama on Replacing Scalia
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The party’s candidates asserted Saturday that President Obama should not nominate a successor as they sought to court a conservative base that has driven the party’s discourse in the current campaign.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday thrust the Supreme Court to the center of the already-volatile Republican presidential race, with the party’s candidates asserting that President Obama should not nominate a successor as they sought to court conservatives who have driven the party’s discourse in the current campaign.

headline: G.O.P. Candidates Call for ‘Delay’ in a Supreme Court Appointment
abstract: It came as no surprise that the Republican presidential candidates called for President Obama to hold off on nominating a replacement for Antonin Scalia.
lead_paragraph: It came as no real surprise that all six Republican presidential candidates called for President Barack Obama to hold off on nominating a Supreme Court justice to replace Antonin Scalia, who died Saturday, portraying the appointment as a crucial opportunity to determine the direction of a raft of ideologically charged cases currently being considered by the high court.

lead_paragraph: Sex, drugs and — what else? — rock ’n’ roll: Martin Scorsese and Mick Jagger mine the 1970s New York music scene in “Vinyl.” A “Bachelor” couple dare to tie the knot. And Lily Tomlin shines as a lesbian poet with familial duties in “Grandma.”

headline: Free Spirit
abstract: This season, you can channel a prairie girl, a sister wife, a cyberpunk, a kooky intellectual. That freedom is exciting, and a form of power.
lead_paragraph: Fashion seems a little like the Wild West right now. Perhaps in part thanks to ever-multiplying shows and the numerous collections designers must create to keep up with demand, there’s a sort of free and pioneering spirit blowing through the season. You can channel a prairie girl, a sister wife, a cyberpunk, a kooky intellectual. You can dress mannish, sexy or demure. Basically, if you wanted, you could wake up and put on a flowing floral dress or a futuristic short skirt or a tailored suit — in a solid, a floral, stripes, plaid or some clashing combo thereof — and in many places, at many kinds of jobs, head out to work. That freedom is exciting, and a form of power.

headline: Republican Debate Takeaways: Saturday Night Fighting
abstract: The candidates debated as if it were one last chance to break through and take down their opponents — and for a few of them, it probably was.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The Republican candidates debated on Saturday night as if it were one last chance to break through and take down their opponents — and for a few of them, it probably was.

headline: Who Won the Debate? Florida Candidates Bask in Sunny Reviews
abstract: Critics and commentators thought Jeb Bush delivered a strong performance and Senator Marco Rubio bounced back from his flop at last week’s debate.
lead_paragraph: The Republican primary debate on Saturday night was perhaps the most contentious face-off of the 2016 campaign, as the candidates shouted at, accused and insulted each other, while enduring frequent booing from the audience. Critics and commentators thought the night was won by Jeb Bush, a former governor of Florida, who delivered a strong performance just a week before the South Carolina primary, and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, who bounced back from his flop at last week’s debate. As for the losers, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas was seen as flat at times under the heat of ad hominem attacks, while Donald J. Trump’s tirades appeared to be wearing thin. Here is a sampling of comments from the chattering class.

lead_paragraph: Envy the brunch crowd, Fashion Week faithful. For them is the 11 a.m. application of bacon, eggs over easy, café au lait. For you, a bracing, near-Arctic day of traversing Manhattan for shows. If there’s one thing Fashion Week lacks, it’s the proverbial day of rest.

lead_paragraph: “Eat your soup. It’s good food,” my paternal grandmother, Bubbe Mary, would say.

headline: A Blended Family Survival Guide
abstract: Blend is how you make smoothies. Put children in a family ‘blender’ and something quite different happens.
lead_paragraph: Almost 20 years ago, when our five kids were all in elementary school, Rique and I blended our families. That’s the word the parenting industry uses. “Blend.” Talk about euphemism. There is no stress in the word “blend.” It’s one utterly pleasant syllable.

headline: 1891: General William Sherman Dies
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archive: General William Sherman dies in 1891.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — General Sherman died at ten minutes to two o’clock this afternoon [Feb. 14]. Death got the upper hand of the old warrior early in the morning, and at half-past five the change was so marked that messengers were hastily sent for Drs. Janeway and Green.

headline: Afghanistan Had Record Civilian Casualties in 2015, U.N. Says
abstract: The United Nations documented 3,545 civilians killed, a reminder of the cost of the conflict at a time when the prospect of peace seems as distant as ever.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban suicide attacks and a fierce battle for the northern city of Kunduz made 2015 the worst year for Afghan civilian casualties since the United Nations began tracking the data, officials said on Sunday, in a sobering reminder of the cost of the conflict at a time when the prospect of peace seems as distant as ever.

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia and the ‘Dead’ Constitution
abstract: The “rock star” of the court showed little interest in compromise but still changed the way the Constitution and laws are interpreted.
lead_paragraph: WHETHER or not you agreed with the man, there is no question that Justice Antonin Scalia changed the United States Supreme Court, the way that the Constitution and laws are interpreted and the image of a Supreme Court justice far more than President Ronald Reagan could ever have foreseen when appointing him.

headline: 1941: U.S. Tells Citizens to Leave Far East
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archive: The U.S. advises Americans to leave Asia in 1941.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Apprehension was aroused in a large section of the American community here today [Feb. 13] when Consul General Frank P. Lockhart issued a circular to all Americans here reiterating the advice of the State Department that American women, children and men whose presence here is not essential withdraw to the United States in the interest both of their own safety and of national security.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Black Velvet
abstract: The luxe fabric popped up on the fall runways at Adam Selman, Jason Wu and Monse.
lead_paragraph: Silky, black velvet made several appearances on the runways in the first few days of New York Fashion Week. First, Adam Selman — a designer known for his use of color and print — showed a head-to-toe black velvet jumpsuit, in a relatively dark collection. Jason Wu interpreted the fabric into a puffer sweater with fur trim and a ladylike slit pencil skirt. And a few hours later, Fernando Garcia and Laura Kim of Monse showed their sophomore collection. It was filled with interesting evening wear — including a floor-length, drapey black velvet number that showed off hints of skin.

headline: Syrian Officer Gave a View of War. ISIS Came, and Silence Followed.
abstract: Abu al-Majd, who fought with government forces, also struck up a relationship with Times correspondents. Then he was sent to Palmyra, and disappeared.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Ours was an unusual, sometimes operatic, correspondence that unfolded over more than a year. Abu al-Majd, a Syrian police officer who was being deployed more and more often like a soldier, texted at all hours, sending news from the front lines and grumbling about boring, sunbaked patrols, his complaints sometimes punctuated by expressions of terror, pride or doubt.

headline: Key Questions and Answers About Antonin Scalia and His Legacy
abstract: A look at Justice Scalia’s influence on cases, his personal life, and how his death will affect the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Justice Antonin Scalia died on Saturday during a hunting trip in Texas. He was the longest serving member of the Supreme Court, appointed in 1986 by President Ronald Reagan. He leaves behind a substantial legal legacy and a host of questions. Here are answers to a few:

lead_paragraph: In a parking lot a few hundred yards beyond Coney Island’s Parachute Jump, where customers floated toward the ground until the 1960s, lie pieces of the future: big white trusses. If they had come with an instruction manual, it would say, “Lots of assembly required.”

headline: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Sunday, Feb. 14
abstract: The Church of Alexander Wang, socially acceptable velvet, Erykah Badu’s styling debut and more.
lead_paragraph: 1. Alexander Wang commented on “today’s youth culture and its various appropriations of high fashion,” wrote Laura Neilson, combining streetwear and tweeds in his fall/winter collection that walked at St. Bartholomew’s on Park Avenue. The beauty look(s) differed from woman to woman. The makeup artist Diane Kendal created a chocolatey-brown glossy eye, and the hairstylist Guido Palau didn’t hesitate to grab the scissors and hair dye, completely transforming the model Katie Moore.

headline: 1891: Oscar Wilde’s Valentine
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Oscar Wilde writes a letter to The New York Herald in 1891 in answer to a review of his play.
lead_paragraph: In February 1891, the European edition of The New York Herald published the following letter from Oscar Wilde, responding to a review of his play, “Guido Ferranti.” The play is otherwise known as “The Duchess of Padua.” It ran for three weeks in January 1891 and has rarely been performed since.

headline: Review: ‘Better Call Saul,’ Quirky and Absorbing in Season Opener
abstract: This AMC drama further explores the title character’s former life as a small-time con artist.
lead_paragraph: Season 2 of “Better Call Saul” begins where Season 1 did: in purgatory, which happens to be a Cinnabon in Omaha. Saul Goodman (Bob Odenkirk), once Walter White’s skeevy lawyer, relocated there to save his skin after the bloody denouement of “Breaking Bad.” Like last year’s opening sequence, it’s a lovely, mournful short film, scored this time to the country standard “Funny How Time Slips Away.”

headline: Victoria Beckham: Fall 2016
abstract: Ms. Beckham, who grew her team from three people to 350 over the course of her career, presents her latest designs.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Beckham, who grew her team from three people to 350 over the course of her career, presents her latest designs.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Extra-Warm Shearling
abstract: Well-timed to the freezing temperatures, Yeezy, Altuzarra and Lacoste showed cozy coats.
lead_paragraph: Winter has finally arrived on the East Coast — just in time for fashion week. But judging from the shows so far, anyone kicking themselves for not investing in a polar-vortex shearling will have something to look forward to next season. At Kanye West’s Yeezy show, there was a covetable butterscotch-colored cropped version; at Lacoste, creative director Felipe Oliveira Baptista showed a convertible, hooded navy coat with zips at the waist that can shorten or lengthen. And at Altuzarra, one jacket came with black and oxblood vertical stripes and oversize pockets. The message is clear: The shearling is the must-have coat of the season.

headline: Syria Accord Looms Over Europe Security Meeting
abstract: The failure to secure an end to the five-year conflict in Syria and worry over Russia’s military intervention there overshadowed the annual security conference in Germany.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — The failure of world powers to quell the five-year conflict in Syria, the Russian military intervention there and the spread of Islamic terrorism overshadowed an annual security conference here, which came as Europe falters ahead of a new effort to cope with its refugee crisis.

headline: At Victoria Beckham, Slick Ponytails and a Soft Palette
abstract: The hairstylist Guido Palau described the beauty look at today’s show as “almost kind of futuristic, but not in a fantastical way.”
lead_paragraph: “The overall aesthetic is a modern woman today,” the hairstylist Guido Palau said this morning of the beauty identity he’s helped to build in recent seasons at Victoria Beckham. “Almost kind of futuristic, but not in a fantastical way; in a very wearable way.” True to that ideal, for fall/winter 2016 he crafted an army of artful, slicked-back ponytails, tied at the nape of the neck with thin black string. The style was worn long, regardless of hair length — short-haired models were given extensions — and was shellacked in front with layers of Redken Triple Take Hairspray 32, sprayed at close range to create a hard “jewel-like” texture. Selectively curling the ponytails with a one-inch iron lent the hair a “loose movement — not curls, just bends,” as Palau said, and a softness to counter the hairline’s abundance of product.

headline: Taraji P. Henson on Alexander Wang, Cookie and the Oscars
abstract: At New York Fashion Week, Ms. Henson talks about diversity in Hollywood and more.
lead_paragraph: There was an oddly somber feel to preshow proceedings at Alexander Wang this season, his usual downtown crowd muffled in big black coats under the cool cloistered ceilings of St Bartholomew’s Church on Park Avenue. The Wang Gang had shown up in their droves to support their friend on Saturday night, including Kylie Jenner and her rapper boyfriend Tyga, the singer Beth Ditto, Zoë Kravitz and Taraji P. Henson, the actress lately known for playing the ferocious matriarch Cookie Lyon in “Empire.” Head to toe in a black and studded Alexander Wang shift dress, Ms. Henson appeared delighted to be at the designer’s show for the very first time.

headline: Egyptian Appeals Court Orders New Trial for Officer Convicted of Manslaughter
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The conviction of a police officer, who shot Shaimaa el-Sabbagh, an activist and poet, during a protest, had been hailed by human rights groups as a rare instance of public accountability.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An appeals court on Sunday overturned the manslaughter conviction of a police officer in the death of a poet and activist whose shooting during a protest march became a national scandal.

headline: Pregame Drills Lacked Flash, but Now They’re Jam-Packed
abstract: The N.C.A.A. has lifted a ban — inspired by Kareem Abdul-Jabbar — on dunks less than 20 minutes before tipoff, so players are soaring whenever they want, much to fans’ delight.
lead_paragraph: Brian Rohleder was perhaps the last player expected to have an impact on Kansas State’s opening game of the 2014 N.C.A.A. tournament.

headline: After Antonin Scalia’s Death, Fierce Battle Lines Emerge
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The debate over who should replace Justice Scalia on the Supreme Court created a complicated calculus for both the Senate and President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An epic Washington political battle took shape on Sunday after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia as Senate Republicans dug in and said they would refuse to act on any Supreme Court nomination by President Obama. But the White House vowed to select a nominee within weeks.

Emily Ratajkowski, who shot to fame with the “Blurred Lines” music video in 2013, was in a sympathetic mood.

headline: Moncler Embraces Winter. The Crowd, Not So Much
abstract: Tip: When it’s 10 degrees and your runway show is outside, start on time.
lead_paragraph: It was around 6:45 on Saturday evening, and I was standing on the second-floor balcony of the David H. Koch Theater, overlooking the Lincoln Center Plaza — and I was freezing.

headline: Ranch Owner Recalls Finding Justice Antonin Scalia’s Body
abstract: Justice Scalia had arrived at the Cibolo Creek Ranch on Friday and was remembered as “very congenial, very convivial” by the ranch’s owner as a group roamed the property and some hunted quail.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — When Justice Antonin Scalia did not respond to a knock at the door of his suite at the Cibolo Creek Ranch at 8:30 a.m. on Saturday, John B. Poindexter, the property’s owner, was not alarmed.

headline: ‘Mourning Lincoln’ Wins Book Prize
abstract: Martha Hodes’s account of how the nation reacted to the president’s assassination takes $50,000 award.
lead_paragraph: “Mourning Lincoln,” the historian Martha Hodes’s account of how ordinary Americans lamented (or celebrated) the assassination of the Great Emancipator, has won the Gilder Lehrman Lincoln Prize, which is awarded annually by Gettysburg College and the Gilder Lehrman Institute of American History. The prize, for “the finest scholarly work in English on Abraham Lincoln, carries a $50,000 cash award.

lead_paragraph: In recent weeks, John Micklethwait, the editor in chief of Bloomberg, has sometimes felt, as he put it, like “a character in a Graham Greene novel. There’s an element of ‘there’s no perfect answer to it.’”

headline: ‘Deadpool’ Breaks Box Office Records for R-Rated Film

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Welcome to the A-list, Deadpool.

headline: ‘Super PAC’ Follows Jeb Bush in Taking Donald Trump to Task
abstract: Right to Rise, which had been focusing on attacking Senator Marco Rubio and Gov. John Kasich, changed course to show how Mr. Bush “stands up to Trump.”
lead_paragraph: Up until now, Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush, had focused most of its negative advertising on Senator Marco Rubio and Gov. John Kasich. On Friday, the group altered course, running two negative ads against its candidate’s favorite debate foil: Donald J. Trump.

headline: Review: ‘La Sylphide’ Is City Ballet’s Bittersweet Valentine
abstract: City Ballet offers “Tschaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2” and “La Sylphide,” not hearts and flowers.
lead_paragraph: Peter Martins isn’t one of those choreographers who loves love. He doesn’t get carried away by sentimentality. So it’s no surprise, but kind of refreshing, that he brought back his staging of “La Sylphide” — a ballet about a sylph who lures a young Scotsman away from his fiancée and, in the final heartbreaking moments, loses her wings, goes blind, keels over and dies — to New York City Ballet just in time for Valentine’s Day weekend. I hate cheap red hearts, too.

headline: Will Merkel Pay for Doing the Right Thing?
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: The German chancellor needs to set limits on the number of refugees, but she also needs help from her Western allies.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A former German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, recently called Angela Merkel’s decision to open the door to an unlimited number of refugees a “mistake” and offered this verdict: Merkel had a “heart, but no plan.”

headline: Trial of Chad’s Ex-President Is Punctuated by His Noncooperation
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: Guards had to confine Hissène Habré, the former president of Chad, to the defendant’s chair nearly every day for four months.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Most mornings since September, the former president of the African nation of Chad was woken at dawn in his specially refurbished prison quarters for a trip he loathed.

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 15
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Tuesday’s auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Victoria Beckham
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Beckham offered yet another great men’s wear-inspired flat at her fall/winter 2016 show this morning, but it’s this chunky-heeled boot with a buckle that stood out — especially for how good it will look with all the new midcalf skirts.

headline: The Daily Bag: Victoria Beckham
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The luxurious fur bags at Victoria Beckham are so covetable the models don’t even want to let them go.

headline: Liberal Love for Antonin Scalia
abstract: He made constitutional theory sexy.
lead_paragraph: Antonin Scalia was my hero. He was deeply conservative. He belittled lawyers. His opinions, especially in dissent, could be downright nasty. No justice in the Supreme Court’s history insulted his colleagues more, or more memorably. He was as aggressive and outspoken as I am reserved and cautious. He was a smoker. He was, in short, everything I am not. But I have looked up to him for years.

headline: For ‘Hangmen’ and ‘Escaped Alone,’ Connecting Threads in London
abstract: Martin McDonagh and Caryl Churchill’s two plays, so different, are united by extreme narrative tension.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Martin McDonagh has been sharpening his hooks. Not the kind that one of his homicidal characters might use to flay the flesh of an enemy (or relative), but the sort that a cunning dramatist plunges deep into a theatergoer’s attention and refuses to release until the final curtain.

headline: Review: Kanye West’s ‘The Life of Pablo,’ Songs of Praise and Self
abstract: On his seventh album, Mr. West has perfected the art of aesthetic and intellectual bricolage, shape-shifting in real time and counting on listeners to keep up.
lead_paragraph: It’s unlikely we’ll get a song as singular as Kanye West’s “Ultralight Beam” anytime soon, so best to linger on it, feel out its grooves and curves, allow it to seep into the pores.

headline: Brooks Brothers: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Looks from the Brooks Brothers Collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the Brooks Brothers Collection.

headline: In Grammy Race, the Band Highly Suspect Marvels at Its Surprising Double Shot
abstract: It’s unusual for a low-profile rock band to receive two nominations shortly after its first album.
lead_paragraph: For a little-known band, one Grammy nomination might be explained away as a fluke. Scoring two simultaneous nominations is harder to comprehend, especially in mainstream categories like rock, which tend to favor household names. (Some recent winners: Beck, Foo Fighters, Green Day, Led Zeppelin.)

headline: Review: In Álvaro Enrigue’s ‘Sudden Death,’ a Farcical Duel With Topspin
abstract: Álvaro Enrigue’s droll and erudite novel pits two late Renassance giants, Francisco de Quevedo and Caravaggio, against each other on a tennis court in 1599.
lead_paragraph: Writing with his customary intensity about his favorite sport, David Foster Wallace described tennis as “chess on the run, beautiful and infinitely dense.” In his droll and erudite new novel, “Sudden Death,” Álvaro Enrigue provides his own distinct take on that chess-on-the-run notion and elevates it to an even more exalted level. Pitting two late Renaissance giants against each other, he transforms their match into a clash of ideologies, a contest that von Clausewitz might have described as a continuation of both war and politics by other means.

headline: Slideshow: Off the Runway
abstract: Scenes from the fourth day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the fourth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: The Upmarket Tracksuit
abstract: The upmarket tracksuits, hoodies and other willfully subversive signifiers of survivalist chic have shown up on the New York Fashion Week runways. Here are some examples.
lead_paragraph: The upmarket tracksuits, hoodies and other willfully subversive signifiers of survivalist chic have shown up on the New York Fashion Week runways. Here are some examples.

headline: The Tracksuit Reborn
abstract: The upmarket tracksuits, hoodies and other willfully subversive signifiers of survivalist chic have made their way stateside in force.
lead_paragraph: It’s high time Seventh Avenue reclaimed ownership of a trend that European designers have been exploiting for a season or more. The upmarket tracksuits, hoodies and other willfully subversive signifiers of survivalist chic that were shown for spring at Vetements and Chloé, among others, have made their way stateside in force.

headline: The Lone Wolf at the Westminster Dog Show
abstract: Dog shows in North America employ just one professional judge to evaluate best in show, and at Westminster on Tuesday, that responsibility will fall to Dr. Richard Meen.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Richard Meen fully grasps the monastic nature of his powers. On Tuesday night, just 30 minutes before the best-in-show competition at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Madison Square Garden, he will descend from his sequestered post in the Warwick Hotel in Manhattan to decide, alone, which of the animals is the purest of the purebreds.

headline: A Leisurely Return for the New York State Legislature
abstract: Despite the corruption convictions of their top leaders, and public demand for reform, the Senate and Assembly have done little in this session.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — The scene in the State Capitol last week bore all the hallmarks of democracy at work: advocates and lobbyists pushing their causes, earnest interns scurrying about, and protesters making insistent pleas for funds for everything from housing to hepatitis C.

headline: An Unwanted Bill
abstract: David Kahn offers us a puzzle about the loneliest job in the world since the Maytag repairman.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — They say it’s lonely at the top and I would dare say that no position is lonelier than that of the president of the United States, especially when it comes to making decisions that affect the rest of the free world. Today, we can almost literally see some of those past presidents on their ladder to success in David Kahn’s crossword.

headline: Tombstone Survives on Spirit of the Wild West
abstract: Tourists come from all over the world to the small Arizona city to experience a taste of the past through guided tours and re-enactments.

headline: Guns Blazing, Tombstone Is Back to Its Past
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'Accidents and Safety', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: Re-enactments of life more than a century ago, including a gunfight performance that went awry, keep the small Arizona city booming.
lead_paragraph: TOMBSTONE, Ariz. — Ken Curtis felt a stinging pain beneath the double-stitched leather holster where his Mitchell Arms pistol rests when it is not in his hands, as it was that afternoon in October. He slid a finger inside his pants. Blood oozed from a hole in his lower abdomen. Mr. Curtis took a deep breath and slipped right back into character.

headline: Ted Cruz Attacks Donald Trump Over Planned Parenthood in New Ad
abstract: An ad that shows interview excerpts in which Mr. Trump argues that Planned Parenthood “serves a good function” could be the most potent signal yet that Mr. Cruz views the issue as a chief vulnerability for his rival in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas on Sunday released an advertisement attacking Donald J. Trump for his defense of Planned Parenthood — the most potent signal yet that Mr. Cruz views the issue as a chief vulnerability for his rival in South Carolina.

headline: Revolution Is Absent From Runways
abstract: A fashion review of Alexander Wang, Victoria Beckham, Altuzarra, Yeezy and Rihanna’s first show for Puma.
lead_paragraph: Given all the talk about rule breaking and the appeal of extremes and the rejection of familiar codes of behavior (yadda, yadda, yadda) that has dominated the political and cultural conversation since the 2016 presidential campaign began, it wouldn’t be too outlandish to expect that some of it might find expression in fashion.

headline: Fashion Week Today: For Hood by Air, Pilgrimage on a Collision Course
abstract: Plus: a dancing Karlie Kloss at DVF, vape pens as accessories at Baja East, Zac Posen for Brooks Brothers and more.
lead_paragraph: We’ll be bringing you highlights from the shows, from the extravaganzas to the scrappy upstarts. Here is day 4.

headline: Severe Contraction and Falling Prices in Japan Signal Tough Test for Abenomics
abstract: Japan’s economy shrank in the final three months of 2015, the government said on Monday, its second contraction in three quarters.
lead_paragraph: Japan’s economy shrank in the final three months of 2015, the government said on Monday, undergoing a more severe contraction than experts had expected amid signs that global growth was stalling.

headline: Zika Virus Increases Concerns About Employee Safety
abstract: As reports of infections rise, employees and management at a variety of corporations are grappling with how to handle jobs and projects in affected regions.
lead_paragraph: Early in her pregnancy, Whitney Peak traveled to Rio de Janeiro for her job with Leblon Cachaça, a liquor company based in Brazil. That was in October, before much was known about Zika, a mosquito-borne virus that has spread through South America and that scientists say may be linked to a birth defect and brain damage in babies.

headline: HSBC to Keep Headquarters in London Instead of Hong Kong
abstract: The British bank had announced a review of a possible move last April, citing regulations and a tax on lenders.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — HSBC said on Sunday that it would keep its headquarters in Britain after announcing plans last year to review whether to move its home.

headline: Brazil Pushes Public to Do Its Part in Fighting Zika Spread
abstract: Soldiers distributed fliers that told residents how to reduce the breeding grounds for Aedes aegypti, the mosquito that transmits Zika and other ills.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — Nearly a quarter of a million soldiers, sailors and other military personnel began fanning through Brazilian cities over the weekend as part of an ambitious campaign to combat the mosquitoes that are spreading Zika, the virus believed to be linked to a surge in infants born with severe brain damage.

headline: Movers on Bikes
abstract: The Cargo Bike Collective, a loose-knit group of people who own and ride the extra-long bikes, help move items in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The Cargo Bike Collective, a loose-knit group of people who own and ride the extra-long bikes, help move items in New York City.

headline: On the Move in New York, on Bicycles Built for More Than 2
abstract: When a Manhattan woman needed help moving to a new apartment, she passed over the usual moving companies and called on the Cargo Bike Collective.
lead_paragraph: The movers arrived at Barbara Ross’s apartment on the Lower East Side of Manhattan one Friday last month, grabbing bags of clothes and shoes, framed pictures and boxes of CDs. They carried the items downstairs and loaded them onto four long-framed cargo bicycles parked on Ridge Street.

headline: Edun: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Danielle Sherman presents her latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Danielle Sherman presents her latest collection.

headline: How America Was Lost
abstract: Why is the death of a Supreme Court justice bringing America to the edge of constitutional crisis?
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, the death of a Supreme Court justice wouldn’t have brought America to the edge of constitutional crisis. But that was a different country, with a very different Republican Party. In today’s America, with today’s G.O.P., the passing of Antonin Scalia has opened the doors to chaos.

headline: Not Part of Video’s Script: An Arrest for Flying a Drone
abstract: An attempt to film aerial shots for a promotional video landed Sean Riddle in a holding cell after his drone bumped against the Empire State Building.
lead_paragraph: Sean Riddle said the other inmates in the Manhattan holding cell that night were laughing — at him. Someone had overheard him talking to his court-appointed lawyer.

headline: New Report of U.S.-Made Cluster Bomb Use by Saudis in Yemen
keywords: ['ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT', 'Arms Trade', 'Cluster Munitions', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The report by Human Rights Watch included photos of bombs that did not explode, indicating they failed reliability standards required for U.S. export.
lead_paragraph: Human Rights Watch released a report Sunday providing new indications that Saudi Arabia has fired American-made cluster munitions, banned by international treaty, in civilian areas of Yemen, and said their use may also violate United States law.

headline: Potential Nominees Obama May Consider to Fill Antonin Scalia’s Seat
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Here are six contenders for Justice Antonin Scalia’s vacant seat who are being discussed by close observers of judicial politics.
lead_paragraph: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia in a presidential election year has set up a challenge for President Obama and his legal advisers. They must weigh the best person to put forward, knowing that Republican senators may block that nominee no matter who is chosen. At the same time, if a Democrat prevails in the presidential election, Mr. Obama’s nominee might be confirmed in the Senate’s lame-duck session or would be an obvious front-runner to be renominated by his successor in 2017. Here are six contenders being discussed by close observers of judicial politics.

headline: At United Pickle, Preserving the Standards of a Deli Staple
abstract: Products from the company, a family-owned supplier of pickles and pickled condiments, are used at 2nd Ave Deli, Shake Shack and Delmonico’s.
lead_paragraph: Not every cucumber has what it takes to be a pickle. As dozens of them tumbled from a steel hopper onto a conveyor belt in a Bronx factory, two workers enforced a strict pickle standard.

headline: The Cowboy Pilgrims of Mexico
abstract: More 3,000 people made this year’s three-day journey to a mountaintop statue of Jesus, keeping alive a tradition that began more than 60 years ago.
lead_paragraph: More 3,000 people made this year’s three-day journey to a mountaintop statue of Jesus, keeping alive a tradition that began more than 60 years ago.

headline: Pilgrimage in Mexico Keeps a Cowboy Tradition Alive
abstract: More than 3,000 people made this year’s three-day journey to a mountaintop statue of Jesus, hoping to find redemption, a promise of rain or just a connection to the past.
lead_paragraph: SILAO, Mexico — Sheathed in colorful woolen ponchos and wearing crisp white hats, the cowboys rode their horses through green fields and blond meadows, holding banners of Christ the King and the Virgin of Guadalupe.

headline: In Queens, Antonin Scalia Took Pride in Melting Pot and Confrontation
abstract: Known as a pugnacious reactionary, Justice Scalia had strong opinions about his boyhood borough, stickball, the melting pot and “Joe Sixpack.”
lead_paragraph: Justice Antonin Scalia had a range that extended from in-your-face brash to an even-more-in-your-face pugnacious. He was self-aware, describing himself as “something of a shin kicker” and “something of a contrarian.” Sure, Justice Scalia was born in Trenton — predictably, New Jersey’s governor, Chris Christie, claimed him on Saturday, saying that the 79-year-old justice was “a native son of New Jersey.”

headline: In Mexican Slum, Pope Francis Laments Economic Gap
abstract: By coming to Ecatepec, one of the country’s largest, poorest and most violent cities, the pope placed himself at the center of Mexico’s identity crisis.
lead_paragraph: ECATEPEC, Mexico — Pope Francis stepped into the heartland of Mexican inequality on Sunday, presiding over an enormous outdoor Mass in the impoverished outskirts of the capital and urging the joyous crowd not to fall prey to the wealth, vanity and pride that can create “a society of the few, and for the few.”

headline: Kobe Bryant, in His Final Lap, Is Happy to Surrender the Midseason Stage
abstract: Bryant said before the All-Star Game, a 196-173 victory by the West, that he was relishing an opportunity to “relax and soak it in.”
lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Before the N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday night, Stephen Curry told Kobe Bryant that he planned to accumulate a ton of assists by feeding the ball to Bryant as often as possible. Bryant, on the cusp of retirement with the Los Angeles Lakers, essentially advised Curry to pump the brakes.

headline: Trial Illuminates Porsches’ Rise to Power at Volkswagen
keywords: ['Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Automobiles', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Air Pollution', 'Diesel Power']
abstract: Prosecutors claim that the Porsche holding company misled investors in 2008 on its plan to take over Volkswagen, sending VW stock soaring.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — A criminal trial in Germany has shed new light on how a billionaire family acquired ultimate power at Volkswagen in the years leading up to the carmaker’s emissions-cheating crisis.

headline: Brits Off Broadway Festival Announces Lineup
abstract: The festival will run April 19-July 3 and feature nine New York premieres.
lead_paragraph: New York theatergoers will have a chance to see a new production of the first professionally staged play by Richard Bean (“One Man, Two Guvnors”) when his 1999 play “Toast,” based on his experience working in a bread factory at age 18, is presented at 59E59 Theaters in April. The show comes to New York following a British tour, and is part of the annual Brits Off Broadway Festival, which will run April 19-July 3 and feature nine New York premieres.

headline: Questions for the E.C.B. Leader, Fed Minutes and Walmart Earnings
abstract: This week, Mario Draghi will appear at a hearing in Brussels, the Federal Reserve will release an account of its most recent policy-making meeting and both Walmart and Nordstrom will report fourth quarter earnings.
lead_paragraph: Mario Draghi, the president of the European Central Bank, is likely to face questions on Monday about his response to fears of a renewed banking crisis when he appears in Brussels at a hearing of the European Parliament’s Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs.

headline: Jenny Packham: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Ms. Packham, who is known for dressing Kate Middleton, presents her latest designs.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Packham, who is known for dressing Kate Middleton, presents her latest designs.

headline: Jeb Bush Adds a Weapon (His Brother) Despite Worries It Could Misfire
abstract: Former President George W. Bush is set to take a stage in South Carolina on Monday with his brother, in an appearance that offers a glimpse into the complicated dynamics of a family dynasty.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The brother who was never expected to become president — but did — will be trotted out Monday as a lifeline to the brother who was always expected to become president, but now may not.

headline: The Supreme Court After Justice Scalia
keywords: ['Editorials', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: The Republican effort to delay the nomination process until President Obama leaves office does not serve the cause of justice.
lead_paragraph: When Antonin Scalia was named by President Ronald Reagan to fill a vacancy on the Supreme Court in 1986, the Senate considered the nomination for 85 days, then voted to confirm him. The tally was 98 to 0.

headline: Malawi Gets Its First Grammy Nomination, With Album by Prison Inmates
abstract: The work has been an unexpected boon for the tiny African nation and now goes up against the works of well-known artists in the world music category.
lead_paragraph: ZOMBA, Malawi — Old, overcrowded and unsanitary, the maximum-security Zomba prison holds murderers, robbers, rapists — and Grammy-nominated singers.

headline: Warren Manzi, Author of New York’s Longest-Running Play, Dies at 60
abstract: “Perfect Crime” logged its 11,824th performance, despite the fact that critics often did not like it and theatergoers often did not understand it.
lead_paragraph: Warren Manzi, a playwright whose Off Broadway thriller, “Perfect Crime,” remains the longest-running play in New York theater history — nearly 29 years and counting — despite the fact that critics often did not like it and theatergoers often did not understand it, died on Thursday in Lawrence, Mass. He was 60.

headline: With Death of Antonin Scalia, an Already Volatile Campaign Erupts
abstract: An unpredictable election that had pitted grass-roots activists against traditional party leaders is suddenly erupting into a rare battle royale for control of every branch of government.
lead_paragraph: In the hours after she learned about the death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Saturday, Hillary Clinton intended to confine her response to a 79-word statement extending thoughts and prayers to his family and praising his “energy and passion” on the bench.

headline: Parade in Chinatown Raises Spirits During a Record Plunge in Temperature
abstract: By around daybreak on Sunday, the temperature dipped below zero in Central Park, to minus 1, breaking a century-old record.
lead_paragraph: It was worth asking whether it was jubilation stirred up by the Lunar New Year Parade or an attempt to ward off hypothermia that had people dancing on the sidewalks of Chinatown in Manhattan on Sunday.

headline: Scalia’s Absence Is Likely to Alter Court’s Major Decisions This Term
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'ABORTION']
abstract: Antonin Scalia’s death will complicate the work of the remaining justices, as some cases could result in 4-to-4 deadlocks, and strengthen the Supreme Court’s liberal wing.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Antonin Scalia’s death will complicate the work of the Supreme Court’s eight remaining justices for the rest of the court’s term, probably change the outcomes of some major cases and, for the most part, amplify the power of its four-member liberal wing.

headline: Players Who Start March Like Lions Often Go Out Like Lambs
abstract: Success in spring training typically portends a good regular season. But as some disappointed teams and players know, that is not always the case.
lead_paragraph: Spring training has existed in some form since the 19th century, but to this day no one really knows what to do with the statistics that are generated in that prelude to baseball’s regular season. The tendency of fans to get excited about good performances while writing off bad ones as meaningless has created an ambiguity that the sport seems unable to shake.

headline: Mitch McConnell’s Stance in Confirmation Fight Could Help and Hurt G.O.P.
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate']
abstract: Mr. McConnell’s announcement that he would block a nomination appeals to conservatives, but could alienate moderates and imperil incumbent Republicans in swing states.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Mitch McConnell’s strategy to maintain the Republican majority has been clear: trying to prove that his party can govern. But by saying he will block a Supreme Court nominee who has not even been named, Mr. McConnell is headed toward partisan warfare instead.

headline: Major Donors to Hillary Clinton Include Napster Co-Founder
abstract: Sean Parker gave $300,000 to a joint fund-raising committee for Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign and dozens of state Democratic parties, federal filings show.
lead_paragraph: Sean Parker, the youthful billionaire and co-founder of the music-sharing service Napster, gave nearly $300,000 to a joint fund-raising committee for Hillary Clinton’s presidential campaign and dozens of state Democratic parties, federal filings show.

lead_paragraph: Seven New York Times journalists who investigated the hidden history of the Navy’s SEAL teams, and a 97-year-old reporter for Jet magazine were among the winners of the George Polk Awards in Journalism for 2015, which were announced on Sunday.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Midseason Premiere: Carl’s Big Moment Arrives

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Season 6, Episode 7: Crash and Burn
abstract: Dear Lady Mary, there’s been an accident, and ...

headline: At Opening Ceremony, a Contemporary Vision of the Future
abstract: The designers Humberto Leon and Carol Lim collaborated with the visual futurist Syd Mead of “Blade Runner” for their fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Syd Mead, 82, has been designing the future for more than a half-century. The Los Angeles-based visual futurist and illustrator is known for creating dazzling cityscapes, flying cars, solar sailors and light cycles for such films as “Blade Runner,” “Aliens” and “Tron,” as well as industrial designs for cars, yachts, wristwatches and more at Ford Motor Company, Phillips Electronics and U.S. Steel.

headline: How a Vacancy on the Supreme Court Affected Cases in the 2015-16 Term

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 5: Citizen Axe
abstract: Bobby wonders what it would be like to simply live the good life.
lead_paragraph: Coming off his dalliance last week with the lead singer of a Ratt cover band— surely its repertoire is more expansive, but it’s fun to imagine all-acoustic sets of songs like “Round and Round” and “Lay It Down” — Bobby (Damian Lewis) sits down for his first-ever viewing of “Citizen Kane.” (Quick side note: That he has a 35 mm projector in his house makes him heroic, and perhaps says something, too, about his love of tactile experiences, like biking out to collect the farm-fresh eggs he’s going to cook for breakfast.) It’s significant that Bobby never finishes the movie, taking one phone call before the opening credits and getting a visit from Wendy somewhere in the middle. But if he’d finished “Citizen Kane,” he would have learned the following:

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Series Premiere: A Golden Ear and a Silver Tongue
abstract: HBO’s new series, about the music industry in the 1970s debuted with a two-hour, Martin Scorsese-directed episode.
lead_paragraph: When Richie Finestra, the record-biz operator played by Bobby Cannavale, signs up his first client, they connect by name-checking favorite musical artists: Pinetop Perkins, Skip James, Kokomo Arnold. “Vinyl” does the same bonding ritual with its viewers, barraging them with beloved ’70s bands on the soundtrack, from Abba to Mott the Hoople, and mentioning everyone from Peter Frampton to David Geffen. Judging by its two-hour pilot, the show provides the thrill of nostalgia as effectively as “Mad Men” did: it remains to be seen whether it also has a story that’s worthy of its production values.

headline: Rangers Lead With Their Fists in a Much-Needed Victory Over the Flyers
abstract: An early fight between the Rangers rookie Dylan McIlrath and Philadelphia’s Wayne Simmonds, who had injured Ryan McDonagh the last time the teams met, set the tone for a physical game.
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia Flyers forward Wayne Simmonds made sure to slow down before he passed the Rangers rookie defenseman Dylan McIlrath at center ice as they warmed up for Sunday’s game at Madison Square Garden. The two tough guys talked briefly, then went their separate ways.

lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and Hillary Clinton took their increasingly contentious battle for the Democratic nomination to a predominantly black church in Las Vegas on Sunday morning.

headline: Obama May Meet Zika Head On in Cuba
abstract: President Obama wants to visit Cuba, where, disease experts say, the arrival of the Zika virus is almost certain.

headline: U.S. Aid for Abortions for Women With Zika

headline: O Yeah, Canada: The Border Republicans Forgot
abstract: The Republicans have never been afraid of the great white north, emphasis on white.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates who battled for votes in New Hampshire last week, rousing the rabble with their usual talk of scary aliens at the border, were strangely silent about the closest international boundary. They did not warn of the Canadians who flood south by the millions each year to play and work, taking our Christmas-tree-selling jobs. They did not mention the Canadian scofflaws — nearly 100,000 in fiscal 2015 — who overstay their visas, the most of any nationality.

headline: Don’t Privatize Air Traffic Control
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Privatization', 'Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'United States Politics and Government', 'AIR TRAFFIC CONTROL']
abstract: The current system is the safest in the world, and there is no credible evidence that a private one would be better.
lead_paragraph: Some Republicans in the House have come up with a solution in search of a problem: privatizing air traffic control. Democrats, the Obama administration and sensible Republicans ought to oppose this measure, which would do nothing to improve the present, federally operated system and indeed could make it worse.

headline: After Setbacks, Newark Alters a Program to Encourage Home Building
keywords: ['Area Planning and Renewal', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Building (Construction)']
abstract: Participants who bought vacant lots from the city last year struggled with planning, permits and loans. Newark is now stepping in with more help for them.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — For the past week, on a block of North 13th Street just past the Morris & Essex Line tracks in this tumbledown city, the air has been full of diesel fuel and promise.

headline: Young Latinos Power Both Democrats in Nevada Caucus Campaign
abstract: The fight between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders is giving a state’s Hispanics a chance to draw attention to their hardships and priorities.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Liz Hernandez learned what deportation was at age 5, when immigration officers burst into her home and hauled away her father and four uncles. Five years later, she and her mother, younger sister and infant brother, after a brief return to Mexico in a failed attempt to start a family farm, crossed the desert headed north again in a sweltering van driven by smugglers.

lead_paragraph: In previously unseen photographs, the former Times photographer Don Hogan Charles Jr. reveals Harlem’s residents as fully rounded people, counter to the fearful perception reported in the 1960s.

headline: Ehud Olmert, Ex-Prime Minister of Israel, Begins Prison Sentence
abstract: In a video, Mr. Olmert acknowledged that he had “made mistakes,” but he insisted that he had done nothing criminal.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Describing his fall as “painful and strange,” Ehud Olmert became on Monday the first former Israeli prime minister to enter prison, beginning a 19-month term for bribery and obstruction of justice.

headline: Support for Breast-Feeding, in a Multitude of Ways
abstract: New guidelines urge policy changes to allow more women to breast-feed.
lead_paragraph: In 2001, when Dr. Alison Stuebe was pregnant with her first child, breast-feeding was a personal challenge that soon morphed into a professional research interest. Her son Noah was 3 months old when she began her residency in maternal-fetal medicine at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston. Determined to nurse him for a year, she arrived at the hospital carrying a breast pump and, through sheer determination, more than met her goal. Noah was 2½ before he was weaned.

headline: Doctor’s Orders: Stay in Bed and Do Nothing
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Parenting', 'Pregnancy and Childbirth', 'Premature Babies']
abstract: Bed rest is like Las Vegas. It’s nice for three days, but stay any longer and you might lose your mind.
lead_paragraph: It’s 3 in the morning when a lovely woman dressed in baby blue slips through a crack in the door to take my vital signs: temperature, blood pressure. She pings my knees with a rubber mallet, does a jerky massage on my feet to see if they’re swollen.

lead_paragraph: David Neville and Marcus Wainwright, British school friends and co-CEOs of Rag & Bone, discuss how sitting side by side in their Meatpacking District office informs their creative process.

abstract: Day 5 highlights include shows from Carolina Herrera, Rosie Assoulin, Jeremy Scott and Thom Browne.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week is comfortable caroming into its second half on Presidents’ Day Monday. (You didn’t think anything so slight as a national holiday would interrupt fashion week, did you?) By Thursday, many of the gathered fashion tribe will be heading to London to continue the international jaunt. But before then, there’s lots to see.

headline: In the Studio with Rag & Bone
abstract: Getting bigger doesn’t always make things easier, according to David Neville and Marcus Wainwright.
lead_paragraph: In episode one of season four of our In the Studio series, David Neville and Marcus Wainwright, British school friends and chief executives of Rag & Bone, discuss sharing an office, the problem with walls, and work/life balance. And that’s what didn’t make it into the video. (The interview has been edited and condensed.)
