abstract: The delightfully improbable stick insect uses two pairs of legs to walk and the front pair to check out what lies ahead.
lead_paragraph: The delightfully improbable stick insect uses two pairs of legs to walk and the front pair to check out what lies ahead.

headline: Stick Insect Helps Scientists Study How Animals Move
abstract: Using motion-capture video, scientists study how the Indian stick insect moves.
lead_paragraph: Stick insects, which look like walking twigs, are popular as pets and research subjects because they’re easy to keep, can’t fly away, and move at a pace that allows observation and study.

headline: SoftBank Announces Stock Buyback of About $4.4 Billion
abstract: It would be the biggest share repurchase the company has made.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The multinational media and telecommunications conglomerate SoftBank said on Monday that it would buy back shares worth 500 billion yen, the biggest share repurchase it has ever made.

headline: From Black-and-White Negatives, a Positive View of Harlem
abstract: In these previously unseen photographs, the former New York Times photographer Don Hogan Charles Jr. reveals Harlem’s residents as fully rounded people — counter to the fearful perception that was reported in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 8, 1966, The New York Times ran an article about how many Harlem residents wished more white people would visit to see for themselves their community’s reality. The article, by McCandlish Phillips, detailed in an almost anthropological way the Harlem of 1966 to Times readers.

headline: Medical Residents, Misplaced Pride and Saner Hours
abstract: Studies suggest there are no harms from long hours, but reduced hours aren’t a problem either.
lead_paragraph: When one of my best friends in medical school returned from an interview for a surgical residency program, he told me how some of the surgeons there bragged that they were worked so hard that the divorce rate among their trainees was greater than 100 percent — some of them burned through two marriages.

headline: Opposition Candidate Briefly Held Before Uganda’s Presidential Vote
abstract: Kizza Besigye, who is challenging President Yoweri Museveni for the presidency, had been arrested as he was holding a rally.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Uganda’s leading opposition figure was arrested on Monday, three days before the East African country’s presidential elections.

headline: Strong Dollar Blues
abstract: Shoulda seen this coming.
lead_paragraph: Gavyn Davies joins the chorus of those worried that the Fed is in denial about its interest-rate misstep:

headline: Past Grammy Looks: The Good, the Bad and the Memorable
abstract: A glimpse back at some noteworthy Grammy style moments.
lead_paragraph: The Grammy red carpet is usually on the more outrageous end of the fashion spectrum, with musicians showing off their personal style. Here is a look back at some noteworthy style moments: the good, the bad and the memorable.

headline: Nikita Kamayev, Ex-Head of Russian Antidoping Agency, Dies
abstract: Kamayev, 52, a former director of the agency, known as Rusada, apparently had a heart attack. The agency’s founding chairman, Vyacheslav Sinev, died Feb. 3.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A former director of the disgraced Russian antidoping agency has died unexpectedly, a state news agency reported Monday, becoming the second former top official of the agency to die this month.

headline: Rising Yen Adds to Abe’s Challenges as Japan’s Economy Contracts
abstract: The economic campaign that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe began three years ago, known as Abenomics, relied on a relatively weak currency.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — When Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan began a campaign three years ago to turn around his country’s economy, he took aim at areas as varied as taxes, trade and women in the workplace. The campaign, given the nickname Abenomics, relied heavily on one strategy: weakening the country’s currency.

headline: Republicans Risk Five Key Senate Races With Supreme Court Stance
abstract: The same Republicans whose defeats might cost their party control of the chamber might also be likely to back President Obama’s nominee.
lead_paragraph: The impending battle over replacing Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court will undoubtedly loom over this year’s presidential contest. But it may have an even larger role in an often overlooked 2016 election contest: the fight for control of the Senate.

headline: Syrian Hospitals Hit as Battlefield Grows More Chaotic
abstract: As United States allies clash and tensions between Russia and Turkey escalate, airstrikes at four medical facilities killed 50, including children.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The prospect of a wider war loomed over an increasingly chaotic battlefield in northern Syria on Monday, as fast-moving clashes pitted United States allies against one another and tensions grew between two major powers, Russia and Turkey.

headline: Le procès Hissène Habré, un succès à ne pas répéter
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Jamais dans une affaire de crimes contre l’humanité la voix des victimes n’aura été aussi dominante. Et l’Union africaine conclut : ne recommençons pas.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Sénégal — La semaine dernière, les acteurs du procès de Hissène Habré se sont retrouvés ici pour leurs plaidoiries finales devant les Chambres africaines extraordinaires (CAE), un tribunal créé spécialement pour juger l’ancien président du Tchad. Habré, au pouvoir de juin 1982 à décembre 1990, est poursuivi, entre autres, pour de nombreux crimes de guerre et crimes contre l’humanité commis contre ses opposants politiques.

headline: Oxford’s Halley Professor on How the Climate Challenge Could Derail a Brilliant Human Destiny
keywords: ['Carbon Dioxide', 'Earth', 'Global Warming', 'Gravitation and Gravity', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: The Halley Professor of Physics at Oxford asks whether humanity is capable of applying the patient and creative investment of brain power and money to curtailing climate change that it invested in finding ripples in spacetime.
lead_paragraph: Sustained large investments in fundamental science paid off in a big way last week, as Dennis Overbye so beautifully reported in The Times’s package on confirmation of Einstein’s 1916 conclusion that massive moving objects cause ripples in spacetime — gravitational waves.

headline: 1941: British Parachutists Invade Italy
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain sends troops by parachute into Italy in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a brief statement the British officially admitted today [Feb. 15] that they had dropped parachute troops by plane in southern Italy on Monday night and Tuesday morning.

headline: Zika Virus in Colombia Presents Complicated Choice About Abortion
abstract: The illness appeared in the country too recently for most pregnant women who contracted it to determine the risk of birth defects.
lead_paragraph: CÚCUTA, Colombia — Margarita Rosa Barrios was six weeks pregnant when she began to feel the symptoms that every expecting mother here has come to dread: swollen eyes, aching joints, three days of fever. Just as she feared, she had the Zika virus.

headline: How Does One Dog Recognize Another as a Dog?
abstract: Studies of dogs’ ability to discriminate their kind from other animals show they can do so based on purely visual evidence, even in images.
lead_paragraph: Q. How does one dog instantly recognize another as a dog, not some other animal?

headline: Donald Trump Escalates Rhetoric Before South Carolina Primary
abstract: If Donald J. Trump wins the Republican primary in South Carolina on Saturday, it will be after reverting to the storm-the-gates populism that led to his political rise. It will also raise the stakes for party leaders who want to stop his candidacy.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, whose presidential campaign has doused the Republican Party with the verbal equivalent of napalm, has escalated his rhetoric to new levels of intensity before the crucial South Carolina primary this week. It is a vote that, if he wins, could erode the prospects of Republican leaders’ stopping his candidacy.

headline: Documentary on Migrants Wins Praise at Berlin Film Festival
keywords: ['Berlin International Film Festival', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis']
abstract: “Fuocoammare,” or “Fire at Sea,” has had strong reviews since it was first shown in Berlin on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — As European leaders wrestle with a wave of migrants that is testing their commitment to open borders and their democracies, a documentary about the Italian island of Lampedusa — for years the first point of arrival in Europe for hundreds of thousands migrants from North Africa — has emerged as one of the strongest films at this year’s Berlin International Film Festival.

headline: Bluffer’s Guide to the Oscars: Best Actor
abstract: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.
lead_paragraph: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.

headline: Silicon Valley Gives Ex-Convict a Familiar Feeling
abstract: The bravado, rule-breaking and renegade attitudes that Chrisfino Kenyatta Leal sees in his work with start-ups remind him of his time in prison.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — If you are, for whatever reasons, seeking a large number of young white men in plaid shirts who are partial to standing desks and seminars on “growth hacking” and “journey mapping,” look no further than San Francisco’s RocketSpace.

headline: Left-Leaning Economists Question Cost of Bernie Sanders’s Plans
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Some who share the candidate’s goals suggest that his proposals, especially on health care, could increase the federal government’s size by over 50 percent.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With his expansive plans to increase the size and role of government, Senator Bernie Sanders has provoked a debate not only with his Democratic rival for president, Hillary Clinton, but also with liberal-leaning economists who share his goals but question his numbers and political realism.

headline: Bernie Sanders and a First for Jews
abstract: The Vermont senator is wary of identity politics, but his secular socialism is rooted in community.
lead_paragraph: ON the night of his resounding victory in the New Hampshire primary, Bernie Sanders, the first Jew ever to win a presidential nominating contest in American history, got uncharacteristically personal in his victory speech. “I am the son of a Polish immigrant,” he told his frenzied crowd.

headline: Johnny Lattner, Heisman-Winning Halfback With Notre Dame, Dies at 83
abstract: Lattner, who was inducted into the College Football Hall of Fame in 1979, was an all-around talent who excelled at both offense and defense.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Lattner, the versatile halfback who won the 1953 Heisman Trophy playing for an unbeaten Notre Dame team, died on Saturday at his home in Melrose Park, Ill., a suburb of Chicago. He was 83.

headline: Anti-Gay Actions in Indonesia Threaten a Fragile Population
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Hate Crimes', 'Instant Messaging', 'Emojis and Emoticons']
abstract: Recent recommendations aimed at chipping away at the social standing of lesbians and gays have caught most human rights activists in Jakarta by surprise.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — First, a senior Indonesian government minister called for a ban on gay groups on university campuses. Another official pressured smartphone instant-messaging services to drop gay- and lesbian-themed emoji, prompting one company to comply.

headline: 1966: Russia Rejects Foreign Outcry
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Soviet Union rejects foreign criticism of the convictions of two writers in 1966.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The Soviet Union today [Feb. 15] rejected foreign criticism — including some from Western Communists — of the conviction here of writers Andrei D. Sinyavsky and Yuli M. Daniel. As the criticism poured in, Soviet officials appeared to be learning again, as they did in the Boris Pasternak case, of the power of the pen to stir international emotions. Mr. Sinyavsky and Mr. Daniel, both 40, were convicted yesterday of ‘‘anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda’’ after a four-day trial and were sentenced to a total of 12 years in a ‘‘strict regime’’ labor camp. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 16, 1966

headline: Benicio Del Toro and Laura Dern Join Cast of New ‘Star Wars’ Film
abstract: The new movie began filming Monday in London, and was scheduled for release in December 2017.
lead_paragraph: Hot on the heels of the record-setting “Star Wars: The Force Awakens,” the next installment of the franchise began filming in London on Monday, with Benicio Del Toro and Laura Dern joining the cast, the Walt Disney Company announced.

headline: Lionel Messi’s Foot Sends Penalty Kick Into Lore
abstract: Instead of blasting his penalty kick into the net on Sunday, Messi, playing for Barcelona, tapped it softly to the right, and Luis Suárez punched it in.
lead_paragraph: Leave it to Lionel Messi to turn a straightforward penalty kick into a breathtaking moment.

headline: Woman Recalls Escape From Brooklyn Fire That Injured 4
abstract: The blaze broke out around 10:20 p.m. Sunday in a three-story residential building and eventually spread to two neighboring buildings.
lead_paragraph: She heard the screams in Polish coming from somewhere nearby — “Fire! Fire!” — and immediately thought of the two young women living next door, asleep on a frigid Sunday night.

headline: Silk Road Market Caters to Lovers of Acceleration, Handling and Plumage
abstract: The market fills with ethnic Uighurs engaged in a frenzied, mercantile display of traditional male bonding. The objects of their attention: pigeons.
lead_paragraph: KASHGAR, China — In many parts of the world, pigeons are an urban pest or, at best, a tasty meal. But here in this storied, ancient outpost near China’s border with Kyrgyzstan, they are much more: a hobby, an investment and, for some, an addiction.

headline: Honolulu Biennial in 2017 to Spotlight Local and International Contemporary Artists
abstract: Isabella Ellaheh Hughes, a co-founder of the first Biennial, called it a chance to highlight “our tremendous local talent.”
lead_paragraph: Hawaii has a population of more than 1.4 million people but not a single museum is dedicated to contemporary art, said Isabella Ellaheh Hughes, a co-founder of the first Honolulu Biennial, which will open in spring 2017.

headline: 8 Recipes for the Week
abstract: Words of wisdom, big-flavor vegetable soups and more for the week ahead.
lead_paragraph: “I work every morning, all morning, sometimes in the afternoons,” the novelist Jim Harrison told Esquire a few years ago. “Then sometimes I hunt in the afternoons — quail, doves, grouse up north — but just to stay alive, because writers die from their lifestyle but also from their lack of movement.”

headline: At Victoria Beckham, Casual Corsets Meet Men’s Wear
abstract: The designer showed a fall/winter 2016 collection that she says reveals her evolving personal style.
lead_paragraph: The designer showed a fall/winter 2016 collection that she says reveals her evolving personal style.

headline: Research Hints at Promise and Difficulty of Helping People With A.D.H.D. Learn
abstract: Two studies looking at the effectiveness of self-testing on a topic instead of restudying it provided mixed results.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few decades, cognitive scientists have found that small alterations in how people study can accelerate and deepen learning, improving retention and comprehension in a range of subjects, including math, science and foreign languages.

headline: South Carolina Church Bridges Racial Gap, but Not Political Divide
abstract: Members of Redemption, based in Greenville, S.C., are proud of their ethnic diversity. But discussion of the state’s presidential primaries? “A taboo,” one woman there said.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — The members of Redemption church, a bracing blend of black and white with a smattering of Latinos, flowed into their arena-size sanctuary on one of the last Sundays before the South Carolina primaries. They prayed side by side in the glow of the animations streaming across a million-dollar video wall. They sang together, arms raised, to carefully calibrated worship music that fused strummy, sentimental rock with melismatic soul. They mingled afterward in the church’s Higher Grounds Café & Coffee Bar, standing in line for chicken-wing lunches.

headline: Slideshow: Off the Runway
abstract: Scenes from the fashion shows during day three of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the fashion shows during day three of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Americans and Dutch Train Senegal Commandos as Fears of Terrorism Grow
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Muslims and Islam', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The exercises come at a time of heightened worries after recent Qaeda attacks at luxury hotels in the capitals of Mali and Burkina Faso.
lead_paragraph: ST.-LOUIS, Senegal — On a hazy afternoon last week, about two dozen Senegalese commandos dressed in dark green camouflage uniforms landed their black Zodiac boats on a sandy beach and clambered ashore, their M-16 rifles at the ready.

headline: An Anti-Corruption Charade in Honduras
abstract: Instead of backing toothless investigations, the U.S. should use its financial leverage against political graft in Central America.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Last spring and summer, huge protests set off by corruption scandals engulfed two Central American nations. In Guatemala, an investigation led by a United Nations-sponsored International Commission Against Impunity exposed a far-reaching customs corruption ring and uncovered evidence that its leader was none other than the country’s president, Otto Pérez Molina. Protests in Guatemala City grew, and in September, Mr. Pérez Molina resigned and was sent to jail to await trial.

headline: Hood by Air’s Shayne Oliver Returns to His American Roots
abstract: Inspired by the past year and a half spent in Italy — and our country’s founding fathers — the designer introduced a fresh yet nostalgic take on his signature streetwear.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the past year and a half spent in Italy — and our country’s founding fathers — the designer introduced a fresh yet nostalgic take on his signature streetwear.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Diane von Furstenberg and Prabal Gurung in Pictures
abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

headline: Scalia’s Supreme Court Seat Has Been Vacant For More Than 400 Days
abstract: Since 1900, the Senate has voted on eight Supreme Court nominees during an election year. Six were confirmed.
lead_paragraph: Since 1900, the Senate has voted on eight Supreme Court nominees during an election year. Six were confirmed.

headline: The St. Petersburg Lottery
abstract: How much would you be willing to play a game in which your expected gain is infinite?
lead_paragraph: This week’s challenge was suggested by Adam Kucharski, a lecturer in mathematical modeling at the London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine, where he studies the dynamics of infectious diseases, particularly emerging infections. Adam is also an award-winning writer, and author of “The Perfect Bet: How Science and Math Are Taking the Luck Out of Gambling,” the story of the mathematicians who make millions by doing the impossible: cracking the code of gambling.

headline: Bard Music Festival Tackles the Puccini Paradox
abstract: The event will examine why he was enormously successful but critically underrated.
lead_paragraph: This summer’s Bard Music Festival will focus on Puccini — whose works will be performed alongside those of his predecessors, contemporaries and successors — to explore the paradox of how he became one of the most successful opera composers of all time despite often being critically underrated.

headline: Life Insurance Made Easy
abstract: The insurance can be complicated and something few like to think about, but buying a simple 20-year term policy is a plan that many can live with.
lead_paragraph: As soon as somebody depends on you financially, you need life insurance.

headline: Carolina Herrera: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Ms. Herrera’s latest designs.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Herrera’s latest designs.

headline: How the Bafta Winners Do (and Don’t) Foretell the Oscars
abstract: ‘The Revenant’ takes five awards, but only the best actress and actor honorees, Leonardo DiCaprio and Brie Larson, are sure bets in Hollywood.
lead_paragraph: Huge surprises out of the British Academy of Film and Television Arts awards Sunday: Leonardo DiCaprio kissed Maggie Smith for the Valentine’s Day kiss cam, but Michael Fassbender would not kiss his girlfriend, Alicia Vikander, creating a moment so awkward that BBC cut it!

headline: Deal on Aviation Emissions Sets Can’t-Miss Goals
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Global Warming', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Last week’s proposed efficiency standard for aircraft emissions is lower than what the industry is on track to achieve anyway in the next decade.
lead_paragraph: If the global goals laid out at the recent Paris climate conference are to be met, curbing aviation emissions is critical. But don’t expect last week’s agreement to set the first standards for airplanes to make a big dent. In fact, it will do little to reduce the rise in emissions from airlines, the fastest-growing source of greenhouse gases responsible for climate change.

headline: Uptown — but Natural — Beauty at Carolina Herrera
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: The look at the fall/winter 2016 show was simultaneously immaculate and soft.
lead_paragraph: “It’s not about ‘she woke up like this,’ or that she did it herself,” said the hairstylist Orlando Pita, referring to the uptown, well-bred beauty persona behind Carolina Herrera’s fall/winter 2016 show. That idea was translated into impeccable blowouts and polished curls with slightly off-center parts. Using Tresemmé Beauty Full Volume Mousse throughout the hair, Pita spread volume evenly for a natural — rather than ‘Dynasty’ — effect. Pita and his team diffused natural frizz out of curly hair — and flatironed straight locks slightly to create a glasslike finish.

headline: Verbatim: John Kasich Suggests Changing Your College Major
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, a Republican candidate for president, talked to college students about possible jobs, and training for jobs in today’s marketplace, at Grand Valley State University in Michigan on Monday.
lead_paragraph: — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, at Grand Valley State University in Allendale, Mich., on Monday, relating the story of a discussion with a political science major — he told the student he knew of lots of available jobs in such studies, eventually, like, at Nordstrom.

headline: 1952 | Scalia, 16, Attacks the Democrats
abstract: A 16-year-old Antonin Scalia first appeared in The Times as a high school debater, attacking the Truman administration.
lead_paragraph: It was a presidential election year and Antonin Scalia figured in it — in a very small way.

headline: U.S.-Owned Plane Carrying Corpse and Cash Is Impounded in Zimbabwe
abstract: The cargo jet, transporting money for the South African Reserve Bank, was seized during a refueling stop after a body dripping blood was found on board.
lead_paragraph: It was supposed to be a routine refueling stop in Zimbabwe by an American-owned cargo plane, traveling to South Africa from Germany. Then airport officials noticed blood spattered on the fuselage and found a corpse and a small fortune in South African cash inside.

headline: New Jersey Mayor’s One-Man Mission to Help Cuban Migrants Draws Scrutiny
abstract: Felix Roque of West New York, N.J., has spent over $200,000 helping more than 150 Cubans en route to the United States, but government officials say he is interfering.
lead_paragraph: Felix Roque was impatient. At the end of December, Dr. Roque, a pain specialist and the mayor of West New York, N.J., canceled his appointments and got on a plane to Costa Rica.

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Spot an Opportunity Amid Market Volatility
keywords: ['Hedge Funds', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Some big-name managers are starting new hedge funds, sensing a chance to make big, bold bets on the volatility in stocks, bonds and commodities.
lead_paragraph: Stock markets are plunging. The price of oil is in turmoil. And hedge funds just came off their worst year since the peak of the financial crisis in 2008.

headline: Wild Tomatoes Repel Whiteflies, Study Finds
abstract: The farm pests attack many domestic crops, but crossbreeding with wild types may help yield insect-resistant varieties, researchers suggest.
lead_paragraph: Whiteflies are the scourge of many farms, damaging tomatoes, peppers, eggplants and other crops. Now, researchers in Britain report that a species of wild tomato is more resistant to the pest than its commercial counterparts.

headline: Tasked With Combating Opium, Afghan Officials Profit From It
abstract: In a peaceful corner of Helmand Province, poppies grow in plain sight, directly taxed by a government ever more deeply involved in the drug trade.
lead_paragraph: GARMSIR, Afghanistan — The United States spent more than $7 billion in the past 14 years to fight the runaway poppy production that has made Afghan opium the world’s biggest brand. Tens of billions more went to governance programs to stem corruption and train a credible police force. Countless more dollars and thousands of lives were lost on the main thrust of the war: to put the Afghan government in charge of district centers and to instill rule of law.

headline: Misha Nonoo and Opening Ceremony Party on Valentine’s Day
abstract: Karolina Kurkova and Caroline Vreeland at Valentine’s Day cocktails; Rosario Dawson and Chinese dragons at Opening Ceremony’s after-party.
lead_paragraph: Karolina Kurkova and Caroline Vreeland at Valentine’s Day cocktails; Rosario Dawson and Chinese dragons at Opening Ceremony’s after-party.

abstract: Karolina Kurkova and Caroline Vreeland at Valentine’s Day cocktails; Rosario Dawson and Chinese dragons at Opening Ceremony’s after-party.
lead_paragraph: Misha Nonoo and Alexander Gilkes hosted a Valentine’s party at their Greenwich Village home Sunday night. The Brazilian model Lais Ribeiro and her mom posed in the heart-shaped photo booth.

headline: Ted Cruz Ad Goes After Donald Trump’s Stance on Planned Parenthood
abstract: The Texas senator’s campaign is trying a new line of attack against Mr. Trump for his generally favorable view of Planned Parenthood.
lead_paragraph: Ted Cruz’s campaign has opened a new line of criticism against Donald J. Trump, running an ad called “Currency” for Mr. Trump’s positions in favor of Planned Parenthood.

headline: Your Daily Fashion Week Recap for Monday, Feb. 15
abstract: A Hood by Air pilgrimage, Opening Ceremony x Syd Mead and more.
lead_paragraph: 1. Hood by Air’s Shayne Oliver brought a hodgepodge of materials to the runway — including fur, leather (regular and patent), plastic wrap, rubber and bag tags — for the brand’s fall/winter 2016 show, titled “Pilgrimage.” “I’ve been trying to create new silhouettes that bring HBA more into a fashion context,” the designer said. See more photos from the show.

headline: Q. and A.: Steps Toward Settling Puerto Rico’s Debt
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Answers to questions about Puerto Rico’s debt and possible default.
lead_paragraph: How much of Puerto Rico’s overall debt is because of the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority?

headline: Pro-Jeb Bush Group Cancels Some Advertising in Super Tuesday States
keywords: ['Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush that has dominated the ad-spending battle so far, has canceled up to a third of its ad reservations in March 1 primary states, according to media buying sources.
lead_paragraph: Right to Rise, the “super PAC” supporting Jeb Bush that has dominated the ad-spending battle so far, has canceled up to a third of its ad reservations in March 1 primary states, according to media buying sources.

headline: At Puerto Rico’s Power Company, a Recipe for Toxic Air, and Debt
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Air Pollution', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances']
abstract: For years, Abraham Ortiz, of Puerto Rico’s power authority, reported that it bought oil that failed to meet clean-air standards. He was ignored.
lead_paragraph: As a lab director at Puerto Rico’s power authority, Abraham Ortiz uncovered what he suspected was a pattern of lawlessness in the authority’s purchasing department, a secretive place where officials controlled contracts to buy billions of dollars’ worth of oil.

headline: Meet Dôen — a Breezy, Bohemian New Brand
abstract: The direct-to-consumer, contemporary line stocks casual staples inspired by the founders’ Santa Barbara upbringing.
lead_paragraph: The direct-to-consumer, contemporary line stocks casual staples inspired by the founders’ Santa Barbara upbringing.

headline: Ted Cruz Calls Donald Trump’s Sister, a Judge, an ‘Extremist’
abstract: Senator Ted Cruz took aim on Monday at the judicial record of Donald J. Trump’s sister, calling her a “radical pro-abortion extremist” unfit for the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: AIKEN, S.C. — Senator Ted Cruz took aim on Monday at the judicial record of Donald J. Trump’s sister, calling her a “radical pro-abortion extremist” unfit for the Supreme Court.

headline: A New, Bohemian Line — with Empowerment Built In
abstract: The sisters behind Dôen, launching today, say their “sourcing philosophy is about doing things mindfully.”
lead_paragraph: When both Margaret Kleveland and her sister Katherine had children within the space of just over a year, it quickly became clear to them that their corporate jobs in fashion weren’t going to cut it any longer. “We had always talked about starting a label together, but it was always one of those things we thought would happen down the road,” says Katherine, who formerly served as the Executive Vice President of Design at Joie. It wasn’t until Margaret, who worked in design and development at B&B footwear design, had a son in the summer of 2015 that the two women decided to finally launch their brand. “We had a phone conversation and we were just like, ‘It’s time, let’s do it.’”

headline: The Author Pat Conroy Announces He Has Pancreatic Cancer
abstract: The “Prince of Tides” novelist says he plans “to fight it hard.”
lead_paragraph: The lyrical Southern novelist Pat Conroy, whose books include “The Prince of Tides” and “The Great Santini,” announced Monday that he had pancreatic cancer.

headline: What Would Scalia Want in His Successor? A Dissent Offers Clues
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: In a passage from his dissent from the Supreme Court’s decision in June on same-sex marriage, Justice Antonin Scalia criticized the court’s lack of diversity.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What sort of person would Justice Antonin Scalia have wanted President Obama to name as his successor? We know more than you might think.

headline: Colorado Planned Parenthood Clinic Reopens After Deadly Attack
abstract: That attack in November, by a gunman who is now in custody, left three people dead and caused the clinic in Colorado Springs, Colo., to close for almost three months.
lead_paragraph: COLORADO SPRINGS — The Planned Parenthood clinic attacked in November by a gunman professing anti-abortion views reopened on Monday with a packed schedule of patients and no end to the pressures on it: Two protesters stood nearby, holding signs and accusing the organization of harming women and killing babies.

headline: The Corset Comeback
abstract: At New York Fashion Week, a telling handful of designers are romancing the corse. Here are some examples.
lead_paragraph: At New York Fashion Week, a telling handful of designers are romancing the corse. Here are some examples.

headline: The Corset: Back in Form
abstract: At New York Fashion Week, the corset has been revived from its yearslong fainting spell.
lead_paragraph: Victoria Beckham slashed and sliced it; Rihanna laced it up like a high-top sneaker at Fenty x Puma; Laura Vassar and Kristopher Brock of the Brock Collection rendered their version in courtly brocade.

headline: Our Brains Remember the Good Stuff
abstract: Researchers have found that the human brain is attracted to things that were once pleasing, but no longer are.
lead_paragraph: The human brain is attracted to things that were once pleasing even if they no longer are, researchers report. Study participants were asked to find red and green objects on a computer screen filled with different colored objects. They received small rewards for finding the objects: $1.50 for the red ones and 25 cents for the green ones.

headline: Tommy Hilfiger: Fall 2016
abstract: Mr. Hilfiger’s latest fall looks.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Hilfiger’s latest fall looks.

headline: Grammys 2016: Highlights and Analysis
abstract: Taylor Swift’s “1989” won album of the year, and Mark Ronson and Bruno Mars took home the prize for record of the year. Kendrick Lamar swept the rap categories.

headline: Future Earns His Third Straight No. 1 With ‘EVOL’
abstract: The LP, which was available only through Apple Music and iTunes for its first week, sold the equivalent of 134,000 albums.
lead_paragraph: For the third time in less than seven months, Future is on top.

headline: Opening Ceremony Sees the Future. And It Hovers.
abstract: Humberto Leon and Carol Lim’s unexpected inspiration: space-farming.
lead_paragraph: Trend proposals come flying down the runway during New York Fashion Week at incredible speed, but even among that melee, “hydroponic space agriculture” is bound to stand out.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Reimagined Check
abstract: Suno, Victoria Beckham and Jason Wu have reinterpreted the classic print.
lead_paragraph: As we hit the halfway point of New York Fashion Week, a few trends have begun to emerge: Several runways have featured playful check prints — recast every which way. At Suno, a beautiful jacket and pleated skirt came in muted tartan; at Victoria Beckham, where many looks included woven jackets, a checkered dress with cutouts was a standout. Jason Wu, meanwhile, showed a navy coat that recalled parochial school — but elevated with yellow and gray stripes.

headline: Congress Girds for What It Loves Most: A Battle Royal Over Supreme Court Pick
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: With the ideological tilt of the nation’s highest court at stake, Congress, and the presidential campaigns, have a major issue to fight over.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The outbreak of political conflict over whether the Senate should even consider President Obama’s choice to replace Justice Antonin Scalia on the Supreme Court jolted awake a capital that was settling in for a sleepy, humdrum year in the shadow of the raucous and unpredictable presidential campaign.

headline: Review: Cleveland Orchestra Plays Mozart, and to Its Strengths
abstract: This ensemble, led by Mitsuko Uchida, displayed clarity and a warm cohesion in a program at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Less than a month after bringing an astonishing, hair-trigger program to Carnegie Hall — a wintry new vocal cycle by Hans Abrahamsen and a sensitive yet turbocharged Shostakovich performance — the Cleveland Orchestra returned on Sunday with something completely different.

headline: Grand Central Terminal Goes Dark After Power Failure
abstract: A Metropolitan Transportation Authority spokesman said a water pipe had burst, cutting power to the lower level of the terminal. Shops and restaurants were closed, but trains kept running.
lead_paragraph: It could have been a set from a zombie movie, hulking forms emerging from shrouded subway stairs, wandering aimlessly into the light. Hungry and confused.

headline: Letters From Pope John Paul II Show Deep Friendship With Woman
abstract: Newly released letters that the future Pope John Paul II wrote to an American philosopher, Anna-Teresa Tymieniecka, portray a startling affection.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — The future Pope John Paul II, Karol Wojtyla, began a friendship with a Polish-American philosopher in 1973 that lasted the rest of his life. She hosted him when he visited New England and translated a book of his, and they stayed in touch, off and on, until his death in 2005.

headline: Donald Trump Calls Ted Cruz ‘Unstable’ and ‘Dishonest’
abstract: Liar. Liar. Nuts. Unstable. Liar. Those words made up the rosary of attacks that Donald J. Trump hung around Senator Ted Cruz in in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Liar. Liar. Nuts. Unstable. Liar.

headline: Starting Windows 10 Without a Password
abstract: You can automatically sign into Windows 10 without having to type in your password every time, but make sure your computer is in a secure location.
lead_paragraph: Q. Can I change the settings on my Windows 10 laptop so that I don’t have to enter a password every time I start the computer?

headline: More Republicans Say They’ll Block Supreme Court Nominee
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: G.O.P. senators appeared to be supporting the call of their majority leader to let the next president pick Justice Antonin Scalia’s successor.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Monday began to close ranks behind a vow by Senator Mitch McConnell, the majority leader, to block consideration of any nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia, who died over the weekend, for the remainder of President Obama’s term.

headline: Verbatim: Donald Trump on Dreamers
abstract: Donald J. Trump referred to the children of undocumented immigrants at a news conference in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: — Donald J. Trump, referring to the children of undocumented immigrants at a news conference in South Carolina.

headline: Ads From Pro-Cruz Group Attacking Marco Rubio Are Pulled in South Carolina
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The ad from Stand for Truth, the “super PAC” supporting Mr. Cruz, attacks Mr. Rubio’s record on immigration.
lead_paragraph: Television stations in South Carolina have pulled an ad from Stand for Truth, the “super PAC” supporting Senator Ted Cruz, after a legal review.

headline: No Comment Necessary: Mitch McConnell on the Supreme Court, Then and Now
abstract: Senator McConnell’s views on Supreme Court nominees appear to have changed a lot over the years.
lead_paragraph: Mitch McConnell, Feb. 13, 2016: “The American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court justice. Therefore, this vacancy should not be filled until we have a new president.”

headline: By Phone, James Dobson Tells South Carolinians Ted Cruz Is Only Alternative to Donald Trump
abstract: Some South Carolina voters received a recorded phone call on Sunday from James C. Dobson, the evangelical leader, calling Ted Cruz the only real alternative to Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. – In a recorded phone message made to South Carolina voters on Sunday night, James C. Dobson, the evangelical leader, called on Republicans to support Senator Ted Cruz for president as the only real alternative to Donald J. Trump.

headline: A New Culprit in Lyme Disease
abstract: Researchers have discovered a second bacterium that may cause the condition.
lead_paragraph: Mosquitoes may be receiving all the attention amid the Zika virus epidemic, but they are hardly the only disease vectors to worry about. Researchers at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., have discovered a new species of tick-borne bacteria that causes Lyme disease.

headline: 40 Trillion Bacteria on and in Us? Fewer Than We Thought.
abstract: The oft-repeated 10-to-1 ratio of microbes to human cells was unrealistic, researchers say. The numbers of microbes and human cells are about the same.
lead_paragraph: There are a lot of bacteria on us and in us — our microbiome, it is called. Calculating exactly how many microbes each of us carries is hard, and the most common number cited, both in popular and scientific literature, is almost certainly wrong.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers respond to articles in Science Times.
lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR:

headline: Sies Marjan, New York Fashion Week’s Most Buzzed-About Debut, Turns Its Back on Black
abstract: The designer’s first show, in an expansive, under-construction penthouse in TriBeCa, dominated the week’s chatter almost immediately.
lead_paragraph: It takes a certain amount of élan to make a goatskin coat, a double duchesse satin blouse, capri-length cargo pants and stamped-croc slip-ons in a yellow so bright it could make the sun blush.

headline: Emmy Rossum is So Happy to Be Home, Despite the Dirt Floor
abstract: In the garden of the Frick, the actress was wearing one dress by designer Carolina Herrera but had her eye on another.
lead_paragraph: It was snowing Monday morning, but inside the Frick, where Carolina Herrera presented her fall 2016 collection that morning, a flurry of starlets were sporting barely-there clothes for far warmer climes. Emmy Rossum, for one, wore a sleeveless floral-print tea dress in pale pink from Mrs. Herrera’s spring 2016 collection, and answered some questions.

headline: Cornell’s Plan to Merge Hotel School Gets an Icy Reception
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Business Schools']
abstract: Alumni and students reacted with annoyance after a vote to fold the world’s oldest undergraduate program devoted to the hospitality industry into a new business college.
lead_paragraph: ITHACA, N.Y. — They call themselves “hotelies”: students and alumni of the Cornell University School of Hotel Administration, the world’s oldest undergraduate program devoted to the hospitality industry and, many say, the best.

headline: ‘A Doubter’s Almanac,’ Ethan Canin’s Latest Novel, Has Real-Life Parallels
abstract: Mr. Canin used his own drive and success to help color the protagonist in his latest book.
lead_paragraph: Ethan Canin was shopping at a grocery store in Iowa City recently, when he paused to marvel at a neatly stacked pyramid of oranges. To Mr. Canin, the pile of fruit perfectly illustrated the Kepler conjecture, a 17th-century mathematical premise about the most efficient way to stack spherical objects. Mathematicians have wrestled with the conjecture for centuries, but the store clerk had solved the problem intuitively.

headline: Getting People to Exercise Requires the Right Incentive
abstract: People will exercise more if you give them money — but only if they are paid in the right way.
lead_paragraph: People will exercise more if you give them money — but only if they are paid in the right way.

headline: Yolanda Foster: Watching Her Daughter Gigi Hadid From the Front Row
abstract: The former model talks about her daughter’s appearance at Tommy Hilfiger, her battle with Lyme disease and what’s next for her.
lead_paragraph: Yolanda Foster, the mother of Gigi Hadid and a former model herself, was at the Park Avenue Armory on Monday, watching from the front row as her daughter walked in the Tommy Hilfiger show.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Tommy Hilfiger
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Jewels and Jewelry', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: T plucks the best jewels right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Tommy Hilfiger’s paste and pearl drop earrings look as precious as a family heirloom — but are a whole lot more fun. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

headline: North Korea Leader Should Be Told He Could Face Trial, U.N. Official Says
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The official, Marzuki Darusman, also said the United Nations should create a panel to identify ways of prosecuting North Koreans for heinous crimes.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — A United Nations human rights investigator said in a report released Monday that the organization should officially notify North Korea’s top leader, Kim Jong-un, that he and subordinates could face trial for heinous crimes. The investigator also recommended the creation of an expert panel to identify ways of prosecuting them.

headline: Steven Stucky, Composer Who Won a Pulitzer, Dies at 66
abstract: Mr. Stucky was associated with the Los Angeles Philharmonic as composer in residence for more than 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Steven Stucky, a Pulitzer Prize-winning American composer whose work was widely commissioned by major orchestras around the world and who earned respect as a conductor, teacher and author, died on Sunday at his home in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 66.

headline: Review: Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane’s ‘Body Against Body,’ Through a Fresh Lens
abstract: Performing at Queens Theater, the dancers moved from tender beauty to sensuality to gusto.
lead_paragraph: “Isn’t it true,” a woman seated behind me asked after a performance by the Bill T. Jones/Arnie Zane Dance Company, “that the definition of dance is moving to music?” That’s a question you’re unlikely to hear at New York Live Arts, where the Jones/Zane troupe has its home, but the company was on tour — at Queens Theater, in Corona — a destination easily reached from Manhattan and yet distant enough from downtown to shift your perspective on “Body Against Body,” a program of duets created 20 to 30 years ago.

headline: Champions League Returns With Teams Shifting Priorities Up a Notch
abstract: For Paris St.-Germain and several other teams, the European season now takes precedence over domestic concerns.
lead_paragraph: Paris St.-Germain has played 38 games in various competitions this season. But its current campaign shifts into a new stage — some would argue its most important stage — with the start of the Champions League knockout rounds on Tuesday.

headline: Review: Art and Nature Blend in a Concert by Contemporaneous
abstract: From primal drumming to musical sculpture, this ensemble did not fail to deliver intensity.
lead_paragraph: A bitter wind off the harbor on Thursday evening kept making creaking and popping sounds emerge from the garage door that defines one wall of Pioneer Works, the Red Hook, Brooklyn, warehouse converted into a sprawling art space in 2012.

headline: Unusual Molecules Shine Light on New Applications
abstract: The discovery of molecules that light up only when close together has led to advances in areas like TVs and fluorescent technology for the human body.
lead_paragraph: Ben Zhong Tang was stumped. A chemist at the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, he was looking at a powder that glowed bright green under ultraviolet light. But when the powder was dissolved in a clear solution, the glow disappeared.

headline: Recalling Scalia, a Literary Stylist Who Scorned ‘Jiggery-Pokery’
abstract: Talking with Yury Kapgan, an intellectual-property lawyer who analyzed the justice’s prose in a journal article titled “Of Golf and Ghouls.”
lead_paragraph: The legal opinions of Justice Antonin Scalia, who died on Saturday after nearly 30 years on the Supreme Court, have long received attention as much for their elegant, learned and often scathing style as for their staunchly conservative substance.

headline: Review: In ‘Funny Girl,’ Sheridan Smith Does the Heavy Lifting
abstract: In this revival, Ms. Smith plays Fanny Brice, the role that sent Barbra Streisand soaring into the stratosphere in the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “When you’re gifted, then you’re gifted,” sings Fanny Brice in the hit revival of “Funny Girl,” currently enjoying a sold-out run at the small but mighty Menier Chocolate Factory before transferring to the West End in April. Since Fanny is portrayed by Sheridan Smith in Michael Mayer’s dutiful production of this 1964 biomusical, no one is likely to challenge such a self-assessment.

headline: Review: Maxwell’s Sensual R&B Makes a Big Room Intimate
abstract: This singer’s seductive style, which catapulted him to stardom the 1990s, was on full display in a concert at the Barclays Center.
lead_paragraph: From the stage of Barclays Center on Sunday night — Valentine’s Day — Maxwell urged, “I want all of the couples who came tonight to procreate this evening,” answered by cheers and laughter. Seven years after releasing his latest album and five years after his previous New York City concert, Maxwell was ready to resume his career as one of R&B’s most elegant accessories to seduction.

headline: ‘Embrace of the Serpent,’ Ciro Guerra’s Searching Tale About Invaded Amazon Cultures
abstract: Wary of the jungle’s pitfalls, a Colombian director consulted a shaman about whether the rain forest would welcome his filming.
lead_paragraph: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — In 1979 the German director Werner Herzog set out into the Peruvian Amazon to begin filming “Fitzcarraldo,” the quixotic tale of an Irish rubber baron’s quest to build an opera house in the jungle.

lead_paragraph: Mr. Scott’s latest collection.

lead_paragraph: As Barneys returns to its downtown Manhattan roots, notable shoppers reminisce about their first big purchase at the store.

abstract: Scenes from the fifth day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the fifth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Review: ‘The Right Kind of Crazy,’ on the Team That Landed the Mars Rover Curiosity

lead_paragraph: When the Mars rover Curiosity stuck its landing on the red planet on Aug. 6, 2012, it not only opened a new era of space exploration and a bright new door to NASA’s future, but it also signified a triumph of human ingenuity over staggering odds.

headline: No Mention of ‘Birther’ Debate as Donald Trump Woos Blacks in South Carolina
abstract: Mr. Trump appears to be hoping that any memory of his 2011 demand to see the birth certificate of the nation’s first black president is a distant one in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump, looking to amass as many votes as possible in the South Carolina primary, is increasingly trying to appeal to the state’s black voters. In doing so, he appears to hope that any memory of his 2011 demand to see the birth certificate of the nation’s first black president is a distant one.

Bush administration had “lied” in the buildup to the invasion of Iraq in 2003, the conservative radio host Rush Limbaugh said that Mr. Trump had used the language of Democrats to attack the former president.

headline: Review: Vox Luminis Explores Bach’s Family Tree
abstract: “The Bach Dynasty,” at the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, near Times Square, was an offering from the Miller Theater’s Early Music series.
lead_paragraph: That Bach came from hardy compositional stock is well known. But the actual music of his forebears remains obscure.

headline: Police Investigating Claim Eliot Spitzer Choked Woman in Plaza Hotel
abstract: Law enforcement officials said the woman made the claim to hospital employees, but Mr. Spitzer’s lawyer said she retracted it.
lead_paragraph: Eliot Spitzer, who resigned as governor of New York in 2008 amid reports that he was a client of a high-priced prostitution ring, is now at the center of a new criminal investigation, according to officials, after a 26-year-old woman said he choked her when they were alone in a room at the Plaza Hotel.

headline: Group Backing Ted Cruz Makes $573,000 Ad Buy in Nevada
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Keep the Promise I said it would also increase its field operations in the state, as Mr. Cruz and his allies hope to capitalize on Donald J. Trump’s perceived weakness in ground organization.
lead_paragraph: The most prominent “super PAC” supporting Ted Cruz said on Monday that it was placing a $573,000 ad buy in Nevada and boosting its field operations in the state.

headline: Review: In ‘Drunken With What,’ a Streamlined ‘Mourning Becomes Electra’
abstract: Deconstructing Eugene O’Neill’s take on Aeschylus’ “Oresteia” cycle, Target Margin mostly strips the stage and places the audience at a remove.
lead_paragraph: Eugene O’Neill had some difficulty settling on a form and a style for the trilogy of plays that would constitute “Mourning Becomes Electra,” his 1931 adaptation of Aeschylus’ “The Oresteia.” He tried verse, he tried masks; he tried abandoning the play entirely and writing a life of Aeschylus instead. The script ultimately blended Greek tragedy with Yankee mythos, Freudian theory with melodrama. Hailed as a masterpiece in its day, it is a lot less popular now.

headline: R.N.C. Disputes Donald Trump’s Claim on Debate Being Stacked With Donors
abstract: The Republican National Committee said only 10 tickets for the debate on Saturday went to donors, which meant the boos Mr. Trump heard must have come from elsewhere in the audience of 1,600.
lead_paragraph: The Republican National Committee is pushing back against Donald J. Trump’s claim that the jeers that serenaded him during the presidential debate on Saturday were from an audience stacked with big money donors.

headline: In Supreme Court Vacancy, Ted Cruz Senses an Opening
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia has given the Texas senator a chance to warn of a future with meager gun rights and “unlimited abortion.”
lead_paragraph: AIKEN, S.C. — A conservative titan. A judicial morass. A Senate showdown with President Obama.

headline: U.S. Closing a Loophole on Products Tied to Slaves
keywords: ['Fishing, Commercial', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Human Trafficking', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: President Obama will close a loophole this week that allowed fish caught by forced labor into the American market, part of a flurry of recent actions to address lawlessness at sea.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama will sign legislation this week that effectively bans American imports of fish caught by forced labor in Southeast Asia, part of a flurry of recent actions by the White House, federal agencies, international trade unions and foreign governments to address lawlessness at sea and to better protect offshore workers and the marine environment.

headline: What Planners of Brooklyn-Queens Streetcar Line Can Learn in New Jersey
abstract: The Hudson-Bergen Light Rail, across the river from New York City, offers a look at the benefits and challenges of a street-level transit line.
lead_paragraph: HOBOKEN, N.J. — With Mayor Bill de Blasio proposing a streetcar line from Brooklyn to Queens, city planners do not have to search far for an example of a similar system to help guide them.

headline: Yemen: Embattled City at Risk of Famine, United Nations Warns
abstract: Combatants have prevented aid groups from delivering emergency supplies, the United Nations said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Taiz, a city that has come under siege in the nearly year-old Yemen conflict, are one step away from famine because combatants have prevented aid groups from delivering emergency supplies, the United Nations said on Monday. The World Food Program, the organization’s anti-hunger agency, said it had managed to send some aid into Taiz over the weekend, but described the shipment as a “one-off delivery” that would feed only 3,000 families for a month. Taiz residents are now among roughly 7.6 million people in Yemen who are classified as “severely food insecure” — a condition in the five-point Integrated Food Security Phase Classification scale just above famine level.

headline: Bahrain: 4 Journalists Detained
keywords: ['News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: Press freedom advocates protested to Bahrain over the arrest of four American journalists who had been reporting on the fifth anniversary of the political opposition uprising in the Gulf monarchy.
lead_paragraph: Press freedom advocates protested to Bahrain on Monday over the arrest of four American journalists who had been reporting on the fifth anniversary of the political opposition uprising in the Gulf monarchy, an ally of the United States. The Bahrain authorities, who seized the four on Sunday, did not identify them by name, but the family of one identified her as Anna Therese Day, a freelance journalist and Fulbright Fellow who has reported for The Huffington Post and other media outlets. The Bahrain police website said the four were suspected of having entered Bahrain illegally and “participating in an unlawful gathering.” The Committee to Protect Journalists in New York called for their immediate release.

headline: Israel: Ex-Prime Minister Begins Prison Term for Bribery Conviction
abstract: Ehud Olmert, who was convicted in 2014, begins a 19-month term for bribery and obstruction of justice.
lead_paragraph: Describing his fall as “painful and strange,” Ehud Olmert became on Monday the first former Israeli prime minister to enter prison, beginning a 19-month term for bribery and obstruction of justice. In a video released by his office shortly before the armored car carrying him swept through the prison gates, Mr. Olmert, 70, who was convicted in 2014, acknowledged that he had “made mistakes,” but he insisted that he had done nothing criminal. Looking somber and fatigued, Mr. Olmert remarked: “I accept the sentence with a very heavy heart. Nobody stands above the law.”

headline: Lincoln Memorial to Get Major Renovation
abstract: David M. Rubenstein will fund most of a project that will include cleaning, repairing earthquake damage and building space for educational programs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Lincoln Memorial will undergo some of its most extensive renovations to date, the National Park Service said on Monday, including efforts to wash away dirt and debris, repair damage sustained during a 2011 earthquake, and build a substantial space for educational programs under the memorial.

headline: Leo Van Munching Jr., Empire Builder for Heineken, Dies at 89
abstract: Mr. Van Munching went to work for his father’s company in the 1950s and expanded the Heineken brand, and by 1971, it accounted for 41 percent of all imported beer sales in the country.
lead_paragraph: Leo Van Munching Jr., whose stewardship of the importing company started by his father made the Dutch-brewed beer Heineken and its low-calorie sibling, Amstel Light, familiar brand names in the United States, died on Sunday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 89.

headline: An Asia Summit Meeting Is Overshadowed by Scalia
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: President Obama laid out a full agenda of economic and security issues, led by the tensions with China over its aggressive reclamation of land on disputed reefs and islands in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — President Obama welcomed the leaders of 10 Southeast Asian countries to this desert oasis for a summit meeting on Monday, giving him another chance to shine a spotlight on one of his most ambitious geopolitical projects: the “pivot” to Asia.

headline: In Queens, Broadcasting Banter From a Bar in a Garage
abstract: Five middle-age men take to the airwaves weekly for “Live From the Barrage,” a radio show and podcast that covers an eclectic mix of music, sports and typical tavern chatter.
lead_paragraph: It was Friday night again, and the men trickled in — Brian, Ryan, Pat and Tommy — and joined their friend John at a bar lined with ashtrays, shot glasses and bottles of Irish whiskey.

headline: At Mass, Pope Francis Embraces ‘Misunderstood’ of Mexico
abstract: Francis invoked the harsh treatment endured by indigenous people and called for social justice.
lead_paragraph: SAN CRISTÓBAL DE LAS CASAS, Mexico — Pope Francis came to the highlands of Mexico’s southern frontier on Monday to offer a pastoral embrace to the region’s impoverished indigenous people, expressing shame over discrimination and exploitation and honoring the legacy of a beloved local bishop who once clashed with the Mexican government — and the Vatican.

headline: Saying Farewell to David Frei, Westminster’s Nuzzling Voice
abstract: Frei, a comforting fixture for TV viewers for more than a quarter-century, is calling his final Westminster dog show.
lead_paragraph: David Frei’s voice has become as familiar as the woof of a beloved family pet during his 26 years as the lead commentator of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show. Clad in a tuxedo, he re-enters the lives of dog enthusiasts each February for two nights of prime-time canine analysis and storytelling.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10, Episode 5: Mulder’s Magic Mushrooms
abstract: The penultimate episode features terrorists, drugs and line dancing.
lead_paragraph: “The X-Files” took inspiration from a variety of sources this week in a slow-starting episode that ended up being quite enjoyable and ultimately a little heartbreaking. We saw Mulder dancing shirtless and communicating with the near dead and Scully mentoring a younger agent who bore more than a passing resemblance to Mulder.

headline: ‘A Crisis Every Day’ for the Mayor Trying to Rescue Atlantic City
abstract: Donald Guardian, who became mayor the same year four casinos closed, is struggling to reduce the city’s expenses as state leaders craft a way forward.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — Even a short list of the troubles that have befallen this fading seaside resort since Donald Guardian was elected mayor would make anyone wonder why he got himself into this mess.

headline: Kendrick Lamar Sweeps Rap Field at Grammys; Taylor Swift Wins Best Album
abstract: Mr. Lamar, with 11 nominations in nine categories, took home five prizes over all, while Ms. Swift won for “1989.”
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The 58th annual Grammy Awards on Monday celebrated a young generation of chart-dominating pop stars, with Taylor Swift winning album of the year for “1989” and Kendrick Lamar sweeping the rap categories, even as the show devoted much of its airtime to lionizing musical heroes of decades past.

headline: ‘Real Clothes on Real Girls’: Diane von Furstenberg’s Immersive Experience
abstract: The designer showed her latest collection in her Manhattan headquarters, with models playing out different everyday scenarios.
lead_paragraph: “Real clothes on real girls.” That was how Diane von Furstenberg described the idea behind her fall … well, call it an immersive experience: the fashion equivalent of the theatrical trend embodied by “Then She Fell” and “Sleep No More.”

headline: Jeb Bush, With Assist From George, Goes After Donald Trump
abstract: The Bush family, a dynasty that defined Republicanism for decades, clashed on Monday with the new and irreverent face of the party, Donald J. Trump, in one of the most powerful collisions of the primary campaign so far.
lead_paragraph: NORTH CHARLESTON, S.C. — The Bush family, a dynasty that defined Republicanism for decades, clashed on Monday with the new and irreverent face of the party, Donald J. Trump, in one of the most vivid and powerful confrontations in the presidential primary campaign so far.

headline: A New Season for the Mets’ Matt Harvey, but One Pitch Is Hard to Shake Off
abstract: For Harvey, the coming months represent a new chapter in his career. He should be free of the innings limits and pitch counts that hung over him at times last season.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Matt Harvey had a quiet off-season, for the most part. He took some time to rest, attended a bunch of Knicks and Rangers games and began working out at Scott Boras’s training facility in California, trying to make sure his right arm would be strong and durable as he heads into his second full season following Tommy John surgery.

headline: Dispute With New York City Threatens Success Academy’s Pre-K
abstract: A critical deadline passed in a dispute between the charter school network and the de Blasio administration over the network’s prekindergarten program, leaving its fate in doubt.
lead_paragraph: A critical deadline passed on Monday in a dispute between Success Academy charter schools and the de Blasio administration over the charter school network’s prekindergarten program, leaving its fate in doubt.

headline: How to Bring the Supreme Court Back Down to Earth
keywords: ['Appeals Courts (US)', 'Federal Courts (US)', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: In nominating Justice Antonin Scalia’s successor, President Obama has a chance to reconnect the court with the people it is supposed to serve.
lead_paragraph: Seven of the eight justices on the Supreme Court today all come from the federal appeals courts. (So did Justice Antonin Scalia, who died Saturday.) Only Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who was a judge in California, served outside the East Coast cities of Boston, New York, Philadelphia and Washington. All eight attended law school at Harvard or Yale. None ever held elected office. Today’s court is “in some ways the most insulated and homogenous in American history,” as Adam Liptak wrote in 2009.

headline: Before Scalia’s Death, a Clash Between G.O.P. and Obama Over Appellate Judges
keywords: ['Federal Courts (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Since Republicans took control of the Senate, the confirmation process for President Obama’s nominees to the 12 regional federal courts of appeal has essentially been halted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The vow by Senate Republicans to block whomever President Obama nominates to fill the sudden vacancy on the Supreme Court presages a prolonged election year struggle, but the clash is less a new front against the White House than an escalation of a battle that had begun at the appeals court level before Justice Antonin Scalia died.

headline: Opera Philadelphia Will Mount ‘Breaking the Waves’ Adaptation
abstract: The production will be part of a season of notable projects including a “Macbeth” set in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: “Breaking the Waves,” a new chamber opera by Missy Mazzoli with a libretto by Royce Vavrek that is based on the psychosexual 1996 Lars von Trier film of the same name, will be given its world premiere in September by Opera Philadelphia, the company announced Tuesday.

headline: Borzoi, Bulldog, German Shepherd and Shih Tzu Are Group Winners
abstract: The dogs were chosen from the hound, nonsporting, herding and toy groups during the first night of judging at the Westminster show.
lead_paragraph: The first night of judging at the 140th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show produced winners in four groups Monday at Madison Square Garden. A borzoi named Lucy was first among the hounds; Panda, a Shih Tzu, was named the top toy; Annabelle, a serene bulldog, was selected as the best in the nonsporting group; and Rumor, a German shepherd who was the top dog heading into the show, won the herding group.

lead_paragraph: To belt, to dance, to rap or to mourn? The 58th annual Grammy Awards cycled through those modes on Monday night in its live broadcast from the Staples Center.

abstract: For the past ten years, Mindaugas Kavaliauskas has been zipping through airports, traveling extensively to produce photography events. He eventually slowed down, capturing the beauty in moments of familiarity. The following captions for the slideshow were provided by the photographer.

headline: E-Commerce: Convenience Built on a Mountain of Cardboard
keywords: ['E-Commerce', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Containers and Packaging', 'Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Delivery Services', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fuel Efficiency']
abstract: Delivery services now come through in hours, not days. But the boxes after boxes generated create environmental concerns, and some guilt.
lead_paragraph: Ruchit Garg, a Silicon Valley entrepreneur, says that he worries that something isn’t right with his Internet shopping habit. With each new delivery to his doorstep — sometimes several in a day — he faces the source of his guilt and frustration: another cardboard box.

headline: Transgender Patients Face Challenges at the Hospital
abstract: From medical issues to roommates, transgender patients face barriers to good health care. Some institutions are trying to change that.
lead_paragraph: After a skiing accident in January left him with a smashed knee, Beck Bailey, a transgender man in Greenfield, Mass., spent 15 days in a Vermont hospital undergoing a handful of surgeries. As part of his normal routine, Mr. Bailey gives himself regular shots of testosterone. But the endocrinologist on duty in Vermont told him that patients should not take testosterone post surgery.

headline: A Frequent Flyer’s Photos of Air Travel
abstract: For the past ten years, Mindaugas Kavaliauskas has been zipping through airports, traveling extensively to produce photography events. He eventually slowed down, capturing the beauty in moments of familiarity.
lead_paragraph: Mindaugas Kavaliauskas grew up in Lithuania when it was still a part of the Soviet Union and he remembers flying as a teenager to Moscow to see his grandmother in the 1980s. Air travel seemed “a matter of privilege, luxury.” And now? Well, he has used the word “bus” more than once.

headline: The Chirp Heard Across the Universe
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Science and Technology', 'Gravitation and Gravity', 'Physics', 'Research']
abstract: The discovery of a sound from a billion years ago bolstered a theory of Einstein’s, and it underscores the importance of pursuing our own curiosity.
lead_paragraph: The faint chirp detected by what must be two of the largest and most sensitive microphones ever made — a brief, rising tone from gravitational waves generated by an immeasurably powerful collision of two black holes a billion years ago — has engendered a number of articles about why we should concern ourselves, and by extension dedicate so many resources, to exploring an event so distant in time and space. Various justifications have been offered, from lists of the practical benefits of past discoveries that seemed useless when they were made, to the metaphysical notion that the better we understand our universe, the better we understand ourselves.

headline: In Election Years, a History of Confirming Court Nominees
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Constitution (US)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Even unpopular or lame duck presidents successfully carried out their constitutional duties to fill Supreme Court vacancies during election seasons.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — “THE American people should have a voice in the selection of their next Supreme Court justice,” Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the Republican majority leader, announced after news of Justice Antonin Scalia’s death. “Therefore, this vacancy should not be filled until we have a new president.” Many of the Republican presidential contenders have heartily endorsed this argument.

headline: How the Coal Industry Flattened the Mountains of Appalachia
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Water Pollution', 'Mountains', 'Mountaintop Removal Mining', 'Water', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Coal']
abstract: The destructive coal mining process known as mountaintop removal is leaving behind a grossly disfigured landscape.
lead_paragraph: As the destructive coal mining process known as mountaintop removal ebbs in Appalachia, it is leaving behind what amounts to its own grim field of tombstones: A grossly disfigured landscape pocked with decapitated mountains standing flat as mesas and inhospitable to forest restoration.

headline: Let Ohio Vote First
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: It’s time to loosen the grip Iowa and New Hampshire have on our elections.
lead_paragraph: We, as voters and election-obsessed bystanders, made it past the first two contests in this eons-long presidential primary, but seven candidates weren’t so lucky.

headline: A College Education for Prisoners
abstract: It’s past time to restart prison education programs, providing the marketable skills that keep past offenders from returning to jail.
lead_paragraph: States are finally backing away from the draconian sentencing policies that swept the country at the end of the last century, driving up prison costs and sending too many people to jail for too long, often for nonviolent offenses. Many are now trying to turn around the prison juggernaut by steering drug addicts into treatment instead of jail and retooling parole systems that once sent people back to prison for technical violations.

headline: 인간 자폐증 연구를 위해 자폐증 행동을 보이는 원숭이를 만들다
abstract: 중국 과학자들이 유전자 이식을 통해 인간의 자폐증과 유사한 행동을 보이는 원숭이를 만들어 자폐 증상을 유발하는 뇌 회로 상의 결함을 찾아내려고 한다.
lead_paragraph: 유전자 이식을 통해 자폐증과 유사한 행동을 하는 원숭이가 만들어졌다. 원숭이는 인간과 매우 유사하므로 이 원숭이를 대상으로 여러 치료법을 시도해 봄으로써 자폐증에 대한 더 많은 정보를 얻을 수 있을 것으로 보인다.

headline: Denise Matthews, Pop Singer Known as Vanity, Dies at 57
abstract: Ms. Matthews toured with Prince in the 1980s before eschewing her wild persona for life as a minister.
lead_paragraph: Denise Matthews, the singer, model and actress known as Vanity, who toured with Prince in the 1980s before eschewing her wild persona for life as a minister, died on Monday in Fremont, Calif. She was 57.

headline: John Slaney Has a New Shot at Glory, 25 Years After His Moment
abstract: Slaney is known for his 1991 goal that helped Canada win the world junior championships, but at 44, he is enjoying his first full N.H.L. season, as a Coyotes assistant.
lead_paragraph: The calls came to John Slaney for more than two decades, typically right before Christmas. Canadian sports media outlets would request interviews, asking Slaney to wax nostalgic about what remains the highlight of his hockey career: his dramatic goal against the Soviet Union on Jan. 4, 1991, which earned Canada a gold medal at the world junior hockey championships.

headline: New York Schools Wonder: How White Is Too White?
abstract: The city’s Education Department is allowing seven schools to set aside seats for low-income families, English-language learners or students engaged with the child welfare system.
lead_paragraph: How white is too white? At the Academy of Arts and Letters, a small K-8 school in Brooklyn founded in 2006 to educate a community of “diverse individuals,” that question is being put to the test.

headline: How a Reporter’s Quest for Online Bargains Led to a Network of Syrian Contacts
abstract: Hwaida Saad, a journalist in The Times’s Beirut bureau, has grown online connections to people on all sides of Syria’s civil war.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — As the Syrian war erupted in 2011, Hwaida Saad, a Lebanese journalist in The New York Times’s Beirut bureau, rummaged through her contacts, looking for phone numbers.

headline: Fashion Week: Eveningwear, With a Chance of Showers
abstract: Day 6 of New York Fashion Week includes Tory Burch, Vera Wang, Rodarte, Narciso Rodriguez and the latest from Brandon Maxwell, Lady Gaga’s stylist.
lead_paragraph: Don’t rain on my parade? Don’t ask for the impossible. The forecast for today calls for two things: Showers and runway shows. Skip the suede boots and pack the umbrellas. Through inclement weather, New York Fashion Week soldiers on.
