headline: Why Poland Needs American Support
abstract: My country needs NATO as a bulwark against Russian aggression.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — SITTING next to Barack Obama at a luncheon during the United Nations General Assembly session in 2009, President Lech Kaczynski of Poland gave his counterpart a copy of “The Peasant Prince,” a biography of Thaddeus Kosciuszko, the Polish military commander who joined George Washington’s army in 1776 and drew up the strategy for the Battles of Saratoga, the turning point of the American Revolution.

headline: Democrats See Chance to Bolster Enthusiasm in G.O.P. Pledge to Block Scalia Replacement
abstract: Republican senators who are thought most susceptible to a political backlash for blocking any new Supreme Court nominee appear to be shaking off concern and joining the call to wait for the next president to fill the vacancy caused by Antonin Scalia’s death. And that is just fine with some Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Republican senators who are thought most susceptible to a political backlash for blocking any new Supreme Court nominee appear to be shaking off concern and joining the call to wait for the next president to fill the vacancy caused by Antonin Scalia’s death. And that is just fine with some Democrats.

headline: New York Today: The Great Indoors
abstract: Tuesday: What to do with kids this week, warm weather tease, and the Brooklyn Bridge for rent.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:43 a.m.

headline: Review: Premiere of Wheeldon’s ‘Strapless’ at the Royal Ballet
abstract: The British choreographer presents a portrait of a Belle Époque scandal in Paris as part of a triple bill at the Royal Ballet in London.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A new ballet by the British choreographer Christopher Wheeldon is an event, and one with a score by Mark Anthony Turnage (“Anna Nicole”) even more so. On Friday night, the great and the good had turned out at the Royal Opera House here to see the premiere of “Strapless,” part of a Royal Ballet all-Wheeldon bill that included “After the Rain,” created for New York City Ballet in 2005, and “Within the Golden Hour” ( San Francisco Ballet, 2008).

headline: Bernie Sanders, Seeking to Court Black Voters, Will Visit South Carolina and Georgia
abstract: Though Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has received the endorsement of several black politicians and artists, he still trails Hillary Clinton in South Carolina, where African-Americans are likely to make up more than half of the electorate.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will head south on Tuesday to court voters in South Carolina, where a recent poll shows him trailing Hillary Clinton, and to host a rally in Georgia as part of his campaign’s tour of black colleges and universities.

headline: Fat Cats on a Diet: Will They Still Love You?
abstract: Cats don’t hold a grudge if you limit their food to help them slim down, a new study shows.
lead_paragraph: Maya has had a tough time slimming down. After 16 months of dieting, she’s dropped 10 pounds and 6 ounces.

headline: Belgian Police Charge 3 in Investigation of ISIS Network
abstract: The arrests in Brussels were not directly connected to the Paris terrorist attacks last year, an official said.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Belgian police raided nine homes and arrested 10 people in Brussels as part of an investigation into an Islamic State recruitment network, a spokesman for the federal prosecutor’s office said on Tuesday.

headline: A Fight in the Trenches, From South Carolina to Nevada
abstract: As the race for the South Carolina Republican primary winds down to the final five days, it has become a battle for the soul of the party — between Donald J. Trump and the party’s last president, George W. Bush.
lead_paragraph: As the race for the South Carolina Republican primary winds down to the final five days, it has become a fight for the soul of the party — between Donald J. Trump and the party’s last president, George W. Bush. The fight for votes, however, is between Mr. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, with Jeb Bush, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio right behind them.

headline: Republicans and Hispanics: The Extent of the Damage Done
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Voting and Voters', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Surveys show more Hispanics are feeling hostility from the G.O.P., and many in the party blame Donald Trump.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party has ended up someplace where many of its leaders didn’t want it to be — divided about how much it cares about Hispanic voters.

headline: The Quietly Subversive Fictions of Dana Spiotta
abstract: Over the course of her career, the author has created a new kind of great American novel.
lead_paragraph: When Dana Spiotta was working on her fourth novel, ‘‘Innocents and Others,’’ she sat beneath a huge bulletin board pinned with her sticky notes and research materials: lists of relevant words (passion, transformation, intimacy) and ‘‘seeing’’ devices (zoetrope, stereoscope, camera obscura), and photographs of Orson Welles, Jean-Luc Godard and the Maysles brothers. ‘‘It’s like walking into the book,’’ Spiotta told me. ‘‘You feel it all around you.’’

headline: Xinjiang Region of China Bans Glacier Tourism, Citing Risk to Ecosystem
abstract: Officials in the far western region say that tourism is harming the fragile glaciers and that they should be observed from a distance.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Glaciologists in China and elsewhere have said for years that climate change is the main cause of glacier erosion, which threatens the water sources of much of humanity.

headline: Israeli Officers Briefly Detain Two Journalists
abstract: The Washington Post’s Jerusalem bureau chief and a colleague were detained after being accused of “inciting” Palestinians while conducting interviews outside the Old City.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli authorities issued statements of regret on Tuesday after police officers briefly detained The Washington Post’s bureau chief in Jerusalem and a colleague while they were conducting interviews at the Damascus Gate into the Old City, a site of frequent attacks by Palestinians against Israeli Jews in recent months.

headline: At the Grammys, a Muted Night for Fashion
abstract: Taylor Swift didn’t just dominate the awards. She dominated the red carpet in a surprisingly low-key evening for style.
lead_paragraph: Maybe designers just hit overload. Maybe with the current fashion season, the coming Oscars and the British Academy of Film and Television Arts awards last Sunday, they just thought: We can’t handle another awards show. Maybe the musicians attending thought: Enough with the fashion credits; we want the focus to be on us and our art. Leave the crazy clothes to the MTV Video Music Awards; make this about the music.

headline: Chinese Writer Says He’s Forbidden From Traveling to U.S. for Harvard Prize
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: Yang Jisheng said that officials from his former employer, the Xinhua News Agency, had forbidden him from traveling to Harvard.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The author of a landmark book documenting the millions of deaths from China’s Great Famine said on Tuesday that his former employer, the official Xinhua News Agency, had forbidden him from traveling to Harvard University next month to receive an award honoring his courage and integrity.

headline: Oil Output Freeze Has a Catch: Attracting OPEC Unity
abstract: Saudi Arabia, Russia, Venezuela and Qatar agreed to hold production steady as a way to bolster energy prices. But they will proceed only if others do.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — As prices have dropped ever lower, smaller oil producing nations on precarious financial ground have regularly pushed their bigger brethren to stop pumping at record levels and help calm the markets.

headline: Want Viagra? Proposed Kentucky Law Would Require Note From Spouse
abstract: State Representative Mary Lou Marzian, a Democrat, said she wanted to make a point about government interference in women’s issues like abortion.
lead_paragraph: A Kentucky state representative believed that a new law requiring women to have a medical consultation 24 hours before having an abortion smacked of sexism.

headline: Table for One: Pulling Up a Chair for Solo Diners
abstract: Hotels and resorts are making sure that solo diners are comfortable, with people-watching views and reading matter and chances to mingle with others.
lead_paragraph: Table for one? Done.

headline: Gefilte Fish and Gumbo in Buenos Aires
abstract: On menus in the Argentine capital, chefs continue to move beyond meat and pasta.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday night, a small group stood outside Mishiguene in Buenos Aires, chatting and sipping digestifs after an opulent 12-course tasting menu. Not five minutes had passed when a fellow diner opened the door and bellowed: “Come back in, you have to see this!” The restaurant’s chef, Tomás Kalika, had momentarily stopped dinner service to introduce an accordionist and a clarinetist who began to play joyous klezmer songs, eventually bringing patrons to their feet.

headline: ADT in $6.9 Billion Deal to Sell Itself to Apollo Buyout Firm
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Security and Warning Systems']
abstract: In the biggest leveraged buyout of the year so far, Apollo Global plans to merge the security company ADT Corporation with two other security firms.
lead_paragraph: The ADT Corporation, which provides home and business security systems for 6.5 million customers, is being acquired by the private equity firm Apollo Global Management for $6.9 billion in the largest leveraged buyout so far this year.

headline: U.N. Rights Official Urges China to Release Detained Lawyers
keywords: ['Political Prisoners', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Legal Profession']
abstract: Zeid Ra’ad al-Hussein, the high commissioner for human rights, expressed concern over a “very worrying pattern” of arrests and disappearances.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The United Nations’ top human rights official called on China on Tuesday to immediately and unconditionally release a group of lawyers detained starting last summer, and he expressed concern over a “very worrying pattern” of arrests and disappearances.

headline: 1916: Oath Binds Allies to Belgium
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archive: The Allies promise to protect Belgium in 1916.
lead_paragraph: HAVRE — Great Britain, France and Russia, the guarantors of the independence of Belgium, which Germany, another guarantor, has so ruthlessly violated, have entered into a solemn pact that they will not lay down the sword until the integrity of King Albert’s Kingdom has been re-established, its political and economic independence have been restored and generous compensation has been paid for the wrongs which it has suffered. Italy and Japan, although these Powers were not signatories to the original treaty, have associated themselves in the undertaking of the Triple Entente, their Ally. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1916

headline: Rubio Tax Cut Got Bigger and Bigger
keywords: ['Income Tax', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: An already sizable tax cut from one Republican senator evolved into one that is even bigger — and particularly generous toward the highest earners.
lead_paragraph: If you want an insight into what Senator Marco Rubio’s instincts on policy are, just look at what happened when he got his hands on another senator’s tax cut plan: It became about three times larger, and way more tilted toward the rich.

headline: Why Angela Merkel Could Lead the U.N.
abstract: The German chancellor’s emergence as Europe’s pre-eminent leader makes her a strong candidate to succeed Ban Ki-moon.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Filed away at the back of an office at United Nations headquarters in Turtle Bay, in New York, is a small collection of yellowing letters, containing appeals from the organization’s first secretary general, a former Norwegian minister named Trygve Lie, to be allowed to relinquish his post. To this day, his motive is unclear: Was he desperate to escape the burdens of high office? Or did he believe in his own indispensability and wish to evoke pleas from member states for him to remain?

headline: Matchmaking at a 7-Eleven
abstract: The young woman, lost in Queens, simply wanted to get out of the rain and get to class, but the convenience store owner was thinking of his son.

abstract: The band that was playing at the Bataclan when gunmen killed 90 people there returned to Paris. The show included survivors.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The sold-out concert by Eagles of Death Metal here Tuesday night was at once a tribute to those who died in the November terrorist attacks during a performance by the band and a celebration of those who survived.

headline: Uganda’s Least Equal Voters: The L.G.B.T.I.
abstract: One hate law has been overturned, but the government still finds ways to silence and punish L.G.B.T.I. activists and groups.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As an attorney and Uganda human rights activist, America’s elections thrill me. It is breathtaking to witness democracy in full roar, as candidates vie for the nation’s highest office.

headline: Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton to Meet Civil Rights Leaders
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will meet with the heads of several civil rights organizations, an effort that comes as he continues to court black voters ahead of the Democratic caucuses in Nevada and the party’s South Carolina primary.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont will meet with the heads of several civil rights organizations in Washington on Thursday morning, an effort that comes as he continues to court black voters ahead of Saturday’s Democratic caucuses in Nevada and the party’s Feb. 27 South Carolina primary.

keywords: ['Civilian Casualties', 'Persian Gulf War', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The destruction of the Amiriya bomb shelter in Baghdad killed over 400 civilians at the start of an American entanglement in Iraq that has yet to end.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — It was once a well-kept memorial for hundreds of Iraqi civilians who were killed by American bombs while they slept, a powerful symbol of suffering embraced by a dictator’s propaganda machine.

headline: 1941: British Mine Singapore Coast
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archive: The British government lays a new mine field off Singapore in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The laying of a new mine field off Singapore, already one of the most strongly fortified naval and air bases in the world, was announced today [Feb. 16] by the British government. Any vessel wishing to pass through the area off the east coast of the Malay Peninsula must apply to British naval authorities at Singapore for a route, the announcement said, while any ship disregarding these instructions would do so at its own peril. The announcement made clear that Great Britain fully realized the gravity of the Far Eastern situation and was preparing for any eventualities. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 17, 1941

headline: Taking Creepiness Out of Computer Voices
abstract: Software designers for companies like Apple and Google are working to bring digital assistants past the “uncanny valley,” where technology becomes unsettling.
lead_paragraph: As machine learning and the use of artificial intelligence spread, technologists are running into questions over when A.I. can get too real — and too creepy.

headline: A Warning on the Federal Reserve’s Limits
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Income Inequality']
abstract: Mohamed A. El-Erian, the former Pimco chief, says serious investment in the “real economy” is needed, and only Congress and the White House can do it.
lead_paragraph: Inside the hurricane-force partisanship swirling around the capital, Washington has retained a singular bulwark for mainstream consensus: Federal Reserve stewardship of economic policy.

headline: A Possible Preview of Next Year’s Oscar Race
abstract: The Sundance drama “Christine,” about a television journalist who killed herself on-air, has generated awards talk for Rebecca Hall.
lead_paragraph: Too early to talk about next year’s Oscar race? Never!

headline: My Unicorn Problem
abstract: What if you don’t believe in magic?
lead_paragraph: It has been an interesting few months on the progressive side of the political debate, and I mean that in the worst way. A significant number of progressives are very, very excited by the unexpected support for Bernie Sanders, and are shocked and horrified to find many — I think most — liberal policy wonks rather skeptical. For me this is somewhat familiar territory: I was skeptical about Barack Obama’s promises of transcendence back in 2008, too. And then as now a fair number of enthusiasts took no time at all to declare that I was a corrupt villain, a tool of the oligarchs, desperate for a job with Hillary etc.. OK, this too shall pass. But I thought it might be worth saying a bit more about where people like me find ourselves.

headline: Dispatcher in Deadly German Train Crash Faces Investigation
abstract: He was overseeing a single-track stretch in southeastern Germany on Feb. 9 at the time of the accident near Bad Aibling, a chief prosecutor said.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — A dispatcher is under investigation for involuntary manslaughter following the deaths of 11 people after the German authorities concluded human error led two trains to collide in Bavaria last week, prosecutors said on Tuesday.

headline: The War After Scalia
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Capital Punishment', 'McCutcheon v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Why, despite the risks, conservatives have to resist an Obama nominee.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of Antonin Scalia’s death, two lines of critique are circulating concerning Senate Republicans’ immediate declaration that they won’t approve any replacement before the next president is elected and inaugurated. The first, offered by David Frum, Chris Cillizza and others, holds that Mitch McConnell and Co. would have been better served politically by pretending to consider an Obama nominee and then simply using a sixty-vote threshold to avoid approval, rather than coming across as baldly intransigent from day one. The second one, offered by Slate’s Mark Joseph Stern (who wrote one of the more generous liberal eulogies for Scalia), goes further and argues that Senate Republicans are gambling significantly by declining to approve a moderate-liberal nominee, since if they lose the Senate and the White House this fall they could end up with a more radical, precedent-overturning liberal on the court instead of a compromise choice. Here’s Stern:

headline: Pact on U.S.-Cuba Flights Reopens Battle for Seized Property
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'AIRPORTS', 'Cuban-Americans', 'United States International Relations', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: American law prohibits profiting from holdings confiscated from its citizens, and the exiled heir to the Havana airport hopes to stake a legal claim.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — The Obama administration’s top transportation officials joined Cuban dignitaries at the Hotel Nacional in Havana on Tuesday to sign an agreement that will restore commercial airline service between the two countries for the first time in more than 50 years.

lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — A plan to convert Pittsburgh’s 12-story landmark Macy’s department store into a one-million-square-foot mixed-used behemoth has become one of the latest votes of confidence in the decade-long resurgence of the city’s downtown.

lead_paragraph: How proposed changes to France’s Constitution to fight terrorism compare with laws in other countries.

headline: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, Former U.N. Secretary General, Dies at 93
abstract: The Egyptian diplomat led the United Nations in a chaotic period that began with hopes for peace after the Cold War but ended after a single term.
lead_paragraph: Boutros Boutros-Ghali, an Egyptian diplomat who led the United Nations in a chaotic 1990s tenure that began with hopes for peace after the Cold War, but failed to cope with genocide in Rwanda and Bosnia and ended in angry recriminations with Washington, died on Tuesday in an Egyptian hospital. He was 93.

headline: Catherine Opie in Conversation With Rodarte
abstract: The photographer is the subject of a handful of new shows in New York and Los Angeles. She spoke with the designers Laura and Kate Mulleavy for T.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Catherine Opie is the focus of several new shows on both coasts. A current exhibition at Lehmann Maupin in New York, split between the gallery’s Chelsea and Lower East Side locations, showcases a wide assortment of her work — including landscapes, portraits and pieces from her “700 Nimes Road” series, photographs of Elizabeth Taylor’s belongings.She is also currently the subject of three shows in Los Angeles — at LACMA, MOCA’s Pacific Design Center and the Hammer. She spoke to the Rodarte designers Laura and Kate Mulleavy, her frequent collaborators who will show their fall/winter 2016 collection today, for T.

abstract: A mobile pizzaiolo sets up permanent shop on the border of Carroll Gardens and Red Hook.
lead_paragraph: A mobile pizzaiolo sets up permanent shop on the border of Carroll Gardens and Red Hook.

headline: Pizza Moto Comes to Rest in Brooklyn
abstract: An oven on wheels now has a bricks-and-mortar restaurant where the creative pies are among New York’s brick-oven best.
lead_paragraph: David Sclarow built his first wood-burning pizza oven so he could feed guests at the wedding of two cheesemakers. They were getting married some distance from Brooklyn, where he lived, so he layered the bricks and concrete on top of a flatbed trailer that he could hitch to the back of his Volkswagen Doka. The next time he took his mobile pizza oven for a spin, it collapsed, but by that point, he liked it so much that he rebuilt it.

headline: New York Police Still Struggle to Follow Street-Stop Rules, Report Finds
abstract: The findings, in a report filed by the federal monitor, Peter L. Zimroth, portray an agency straining to make its routine inquiries of citizens constitutional.
lead_paragraph: A review of hundreds of street stops by the New York Police Department last year found that in over one-quarter, officers failed to document the suspicion that prompted them to stop someone for questioning. In most instances, sergeants signed off on the stop-and-frisk paperwork even when the forms filled out by officers omitted required information.

headline: Facts & Figures: South Carolina Trump Supporters on the Civil War
abstract: Thirty-eight percent of Trump supporters in the state wish the South had won, according to a new poll.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-eight percent of Donald Trump supporters in South Carolina wish the South had won the Civil War, according to a new poll by Public Policy Polling. Another 38 percent are undecided, and 24 percent are glad the North won.

headline: Two Poems by J.R.R. Tolkien Found in School Publication in England
abstract: Two poems by J.R.R. Tolkien are found in the 1936 yearbook for Our Lady’s School in Oxfordshire, England.
lead_paragraph: “Grim was the world and grey last night/The moon and stars were fled.” So begins “Noel,” one of two previously unseen poems by J. R. R. Tolkien, discovered in a 1936 school annual in England. Stephen Oliver, the headmaster of Our Lady’s School in Abingdon, Oxfordshire, found the poems after being contacted by Wayne Hammond, a Tolkien scholar, who had discovered a note by the author mentioning their publication.

headline: What I Learned From Justice Scalia
abstract: When the late Supreme Court justice was the man I knew as ‘Boss.’
lead_paragraph: When I first met Antonin Scalia, I was a small child with one brown ponytail atop my head. Which is odd, because I was a full-grown woman and my hair was short and blond. Still, sitting on the black leather sofa in his chambers, I remember shrinking. Overpowered by his intellect and his enormous personality, I felt that my feet no longer touched the floor. I had become Lily Tomlin’s iconic character, Edith Ann, in that great big rocking chair. And now I had to convince this giant of a man to hire me as his law clerk.

headline: Fed’s Neel Kashkari Says Banks Are ‘Still Too Big to Fail’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)']
abstract: The Minneapolis Fed president, a key Treasury official during the financial crisis, called for reining in banks to address a “risk to our economy.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the 2008 financial crisis, Neel Kashkari worked tirelessly to save the nation’s largest banks. As a senior Treasury Department official in the George W. Bush and Obama administrations, he helped those banks grow larger than ever.

headline: 3 Americans Kidnapped in Baghdad Are Released
keywords: ['Kidnapping and Hostages', 'Shiite Muslims', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The State Department credited the Iraqi government with playing a role in winning their release by Shiite militiamen.

After showers, medical checkups and a meal at the American Embassy, they were quickly put on a plane out of the country.

headline: U.N. Says Aid Delivery Near in Syria for 5 Towns

headline: ‘Come From Away,’ a Sept. 11 Musical, Is Coming to Broadway

lead_paragraph: The events of Sept. 11, 2001, do not seem to be the most obvious fodder for a Broadway musical. But after successful runs at La Jolla Playhouse and Seattle Repertory Theater, “Come From Away” – tracing how the residents of Gander, Newfoundland, took in thousands of diverted airline passengers that terrible day – will come to New York in the spring of 2017.

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — In the early years of the Obama administration, the United States developed an elaborate plan for a cyberattack on Iran in case the diplomatic effort to limit its nuclear program failed and led to a military conflict, according to a coming documentary film and interviews with military and intelligence officials involved in the effort.

headline: Bedford & Co. Fires Up a Wood Grill
abstract: Also, the chef Matthew Kenney uses a wood-fired oven for vegan pies; diner-style food at Mr. Donahue’s; and Porter House gets a makeover.
lead_paragraph: Bedford & Co. The latest decorative statement in New York restaurants is a woodpile. Increasingly, chefs are installing wood-fired grills and ovens and, like John DeLucie in this new venture, putting stacks of split logs on display. And not just for show. “I saw this grill in Argentina,” he said of the wood-fueled contraption in his open kitchen. “I knew I had to have one.” He features wood-grilled dishes like oysters, lamb ribs, artichokes, beets and whole fish. This restaurant represents a fresh start for Mr. DeLucie, who the last few years has closed all his others, including Crown, the Lion and Bill’s Food & Drink, which he owned with partners. Bedford & Co., done in dark browns and olive green, is on two levels in the new Renwick hotel: (Opens Wednesday): 118 East 40th Street, 212-634-4040, bedfordandco.com.

lead_paragraph: Purple magazine held its annual fashion week party at Narcissa in the Standard, East Village hotel, where diners were treated to a throwback party favor: disposable cameras. The famed photographer Ellen von Unwerth takes a selfie.

headline: How Mansur Gavriel Turned a White Box Into a Cozy Home
abstract: For their fall/winter 2016 presentation, Rachel Mansur and Floriana Gavriel transformed the Swiss Institute in Soho into a domestic scene.
lead_paragraph: A sometimes overlooked part of fashion week (by showgoers, at least) are sets, but designers can spend months transforming a space for their collection. For their fall/winter 2016 presentation, Rachel Mansur and Floriana Gavriel of the New York City-based accessories brand Mansur Gavriel enlisted a handful of collaborators to turn the Swiss Institute in Soho into a domestic scene. The final result displayed their pieces amid a cozy living room and kitchenette — complete with fresh food. “As designers, we think in terms of a world,” Mansur says. “Although we’ve only been able to express shoes and bags, so far, we’re always thinking about the emotional aspect — and not product-driven — and that’s what we want to roll out.” Scroll over the images above and below to go inside the presentation.

headline: Music by Fashion’s Most In-Demand Sound Director — for Chloë Sevigny
abstract: For the fragrance company Régime des Fleurs, Michel Gaubert collaborated on a song with the actress and six different musical artists.
lead_paragraph: This season, the French sound illustrator Michel Gaubert is scoring New York Fashion Week shows for Lacoste, Adam Selman, Proenza Schouler, Diane Von Furstenberg, Rodarte, Michael Kors, Jeremy Scott and Tory Burch. But on Sunday afternoon, he traded the runway for an East Village furniture store, to celebrate a different kind of creative collaboration: “Prayer to Saint Thérèse” — an original audio work spoken by Chloë Sevigny, and turned into song. “I’ve been a fan of Chloë for a long time,” said Gaubert. Part of Régime des Fleurs’ Artefacts program, which pairs exquisite old objects with original artistic works, the song honors the patron saint of flowers — a fitting ode to the fragrance brand’s handmade perfumes, which are heavily inspired by art history.

headline: ‘Indentured,’ by Joe Nocera and Ben Strauss
abstract: How the N.C.A.A. went from protecting student-athletes to exploiting them.
lead_paragraph: The N.C.A.A., the nonprofit organization that once governed college athletics and now more closely resembles a sprawling sales team for high-end workout gear, was, like so many despots before it, meant to be a force for good. Its first executive director, a former sportswriter named Walter Byers, built the organization as a buffer against creeping capitalism and shady gambling interests — a way to protect ­student-athletes from the rampaging hordes of greed charging in from the sidelines. It was meant to be a place of purity.

headline: The Right Sauces for Whole Wheat Pasta
abstract: Robust ones, like ragù and pesto, can stand up to the noodles’ assertive flavor.
lead_paragraph: Whole wheat pasta just doesn’t work with all sauces. Its nutty, somewhat assertive flavor can overpower a subtle sauce, and its texture, which can be granular, doesn’t work with others.

headline: Apollo Builds In Safeguards for Its ADT Deal
abstract: During tough times for big leveraged deals, Apollo Global has employed some creative maneuvers in its $7 billion buyout of the security company ADT.
lead_paragraph: Leon D. Black is giving new meaning to secured loans. Apollo Global, the private equity firm he helps run, has agreed to buy the home safety and fire protection company ADT for about $7 billion. It’s a buyout of alarming size given the fear coursing through credit markets, but the deal comes with plenty of safeguards.

headline: ‘West of Eden,’ by Jean Stein
abstract: In “West of Eden,” Jean Stein continues the project she began in “Edie,” recording our nation’s “trickster promise.”
lead_paragraph: Oral history looks all too easy. When the Belarussian writer Svetlana Alexievich won the 2015 Nobel Prize in Literature for her oral histories of humanitarian crises, it seemed an overdue confirmation of the genre’s literary nature — not just its capacity to tell sweeping, timeless human stories, but also the craft and cunning involved in its artful assemblage of specific, individual voices. In this country the form has proved to be both a serious vehicle for popular history and a reliable producer of best sellers, beginning with Studs Terkel’s “Working” in 1974. But it was Jean Stein’s 1982 book “Edie: American Girl,” edited with George Plimpton, that gave oral history the particular shimmer that comes when lofty literary aims happen to coincide with sheer entertainment value. “Edie” conjured the tragic life of Edith Sedgwick, who was born into a patrician New England family, grew up with seven siblings on isolated ­ranches near Santa Barbara under the yoke of a semi-deranged father, came east and after a stint in a mental hospital became Andy Warhol’s arm candy and a figure in New York counterculture, before being cast out by him and dying at 28 of an overdose. In many ways Stein’s new book, “West of Eden,” continues the larger project she began in “Edie”: chronicling a trickster promise embedded in our national consciousness — something shining and elusive and at its center not just ugly but quite often deadly.

headline: Conspiracy Theories About Zika Spread Through Brazil With the Virus
abstract: Rumors have replicated through social media and word of mouth, frustrating Brazilian officials as they grapple with a mysterious pathogen.
lead_paragraph: SALVADOR, Brazil — The Zika virus, some Brazilians are convinced, is the inadvertent creation of a British biotech company that has been releasing genetically modified mosquitoes to combat dengue fever in Brazil. Others here and elsewhere see it as a plot by global elites to depopulate the earth and install a “one-world government.”

Even so, it reflects a heightened sense of urgency about the refugee crisis and sends a strong signal that the Western alliance stands ready to help Europe cope with it.

headline: Review: A Look Into the Life of Henry James, in His Own Unsimple Words
abstract: On the 100th anniversary of the author’s death, his autobiographical works have been gathered together, along with a selection of his other personal writing, by the Library of America.
lead_paragraph: “I hate American simplicity,” Henry James (1843-1916) said to his niece Peggy, who had the sense to write his comment down. “I glory in the piling up of complications of every sort. If I could pronounce the name James in any different or more elaborate way I should be in favor of doing it.”

headline: Review: So Percussion, Glenn Kotche and Shara Worden Join in Making a Joyful Noise
abstract: The program at Zankel Hall included a new piece by Mr. Kotche, one composed by Ms. Worden and So, and more, amid a clangor of nonstandard percussion.
lead_paragraph: It’s a good thing the sirens that wailed through Zankel Hall on Friday didn’t signal an emergency: The auditorium was so densely packed at the start of So Percussion’s late-evening concert that it would have taken a while to evacuate. But there was no danger mistaking these piercing sounds, produced on hand-cranked sirens by the ensemble’s members, Eric Cha-Beach, Josh Quillen, Adam Sliwinski and Jason Treuting, for anything other than the opening fanfare of a performance that would prove entertaining, virtuosic, occasionally lyrical, but most often joyfully loud.

headline: Review: ‘Climate Control,’ Where Hot and Cold Mix It Up in a Pas de Deux
abstract: In this work, Kathryn Posin provides an epigraph from Robert Frost’s poem about the world ending in fire or ice.
lead_paragraph: They come from different tribes. She, in her fur-trimmed hood, could be a Native American of the far north, though her pointe shoes are puzzling. He, with his chest bare above what looks like a grass skirt, might be Polynesian, though the skirt is made of silvery tinsel and his crown suggests ice. She wields a small electric fan; he, a flashlight. But this woman and man join together in a traditional ballet pas de deux.

abstract: Jean Touitou presents his first NYFW show.
lead_paragraph: Jean Touitou presents his first NYFW show.

lead_paragraph: Mexico and More — Pictures of the Day

abstract: A Kentucky bill would require men to get authorization from their spouses before taking erectile-dysfunction drugs.
lead_paragraph: “I want to protect these men from themselves.”

headline: Feb. 16, 2016 — Photos of the Day
abstract: Photos from Mexico, North Korea, Gaza City and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Mexico, North Korea, Gaza City and the United States.

headline: After a Rocky Start, Ted Cruz Had Success Before Supreme Court
abstract: As Texas solicitor general, he appeared before the court many times and had a two-decade relationship with Justice Antonin Scalia.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On the first Monday in October 2003, as the Supreme Court began a new term, a 32-year-old lawyer who then called himself R. Edward Cruz made his first appearance before the justices. It did not go well.

headline: They Held Power. They Stole Millions.
abstract: The Justice Department has led an effort to recover assets that it says were stolen by foreign officials — dictators, politicians and ruling elites – and laundered in the United States. Here is a look at some of the cases it is pursuing:
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has led an effort to recover assets that it says were stolen by foreign officials — dictators, politicians and ruling elites – and laundered in the United States. Here is a look at some of the cases it is pursuing:

headline: Wanted by U.S.: The Stolen Millions of Despots and Crooked Elites
abstract: Teams of government lawyers, the F.B.I. and Homeland Security are trying to recover assets the United States says were stolen by foreign officials.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine a public official with more toys than Teodoro Nguema Obiang Mangue, who spent $300 million on Ferraris, a Gulfstream jet, a California mansion and even Michael Jackson’s “Thriller” jacket. The buying spree is all the more remarkable since this scion of the ruling family of Equatorial Guinea, one of Africa’s smallest countries, bought all this while on an official salary of $100,000 a year.

headline: Michael Moore Says No, Donald Trump Is Not Like Him
abstract: While some Republican rivals are trying to tar Mr, Trump as a “Michael Moore Republican,” Mr. Moore says he finds the candidate and his campaign frightening.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s rivals are trying to tar him as a “Michael Moore Republican” after his lampooning of George W. Bush as a president who lied to America and failed to keep the country safe. But Mr. Moore, the liberal filmmaker, does not see much similarity between himself and Mr. Trump.

headline: German Police Raid Property of Group Linked to ISIS
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Police', 'Search and Seizure', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: More than 200 officers and intelligence agents raided an office and 12 homes in the northern city-state of Bremen to enforce a ban on a Salafist group.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — More than 200 police officers and intelligence agents raided an office and 12 homes in the northern German city-state of Bremen on Tuesday to enforce a ban on a Salafist group linked to a previously outlawed group that sent at least 15 people to join the Islamic State in Syria, the authorities said.

headline: The Art and Fashion of Lynn Wyatt’s Paddle8 Auction
abstract: The auction site will sell pieces of couture owned by the Texas socialite and her friends.
lead_paragraph: The auction site will sell pieces of couture owned by the Texas socialite and her friends.

headline: A Famous Texan Socialite on Feeling Comfortable in Couture
abstract: Lynn Wyatt auctions off several of her custom made pieces to benefit the Rothko Chapel in Houston.
lead_paragraph: The legendary Houston socialite Lynn Wyatt likes to describe her couture gowns as “old friends.” The sentiment refers to her penchant for re-wearing the same custom outfits on multiple occasions — and the fact that many of the dresses were designed by close friends. This week, Wyatt, 80, will auction off 17 of her most iconic couture outfits from the ’70s, ’80s, and ’90s — including designs by Chanel, Valentino, Yves Saint Laurent and Givenchy — on Paddle8. A portion of the proceeds will go to benefit the Rothko Chapel in Houston.

headline: Kirsten Dunst and Jennifer Jason Leigh Bask in Rodarte’s Spell
abstract: The Mulleavy sisters, favorites of indie-minded Hollywood starlets, showed a collection of frilled leather and sheer lace.
lead_paragraph: On the damp, drizzly afternoon of Rodarte’s show, Kirsten Dunst, a longtime friend of the designers, was seated front row in a sheer, feathered Rodarte dress. It was hardly the thing for inclement weather, though Ms. Dunst cut through all questions of pragmatism and practicality with the plain-spoken truth about doing fashion week as a celebrity: “In a car, out of a car,” she said.

headline: John J. Riccardo, Former Chairman of Chrysler, Dies at 91
abstract: Mr. Riccardo, who took over at a time of turmoil in 1975, recruited Lee Iacocca to succeed him, a bet that paid off when it helped win government aid.
lead_paragraph: John J. Riccardo, who as chairman and chief executive of Chrysler recruited Lee Iacocca before stepping aside as the automaker neared bankruptcy, died on Saturday in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 91.

headline: Prado Museum Rescinds Loan of Downgraded Hieronymus Bosch Works
abstract: Researchers working on a major retrospective suggested that two works from Madrid’s Prado museum were likely not the work of Bosch himself.
lead_paragraph: AMSTERDAM — The Prado museum in Madrid has rescinded the loan of two works to a major retrospective of Hieronymus Bosch after researchers downgraded the attribution of the paintings to Bosch’s workshop or followers rather than to the 16th-century Dutch master himself.

headline: Apple Plans $12 Billion Bond Sale for Buybacks and Dividends
abstract: Apple often uses the debt markets despite having $215.7 billion in cash, largely because most of that is abroad and would be taxed if brought home.
lead_paragraph: Apple announced plans on Tuesday to sell up to $12 billion in bonds to pay for share buybacks and dividends, as blue-chip companies test investors’ appetite for debt after two weeks of turbulent markets.

headline: In Speech on Ending Racism, Hillary Clinton Offers $125 Billion Plan to Help Poor Minorities
abstract: Speaking in Harlem, Hillary Clinton offered job-training and education programs for poor and minority communities, part of an effort to speak directly to African-American voters heading into the South Carolina primary.
lead_paragraph: In a wide-ranging speech on “ending systemic racism,” Hillary Clinton presented a $125 billion plan to assist poor and minority communities with job training, education and re-entering society after incarceration, part of an effort to speak directly to African-American voters as the Democratic primary contest heads to South Carolina.

headline: A Tenacious Team of Two in the Cosby Case
abstract: No parties are more responsible for Mr. Cosby’s legal troubles than Dolores M. Troiani and Bebe H. Kivitz, the lawyers of one of the entertainer’s accusers.
lead_paragraph: NORRISTOWN, Pa. — Of the dozens of women who have said Bill Cosby sexually assaulted them, Andrea Constand is the only one whose complaint has led to criminal sexual assault charges. And Kevin Steele is the prosecutor who is now bringing her case to trial.

headline: Accessories Designers Grab Some Fashion Week Heat
abstract: Clothing labels may claim the lion’s share of coverage, but shoemakers and bag makers, like Paul Andrew and Mansur Gavriel, create excitement, too.
lead_paragraph: With the cameras trained mostly on the catwalks, it is easy to forget that the accessories designers who show during fashion week also have the power to turn heads.

headline: Review: ‘Embrace of the Serpent,’ Where Majesty Meets Monstrosity
abstract: Ciro Guerra’s film explores the devastation of the Amazon jungle through two historical journeys and the viewpoint of a fictional tribal shaman.
lead_paragraph: “The horror! The horror!” The terminal valediction of Kurtz in Joseph Conrad’s “Heart of Darkness” is deconstructed with a raging eloquence in the Colombian director Ciro Guerra’s majestic, spellbinding film, “Embrace of the Serpent.” Is the unspeakable savagery evoked by his dying words really beyond the reach of the civilized imagination? I doubt it.

headline: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton Easily Top New Poll in South Carolina
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Mr. Trump outpolled Ted Cruz among likely Republican voters in South Carolina (38 percent to 22 percent), while Hillary Clinton was ahead of Bernie Sanders by 18 percentage points in a new CNN/ORC survey.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton hold commanding leads in South Carolina ahead of the primary election there, according to a poll released Tuesday.

headline: Virtual Reality Companies Look to Science Fiction for Their Next Play
keywords: ['Virtual Reality (Computers)', 'Science Fiction', 'Books and Literature', 'Movies', 'Start-ups', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Wearable Computing', 'Headphones and Headsets']
abstract: Science fiction is both shaping the language that virtual reality companies use to market the technology and defining long-term goals for developers.
lead_paragraph: Tech companies have spent years developing better, cheaper devices to immerse people in digital worlds. Yet they are still figuring out how to make virtual reality the kind of technology that people cannot live without.

headline: A Patient Shot in His Hospital Room? Evolution of a Times Story
abstract: Elisabeth Rosenthal shares insight into her reporting about weapons in hospitals and about The Times’s collaboration with “This American Life.”
lead_paragraph: A student I know at the Icahn School of Medicine got in touch to say that a young man with bipolar disorder had been shot in a Houston hospital room by off-duty police officers moonlighting on the security staff. I was skeptical.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Rodarte
abstract: T plucks the best jewels right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: A cuff of climbing silver calla lilies clipped to the upper arms of models at Rodarte’s romantic show made for the chicest of corsages. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: John Kasich Hopes for Another Success Story in Michigan
abstract: After a second-place finish in New Hampshire, Mr. Kasich hopes to sell himself to the people of Michigan, which neighbors Ohio, the state he governs.
lead_paragraph: LIVONIA, Mich. — Four days before the South Carolina primary, Gov. John Kasich stepped off his campaign bus into a crowded Republican Party office near Detroit on Tuesday morning and marveled at how many people had shown up to see him.

headline: Ukraine’s Prime Minister, Arseniy Yatsenyuk, Survives No-Confidence Vote
abstract: Mr. Yatsenyuk faced wavering allies in the party of President Petro O. Poroshenko, who had called on him to resign.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The pro-Western government that took power in Ukraine after street protests two years ago barely survived a no-confidence vote in Parliament on Tuesday amid infighting and widespread disappointment over its failure to deliver on promises to root out corruption.

headline: A Conversation With Brian Ezra
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Brian Ezra is a founding principal of Avery Hall Investments, a residential developer focused on Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Ezra, 34, is a founding principal of Avery Hall Investments, a residential developer focused on Brooklyn. The company, which was started in 2013, is working on several projects, including residential and mixed-use developments in Boerum Hill, Cobble Hill and Park Slope. Mr. Ezra grew up in Park Slope.

headline: At Film Comment Selects, Period Pieces Lead the Way
abstract: The annual February showcase, which begins Wednesday at the Walter Reade Theater, has a retrospective feel in its slimmed-down 12-film main program.
lead_paragraph: Even when it looks backward, Film Comment Selects is not a festival that you would ever accuse of dwelling in the past. The editors of Film Comment, the magazine of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, have programmed their annual February showcase with a combination of under-the-radar art house entries and idiosyncratic revivals that reliably deliver an atmosphere of cutting-edge eclecticism.

headline: Review of New York Police Department's Street Stops
abstract: A review of hundreds of street stops by the New York Police Department last year found that in over one-quarter, officers failed to document the suspicion that prompted them to stop someone for questioning.
lead_paragraph: A review of hundreds of street stops by the New York Police Department last year found that in over one-quarter, officers failed to document the suspicion that prompted them to stop someone for questioning.

abstract: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

abstract: Ms. Assoulin, who recently dressed Amal Clooney, presents her fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Ms. Assoulin, who recently dressed Amal Clooney, presents her fall collection.

headline: Deconstructing the Westminster Dog Show
abstract: Sharing the jokes, observations and reactions of three New York Times reporters assigned to cover the Best in Show competition at the Westminster Dog Show.

abstract: Scenes from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Kate Bosworth, front row at Tory Burch, talks about her latest film; A.P.C’s first New York show; Gypsy Sport’s finale, complete with a model and her 6-week-old daughter, Rain, clutched to her chest; and more from the sixth day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Coach: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Stuart Vever’s presents his fall collection as Coach celebrates its 75th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Stuart Vever’s presents his fall collection as Coach celebrates its 75th anniversary.

headline: Rodarte’s Fall Show
abstract: Rodarte’s new collection included a heady mix of frilled leather and sheer lace.
lead_paragraph: Rodarte’s new collection included a heady mix of frilled leather and sheer lace.

headline: Rosie Assoulin Sees the Light
abstract: Beyoncé wears one of the designer’s bodysuits in her new video, but the atmosphere at her fall presentation was more understated.
lead_paragraph: If the varicolored candles lighting the way to Rosie Assoulin’s presentation in the meatpacking district on Monday posed a fire hazard, no one seemed to mind. Most visitors milling around the otherwise austere space on Gansevoort Street were far too busy taking in Ms. Assoulin’s romantically inclined collection of floor-length coats, dresses and jumpsuits, some effusively ruffled, others pointedly underadorned.

headline: Puerto Rico’s House of Representatives Passes Bill to Restructure $9 Billion in Debt
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Government Bonds', 'Municipal Bonds', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: If the bill is signed into law by the governor this week, the plan must next survive a rate-setting process by a newly formed regulatory body.
lead_paragraph: A plan to restructure about $9 billion of Puerto Rico’s debt, hailed as a model for the rest of the island’s debt-laden government, moved toward the desk of Gov. Alejandro García Padilla to be signed into law on Tuesday, after winning approval by Puerto Rico’s House of Representatives.

headline: Bill Clinton Makes Case for Hillary Clinton’s Candidacy in South Carolina
abstract: Citing his wife’s achievements, Mr. Clinton suggested that a Hillary Clinton administration would continue the work of the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Former President Bill Clinton stumped for his wife, Hillary, on Tuesday at community center packed with a diverse crowd of some 1,000 undecided voters, supporters and even a few conservatives.

headline: A Fight Over Argentina’s Debt Produces No Winners
abstract: An entire country has been subject to the vicissitudes of luck and litigation strategy.
lead_paragraph: The battle over Argentina’s debt is at the end stage, as the hedge funds and the country enter into negotiations to resolve the dispute.

headline: Review: Bolaño’s Mysterious ‘2666,’ Distilled to 5½ Hours by the Goodman Theater
abstract: In this ambitious staging, a tale that runs about 900 pages is rendered through informative sketches of events, losing some of its shimmering layers.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — The obvious challenge in adapting a novel to the stage is how to make a story lying flat on the page leap to three-dimensional life. The task is particularly confounding in the case of “2666,” Roberto Bolaño’s magnum opus, published after his death at 50 in 2003. The book spans two continents, nearly a century, two converging story lines — each dangling digressions like an overtrimmed Christmas tree — and runs to around 900 pages of dense prose.

headline: A Fluffy White Dark Horse at Westminster
abstract: The Samoyed is one of 152 breeds and varieties that have not won best in show at Westminster — only 47 have won — but a breed shutout can end in a torrent.
lead_paragraph: In the bleachers behind Ring 6 of the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show at Pier 94 on Tuesday, Janice Lynch and Brenda Mantz of Falls Church, Va., were taking turns chatting up their Samoyeds while waiting for judging in the breed to begin. More important, the two dozen Samoyeds were biding their time until the Doberman pinschers got out of the ring.

headline: Former U.N. Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali
abstract: Boutros Boutros-Ghali served as the United Nations secretary general during the chaotic 1990s.
lead_paragraph: Boutros Boutros-Ghali served as the United Nations secretary general during the chaotic 1990s.

headline: President Obama Criticizes G.O.P. Field, Particularly Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Obama described the Republicans presidential candidates as “troubling” to people around the world and singled out Mr. Trump as singularly unfit.
lead_paragraph: President Obama on Tuesday offered an extended critique of the Republicans running to replace him, describing them as “troubling” to people around the world and singling out Donald J. Trump as someone who would not be a serious president.

headline: Viral Student Loan Nightmare Is Not What It Seems, Authorities Say
abstract: U.S. marshals arrested a Houston man over a $1,500 student loan that was almost 30 years old. Then the story gets complicated.
lead_paragraph: In a country where 40 million people owe upward of $1.2 trillion on their student loans, it’s not hard to imagine why a tale about armed federal agents’ showing up at the door of a Texas man to arrest him over unpaid student loans set the Internet abuzz.

headline: Behind the Scenes at the Dog Show
abstract: The Westminster dog show, which had 199 breeds and varieties in competition, concluded Tuesday night. C. J., a German shorthaired pointer, was named best in show.
lead_paragraph: The Westminster dog show, which had 199 breeds and varieties in competition, concluded Tuesday night. C. J., a German shorthaired pointer, was named best in show.

headline: Suitor on Tinder App Is Accused of Theft From 2 Women
abstract: Prosecutors said Brandon Kiehm met the women on the dating site and persuaded them to give him $26,000, claiming he needed to pay medical bills for relatives.
lead_paragraph: The women liked the way the man looked in his picture on the dating app Tinder, so they swiped right to indicate interest in getting together. He said that his name was Tristan Acocella, that he was in finance and that his sister had cancer.

headline: Jerome Weinrib, ABC Carpet’s Old-School Proprietor, Dies at 86
abstract: Mr. Weinrib helped build a business started by his grandfather in 1897 into a string of stores that generate $150 million in annual sales.
lead_paragraph: Jerome Weinrib, an old-school rug merchant who helped build ABC Carpet into one of New York’s most successful home furnishing brands, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 86.

headline: Embattled Pennsylvania Attorney General Says That She Will Not Seek Re-election
abstract: Attorney General Kathleen G. Kane of Pennsylvania said she would continue battling what she has called a corrupt “old-boys’ network” that has plotted to remove her from office.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Kathleen G. Kane of Pennsylvania said on Tuesday that she will not seek re-election this fall, the latest twist in a political potboiler that has shamed a succession of state officials, destroyed several careers and left Ms. Kane facing felony charges and impeachment.

headline: Alabama: Spill Recovery Money Won’t Go to Hotel
keywords: ['Gulf of Mexico Oil Spill (2010)', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings']
abstract: A federal judge in Mobile, Ala., blocked the use of more than $58 million of BP oil spill recovery money for construction of a hotel along the Gulf of Mexico.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Mobile, Ala., on Tuesday blocked the use of more than $58 million of BP oil spill recovery money for construction of a hotel and conference center along the Gulf of Mexico. Senior Judge Charles R. Butler Jr. said government officials had not appropriately determined whether there were “reasonable restoration alternatives” to the project, which supporters have called crucial to attracting visitors after the spill in 2010. The project’s executive director, Cooper Shattuck, said that “there are other funds available for the continued work on the lodge that do not include taxpayer dollars.” Robert Wiygul, a lawyer for the Gulf Restoration Network, which challenged the plan, praised the decision.

headline: Zimbabwe: Owner of Impounded Jet Says Body on Board Was a Stowaway
abstract: The American corporate owner of the cargo jet impounded in Zimbabwe after the bloodied body of a man was discovered aboard during a refueling stop confirmed that man was a stowaway.
lead_paragraph: The American corporate owner of the cargo jet impounded in Zimbabwe after the bloodied body of a man was discovered aboard during a refueling stop confirmed on Tuesday that man was a stowaway found in a compartment adjacent to the nose landing gear. The owner, Western Global Airlines of Estero, Fla., also said that it was working with the Zimbabwean authorities to investigate the matter. The MD11 aircraft, en route on Sunday to Durban, South Africa, from Munich, Germany, was carrying a “diplomatic shipment” for the South African Reserve Bank, the company said. Officials quoted in Zimbabwe news accounts said the shipment was a large amount of South African currency. Western Global Airlines, which specializes in cargo flights to Africa, said that the identity of the body had yet to be established but that there was “no indication that his presence is related to the company or this specific cargo shipment.”

headline: Pope Francis Entreats Mexico’s Youth to Resist Call of Drug Cartels
abstract: Francis delivered a searing indictment of the Mexican underworld, urging the nation’s youth to value themselves and resist the temptation to join forces with groups “that sow terror.”
lead_paragraph: MORELIA, Mexico — Pope Francis delivered his most searing indictment of the Mexican underworld Tuesday, encouraging the nation’s youth to value themselves and resist the temptation to join forces with “criminal organizations that sow terror.”

headline: Long After Bergdahl’s Release, His Hometown Is Still Under Siege
keywords: ['Threats and Threatening Messages', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Desertion (Military)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Prisoners of War', 'Courts-Martial']
abstract: Residents of Hailey, Idaho, say the town has been changed by the threats that came after the release of Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl.
lead_paragraph: HAILEY, Idaho — It was the third text message from the unfamiliar number — the one that made direct reference to Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl — that frightened Sherry Horton. It was written in nearly unintelligible gibberish, but its tone was unmistakably menacing.

headline: F.D.A. Issues Zika Virus Guidelines for Blood Supply
abstract: The Food and Drug Administration is advising some blood banks to import blood from regions without an outbreak and certain at-risk donors to delay making a donation.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Tuesday issued new guidelines for blood banks intended to help prevent the contamination of the nation’s blood supply with the Zika virus.

headline: Spaniard to Face U.S. Trial in Art Scandal
abstract: The national court ordered the extradition to the United States of Jesús Ángel Bergantiños Díaz, accused in a major art market scandal that involved the sale of nearly $70 million in forged paintings through a New York gallery.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — The national court on Tuesday ordered the extradition to the United States of a Spanish businessman accused in a major art market scandal that involved the sale of nearly $70 million in forged paintings through Knoedler & Company, once New York’s oldest gallery.

headline: George Gaynes, a Versatile Character Actor, Dies at 98
abstract: Mr. Gaynes appeared in hundreds of episodes of sitcoms and dramas on television, 35 Hollywood and made-for-television films, and many plays, musical comedies and operas in New York and Europe.
lead_paragraph: George Gaynes, who played a grouchy foster parent on the 1980s sitcom “Punky Brewster,” the beleaguered commandant in seven “Police Academy” films and a soap opera star with a crush on Dustin Hoffman in drag in the Hollywood hit “Tootsie,” died on Monday at his daughter’s home in North Bend, Wash. He was 98.

headline: At Oscar de la Renta, an Innocent, Idyllic Beauty Look
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: Hair and makeup at the fall/winter show evoked bygone days — from the 18th century to the Edwardian era to the Peggy Moffitt ’60s.
lead_paragraph: The beauty look at Oscar de la Renta’s fall/winter 2016 show today was evocative of Edwardian beauties — with a touch of coquettishness. Hair was a soft, romantic bun achieved by separating manes into three portions. A bottom layer was left slightly limp at the neck, the hairline loose, lending a pastoral, lived-in quality. The choice to leave knots in a hairnet, noted the hairstylist Guido Palau, “nods to another time and is very contained and proper,” but still very easy, with softness around the face. Nails were also reminiscent of another era. Inspired by 18th-century manicures, which entailed buffing nails to a shine, models’ were given a coating of sheer pink polish, followed with Essie Matte About You topcoat for a satin finish.

headline: Eyeing South Carolina, Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders Vie for Crucial Voters
abstract: Mrs. Clinton visited Harlem to propose $125 billion in new spending for poor and minority communities, and Mr. Sanders barnstormed the South, pledging to combat institutional racism.
lead_paragraph: Scrambling for the support of black voters as a crucial primary in South Carolina nears, Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont made appeals on Tuesday to corral their backing. Mrs. Clinton used an address in Harlem to propose $125 billion in new spending to reinvigorate poor and minority communities, and Mr. Sanders barnstormed the South, pledging to combat institutional racism and reform police departments nationwide.

headline: Now Is the Winter of Odd Mets Content
abstract: With pitchers and catchers beginning spring training, the Mets are in the unaccustomed position of top dog, even as the Yankees do not appear ready to go away.
lead_paragraph: When last seen, the Mets’ magic had come undone. The second baseman with the golden bat turned fumble-fingered; the staff ace became hittable in his moment of redemptive glory; the alchemist manager mixed the wrong potions and mistimed the summoning of relievers.

headline: Oscar de la Renta: Fall 2016 RW
abstract: Peter Copping’s last ready-to-wear collection as creative director.
lead_paragraph: Peter Copping’s last ready-to-wear collection as creative director.

headline: Giants’ Coaching Changes Start and Nearly End at Top
abstract: Fans might have been hoping for a leadership overhaul under Ben McAdoo, but the Giants said 12 assistants from Tom Coughlin’s staff had been retained.
lead_paragraph: Fans of the Giants might have been hoping for some kind of leadership overhaul under the new head coach Ben McAdoo, but the team announced Tuesday that 12 assistant coaches from the former coach Tom Coughlin’s staff had been retained.

headline: Sarah Parcak to Use TED Prize Money for Crowdsourcing on Archaeological Sites
abstract: Sarah H. Parcak, a pioneering space archaeologist, will use her $1 million TED prize for a program where everyone can monitor archaeological sites.
lead_paragraph: If someone gave you $1 million to fulfill a dream, what would it be?

headline: Christie Calls for End to Partisan Politics in State Budget Address
abstract: Less than a week after dropping out of a fierce presidential race, Gov. Chris Christie urged New Jersey lawmakers to focus on solving some of the state’s most pressing problems.
lead_paragraph: After spending much of the past year engaged in partisan politics as he campaigned for the Republican presidential nomination, Gov. Chris Christie asked New Jersey lawmakers on Tuesday to put aside their petty political differences as they worked to solve some of the state’s most pressing problems.

headline: Obama’s Options for a Supreme Court Nominee, and the Potential Fallout
abstract: Both parties are calculating how to leverage the vacancy on the court. There are many possible paths, with political consequences on both sides.
lead_paragraph: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia immediately prompted lofty-sounding pronouncements from leaders of both parties. But behind the public statements, the two parties are engaged in raw political calculations about how to best leverage the vacancy, underscoring the country’s deep polarization and the reality of how elections are waged nowadays.

headline: N.S.A. Discloses Inspector General Reports on Surveillance Program
abstract: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by the New York Times, the N.S.A. has partly declassified and disclosed these inspector general reports. They primarily relate to its warrantless surveillance program under the FISA Amendments Act.
lead_paragraph: In response to a Freedom of Information Act lawsuit by the New York Times, the N.S.A. has partly declassified and disclosed these inspector general reports. They primarily relate to its warrantless surveillance program under the FISA Amendments Act.

headline: N.S.A. Gets Less Web Data Than Believed, Report Suggests
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'E-Mail', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act (FISA)']
abstract: A new report suggests that the government is receiving far less data than privacy advocates have long suspected.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A newly declassified report by the National Security Agency’s inspector general suggests that the government is receiving far less data from Americans’ international Internet communications than privacy advocates have long suspected.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 17, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “It’s nice that science fiction exists because these are really creative people figuring out what the ultimate use of any technology might be. They come up with a lot of incredible ideas.”

headline: Mexico’s Kingpin Strategy Against the Drug Cartels

headline: Who Are We?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Socialism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Entrepreneurship', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The leading presidential candidates are missing the real America if they believe their attacks on the pillars of the nation’s strength.
lead_paragraph: I find this election bizarre for many reasons but none more than this: If I were given a blank sheet of paper and told to write down America’s three greatest sources of strength, they would be “a culture of entrepreneurship,” “an ethic of pluralism” and the “quality of our governing institutions.” And yet I look at the campaign so far and I hear leading candidates trashing all of them.

headline: A Tale of Horror at the United Nations
abstract: The organization is failing some of the world’s most vulnerable children by not cracking down on sexually abusive peacekeeping troops.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations is failing some of the most vulnerable children it is supposed to protect. A decade ago, the organization acknowledged that some of the peacekeepers sent to international conflict zones were sexually abusing local women and children, and it promised corrective action. The scourge continues, prompting one senior United Nations official to recoil at what he called the “constant horror story of allegations” against the peacekeepers.

headline: Donald Trump’s Secret? Channeling Andrew Jackson

lead_paragraph: SINCE Donald J. Trump shot to the top of Republican polls last fall, pundits have tried to make sense of his popularity. He has been described as a modern-day product of reality-TV narcissism, or the second coming of European fascism. But as he cruises into the South Carolina primary after beating his rivals by double digits in New Hampshire, it’s clear that neither idea quite explains his strength.

headline: ‘Ginny Gall,’ by Charlie Smith
abstract: Charlie Smith’s coming-of-age novel examines black suffering, aspiration and endurance in the Jim Crow South.
lead_paragraph: When Delvin Walker, the protagonist of Charlie Smith’s novel “Ginny Gall,” is deep into his prison sentence for a crime he did not commit, a fellow inmate introduces him to the work of Zora Neale Hurston. The inmate quotes a line memorized from Hurston’s essay “How It Feels to Be Colored Me”: “I do not belong to that sobbing school of Negrohood who hold that nature has somehow given them a lowdown dirty deal.” Delvin lets out a low whistle of disbelief in response. “Well, no wonder I never heard of that woman,” he says, and the inmate posits that, unlike them, Hurston must be “somebody who’s found a way out of the general disrespectfulness.”

headline: ‘The Queen of the Night,’ by Alexander Chee
abstract: This novel’s heroine travels from a Minnesota farm to the Paris Opera.
lead_paragraph: In opera, voice is everything. The narrator of “The Queen of the Night,” Lilliet Berne, is a star of the Paris Opera. She possesses a rare and delicate Falcon soprano range, named for ­Marie-Cornélie Falcon, whose voice famously shattered in the middle of a performance and never recovered. Lilliet’s world is one of silence and sound, of risk and fragility, and the balance between vocal power and expression.

headline: Which Type of Exercise Is Best for the Brain?
abstract: For the first time, scientists compared the neurological impacts of different types of exercise in rats: running, weight training and high-intensity interval training.
lead_paragraph: Some forms of exercise may be much more effective than others at bulking up the brain, according to a remarkable new study in rats. For the first time, scientists compared head-to-head the neurological impacts of different types of exercise: running, weight training and high-intensity interval training. The surprising results suggest that going hard may not be the best option for long-term brain health.
