lead_paragraph: President Obama is back in Washington, but the Senate remains out of town on the President’s Day holiday recess — and that has its benefits and disadvantages as the Supreme Court fight heats up.

headline: Palau vs. the Poachers
keywords: ['Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Maritime Crime', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: The island nation has mounted an aggressive response to illegal fishing in their waters. How they protect themselves may help the rest of the world save all of the oceans.
lead_paragraph: Late on a January 2015 evening in Shepherdstown, W.Va., a data analyst named Bjorn Bergman, surrounded by whiteboards scribbled with computer code, was orchestrating a high-stakes marine police chase halfway around the world. Staring at his laptop in a cramped ground-floor office, he drank from his sixth cup of coffee and typed another in a long series of emails: ‘‘Try and cut them off rather than making for the last known position.’’ Nearly 9,000 miles away, the Remeliik, a police patrol ship from the tiny island nation Palau, was pursuing a 10-man Taiwanese pirate ship, the Shin Jyi Chyuu 33, through Palauan waters. Bergman, working for a nonprofit research organization called SkyTruth, had mastered the use of satellite data to chart a ship’s most likely course. Instead of pointing the police to where the pirate ship was, he would tell them where it was about to be. He took another sip of coffee, studied his screen, then typed again: ‘‘It may be advisable for the Remeliik to turn southeast.’’

headline: Do Women Need Legislative ‘Protection’?
abstract: Next month, the Supreme Court will hear the biggest abortion case in decades — and consider whether laws designed to give women special treatment actually hurt them.
lead_paragraph: In September 1905, a laundress named Emma Gotcher reported Curt Muller, the owner of Portland Grand Laundry, for making her work more than 10 hours — the state’s legal limit for women — on, of all days, Labor Day. Gotcher was a labor activist, married to a leader of the Shirtwaist and Laundry Workers’ Union. The court found Muller guilty of violating Oregon law and fined him $10. He refused to pay, and on appeal to the Supreme Court, his lawyer drew national attention by making a feminist argument: Limits on women’s work hours actually discriminate against them. Two years earlier, in the well-known case Lochner v. New York, the Supreme Court struck down a state law that restricted bakers, most of them men, to the same 10-hour day. The bakers were ‘‘in no sense wards of the state,’’ the court said. Why, Muller’s lawyer asked, should women be treated differently?

headline: Jon Taffer Sees Shakespeare in Reality TV
abstract: The host of “Bar Rescue” on the power of transformation television, abstaining from alcohol and the two times he cried in a bar.
lead_paragraph: On your reality show ‘‘Bar Rescue,’’ you do speedy overhauls of failing bars. Do you ever worry that moving so quickly sort of undermines the owners? There’s an independent website called Bar Rescue Updates that we have nothing to do with, and they track us. According to them, we have a 70 percent success rate — the highest in all of transformation television.

headline: Are We Doomed to Slow Growth?
keywords: ['Science and Technology', 'Productivity', 'United States Economy', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Education (K-12)', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Innovation', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The pace of technological innovation may well determine the health of the American economy over time. But what matters most is how it changes us.
lead_paragraph: One day in 1980, when I was 10, I sat in my great-grandmother’s living room and poured out questions about what life was like for her as a girl in Belarus. At 90, she was still sharp and could answer my questions. But she didn’t betray any of the emotion I hoped for. Born in 1890, in a tiny village powered by horses and the sun in a manner hardly changed from the time of ancient Rome, she grew up to witness the invention of the airplane and the adoption of electricity and the telephone. I wanted her to join me in marveling at this series of world-changing transformations, which I knew were beyond anything her girlhood self could have imagined. She just answered my questions calmly, politely. ‘‘No, I don’t remember the first airplane I saw.’’ ‘‘No, I don’t remember the first person I called on a telephone.’’

headline: Reinvention in Walla Walla’s Wine Country
abstract: Thanks to fine restaurants and charmingly off-kilter wineries, Walla Walla has become a destination for gastronomes and oenophiles alike.
lead_paragraph: There are only so many occasions on which a responsible adult can justify consuming alcohol and food nonstop for an entire week. Turning 40 is one of them.

headline: Leaving ‘Full House’ Was His Biggest Regret. So He Rebuilt It.
abstract: The sitcom’s creator calls leaving the show the biggest regret of his life. Now he’s rebooting it, complete with laugh track, for Netflix.
lead_paragraph: In one of the valleys between the peaks of his career, Jeff Franklin had an idea for a TV series. Called “House of Comics,” it would follow three aspiring stand-ups living together in Los Angeles. “It was three single guys trying to cause trouble, and then turning it into material for their act,” Mr. Franklin explained. “That was the show I wanted to do.”

headline: Judge John Hodgman on a Home Cellphone Ban
abstract: Kids will always find a way to ignore you.
lead_paragraph: Denise writes: We are expecting our first baby, and I want her to grow up in a home where people still pay attention to one another. I’d like to put a friendly sign on our door that asks guests to use phones in our home only in the event of an emergency. My husband cringes at the thought.

headline: Should I Speak Up for a Pet Pig?
keywords: ['Ethicists, The (Times Column)', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Genetics and Heredity', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Pigs']
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on unintentional animal abuse, revealing someone’s genetic heritage and telling neighbors about their teenager’s illicit behavior.
lead_paragraph: I am in a profession where I often go to people’s houses to work with their children. I have one client whom I like very much and who has requested my services a number of times, but whenever I leave that client’s house, I find myself troubled. This family has a teacup pig, which lives with them in a medium-size apartment. I consider myself an animal lover, and it so happens that I have looked into the fad of teacup pigs. I know that they are really piglets of a larger variety, the potbellied pig, which are unintentionally underfed by owners who have been led by dishonest sellers to believe that the pigs need to eat less than they really do. Right now the pig is small, perhaps 10 to 15 pounds, but I know it will keep growing and that the lowest healthy weight for a full-grown ‘‘teacup pig’’ is about 60 pounds; a potbellied pig can easily grow to more than 100 pounds. I asked the family how big the pig would get, thinking perhaps they knew the facts and had some plan. They told me that they expect it to remain the size it is now. The worst part? They often remark that the pig is acting hungry; I imagine they feed him the too-small amount they were directed to by the seller. I believe that this family loves their pig very much and that I am witnessing an unintentional act of animal cruelty, but I am in a quandary: Should I tell them that they are unwittingly mistreating their beloved pet? I worry that I would be overstepping my professional bounds. People can be very touchy when it comes to their pets, and I want to maintain cordial relations with them for the sake of my continued employment. Do I have an ethical obligation to tell them the truth about teacup pigs? Name Withheld

headline: Clinton, Sanders and the Underrated Power of the Black Voter
abstract: We’re living in an era when African-Americans have essentially played kingmaker in the most important elections in the nation.
lead_paragraph: If you were asked to assess African-American voting power, you might think about the long history of disenfranchisement that still lingers today, in troubles in Ferguson, Mo.; in efforts to roll back the Voting Rights Act; or in recent moves to limit voting access around the country.

headline: Final Days Before Crucial Votes Offer Viewers a Full Television Lineup
abstract: The 2016 presidential campaign has unfolded largely on television, so it’s only fitting that the final days of the Republican primary in South Carolina and the Democratic caucuses in Nevada will play out in televised town-hall-style meetings.
lead_paragraph: The 2016 presidential campaign has played out largely on television, whether in the form of ads or news conferences or the reams of Donald J. Trump coverage. So it’s only fitting that the final days of the Republican primary in South Carolina and the Democratic caucuses in Nevada will play out in televised town-hall-style meetings.

First, Joseph Altuzarra closed his show with a floor-length boho gown that was toughened up with sequins. Derek Lam showed a beaded black V-neck paired with an armor-like metallic skirt. And yesterday on the dreamy Rodarte runway, Kate and Laura Mulleavy added a sparkly touch to their signature, intricate gowns.

And given the prime showcase for the musical’s opening number on the Grammys broadcast on Monday night, that dominating run could continue for quite a while.

headline: 1916: Germany’s Defensive Guns

This request was handed to Mr. Robert Lansing, Secretary of State, by Count von Bernstorff to-day [Feb. 17], following the protest at Germany’s Memorandum that after March 1 its submersibles would begin the new campaign. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 18, 1916

lead_paragraph: Arriving on the winds of great notices in Chicago, where it received two productions from the Goodman Theater, Noah Haidle’s “Smokefall” makes its New York premiere this month. Mr. Haidle’s previous plays have toyed with fantasy and form, and “Smokefall” is no exception. Although it nominally tells of four generations of a Michigan family, the play has elements of surrealism: a character named Beauty, for instance, never speaks and prefers subsisting on dirt and paint to regular food. A novel diet, certainly, if not the most sensible.

headline: ‘Over-Scheduled Andrew,’ by Ashley Spires
abstract: A new picture book about a harried little bird takes aim at the current vogue for jam-packing children’s days with adult-run activities.
lead_paragraph: There are some picture books that reach for timelessness, offering no details that give away exactly when the story is taking place, or when it was written. And there are some that speak directly to their moment. “Over-Scheduled Andrew” is (you guessed it) firmly in the latter camp, taking aim at the current vogue for jam-packing children’s days with adult-run activities. This book represents the backlash against the frantic pursuit of what’s often known as “enrichment,” a term that can seem most apropos for the wallets of the adults who teach and coach all these after-school classes, teams and activities. Spires’s message is not subtle: She writes as an unapologetic champion of the idea that, rather than pushing elementary-schoolers into organized, goal-oriented pursuits, we would enrich their lives more by offering them, say, a couple of unstructured hours with a giant cardboard box, some scissors, packing tape and markers, and no grown-ups chirping directions at them.

Bush.

headline: When Harry Truman Nearly Doubled the Minimum Wage
abstract: The minimum went from 40 to 75 cents an hour, and unemployment went down.
lead_paragraph: One of the arguments against raising the federal minimum wage from $7.25 an hour today to $15 an hour over five years is that the United States has never had an increase that large. There is solid research to show that modest increases in the minimum help low-wage workers without harming low-wage employers. But there is no similarly rigorous research on the effects of large increases.

Its demise offers a lesson in both the limitations of public diplomacy and the obstacles to providing high-quality television journalism.

headline: In Neanderthals’ DNA, Ancient Humans May Have Left Genetic Mark

abstract: On top of abundant evidence that humans carry Neanderthal DNA, a new study shows that the interbreeding went both ways.
