headline: ‘International Pop’: The Usual Suspects and More
abstract: The exhibition at Philadelphia Museum of Art through May 15 represents nearly 90 artists worldwide.
lead_paragraph: “International Pop,” which opens Wednesday, Feb. 24, at the Philadelphia Museum of Art, lays waste to the idea of Pop Art as a mostly American — or even American-British-German — phenomenon. Beginning with one of Jasper Johns’s 1958 “Flag” paintings, this revisionist show, which originated at the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis, includes the usual suspects from either side of the Atlantic. But it encompasses many more unusual artists who responded to the rise of consumer culture, popular media and various forms of imperialism while also experimenting with new art forms during the turbulent 1960s and ’70s.

headline: A Marathon Evening of Prokofiev Piano Concertos at BAM
abstract: Valery Gergiev conducts the Mariinsky Orchestra in a performance featuring five pianists at the Brooklyn Academy of Music
lead_paragraph: It’s not often that Prokofiev fans have a chance to hear all five of his Piano Concertos in one evening. On Wednesday, Feb. 24, Valery Gergiev conducts the Mariinsky Orchestra in a marathon performance featuring five pianists, beginning with George Li playing the single-movement Concerto No. 1. Alexander Toradze will perform the fiendishly difficult, fascinating second concerto, dedicated to a close friend of Prokofiev’s who committed suicide. The pianist Sviatoslav Richter described the “Intermezzo” of the brooding work, which has a huge, roiling cadenza, as evoking “a dragon devouring its young.”

headline: Fed Officials, at Meeting, Found Economic Outlook Cloudy
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers declined to offer a forecast for economic conditions, saying it was unclear whether market turmoil would impede growth.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal Reserve officials threw up their hands in January, deciding that they could not decide whether market turmoil would impede domestic economic growth.

headline: Sendak’s ‘Wild Things,’ Via Spike Jonze
abstract: The 2009 adaptation of “Where the Wild Things Are” concludes Nitehawk Cinema’s Little Bookworms series
lead_paragraph: It wasn’t easy for Spike Jonze to create his 2009 adaptation of Maurice Sendak’s 1963 classic, “Where the Wild Things Are,” about a lonely boy’s escape to a fantastical island populated by fearsome if benign monsters. His original conception for the film — which ends the Nitehawk Cinema’s Little Bookworms series on Feb. 27 and 28 (Saturday and Sunday) — was too dark for Warner Bros., and the giant supporting characters, offspring of Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, had animatronic issues. But the director persisted, and the movie, written by Mr. Jonze and Dave Eggers and offering gentle songs by Karen O of the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, became a classic of its own. The newcomer Max Records plays the hero, Max, but it’s the ensemble behind the beasts (including Forest Whitaker, Lauren Ambrose, Catherine O’Hara and Chris Cooper) who sparkle. As Max’s buddy Carol, James Gandolfini (Tony Soprano himself) had perhaps the most tender role of his career. Ages 6 and up. (136 Metropolitan Avenue, Williamsburg, Brooklyn; nitehawkcinema.com.)

headline: ‘Girls’? Aren’t They Women Yet?
abstract: Season 5 of “Girls” on HBO opens with a wedding.
lead_paragraph: When last we saw our “Girls,” they were growing up. Marnie (Allison Williams), having been abandoned at their showcase by Desi (Ebon Moss-Bachrach), stepped onstage to find her voice. Jessa (Jemima Kirke), after witnessing the agony of birth, decided to become a therapist. Shoshanna (Zosia Mamet), faced with the option of moving in with Scott (Jason Ritter), chose to take a job in Japan. And Hannah (Lena Dunham) — after tearfully rebuffing Adam (Adam Driver) in his plea to get back together — was seen, six months later, kissing a new guy, Fran (Jake Lacy), in the snow.

headline: At Michael Kors, ‘I Woke Up Like This’ Beauty Sticks
abstract: For the designer’s fall/winter 2016 collection, makeup was inspired by off-duty models — and at times included eyeliner left over from other shows.
lead_paragraph: Michael Kors’s models are known to have a healthy, sun-kissed glow. But this season, the show’s makeup artist, Dick Page, traded consistently bronzed complexions for a leftover-from-the-night-before look. Inspired by what off-duty models might look like in real life, Page didn’t remove any of their existing eye makeup — at times leftover from previous shows — before getting to work. He then closely lined lids with either a black, brown or navy hue before smudging it with his fingers.

headline: Makeover Set for Police Building at Heart of a Sleeker Times Square
abstract: The Police Department will solicit proposals to bring the building into the present, in an area that has gone from seedy to hyper-commercial.
lead_paragraph: The identical mosaic tile maps of New York City on the sides of the police substation in Times Square hark back to a different era. Some of the Monopoly-like symbols among the tiles that once helped tourists locate landmarks are gone. So, too, are a number of those landmarks, like the old Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Blackhawks Rally Past Rangers in Ryan McDonagh’s Return
abstract: The Rangers welcomed back McDonagh, their captain, who had missed six games with a concussion, but they lost in regulation at home for the first time since late December.
lead_paragraph: A day before visiting the White House to mark their third Stanley Cup victory in six seasons, the Chicago Blackhawks stopped by Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.

headline: Celebrating When Hip-Hop Had Its Crossover
abstract: A crossover oldies tour includes Tone Loc, Kid ‘n Play and Salt-N-Pepa.
lead_paragraph: First, the hairsplitting: “I Love the 90s” is an excellent concept for a tour of came-and-went hip-hop-meets-pop dynamos, but in this lineup, which comes to New York and New Jersey this week, the Technicolor end of the late 1980s is the real touchstone. That’s when the croaky-voiced Tone Loc was at his peak, when Kid ‘n Play and Salt-N-Pepa were perfecting their dance moves, when Rob Base was fine-tuning his chants.

headline: Lady Gaga Applauds Brandon Maxwell, and Kirsten Dunst Dances With Rodarte
abstract: Brandon Maxwell hosts a show and after-party at the Monkey Bar on the Upper East Side, while the Rodarte sisters, Kate and Laura Mulleavy, hold an after-party at Berlin in East Village.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Maxwell hosts a show and after-party at the Monkey Bar on the Upper East Side, while the Rodarte sisters, Kate and Laura Mulleavy, hold an after-party at Berlin in East Village.

headline: Mari Giudicelli’s Debut Shoe Collection
abstract: The model launches her eponymous brand of loafers and mules this week.
lead_paragraph: The model launches her eponymous brand of loafers and mules this week.

headline: Blake Lively Talks About Michael Kors
abstract: The actress Blake Lively from the front row of his show on Tuesday and had brought her mother along.
lead_paragraph: Michael Kors has made a fortune from perfecting a certain look that is all his own. Camel coats, deep tans and a glossy blowout? So Michael Kors. Tan leather bag and shoes? Very, very Michael Kors. Bare legs in winter because you have a car waiting for you in the snow outside? The definition of Michael Kors.

headline: Lady Gaga Applauds Brandon Maxwell, and Kirsten Dunst Dances With Rodarte
abstract: Brandon Maxwell hosts a show and after-party at the Monkey Bar on the Upper East Side, while the Rodarte sisters, Kate and Laura Mulleavy, hold an after-party at Berlin in East Village.
lead_paragraph: Brandon Maxwell held a party immediately following his runway show at the Monkey Bar on the Upper East Side. Lady Gaga attended, giving her former stylist and friend a standing ovation as the models streamed out for the finale. And at the Berlin bar in the East Village, the Rodarte designers gathered their friends, including Kirsten Dunst and Tavi Gevinson, to celebrate their collection and Kate Mulleavy’s birthday.

headline: Find Out What’s New in Smartphones at Mobile World Congress
abstract: Tech news apps can be used to keep up with what’s new and on the way, as seen at the mobile industry’s annual trade show in Spain.
lead_paragraph: EVERY year, the smartphone world gathers in Spain for a giant trade show called Mobile World Congress, M.W.C. for short. Thousands of exhibitors show off their current and coming wares, including smartphones, wearable technology and new apps.

headline: Spanish Unit of China’s ICBC Raided in Money Laundering Case
abstract: The Madrid branch of the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China is accused of helping Chinese and Spanish criminal syndicates commit financial fraud.
lead_paragraph: The Spanish police raided the Madrid subsidiary of one of China’s largest banks on Wednesday and arrested five of its directors as part of a broad investigation into money laundering.

headline: Russia Sues Ukraine in London Court Over Unpaid Debt Claim
abstract: The Russian finance ministry says it is owed $3 billion, escalating a legal battle between the countries that is already raging in European courts.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia filed a lawsuit against Ukraine in the London High Court on Wednesday over $3 billion in unpaid loans, escalating a legal battle that is adding to the geopolitical tensions between the two countries.

headline: Nikki Haley Endorses Marco Rubio as South Carolina Prepares to Vote
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio received the endorsement of South Carolina’s governor, Nikki R. Haley, a stamp of approval that could prove significant as his campaign tries to break out in the state’s primary on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: CHAPIN, S.C. — Senator Marco Rubio received the endorsement Wednesday of South Carolina’s governor, Nikki R. Haley, a stamp of approval that could prove significant as his campaign tries to break out ahead in the state’s primary on Saturday.

headline: Argentina Battles Major Outbreak of Dengue as Mosquito Population Swells
abstract: The authorities said that two provinces had been hit especially hard by dengue, and that the outbreak — the worst in seven years — had not yet peaked.
lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Argentina is grappling with its worst outbreak of dengue in seven years as the population of Aedes aegypti mosquitoes, which also transmit the Zika virus, expands in the subtropical northeast of the country.

headline: 73-Story Tower Would Be Brooklyn’s Tallest by Far
abstract: The building, which would rise beside Junior’s Restaurant on DeKalb Avenue in Downtown Brooklyn, would be almost twice as high as anything around it.
lead_paragraph: Scrutiny is about to begin of a proposal for the tallest tower in Brooklyn, one that would be impossible to ignore.

headline: A New Shoe Brand Focuses on the Classics
abstract: The model Mari Giudicelli unveils her eponymous line this week.
lead_paragraph: The model Mari Giudicelli is best known for her work for brands such as Maryam Nassir Zadeh, Ulla Johnson and Eckhaus Latta — she’s appeared in countless runway shows, magazine editorials and ad campaigns. But now, she’s becoming a designer in her own right: on Friday, she will debut her eponymous shoe line — a selection of classic, simple loafers and flats in suede and exotic skins.

headline: Once No. 4, Juan Martín del Potro Starts Over Again at 1,041st
abstract: In his first tennis match in 11 months after a wrist operation, Del Potro, 27, beat Denis Kudla on Tuesday night at the Delray Beach Open.
lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — Eleven months was long enough for Juan Martín del Potro to ponder whether he wanted to attempt another comeback from wrist surgery. One match into his return from his fourth wrist operation, he appeared satisfied with his decision.

headline: Teaching Climate Change
abstract: “The fate of the world literally depends on the education of the American public and its understanding of the impending crisis.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Housing Aid for Homeless
abstract: An advocacy group writes that It is illegal for city landlords to reject applicants or evict tenants because they pay rent using assistance vouchers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Ted Cruz Rebuffs Donald Trump Ad Lawsuit Threat
abstract: Ted Cruz encouraged Donald Trump to sue him over an ad Mr. Trump does not like.
lead_paragraph: SENECA, S.C. — He read aloud from a cease-and-desist letter. He presented the video evidence. He said he looked forward to deposing his chief rival for the Republican nomination.

headline: Police Seek Suspect After Fatal Brooklyn Shooting
abstract: The victim was shot during an argument outside an apartment building that has a history of drug activity, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The police on Wednesday were searching for an assailant who fatally shot a Brooklyn man during an argument outside an apartment building that has a history of drug activity.

headline: Privacy and Cable TV
abstract: The National Cable and Telecommunications Association writes that “Big Tech doesn’t need a government handout to deliver programming.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Explaining Apple’s Fight With the F.B.I.
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'iPhone']
abstract: Technologists and legal experts are dissecting what the company can’t, or won’t, do to help unlock the iPhone of a San Bernardino attacker.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday evening, a federal court ordered Apple to help the F.B.I. unlock an iPhone used by one of the attackers who killed 14 people in San Bernardino, Calif., in December.

headline: Vatican Sex Abuse Panel
abstract: A reader writes that “the matter of ecclesiastical sanction may be better addressed in national church tribunals rather than Vatican tribunals.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Sandy Alderson, Feeling Better, Is Focused on Health of Pitchers and Wright
abstract: Alderson, the team’s general manager, learned he had cancer after the Mets clinched the N.L. East and considered the team’s playoff run a nice distraction.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — A few days after the Mets clinched the National League East in September and General Manager Sandy Alderson was doused with champagne, looking happier than he had in years, he was told he had cancer. He dealt with the news quietly as he fine-tuned his roster and had two more champagne baths in the Mets’ run to the World Series.

headline: Seeking a More Humane Way to Die
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Life-Sustaining Support Systems, Withdrawal Of', 'Hospitals', 'Elder Care', 'Hospice Care']
abstract: Doctors and a family member discuss end-of-life choices.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Heartburn Drugs Tied to Dementia Risk
abstract: The popular heartburn drugs known as proton pump inhibitors have been linked to an increased risk of Alzheimer’s and other forms of dementia.
lead_paragraph: The popular heartburn drugs known as proton pump inhibitors have been linked to a range of ills: bone fractures, kidney problems, infections and more. Now a large new study has found that they are associated with an increased risk for dementia as well.

headline: Aid Deliveries Begin to 5 Besieged Syrian Towns
abstract: The deliveries by truck convoys amounted to the first significant benefit to afflicted civilians trapped for months by war.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — More than 100 trucks laden with emergency food and medicine began deliveries on Wednesday to tens of thousands of desperate Syrians in five locations besieged for months by the civil war, United Nations officials and relief workers reported.

headline: Mile 13 in the Deployment Marathon
abstract: Halfway through a deployment, looking for the “I can do this” moment.
lead_paragraph: The hardest part of the journey is the first step, right? Respectfully, I disagree; I think it’s the steps in the middle. We’ve just passed the halfway point in my Navy husband’s seven-month deployment (preceded by over a year of constant in-and-out travel for training, called “work-ups”), and instead of sprinting to a finish line, it feels like my 5-year-old daughter, 3-year-old son and I are crawling along a never-ending trail.

headline: Ex-Eurythmic Dave Stewart, the Zelig of Pop
abstract: The hyperconnected musician talks about his new memoir, “Sweet Dreams Are Made of This: A Life in Music.”
lead_paragraph: We all know Six Degrees of Kevin Bacon: How many steps does it take to connect any famous person to the ubiquitous character actor?

headline: A Powerful ‘Elektra,’ Sheep at the Armory and Other Spring Classical Highlights
abstract: Metropolitan Opera productions, a Dutch composer’s spectacle, a tribute to Robert Shaw and the New York Philharmonic’s second new-music biennial are must-sees this spring.
lead_paragraph: Speculation swirls around any new production at the Metropolitan Opera. But the company’s staging of Strauss’s “Elektra,” opening on April 14, has been awaited with particular eagerness, and has already been deemed a milestone in the career of its director, Patrice Chéreau.

headline: Ratmansky and Lil Buck on the Spring Dance Calendar
abstract: American Ballet Theater highlights the prolific Alexei Ratmansky; Lil Buck and Jared Grimes unite with Wynton Marsalis; and more dance events of the new season.
lead_paragraph: Some kinds of climate change are good. The eight-week repertory announced by American Ballet Theater for its annual spring season at the Metropolitan Opera House is the best news for this company in more than 25 years. More than that, it refreshes the whole New York dance environment. Instead of relying chiefly on fare choreographed over a century ago in inadequate productions (as it once did), the company is giving extensive time to important 20th- and 21st-century ballets.

headline: A Former Tween Idol, Reborn Off Broadway
abstract: Nat Wolff is all grown up in a revival of Sam Shepard’s “Buried Child.”
lead_paragraph: Nat Wolff arrives at Joe Allen, the Midtown restaurant that’s served as a hangout for off-duty actors for over 50 years, with a gash on his finger. The 21-year-old is currently starring in a revival of Sam Shepard’s 1978 Pulitzer Prize-winning play “Buried Child” at the Alice Griffin Jewel Box Theatre, and at the previous night’s performance — during a scene in which his character, Vince, violently hurls glass bottles against a wall — he looked down to find a pool of blood at his feet. To many, Wolff is best known for his roles as a teenager blinded by cancer in “The Fault in Our Stars” and as the lead opposite Cara Delevingne in last summer’s “Paper Towns,” both adaptations of John Green novels. By contrast, Shepard’s drama, about three generations of a Midwestern family coming to grips with an economic depression and personal tragedy, marks a step up in intensity. “I insisted when we started that we use real glass in the play,” Wolff says, examining his hand. “But now I’m not so sure.”

headline: Cliffside Home Will Go to Los Angeles County Museum of Art
abstract: An angular glass residence designed by John Lautner will be donated to the museum by the real-estate investor James Goldstein.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Soon after Michael Govan took his job as the director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art in 2006, he began talking about acquiring “a major work of architecture” for the museum to oversee, preserve and open up to visitors. Now, almost 10 years into his job, he has managed to make his first acquisition: The Sheats-Goldstein residence, an angular glass-walled home designed by John Lautner that comes complete with a nightclub, tennis court and a “skyspace” installation by the artist James Turrell in its backyard.

headline: No Flower is Getting More Love This Season Than the Daisy
abstract: Expect a floral explosion as spring looks start to arrive in stores.
lead_paragraph: Expect a floral explosion as spring looks start to arrive in stores.

headline: Be Cautious When Choosing a Tax Preparer
abstract: Consumers should ask a potential preparer many questions, regardless of whether that person has credentials.
lead_paragraph: Consumers looking for someone to handle their income tax returns may not know that many paid tax preparers aren’t required to have special training or pass a test to prove their expertise. So it’s important to do some research before handing over your financial information.

headline: Photos of the Day: Turkey and Elsewhere
abstract: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Turkey and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: Paris Doesn’t Get Sweatpants, Yet. So A.P.C. Brought Its Own to New York.
abstract: Jean Touitou, the founder of the French label A.P.C., expounds on athleisure, sandals with socks, and Camus and Sartre.
lead_paragraph: Jean Touitou of A.P.C. is as close as contemporary fashion comes to a saloniste. The outspoken founder of the label, whose stores reliably dot the cool neighborhoods of the globe, declines runways and shows his collections in group presentations that he narrates, microphone in hand, often pausing to quote from Proust or digress into discussions of his late cousin’s genius unpublished novel. They are not without incident (as when he stumbled into a fiasco of race relations and political correctness by quoting his friend and collaborator Kanye West), and they are never without interest.

headline: Feb. 17, 2016 — Photos of the Day
abstract: Photos from Turkey, Uganda, Russia and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Turkey, Uganda, Russia and Germany.

headline: Naian González Norvind Reaches for High Notes in ‘Her Requiem’
abstract: The actress will play a 17-year-old violinist in the play by Greg Pierce.
lead_paragraph: Lately, the Fauré Requiem has weighed heavily on Naian González Norvind’s mind. So have the requiems of Mozart, Dvorak and Verdi.

headline: University of Texas Sets Parameters for Concealed Handguns on Austin Campus
abstract: The university president, Gregory L. Fenves, in announcing the policy, which follows state law, said he still did not believe handguns belonged on campus.
lead_paragraph: Despite his own reservations, and those of much of his staff and student body, the president of the University of Texas at Austin on Wednesday announced rules that will allow concealed handguns to be carried on campus, including in classrooms.

headline: Sarah Charles Lewis Bids for Posterity in ‘Tuck Everlasting’
abstract: The 11-year-old actress has moved from Georgia to New York to star in the new musical.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Charles Lewis is only 11, but already she has a position on immortality: If offered a liquid that would allow her to live forever, but keep her always at her current age, she would decline.

headline: 2016-02-15-Report
abstract: A policy governing concealed carry on campus was developed to comply with a new state law.
lead_paragraph: A policy governing concealed carry on campus was developed to comply with a new state law.

headline: UT Austin s Campus Carry Policies Office of the President the University of Texas at Austin
abstract: In an open letter, Gregory L. Fenves, president of the University of Texas at Austin, announces a policy that will generally allow concealed carry, which has been prohibited on the campus.
lead_paragraph: In an open letter, Gregory L. Fenves, president of the University of Texas at Austin, announces a policy that will generally allow concealed carry, which has been prohibited on the campus.

headline: Why Teenage Girls Roll Their Eyes
abstract: Eye-rolling serves a variety of purposes, and the meanings behind the mannerism tell us a lot about what it’s like to be a teenager.
lead_paragraph: Many people can roll their eyes, but adolescent girls have practically monopolized the ocular gesture as a form of communication. Adults on the receiving end of an eye roll are often offended, and sometimes that’s just what the girl had in mind. But frequently, it’s not. Eye-rolling serves a variety of purposes, and the meanings behind the mannerism tell us a lot about what it’s like to be a teenager.

headline: Zainab Jah, ‘Eclipsed’ Star, Is Ready for Battle
abstract: Ms. Jah is slim and not quite 5-foot-2, but on stage she looms larger. Especially when she’s holding a machine gun.
lead_paragraph: In “Eclipsed,” which begins previews Feb. 23 at the Golden Theater, Zainab Jah plays Maima, an AK-47-toting soldier who has given herself the name Disgruntled. But one evening at a South Brooklyn bistro, plates of oysters arrayed before her, Ms. Jah seemed content. “I’m greedy,” she said, with enthusiasm and without apology.

headline: For Director Lileana Blain-Cruz Things Are Going Swimmingly
abstract: In addition to Lucas Hnath’s play “Red Speedo,” Ms. Blain-Cruz’s spring also includes directing works by Alice Birch and Branden Jacobs-Jenkins.
lead_paragraph: The director Lileana Blain-Cruz didn’t so much stand up as pop out of a chair in New York Theater Workshop’s rehearsal studio. She then danced across the floor toward the actors Alex Breaux and Lucas Caleb Rooney. “I’m going to switch something up for you,” she nearly sang, suggesting a change in the fight scene they were rehearsing for “Red Speedo,” now in previews at the theater.

headline: Open Letter from the University of Texas at Austin
abstract: In an open letter, Gregory L. Fenves, president of the University of Texas at Austin, announces a policy that will generally allow concealed carry, which has been prohibited on the campus.
lead_paragraph: In an open letter, Gregory L. Fenves, president of the University of Texas at Austin, announces a policy that will generally allow concealed carry, which has been prohibited on the campus.

headline: 2016-02-15-Report
abstract: A policy governing concealed carry on University of Texas campuses was developed to comply with a new state law.
lead_paragraph: A policy governing concealed carry on University of Texas campuses was developed to comply with a new state law.

headline: Review: Herlin Riley Commands Attention on ‘New Direction’
abstract: Mr. Riley, a drummer, delivers funky, soulful jazz with the help of some young and accomplished bandmates on his new album.
lead_paragraph: “New Direction”

headline: Pope Francis Visits U.S. – Mexico Border
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Popes', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'ROMAN CATHOLIC CHURCH']
abstract: Pope Francis stepped directly into the angry American political debate about immigration on Wednesday when he visited Ciudad Juárez, Mexico, at the border with the United States. He celebrated Mass at a fairground barely 300 feet from the Rio Grande, calling forced migration “a human tragedy.”

headline: Review: Michael Pollan and Pangs of Guilt, Not Hunger
abstract: “Cooked,” based on Mr. Pollan’s 2013 book, is a long-view history lesson in how cooking innovations we take for granted transformed the human species.
lead_paragraph: Michael Pollan is food-shaming us again, this time in a four-part Netflix docu-series. It’s a gentle sort of shaming, and informative, but unless you’ve previously been converted to Pollanology through his books (“The Omnivore’s Dilemma”) or his other screen appearances (“Food, Inc.”), you’ll come away feeling mighty guilty about what you eat.

headline: Review: In ‘Every Song Ever,’ Ben Ratliff Helps the Listener Discern
abstract: Mr. Ratliff explains and counters the confusion that music fans encounter today as they navigate an overload of choices.
lead_paragraph: Complaining that there’s too much good art and entertainment being made at the moment seems churlish — how could that be a problem? Yet it’s undeniable that there is something curiously oppressive about the current bounty, something paralyzing about our ease of access to it. Television is one field where what ought to be a boon feels increasingly like a bane: With scores of new shows each season, keeping up with what’s good gets to seem like a chore. If anything, the overload in music feels even more unmanageable.

headline: Acel Moore, Founder of Black Journalists’ Organization, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Moore awakened his white colleagues and their readers in Philadelphia to everyday life in black communities.
lead_paragraph: Acel Moore, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist who co-founded the National Association of Black Journalists and awakened his white colleagues and their readers to everyday life in black communities, died on Friday at his home in Wyncote, Pa., near Philadelphia. He was 75.

headline: Channing Tatum Gives ‘Hail, Caesar!’ a Tap-Dancing Kick
abstract: The choreographer Christopher Gattelli’s “No Dames!” number in the film offered Mr. Tatum a showcase and took him out of his comfort zone.
lead_paragraph: What turned into one of the most memorable dances on film in recent years started modestly with this description, said its choreographer, Christopher Gattelli: “Burt Gurney does a number on a ship with a mop.”

headline: The Look: Anna Sui’s Frothy Baby-Doll
abstract: The designer looks back on what led to the creation of her hugely popular dress.
lead_paragraph: In the early 1980s, Anna Sui was a young fashion hopeful toiling, mostly unsung, on Seventh Avenue, her look largely influenced by the style and the music of the London youth quake. Flash forward a decade, and a chain of lucky circumstances introduced the Chinese-American designer to her first brush with fame.

headline: At Narciso Rodriguez, Sculpture-Adorned Earlobes
abstract: For her second collaboration with the designer, the jeweler Ana Khouri drew inspiration from the late Brazilian artist Lygia Clark.
lead_paragraph: “Narciso and I have a similar aesthetic and we look at women in the same way,” says the jewelry designer Ana Khouri, referring to her friend and collaborator Narciso Rodriguez. Given her formal training as a sculptor, Khouri views her pieces as “not only dressing the body, but making a connection with the body.” She adds that Rodriguez, too, “is very conscious of lines and forms.”

headline: Lela Rose: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Looks from the Lela Rose Collection.
lead_paragraph: Looks from the Lela Rose Collection.

headline: Facts & Figures: January’s Record-Breaking Heat
abstract: Last month was the warmest January since recording began in 1880 — and it broke another record too.
lead_paragraph: Last month was the warmest January worldwide since recording began in 1880. What’s more, the temperature anomaly for January — a measure of how much the temperature differed from an average of past temperatures for the month — was also the largest ever calculated.

headline: Ted Cruz in Virtual Tie With Donald Trump in New National Poll
abstract: The NBC News/Wall Street Journal survey found that Mr. Cruz had erased Mr. Trump’s lead nationally, leaving them in a virtual tie heading into the South Carolina primary.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz of Texas has erased Donald J. Trump’s lead in a new national poll that could signal a significant shift in the race for the Republican nomination with primary election season in full swing.

headline: Testosterone Gel Has Modest Benefits for Men, Study Says
abstract: Using the gel seemed to improve sexual functioning, but little else, in landmark research published Wednesday in The New England Journal of Medicine.
lead_paragraph: More than a million men have smeared testosterone gels on their bodies in recent years, hoping it would rejuvenate them, energize them, and increase their libido. But until now, there has never been a rigorous study asking if there were any real benefits to testosterone therapy for healthy men with so-called low T.

headline: Boss Women: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Jason Wu, the Taiwanese-born designer, presents his fall women’s collection.
lead_paragraph: Jason Wu, the Taiwanese-born designer, presents his fall women’s collection.

headline: DKNY: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow’s second collection for DKNY.
lead_paragraph: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow’s second collection for DKNY.

headline: The Thinking Woman’s Runway
abstract: From Thom Browne to Rodarte by way of Carolina Herrera, thesis statements at the New York shows.
lead_paragraph: It was snowing outside, speckling the stiletto boots and soaking the tights of the fashion folk, and inside, snow lay lightly on the ground for Thom Browne’s show, deep in the bowels of a Chelsea art gallery where Mr. Browne had recreated Washington Square circa the Henry James years.

headline: Every Minute Counts on the Way to Opening Night
abstract: On one recent Tuesday, we spent an hour each with a dozen upcoming Broadway shows as they worked under looming deadlines. From the costume shop to the first curtain call, here's how the steps and stories, the stitches and salesmanship come together.
lead_paragraph: On one recent Tuesday, we spent an hour each with a dozen upcoming Broadway shows as they worked under looming deadlines. From the costume shop to the first curtain call, here's how the steps and stories, the stitches and salesmanship come together.

headline: Review: ‘Twelfth Night’ by Filter Theater, Set at the Frat
abstract: Shakespeare’s comedy gets a party setting by an English troupe that specializes in wild versions of classic texts.
lead_paragraph: Who needs cakes and ale when you have pizza and lager? In the best bits of “Twelfth Night,” presented at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts in association with the Royal Shakespeare Company, the British troupe Filter Theater reimagines Shakespeare’s comedy as a frat bacchanal. There’s even an improvement on beer pong.

headline: Review: Denes Varjon, a Hungarian Pianist, at Zankel Hall
abstract: The musician performed works from Schumann and Haydn at his concert.
lead_paragraph: A sparsely attended concert at Zankel Hall on Tuesday evening by the Hungarian pianist Denes Varjon demonstrated the difficulty of marketing an artist who may be admired by musicians and industry professionals but is not well known among a broader audience in this country.

headline: Ex-Deutsche Bank Analyst to Pay $100,000 Over Ratings
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Research', 'Fines (Penalties)']
abstract: The former analyst Charles P. Grom settled S.E.C. charges that he kept a buy rating on stock he believed to be in trouble to maintain client relations.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday settled with a former stock analyst over accusations that he had failed to tell investors what he really believed about the value of a company’s shares he was promoting.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, iPhone, Hillary Clinton
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Review: ‘Join or Die With Craig Ferguson’ — Historic Errors
abstract: The comedian hosts a show on the History channel in which comics and experts are asked to compare monumental blunders made in the past.
lead_paragraph: The informational side of television has its standard documentary programming and its standard talk shows, but lately it has also sprouted a sort of mumblecore hybrid of the two. People with varying qualifications prattle about a subject in a way that’s supposed to be entertaining, occasionally bumping into an illuminating fact or idea while doing so.

headline: As Demographics in Cambodia Shift, Youth Seek Political Change
abstract: Two-thirds of the population is under 30, and that generation has outgrown the authoritarian style and patronage system of Prime Minister Hun Sen.
lead_paragraph: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia — Thy Sovantha, Cambodia’s youngest political star, is still seething.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Jack Garratt Chops, Croons and Wobbles
abstract: Mr. Garratt’s debut album, “Phase,” revels in extremes, but each track is supported by an old-fashioned pop structure.
lead_paragraph: “Phase”

headline: Review: BJ the Chicago Kid Waxes Reflective on ‘In My Mind’
abstract: The best parts of BJ’s major-label debut album come when he seems to tax himself with some kind of ethical responsibility.
lead_paragraph: “In My Mind”

headline: Yahoo Closes Online Magazines, a Costly Experiment by Marissa Mayer
keywords: ['Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Magazines', 'News and News Media']
abstract: Yahoo told dozens of employees at 15 digital publications that they were losing their jobs, part of a larger plan to cut the work force by 15 percent.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Marissa Mayer, the embattled chief executive of Yahoo, is gutting one of her signature projects: A cluster of digital magazines devoted to topics like food, autos, real estate, travel and technology.

headline: Review: Dave Holland Trio in a Bracingly Uncorked Evening at the Village Vanguard
abstract: Opening a weeklong run at the club and a five-week tour, Mr. Holland, Kevin Eubanks and Obed Calvaire played with a whirling dynamism.
lead_paragraph: Opening night of a newly incorporated jazz group’s residency can be a crapshoot. Conventional wisdom holds that as time progresses, the music will only get better. But there are provisos and exceptions, most of which were manifest in the Dave Holland Trio’s jubilant, blazingly exploratory first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night.

headline: Bill Cosby Sued Accuser’s Lawyers on Eve of His Criminal Hearing
abstract: A seal was lifted Tuesday on part of a suit filed against Dolores M. Troiani and Bebe H. Kivitz, who have represented Andrea Constand.
lead_paragraph: On the eve of a critical hearing in his criminal case earlier this month, Bill Cosby sued the two lawyers for the woman who accused him of drugging and sexually assaulting her, according to court records.

headline: John Kasich Turns His Sights on New England
abstract: The Ohio governor is not planning to stay in South Carolina on Saturday as voters go to the polls, and instead is turning his focus to Vermont and Massachusetts.
lead_paragraph: BLUFFTON, S.C. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio, who has competed in South Carolina while also looking ahead to more hospitable primary states, is not planning to stay here on Saturday when Republican voters go to the polls.

headline: Harper Beckham, the 4-Year-Old Street-Style Star
abstract: The young daughter of Victoria and David Beckham has her own following, including a fashion blog devoted to her every look.
lead_paragraph: The newest street-style fashion star has been photographed dining at Balthazar and Nobu, shopping at Barneys, vacationing in Marrakesh and the Napa Valley and going to the ballet in London. She favors Chloé, Marc Jacobs and Zara, and seems to have an occasional fondness for the color pink.

headline: Long-Shot Nominees and Their Oscars Fatigue
abstract: As the Oscars loom, some say the season can be like “Groundhog Day.”
lead_paragraph: Shortly after the curtain fell on the 2010 Academy Awards, Michael Barker, the co-president of Sony Pictures Classics, bumped into the French director Jacques Audiard, and was startled to find him grinning from ear to ear. Mr. Audiard’s film, “A Prophet,” had just lost the best foreign-language film Oscar to “A Secret in Their Eyes,” and yet the filmmaker, Mr. Barker said, could not have looked more pleased.

headline: Off the Runway: Feb. 17
abstract: What you need to know from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: What you need to know from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Pope’s Presence Crosses Border Into U.S., Even if He Doesn’t
abstract: In Mexico, Ciudad Juárez was naturally consumed with the visit by Pope Francis on Wednesday. But across the border, El Paso was equally swept up.
lead_paragraph: EL PASO, Tex. — In Mexico, Ciudad Juárez was naturally consumed with the visit by Pope Francis on Wednesday. But across the border here in West Texas, its sister city, El Paso, was equally swept up.

headline: Law Center Finds Surge in Extremist Groups in U.S. Last Year
abstract: The Southern Poverty Law Center said the number of groups organized against racial, religious, sexual or other characteristics rose by 14 percent.
lead_paragraph: Extremist groups thrived in the United States last year as the divisive rhetoric of national political leaders fueled America’s anxieties over the country’s shifting demographics, according to a report by the Southern Poverty Law Center.

headline: A Designer Pop-Up and Brandon Maxwell at Bergdorf Goodman
abstract: Shopping events around New York.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, be sure to check out the Bergdorf Goodman pop-up of Beau Souci, a line founded by Paola Russo, owner of the Los Angeles concept boutique Just One Eye. Designed by Aurélie Larrousse, who graduated from Studio Berçot in Paris, it marries French chic with SoCal cool in looks like a gold and silver watersnake leather skirt ($2,750) paired with a plain white tee ($140).

headline: Erykah Badu, Debut Fashion Week Stylist
abstract: The R&B singer agreed to style the Pyer Moss show, seeing in the label’s designer, Kerby Jean-Raymond, “bravery, honesty and fearlessness.”
lead_paragraph: At the Pyer Moss show at Milk Studios on Saturday, a quintet played classical music in hospital gowns, a jacket had the message “You don’t have any friends in LA” written across the breastplate, and the final model held a sign that said: “My demons won today. I’m sorry.”

headline: The Olsen Twins Expand Their Empire With New Eyewear
abstract: Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, the designers of The Row, celebrated their collaboration with Oliver Peoples at a fashion week party.
lead_paragraph: Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen rolled into the Oliver Peoples Madison Avenue boutique on Tuesday night for a party celebrating their first eyewear collaboration. Perhaps not surprisingly, given the reluctance of The Row designers to engage much with the public or the press, they have cheekily named a pair of $340 oversize tortoise sunglasses “Don’t Bother Me.”

headline: The Blowout Parties of New York Fashion Week
abstract: It may have been low-key compared with previous fashion weeks, but there were plenty of opportunities to cavort with models and celebrities.
lead_paragraph: Blame it on the arctic blast, on awards season, on fashion week’s very influence hanging in the balance.

headline: Off the Runway: Fashion Week, Day 7
abstract: Images from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Above, Jennifer Hudson snaps a photo from the front row of the Michael Kors show. Click on the slide show above for more images from the seventh day of New York Fashion Week.

headline: A Novel Plan for Health Care: Cutting Costs, Not Raising Them
abstract: Intermountain Healthcare is trying to keep rate increases in line with increases in consumer prices.
lead_paragraph: As employees know all too well, health insurance companies have one surefire way to lower costs: Ask their customers to pay more.

headline: Mayor de Blasio’s America: A Pastrami Sandwich From Carnegie Deli
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s tweet celebrated the deli’s reopening and mocked Jeb Bush’s use of the same message with a picture of a handgun.
lead_paragraph: For Mayor Bill de Blasio, happiness is a warm pastrami sandwich.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Plastic and Rubber
abstract: Hood by Air, Narciso Rodriguez and DKNY all riffed on the synthetic materials.
lead_paragraph: Streetwear has officially embraced the weird for fall/winter 2016, with runways dominated by oversize silhouettes, tough boots and pieces wrought in nylon and rubber that appear to be made of plastic bags. At Hood by Air (center), arguably the season’s most talked-about show so far, a duffle coat was matched with rubber bottoms and rubber boots. Last night, the minimalist Narciso Rodriguez (right) added a refreshing edge to his show with a silk and wool trench coat that boasted a plasticky sheen. And today, Maxwell Osbourne and Dao-Yi Chow’s second collection for DKNY (left) was filled with tomboyish pieces like a nylon anorak with matching pants.

headline: Voters in South Carolina Give Jeb Bush Some Campaign Advice
abstract: Fresh off the news that Gov. Nikki R. Haley had endorsed a rival days before the South Carolina primary, a visibly frustrated Mr. Bush took advice from voters on how he could be a better candidate.
lead_paragraph: SUMMERVILLE, S.C. — Jeb Bush has reached the point in his floundering presidential campaign where voters are offering him unsolicited advice.

headline: That time when they said...
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Reviewing past statements by lawmakers on judicial nominations reveals how easily they alternate positions based on control of Congress or the White House.
lead_paragraph: Reviewing past statements by lawmakers on judicial nominations reveals how easily they alternate positions based on control of Congress or the White House.

headline: Marchesa: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Keren Craig and Georgina Chapman present their latest looks.
lead_paragraph: Keren Craig and Georgina Chapman present their latest looks.

headline: Senators Limber Up for a Dexterous Flip on Judicial Nominees
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Senators are seamlessly reversing stances on filibusters and obstructionism depending on which party is in the majority and who holds the White House.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The long-serving senator professed outrage. How dare the opposition refuse a vote on a high-level presidential judicial nominee.

headline: Early Behavior Therapy Found to Aid Children With A.D.H.D.
abstract: Experts said this approach could possibly change standard medical practice, which favors drugs like Adderall and Ritalin as first-line treatments.
lead_paragraph: Children with attention-deficit problems improve faster when the first treatment they receive is behavioral — like instruction in basic social skills — than when they start immediately on medication, a new study has found. Beginning with behavioral therapy is also a less expensive option over time, according to a related analysis.

headline: Accusation at Indiana University Triggers Review of Sexual Misconduct Cases
abstract: Jason Casares, an associate dean who oversees sexual misconduct hearings at the university, was accused by a woman of sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: Indiana University Bloomington will review the handling of 18 sexual misconduct cases after the associate dean who led hearings on the cases was publicly accused of sexually assaulting a woman.

headline: Chinese Missiles in South China Sea Underscore a Growing Conflict Risk
keywords: ['Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A day after Southeast Asian leaders gathered in California, a U.S. official said China had put missile batteries on an island claimed by Vietnam and Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — China’s deployment of surface-to-air missiles on a disputed island in the South China Sea, at the very moment that President Obama is trying to buttress American influence in the region, underscores the growing risk of conflict among the Chinese, their neighbors and the United States.

headline: Apple’s Stance Highlights a More Confrontational Tech Industry
keywords: ['Privacy', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Smartphones', 'iPhone']
abstract: The battle between Apple and law enforcement officials over a terrorist’s cellphone is heading toward an eventual victory for tech companies.
lead_paragraph: The battle between Apple and law enforcement officials over unlocking a terrorist’s smartphone is the culmination of a slow turning of the tables between the technology industry and the United States government.

headline: Three Former New Jersey Governors Ask the State to Reopen the Sheridan Case
abstract: The mysterious, violent deaths of a prominent couple had been ruled a murder-suicide.
lead_paragraph: In the 11 months since a county prosecutor in New Jersey ruled the violent deaths of John and Joyce Sheridan a murder-suicide, their disbelieving family has been waging a determined effort to have the case reopened. On Wednesday, friends of the family released a letter supporting their cause that was signed by some 200 people — including three former governors, a former state Supreme Court justice and several former high-ranking prosecutors.

headline: Pope Francis at the Border
abstract: Where Francis shows love, Republican candidates for president would stoke fear.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis’ trip to Mexico ended on Wednesday in Ciudad Juárez, a city once made hellish by drug violence and still gripped by poverty and crime. He did not seem afraid, and brought with him only smiles and hugs, and words of solace and encouragement.

headline: Manhattan Prosecutor Asks to Be Recused From Spitzer Inquiry
abstract: Cyrus R. Vance Jr., the Manhattan district attorney, cited his close ties to the former governor, who has been accused of assaulting a woman.
lead_paragraph: The Manhattan district attorney has moved to recuse himself from the criminal investigation into an allegation that former Gov. Eliot Spitzer assaulted a 26-year-old woman at the Plaza Hotel, saying the close ties between his office and Mr. Spitzer had created an apparent conflict of interest.

headline: Delta, in Alliance With Danny Meyer, Aims to Elevate Airline Food
abstract: Delta is seeking an edge in the battle for premium-class passengers by serving food intended to be as good as what is served in Mr. Meyer’s restaurants.
lead_paragraph: It is no secret that airlines are waging an increasingly pitched battle for the biggest-spending passengers who fly in premium classes: The carriers have deployed amenities like fluffy feather duvets and spa treatments.

headline: Legal Heavyweights Enter Round 3 in New Jersey Gambling Case
abstract: Twelve judges heard arguments by two former United States solicitors general over whether New Jersey’s plan to operate sports books in its casinos and racetracks was legal under federal law.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Before the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit began the important business on Wednesday of deciding whether New Jersey could offer legal wagering on sports, Judge Thomas L. Ambro offered a tribute to Justice Antonin Scalia, listing his many contributions to the law.

headline: Audit Faults New York City for Not Using Vacant Lots for Affordable Housing
keywords: ['Affordable Housing', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Land Use Policies']
abstract: Comptroller Scott M. Stringer said the city had been slow to develop over 1,000 long-unused properties despite a housing shortage. Housing officials said his conclusions were “false and misleading.”
lead_paragraph: New York City’s scarcity of inexpensive land is often cited as an impediment to building more affordable housing, but the comptroller’s office has identified more than 1,000 city-owned vacant lots across the boroughs that have been sitting idle, most for more than 30 years.

headline: Jordan Spieth and Rory McIlroy Resume Fight for Top Spot
abstract: Spieth, the world’s top-ranked golfer, and McIlroy, newly demoted to No. 3 from No. 2, could face off at the Northern Trust Open in Southern California.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A 12-year-old Jordan Spieth sat glued to the television for the 2006 Rose Bowl, between No. 2 Texas and top-ranked Southern California. The game had the requisite star power and drama for a marquee event in this entertainment capital of the world.

headline: Nikki Haley Endorses Marco Rubio, Aiming to Project Vibrant New G.O.P.
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Endorsements', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Together, Mr. Rubio, the son of Cuban immigrants, and Ms. Haley, the daughter of Sikh immigrants from India, hope to form a powerful contrast to an older generation of Republicans who have long controlled the party.
lead_paragraph: CHAPIN, S.C. — Senator Marco Rubio of Florida on Wednesday won the coveted backing of South Carolina’s governor, Nikki R. Haley, bringing together two of the youngest Republican rising stars at a moment when their party is facing difficult questions about whether instead to look to its past or to political outsiders for leadership.

headline: Andrzej Zulawski, Rebellious Film Director, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Zulawski, known primarily to a small art-house and film festival audience, made no concessions to logic, ordinary human motivations or audience squeamishness.
lead_paragraph: Andrzej Zulawski, a Polish director who blended surrealism, horror and psychic excess in the emotionally savage films “The Important Thing Is to Love,” “Possession” and “My Nights Are More Beautiful Than Your Days,” died on Wednesday in Warsaw. He was 75.

headline: Blacks See Bias in Delay on a Scalia Successor
abstract: Some African-Americans saw the move by Republicans to block a Supreme Court nomination as another attempt to deny the legitimacy of the Obama presidency.
lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — As he left Martha Lou’s Kitchen, a soul food institution here on Wednesday, Edward Gadsden expressed irritation about the Republican determination to block President Obama from selecting Justice Antonin Scalia’s replacement on the Supreme Court.

headline: Albany Again Has Stony Brook’s Number as Winning Streak Ends at 18
abstract: Division I’s longest active winning streak ended at 18 as Albany defeated the Seawolves, who twice have had their N.C.A.A. tournament hopes dashed by the Great Danes.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — As the wins pile up for Stony Brook again this season, the Seawolves remain haunted by the question that has troubled them for five agonizing years, beginning with when they first reached the cusp of the N.C.A.A. tournament: Can they finally win when it matters?

headline: William H. Tankersley, Watchdog for CBS Taste Standards, Dies at 98
abstract: Mr. Tankersley was in effect the network’s main censor from the mid-1950s to 1972, a time of envelope-pushing, though he saw his job as guarding CBS’s reputation.
lead_paragraph: William H. Tankersley, who defined broadcast standards for CBS during a volatile period of change in mores on television and in American society, doing celebrated battle with envelope pushers like Norman Lear and the Smothers Brothers, died on Feb. 5 in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 98.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 17, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “One could say that Daesh has won because its goal has been to sow trouble, and they have succeeded.”

headline: With Much Unsettled for Nets, Brooklyn Complex Is a New Center of Gravity
abstract: Even after they left New Jersey over three years ago, the Nets continued to practice there. That changed on Wednesday with the opening of a new practice site in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Mikhail D. Prokhorov smirked as guests were served an array of refreshments at a ceremony Wednesday for the opening of the Nets’ new practice site in the Sunset Park neighborhood of Brooklyn.

headline: Rikers Guard Charged With Lying in Inmate’s Death Pleads Guilty
abstract: Carol Lackner, a New York correction officer, was sentenced to five years of probation over charges that she lied about checking on a prisoner who overheated in his cell.
lead_paragraph: A New York City correction officer on duty at Rikers Island when a homeless veteran overheated before dying in his cell pleaded guilty on Wednesday to a felony charge that she lied about checking on inmates that night, the authorities said.

headline: Trial Starts in Attack at Exhibit of Anti-Islam Cartoons
abstract: Abdul Malik Abdul Kareem is accused of bankrolling and motivating two men who traveled to Garland, Tex., and opened fire on an event showing artwork depicting the Prophet Muhammad.
lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — Federal prosecutors opened their case here on Wednesday against a man accused of being the mastermind behind a thwarted attack last year at an anti-Islam cartoon exhibit in Texas that left two gunmen dead in a shootout.

headline: Modern Love: The Podcast | Magically Interrupted
abstract: The actor Michael Shannon reads the essay “A Memory Magically Interrupted,” about how a grandmother’s struggle with Alzheimer’s healed her family.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s episode of Modern Love: The Podcast (the sixth so far), the actor Michael Shannon (“Boardwalk Empire,” “Take Shelter,” “Revolutionary Road”) reads “A Memory Magically Interrupted” by Robert Leleux.

headline: Review: In Shepard’s ‘Buried Child,’ a Father and Family Dissolve Into Darkness
abstract: This revival of the award-winning American gothic play stars Amy Madigan and Ed Harris as parents in a dysfunctional Illinois farmhouse.
lead_paragraph: So you’ve come back, have you? And it’s exactly as you remember, and like nothing you can recall. Yes, honey, you’re home. Wherever that happens to be, it’s the place you can never return to and never escape from.

headline: So THAT’S the Trick Here
abstract: Interesting gridwork by Bruce Haight.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — Interesting-looking grid today, Isn’t It?

headline: CUNY Schools to Lure Foreign Entrepreneurs With New Visa Program
abstract: Eighty entrepreneurs from abroad will set up shop on seven campuses, advising professors and students while starting their own businesses.
lead_paragraph: The next Elon Musk may soon be working at a City University of New York campus in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, perhaps joined by the next Sergey Brin in Flushing, Queens. And they could be creating hundreds of jobs.

headline: Are You a Recent Migrant to Germany? We Want to Hear From You
abstract: The Times wants to hear from those who have recently migrated to Germany about life in their new home.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s decision to throw open its borders last summer to an unprecedented flow of migrants inspired admiration and condemnation at home, in Europe and around the world.

headline: Knicks Shrug Off Losses and Trade Rumors as They Try to Refocus
abstract: The Knicks, who are 1-10 in their last 11 games, resumed practice with an unchanged roster after the All-Star break as their interim coach, Kurt Rambis, said their goal was to make the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — Eight days removed from their most recent game and winless in February, the Knicks reconvened for practice Wednesday afternoon after an extended All-Star break.

headline: Proenza Schouler: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, who are exploring the see now buy now technique, present their latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez, who are exploring the see now buy now technique, present their latest collection.

headline: Donald Trump Wants to Hold to Middle Ground on Mideast, for Now
abstract: The candidate says he wants to be in a better negotiating position, should he capture the presidency.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump declined to say on Wednesday night which side deserves blame for the violent clashes between Israelis and Palestinians, adding he wants to remain “neutral” heading into a potential presidency so he can be best positioned to negotiate a deal between the two sides

headline: Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz Clash, Yet Find Common Ground
abstract: The candidates have a chance to explain their positions in a manner that comes across on the campaign trail, but rarely on the debate stage.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. – Senator Marco Rubio of Florida shared his concerns about safety in football, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas sang a few bars, and Ben Carson opened up about why he left the medical field.

headline: Charges Dismissed Against 6 Ex-Employees of Rentboy.com
abstract: Federal authorities continue to pursue a case against the website’s former chief executive on charges of money laundering and promoting prostitution.
lead_paragraph: Federal authorities have dismissed charges against six former employees of the website Rentboy.com, while continuing to move forward with a case against the chief executive on counts of money laundering and promoting prostitution, according to court documents posted on Wednesday.

headline: What to Watch Thursday
abstract: Craig Ferguson returns to a late-night post, and both the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates participate in town halls.
lead_paragraph: Admit it: You’ve missed Craig Ferguson. But now he’s back, examining the historical foibles of his adopted country in “Join or Die.” “Mom” tackles addiction with the help of the surgeon general. And the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates answer questions at town hall meetings.

headline: Apple Letter on iPhone Security Draws Muted Tech Industry Response
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Privacy', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'iPhone']
abstract: A complicated set of factors influences the reactions of technology companies to government demands to unlock a path to customer data.
lead_paragraph: After a federal court ordered Apple to help unlock an iPhone used by an attacker in a December mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif., the company’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, penned a passionate letter warning of far-reaching implications beyond the case.

headline: Corrections: February 18, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, February 18, 2016.
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK

headline: Toyota Recalls Nearly 3 Million RAV4s Over Seatbelt Separation
keywords: ['Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Seatbelts', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects']
abstract: In a severe frontal crash, Toyota said, metal seat-cushion frames could slice through the belts, leaving passengers unrestrained.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Toyota recalled nearly three million RAV4 sport utility vehicles worldwide on Thursday, saying their rear seatbelts could be severed in a crash, leaving passengers unprotected.

headline: Ingram Micro Sold to Chinese Company for $6 Billion
abstract: Ingram, based in Irvine, Calif., said the sale to Tianjin Tianhai, a subsidiary of HNA Group, would help it increase investment and expand its reach.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Tianjin Tianhai, a Chinese shipping group, will buy the technology distributor Ingram Micro for $6 billion in the latest mega-deal involving a Chinese company.

headline: Racial Gerrymandering in North Carolina
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voter Registration and Requirements', 'State Legislatures']
abstract: Republicans in the state have used various machinations to disenfranchise voters.
lead_paragraph: The North Carolina legislature is hurriedly redrawing the lines of two congressional districts that had been gerrymandered along racial lines and ruled unconstitutional by a Federal District Court. Unless the Supreme Court steps in, the Republican-controlled legislature must draw new maps by Friday, in time for the March 15 state primary, under an order from the district court.

headline: Republicans See How Long They Can Hold Their Breath
abstract: And if the president makes a Supreme Court nomination, they’ll cover their eyes and become invisible.
lead_paragraph: Maybe we’d better refrain from having any new opinions until after the election.

headline: Politics: All in My Family
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Youth', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A father tries to better understand the political awakening and sensibilities of his children.
lead_paragraph: One of the more interesting features of the Democratic primary process is the generational divide among support for candidates — older Democratic voters generally prefer Hillary Clinton, and younger ones overwhelmingly prefer Bernie Sanders.

headline: How to Break a Party
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The 2016 primary has exposed the deep divisions in the G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: Beginning with the Tea Party wave and continuing through the not-Romney musical chairs of the 2012 Republican primary and the battles over debt limits and fiscal cliffs, most coverage of the Republican Party’s internal divisions during the Obama era fell into an easy groove: There was the establishment, and there was the base.

headline: America’s Stacked Deck
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Voting and Voters']
abstract: Voters are right to be angry and demand change, but scapegoating isn’t the answer.
lead_paragraph: It’s a little bizarre this political season to see wealthy candidates in both parties denouncing our political system for representing mostly the interests of, well, wealthy people.

headline: China’s Missile Provocation
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Missiles and Missile Defense Systems', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Law of the Sea (UN Convention)', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: China’s decision to deploy missiles on a disputed island further fuels regional tensions.
lead_paragraph: China’s decision to station surface-to-air missiles on a disputed island in the South China Sea is the latest in a series of provocative acts that is fueling regional tensions. This unwise move raises new doubts about President Xi Jinping’s pledge not to “pursue militarization” in a vital waterway and passage for $5 trillion in annual trade.

headline: Resetting the Post-Scalia Supreme Court
abstract: The court has become an agent of partisan warfare to an extent that threatens real damage to the institution.
lead_paragraph: In the days since Justice Antonin Scalia’s death, there has been plenty of talk about the substantial impact his absence will have on the Supreme Court’s docket. I’d like to shift the focus to the Roberts court itself.

headline: Crimes, iPhones and Encryption
abstract: Should companies, like Apple, have to unlock encrypted communication in the case of a crime?

headline: Mainstream G.O.P. Field of Three Faces Brutal Delegate Math
abstract: If the G.O.P. fails to settle on Marco Rubio, Jeb Bush or John Kasich by Super Tuesday, the delegate count will start to favor Donald Trump and Ted Cruz.
lead_paragraph: If the Republican Party remains divided for much longer, it will start getting more difficult for a mainstream candidate to win the nomination.

headline: How to Win an Election
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Advertising']
abstract: How candidates use the art of storytelling to help swing elections.
lead_paragraph: Every election cycle, we’re asked to make monumental decisions about which people and policies should control our country, and we have to sort through a barrage of information to arrive at our selections. Often, we pick the candidate who breaks through the noise with a message that resonates with us. The politicians that prevail politicians are excellent storytellers.

headline: Shedding a House to Buy an Upper East Side Apartment
abstract: Susan and Morgan Snyder gave up a house in Virginia for an apartment in New York.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after they married in 1983, Morgan and Susan Snyder moved to Westchester County to be near Mr. Snyder’s job. “We discovered the city once we got to Westchester,” Mrs. Snyder said.

headline: Scuba Diving in Thailand: A Balancing Act
abstract: A father-son relationship deepens during a scuba trip exploring an exotic underworld off Thailand.
lead_paragraph: Last spring, when my 22-year-old son Forrister and I pulled on wet suits and shouldered scuba tanks for our first night dive, we’d been aboard the Chinese junk in the Indian Ocean off Thailand for all of 24 hours. As our launch shuttled us out to smooth granite rocks just peeking above the surface near Island No. 9 in the Similan archipelago, I wondered whether I’d made a terrible mistake. Even including that day’s three dives, the sum total of Forrister’s diving experience amounted to only seven.

headline: A Supreme Court With Merrick Garland Would Be the Most Liberal in Decades
abstract: It should be no surprise that Justice Antonin Scalia’s death has led to a political fight. His replacement on the court could lead to a historic change in the court’s balance of power.
lead_paragraph: It should be no surprise that Justice Antonin Scalia’s death has led to a political fight. His replacement on the court could lead to a historic change in the court’s balance of power.

headline: Chase Elliott, a Hall of Famer’s Son, Gains Respect Quickly
abstract: Elliott, 20, whose father is Bill Elliott and who approaches his sport with reverence, will be driving Jeff Gordon’s No. 24 Chevrolet on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Years ago, in a perhaps prescient moment, a family friend decided that the name William Clyde Elliott II did not fit a young boy. So he nicknamed the lad Chase, and the moniker stuck.

headline: Deadlocks and Rearguments: What’s Ahead for the Supreme Court
abstract: What matters loom largest for the justices when they return to the bench on Monday, a week after the death of their colleague, Antonin Scalia?
lead_paragraph: What lies ahead for the Supreme Court when it returns to the bench on Monday, a week after the death of Justice Antonin Scalia?

headline: Fashion Week: We Hardly Knew Ye
abstract: Highlights from the final day of Fashion Week include Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein Collection and Marc Jacobs.
lead_paragraph: It went by in the blink of an eye, as it always does: There went Kanye West, there went Rihanna, there went Alexander Wang, all the best and buzziest of New York Fashion Week. They have deposited us here, on its final day. But not before the biggest names — they for whom first names alone suffice — come out.

headline: Nigeria’s Booming Film Industry Redefines African Life
abstract: Nollywood is resonating across the continent with its stories of a pre-colonial past and of a present caught between village life and urban modernity.
lead_paragraph: ASABA, Nigeria — Sitting on a blue plastic stool in the sweltering heat, Ugezu J. Ugezu, one of Nigeria’s top filmmakers, was furiously rewriting his script as the cameras prepared to roll. “Cut!” he shouted after wrapping up a key scene, a confrontation between the two leading characters. Then, under his breath, he added, “Good as it gets.”

headline: A Bronx Precinct Where Killings Persist
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Public and Subsidized Housing', 'Series', 'Police']
abstract: The death of a woman at the Mott Haven Houses in the 40th Precinct reveals a swirl of deeper dysfunction.
lead_paragraph: The strangers slept no more than a dozen steps apart in a housing project in the South Bronx — she on a cot pushed up against the wall in the living room of her ailing mother’s apartment, and he in a narrow, airless hallway of the building, on the threshold of his family’s door.

headline: Long Sleeves and Bug Spray in São Paulo
abstract: For most of the women I know in Brazil, the Zika virus has inspired confusion, not fear.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — Last December, I suddenly found myself in possession of two bottles of the most precious liquid in town: Exposis Extrême, an extra-strong insect repellent. It’s deemed the best protection against the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which transmits dengue, chikungunya and, now, the Zika virus. Its active ingredient is icaridin, which also repels ticks and the mosquitoes that carry malaria. I’d bought the bottles earlier in the year, during an outbreak of dengue fever, in the hope that a high-quality bug spray would keep me safe from the virus. (It didn’t. I came down with dengue, anyway.)

headline: Syria's White Rose
abstract: The West has capitulated. Syria is a land of the dead and the dying, in need of heroes to redeem humanity.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — At the end of Bertolt Brecht’s “Life of Galileo,” there is a sharp exchange. Andrea Sarti, a student of the astronomer, says, “Unhappy is the land that breeds no hero.” To which Galileo shoots back: “No, Andrea. Unhappy is the land that needs a hero.”

headline: The World’s Best News Photos
abstract: The World Press Photo contest winners were announced, with a moody black-and-white image depicting the hardship of the Syrian migration crisis winning photo of the year. The New York Times also won five awards.
lead_paragraph: An update regarding two winning photographers using pseudonyms for their entry names has been added below.

lead_paragraph: When you’re spending hundreds of thousands of dollars to stage a fashion show, the fine points matter — not just the clothes, but the when, the where and the how, too. So it was hardly a coincidence that Proenza Schouler’s fall show happened to be at the Whitney Museum of American Art on Gansevoort Street.

keywords: ['Kurds', 'Terrorism', 'United States International Relations', 'International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — In blaming a Syrian Kurdish militia supported by the United States for a deadly car bombing in Ankara, Turkey added new urgency on Thursday to a question its president recently posed to the Obama administration: Are you on the side of a NATO ally — Turkey — or its enemies?

headline: Charlotte Rampling Lets Tailoring Do the Talking
abstract: No ruffles here. Eschewing a stylist, the 70-year-old actress prefers crisp, polished pieces by designers like Stella McCartney, Hermès and Armani.
lead_paragraph: By now the English actress Charlotte Rampling, 70, has little left to prove. She modeled, sang and partied as an emblem of the Swinging Sixties. She starred in foreign art house films like “The Night Porter” and in American comedies like Woody Allen’s “Stardust Memories.” She has spoken her mind to the press for decades.

headline: Zika Outbreak Could Be an Omen of the Global Warming Threat
abstract: In the coming decades, global warming is likely to increase the range and speed of the life cycle of the particular mosquitoes carrying viruses like Zika.
lead_paragraph: The global public health emergency involving deformed babies emerged in 2015, the hottest year in the historical record, with an outbreak in Brazil of a disease transmitted by heat-loving mosquitoes. Can that be a coincidence?

headline: Senate Republicans Face Ire From Editorial Boards Over Supreme Court Stance
keywords: ['Elections, House of Representatives', 'Elections, Senate', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: For senators from places where good governance and political courage are viewed as inherent state virtues, a critical editorial can still sting. And Republican pledges to block President Obama from submitting a nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia has captured the attention of the civic watchdogs.
lead_paragraph: In the world of insta-pundits and unmonitored comments, newspaper editorials may seem quaint, evoking cranky gentlemen of a certain age banging away with wrath on their keyboards about the incandescent issues of the day.

headline: OatMeals
abstract: The hot breakfast cereal is reborn as an indulgence in Greenwich Village.

headline: Hot Cereal 30 Ways at OatMeals in Greenwich Village
abstract: A cafe serves oats inspired by Asian cuisines, candy and Elvis.
lead_paragraph: For much of human history, oats were thought of, pityingly, as weeds. The Bible passes over them in silence. The Greeks and Romans snubbed them as a sickly form of wheat. They were fed to horses and, later, to castoff orphans in the workhouses of Victorian England, as grains afloat in murky water, under the name “gruel.”

headline: New York Today: Working the Wee Hours
abstract: Thursday: Work before dawn, near-freezing weather and the gold beneath our feet.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 10:01 a.m.

headline: Hospital Raid by Afghan Forces Is Said to Kill at Least 3
keywords: ['Hospitals', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Geneva Conventions']
abstract: Initial reports differed on whether the units involved in the raid south of Kabul, possibly accompanied by NATO advisers, were from the Afghan Army or the police.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Afghan security forces, possibly accompanied by NATO advisers, raided a hospital south of Kabul and abducted and then killed at least three men suspected of being insurgents, hospital officials and residents said on Thursday.

keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Gifts to Public Officials']
