lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Does it block traffic? Disrupt normal life? Is the guest list too long? The feast too lavish?

headline: ‘Hairy Panic’ (a Plant) Strikes Australian Town of Wangaratta
abstract: The windblown grass has become a major nuisance, leaving the town inundated with tumbleweeds and drawing the attention of the global news media.
lead_paragraph: A plant known as hairy panic has left parts of a small town in southeastern Australia overwhelmed with tumbleweeds, and global news media attention, with residents and journalists recording bizarre scenes of dry, yellow grass piling up around cars and doorways.

headline: Food Lessons From Families of Kids With Allergies
keywords: ['ALLERGIES', 'Children and Childhood', 'Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Families and Family Life', 'Parenting']
abstract: They have something to teach the rest of us about healthful eating: It’s not as hard as we think.
lead_paragraph: “I always think that my kids eat healthier because of their allergies,” said Cristina Henriquez, a writer who lives in Chicago. Her children are 8 and 3 and, between them, are allergic to eggs, peanuts, fish, shellfish, dairy and tree nuts. There’s very little processed food in their house, she notes, and they eat out very rarely.

headline: Hillary Clinton Ad Makes an Emotional Pitch to Hispanics
abstract: A television commercial in Nevada features a touching moment between the Democratic candidate and the young daughter of undocumented immigrants.
lead_paragraph: With days to go before Nevada caucuses, the Hillary Clinton campaign has released an advertisement, titled “Brave,” that features a single, poignant moment from the campaign trail to highlight the candidate’s position on immigration.

headline: A Black Police Officer’s Fight Against the N.Y.P.D.
abstract: Edwin Raymond thought he could change the department from the inside. He wound up the lead plaintiff in a lawsuit brought by 12 minority officers.
lead_paragraph: Every morning before his shift, Edwin Raymond, a 30-year-old officer in the New York Police Department, ties up his long dreadlocks so they won’t brush against his collar, as the job requires. On Dec. 7, he carefully pinned them up in a nautilus pattern, buttoned the brass buttons of his regulation dress coat and pulled on a pair of white cotton gloves. He used a lint roller to make sure his uniform was spotless. In a few hours, he would appear before three of the department’s highest-ranking officials at a hearing that would determine whether he would be promoted to sergeant. He had often stayed up late worrying about how this conversation would play out, but now that the moment was here, he felt surprisingly calm. The department had recently announced a push to recruit more men and women like him — minority cops who could help the police build trust among black and Hispanic New Yorkers. But before he could move up in rank, Raymond would have to disprove some of the things people had said about him.

headline: A New California Cuisine
abstract: Roasted yams get the West Coast treatment.
lead_paragraph: Travis Lett is a bearded, hippie-chic chef who runs a trio of popular restaurants in the beachside community of Venice, Calif. The flagship is Gjelina, a loud, fashionable and vegetable-centric neighborhood spot as well known for the attractiveness of its clientele as for its pizzas and salads, slathered toasts and smoky pastas. The restaurant is an aspirational lifestyle camp, replete with fire pit and sloe-eyed waiters.

headline: Letter of Recommendation: XpresSpa
abstract: A place to recover from the T.S.A. experience.
lead_paragraph: Getting permission to travel by air should not be as degrading as it is. As a matter of course, you — with your wide eyes and genuine smile and clear conscience and valid identification — are bombarded by invisible rays that reveal explicit details of your anatomy. You are made to endure unwanted touching, particularly if, like me, the scanning of your body invariably leads to follow-up searches of the tip of your head and the seat of your pants. Every single time. Then, the blue latex gloves come out, and even if you have the presence of mind to ask that they put on a new pair to comb through your hair and conduct something that is not not a rectal exam ­­— no penetration, not exactly, and yet — they will be resentful. And though they will acquiesce, they will punish you for your request by going extra rough on both your tender head and your poor, weary rear.

headline: Shaun White Says ESPN Kept Him Out of X Games Over Criticism
abstract: White, a top snowboarder, said he was not invited to the event in Aspen, Colo., last month because of comments he had made about the network.
lead_paragraph: Shaun White said remarks he made to Forbes magazine in the fall led ESPN to forgo inviting him to the Winter X Games in Aspen, Colo., last month. The comments followed weeks of speculation about why White, the most famous and accomplished athlete in snowboarding, was absent from one of the biggest showcases for his sport.

headline: Looking at Edvard Munch, Beyond ‘The Scream’
abstract: An exhibition at the Neue Galerie aims to put Munch in historical and cultural perspective.
lead_paragraph: Visit Oslo in midwinter and high summer and you’ll know the atmospheric sources of Edvard Munch’s art: barely broken darkness, and sunlight you can’t escape. Both are evoked in “Munch and Expressionism” at the Neue Galerie, where paintings and prints by Munch and his younger German contemporaries glow and flare like lamps against midnight-blue walls.

headline: Seth Rudetsky, Broadway’s Go-To Guy, Flirts With ‘Disaster!’
abstract: Mr. Rudetsky is so immersed in New York theater, he’s sometimes known as the mayor of Broadway. His latest project is a spoof of ’70s disaster films.
lead_paragraph: Seth Rudetsky is not a household name except on Broadway, where he is so well known and well connected that he is sometimes referred to as the mayor of the place. A hazard of being around him is that you feel you have spent the rest of your life in slow motion. Mr. Rudetsky, who is 48 and likes to say he suffers from “adult A.D.D.,” is a multitasker’s multitasker. Several days a week he is the afternoon D.J. on “Seth’s Big Fat Broadway,” a show on Sirius/XM satellite radio, where he is also the host of a weekly talk show, “Seth Speaks,” not to be confused with “Seth’s Broadway Chatterbox,” a weekly talk show he does live at the Midtown cabaret Don’t Tell Mama, or “Rhapsody in Seth,” his one-man autobiographical play, or, for that matter, “This Week in the Life of Seth Rudetsky,” a weekly column he writes for Playbill.com.

headline: Clashes and Surprises Emerge in Prelude to South Carolina Primary
abstract: It’s becoming easier to see how the Republican race will shape up after the South Carolina primary on Saturday. It’s less clear how it will shake out.
lead_paragraph: It’s becoming easier to see how the Republican race will shape up after the South Carolina primary on Saturday. It’s less clear how it will shake out.

headline: Why Am I Obsessed With a Cellphone Game About Collecting Cats?
abstract: Where does the appeal of Neko Atsume: Kitty Collector lie — in the history of Japanese art, or the strange nature of the cat?
lead_paragraph: Neko Atsume: Kitty Collector is a cellphone game about collecting cats. It is not a complicated game. It is, in fact, barely a game at all. And yet I have become obsessed with it.

headline: What’s at Stake as Britain and E.U. Discuss How to Maintain a Union
keywords: ['Referendums', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'International Relations', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: There are no guarantees that leaders in Brussels will reach a deal to convince Britain to stay in the bloc, and Prime Minister David Cameron could also face a tough campaign to avoid an exit.
lead_paragraph: Leaders of the European Union nations will meet on Thursday and Friday in Brussels in an effort to agree on changes to rules intended to persuade Britain to remain a member of the bloc.

headline: Darryl Pinckney: By the Book
abstract: The author, most recently, of “Black Deutschland” read “Othello” early: “It was important to me that ‘we’ were there, proof that ‘we’ had been on the mind of the exalted William Shakespeare.”
lead_paragraph: The author, most recently, of “Black Deutschland” read “Othello” early: “It was important to me that ‘we’ were there, proof that ‘we’ had been on the mind of the exalted William Shakespeare.”

headline: The Daily Bag: Michael Kors

lead_paragraph: The 1960s were the inspiration at Michael Kors, but with a fresh streak of rebellion. This chalk white chain bag strikes the perfect balance between Mod and modern. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Boxing', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: Saying it strongly opposes discrimination, Nike terminated Pacquiao’s contract after he called people in gay relationships “worse than animals.”
lead_paragraph: Nike has terminated its relationship with Manny Pacquiao, the champion boxer who is campaigning for the Senate in the Philippines, one day after he publicly apologized for calling people in gay relationships “worse than animals” during an interview with a local broadcaster.

headline: 2 Los Angeles Police Officers Accused of Repeated Sexual Assaults
abstract: Prosecutors said the two officers were on duty and armed during assaults against four women over the course of more than two years.
lead_paragraph: Two officers from the Los Angeles Police Department have been charged with repeatedly sexually assaulting four women over the course of more than two years, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: IBM Buys Truven for $2.6 Billion, Adding to Trove of Patient Data
keywords: ['Artificial Intelligence', 'Medicine and Health', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Electronic Health Records', 'Cloud Computing']
abstract: IBM has bought four companies since it created Watson Health last April, gaining data on millions of patients that it will use to try to improve care.
lead_paragraph: IBM is looking to enhance the growth of its Watson Health business with the $2.6 billion purchase of Truven Health Analytics, which has data on the cost and treatment of more than 200 million patients.

headline: Drake’s New Album, Prepared by Moody Sensualists
abstract: “Views From the 6” is scheduled to be released in April, and Noah Shebib is Drake’s crucial presence under the hood.
lead_paragraph: On the Friday before Valentine’s Day, as Drake was getting ready to coach Canada’s team to a victory over the United States in the N.B.A.’s celebrity All-Star Game in Toronto, his longtime musical partner Noah Shebib, known as 40, was in his studio not far away, prepping for another night of work on “Views From the 6,” the forthcoming Drake album scheduled to be released in April.

headline: Anthony Braxton’s Tempo Emphasizes the Upbeat
abstract: This avant-garde composer, now 70, will be performing and releasing three boxed sets of new music this season.
lead_paragraph: At 70, the composer, saxophonist, pianist and inveterate musical big-picture-ist Anthony Braxton sounds ebullient.

headline: Video Found in Belgium of Nuclear Official May Point to Bigger Plot
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Terrorism', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The footage indicated that the terrorist network involved in the Paris attacks on Nov. 13 may also have wanted to obtain radioactive material.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — A suspect linked to the Nov. 13 Paris attackers was found with surveillance footage of a high-ranking Belgian nuclear official, the Belgian authorities acknowledged on Thursday, raising fears that the Islamic State is trying to obtain radioactive material for a terrorist attack.

headline: Spring Preview: Music Festivals Where Experiments Meet the Beat
abstract: Moogfest in North Carolina, the Big Ears Festival in Tennessee and Manana 2016 in Cuba are all putting fusion on their menus.
lead_paragraph: The best music festivals don’t strive to offer something for everybody. They go deep, programming live performances like a set by an inspired disc jockey, where each selection responds to and illuminates the rest. They don’t confine themselves by genre, but they do flaunt their particular aesthetics, with the promise that the main draws and the unknown quantities are worth hearing side by side.

headline: Donald Trump Flaunts Real Estate Prowess With Campaign Yard Signs
abstract: A document that Donald J. Trump’s campaign distributes to volunteers and staff members in South Carolina lays out, in elaborate detail, where large signs bearing his name can and cannot be staked into the ground — touching on local law and the unspoken Trumpian rules of real estate.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — Donald Trump delights in breaking the rules of presidential politics.

headline: Ontario Farmers Fight to Send a Herd of Ex-Cons Back to the Pen
abstract: Livestock owners, locals and a few celebrities have spent over five years trying to reopen the farm at the Collins Bay Institution, a prison complex.
lead_paragraph: KINGSTON, Ontario — It is easy to pick out the short-timers from the lifers on Jeff Peters’s beef and pork farm. The 14 black-and-white Holstein dairy cows stand in sharp contrast to the farm’s regular herd of chocolate brown Limousin beef cattle in the open winter barns.

headline: Privacy vs. Security, Battle Lines Drawn
abstract: Since the Snowden revelations, Silicon Valley has eyed Washington warily. Apple’s resistance to unlocking one its phones has broken the detente.
lead_paragraph: The tech industry’s battle with the United States government over encryption has reached a fever pitch.

headline: Windows 10 Upgrade Options for Vista Users
abstract: Moving on up from Microsoft’s 10-year-old operating system is not impossible, but it takes time, money and patience.
lead_paragraph: Q. My somewhat ancient Hewlett-Packard laptop is running Windows Vista, and I never see Vista mentioned in articles about upgrading operating systems. Can it be upgraded to Windows 10?

headline: Walmart Profit Fell 8% in 4th Quarter
abstract: The retailer said sales slowed at the end of the year, and predicted that a strong dollar and a plan to close stores would dampen its sales this year.
lead_paragraph: Walmart said on Thursday that profit fell about 8 percent last quarter, and it lowered its sales forecast for this year, citing a strong dollar and the costs of a plan to close more than 200 stores worldwide.

headline: 1941: U.S. Emphasizes Japan’s Deeds
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The United States responds to peace proposals by Japan in 1941.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Sumner Welles, Under Secretary of State, told Japan today [Feb. 18] that deeds speak louder than words, by way of comment on statements from Tokio in the last twenty-four hours tending to minimize the Japanese threat to Singapore and the Dutch East Indies and to deflect the blame for anxiety upon Great Britain and the United States.

headline: Angela Raiola, ‘Big Ang’ of TV’s ‘Mob Wives,’ Dies at 55
abstract: Ms. Raiola was the formidable but lovable reality TV star who attracted a cult following as a cast member of the VH1 show.
lead_paragraph: Angela Raiola, the formidable but lovable reality TV star known as “Big Ang” who attracted a cult following on VH1’s “Mob Wives,” died early Thursday in Manhattan. She was 55.

headline: Review: ‘Race’ Chronicles Jesse Owens’s Rise to Olympic Glory
abstract: Stephen Hopkins’s film takes one of the least challenging paths in telling Owens’s story, confining its time span to three years, from 1934 to 1936.
lead_paragraph: The ingredients of “Race,” a studiously uplifting biopic of Jesse Owens, the phenomenal star of the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin, remain as volatile as they were 80 years ago, although nowadays they are camouflaged. This true story of an impoverished black youth from the streets of Depression-era Cleveland who ascends to greatness by shattering track-and-field records and undercutting Adolf Hitler’s racist agenda is a safe, by-the-numbers tribute.

headline: A Make-or-Break Moment for Marco Rubio’s Candidacy
abstract: Endorsements and poll numbers have his campaign, still recovering from New Hampshire, boldly predicting a strong finish in South Carolina’s primary.
lead_paragraph: CHAPIN, S.C. — Aglow in floodlights and beaming with confidence, Senator Marco Rubio of Florida and Gov. Nikki R. Haley of South Carolina looked every bit like a potential national ticket here on Wednesday, giving his supporters a glimpse of what many Republicans have long coveted: a multicultural new look for a party hungry to be competitive in November.

headline: Holding Out Hope for ‘Room’ to Win the Oscar for Best Picture
abstract: With Academy Award voting down to its final days and voters split, the small film company A24 sees a possibility that its long-shot contender “Room” can win.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Surprises almost never happen anymore at the Academy Awards. The vote-mongering machinery and punditry have grown too powerful.

headline: When Cancer Treatment Offers Hope More Than Cure
abstract: With the most recent return of her leukemia in the fall, I asked her, not for the first time, if she had been through enough, and would like to forgo any more treatment.
lead_paragraph: We joked that she had nine lives.

headline: Los Angeles Hospital Pays Hackers $17,000 After Attack
abstract: The hackers had deployed a malware attack to hold the computer system of Hollywood Presbyterian Medical Center hostage and demanded the ransom.
lead_paragraph: It sounds like the plot of a Hollywood thriller, but the all-too-real scenario played out this month at a large Los Angeles hospital: Hackers seized control of critical computer systems and the hospital paid a $17,000 ransom to release them.

headline: Paul Graham and Seizing the Everyday Moments
abstract: The British photographer, the subject of a retrospective in San Francisco, discusses his devotion to the subject of “the flow of life all around us.”
lead_paragraph: “Stare,” wrote Walker Evans, the canonical 20th-century photographer. “It is the way to educate your eye, and more. Stare; pry; listen; eavesdrop. Die knowing something. You are not here long.”

headline: Obama Going to Cuba; First Visit by U.S. President in 88 Years
keywords: ['Embargoes and Sanctions', 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: The visit is part of an effort to end more than a half-century of estrangement and forge normalized relations with a Cold War adversary.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s decision to travel to Cuba next month and meet with President Raúl Castro reflects his determination to do as much as possible before he leaves office to pry open the historic and ideological barricades that have separated the United States from its neighbor since the Cold War.

headline: Marco Rubio Objects as Supporter Calls Hillary Clinton ‘a Traitor’
abstract: An audience member at a rally in South Carolina for Senator Marco Rubio called Hillary Clinton “a traitor,” prompting an objection from the candidate.
lead_paragraph: GREENVILLE, S.C. — An audience member at a rally for Senator Marco Rubio called Hillary Clinton “a traitor,” prompting an objection from the candidate.

headline: Review: ‘American Girls,’ on the Secret Online Lives of Teenagers
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Social Media', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Nancy Jo Sales examines how smartphones and social media disrupt the lives of young people, notably teenage girls.
lead_paragraph: The murder last month of a 13-year-old Virginia girl — who had communicated with one of her suspected killers through Kik, the popular messaging app that offers its users anonymity — has reignited worries about teenagers’ use of social media. It is only the latest in a wave of stories that underscore the hazards facing young people in cyberspace.

headline: CBS Poll Shows Donald Trump Keeping Lead Nationally
abstract: A new national poll from CBS News found that Donald J. Trump still holds a dominant lead atop the Republican field of presidential candidates, suggesting that he remains in a strong position ahead of the coming wave of primary elections.
lead_paragraph: A new national poll from CBS News found that Donald J. Trump still holds a dominant lead atop the Republican field of presidential candidates, suggesting that he remains in a strong position ahead of the coming wave of primary elections.

headline: Golden State Warriors Are Somehow Exceeding Expectations
abstract: With the N.B.A. resuming play on Thursday night, it’s a good time to take stock of the league’s biggest first-half surprises.
lead_paragraph: After a six-day break for dunking over mascots and a 196-173 exhibition game, the N.B.A. season finally resumed on Thursday night. The symbolic halfway mark of the season is always an appropriate time to take stock. Preseason hopes have been dashed for some, while excitement is rising for others.

headline: 1966: Refugees Flee From Viet Cong
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: In Vietnam, refugees flee from the Viet Cong in 1966.
lead_paragraph: BONG SON, South Vietnam — Nearly half of the An Lao valley’s 10,000 residents chose to abandon their rich rice paddies today [Feb. 18] and flee from the Viet Cong. Men, women and children clutched U.S. soldiers and begged to be flown to safety. More than 4,500 refugees have streamed out of the valley since soldiers of the US 1st Air Cavalry Division came in ten days ago, a cavalry spokesman said. Today, the last cavalry troopers left the valley. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 19, 1966

headline: Shame and Guilt Drives Several New Productions, Which Is Good for Us
abstract: Some unpleasant emotions are at the heart of “Hughie,” “Long Day’s Journey Into Night,” “The Crucible” and “Hold On to Me, Darling.”
lead_paragraph: Until the snake slithered into the picture, the Garden of Eden was a drama-free zone. It wasn’t just that theater requires an audience of more than beneficent animals and foliage. How could anyone put on a gripping play without the essential elements of sin and the feelings it inspires? Where’s the drama, in other words, in a world without guilt?

headline: Left-Field Musicals Take Center Stage
abstract: Broadway has had some success lately with shows that ignored tired templates. This spring offers worthy additions to that encouraging trend.
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, it seemed as though some kind of legislation had been passed decreeing that Broadway musicals could come in only a handful of styles. The musical adapted from a popular movie. The nostalgia-driven show recycling songs from pop charts past. The Disney family spectacle. The pop-opera born of the British invasion in the 1980s, whose legacy held sway despite the failure of many imitators.

headline: The Artist Who Dared to Paint Ireland’s Great Famine
abstract: An exhibition at Ireland’s Great Hunger Museum in Connecticut resurrects the audacious career of Daniel Macdonald.
lead_paragraph: HAMDEN, Conn. — It is called An Gorta Mor, or the Great Hunger, an evocative term that still fails to convey the full horror of the Irish potato famine, perhaps the single worst catastrophe in 19th-century Europe. Between 1845 and 1852, Ireland lost more than a quarter of its population to starvation, disease and emigration, while its English overlords hemmed, hawed and, in at least one prominent case, cited God’s will as justification.

headline: Sidewalk ‘Compliments’
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Women and Girls', 'Families and Family Life', 'Dating and Relationships']
abstract: Plus, lawyer networking tips; the scoop on in-laws; and dating truths.
lead_paragraph: Occasionally, a guy in the street signals that he needs my attention. So I take off my earphones to hear what he has to say. He could be looking for directions in the big city. But usually, it’s, “Excuse me, I just have to tell you how attractive you are.” This annoys me, as if my purpose in life is to be pretty. I get that no one likes rejection. So “Go away” is not a polite response. But “Thank you” sends the wrong message. I am not thankful. These comments ruin my groove. Thoughts?

headline: Readers Respond: ‘A Mother’s Reckoning’
abstract: Readers comment on a review of Sue Klebold’s memoir about her son, one of the killers at Columbine High School in 1999.
lead_paragraph: Susan Dominus’s review of “A Mother’s Reckoning” by Sue Klebold, the mother of one of the two boys who killed 12 classmates and a teacher, and then killed themselves, at Columbine High School in 1999, has drawn more than 900 comments from Times readers. Ms. Dominus posits that the central question of the memoir is how parents can prevent a tragedy like the Columbine shooting. Some readers said there was no way. “We are all just trying to do our best and there but for the grace of God go I,” said The Writer Stuff of Missouri.

headline: That (Very, Very) Old Black Magic in ‘The Witch’
abstract: How Robert Eggers went about creating his long-ago and dark world.
lead_paragraph: It’s not long after “The Witch” begins that things get very, very dark. Within the first 10 minutes, the infant son of an isolated 17th-century Puritan family goes missing, snatched away and taken into the woods by the menacing title character. Let’s just say she has no plans to keep the little boy safe.

headline: Review: In ‘The Cherry Orchard,’ the Myopia of an Aristocratic Family
abstract: This Russian production at the Brooklyn Academy of Music plants actors amid the audience to heighten a sense of trepidation and exasperation.
lead_paragraph: Nothing happens in the plays of Anton Chekhov. But everything happens, too. People complain about restaurants, sing comic songs, make speeches in praise of bookcases even as they’re loving and losing and dying. You’ll feel that paradox acutely in the Maly Drama Theater’s “The Cherry Orchard,” Chekhov’s final play, adapted and directed by Lev Dodin in ways both frustrating and wonderfully exciting.

headline: Two Reunions, Bittersweet and Foreboding, in ‘The Brothers Size’
abstract: The production, poetic yet unpretentious, explores the friction between siblings and a former prison mate near a Louisiana bayou.
lead_paragraph: Early in “The Brothers Size,” I stopped trying to analyze why this play felt so alive. Instead I just trusted my emotions, and that made this production, at Luna Stage in West Orange, still more satisfying. Indeed, it’s easy to list the show’s qualities: an outstanding cast, a powerful script, smart staging. What’s harder is describing its magic.

headline: Same Expectations for Yankees, but Further From Reach
abstract: At Joe Girardi’s state of the Yankees address on Thursday, it was clear that times have changed for his team, which is north of baseball’s middle but south of the Mets.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Jennifer Steinbrenner Swindal sat quietly in the back of a conference room Thursday at the ballpark that bears her father’s name. The Yankees’ manager, Joe Girardi, gave his annual spring training address, hopeful his team could do better after three years in a row without taking part in a playoff series. Nobody asked about his job security.

headline: New Databases Offer Insights Into the Lives of Escaped Slaves
abstract: Historians in the United States and Britain are tapping these tools to piece together family trees and identify patterns in the lives of runaways.
lead_paragraph: When slaves fled American and British farms and townhouses, their owners often placed detailed newspaper ads offering rewards to anyone who returned the fugitives. The written notices described the runaway slaves’ mannerisms, clothes, hairstyles, skin markings, teeth and skills, as well as information about plantations that the escapees might have tried to reach, hoping to reunite with family members or less cruel past owners.

headline: Volkswagen Memos Suggest Company Misled U.S. Regulators
keywords: ['Diesel Power', 'Air Pollution', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Fuel Emissions (Transportation)']
abstract: Documents suggesting VW executives knew of elevated diesel emissions in early 2014 could create problems with regulators, car owners and stockholders.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen internal memos and emails suggest that company executives pursued a strategy of delay and obfuscation with United States regulators after being confronted in early 2014 with evidence that VW diesel vehicles were emitting far more pollutants than allowed.

keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Maybe the Pope’s criticism and Mr. Trump’s response will lead to more questioning of Republican candidates who lead with their Christian faith.
lead_paragraph: The headlines are blazing, Twitter is lit up, the political press is all hot for the kind of story it loves to tell: two huge celebrities attacking each other.

headline: Review: In ‘The Witch,’ a Family’s Contract With God Is Tested
abstract: Around 1630 in New England, a family leaves a plantation to settle down alone at the edge of a forest.
lead_paragraph: A finely calibrated shiver of a movie, “The Witch” opens on a scene of religious wrath. On a New England plantation, around 1630, a true believer, William (Ralph Ineson), and his family are facing a grim assemblage. The setting is a kind of meeting house crowded with men, women and children, a congregation whose silence and unsmiling faces imply disapproval or perhaps fear. Whether they’re standing in judgment doesn’t matter to William, whose arrogant faith in his own notion of Christianity is as deep and darkly unsettling as his sepulchral voice. It’s the sort of soul-and-earth-quaking voice you can imagine one of the biblical patriarchs having, the kind that Abraham used on God and Isaac alike.

headline: Movie Review: ‘The Witch’
abstract: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Witch.”
lead_paragraph: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews “The Witch.”

headline: Lively Vintage Photos of Supermodels and Superclubs
abstract: “The Isaac Mizrahi Pictures: New York City 1989-1993,” by Nick Waplington, captures a singular era in Manhattan fashion and nightlife.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Nick Waplington’s new book captures a lately much longed-for cultural moment in New York City’s history, when supermodels ruled the runways and club kids held court at all hours. Waplington was introduced to the fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi by his mentor, the fashion photographer Richard Avedon, and was quickly welcomed into Mizrahi’s fashion fold, where he was a fly on the wall at fittings with Naomi, Christy and Linda. “It was a very fun time to be in his studio,” Waplington says. “This was before cellphones, so various boyfriends of the models would call up on the office phone and they’d put them on speakerphone and have these funny, piss-taking conversations with them without them knowing that everyone was listening. This would happen with Spike Lee quite a lot when he was dating Veronica Webb.”

headline: “The Isaac Mizrahi Pictures: New York City 1989-1993”
abstract: Selections from the photographer Nick Waplington’s forthcoming photo book.
lead_paragraph: Selections from the photographer Nick Waplington’s forthcoming photo book.

headline: Supreme Court Appointment Could Reshape American Life
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Citizens United v Federal Election Commission (Supreme Court Decision)']
abstract: An appointment by President Obama of a successor to Justice Antonin Scalia could set in motion a profound ideological shift on the court and create a new liberal majority.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — There is a reason Republican senators are so adamant in their refusal to let President Obama appoint a successor to Justice Antonin Scalia, a towering figure in conservative jurisprudence. An Obama appointment would be the most consequential ideological shift on the court since 1991, creating a liberal majority that would almost certainly reshape American law and American life.

headline: Measuring the Planet’s Health in Vibrant Shades of Green
abstract: By seeing which ecosystems are experiencing the most change at the plant level, scientists hope they will be able to make better predictions.
lead_paragraph: From space, Earth appears as a blue marble. But some researchers have been studying the planet through a different-colored lens: green.

headline: At Wake for Staten Island Stabbing Victims, Tears and One Word: Why?
keywords: ['Funerals and Memorials', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Homeless Persons']
abstract: Rebecca Cutler and her young daughters Ziana Cutler and Maliyah Sykes, who were killed at a motel last week, were mourned in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: They were items that have no place in a funeral home: images of children’s toys, and a puppy and teddy bear made of pastel flowers.

headline: Review: Twisted Sister’s Hard Road and Drummer Shortage
abstract: Directed by Andrew Horn, “We Are Twisted_______ Sister!” chronicles the rock band’s difficult path to making it in the music business.
lead_paragraph: “We went through a succession of drummers,” one member of the titular band in “We Are Twisted _______ Sister!” recalls at a relatively late point in this largely fascinating but arguably overlong documentary directed by Andrew Horn. That should ring a bell with aficionados of rock docs both actual and fictional, and the movie does contain further echoes of the classic comedy “This Is Spinal Tap.” A crucial difference is that this film’s subjects, and particularly the core members Jay Jay French and Dee Snider, are polar opposites of Tap’s pitifully un-self-conscious dim bulbs.

keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Euro (Currency)', 'International Relations']
abstract: The leaders of the 28 nations are meeting in Brussels to confront issues over Britain and the migrant crisis that challenge the longtime goal of “ever closer union.”
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The leaders of the 28 European Union nations assembled again in an atmosphere of crisis on Thursday, confronting the details of a deal to keep Britain from bolting from the bloc as well as the complexities of stemming the flow of migrants to the Continent.

headline: Review: Dmitri Hvorostovsky Sings of Life, Love and Sadness at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The baritone, joined by the pianist Ivari Ilja, performed songs by Glinka, Tchaikovsky and others in a concert shaded by knowledge of his illness.
lead_paragraph: The charismatic baritone Dmitri Hvorostovsky looked a little thin when he appeared at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday for a sold-out song recital. That was understandable. As the worldwide admirers of this great Russian artist know, Mr. Hvorostovsky, 53, has been undergoing treatments for a brain tumor that have caused him to cancel swaths of performances.

abstract: American Museum of Natural History: ‘Countdown to Zero’ (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.

lead_paragraph: At the Calvin Klein Collection show on Thursday, there was Margot Robbie, the Hollywood siren — so voluptuously gorgeous that when she appeared as herself in “The Big Short,” she was shown sipping Champagne in a bubble bath — demurely attired in a coat, trousers and turtleneck sweater. (By Calvin Klein Collection, naturally.)

headline: Sugarplum Fairies and Cavaliers Move Ahead at City Ballet
abstract: A number of dancers with roles in the latest George Balanchine’s “The Nutcracker” are making their debuts in new roles at City Ballet.
lead_paragraph: A ballet company is a family. A retirement is a grievous loss, a role debut an exciting new stage of life. New York City Ballet presented an exceptional number of new Sugarplum Fairies and Cavaliers (in George Balanchine’s “The Nutcracker”) Christmas week; in the current six-week season (through Feb. 28), several of those dancers have acquired other new roles.

headline: Schomburg Center Commemorates a 90-Year History
abstract: Two exhibitions and several discussions celebrate the history of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture.
lead_paragraph: Readers of Weekend Miser know that New York City has no shortage of free and low-cost cultural events — after all, for the past five years the Miser has been highlighting them. Now the time has come to bid adieu, but not without one last column. And it seems fitting to include events through February, most with ties to Black History Month.

headline: Review: A ‘Lear’ With Hops, Spins and Posturing
abstract: “Lear” has its United States premiere at New York Live Arts, in a dancing reduction of that Shakespeare tragedy.
lead_paragraph: “This is not Lear,” said the distinguished actress and dancer Valda Setterfield. She wasn’t kidding. Although those are the lines written for the title character of “King Lear,” the “Lear” that had its United States premiere at New York Live Arts on Wednesday, a collaboration between Ms. Setterfield and the Irish choreographer-director John Scott, was a reduction of Shakespeare’s play in many senses, only one of which could be considered positive: The show lasts not much more than an hour.

abstract: “Love,” a new Netflix series, and “Togetherness,” in Season 2 on HBO, are a pair of bittersweet candy hearts about romance among the creative class.
lead_paragraph: In comedy, they say timing is everything. That goes double for romantic comedy. The genre is built on the tension between fate and circumstance: Two people are meant to be together, but the plot keeps them out of sync until divine order is restored.

headline: Review: Miranda Cuckson and Ekmeles Draw Links Across Time
abstract: The violinist and the vocal ensemble crossed the avant-garde with the Flemish Renaissance in “Luigi Nono and the Human Voice” at National Sawdust.
lead_paragraph: Jagged lines crisscross the walls, floor and ceiling at National Sawdust, the performance space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. A visitor focusing on the white spaces in between might see a study in separation, each panel an ice floe isolated by channels of dark water. But train an eye on the black bands, and connections pop out as trajectories intersect, sometimes at wild angles.

headline: Review: ‘Snowtime!’ Tells of an Escalating Snowball War
abstract: This animated movie, intended for a young audience, is a remake of a 1984 film called “The Dog Who Stopped the War.”
lead_paragraph: You don’t realize how thoroughly a certain style of animated children’s movie has become the norm until you see one like “Snowtime!” that doesn’t fit the mold. The slower pacing, the lack of authority figures who need to be defied or corrected, the subdued rather than out-front messages — this movie looks and feels quite different from most recent animated blockbusters.

headline: Review: ‘Risen,’ a Tale of Conversion Starring Joseph Fiennes
abstract: The producers, in trying to appeal to believers and nonbelievers alike, aim for drama in the story of Clavius, a Roman army tribune.
lead_paragraph: Unfolding like a clunky episode of “Law & Order,” the biblical procedural “Risen” confronts the Resurrection through the stiffly skeptical countenance of Joseph Fiennes, who takes on the role of Clavius, a Roman army tribune, as if it were a life sentence.

headline: Capturing Human Moments Amid Chaos in Israel and the West Bank
abstract: An exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum explores the region through the eyes of 12 outside photographers.
lead_paragraph: In “This Place,” an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum, life and photography and art cause sparks to fly. Its more than 600 images have been taken by 12 well-known photographers, and document life on one of the most contested stretches of land in the world: Israel and the West Bank, where Jews and Muslims, Israelis and Palestinians, Bedouins and Africans, among others, often live tensely side by side, and the threat of violence is never far away.

headline: Review: In ‘Forsaken,’ the Sutherlands Bond in the Old West
abstract: A gunslinger returns to his hometown and encounters challenges as he reconnects with his father in this film set in 1872.
lead_paragraph: A starry father-son pairing is largely squandered in “Forsaken,” an old-school western that is a little too old school for its own good.

abstract: The museum says the monographic show, which opens Nov. 20, will be the artist’s first major exhibition in the U.S. since a 1970s Guggenheim show.
lead_paragraph: Francis Picabia has always been tough to pin down.

headline: Op Art Through a Latin Lens
abstract: “The Illusive Eye” at El Museo del Barrio considers the contributions South American artists made to the kinetic and Op Art movements.
lead_paragraph: In the winter of 1965, the Museum of Modern Art opened “The Responsive Eye,” the landmark show that introduced Op Art and related trends to the general public. It was the museum’s most popular exhibition to that date. Now, 51 years later, “The Illusive Eye: An International Inquiry on Kinetic and Op Art” at El Museo del Barrio looks back on that show and finds it wanting.

headline: Lady Gaga: Marc Jacobs’s Most Talked About Model
abstract: She walked in the designer’s fall/winter 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: For his fall/winter 2016 show, Marc Jacobs cast a special guest — Lady Gaga. The platform boots-habitué was slipped into the lineup of well-shod models, wearing an oversize coat with fur sleeves over a pussy-bow blouse. The designer also outfitted Gaga at Monday night’s Grammy Awards in an ornate blue gown for the red carpet and a sequined white suit during her David Bowie tribute performance. (Another notable cameo in the show: Hillary Clinton, whose visage appeared on Jacobs-designed shirts worn by both a front-row Anna Wintour and the designer himself.)

headline: Review: In ‘Diamond Tongues,’ Leah Goldstein Plays a Flawed Actress
abstract: Ms. Goldstein’s character is resentful and disarming as she tries to make it in show business in Toronto.
lead_paragraph: “Diamond Tongues,” an alternately sweet and slashing microbudget comedy from Canada, makes a great vehicle for Leah Goldstein, a musician and performance artist appearing in her first movie. As Edith, an aspiring actress who seems blind to her deficits and personal flaws, Ms. Goldstein gives a performance that requires her to swing between disarming and loathsome. She demonstrates impressive skill in slowly peeling away her character’s charm.

headline: Review: Yo La Tengo and Alvin Lucier, With Balloons
abstract: The band and the composer shared concepts and whispered memories at the Ecstatic Music Festival on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: The composer Alvin Lucier, now 84, is interested in repetition, long tones, overtones, music as process, music as directed improvisation, the perception of sound and any metaphorical ideas that might roll out of those perceptions like dividends.

headline: Don’t Knock New York, and Other Meanings of DKNY
abstract: Maxwell Osborne and Dao-Yi Chow are still trying to redefine the brand Donna Karan built.
lead_paragraph: What does DKNY stand for? Once upon a time it was Donna Karan New York, the younger, hipper, streetier sister of the Donna Karan collection.

headline: Review: Trullo d’Oro Transports to Southern Italy
abstract: The cozy restaurant is named after the conical roofs found in the Puglia region, where relatives of the owners have an establishment.
lead_paragraph: Trullo d’ Oro, a five-month-old restaurant in Hicksville, is the kind of warm and cozy Italian place that Long Islanders love. The homey old-world scene is set by red and white checked tablecloths, stucco walls dotted with copper pots and pans and, most of all, the friendly staff and owners.

headline: An American President in Cuba
abstract: Mr. Obama’s trip to Cuba may do more to plant seeds of change than the failed policies of his predecessors.
lead_paragraph: President Obama spoke passionately last year about the importance of term limits during a visit to Africa, where he argued that “nobody should be president for life.” His administration has been more muted on this issue in Latin America, where a handful of leaders have become strongmen disinclined to share or relinquish power.

headline: The Met and a New Logo
abstract: The new design has not failed to attract strong reactions as it starts to appear on the institution’s posters, mailings and the Met Breuer signs.
lead_paragraph: Who knew a logo could cause such controversy?

headline: Review: At Shell & Bones, a Sleek Space and a Dazzling View
abstract: The New Haven restaurant that opened in July offers a view of the city’s harbor and Long Island Sound.
lead_paragraph: What is it about a dazzling view that elevates a meal? Many of us have experienced how even humble fare, when paired with a knockout beachfront or mountaintop vista, can seem lavish.

headline: Supreme Court Precedents That May Be at Risk
abstract: Divisive Supreme Court decisions are more likely to be re-examined — and possibly overturned — when a court changes. In the Roberts Court, 85 cases split 5 to 4 or 5 to 3 with Justice Scalia in the conservative majority, many with similar judicial themes.
lead_paragraph: Divisive Supreme Court decisions are more likely to be re-examined — and possibly overturned — when a court changes. In the Roberts Court, 85 cases split 5 to 4 or 5 to 3 with Justice Scalia in the conservative majority, many with similar judicial themes.

abstract: Sienna Miller at Ralph Lauren, Zoë Kravitz at Calvin Klein and Kendall Jenner taking a break from walking the runway.
