lead_paragraph: Cyrille Aimée is a rising star in the galaxy of jazz singers.

headline: How Cyrille Aimée, Jazz Singer, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: The vocalist, who lives in Brooklyn when she’s not on the road, makes time to listen to the birds, catch up with friends and maybe catch a show.
lead_paragraph: A rising star in the galaxy of jazz singers, Cyrille Aimée won first place in the Sarah Vaughn International Jazz Vocal Competition in 2012. The radio host Jonathan Schwartz has described her as “electrifying” and as a singer “in Ella Fitzgerald’s territory.” Born in France to a French father and a Dominican mother, Ms. Aimée, 31, came to the United States to study at the Purchase College Conservatory of Music. She will perform selections from the album she released last month, “Let’s Get Lost,” on Feb. 24 at the Lycée Français de New York. Ms. Aimée lives in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: Art and 3-D Magic in a German Subway
abstract: The two-mile-long Wehrhahn is the result of a 15-year collaboration among artists, architects, civil engineers and the government.
lead_paragraph: DÜSSELDORF, Germany — An escalator descends into a dense soundscape of birdsongs. Windows appear to open onto outer space. An overhead LED screen converts human movements into colorful geometric animations.

headline: Cameroon Blames Boko Haram in Pair of Suicide Bombings
abstract: A week after Cameroon began a new offensive against the militant group, two attackers detonated explosives in Mémé, local reports said, killing nearly two dozen people.
lead_paragraph: YAOUNDÉ, Cameroon — A double suicide bombing attack in northern Cameroon on Friday morning left nearly two dozen people dead and more than 50 injured, officials said, laying the blame on the Boko Haram militant group.

headline: The Anger on London’s Stages Is Palpable, and Thrilling
abstract: “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,” “The Master Builder” and “Uncle Vanya” are all studies in the power of rage.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rage ricochets in the National Theater’s first-rate revival of August Wilson’s great, early play “Ma Rainey’s Black Bottom,” glancing off the walls like bullets in a closed room. In this incisively staged production, which opened here earlier this month, it’s clear from the beginning that somebody is going to get hurt. The victim may be random, yet the cause is anything but.

headline: Questionable Campaign Tactics Persist in South Carolina
abstract: In a state known for dirty politics, presidential candidates are embracing campaign strategies that often straddle the line between underhanded and dishonest.
lead_paragraph: From Lee Atwater’s whispers that a congressional candidate was psychotic to rumors that John McCain had fathered a black child out of wedlock to fake Mormon holiday cards supposedly sent by Mitt Romney, South Carolina is infamous for its dirty politics.

headline: Brian France on Nascar’s Future: ‘We Can’t Stand Around’
abstract: Before the Daytona 500 kicked off the Nascar season, France discussed the state of his sport, including diversity efforts and a new franchise system for ownership.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Brian France, grandson of Nascar founder Bill France, has been the organization’s chief executive and chairman since 2003, overseeing record television and sponsorship contracts as well as implementing seismic changes, like the Chase for the Sprint Cup. Four days before the Daytona 500 kicks off the Nascar season Sunday, France, 53, sat down to discuss the state of the circuit. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: For Costly Debt, Home Is Where the Deduction Is
keywords: ['Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Personal Finances', 'Credit and Debt', 'Home Equity Loans', 'Income Tax', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Credit Cards']
abstract: Because interest on some home mortgages is tax-deductible, borrowing against a home can be a useful tool to pay off other, nondeductible debt.
lead_paragraph: You cannot turn the clock back to make yourself younger. But you may be able to turn it back to a time when it was easier to obtain certain income tax deductions.

headline: So You Wanna Be a NASA Astronaut? Pretty Unlikely
abstract: By the deadline on Thursday, more than 18,300 people had submitted their résumés in hopes of joining the next group of NASA astronauts.
lead_paragraph: More people than ever are hoping they have “The Right Stuff,” and more people than ever will be disappointed that they do not.

headline: Proof of Zika’s Role in Birth Defects Still Months Away, W.H.O. Says
abstract: While the evidence is strong that the virus is behind Brazil’s surge of birth defects, experts are waiting for pregnant women in a clinical trial to start giving birth in June.
lead_paragraph: Public health officials are nearly certain that the Zika virus is behind Brazil’s surge of babies being born with tiny heads and damaged brains, but they do not expect to have proof until June at the earliest, the World Health Organization said on Friday.

headline: Maple Leafs’ Komarov Is Suspended for Hit to Rangers’ McDonagh
abstract: Leo Komarov elbowed Ryan McDonagh in the head Thursday, a day after McDonagh had returned from a concussion that caused him to miss four games.
lead_paragraph: The N.H.L. suspended Maple Leafs forward Leo Komarov for three games for elbowing Rangers defenseman Ryan McDonagh in the head during a game Thursday in Toronto.

headline: Review: ‘The Mermaid’ Features Stephen Chow Behind the Camera
abstract: This slapstick eco-fable and love story has, in addition to mermaids, a half-octopus and a femme fatale.
lead_paragraph: The remarkable Hong Kong filmmaker and comic performer Stephen Chow (“Shaolin Soccer,” “Kung Fu Hustle”) has in recent years opted to stay behind the camera. And perhaps it is his absence from the screen that made Sony keep his new movie, “The Mermaid,” low-profile for its United States release.

headline: Francis and Trump: Populist Leaders Preaching Divergent Messages
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Christians and Christianity', 'Income Inequality', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)']
abstract: Pope Francis and Donald J. Trump each has diagnosed similar societal issues, seeking followers in seas churning with anger, dislocation, spiritual alienation and economic inequality.
lead_paragraph: ROME — In the cage fight of American presidential politics, the matchup is irresistible: Pope Francis, leader of the world’s 1.2 billion Roman Catholics, the pope of the poor who has knelt to wash the feet of prisoners and Muslims, versus Donald J. Trump, billionaire Republican who disparages Muslims and kneels to no one.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: iPhone, Donald Trump, Harper Lee
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: W.H.O. Advises Caution, but Not a Halt, in Blood Collection in Zika-Affected Areas
abstract: With the virus rapidly spreading throughout Latin America and the Caribbean, it may be “logistically impossible” to import blood for all of the region, officials say.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization issued recommendations on Friday for safeguarding the blood supply from the Zika virus, but said blood collection might need to continue in some affected areas, despite concerns that the virus may be linked to birth defects and a form of temporary paralysis.

headline: No Love Lost Between Ted Cruz and Donald Trump Supporters
abstract: At nearby rallies, supporters of Mr. Trump and Mr. Cruz echoed the candidates’ language and themes – a sign that the bitter feud between the candidates has seeped into voters.
lead_paragraph: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C. — Speaking just six miles apart on Friday morning, Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas renewed their bitter personal feud, while their supporters echoed the candidates’ language and themes – a sign that the bitterness between the two men has now seeped deeply into the feelings of voters.

headline: Review: ‘The Reef’ Speaks in the Tongue of a Chamber Orchestra
abstract: An ode to surfing, by the Australian Mick Sowry, with a varied suite of works as accompaniment, instead of dialogue or a film score.
lead_paragraph: Surfing movies tend to offer spectacular scenes of cresting seas and intrepid athletes riding perfect waves. So does “The Reef,” an 80-minute film by the Australian surfer-turned-director Mick Sowry, which presents a mythologized tale of a surfing trip near a marine park in Western Australia.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
abstract: Uganda and More — Photos of the Day
lead_paragraph: Uganda and More — Photos of the Day

headline: Feb. 19, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Uganda, Greece, Sicily and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Uganda, Greece, Sicily and the United States.

headline: How ‘To Kill a Mockingbird’ Changed Their Lives
abstract: New York Times readers shared their most notable moments from Harper Lee’s first novel.
lead_paragraph: Harper Lee’s “To Kill a Mockingbird” has transported generations of readers to small-town Alabama in the 1930s and confronted them with a sobering tale of racial inequality in the Deep South during Jim Crow. Read by many students in middle school and high school, it has left a mark on innumerable lives.

headline: Jordan Spieth Improves but Makes ‘Too Many Mistakes’ and Misses the Cut
abstract: Spieth, the world No. 1, had to take solace in the fact that his second round beat his average of 69.4 from his previous two appearances at Riviera as a pro.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As he stepped down from the interview stand, Dustin Johnson ran into Jordan Spieth, who was on his way to address reporters. Johnson asked Spieth how he had played. “Better than yesterday,” Spieth said, to which Johnson impishly replied, “That wasn’t hard to do.”

headline: ‘WarGames’ and Cybersecurity’s Debt to a Hollywood Hack
abstract: After seeing the Matthew Broderick movie, President Reagan questioned the vulnerability of military computers, leading to a classified directive.
lead_paragraph: Movies rarely influence public policy, but Washington’s policies on cyberattacks, computer surveillance and the possibility of cyberwarfare were directly influenced by the 1983 box-office hit “WarGames.”

headline: A Harvard Sociologist on Watching Families Lose Their Homes
abstract: The academic Matthew Desmond, author of the forthcoming book “Evicted,” tells of his fieldwork and frustrations.
lead_paragraph: The first time the sociologist Matthew Desmond rode along during an eviction, he was shocked by the suddenness of “seeing your house turn into not your house in seconds.”

headline: What Does the Academy Value in a Black Performance?
abstract: Black artists have been nominated for best actress or actor on 30 occasions. Over the last few weeks, I watched all of them.
lead_paragraph: When the Oscar nominations were announced last month, revealing that not one black actor was in the running, the resulting furor touched on the performances that critics said should have been considered: What about Idris Elba in “Beasts of No Nation”? Michael B. Jordan in “Creed”? Will Smith in “Concussion,” or one of the stars of “Straight Outta Compton”?

headline: Hats Off to the Circumflex
abstract: An accent mark invented in the ancient world has become a focal point in France’s debate over spelling reform.
lead_paragraph: London — FOR me, learning French a quarter-century ago at high school in Scotland, the circumflex that perched atop certain vowels (ê) was an enigma. It lacked the flamboyance of the accent aigu (é) or accent grave (è), modifying pronunciation so subtly I could barely discern it. Nor did it possess the utility of the tréma, which divided vowel sounds in two (aï). When I finally found out that the circumflex stood in for a discarded letter S, everything clicked into place: Opaque words like bête, coût and huître now morphed into their English equivalents before my eyes, resolving themselves into “beast,” “cost” and “oyster.”

headline: Review: Frederica von Stade, Wickedness in a One-Act Opera
abstract: Ms. von Stade plays the ornery, bigoted, faded Southern belle at the center of “A Coffin in Egypt” at Jazz at Lincoln Center.
lead_paragraph: Over the course of a long, distinguished career, the mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade went from portraying adorable youngsters — Mozart’s Cherubino and Zerlina, Rossini’s Rosina — to darker, more complicated women in operas like “The Aspern Papers,” “The Dangerous Liaisons” and “Dead Man Walking.”

headline: 9 Memorable Moments From New York Fashion Week
abstract: Marc Jacobs goes Gaga, Rihanna exercises her designer side, the Olsen twins hold an open house, and more highlights from a jampacked nine days.
lead_paragraph: Marc Jacobs goes Gaga, Rihanna exercises her designer side, the Olsen twins hold an open house, and more highlights from a jampacked nine days.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Signs Measure Raising City Officials’ Pay
abstract: The raise, approved by the City Council this month, was criticized because it was $10,185 greater than the one recommended by an advisory panel.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio signed several bills into law on Friday during a ceremony in City Hall’s ornate Blue Room, using multiple black pens that he presented to dignitaries and advocates. But there was a pen that none of the attendees wanted to take home: the one he used to sign the bill that gave members of the City Council and other elected officials a sizable pay raise.

headline: Will Democracy Follow Capitalism Into Cuba?
abstract: President Obama will encounter a different, more enterprising country in his visit next month. But freedom remains a distant goal.
lead_paragraph: THANKS disproportionately to their mother, my kids have a gratifyingly acute sense of the urgency of addressing the dire straits in which far too much of the world’s population lives.

headline: Review: The Budapest Festival Orchestra, Martial and Lyrical
abstract: The orchestra, led by Ivan Fischer, presents work by Weber, Liszt and Prokofiev at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The last time I heard the Budapest Festival Orchestra play in New York, its longtime conductor and music director, Ivan Fischer, had prepared a little joke: In the middle of one of Dvorak’s Slavonic Dances, a percussionist walked past his colleagues to the front of the stage, settled down on a soloist’s bench set up there and reached into his jacket for a mallet and a tiny brass bell. Then he joined in the music, adding little pealing accents that suddenly seemed like the work’s main feature.

headline: 3 Rabbis and a Judge Savor the Enduring Back-and-Forth of Tennis
abstract: A group with octogenarians at its core has been meeting in Manhattan for weekly tennis sessions for more than 45 years.
lead_paragraph: When the three rabbis and a judge walk onto the court at a Manhattan tennis center on Wednesday nights, it is no joke.

headline: Bill Cunningham’s Evening Hours
abstract: Mr. Cunningham covers events in February.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Cunningham covers events in February.

headline: Bernie Sanders Pushes Supporters to Turn Out in Nevada
abstract: Holding rallies in three cities hundreds of miles apart, Mr. Sanders urged the state’s Democrats to “show the world that democracy is alive and well here in Nevada.”
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont spent Friday crisscrossing Nevada, holding rallies in three cities hundreds of miles apart and making his final pitch to voters on the eve of the state’s Democratic caucuses.

headline: Donald Trump Calls for Boycott of Apple in Dispute With Government
abstract: Several Republican candidates have criticized Apple’s stance on the F.B.I.’s request to help it unlock the San Bernardino gunman’s iPhone, but Mr. Trump is the first to call for a boycott.
lead_paragraph: PAWLEYS ISLAND, S.C. — The political backlash against Apple for refusing to help the F.B.I. hack an iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino attackers escalated on Friday with Donald J. Trump calling for a boycott of the company.

headline: Judge Deals Setback to Holdouts in Negotiations With Argentina
abstract: A federal judge in New York says he will lift an injunction that locked Argentina out of international markets in a long battle over defaulted debt.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge presiding over a long-running battle between Argentina and a group of New York hedge funds said on Friday that he would lift an injunction that had locked Argentina out of international markets.

headline: Writers, Teachers and Lawyers React to Harper Lee’s Death
abstract: Reflections on the legacy of the celebrated American writer.
lead_paragraph: Reflections on the legacy of the celebrated American writer.

headline: The Life of Pablo vs. the Life of Kanye
abstract: How does the self-proclaimed “greatest living artist” measure up to Pablo Picasso?
lead_paragraph: How does the self-proclaimed “greatest living artist” measure up to Pablo Picasso?

headline: Kanye West Is Fixing His Album in Public. You’ll Want to Read the Edits.
abstract: The rollout of “The Life of Pablo” has been an unprecedented marathon. Will it ever be done? Perhaps that’s the wrong question.
lead_paragraph: When Kanye West first tweeted a handwritten 10-song track list for his seventh album, “The Life of Pablo,” late last month, the photo was captioned, “So happy to be finished with the best album of all time.”

headline: Bill Cunningham | ‘Finally, Something to Wear to the Office’
abstract: Diversity in all its facets was vividly displayed on the guests attending last week’s New York Fashion Week show.
lead_paragraph: Diversity in all its facets was vividly displayed on the guests attending last week’s near-300 fashion shows and presentations. At times, it seemed as if we were back in the 1980s, with the tattooed, pierced and embellished downtown kids (spotted at Jeremy Scott, Gypsy Sport, Hood by Air and Xuly.Bët) presenting a radical contrast to uptown’s simplicity of style (seen at Ralph Lauren, Michael Kors and Proenza Schouler). Each group interprets taste for its lifestyle.

headline: Friday Night Music: San Fermin, Methuselah
abstract: Like a dirty bouquet with your wine.
lead_paragraph: A lovely acoustic performance:

headline: Supreme Court Won’t Intervene in North Carolina Election Fight
keywords: ['Redistricting and Reapportionment', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Voter Registration and Requirements']
abstract: A lower court had forced the Republican-dominated legislature to redraw its congressional maps on grounds they amounted to racial gerrymandering.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The United States Supreme Court declined late Friday to stay a lower court ruling that has forced North Carolina’s Republican-dominated legislature to redraw its congressional electoral maps on the grounds that the original maps amounted to racial gerrymandering.

headline: Streetcar Service Proposed by Mayor de Blasio May Require 2 New Bridges
keywords: ['Cable Cars and Trams', 'Bridges and Tunnels', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: The $2.5 billion proposal might require a bridge between Greenpoint, Brooklyn, and Long Island City, Queens, and another one over the Gowanus Canal near Red Hook, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: The Brooklyn-Queens streetcar proposed by Mayor Bill de Blasio could require the construction of two new bridges, one over Newtown Creek and a second over the Gowanus Canal, a top administration official said on Friday.

headline: In Harper Lee’s Novels, a Loss of Innocence as Children and Again as Adults
abstract: “To Kill a Mockingbird” and “Go Set a Watchman” raise different questions about how American society deals with racial inequality.
lead_paragraph: Harper Lee will forever be remembered for her 1960 classic “To Kill a Mockingbird” — a novel that became a staple of middle-school curriculums, and for several generations of readers, a coming-of-age story that spoke to their own losses of childhood innocence.

headline: After Tests in the North, Conservatives in South Korea Call for a Nuclear Program
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'International Relations', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: After nuclear tests and satellite launches in North Korea, a small band of conservative politicians and pundits in South Korea are pushing a strategy of arming their own country.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In the wake of North Korea’s nuclear tests and satellite launches, some conservatives in South Korea are championing a strategy that was once seen as unthinkable: arming their own country with nuclear weapons.

headline: Umberto Eco, 84, Best-Selling Academic Who Navigated Two Worlds, Dies
abstract: Mr. Eco was an expert in the arcane field of semiotics whose seven works of fiction included the blockbuster medieval mystery “The Name of the Rose.”
lead_paragraph: Umberto Eco, an Italian scholar in the arcane field of semiotics who became the author of best-selling novels, notably the blockbuster medieval mystery “The Name of the Rose,” died on Friday at his home in Milan. He was 84.

headline: City Steps Up Gas Line Inspections After Fatal Blast in East Village
abstract: A city department conducted 343 inspections of gas plumbing last year, five times as many as in 2014, and has hired additional inspectors in the past year.
lead_paragraph: When Mark G. Peters, the commissioner of the New York City Investigation Department, got a glimpse of the system for reporting the unauthorized tapping of pipes that supply gas for heating and cooking, he felt like a time traveler.

headline: Plausibility
abstract: Just FYI.

headline: Trump Shows His Inner Rabbit
abstract: Donald Trump quickly moved his attention from the pope to another battle.
lead_paragraph: I am sorry to note that Donald Trump no longer seems to be at war with the pope.

headline: Monroeville, Ala., Remembers Harper Lee, Its Most Celebrated Resident
abstract: Ms. Lee’s death on Friday at 89 struck a chord around the world, but nowhere did it resonate as deeply as in the town where she grew up.
lead_paragraph: The sisters would typically come in for chicken salad and potato soup, arriving just before the Courthouse Cafe in Monroeville closed for lunch at 2 p.m., when there were few customers left.

headline: Saudis Cut Off Funding for Military Aid to Lebanon
abstract: The move was a new step in a proxy war between countries who are on opposing sides in the wars in Yemen and Syria and competing for influence elsewhere across the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Saudi Arabia said Friday that it was stopping payment on $4 billion worth of military aid and other support for the army and security services of Lebanon because the country did not condemn attacks on Saudi diplomatic missions in Iran.

headline: Obscure Kurdish Group Claims Hand in Bombing Turks
abstract: The Kurdistan Freedom Hawks claimed responsibility for a bombing that killed 28 in Turkey’s capital, but Turkey’s leaders continued to blame a different Kurdish group, an ally of the United States.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — An obscure Kurdish militant group that is an offshoot of the Kurdistan Workers’ Party, which has long waged an insurgency inside Turkey, claimed responsibility on Friday for a car bombing this week in Ankara that killed 28 people. The group said the attack was in revenge for the Turkish Army’s campaign against Kurdish insurgents in the country’s southeast.

headline: Superdelegates, Clarify Your Role
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: It wouldn’t hurt for Democratic Party insiders to acknowledge that the presidential nomination rightly belongs to the majority vote-getter.
lead_paragraph: Even after Bernie Sanders’s overwhelming popular victory in New Hampshire on Feb. 9, some of his supporters began fretting about a new menace to his candidacy: “superdelegates” who — at least in theory — could deliver the nomination to Hillary Clinton in July’s convention.

headline: New Chinese Rules on Foreign Firms’ Online Content
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Censorship', 'News and News Media', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: New regulations will forbid any foreign company from publishing online content in China without the government’s consent.
lead_paragraph: China is taking another step to restrict what can be posted on the Internet in its country by issuing new rules barring foreign companies or their affiliates from engaging in publishing online content there without government approval.

headline: Tony Phillips, Whose Play Sealed 1989 World Series, Dies at 56
abstract: Mr. Phillips spent half of his 18-year major league career with the Oakland Athletics, finding glory with them in a World Series delayed by an earthquake.
lead_paragraph: Tony Phillips, a veteran infielder and outfielder whose final defensive play sealed the Oakland Athletics’ sweep of the San Francisco Giants in 1989 in a World Series that was interrupted for 11 days by a powerful earthquake, died on Wednesday in Scottsdale, Ariz. He was 56.

headline: Sabathia May Not Stay a Starter, Despite His Sobriety and a $25 Million Salary
abstract: The Yankees are hoping that C.C. Sabathia’s 30-day stint in an alcohol rehabilitation clinic last fall might have the same restorative effect on his body that Sabathia says it has had on his soul.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — C. C. Sabathia still wears a brace to keep his degenerative right knee from collapsing. He still weighs 305 pounds, a few crumb cakes short of the weight he carried a year ago. In baseball’s age of market efficiency, he remains a walking albatross — the highest-paid player on baseball’s biggest payroll and the winning pitcher in six games last season.

headline: David Wright Searches for Appropriate Balance Between Rest and Work
abstract: In a spring training generally devoid of intrigue for the Mets, David Wright’s health and playing time are a source of uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When the Mets infielders took their positions Friday for an unofficial workout, David Wright received the first ground ball at third base. The pitchers’ workouts had ended, and several team officials and dozens of fans gathered around to watch. What they saw was this: Wright fielded the ball cleanly and made a smooth throw to first base, with his tongue out.

headline: South Carolina’s Legacy, Exploited by Trump
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Civil War (US) (1861-65)']
abstract: Racial animus still drives the state’s Republican primary.
lead_paragraph: The massacre of nine black citizens at a church in Charleston last summer exposed decades of dissembling by South Carolina politicians who had pretended that the Confederate flag was not an emblem of hate or slavery — but a neutral symbol of “Southern pride.”

headline: Donald Trump in Triage Mode After Shocking Conservatives With Health Care Comments
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicare']
abstract: Up to now, Mr. Trump has been impervious to allegations of inconsistent policy positions.
lead_paragraph: He has broken with many Republicans on taxing the rich, threatening trade wars and keeping Planned Parenthood alive. On Friday, Donald J. Trump faced criticism for an even bolder act of conservative heresy: embracing the core tenet of the Affordable Care Act.

headline: Discipline Near in at Least 2 M.L.B. Abuse Cases
abstract: Off-season episodes involving Aroldis Chapman, Yasiel Puig and Jose Reyes have presented Major League Baseball with the first test cases of its new domestic violence policy.
lead_paragraph: BONITA SPRINGS, Fla. — Rob Manfred, the Major League Baseball commissioner, said Friday that he was close to issuing discipline in at least two of the three domestic violence cases before him. Off-season episodes involving the Yankees’ Aroldis Chapman, the Los Angeles Dodgers’ Yasiel Puig and the Colorado Rockies’ Jose Reyes have presented Manfred with the first test cases of Major League Baseball’s new domestic violence policy.

headline: After Whirlwind Arrival, Nets’ New General Manager Slowly Exhales
abstract: At a news conference at Barclays Center on Friday night, Sean Marks, the Nets’ new general manager, took time to talk about his plans for the team, among the worst in the N.B.A.
lead_paragraph: The Nets hired Sean Marks to be their new general manager less than five hours before the N.B.A. trade deadline on Thursday.

headline: And Now, Shia LaBeouf Will Spend 24 Hours in an Elevator
abstract: The actor known for box office hits and bizarre performance art chatted up visitors who waited to meet him in an elevator at Oxford University.
lead_paragraph: Shia LaBeouf, the mercurial actor known equally well for box office hits and bizarre performance art, took up a 24-hour residence on Friday in a tiny, makeshift performance space at one of the most prestigious universities in the world, where he said he would chat with any visitor willing to brave the long lines and the cramped quarters.

headline: Reporters’ Group Calls for Turkey to Release Syrian Citizen-Journalist
abstract: The Committee to Protect Journalists said the journalist, Rami Jarrah, had been detained for unclear reasons after reporting in Syria.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Committee to Protect Journalists called on the Turkish authorities on Friday to free Rami Jarrah, a prominent Syrian citizen-journalist, who it said had been detained for unclear reasons after a recent reporting trip to Syria.

headline: Single-Speed Two-Wheeler
abstract: A particularly crunchy Saturday puzzle from James Mulhern.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — When it comes to Saturday puzzle-solving, it sometimes helps to call in the cavalry, especially for those entries that are completely outside your wheelhouse.

headline: Xiao Gang, China’s Top Securities Regulator, Ousted Over Market Tumult
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Xiao Gang was chief of the China Securities Regulatory Commission. His replacement is Liu Shiyu, chairman of the Agricultural Bank of China.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s top securities regulator, Xiao Gang, has been forced out, the official Xinhua News Agency announced on Saturday, after facing stinging criticism for amplifying the country’s stock market turbulence.

headline: Hazing Allegations Investigated in Buffalo State Student’s Death
abstract: Bradley Doyley, from Brooklyn, was hospitalized amid reports that he had fallen ill while trying to join the Alpha Phi Alpha fraternity.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in western New York are investigating whether fraternity hazing played a role in the death of a 21-year-old Buffalo State College student from Brooklyn, the college said on Friday.

headline: High Octane Is a Brotherly Blend
abstract: The Chino Hills Huskies are the best high school boys’ basketball team in the country. And three of the team’s starters are brothers, with a surname that could not be more apt — Ball.
lead_paragraph: CHINO HILLS, Calif. — The best high school boys’ basketball team in the country scores at a video-game clip of 99.6 points per outing, and it does not wait around to see if opponents can keep up. During a holiday tournament in December, it beat an opponent from Milwaukee by scoring 125 points. The next night, it poured in 124 against a challenger from metro Atlanta.

headline: Millrose Games’ Glamour Is Diminished; Prestige Is Not
abstract: Athletes at the elite annual indoor track meet taking place Saturday in Manhattan may no longer be timed by tuxedo-clad men. But they are as competitive as ever.
lead_paragraph: If athletes are talented enough to land a coveted spot in the Millrose Games, the elite annual indoor track meet taking place Saturday in Manhattan, they are participating in a relic from a golden era of track and field — one when top athletes were knighted, runners were timed by tuxedo-clad men with gold timepieces and thousands of spectators cheered them on.

headline: Second Avenue Subway Could Revive the W Line, Officials Say
abstract: The W subway line, created in 2001, was discontinued in 2010 amid budget cuts at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
lead_paragraph: The W subway line from Queens to Lower Manhattan could be making a comeback.

headline: Jaroslav Halak Stops 27 Shots as Islanders Shut Out the Devils
abstract: Islanders goaltender Jaroslav Halak, who has battled injury and inconsistency, ended a skid in which he had won only one of five starts.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — The Islanders’ best goaltender for the past two weeks — if not the past two months — pulled on a blue baseball cap and plopped on a stool near a corner of the bench. Thomas Greiss had earned the night off. Jaroslav Halak would have to bail out the Islanders.

headline: Knicks’ Loss to Nets Shows They Still Need Help (It May Arrive Monday)
abstract: It may be a stretch to say that Jimmer Fredette, who will join the Knicks, is the answer. But after the loss, the Knicks are running out of options.
lead_paragraph: The Knicks were incapable of losing any games for nine days over the recent N.B.A. All-Star break. It was a blissful stretch of inactivity. Carmelo Anthony visited some of his high-profile pals in Toronto. Several teammates traveled to tropical locales, hard-earned reprieves from a season in full decline.

headline: ESPN Blesses New Lineup From Verizon
abstract: ESPN, which sued Verizon last year after being excluded from a new basic-cable package, voiced its pleasure over changes announced Friday to the channel lineup.
lead_paragraph: ESPN, which sued Verizon last year after being excluded from a new basic-cable package, voiced its pleasure over changes announced Friday to the channel lineup.

headline: When It Comes to Lowering Expectations, John Kasich Is South Carolina’s Clear Winner
abstract: Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio has practically written off South Carolina, looking toward the more moderate political climate in the Midwest and Northeast.
lead_paragraph: MOUNT PLEASANT, S.C. — Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio will not be in South Carolina when the primary results come in on Saturday night. But he has already deemed his efforts here successful.

headline: Msgr. Thomas J. Hartman, Half of ‘God Squad,’ Dies at 69
abstract: Monsignor Hartman wrote a syndicated column and appeared on radio and on a cable television show as part of an interfaith duo with Rabbi Marc Gellman beginning in 1987.
lead_paragraph: Msgr. Thomas J. Hartman, the self-styled straight man of a Catholic-Jewish duo that for a generation traded congenial religious repartee as “The God Squad” on television and radio and in a newspaper column, died on Tuesday in Uniondale, N.Y. He was 69.

headline: Dana Raphael, Proponent of Breast-Feeding and Use of Doulas, Dies at 90
abstract: Dr. Raphael, a medical anthropologist and protégée of Margaret Mead, was among the first scientists to challenge milk formula manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: Dana Raphael, an apostle of breast-feeding and a catalyst for the movement to recruit nonmedical caregivers to assist mothers during and after childbirth — attendants she called doulas — died on Feb. 2 at her home in Fairfield, Conn. She was 90.

headline: Man Captured on Film Being Arrested in a 1963 Protest Is Bernie Sanders, His Campaign Says
keywords: ['Civil Rights Movement (1954-68)', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: A film company had uploaded footage of a man who appeared to be Bernie Sanders being arrested at a protest, and on Friday his campaign confirmed it was the Vermont senator.
lead_paragraph: In recent days, Hillary Clinton’s campaign has questioned Senator Bernie Sanders’s commitment to civil rights, trying to cement her support among black voters who could be crucial in upcoming primaries such as South Carolina’s.

headline: Chelsea Clinton Pounds Pavement and Doors to Get a Few More Votes for Mom
abstract: The former first daughter, pregnant with her second child, has been campaigning nonstop for Hillary Clinton and knocked on doors in Las Vegas on Friday.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Imagine you are just home from work on a warm February evening, from your casino or construction job. You open a cold beer and plop down on the sofa. You hear a knock on the door. It is Chelsea Clinton.

headline: London Fashion Week: Shock of the New, Warmth of the Old
abstract: The shows begin with fresh faces (Faustine Steinmetz), stalwarts (Paul Smith) and some highly anticipated returns (Mulberry, Alexander McQueen).
lead_paragraph: And so on to London for the shortest of the four fashion weeks on the seasonal calendar. Weekend or not, there is a lot to see, with a flurry of new — and familiar — faces on the schedule.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: Catch up with best-picture nominees, including “Room,” before the Oscars. Or watch “Magic Mike XXL,” a movie with its own special charm.
lead_paragraph: With eight days until the Oscars, there’s still time to catch up with best-picture nominees. Start with “Room” or “Mad Max: Fury Road.” For one not on the list but with its own charm, tune in to “Magic Mike XXL.”

lead_paragraph: “Whether they teach or don’t teach, I can’t tell. But now, at least, they come to school.”

headline: Washington Pauses for Justice Antonin Scalia’s Funeral
abstract: The funeral on Saturday was one of those ritual moments when the perpetual struggle at the intersection of law and politics is briefly suspended.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With pageantry, spirituality and a touch of his own trademark humor, Justice Antonin Scalia was honored on Saturday as a capital riven by his death briefly set down its political weapons to mourn what his son called “the country’s good servant.”

headline: Fashion’s Newest Trend: Silence in the Front Row
keywords: ['New York Fashion Week', 'Celebrities', 'News and News Media', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Design']
abstract: Increasingly, the celebrities who turn up at fashion shows seem to be doing so only if they don’t have to give interviews.
lead_paragraph: It’s a tried-and-true ritual of New York Fashion Week. Designers hold shows and invite a few celebrities to sit in the front row: perhaps the star of a new hit television series or a rising ingénue or even someone who has recently won an Oscar or who may be nominated for one. Sometimes money is exchanged or clothes given or old favors called in.

headline: The Boy From Brooklyn: David Geffen Comes Home, With Cash to Spare
abstract: Five decades after leaving for Los Angeles, David Geffen is returning to New York, bringing with him all the clout $100 million can buy.
lead_paragraph: At Chookie’s Luncheonette in the 1950s, a teenage David Geffen used to hang out with his pals from New Utrecht High School in Brooklyn, drinking egg creams and gizmos, listening to Bobby Darin and Paul Anka on the jukebox.

headline: 9 Ways to Survive the Cold Stylishly
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Coats and Jackets', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: New York Fashion Week attendees offer their tips, tricks and cautionary tales.
lead_paragraph: Mother Nature bows to no one: It’s a truth that fashion week congregants rediscovered this week when New York City fluctuated between snow, slush and icebox just as the runway show calendar picked up heat. Bare legs? Strappy heels? Slinky dresses? Not for the savviest of stylistas. Below, their tips, tricks and cautionary tales to staying fashionable while freezing.

headline: After Paris Terror Attacks, France Struggles With Faith on the Job
keywords: ['Muslims and Islam', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Paris Attacks (November 2015)', 'Workplace Environment', 'Religion-State Relations', 'Terrorism']
abstract: France’s brand of secularism discourages, and sometimes bans, public religious expression, making workplaces prone to misunderstandings.
lead_paragraph: A week after the terrorist attacks in France last November, Bachir B., a passenger screener at Orly airport south of Paris, was called into his manager’s office. Bachir, a devout Muslim who wears a thick beard in keeping with his faith, was ordered to trim his facial hair. His boss even offered to buy him a beard clipper as a birthday gift.

lead_paragraph: Two plainclothes New York City police officers were shot in Brooklyn early Saturday during an exchange of fire with a gunman who had led officers on a brief car chase, officials said.

abstract: Britons will vote on June 23 on whether to stay in the European Union or to quit, a decision that could have momentous consequences for Britain and Europe.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Britons will vote on June 23 on whether to stay in the European Union or to quit, Prime Minister David Cameron said on Saturday, announcing the date of a referendum that could have momentous consequences for a divided Britain, and for the rest of Europe.

headline: Got an A in Algebra? That’s Worth $120

lead_paragraph: As the first person in her family to apply to college, Ashley Ayala-Perez was completely new to the undergraduate admissions process. Even more daunting, she had to figure out how she was going to pay for college — and navigate the scholarship bureaucracy.

headline: Chinese Securities Regulator Is Out, but Little May Change
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The dismissal of Xiao Gang is a gamble by President Xi Jinping that he can limit damage to the Communist Party from the struggling economy.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — As China’s economic woes intensified, the nation’s top securities regulator appeared to have the support of the Communist Party leadership, even when his efforts to stabilize the stock markets faltered and in some cases made matters worse. Just weeks ago, he issued a lengthy defense of his record and the securities agency aggressively denied reports he had offered to resign.

headline: Slave Labor on the High Seas
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Forced Labor', 'Seafood', 'Maritime Crime', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Law and Legislation', 'Fishing, Commercial']
abstract: The United States is taking some important new steps to clamp down on the use of indentured workers on the high seas.
lead_paragraph: Shocking revelations about the international fishing industry’s reliance on slave labor have caused many people to question the origin of the shrimp or tuna they eat. The disclosures have also led the United States to take some important new steps to clamp down on the use of indentured workers and discourage other unlawful activities on the high seas.

headline: Serbian Hostages Killed in U.S. Airstrikes Against ISIS in Libya
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: The deaths of two Serbian Embassy employees drew protests from Serbia and raised questions about the American intelligence that led to the strikes.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Two Serbian hostages died in American airstrikes on an Islamic State training camp in western Libya on Friday, Serbian leaders said on Saturday in statements that criticized a military operation that had been presented as a clean strike against extremism.

headline: Justice Antonin Scalia’s Faith and Values Inspired Many Mourners
abstract: Lines formed hours before a funeral Mass at Washington’s huge Catholic church, where mourners shared the justice’s faith and conservatism.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Lines began forming outside the Basilica of the National Shrine of the Immaculate Conception, this city’s giant Catholic monument, three hours before the funeral Mass began for Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court. On a chilly but slowly brightening morning, young and old alike dressed up to pay their last respects to a man who died unexpectedly in his sleep last weekend in a year with momentous court decisions hanging in the balance.

headline: In the Government vs. Apple, Who Wears the Black Hat?
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Search and Seizure', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Computer Security']
abstract: The dispute about a single iPhone could open a Pandora’s box of global issues over privacy rights.
lead_paragraph: THE dispute between the Justice Department and Apple over access to the phone of Syed Rizwan Farook, one of the gunmen in the San Bernardino massacre, comes down to this question: Shouldn’t the government have more legal and moral authority to weigh complicated issues of privacy and national security than a company that makes phones?

headline: Break Up the Insulin Racket
keywords: ['Insulin', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Diabetes', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Too many Americans with diabetes can’t afford their medication.
lead_paragraph: ONE of my patients — whom I will call Mrs. B — is a 78-year-old who has had Type 2 diabetes for over 30 years. She takes several injections of insulin each day. Her blood sugars have been running too high, but she doesn’t want to increase the dose of her insulin. She told me she simply can’t afford to.

headline: Gadsden Finds God
abstract: An unusual collaboration between local officials and churchgoers is transforming lives in Florida.
lead_paragraph: An unusual collaboration between local officials and churchgoers is transforming lives in Florida.

headline: Hillary Clinton Beats Bernie Sanders in Nevada Caucuses
abstract: Early organizing in the state and a last-minute push for support from casino workers, many of them black or Hispanic, were credited in Mrs. Clinton’s victory.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Buoyed by the support of minority voters and enthusiastic workers in the city’s big casinos, Hillary Clinton defeated Senator Bernie Sanders in the Nevada caucuses on Saturday, thwarting his momentum and proving to an anxious Democratic Party that she can assemble a broad coalition to carry her to the general election.

headline: Donald Trump Wins South Carolina Primary; Cruz and Rubio Vie for 2nd
abstract: Mr. Trump’s victory, his second in the first three nominating contests, puts him in a strong position heading into Southern state primaries on March 1.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Donald J. Trump rolled to a commanding victory in the South Carolina primary on Saturday, solidifying his position as the Republican presidential front-runner after a savage campaign that drove Jeb Bush, the son and brother of presidents, to quit the race.

headline: Five Years In, Millrose Games Have Found Their Footing at the Armory
abstract: The event, formerly held at Madison Square Garden, now roughly breaks even and has better television exposure than in years past.
lead_paragraph: Indoor track has been a sport in decline for years, but the death knell of its marquee meet — the Millrose Games — seemed imminent a half-decade ago.

headline: In London, One Designer’s Playful Take on the Museum
abstract: Faustine Steinmetz’s presentation at the Tate Britain this morning riffed on the traditional format of viewing art.
lead_paragraph: Faustine Steinmetz, a French designer who presented at London Fashion Week today, has never been interested in runway shows. “Fashion became a little bit too much about the front row, and who’s sitting there, and who’s modeling, and that kind of crap,” she told T earlier this week. “And I think a presentation really brings it back to ‘objets d’art.’”

headline: Jim Davenport, an Original San Francisco Giant, Dies at 82
abstract: Davenport, an infielder who started with the Giants in 1958, their first season in California, won a Gold Glove in 1962, the year the team lost to the Yankees in the World Series.
lead_paragraph: Jim Davenport, an infielder who played third base for most of his career with the San Francisco Giants and battled the Yankees in the World Series in 1962, the first time the Giants had played in one since they left New York, died on Thursday in Redwood City, Calif. He was 82.

headline: Daytona, a Track That Opened in 1959, No Longer Feels Like an Antique
keywords: ['Automobile Racing', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Daytona 500 (Auto Race)']
abstract: After a $400 million renovation, Daytona International Speedway is roaring into the 21st century with 1,400 televisions, luxury suites, Wi-Fi and interactive displays.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — Jeff Gordon had no frame of reference. As he stood along one of the concourses at the lavishly renovated Daytona International Speedway, he chuckled at the realization that “in my 23 years of coming here, this is the first time I’ve actually seen this speedway from this side of the fence.”

headline: Raptors Transform Without Trades
abstract: Toronto was inactive at the deadline, but General Manager Masai Ujiri’s off-season moves and Kyle Lowry’s improvement have put the team in a better position.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest stories of the N.B.A.’s trade deadline was the decision by the Toronto Raptors to stand pat. The Raptors, who will visit the Knicks on Monday, have the second-best record in the Eastern Conference and are widely seen as the team best suited to challenge the Cleveland Cavaliers for conference superiority. Although Toronto was the subject of many rumors, it made no transactions.

headline: The Female Pilots We Betrayed
keywords: ['Pilots', 'Women and Girls', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: They risked their lives in World War II. They deserve to rest at Arlington.
lead_paragraph: DURING World War II, Elaine Danforth Harmon was stationed at an Army air base in Las Vegas. Her job was to fly a two-seat aircraft with men who had been overseas and needed a refresher course in “instrument flying” — navigating by compass and altimeter, instead of by the landscape. Ms. Harmon served as a lookout “to make sure that we didn’t run into any other airplanes,” she told me.

lead_paragraph: Steven Galster, the founder and executive director of the Freeland Foundation, based in Bangkok, is known for his aggressive and inventive covert and overt operations to combat wildlife and human trafficking.

lead_paragraph: Why many millennials are attracted to Bernie Sanders and European social democracy.

headline: Gov. Walker Resumes His War on Workers
abstract: The governor has signed a “reform” plan that will gut much of the state’s historic Civil Service system.
lead_paragraph: What’s a politician to do after his ballyhooed campaign for the Republican presidential nomination flames out before the first vote is cast? In the case of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin, it means returning home to the anti-labor obsession that got him noticed in the first place — and signing into law, less than two weeks ago, a “reform” plan that promises to gut much of the state’s historic Civil Service system.

headline: Reporting Scalia’s Death, With All Deliberate Speed
abstract: In general, Times coverage of Justice Antonin Scalia’s death was impressive, but it was not without a few bumps along the way.

headline: Cruz and Rubio, Separated at Mirth

lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — TED CRUZ described Marco Rubio last week as “Donald Trump with a smile,” saying that both are quick to call their critics liars, though Rubio does it amiably.

headline: Clash of the Populists
abstract: Donald Trump and Pope Francis have much in common.
lead_paragraph: THE Book of Daniel predicted it. The Book of Revelation confirmed it. The Necronomicon spelled it out in language too terrible for human ears to hear. And if you read “The Art of the Deal” backward in the original Sanskrit, you’ll find it foretold there as well: Before the seventh seal is opened, before Famine and Pestilence are loosed, the Man in White must do battle with the Combed-Over Titan, amid the ravening shrieks of Twitter and beneath the unblinking eye of Cable News.

headline: The Ad Blocking Wars
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Online Advertising', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Wireless Communications', 'Mobile Applications']
abstract: It’s like being “caught between two parents fighting.”
lead_paragraph: YOU might have noticed that even when using a lightning-fast Internet connection, it takes a few beats, enough time to drum your fingers, for web pages to load. It’s likely because of online advertising, which bogs down your browser, drains your battery and jacks up mobile charges — not to mention collects private data.

headline: Why Sexism at the Office Makes Women Love Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Women and Girls', 'Discrimination', "Women's Rights", 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: More time in a sexist world, and particularly in the workplace, radicalizes women.
lead_paragraph: THE poll numbers and primary results so far tell a simple story: Younger Democratic women are mostly for Bernie Sanders; older women lean more toward Hillary Clinton.

headline: The Crisis of Minority Unemployment
abstract: A subsidy program that Congress let expire is just the kind of thoughtful measure needed to help combat the devastating joblessness in minority areas.
lead_paragraph: The staggering problem of chronic unemployment among minority men was starkly presented in a report from the Great Cities Institute at the University of Illinois at Chicago. It found that in Los Angeles and New York City about 30 percent of 20- to 24-year-old black men were out of work and out of school in 2014. The situation is even more extreme in Chicago, where nearly half of black men in this age group were neither working nor in school; the rate was 20 percent for Hispanic men and 10 percent for white men in the same age group.

headline: Why Do We Teach Girls That It’s Cute to Be Scared?
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Women and Girls', 'Fear (Emotion)', 'Children and Childhood', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Stop telling your daughters to be careful all the time. Let them face their fears.
lead_paragraph: I WAS one of the first women in the San Francisco Fire Department. For more than a dozen years, I worked on a busy rig in a tough neighborhood where rundown houses caught fire easily and gangs fought with machetes and .22s. I’ve pulled a bloated body from the bay, performed CPR on a baby and crawled down countless smoky hallways.

LUCIE, Fla. — On Friday, the first official workout day of his 19th season in the majors, Bartolo Colon arrived at the Mets’ training complex around 7:30 a.m. in a white Range Rover with shiny black rims. He parked in the space second from the door, next to Manager Terry Collins, where a blue-and-orange sign displayed his jersey number.

headline: Grandma-Inspired Hair at Simone Rocha
abstract: Models were given a classic blue rinse — and messy updos — backstage at the designer’s fall/winter 2016 show.
lead_paragraph: Simone Rocha, who only recently became a mother while designing her fall/winter 2016 collection, was inspired by birth — and rebirth — this season. “Imagine a young girl who is dressing in her grandmother’s clothes, stealing her chandelier earrings and reinventing her elderly hair in a disheveled way,” said the hairstylist James Pecis of the show’s twisted faux-bob constructions that felt more grungy than grannyish. “It’s classic blue-rinse hair,” he said, referring to the old dye used to tint and temper bright grays, “that’s a bit swampy.”

headline: Team Managers’ Games Take On a New Importance
abstract: In gyms across the country, managers play other managers in friendly scrimmages that have become organized events complete with rankings.
lead_paragraph: When the text message arrived at 10:15 p.m. Tuesday, Justin Talavera had to be the one to deliver the disappointing news to his team: DePaul’s flight into New York had been delayed, and that night’s game had been forfeited.

headline: Taylor Fritz, a Rising American Star, Learns That It’s an Exhausting Climb
abstract: Fritz, 18, widely seen as the future of United States men’s tennis, has been adjusting to the whirlwind that is the professional game.
lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — Taylor Fritz is quickly finding out that life as a professional tennis player can be a whirlwind.

headline: Live Projections of the Final Result in Nevada
abstract: The Upshot’s estimates of election results include the parts of a state that have not yet reported their votes.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot’s estimates of election results include the parts of a state that have not yet reported their votes.

headline: Ryan McDonagh’s Latest Bruising Gives Rangers’ Keith Yandle Another Chance to Shine
abstract: With the captain out with a bruised jaw and neck spasms, Yandle, a veteran defenseman, will very likely get more playing time.
lead_paragraph: GREENBURGH, N.Y. — For the second time in two weeks, the Rangers are plowing ahead without defenseman Ryan McDonagh, who was left with a bruised jaw and neck spasms — but no concussion — after Leo Komarov of the Toronto Maple Leafs elbowed him on Thursday.

headline: In New York, Thousands Protest Officer Liang’s Conviction
abstract: Demonstrators denounced the guilty verdict against Officer Peter Liang, who was found culpable in the shooting death of an unarmed man in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: On the vast lawn of the plaza near the courthouse in Brooklyn where Peter Liang, a former New York City police officer, was convicted in the fatal shooting of an unarmed black man just over a week ago, a crowd of several thousand people gathered on Saturday.

headline: Voting in Nevada and South Carolina
abstract: Two key contests today could answer pressing questions about the presidential campaign.
lead_paragraph: Two key contests today could answer pressing questions about the presidential campaign.

headline: For 45 Years in Prison, Louisiana Man Kept Calm and Held Fast to Hope
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Albert Woodfox, 69, who was released on Friday, said he relied on his mind to survive decades in solitary confinement: “When I began to understand who I was, I considered myself free.”
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — A hotel door, a short elevator ride, a stroll through the lobby and the urge to take a walk were all that separated Albert Woodfox from the great wide world.

headline: Caucusing in the Staten Island Room? Only in Las Vegas
abstract: The midday Nevada caucuses are as singular as they are colorful, and a world away from the more serious and high-minded ones in Iowa.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Clad in suits with earpieces, stained white kitchen garments and aprons, housekeeping skirts and pantsuits, the casino workers came to caucus as they can only in Nevada, breaking away from their jobs at midday Saturday to cast their votes not far from the craps tables.

headline: Gareth Pugh: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Mr. Pugh presents his fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Pugh presents his fall collection.

headline: Harper Lee Is Memorialized as She Lived: Quietly and Privately
abstract: Friends and family gathered in Monroeville, Ala., for a simple, private service for the publicity-shy author.
lead_paragraph: MONROEVILLE, Ala. — Friends and family from around the corner and across the country gathered here on Saturday to pay final respects to Harper Lee, the author whose Pulitzer Prize-winning novel about racial inequality in the South during the Jim Crow era inspired generations of readers.

headline: Awesome!
abstract: Patrick Berry reminds me of past good times in Beantown.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — This one made me smile for a few reasons. First, it’s a Patrick Berry puzzle, which is always awesome. Secondly, “awesome,” for better or worse, is one of my favorite words. And finally, the theme reminded me of some very good times spent in the city of Boston. You’ll see why as you solve.

headline: India to Change Its Decades-Old Reliance on Female Sterilization
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Sterilization (Reproductive)', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: For decades, India has relied on female sterilization as its primary mode of contraception, funding about four million tubal ligations every year.
lead_paragraph: MAHENDRAGARH, India — This is what family planning in India often looks like: Women in their 20s, mostly farmers’ wives, gather at dawn on the stairs of a district hospital. Hours later, a surgeon arrives. His time is short. He asks the women to sit in a row on the floor of the operating room and then, in operations lasting a few minutes apiece, uses a laparoscope to sever their fallopian tubes, ensuring they will never again bear a child.

headline: Trump Now Faces True Test; Clinton’s Win Suggests National Edge
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s victory in Nevada suggested a narrow national advantage, while Republicans moved closer to a clarifying three-way battle.
lead_paragraph: We started getting some clarity in the Republican and Democratic races Saturday night. Hillary Clinton squeaked out a win in Nevada — but did so in a way that suggests she has, despite Bernie Sanders’s strength, maintained her national advantage. Marco Rubio’s strong showing in South Carolina helped push Jeb Bush out of the race, giving Mr. Rubio a chance to unify the mainstream of the Republican Party and bring about a true three-way race.

abstract: The Upshot’s estimates of election results include the parts of a state that have not yet reported their votes.
lead_paragraph: The Upshot’s estimates of election results include the parts of a state that have not yet reported their votes.

headline: South Carolina Exit Polls
abstract: Surveys of Republican voters exiting voting locations throughout South Carolina on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Surveys of Republican voters exiting voting locations throughout South Carolina on Saturday.

headline: SiriusXM Fights to Dominate the Dashboard of the Connected Car
abstract: While other music outlets struggle, the satellite-radio network is a success story. However, the Internet-connected car will pose a challenge.
lead_paragraph: On the 36th floor of a Midtown Manhattan skyscraper, the actors Ice Cube and Kevin Hart joshed with fans inside a glass-walled radio studio one afternoon last month. They were in the broadcast headquarters of SiriusXM, and across the lobby, near Howard Stern’s dedicated wing, Brooke Shields posed for selfies with three “Sesame Street” puppets, while Senator Rand Paul — at that point, still a candidate for president — hovered with a small entourage. Overhead, a screen announced the imminent arrival of the thrash-metal band Anthrax.

headline: Fiji Declares a State of Natural Disaster After Fierce Cyclone
abstract: The storm, which had gusts up to 202 miles per hour, killed five people and left villages destroyed.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY — Government officials declared a state of natural disaster in Fiji after a cyclone tore through the archipelago on Saturday, destroying villages and leaving five dead, Prime Minister Frank Bainimarama said on Sunday.

headline: Hillary Clinton Beats Bernie Sanders in Nevada Caucuses
abstract: After defeating Bernie Sanders in Nevada, Hillary Clinton is now in a stronger position heading into South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: After defeating Bernie Sanders in Nevada, Hillary Clinton is now in a stronger position heading into South Carolina.

headline: Ruben Amaro Makes Rare Transition: Front Office to First-Base Line
abstract: Amaro, fired as the Phillies’ general manager in September, accepted a job as the Red Sox’ first-base coach rather than pursue work in TV or another front office.
lead_paragraph: FORT MYERS, Fla. — It was a question perhaps unlike any other in baseball history. At a Boston Red Sox team event last month, a pitcher asked a first-base coach how close he had come to trading for him.

headline: Yankees’ Offer Could Lead to an Accord Over Tickets
abstract: After announcing they were dumping print-at-home tickets, the Yankees said they would be willing to allow StubHub and other companies to unlock mobile tickets so that they could be resold outside the team’s ticket exchange.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees have not won a playoff game since 2012, and they spent the winter addressing this shortcoming in a very un-Boss-like manner, becoming the only team in baseball not to sign at least one free agent.

headline: After 54 Holes in California, Bubba Watson Has a Slim Lead on a Crowd
abstract: At 12-under-par 201 in the Northern Trust Open, Watson is in search of his second title in three years at Riviera Country Club.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Call it a West Coast preview of the Masters. After 54 holes, the Northern Trust Open has a leaderboard that would make the dogwoods at Augusta National stand taller.

headline: Centrowitz, With Burst on Last Lap, Retains Wanamaker Mile Title
abstract: Matthew Centrowitz set a meet record in the Wanamaker mile at the Millrose Games, recording the fourth-fastest indoor mile time ever.
lead_paragraph: The Wanamaker Mile is always the fitting finale of the Millrose Games, the country’s premier indoor track meet, and this year’s showdown between Matthew Centrowitz, the reigning champion, and Nick Willis of New Zealand did not disappoint.

headline: Jeb Bush Bows Out of Campaign, Humbled and Outmaneuvered
abstract: In the year of the unconventional outsider, Mr. Bush ran his campaign as the conventional insider. It doomed him, and on Saturday he left the race.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Jeb Bush dropped out of the presidential race on Saturday, ending a quest for the White House that started with a war chest of $100 million, a famous name and a promise of political civility but concluded with a humbling recognition: In 2016, none of it mattered.

headline: A Quick Turnaround as Drew Hunter Breaks High School Mile Mark
abstract: In the Armory Invitational Mile, the undercard at the Millrose Games, Hunter finished in 3:57.81 to set a record for the second time in two weeks.
lead_paragraph: Drew Hunter broke his national high school indoor mile record at the Millrose Games on Saturday in an event that proved to be as much a coronation ceremony as a race. With major cross-country victories and another national record for the 3,000 meters under his belt, he is now indisputably the top young distance runner in the United States and one of the fastest in history.

headline: A Win for Hillary Clinton, With Signs of Challenges Ahead
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Elections', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Youth']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton won among African-Americans and women, but lost among youth voters.
lead_paragraph: With about 80 percent of results tallied, Hillary Clinton was the projected winner of the Nevada Democratic caucus, a win the campaign, now headed to South Carolina for its Feb. 27 primary, attributed to support from African-Americans. The win was hard-fought and surprisingly close: Polls a little over a month ago gave Mrs. Clinton a more than 20-point lead over Bernie Sanders. The Clinton operation was in Nevada six months earlier than the Sanders campaign, though over the past two weeks, Mr. Sanders had flooded the state with staffers and outspent Mrs. Clinton 2 to 1 on advertising.

headline: Ted Cruz Shows Marco Rubio Speaking Obama’s Language
abstract: In “Sales Pitch,” back-to-back clips present Senator Rubio and the president saying similar things during the 2013 battle over an immigration overhaul.
lead_paragraph: First he mocked the similarities in their biographies, calling Senator Marco Rubio “the Republican Obama.” Now, in an ad called “Sales Pitch,” Senator Ted Cruz is hammering Mr. Rubio for serving up the same talking points as President Obama’s.

headline: China Labels Protesters ‘Radical Separatists,’ and They Agree
abstract: Violence in the bustling Mong Kok district was the most startling sign yet of the rise of a confrontational local movement and the unlikely goal of Hong Kong independence.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Days after Hong Kong’s worst riot in years, the Chinese government’s top official in the city said the violence was the work of “radical separatists” — the sort of label the Communist Party has applied to its opponents from Tibet to Taiwan whose real motive, it says, is to divide China.

headline: Russia Pulls Back From Cooperating With U.S. on Afghanistan
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: On an old Cold War battlefield where Russia fought a nearly decade-long war against United States-supplied fighters, Moscow has a new strategy: the cold shoulder.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For all the conflicts in the world in which Washington is at odds with Moscow, the deteriorating security situation in Afghanistan has been one area where the Obama administration’s interests and Russia’s concerns coincide.

headline: Yoweri Museveni, Uganda’s President, Wins a Widely Criticized Election
abstract: Mr. Museveni, the country’s longtime president, cruised to victory in an election marred by irregularities, violent protests and the arrest of his main opponent.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Yoweri Museveni, the longtime president of Uganda, cruised to victory on Saturday in a hotly contested election marred by irregularities, violent protests and the arrest of his principal opponent.

headline: Afghan Troops Retreat Under Pressure From Taliban
keywords: ['Defense and Military Forces', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The pullout in the southern Helmand Province is the latest blow to an area that had been teetering for months in the face of resurgent Taliban members.
lead_paragraph: LASHKAR GAH, Afghanistan — The last of the Afghan forces have pulled out of the strategic district of Musa Qala in southern Helmand Province, officials said on Saturday, months after the Taliban overran most of the district and kept them holed up in desert outposts.

headline: Core Groups Hold Steady for Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Mr. Trump was the choice of men, moderate conservatives and voters without college educations. Mrs. Clinton found support in women, older voters and blacks.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump won the South Carolina Republican primary with a strong showing among his core supporters — men, moderate conservatives, those without college degrees and older voters.

headline: In Zika Epidemic, a Warning on Climate Change
abstract: In the coming decades, global warming is likely to increase the range and speed the life cycle of the particular mosquitoes carrying viruses like Zika.
lead_paragraph: The global public health emergency involving deformed babies emerged in 2015, the hottest year in the historical record, with an outbreak in Brazil of a disease transmitted by heat-loving mosquitoes. Can that be a coincidence?

headline: Knicks End Skid With Win Over Timberwolves, Rambis’s Former Team
abstract: Kurt Rambis, the Knicks’ interim coach, who was fired as Minnesota’s coach after the 2011 season, earned a victory in his return to Target Center.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The Minnesota Timberwolves rank next to last in the N.B.A. in average attendance, but the return of their former coach Kurt Rambis, now the Knicks’ interim coach, probably had little to do with the larger-than-usual crowd of 16,663 at Target Center.

headline: The Party of Bush Yields, Warily, to a New Face: Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: After Jeb Bush’s exit, the Republican establishment is confronted with an urgent decision: Either embrace Donald J. Trump or destroy him.
lead_paragraph: In his emotional seven-minute farewell to a Republican Party that elevated his father and brother to the White House, there were two words that a choked-up Jeb Bush could not bring himself to utter: “Donald Trump.”

abstract: Donald J. Trump’s victory put him in a strong position heading toward Super Tuesday, March 1.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump’s victory put him in a strong position heading toward Super Tuesday, March 1.

lead_paragraph: South Carolina Republicans delivered a 10-point win for Donald Trump and muddled second and third place finishes for Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz, separated by less than a percentage point.

headline: Donald Trump Lent Himself $5 Million in January
abstract: Mr. Trump increased his total loans to $17.5 million and substantially quickened his spending during the month, according to campaign finance reports filed Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump lent his campaign nearly $5 million in January, increasing his total loans to $17.5 million, and he substantially quickened his spending during the month, according to campaign finance reports filed Saturday.

headline: Can Johnny Coca Save Mulberry?
abstract: After 30 months with no show, the British brand and its new creative director are about to make their big debut. The stakes are very high.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — “I have always liked a challenge,” said Johnny Coca, the new creative director of Mulberry, as he sipped a green tea last week, deep in the heart of the brand’s headquarters on Kensington Church Street here.

lead_paragraph: At least seven people in the Kalamazoo, Mich., area were killed and several were critically injured Saturday night by a gunman who the police said randomly opened fire as he drove around the city and its suburbs.

abstract: Jeb Bush is out, leaving everyone wondering who his supporters might vote for instead.

headline: South Carolina and Nevada Takeaways: Messages Get Results
abstract: Donald J. Trump blundered and blustered his way to victory in South Carolina, while Hillary Clinton won Nevada with a sharper message about equality.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump came into South Carolina with momentum after a big win in New Hampshire — and he seemed to try his best to undercut himself. He attacked George W. Bush, a popular figure in the state, for his handling of terrorism and the Iraq war. He repeatedly picked fights with the well-liked Gov. Nikki R. Haley. He held forth on national television about his friendships with Howard Stern and Michael Jackson.

headline: Kalamazoo Searches for Motive in Spree That Killed 6
abstract: The police arrested Jason B. Dalton, 45, and said they were investigating whether he had been ferrying passengers for Uber on the night of the rampage in Kalamazoo, Mich.
lead_paragraph: KALAMAZOO, Mich. — The shootings came out of nowhere, one after the other, and with no apparent connection.

lead_paragraph: Elizabeth Barrow celebrated her 100th birthday at a backyard gathering with her son and three grandchildren in the coastal Massachusetts town where she raised her family and cooked lunches in a school cafeteria.

headline: 1916: A Day of Air Battles
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The fighting on the Western front is marked by a series of French aerial successes in 1916.
lead_paragraph: The fighting on the Western front yesterday was marked by a series of brilliant French aerial successes, chief among which was the destruction of a Zeppelin, brought down in flames by an incendiary shell near Brabant-le-Roi. Five German aeroplanes were also destroyed yesterday.

headline: Models Turn Out for Natalia Vodianova’s Charity Fund Fair
abstract: The event, in its second year, was co-hosted by Karlie Kloss and staffed by the likes of Petra Nemcova, Arizona Muse and Erin O’Connor.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The fashion world often feels like a circus, but rarely to the extent it did Saturday night when the Fabulous Fund Fair, a glittering children’s charity gala hosted by the Russian supermodel Natalia Vodianova and staffed by her fellow catwalkers, rolled into the Old Billingsgate venue.

headline: Is There Any Stopping Donald Trump?
abstract: There was thought — and hope — that he’d fade. Think again.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few months and even weeks, the question among many flabbergasted Republican traditionalists and incredulous political analysts was when the forces of gravity would catch up with Donald Trump and send him tumbling to earth.

headline: Apple Still Holds the Keys to Its Cloud Service, but Reluctantly
abstract: Through encryption, the tech giant tried to remove itself from the equation when law enforcement requested access. But iCloud presents challenges.
lead_paragraph: In Silicon Valley — if not Washington — Apple is being hailed for digging in its heels on a court order requiring it to aid the Federal Bureau of Investigation in gaining access to an an iPhone used by one of the attackers in the December mass shooting in San Bernardino, Calif.

headline: Stop Asking if My 4-Year-Old Has a ‘Girlfriend’
abstract: Gender indoctrination for the pre-K set.
lead_paragraph: My father isn’t the first person to ask my son if he has a girlfriend. The question pops up frequently when we’re visiting friends of my mother’s over the holidays or talking to affable cashiers at the supermarket. It’s always asked in the same way — with genial good humor and an air of expectation, as if they already know the answer.

headline: Referendum to Let Bolivian President Seek a Fourth Term Appears Headed for Defeat
abstract: The popularity of Evo Morales, a left-wing leader whose years in office have coincided with wider prosperity, had slipped with the referendum’s approach.
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — A referendum that would allow the Bolivian president, Evo Morales, to run for a fourth term looked imperiled on Sunday, as early exit polls predicted that it would fail by a small margin and the president’s rivals declared victory.
