headline: 1941: Tokio-Moscow Treaty Reported Near
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The Soviet Union and Japan reportedly reached an agreement for a mutual trade pact in 1941.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Japan and the Soviet Union have reached an agreement in principle for a mutual trade pact, a radio report from Saigon, French Indo-China, said last night. It was learned here today that a Russo-Japanese trade and non-aggression treaty of far-reaching scope was imminent. The information came from private sources at Shanghai and was not confirmable in official circles.

headline: A Long Island Enclave Where Skeet Shooting Is Legal, to the Surprise of Village Officials
abstract: Officials in Upper Brookville, N.Y., recently discovered that its local code allows the sport, leading to a debate about whether the law should be changed.
lead_paragraph: UPPER BROOKVILLE, N.Y. — The caller said he was thinking about buying a house and wanted to know: Could he go skeet shooting in the yard?

headline: U.S. Calls for Release of Uganda’s Opposition Leader
abstract: The police arrested the most popular challenger to the president before the results of a flawed election were announced.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — The United States called for the release of Uganda’s chief opposition leader, Kizza Besigye, who has been under house arrest since Friday, before President Yoweri Museveni was declared the winner of a presidential election marred by widespread irregularities.

headline: The Young British Designer Mentored by Marc Jacobs
abstract: Amie Robertson, of A.V. Robertson, showed her first collection at London Fashion Week yesterday.
lead_paragraph: For Amie Victoria Robertson, embroidery is a question of obsessive detail. At her graduation show at Central Saint Martins in 2014, the designer showed giant dresses embellished with clusters of florals made from Swarovski crystals and pearls. “The skirts were so huge that they had to redesign the catwalk,” Robertson says, laughing. “That scarred me a bit, and after that I decided to make couture-like pieces that are more casual and wearable.”

headline: What to Cook This Week
abstract: Planning a weekend grocery run, making homemade pizza and more for the week ahead.

headline: Ticket Sellers Promise Marquee Names, but the Comics Rarely Show
abstract: In Times Square, hawkers promise a chance to go to comedy clubs to see performers like Tina Fey, whether or not any such appearance is planned.
lead_paragraph: Paige Kaden, who is new to town, stood on a frigid block in Times Square on Thursday afternoon, looking for a man named John. She was angry.

headline: Trump Targets Free Trade, and G.O.P. Follows Suit
abstract: By railing against the effects of free trade on domestic workers, Donald Trump has forced some Republicans to dial back their own views on the issue.
lead_paragraph: Any doubts that Donald J. Trump has had a huge (as he might say) influence on the Republican Party were dispelled this month when Senator Rob Portman came out against the Trans-Pacific Partnership.

headline: Review: In ‘The Woodsman,’ a Love Lost in Oz Under a Witch’s Spell
abstract: James Ortiz’s play uses puppets and actors, chorus and a lone violin to reimagine the corner of L. Frank Baum’s Oz where the Tin Man came to be.
lead_paragraph: The moment you step through the door, enchantment envelops you. Flocks of Mason jars hang suspended, glowing with amber light. Bare branches sprout from walls in the orchestra or reach scraggy arms across the ceiling, almost into the balcony. Thunder rumbles under birdsong.

headline: Liv Tyler’s Final Touches for Belstaff
abstract: The actress’s 12-piece capsule collection, inspired by Amelia Earhart, will be in stores in September.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Celebrity collaborations with luxury brands are a dime a dozen these days, and most of the time it’s a marriage of convenience where neither party knows nor particularly cares about the other.

headline: Mulberry: Fall 2016
abstract: Johnny Coca’s debuts his first collection for Mulberry.
lead_paragraph: Johnny Coca’s debuts his first collection for Mulberry.

headline: Samsung Announces Gear 360, a New Virtual Reality Camera
abstract: The camera will go on sale later this year. The company also announced two new smartphones, the Galaxy S7 and the Galaxy S7 Edge.
lead_paragraph: With competition continuing to heat up in the handset market, Samsung Electronics is relying heavily on virtual reality to help distinguish its smartphones.

headline: After South Carolina, Cruz and Rubio Vie to Become Top Rival to Trump
abstract: Senators Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz urged the rest of the party to coalesce around their campaigns as Mr. Trump gained even more momentum.
lead_paragraph: Mainstream Republicans grappled on Sunday with Donald J. Trump’s sweeping victory in South Carolina as if cycling through stages of grief, with some refusing to accept that he could be the party’s eventual nominee and others searching for ways to prevent his insurgent candidacy from becoming unstoppable.

headline: Belstaff: Fall 2016
abstract: Delphine Ninous’s latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Delphine Ninous’s latest collection.

headline: No, the Polling Doesn’t Prove Bernie Sanders Won the Hispanic Vote in Nevada
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The entrance-exit polling favoring Mr. Sanders had a small sample of precincts and voters and was not devised to make a precise estimate.
lead_paragraph: One of Saturday’s biggest election surprises was the entrance and exit polling measuring Hispanic voters in the Nevada caucus. It found that Bernie Sanders defeated Hillary Clinton by eight percentage points among Hispanic voters, overturning months of conventional wisdom about Mrs. Clinton’s strength among nonwhites.

headline: Ted Cruz and Donald Trump Head Toward Super Tuesday With G.O.P.’s Deepest Pockets
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Campaign Finance', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: The two insurgent candidates appear to be in the best position financially to compete in an expensive stage of the campaign: the day when twelve states vote at once.
lead_paragraph: A seven-month, $220 million surge of spending on behalf of mainstream Republican candidates has yielded a primary battle dominated by Donald J. Trump and Senator Ted Cruz of Texas, two candidates reviled by most of the party’s leading donors.

headline: What to Watch Sunday
abstract: “Girls” kicks off its fifth season with a wedding. And dast members of “Cheers,” “Friends” and “Taxi” celebrate the director James Burrows.
lead_paragraph: Are our “Girls” about to become women? Check out the Season 5 premiere. Cast members of “Cheers,” “Friends,” “Frasier” and “Taxi” pay tribute to the director James Burrows. And step into the ring with Sylvester Stallone and Michael B. Jordan in “Creed.”

headline: Huishan Zhang: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Mr. Zhang presents his fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Zhang presents his fall collection.

headline: Welsh Town Leads a British Revolt Against the Tax System and Corporations
abstract: Crickhowell, population 2,063, has become famous for being one of Britain’s last holdouts against the encroachment of big retail chains.
lead_paragraph: CRICKHOWELL, Wales — Fifty small businesses line the cobbled streets of Crickhowell. There is a bookstore and a bakery, a salmon smokery and a pub.

headline: Paul Smith: Fall 2016
abstract: Mr. Smith, who recently collapsed his diffusion lines, presents his latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Smith, who recently collapsed his diffusion lines, presents his latest collection.

headline: American Sleep Patterns Vary by Age, Race and Place, Study Finds
abstract: About 65 percent of Americans get at least seven hours of sleep each night, the threshold that a new survey’s authors used to define a healthy rest.
lead_paragraph: One out of three Americans do not get enough sleep, according to a new study from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, which found that sleep schedules varied by race, age and geography.

headline: Tim Etchells Wins Award in Honor of Spalding Gray
abstract: Mr. Etchells is the artistic director of Forced Entertainment, a British theater troupe.
lead_paragraph: This year’s Spalding Gray Award, named for the prolific monologuist who died in 2004, has been awarded to Tim Etchells, the British interdisciplinary artist and artistic director of the theater troupe Forced Entertainment.

headline: Kerry Says U.S. and Russia Near Syria Truce Deal as 100 Die in Attacks
abstract: The secretary of state said the “cessation of hostilities” would go into effect in days, but did not give a specific deadline.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Secretary of State John Kerry announced on Sunday an agreement with Russia for an imminent, if “provisional,” partial truce in Syria, saying it largely awaited a conversation between President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin to work out final details.

headline: Review: In ‘Evicted,’ Home Is an Elusive Goal for America’s Poor
abstract: The book follows the lives of eight families in Milwaukee, some black and some white, all several leagues below the poverty line.
lead_paragraph: One of the most heartbreaking moments in Matthew Desmond’s “Evicted: Poverty and Profit in the American City”— and there’s a shameful assortment to choose from — is when 13-year-old Ruby Hinkston takes refuge in the public library. She’s come to use the computer. It turns out that she’s been slowly building her dream house with a free online game, and she wants to visit it again.

headline: Donald Trump Struggles to Explain Comments on Persian Gulf War From 2002
abstract: Mr. Trump, appearing on “Meet the Press” on Sunday, said he couldn’t explain comments from an interview with Howard Stern in which he said he wished the war in 1991 had been “done correctly.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday that he wasn’t precisely sure what he meant in 2002 when he told the radio host Howard Stern that he wished the Persian Gulf war in 1991 had been “done correctly.”

headline: Temperley London: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Alice Temperley presents her latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Alice Temperley presents her latest collection.

headline: Celebrating the Many Changes of David Bowie, the Thin White Duke
abstract: Mr. Bowie’s music was performed all weekend by the Loser’s Lounge at Joe’s Pub in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Bowie’s music was performed all weekend by the Loser’s Lounge at Joe’s Pub in the East Village.

headline: Alexander McQueen: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Sarah Burton presents her fall collection.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Burton presents her fall collection.

headline: Caution Rebuffed, Unicorns and Other Start-Ups Fixate on Rainbows
abstract: As stocks gyrate and venture capital pulls back, many Silicon Valley start-ups of every size remain upbeat, at least about their own prospects.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Technology stocks are gyrating. Valuations for once-vaunted private companies have been slashed and some start-ups have shut down. Even Apple’s chief executive, Timothy D. Cook, recently said he was “seeing extreme conditions unlike anything we have ever experienced.”

headline: ‘Deadpool’ Holds Top Spot at Box Office
abstract: ‘Deadpool’ continued its historic run in its second week. “Kung Fu Panda 3” ranked second.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES – Three new niche films generated O.K. audience interest over the weekend, as “Deadpool” remained the mainstream movie of the moment.

headline: Yale Banishes Demons. Next Are Tigers and Lions.
abstract: The Bulldogs beat Penn on Saturday at the Palestra, the site of some tough losses, and with a lead on Princeton and Columbia, they remain in position to end a 53-season N.C.A.A. tournament drought.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Yale may always be, as its fictional alumnus C. Montgomery Burns once put it on “The Simpsons,” first in gentlemanly club life, but in Ivy League men’s basketball, it has not finished alone in first since 1962.

headline: London Mayor Joins Chorus Demanding Exit From E.U.
keywords: ['Referendums', 'International Trade and World Market', 'International Relations', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The announcement by Mayor Boris Johnson, one of the Conservative Party’s most popular figures, is a new challenge for Prime Minister David Cameron.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister David Cameron faced another jarring reminder of the country’s deep divisions over whether Britain should stay in the European Union on Sunday when Mayor Boris Johnson of London, a fellow Conservative and one of the party’s most popular figures, announced that he would join the forces campaigning to exit the bloc.

headline: Yoenis Cespedes Appears Early; the Mets Appear Pleased
abstract: Cespedes arrived at the Mets’ complex three days before position players were required to report, leading Manager Terry Collins to say, “That’s the sign of a real pro.”
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — The position players were not required to report to spring training for another three days, so the Mets’ complex was relatively quiet Sunday when Yoenis Cespedes made his entrance with his new wheels: a custom pickup that looked ready for a monster truck rally.

headline: Denny Hamlin Wins Daytona 500 With Late Surge
abstract: In the 58th running of the race, Hamlin won by its closest margin ever — barely the nose of his car — and became the first driver to win in a Toyota.
lead_paragraph: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. — With a margin of victory that was both historic and microscopic, Denny Hamlin claimed the 58th running of the Daytona 500 by barely the nose of his racecar.

headline: Rebellious Youth-Inspired Beauty at Topshop Unique
abstract: Models sported varied hairstyles, clubby eye makeup and individual attitudes.
lead_paragraph: “We’ve been thinking about the mishmash of styles and sounds floating around Soho in the late 1980s. There was still a hangover from punk, but the New Romantic thing was happening and people were starting to go to raves,” said Topshop Unique’s creative director Kate Phelan backstage at today’s show. The label’s fall/winter 2016 collection explored, once again, British youth culture. “This is not an army of replica girls,” Phelan added. “It’s about having your own individual attitude.”

headline: The Letters From Harper Lee to Berkeley Breathed
abstract: The letters written to the cartoonist Berkeley Breathed from Harper Lee, with notes.
lead_paragraph: The letters written to the cartoonist Berkeley Breathed from Harper Lee, with notes.

headline: Truce Unravels as Fighting Picks Up in Ukraine
abstract: A resumption of hostilities suggests that Russia, which supports the rebels, is willing to sustain the conflict there as well as in Syria.
lead_paragraph: MARYINKA, Ukraine — Though overshadowed by the war in Syria, fighting in eastern Ukraine has picked up sharply in recent weeks, residents along the front line, commanders and European monitors say.

headline: The European Dream: A Requiem
abstract: The continent’s dream was built on the partnership of France and Germany, now drifting dangerously apart.
lead_paragraph: Paris — Jihadist attacks, a migrant flood, Greek debt, surging nationalism: Across the European Union, anxiety and division are brewing in a way not seen since the 1940s.

headline: Election of a Female President Opens a New Era for a Former Boys Club
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Organizations, Societies and Clubs', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Susan Morrison, the articles editor at The New Yorker, is the first woman to lead the Century Association, New York City’s pre-eminent private club of arts and letters, in its 169-year history.
lead_paragraph: One evening last month, after the traditional cocktails and black-tie meal, the members of the Century Association gathered in the reading room of their Renaissance-style clubhouse on West 43rd Street and, with little fanfare, made a bit of literary history.

headline: When Harper Lee, of ‘Mockingbird,’ Corresponded With Opus the Penguin’s Creator
keywords: ['Letters', 'Books and Literature', 'Cartoons and Cartoonists', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: In letters between the author of “To Kill a Mockingbird” and the man behind the comic strip “Bloom County,” a mutual admiration was expressed.
lead_paragraph: Generations of admiring readers knew Harper Lee as the reclusive author of the classic novel “To Kill a Mockingbird.” But a relative few were given a glimpse of another side of Ms. Lee: that of a witty, impish and loyal pen pal.

headline: 5G Is a New Frontier for Mobile Carriers and Tech Companies
abstract: Fed by users’ appetite for watching videos, the world’s largest carriers are rushing to offer ultrafast wireless technology first. Some of their efforts will be on display this week at the Mobile World Congress.
lead_paragraph: GUILDFORD, England — On the outskirts of this sleepy commuter town just south of London, plans are underway to build the fastest cellphone network in the world.

headline: When Peacekeepers Come Home
keywords: ['Third World and Developing Countries', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Struggling poor countries rent troops to the U.N. who can return as an influence on politics.
lead_paragraph: Over decades, several truths have emerged about United Nations peacekeeping forces. They can do immense good by separating combatants and pacifying civilian areas. They are, on occasion, guilty of sexual violence and financial corruption in the societies they have been sent to help. And increasingly, the troops are drawn from less wealthy countries, rather than the rich nations that finance the operations.

headline: Art in San Bernardino
abstract: Images documented by a poet and a photographer in the California city.
lead_paragraph: Images documented by a poet and a photographer in the California city.

headline: Young Voters, Motivated Again
abstract: So far, voters age 18 to 29 in both parties are turning out in numbers that rival 2008, contributing to some interesting results.
lead_paragraph: In one of the more pleasant surprises of this presidential campaign, young Americans are voting in big numbers, contributing to some unexpected results so far.

headline: A Bruised San Bernardino Shows Cultural Stirrings
abstract: A poet and a photographer, both professors, are helping to lead efforts to reinvigorate and redefine the city through the arts.
lead_paragraph: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif. — When Juan Delgado, a poet and professor here, thinks about his beloved and beleaguered city, he often turns to the image of a dandelion, the much-maligned flower known for its deep roots and its ability to thrive under adverse circumstances. “The dandelion is not easily uprooted,” he observes. “Its beauty is persistence.”

headline: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Feb. 22
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes Monday’s regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

headline: Quick but Efficient
abstract: Ed Sessa starts off our solving week. Bring your own Clorox wipes.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — The vast majority of crossword puzzles are not washable, but it would be nice if this one by Ed Sessa could at least be wiped down. It’s literally dripping with DIRTY stuff.

headline: Refugee Influx in Germany Sets Off a Brooding Cultural Debate
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Berlin International Film Festival', 'Theater', 'Movies', 'Asylum, Right of', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Documentary Films and Programs']
abstract: From the Berlin film festival to theater stages to journals, cultural commentators are debating the nation’s identity as the country struggles with a migrant crisis.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The 66th annual Berlin International Film Festival wrapped up over the weekend. But perhaps more gripping than any drama onscreen is the one playing out in Germany itself, where the arrival of more than one million asylum-seekers in the past year — 80,000 of them in Berlin — has been challenging the country’s ideas about itself.

headline: Spinning Tunes in Ghana, With the World on His Mind
abstract: D.J. Katapila is known for his stamina and his sometimes madcap efforts at making and playing dance music.
lead_paragraph: Marathon D.J. sets are a staple of electronic music culture. From Berlin clubs to Bushwick loft parties, headlining D.J.s sometimes spend three, six or even eight hours behind the decks. But these feats of song-selecting endurance pale compared with the typical weekly schedule of D.J. Katapila, a musician in Accra, the capital of Ghana, in West Africa.

headline: Reporting on Life, Death and Corruption in Southeast Asia
keywords: ['Corruption (Institutional)', 'Defense and Military Forces', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat"]
abstract: Thomas Fuller, a New York Times correspondent who is leaving the region after a decade, says one theme there keeps recurring: impunity.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — The protesters built what looked like medieval ramparts topped with sharpened wooden stakes in the heart of Bangkok. The military was preparing to sweep them out.

headline: Review: ‘Suspects,’ Britain’s Unscripted Relative of ‘Law & Order’
abstract: Crime fans who like a certain prosaic quality in their police work and who disdain any knowledge of the cops’ personal lives will eat it up.
lead_paragraph: When “Suspects” had its premiere in Britain in 2014, it was called innovative and revolutionary. If you were a detective, you might have asked: Hasn’t anyone seen the American or British versions of “Law & Order,” let alone classic British series like “The Bill” or “Taggart”?

headline: A Lingerie Brand Offers Real Women as (Role) Models
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Lingerie and Underwear', 'Eating Disorders', 'Beauty (Concept)', 'Models (Professional)', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: To promote positive body image, Aerie features models of various shapes in its ads and is working with the National Eating Disorders Association.
lead_paragraph: Attempts to move away from airbrushing in advertising have ebbed and flowed over the last decade, but at a time when even Barbie now comes in petite, tall and curvy, more retailers are turning to authentic-looking women to market their products.

headline: Muted Response to Bernie Sanders at South Carolina Church
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: The difficulty of Bernie Sanders’s task of gaining support from African-American voters in South Carolina became apparent during a stop on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: WEST COLUMBIA, S.C. — The problem began as soon as Bernie Sanders walked into the dining room of the revered, and predominantly black, Brookland Baptist Church. Instead of flocking to him, as people do at his large college rallies, many of church’s 780 members looked up for a moment, then quietly went back to eating their Sunday feast — unmoved as Mr. Sanders, the Democratic senator from Vermont, tried to work the room.

headline: Review: ‘Madama Butterfly’ Showcases Ana María Martínez
abstract: In this Puccini work at the Metropolitan Opera, Ms. Martínez, a soprano, performed a bit of theatrical magic.
lead_paragraph: Half an hour of intermission separates the first and second acts of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly” at the Metropolitan Opera. But in the libretto that gap covers three years of suffering for the title character, a betrayed young geisha waiting in vain for the return of her American husband.

headline: Oscars Pin Hopes on Chris Rock for Ratings
keywords: ['Ratings (Audience Measurement)', 'Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'Television', 'Minorities', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Returning after 11 years, Mr. Rock inherits a ceremony in crisis as the academy grapples with slipping viewership and problems with diversity.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The last time Chris Rock hosted the Oscars, he was judged by many to be a bust.

headline: Bernie Sanders Hits a Roadblock
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Voting and Voters', 'Youth', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: Despite doing well with a number of voter groups, so far Sanders has not brought about nearly enough of the political upheaval he is counting on.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders’s loss in the Nevada caucuses, 47 percent to 53 percent, reveals a very real weakness of his insurgent challenge to Hillary Clinton.

headline: After Bush v. Gore
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2000', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting and Voters', 'Frauds and Swindling']
abstract: The dramatic controversy surrounding the 2000 presidential election led to sweeping voting reforms, but opened the door to a new set of problems that continue to impact elections today.
lead_paragraph: The dramatic controversy surrounding the 2000 presidential election led to sweeping voting reforms, but opened the door to a new set of problems that continue to impact elections today.

headline: 16 Years After Bush v. Gore, Still Wrestling With Ballot-Box Rules
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Voting Rights Act (1965)', 'Presidential Election of 2000', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The controversy surrounding the 2000 presidential vote led to sweeping voting reforms, but opened the door to a new set of problems still felt today.
lead_paragraph: Reflecting on baseball attendance, the philosopher Yogi Berra observed that “if people don’t want to come to the ballpark, how are you going to stop them?” He could have said much the same thing about the American electorate. If voters don’t want to go to the polls, what is going to stop them, too? Often enough, nothing has.

headline: Review: Limón Dance Company Reconstructs Its Founder’s ‘Dialogues’
abstract: Working from a silent film remnant, the troupe resurrected this 1951 work, a meditation on Mexico’s violent colonial history.
lead_paragraph: In the golden age of modern dance, works were choreographed and performed and either kept alive through performance or not performed and thus most likely forgotten. In rare cases, a work might have been filmed, leaving a record for posterity. Recently, when Carla Maxwell, artistic director of the Limón Dance Company, was made aware of a film of “Dialogues,” a lost work that José Limón created in 1951, she set out to bring the piece back to life.

headline: Chats That Led to ‘Becoming Mike Nichols’ on HBO
abstract: The stage director Jack O’Brien reflects on his friendship with Mr. Nichols and the interviews for this documentary, which runs Monday on HBO.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, the stage director Jack O’Brien had a long, late lunch with Mike Nichols. He returned home, “exhilarated and sort of drained and exhausted and stimulated,” he said. “There was nothing like talking to Mike.”

headline: Review: George London Foundation Singing Competition Offers Arias to Please a Crowd
abstract: The George London Foundation Awards Competition for young American and Canadian opera singers held the final round of its 45th annual contest on Friday.
lead_paragraph: However you may feel about classical music competitions (and there are reasons to love some and loathe others), it is hard not to become caught up in the final judgments, to see how audience favorites and your own have fared in the judges’ eyes and ears. In the case of the George London Foundation Awards Competition for young American and Canadian opera singers (one of the more lovable affairs), which held the final round of its 45th annual contest on Friday, at the Morgan Library & Museum, the odds were good that at least some of the choices would please everyone.

headline: Like the Last President to Visit Cuba, Obama Seeks a Change
abstract: President Obama will become the first sitting American president to visit Cuba since Calvin Coolidge, who went there in 1928 to show good will and signal a new beginning in relations.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Imagine an American president in his final year in office, making a historic and carefully choreographed trip to Cuba to extend a hand of friendship to an island neighbor after decades of hostility and mistrust.

headline: Bubba Watson Outplays Strong Field at Northern Trust Open
abstract: Led by Watson, who shot a 72-hole total of 15-under 269, the deepest field of 2016 as determined by the Official World Golf Rankings could not challenge the tournament record of 20 under.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Northern Trust Open trophy belonged to Bubba Watson, but for the 31st year, Riviera Country Club came out on top. Led by Watson, the deepest field of 2016, as determined by the Official World Golf Rankings, could not challenge the tournament record, 20 under par.

headline: U.S. Scrambles to Contain Growing ISIS Threat in Libya
abstract: As U.S. intelligence agencies say the number of Islamic State fighters in Iraq and Syria has dropped, the group’s ranks in Libya have roughly doubled.
lead_paragraph: THIES, Senegal — The Islamic State’s branch in Libya is deepening its reach across a wide area of Africa, attracting new recruits from countries like Senegal that had been largely immune to the jihadist propaganda — and forcing the African authorities and their Western allies to increase efforts to combat the fast-moving threat.

headline: Newly Elected Central African Republic Leader Faces Hard Realities
abstract: Faustin Archange Touadéra, a former prime minister, was declared the winner of the presidential election in the Central African Republic, which emerged from a civil war with a devastated economy.
lead_paragraph: BANGUI, Central African Republic — A former prime minister, Faustin Archange Touadéra, has won election as president of the Central African Republic, according to preliminary results, setting the stage for the first elected government in three years for a poverty-stricken country that is just emerging from a devastating civil war.

headline: Allergan Earnings, the Mobile World Congress and Durable Goods Data
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Durable Goods (Economic Indicator)', 'Company Reports', 'Mobile World Congress (Trade Show)', 'Private Equity', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: This week Allergan will report earnings, telecommunications insiders will gather for a conference in Barcelona and the Commerce Department will release durable goods figures.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what to look for this week.

headline: Maple Syrup Makers in New York Savor Aftertaste of a Mild Winter
abstract: Weather conditions in northern New York have been favorable for the production of maple syrup, and the industry may be in for a record-setting season.
lead_paragraph: SALEM, N.Y. — Snowmobile sales have sputtered, ski resorts are struggling and some bait shops, which rely heavily on ice fishing, can barely afford to keep their lights on.

headline: College Student Missing After Plane Lands in a Long Island Harbor
abstract: After a single-engine plane made a forced landing in Setauket Harbor, the police searched for a 23-year-old City College student. The three other passengers were rescued.
lead_paragraph: SETAUKET, N.Y. — The police searched on Sunday for a 23-year-old City College student from Queens who was aboard a small plane that made a forced landing in the frigid waters of Setauket Harbor off the North Shore of Long Island after its engine malfunctioned, the authorities said.

headline: When a State Balks at a City’s Minimum Wage
abstract: In a particularly ferocious version of a divide playing out nationally, state lawmakers and city leaders are fighting over who should have the authority to set wage policy.
lead_paragraph: BIRMINGHAM, Ala. — Veronica Roscoe, who earns $7.75 an hour working at a Burger King here, thought last August that she had won: This city had become the first in the South to approve a local minimum wage.

headline: Stanley Druckenmiller, a Billionaire Financier, Backs John Kasich
abstract: Stanley F. Druckenmiller’s support, Gov. John Kasich’s campaign said, is a sign of his viability in the Republican field, despite his fifth-place finish in the South Carolina primary on Saturday and the challenging path that lies ahead of him.
lead_paragraph: The billionaire financier Stanley F. Druckenmiller has signed on to support Gov. John Kasich presidential bid, the Kasich campaign said on Sunday.

headline: Clinton Campaign Rebuffs Sanders on Latino Vote in Nevada
abstract: Hillary Clinton’s campaign had one of its polling firms that specializes in the Latino vote assess the Nevada caucus results in an effort to rebut the claim by Senator Bernie Sanders that, though he lost overall, he won among Hispanics, a demographic that is crucial to the success of both candidates.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Hillary Clinton’s campaign had one of its polling firms that specializes in the Latino vote assess the Nevada caucus results in an effort to rebut the claim by Senator Bernie Sanders that, though he lost over all, he won among Hispanics, a demographic that is crucial to the success of both candidates.

headline: Wellness App Aims to Improve Workplace Nutrition
abstract: Zipongo, a small tech start-up, has connected with 125 companies to help steer employees toward healthier eating.
lead_paragraph: A growing number of companies are offering their employees digital tools to help improve their eating habits in hopes of increasing productivity, reducing sick days and cutting health care costs.

headline: Olympic Duties Leave UConn’s Geno Auriemma Right at Home
abstract: The Connecticut head coach led a training camp on campus for the U.S.A. Basketball women’s national team amid his team’s N.C.A.A. title chase.
lead_paragraph: STORRS, Conn. — Geno Auriemma spent a couple of hours at the University of Connecticut’s practice center on Sunday overseeing drills, teaching halfcourt sets, encouraging players and pointing out mistakes. He was in his element. At one point during a scrimmage, he noticed a defensive error.

headline: Supreme Court Fight Is New Front in Partisan Warfare
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: The dysfunction that has undermined relations between the executive and legislative branches in the Obama era now threatens to engulf the remaining branch.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The prospect of the Supreme Court’s sitting for a year or even longer at less than full strength means the partisan warfare that has overtaken Washington could produce a whole new kind of government shutdown — one limiting the court’s ability to fully function.

headline: Iran’s Thwarted Reformers Set Careful Goals for Coming Vote
abstract: The agenda of the reformers, once a sweeping manifesto for change in the Islamic republic, has been reduced to simply calling for a high turnout in Friday’s balloting.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — They clapped and cheered, and many shouted for the release of their political leaders under house arrest for the past five years. Some held up pictures of a popular former president, Mohammad Khatami. Pictures of his hands, to be exact, because displaying his portrait is illegal.

headline: A Rising Call to Promote STEM Education and Cut Liberal Arts Funding
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'States (US)', 'Science and Technology', 'Humanities', 'Labor and Jobs', 'State Legislatures', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: At least 15 states offer public education funding incentives for certain high-demand degrees — and humanities majors are not among them.
lead_paragraph: When the Kentucky governor, Matt Bevin, suggested last month that students majoring in French literature should not receive state funding for their college education, he joined a growing number of elected officials who want to nudge students away from the humanities and toward more job-friendly subjects like electrical engineering.

headline: Teaching Bronx Students the Language of Computers
abstract: A growing movement in the borough seeks to equip young people with the knowledge and the skills to write code so that they can navigate an increasingly digital world.
lead_paragraph: The website allows users to post videos of police abuses, track them on an interactive map and even play a game in which the goal is to avoid gunfire from police officers.

headline: What 5G Will Mean for You
keywords: ['5G (Wireless Communications)', 'Smartphones', 'Mobile World Congress (Trade Show)', 'Driverless and Semiautonomous Vehicles', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Wearable Computing']
abstract: Companies say that fifth-generation wireless technology will usher in ultrafast mobile broadband, almost universal connectivity and fast response times.
lead_paragraph: You may soon start hearing a lot about 5G, or the fifth generation of wireless technology. This technology is expected to leap ahead of current wireless technology, known as 4G, by offering mobile Internet speeds that will let people download entire movies within seconds, and it may pave the way for new types of mobile applications.

headline: No Corrections: February 22, 2016
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, February 22, 2016.
lead_paragraph: No corrections appeared in print.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 22, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “ISIS is spreading even to here. If we do not have a multinational effort, ISIS will spread even more.”

headline: Wild Muster a Show of Strength in Their Long-Awaited Outdoor Game
abstract: The reviving Wild routed the defending Stanley Cup champion Blackhawks in an audition for a future N.H.L. Winter Classic.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Not that he was anxious or anything, but the Minnesota Wild owner Craig Leipold said he had started monitoring the weather about a month ago for his team’s Stadium Series outdoor game with the Chicago Blackhawks. A week before the game, he started checking the forecast twice a day.

headline: Yankees Hope New Workout Area Puts Them on Upward Trajectory
abstract: Steinbrenner Field’s 10-foot-tall mound with a 30-yard incline that players sprint up is “just another tool in the toolbox,” said Matt Krause, the team’s strength and conditioning coach.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — When pitcher James Kaprielian rolled up to Steinbrenner Field several weeks ago, he had to blink, rub his eyes and do a double take. As he glanced toward left field, there was an incongruous sight on one of the practice diamonds, something he had never seen on a baseball field — an enormous grass mound, 10 feet tall with a 30-yard incline.

headline: As a Species, the Knuckleball Flutters but Survives
abstract: The pitch that can extend a pitcher’s career is usually used by a handful of major league pitchers. But there are coaches and former knuckleballers who believe in it and work to get promising prospects to trust it.
lead_paragraph: PORT CHARLOTTE, Fla. — Phil Niekro was a 21-year-old pitcher in Class A when his manager, Red Murff, gave him a compliment that propelled him to the Hall of Fame. If Niekro could control his knuckleball just a little better, Murff said, he would pitch in the big leagues.

headline: Jimmer Fredette, a Basketball Prodigy, Now Plays Catch-Up
abstract: Fredette, a star in college and most recently in the N.B.A. Development League, is expected to join the Knicks in a bid to revive his career.
lead_paragraph: WHITE PLAINS — A high-profile spectator found a spot along the baseline Sunday afternoon to watch Jimmer Fredette play his final game (for now, at least) with the Westchester Knicks of the N.B.A. Development League.

headline: Delegate Count Leaving Bernie Sanders With Steep Climb
abstract: The delegate count in the Democratic primary shows Mr. Sanders slipping behind Hillary Clinton in the race for the nomination, and the odds of his overtaking her are growing increasingly remote.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders vowed on Sunday to fight on after losing the Nevada caucuses, predicting that he would pull off a historic political upset by this summer’s party convention.

headline: Review: In ‘The Good Girl,’ a Sexbot Gets Weepy
abstract: In the postapocalyptic dystopia of Emilie Collyer’s feminist sci-fi comedy, which darkens considerably as it goes along, intimacy is constrained.
lead_paragraph: Programmed to please, the sexbot has lately developed a peculiar tic: a postcoital tendency toward tears.

headline: In a Black Church in South Carolina, Bernie Sanders Struggles to Get an ‘Amen’
abstract: Bernie Sanders’s challenge in strengthening his support beyond his largely white base was in stark relief as he campaigned before the state’s primary on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: WEST COLUMBIA, S.C. — The problem began as soon as Bernie Sanders walked into the dining room of the revered and predominantly black Brookland Baptist Church here. Instead of flocking to him, as supporters do at his large college rallies, many of the church’s 780 members present looked up for a moment, then quietly went back to eating their Sunday feast — unmoved as Mr. Sanders, the senator from Vermont, tried to work the room.

headline: Poll Watch: Donald Trump’s Curiously Strong Support Among Evangelicals
keywords: ['Evangelical Movement', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Donald Trump’s victory in South Carolina was driven in part by his surprising embrace by evangelical voters.
lead_paragraph: So far, evangelical voters in three states have weighed in on their preference in the race for the Republican presidential nomination. In both Iowa and New Hampshire, evangelical voters were less likely than non-evangelical voters to support Donald Trump — by 7 and 11 points, respectively.

headline: Governors Devise Bipartisan Effort to Reduce Opioid Abuse
abstract: Concern about the abuse of addictive pain medications dominated sessions of the National Governors Association and a proposal to place numerical limits on prescriptions is in the works.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Alarmed at an epidemic of drug overdose deaths, the National Governors Association decided over the weekend to devise treatment protocols to reduce the use of opioid painkillers.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1, Episode 2: Mugged by God
abstract: Richie has seen “Enter the Dragon” one too many times.
lead_paragraph: The record company president Richie Finestra has been transforming his rage into self-loathing, but beating a man to death (in last week’s pilot) marked a turning point: He’s directing his anger outward, and everything he encounters is in danger, whether that’s an employee who gets fired for talking back or a Jethro Tull LP that gets snapped in half for being insufficiently rocking.

headline: Review: ‘Nice Fish,’ Mark Rylance and Louis Jenkins’s Quirky Ice Fishing Tale
abstract: Drawing on Mr. Jenkins’s prose poems, this play at St. Ann’s Warehouse alludes to larger meanings beneath its homely surface.
lead_paragraph: For a certain slice of New Yorkers — you know who you are — Mark Rylance is the cultural deity that Beyoncé is to, well, a different slice of New Yorkers. At a recent performance of “Nice Fish,” a quirky charmer of a play written by Mr. Rylance and Louis Jenkins, the audience greeted every stuttered utterance of Mr. Rylance’s with delighted laughter and murmurs of pleasure, as if sampling the world’s most ravishing tasting menu.

headline: Escape From Bushworld
abstract: A family of privilege can stop pretending that they’re just folks.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The Bushes always bristled at the “d” word. And now they don’t have to worry about it anymore.

headline: ‘The Walking Dead’ Season 6, Episode 10: Rick Finds Love, Jesus
abstract: Things calmed down in a rebuilding Alexandria but heated up in other ways.
lead_paragraph: That noise you heard Sunday night was the sound of “Walking Dead” nation rejoicing — or the romantically obsessed quadrant, at least. For that was when “Richonne” moved from fan fiction sites and Tumblrs into the actual world of the show, as Rick and Michonne’s friendly joshing about hard days and dental health finally escalated into considerably more. (Cough called it cough… )

headline: Senators Returning to Square Off Head to Head Over Replacing Scalia
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Congress will reconvene on Monday for what is expected to be a protracted fight over any Supreme Court nominee offered by President Obama.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Members of Congress will return to work on Monday, convening for the first time since the death of Justice Antonin Scalia  in what is expected to be a protracted fight over any nominee offered by President Obama to replace the justice on the Supreme Court.

headline: ‘Downton Abbey’ Season 6, Episode 8: Lady Mary, That Skinny You-Know-What
abstract: Among tonight’s highlights are Mary’s impending nuptials, Edith’s thwarted romance, and a Mary-Edith showdown.
lead_paragraph: This recap contains spoilers for Sunday’s episode of “Downton Abbey.”

headline: Copa América Draw Hands U.S. a Tough Task
abstract: The United States’ coach, Jurgen Klinsmann, acknowledged that his team faced difficult matchups.
lead_paragraph: Someday there will be a tournament draw so ominous that even Jurgen Klinsmann will not be able to see its bright side, but Sunday was not that day.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 1, Episode 6: A Weird Couple of Days
abstract: As “Billions” heads into the second half of its first season, viewers should just embrace the show’s lusty delirium.
lead_paragraph: There was reason to suspect, when “Billions” was announced, that Showtime was offering a prestige series about Wall Street, featuring two highly respected actors, Paul Giamatti and Damian Lewis, and a co-creator credit for a New York Times editor.

headline: Rosario Ferré, Writer Who Examined Puerto Rican Identity, Dies at 77
abstract: Ms. Ferré, who wrote novels in both Spanish and English, was a finalist for the National Book Award in 1995 for “A House on the Lagoon.”
lead_paragraph: Rosario Ferré, a formidable figure in Puerto Rican letters who wrote novels in both Spanish and English, and who was a finalist for the National Book Award in 1995 for the family epic “A House on the Lagoon,” which she translated herself from the original Spanish, died on Thursday at her home in San Juan, P.R. She was 77.

headline: Douglas L. Inman, Coastal Science Pioneer, Dies at 95
abstract: Dr. Inman helped change the understanding of the processes that shape the beach and trained generations of scientists who followed in his footprints.
lead_paragraph: When Douglas L. Inman began his career as a coastal scientist in the 1950s, little was known about the coastal region where water, land and air come together, which geologists call the nearshore. It was obvious that beaches differed from place to place, but geologists struggled to do much more than classify them according to their shapes. Little was known about the direct relationships among waves, currents and the movement of coastal sediments like sand.

headline: N.B.A. Game of the Week: Warriors at Thunder
abstract: The Golden State Warriors continue to roll, but injuries have left them vulnerable to achieving the best record in league history, held by the 1995-96 Bulls.
lead_paragraph: Every week, The New York Times chooses one essential game to watch, highlighting hot teams, winning and losing streaks and statistical intrigue in the N.B.A.

headline: A Monthlong Celebration of Albert Camus in New York
abstract: Albert Camus will be honored with a series of readings, performances, concerts and film screenings in New York.
lead_paragraph: “I loved New York, with that powerful love that at times leaves you full of uncertainty and abhorrence,” Albert Camus wrote in 1947, a year after making his only trip to the United States. Now, New York will be paying him a less ambivalent tribute, with a nearly monthlong series of events commemorating the 70th anniversary of his visit to the city.

headline: HPV Sharply Reduced in Teenage Girls Following Vaccine, Study Says
keywords: ['Vaccination and Immunization', 'Human Papillomavirus (HPV)', 'Cervical Cancer', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Women and Girls', 'Medicine and Health', 'Research']
abstract: A vaccine for human papillomavirus, which causes cervical cancer, has reduced its prevalence in teenage girls by almost two-thirds, the study said.
lead_paragraph: A vaccine introduced a decade ago to combat the sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer has already reduced the virus’s prevalence in teenage girls by almost two-thirds, federal researchers said Monday.

headline: Unions Say a Majority of Their Members Support Hillary Clinton
abstract: A group of more than 20 unions representing more than 10 million workers released a statement on Monday reaffirming support for Hillary Clinton.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to dispute what they say is a false narrative that union voters are closely split between Hillary Clinton and Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont, a group of more than 20 unions representing more than 10 million workers released a statement on Monday reaffirming support for Mrs. Clinton.

headline: What to Watch Monday
abstract: “Spotlight” gets the gray areas of journalism right. “The X-Files” return comes to a close. And Mike Nichols reminisces about his early career.
lead_paragraph: Do you thrill to the sound of humming presses and rumbling trucks? Then check out “Spotlight,” the best-picture Oscar nominee that A. O. Scott of The New York Times says gets the gray areas of newspaper journalism right. “The X-Files” return comes to a close with Chris Carter, the show’s creator, at the helm. And Mike Nichols reminisces about his early career.

headline: London Fashion Week: Burberry, Christopher Kane and Erdem
abstract: As the British capital moves into Day 4, the agenda also includes Roksanda, Peter Pilotto and Giles Deacon.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — And so to Monday, the fourth day of the London schedule, which begins with shows from two outsiders who have managed to make the city — and its fashion scene — their own. The Serbian-born Roksanda Ilincic shows her Roksanda collection at 10 a.m., followed an hour later by the Canadian designer Erdem Moralioglu, whose Erdem brand is celebrating its 10th anniversary this year.

headline: Facebook Open Sources Wireless Gear
keywords: ['Wireless Communications', 'Mobile World Congress (Trade Show)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Cellular Telephones']
abstract: The social networking giant wants virtual reality everywhere. That means getting hardware costs down.
lead_paragraph: Facebook created a global computing system faster than any of its peers by working with crowds of outside engineers, patent-free. Now it wants to do the same thing with the world’s wireless communications technology.

headline: Lee Friedlander’s Overlooked Civil Rights’ Photos
abstract: A new book shows how before Lee Friedlander became known as the quintessential street photographer, he chronicled an important — if sometimes overlooked — moment in civil rights history.
lead_paragraph: A new book shows how before Lee Friedlander became known as the quintessential street photographer, he chronicled an important — if sometimes overlooked — moment in civil rights history.

headline: Lee Friedlander’s Overlooked Civil Rights Photos
abstract: A new book shows how before Lee Friedlander became known as the quintessential street photographer, he chronicled an important — if sometimes overlooked — moment in civil rights history.
lead_paragraph: The photographs in Lee Friedlander’s book “Prayer Pilgrimage for Freedom” are of a subject not usually associated with him: the civil rights movement. Among his earliest and least typical images — the photographer was only 22 when he made them — they document a historic, if lesser known, event in the struggle for racial equality and justice.

The Republican race, by contrast, has seen a lot of consolidation — it’s pretty much down to a two-man race — but the outcome is still up for grabs.

headline: Housing Solutions for New York City, Deep in the Weeds
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Land Use Policies', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Comptroller Scott Stringer wants the city to use vacant lots to help ease the affordable-housing crisis.
lead_paragraph: One of the mysteries of life in New York is the persistence of vacant lots. How a city of skyscraping land prices and a million matchbox apartments could also be home to properties that sit behind chain-link fences for years, even decades, as habitat for weeds and broken bottles, seems the definition of inexplicability.

headline: Getting Rid of Big Currency Notes Could Help Fight Crime
abstract: The 500-euro bill is so popular with drug traffickers and terrorists that it is often referred to as a “bin Laden.”
lead_paragraph: Few Europeans use the 500-euro note, and most Americans rarely encounter the $100 bill. Yet hundreds of millions of these notes are in circulation around the world, where they are often used by drug cartels, corrupt politicians, terrorists and tax cheats to evade law enforcement. That’s why officials in Europe and elsewhere are proposing to end the printing of high-denomination bills.

headline: Why Are White Death Rates Rising?
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Minorities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans']
abstract: For­ less-educated white Americans, the problem may be tied to a rosy view of the past.
lead_paragraph: IT’S disturbing and puzzling news: Death rates are rising for white, less-educated Americans. The economists Anne Case and Angus Deaton reported in December that rates have been climbing since 1999 for non-Hispanic whites age 45 to 54, with the largest increase occurring among the least educated. An analysis of death certificates by The New York Times found similar trends and showed that the rise may extend to white women.

headline: Is There Action the U.S. Should Take in Syria?
abstract: Can America do anything to keep Assad from decimating his opponents and widen the fight against ISIS?

headline: EFG International Agrees to Buy BTG Pactual’s Swiss Business
abstract: The combined company would be one of the largest private Swiss banks and would have about 170 billion francs of assets under management.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The private banking and asset management firm EFG International said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire BSI, the Swiss private-banking arm of the Brazilian investment bank BTG Pactual, for 1.33 billion Swiss francs, or about $1.34 billion.

headline: How Does It Feel, Chief Justice Roberts, to Hone a Dylan Quote?
abstract: Eight years after including a disputed version of a Bob Dylan lyric in a dissent, inspiring a surge in citations of the songwriter in legal opinions, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. offered a “textualist” explanation.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Antonin Scalia loved opera, but he also had a soft spot for Bob Dylan.

headline: Renewed Efforts to Stop Subway Sex Crimes
abstract: The New York police are training more female officers, riding trains in street clothes and encouraging riders to report abuse.
lead_paragraph: Fanning out along the platform at the City Hall subway station in Manhattan, the plainclothes police officers blended in with the morning commuters. As they prepared to board a northbound train, they watched closely, their eyes darting from rider to rider.

headline: Student Question | Is Apple Right in Refusing to Unlock the iPhone of One of the San Bernardino Killers?
abstract: What factors are at stake in Apple’s refusal to allow the F.B.I. to unlock the phone of Syed Rizwan Farook?
lead_paragraph: Last week, a judge in California ordered Apple to help the F.B.I. unlock an iPhone used by one of the attackers in the assault in San Bernardino that killed 14 people in December. The following day, Timothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, responded with a letter to Apple customers, warning of the “chilling” breach of privacy posed by the government’s demands.

headline: Staying Healthy While Traveling the Globe
abstract: Drink bottled water, take Pepto-Bismol preventively and avoid hungry lions.
lead_paragraph: On a recent trip to Tanzania with four grandsons, my most important task (beside protecting them from the jaws of a lion or leopard) was to keep them, and myself, in good health. It would not have been much fun to be stuck in a tent next to the commode or flattened on a cot while the rest of the gang viewed a dazzling array of wild animals from the safety of a Land Rover.

headline: Smartphone Era Politics
keywords: ['Smartphones', 'News and News Media', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Social Media', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: People are outpaced by forces they can't grasp. In political discourse, reasonableness dies, provocation works.
lead_paragraph: The time has come for a painful confession: I have spent my life with words, yet I am illiterate. I can ape the vocabulary of my times but it is not mine. Certain things I cannot say, only mouth.

headline: A Sri Lankan Lesson in Free Speech
abstract: In this country still recovering from a brutal civil war, the ideal of an open society is held precious.
lead_paragraph: London — I gave a talk last month at the Galle Literary Festival in Jaffna, Sri Lanka. This festival, whose home is in the southern city of Galle, has become over the past decade one of the brightest lights in Sri Lanka’s cultural firmament. This year, it established “outreach” festivals in Kandy, in Sri Lanka’s hill country, and in Jaffna in the North.

headline: Senate Returns to a Rancor Over the Supreme Court That Could Spread
abstract: The death of Justice Antonin Scalia and President Obama’s stated intention to nominate a replacement have injected a volatile new element into the Senate just as Republicans and Democrats were trying to work together to pass bipartisan legislation on criminal justice, energy policy and an escalating drug crisis.
lead_paragraph: The Senate returns on Monday to a political environment considerably changed from when they left 10 days ago for the holiday break.

headline: Jazz at Lincoln Center Announces Lineup for 2016-17 Season
abstract: The Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra will perform 10 concert programs as part of a first full slate of programming since the reopening of Frederick P. Rose Hall.
lead_paragraph: Jazz at Lincoln Center’s 2016-17 season will celebrate a clutch of jazz centenaries and welcome an array of familiar collaborators, often in new configurations. The season, running from September through next June, has no official theme but could be seen as a homecoming: this will be Jazz at Lincoln Center’s first full slate of programming since the reopening of Frederick P. Rose Hall, after renovations to create the Mica and Ahmet Ertegun Atrium last year.

headline: ScienceTake | Flight of the Sea Snail
abstract: A tiny marine mollusk no bigger than a peppercorn flies through the water with the same wing motion as a fruit fly.
lead_paragraph: A tiny marine mollusk no bigger than a peppercorn flies through the water with the same wing motion as a fruit fly.

headline: A Sea Snail That Moves Like a Flying Insect
abstract: The sea butterfly, which is the size of a peppercorn, flaps winglike appendages and moves through water with a motion similar to that of many insects.
lead_paragraph: Most of the tiny creatures in the sea, collectively called zooplankton, move themselves along by using their limbs to paddle. But the sea butterfly, a marine snail the size of a peppercorn, has long appeared to use winglike appendages to fly through the water.

headline: Scientists Ponder the Prospect of Contagious Cancer
abstract: What if malignant cells, rather than dying with their host, had the ability to travel from body to body, evolving ever-deadlier skills along the way?
lead_paragraph: For all its peculiar horror, cancer comes with a saving grace. If nothing else can stop a tumor’s mad evolution, the cancer ultimately dies with its host. Everything the malignant cells have learned about outwitting the patient’s defenses — and those of the oncologists — is erased. The next case of cancer, in another victim, must start anew.

headline: Cameron’s Referendum Gamble
keywords: ['Politics and Government', 'Great Britain Withdrawal from EU (Brexit)']
abstract: The prime minister’s legacy rests on how Britons will vote on membership in the European Union.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s prime minister, David Cameron, is facing the biggest challenge of his career. The referendum expected this June on whether the country should stay in the European Union will define his legacy.

headline: Narrow Focus May Aid F.B.I. in Apple Case
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Privacy', 'iPhone', 'Computer Security', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The government is portraying its request that Apple open an iPhone used by a terrorist as a one-time demand. Apple sees a much broader issue.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In the months leading up to Apple’s standoff with the United States government over the unlocking of an iPhone, the technology industry braced itself for a big demand — a back door into all of Apple’s products, or a way to destroy the company’s strong encryption.

headline: How to Make the Most of Drugs We Already Have
abstract: Getting the incentives right for new uses can give us more safety and more value for our health care dollar.
lead_paragraph: Though you may not have realized it, there’s a good chance that a doctor has prescribed you a medication for a use other than what it was approved for. This off-label use is perfectly legal, but isn’t as safe as it might be, in part because incentives to invest in costly clinical trials to test such uses are weak.

headline: ‘Easy Money’ Isn’t Cheap: Hong Kong License Plate Sells for $2.3 Million
abstract: The city’s new record price at auction was for “28,” which in Cantonese sounds similar to a phrase for “easy money.” The proceeds will go to charity.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A vehicle license plate in Hong Kong sold at auction for 18.1 million Hong Kong dollars on Sunday, or $2.3 million, the highest price ever paid in the city. The plate carries the number 28, which in Cantonese sounds similar to a phrase for “easy money.”
