abstract: A European business group says Beijing’s policies and recalcitrant Chinese officials have allowed overcapacity to become ‘‘ever more destructive.’’
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The failure of Chinese leaders to tackle the problem of excess industrial production has intensified an economic slowdown in the country and threatens to wreak havoc on global markets, a prominent European business association said in a new report on Monday.

headline: ‘Hamilton’ Wins Kennedy Prize for Historical Drama
abstract: The award goes to “a new play or musical that enlists theater’s power to explore the past of the United States.”
lead_paragraph: The awards keep coming for “Hamilton.”

headline: Dylan Citings in Court
abstract: Here are a few examples of cases in which judicial opinions have cited the lyrics of Bob Dylan.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan’s pointed and versatile lyrics are cited in judicial opinions more than those of any other songwriter. A sampling:

headline: Pringle of Scotland: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Fran Stringer debuts her first womenswear collection alongside Massimo Nicosia.
lead_paragraph: Fran Stringer debuts her first womenswear collection alongside Massimo Nicosia.

headline: Beijing to Raise Threshold on Red Alerts for Smog
abstract: The change in how the air quality alerts would be applied highlights officials’ worries about the social disruption they can cause.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The first red alert over air pollution in the Chinese capital almost brought this city to a standstill in December, with schools shut, construction halted and driving restricted. Now, in a swift policy shift, Beijing plans to issue a red alert based on higher thresholds, despite government pledges to better address the toxic air.

headline: Erdem: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: The Canadian born fashion designer Mr. Moralıoğlu, presents his latest designs.
lead_paragraph: The Canadian born fashion designer Mr. Moralıoğlu, presents his latest designs.

headline: Trump’s Remarks on Pigs’ Blood Elicit Challenge From Sister of Chapel Hill Victim
abstract: Suzanne Barakat, the sister of a Muslim student killed last year, said Donald J. Trump’s words were “a moment when I just said, ‘enough is enough.’”
lead_paragraph: Suzanne Barakat, the sister of a Muslim student killed alongside his wife and sister-in-law last year in an attack in North Carolina, challenged Donald J. Trump to meet with her after a speech in which he spoke approvingly of killing Islamic terrorists with bullets dipped in the blood of pigs.

headline: Sysco to Acquire Brakes Group, a Food Distributor in Europe
abstract: Sysco agreed to pay $3.1 billion in the deal, which will be subject to review by European Union competition authorities.
lead_paragraph: Sysco said on Monday that it had agreed to acquire the Brakes Group, a European food distributor, for $3.1 billion.

headline: Watchdog Group Asks for Inquiry Into Nonprofits Tied to de Blasio
abstract: Common Cause New York filed a complaint with New York City on Monday, saying that groups run by close allies of Mayor Bill de Blasio are running afoul of campaign finance law.
lead_paragraph: A government watchdog group filed a formal complaint with New York City officials on Monday against Mayor Bill de Blasio and the outside political groups tied to him, requesting an investigation into whether their fund-raising and spending violated the law.

headline: Big Names Use Social Media to Support Kesha in Legal Battle
abstract: Singers like Lady Gaga, Miley Cyrus and Taylor Swift are backing Kesha’s battle against her former mentor, Dr. Luke, after a court ruling in New York.
lead_paragraph: Some of the biggest names in music are picking sides publicly in the legal battle between the pop singer Kesha and her former mentor, Dr. Luke, one of the industry’s top hitmakers.

headline: China Moves to Halt ‘Weird’ Architecture
abstract: A directive issued by the State Council and the Communist Party’s Central Committee says buildings should be “pleasing to the eye.’’
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China is home to at least 10 White Houses, three Arcs de Triomphe and one Eiffel Tower. But 2016 might signal the end for China’s more grandiose architecture.

headline: 1941: Mines in Part of Mediterranean
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Britain warns of mines in an area in the Mediterranean in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The British Admiralty, in a move to isolate Italy from Tripolitania and Tunisia and to hamper the Italian fleet in its operations off the southern Italian coast, announced today [Feb. 22] that an area of some 150,000 square miles in the central Mediterranean, with Malta as its focus, was dangerous to shipping, indicating that the area was spotted with mines laid by the British Navy. The danger area runs from Bengasi, in Libya, to Cape Santa Maria di Leuca, the tip of the heel of Italy, then along the Italian coast around the toe, and northward to Point Paolo Fuora. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 23, 1941

headline: Construction Begins on the 5G Wireless Dream
abstract: Imagine wireless speeds that would allow movie downloads in seconds. What was once fantasy could come true in a few more years.
lead_paragraph: Most people think that trying to download an entire movie to a mobile device is the act of a madman. Or the act of someone with plenty of time and money to burn.

headline: Clearing Clutter From the YouTube Video Screen
abstract: If you find the annotations that pop up on top of certain YouTube videos annoying, turn them off in your YouTube account settings.
lead_paragraph: Q. Is there a way to turn off those onscreen text boxes that cover up part of the video while it’s playing on YouTube?

headline: An Island, a Focal Point for a Healthy Marine Ecosystem
keywords: ['Oceans and Seas', 'Fish and Other Marine Life']
abstract: The biomass of phytoplankton around islands is up to 86 percent greater than what’s found in other parts of the ocean.
lead_paragraph: Islands play a crucial role in sustaining marine ecosystems in the Pacific Ocean, according to a new study. The waters surrounding islands are rich in phytoplankton, microscopic organisms that inhabit the upper layers of the oceans and serve as an important food source for larger animals. After studying 35 coral reef islands using satellite imagery and ship-based surveys, researchers concluded that the biomass of phytoplankton around islands was up to 86 percent greater than what is found in other parts of the ocean. The findings appear in the journal Nature Communications.

headline: Michael Jaharis, Pharmaceutical Executive and Philanthropist, Dies at 87
abstract: For nearly half a century, Mr. Jaharis navigated the industry, tinkering with existing drugs to create and sell a series of more refined products.
lead_paragraph: Michael Jaharis, whose business expertise in the pharmaceutical industry made him a fortune estimated at more than $2.2 billion, and who gave major gifts to cultural institutions like the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Art Institute of Chicago and the Metropolitan Opera, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

headline: Margaret Sullivan, New York Times Public Editor, Joining Washington Post
abstract: Ms. Sullivan had been scheduled to leave The Times in August and will stay on for a number of weeks.
lead_paragraph: Margaret Sullivan, the public editor of The New York Times, is leaving to join The Washington Post as its media columnist, the two newspapers announced on Monday.

headline: Review: In ‘The End of Average,’ Cheers for Individual Complexity
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Education (K-12)', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Mathematics', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: The author Todd Rose warns against conclusions drawn from large populations, arguing that they rarely account for important personal variations.
lead_paragraph: All of us want to be normal, yet none of us want to be average.

headline: Burberry: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Christopher Bailey presents his first see now buy now collection.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Bailey presents his first see now buy now collection.

headline: Sylvester Stallone on the Weakest Link in ‘Creed’: Himself
abstract: The supporting-actor nominee says his career wasn’t “in free fall — it was caught in a cave somewhere.”
lead_paragraph: It’s too easy to surmise, given Sylvester Stallone’s slightly slurred and deliberate manner of speaking (the result of facial nerve damage caused by rough forceps at birth), as well as his most enduring screen roles — “Rocky” and “Rambo” — that the man might not be a mental giant. But such assumptions could not be farther from the truth.

headline: Bangladesh Arrests Three Men in Priest’s Beheading
abstract: A Hindu priest was attacked by two men who the police said were involved with an Islamic militant group, the third waited nearby on a motorcycle.
lead_paragraph: DHAKA, Bangladesh — Three men were arrested on Monday in connection with the beheading of the highest-ranking priest of a Hindu temple in northern Bangladesh, officials said.

headline: The Playful, Cartoonish Designs of a Furniture Wunderkind
abstract: The 26-year-old designer Misha Kahn’s irreverent pieces — from inflated chandeliers to slouching side tables — have earned him a solo show at Friedman Benda.
lead_paragraph: Plastic bits and blobs dangle from the ceiling and just about every other surface of the 26-year-old designer Misha Kahn’s studio in Brooklyn, which he shares with fellow designer Katie Stout (who just opened a show with Bjarne Melgaard at Karma gallery). A kind of clubhouse for outlandish furniture, their studio is something of a Willy Wonka wonderland. Kahn’s material irreverence and cheeky sense of humor have already amassed him a following, with commissions from luxury clients like Dior. His work has also been shown at the collection of New York’s Museum of Art and Design. Kahn’s creations, which range from inflated chandeliers to slouching concrete side tables, bring to mind the playfully haphazard aesthetic of ’90s Nickelodeon cartoons like “The Ren and Stimpy Show” — an analogy Kahn welcomes with a laugh, pointing out one of his latest pieces, a fluorescent, amoeba-shaped mirror, as a ready example.

headline: Can You ‘Suntan’ Through a Window?
abstract: Can you get useful quantities of vitamin D while sitting in a sunny window in the heart of winter?
lead_paragraph: Q. On these cold yet sunny winter days, can a person absorb vitamin D by sitting inside next to a sunny window?

headline: Anthony Davis’s 59-Point Night Gives Pelicans Limited Hope
abstract: By one measure, Davis’s performance in a win at Detroit on Sunday was the best by a player since Kobe Bryant’s 81-point game in 2006. But New Orleans has a ways to go.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Davis earned several entries in the record books with his 59-point, 20-rebound explosion at Detroit on Sunday. But was it a sign of improvement for the struggling New Orleans Pelicans, or a single memorable moment in a lost season?

headline: A Turning Point for Syrian War, and U.S. Credibility
abstract: The former French foreign minister, Laurent Fabius, accused President Obama of letting down the whole world by failing to attack Syria in August 2013.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In case anyone missed it, Laurent Fabius, who was the French foreign minister as recently as two weeks ago, accused President Obama of letting down not just Syria but the whole world in 2013.

headline: Uganda Opposition Candidate Kizza Besigye Taken From Home
abstract: Mr. Besigye, the runner-up in the presidential election last week, had been under house arrest, and the United States had called for his release.
lead_paragraph: KAMPALA, Uganda — Kizza Besigye, the runner-up in the Ugandan presidential election last week who was under house arrest, was taken from his home Monday morning by the police near Kampala, the capital, to a remote station, two days after the United States called for his release.

headline: A Black Hole That Has Stopped Swallowing Stars
abstract: At the core of a galaxy some 300 million light-years away is a supermassive, inactive black hole that is about 21 billion times the size of the sun.
lead_paragraph: The brightest orb in the center of this photograph captured by the Hubble Space Telescope is a galaxy some 300 million light-years away called NGC 4889.

headline: London Fashion Week: Alexander McQueen and Topshop Unique in Pictures
abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented yesterday.

headline: No Shortcuts in Evaluating Your Investment Risk
abstract: Questionnaires and other quick ways to determine risk tolerance should not replace a thoughtful assessment of your investment goals.
lead_paragraph: Early in my career, I worked for a big brokerage firm. Back then, I made a habit of seeking out the veteran stockbrokers and quizzing them about their careers. One day, I had a pretty extensive conversation about risk with one of those grizzled Wall Street guys.

headline: Marco Rubio Bets on Nevada, a State That Shaped His Childhood
abstract: Mr. Rubio’s family spent six years in Las Vegas in the 1970s and ’80s, not a well-known chapter in the Florida senator’s life, but a formative one.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — The neighborhoods of squat cinder-block bungalows on this city’s north end do not usually produce a lot of Republicans.

headline: Christopher Kane: The Bandage Dress in 12 Shades of Nude
abstract: The designer looks back on the dresses that set the direction for his career.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Kane’s outsize talent has propelled him from design stints at Donatella Versace Atelier and Topshop to collaborations with pop luminaries like Kylie Minogue and Beth Ditto.

headline: We See France
abstract: Inspiration from a French artist, going meatless and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: A Do-It-Yourself Revolution in Diabetes Care
keywords: ['Diabetes', 'Medical Devices', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Software', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Insulin', 'Open-Source Software', 'Inventions and Patents']
abstract: Parents of children with diabetes have led an egalitarian push for improved technology to monitor the condition, and to even develop cheaper insulin.
lead_paragraph: John Costik got the call at the office in 2012. It was his wife, Laura, with terrible news: Their 4-year-old son, Evan, was headed into the emergency room.

headline: Eric Brown, Record-Breaking British Aviator and World War II Combat Pilot, Dies at 97
abstract: In a career spanning the era of biplanes to the threshold of spaceflight, Captain Brown flew 487 types of aircraft, more than any pilot in history.
lead_paragraph: Eric Melrose Brown, a renowned British Navy test pilot who shattered records and made history with exploits that advanced Allied fighter power in World War II and quests for jet propulsion and supersonic speeds in postwar aviation, died on Sunday in southern England. He was 97.

headline: 1966: France Finished With NATO
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Charles de Gaulle says he will pull France out of NATO in 1966.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President Charles de Gaulle regards the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as finished as far as France is concerned, French government sources said today [Feb. 22]. He is willing to open talks on the future status of American bases in France, they said. But he has no intention of quitting the Atlantic alliance as such, which he regards as different than NATO, they added. The sources said he definitely will pull France out of NATO and its entire integrated command structure by the deadline of April 4, 1969, which he set in his news conference yesterday. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 23, 1966

headline: The Day My Megabus Caught Fire
abstract: There were a series of pops, and before we knew it, the bus was in flames. A first-time trip on a Megabus goes awry.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was my first time taking Megabus, a discount intercity bus service that began in 2006 and quickly gained notoriety for advertising fares as low as $1 each way. Yesterday was also the first time I had to evacuate a bus as it was catching fire.

headline: Univision Aims to Make Hispanic Voting Bloc Even More Formidable
abstract: The company, including its top-rated Spanish-language network and digital platforms, hopes to register about three million new Latino voters this year.
lead_paragraph: About 11 million Hispanics voted in the 2012 presidential election, fewer than half of those who were eligible. Activists in both major political parties have been trying to increase that number, through voter registration drives and appeals over issues like immigration and wage stagnation on the left, and economic freedom on the right.

headline: It’s Possible to Grow a 3-D Printed Ear on a Mouse’s Back
abstract: With the success of growing the body parts in a lab, bioengineers are taking a step toward creating replacement organs that can be transplanted into people.
lead_paragraph: This unattached ear bathed in pink goo may look like a freaky find from Frankenstein’s laboratory, but it’s actually the product of a decade worth of medical research with 3-D printing.

headline: U.S. Soccer Keeping Silent on FIFA Presidential Vote, for Now
abstract: After its show of protest nine months ago did not stop Sepp Blatter from gaining re-election, the federation is planning to avoid a public endorsement.
lead_paragraph: Nine months ago, just before the last election for FIFA president, the United States Soccer Federation publicly endorsed Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan in his race against Sepp Blatter, the longtime and much-maligned incumbent who went on to win re-election easily. At the time, U.S. Soccer’s endorsement was seen as a bold show of protest against the status quo within the scandal-plagued governing body.

headline: The Daily Bag: Mulberry
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Mulberry got a new creative director — and a whole new crop of handbags. This one in particular, a mostly python carry-all with a touch of punk, was pure perfection.

headline: Searing Grapefruit for a Juicy, Refreshing Breakfast
abstract: These “pancakes” are served warm, with maple syrup spiked with fresh ginger juice.
lead_paragraph: At this time of year, there is a dearth of fruit in many parts of the country, but grapefruit from Texas, Florida and Southern California is still very much in season.

headline: U.N. Finds ‘Deliberate’ Destruction of Hospitals in Syria
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A report listed a series of attacks on civilians by government forces and ISIS and said international stakeholders were fueling the violence.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — First, the government soldiers made sure no food could get into rebel-held towns. Then, government planes bombed what health centers remained in those towns, making sure that those who got sick from hunger had no medical care to save them.

headline: Writer Apologizes for SB Nation Article on Convicted Rapist
abstract: Jeff Arnold drew outrage after writing a piece many saw as sympathetic to Daniel Holtzclaw, who was convicted of sexually assaulting women while on duty as a police officer.
lead_paragraph: The author of a deleted SB Nation article on Daniel Holtzclaw, a former police officer and convicted rapist, that was criticized as being overly sympathetic  apologized on Monday, saying that he had produced a piece with “massive shortcomings” but that at least four editors had cleared it before publication.

headline: Tribeca Film Festival Opening With Look at Met’s Costume Show
keywords: ['Tribeca Film Festival (NYC)', 'Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'Art', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The documentary follows the assembling of the fashion exhibition “China: Through The Looking Glass.”
lead_paragraph: For the opening night of this year’s Tribeca Film Festival, the event is getting fashionable. Organizers announced Monday that it will open with the documentary “The First Monday in May,” about the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s popular fashion exhibition from last year,  “China: Through the Looking Glass.”  Organized by the curator Andrew Bolton, that show, from the museum’s Costume Institute, drew more than 800,000 visitors and explored the influence of Chinese culture on Western fashion.

headline: Not Every Drop of a Person’s Blood Is the Same, a Study Says
abstract: Bioengineers at Rice University recently found that different drops from single fingerpricks on multiple subjects varied substantially.
lead_paragraph: As diagnostic tests rely on ever-tinier amounts of blood, some scientists are striking a note of caution. As it turns out, not all drops of blood are identical.

headline: Kevin McCarthy, G.O.P. House Leader, Says He Could Work With Donald Trump
abstract: While Representative Kevin McCarthy’s comments were hardly a ringing endorsement of Donald J. Trump, they were not an expression of concern about the impact that the first-time candidate could have on the Republicans’ chances at taking back the White House
lead_paragraph: Representative Kevin McCarthy, a Republican from California and the House majority leader, said on Monday that he would be able to work with Donald J. Trump as the party’s presidential nominee, the latest signal of acceptance from national figures of the billionaire real estate developer.

headline: Adam Kucharski: The Perfect Bet
abstract: Such beautiful flowers! Can you guess which is the most beautiful?
lead_paragraph: For this week’s challenge we continue with Adam Kucharski, the award-winning author of “The Perfect Bet: How Science and Math Are Taking the Luck Out of Gambling.” We met Dr. Kucharski last week with the St. Petersburg Lottery, in which we were playing directly against a house with infinite resources.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Alexander McQueen
keywords: ['London Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Shoes and Boots']
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: The classic velvet smoking slipper gets the McQueen treatment with embroidered patches in the shape of horses, eyes and lips. — MALINA JOSEPH GILCHRIST

headline: Multitools Make the Man
abstract: The art of equipping yourself for the battle of the everyday.
lead_paragraph: The art of equipping yourself for the battle of the everyday.

headline: ‘The Life of Elves,’ by Muriel Barbery
abstract: Two girls with special gifts can bring about the return of elfin power.
lead_paragraph: Muriel Barbery’s previous novels, “The Elegance of the Hedgehog” and “Gourmet Rhapsody,” took place in the same Paris apartment building. Her latest departs from both that locale and the quotidian world. Set in Burgundy, Italy and a magical place called the Pavilion of the Mists, “The Life of Elves” follows two girls of otherworldly provenance — Clara, the daughter of a human and her elfin lover, and Maria, an elf child who fully resembles a human being — born just as an evil leader is about to unleash his destructive powers.

headline: As 2 Famed Businesses Reopen, Tenants Above Them Remain Without Gas
abstract: Residents in the buildings that house the Carnegie Deli and Barneys are frustrated with the halting work that has left some without heat, hot water or cooking lines for months.
lead_paragraph: Last week, while Mayor Bill de Blasio was downstairs tucking into a pastrami sandwich at the newly reopened Carnegie Deli, Elsie and Pasquale Forino sat in their sky-blue kitchen one floor above having their own breakfast of toast and fruit. When Mr. Forino pressed down the lever on the toaster, the lights dimmed.

headline: ‘A Doubter’s Almanac,’ by Ethan Canin
abstract: A mathematics genius inflicts emotional and physical pain on his wife and children.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to create a great literary monster. The character’s behavior has to evoke repulsion in the readers, meanwhile engaging their sympathy for the suffering soul beneath. In Ethan Canin’s new novel, “A Doubter’s Almanac,” the mathematician Milo Andret is certainly despicable enough. With relish and malice, he manipulates the lives of his family members. He humiliates his wife, curses his daughter and bedevils his son. He uses women. He demeans his colleagues. He is a raging, nasty drunk. Twice, he nearly commits murder. In the face of all this, can Canin also portray him as a tragic figure worthy of pity? The novel’s success hinges upon the answer.

headline: Yahoo’s Decision to Explore a Sale Exposes a Weak Board
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Boards of Directors', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The announcement that the board is exploring “strategic alternatives” is confirmation that it is stumbling as Yahoo’s chief, Marissa Mayer, flounders.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe, but after all these years, the Yahoo board is still a contender for America’s worst corporate board.

headline: Inside Fashion Week
abstract: Glittering rats, organza shirt-dresses and Supreme Court vacancies: Vanessa Friedman, the Times’ chief fashion critic, makes sense of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: Glittering rats, organza shirt-dresses and Supreme Court vacancies: Vanessa Friedman, the Times’ chief fashion critic, makes sense of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Burberry, J.W. Anderson and Simone Rocha: Reflections on a Fashion System
abstract: The packed London schedule also included a new designer at Mulberry, Erdem and Roksanda.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the streets and cafes here, there is a lot of talk about the possibility of a Brexit — Britain’s leaving the European Union, to be decided June 23 in a national referendum — with Prime Minister David Cameron pleading to stay and the London mayor, Boris Johnson, announcing on Sunday that he’s for leaving.

headline: New York Fashion Week: Wet Look Trend
abstract: Lacquered fabrics slick enough to skate on were the last word this week at any number of shows.
lead_paragraph: Lacquered fabrics slick enough to skate on were the last word this week at any number of shows.

headline: How Jeb Bush Spent $130 Million Running for President With Nothing to Show for It
abstract: The Bush campaign and the “super PAC” supporting it burned through an unrivaled war chest over seven months. Here is where some of that money went.
lead_paragraph: When Jeb Bush formally entered the presidential campaign in June, there was already more money behind him than every other Republican candidate combined. When he suspended his campaign on Saturday night in South Carolina, Mr. Bush had burned through the vast majority of that cash without winning a single state. It may go down as one of the least successful campaign spending binges in history. Here is Mr. Bush’s story, as told by his ledger:

headline: Pouring on the Wet Looks
abstract: Borrowing the sheen of ice, for results with a lot more heat.
lead_paragraph: Lacquered fabrics slick enough to skate on were the last word this week at any number of shows. The look, trotted out in high gloss, demi-gloss and lipstick-tinted variations, lent unaccustomed luster to the coats, trousers and calf-clutching fetish boots in the collections of Hood by Air, Lacoste, Proenza Schouler and Calvin Klein, to name but a handful.

headline: While HSBC Stays Upbeat, Investors Worry About Rates and China
abstract: The lender’s executives have made it clear that they think these worries are more imagined than real, but investors fear the worst is yet to come.
lead_paragraph: HSBC shares are being weighed down by fear of the future. The global lender thinks it can bolster returns even as its balance sheet shrinks. That is why it increased the dividend despite a 7 percent drop in underlying pretax profit in 2015. But investors remain more worried about negative interest rates, China’s slowdown and cheap oil.

headline: Christopher Kane: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Mr. Kane, who just launched his first campaign, presents his latest collection.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Kane, who just launched his first campaign, presents his latest collection.

headline: Review: Les Ballets de Monte Carlo’s Rendition of ‘Cinderella’
abstract: Jean-Christophe Maillot’s version, which focuses on the heroine’s deceased mother who has returned as a fairy, was performed at City Center.
lead_paragraph: Why leave a fairy tale just the way it is? The French choreographer Jean-Christophe Maillot is fond of skewing tradition, preferring to delve into the psychological underpinnings of his characters. In his rendition of “Cinderella,” he focuses on the heroine’s deceased mother, who has returned to her daughter’s life as the Fairy. He also rids the story of the usual Cinderella trappings: the fireplace, a pumpkin and glass slippers. Her bare feet are dipped in gold glitter. Of the many confusing and random turns in Mr. Maillot’s high-strung, unfulfilling production, one point is clear: Our Prince has a foot fetish.

headline: Coddled Eggs in Elegant Glass Vessels
abstract: Also, a coffee table book of stars, new loaves at Silver Moon Bakery, Malaysian breakfast spreads, Odeon Granola and a new branch of Russ & Daughters.
lead_paragraph: It’s an indulgence, but if coddled eggs are your solo breakfast luxury, you will need just one of these elegant Jenaer Glas vessels based on a 1930s Bauhaus design by Wilhelm Wagenfeld. Butter the inside, crack in an egg, seal the top and place it in a water bath in a 275-degree oven or on the stovetop for about eight minutes. Include a little cream, some meltable cheese or herbs, and bits of bacon. The instructions (in 10 languages, yet somehow rather inadequate) suggest you also use the coddler for soufflés, pâtés and gratins, but I would keep it for breakfast: Egg coddler, $22, MoMA Design Store, momastore.org.

headline: A Slow Unveiling for Tourette’s Disease
abstract: A condition that was named in 1885 was not mentioned in The New York Times until an article by Jane E. Brody was published in 1975.
lead_paragraph: Tourette’s disease was named in 1885, but The New York Times did not mention it until 90 years later.

headline: U.S. Economy Still on the Rise, White House Report Finds
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Consumer Confidence (Economic Indicator)', 'Unemployment', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Minimum Wage', 'Gross Domestic Product']
abstract: The Economic Report of the President highlighted growing wages, shrinking unemployment and higher consumer confidence.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States economy continued a strong rebound last year, with unemployment falling by half since the depths of the 2008 recession, wages growing and consumer confidence at its highest point in a dozen years, the White House said on Monday. But a slowdown overseas and persistent income inequality at home threaten to sap some of those gains in the years to come.

headline: Bernie Sanders Opens A New Front In His War on Hillary Clinton’s Big Money
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The senator is pressing Mrs. Clinton’s camp to join with him in calling for a ban on campaign donations by lobbyists.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic National Committee has quietly reversed the ban on accepting lobbyist donations that Barack Obama insisted on as a good government reform when he was running for the White House eight years ago. Hailed back then as a step to rein in the power of special interest money, the ban was dropped at some point in recent months by the D.N.C. without public notice. But the reversal was confirmed this month by The Washington Post and immediately became a factor in the party’s contest for the presidential nomination, with Senator Bernie Sanders pressing Hillary Clinton to join his call to instantly restore the Obama ban.

headline: Why Pertussis Is Making a Comeback
abstract: Cases of whooping cough in the U.S. have spiked in recent years. The newer vaccine is not as effective as the old one, but it has fewer side effects.
lead_paragraph: Whooping cough, a potentially life-threatening childhood illness, all but disappeared in the 1940s after a vaccine was developed. Why is it making a comeback now, when most children are vaccinated?

headline: At Burberry: The Starriest Front Row in Town
abstract: A crowd of A-listers turned out for Christopher Bailey’s last show before switching to a see-now, buy-now seasonless schedule.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — As sure as showers will fall during London Fashion Week (there were plenty over the last four days), Burberry will provide the starriest front row of the schedule.

headline: Hill and Friends: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Emma Hill and Georgia Fendley, who were formerly at Mulberry, present their latest collection for their new line.
lead_paragraph: Emma Hill and Georgia Fendley, who were formerly at Mulberry, present their latest collection for their new line.

headline: Podcast: Inside Fashion Week
abstract: Glittering rats, organza dresses and Supreme Court vacancies: The Times’ chief fashion critic, Vanessa Friedman, makes sense of New York Fashion Week.
lead_paragraph: New York Fashion Week ended on Friday with a Marc Jacobs show during which “glittering rats chased their tails around Victorian coats.”

headline: Coercion May Make People Feel Less Responsible for Actions
abstract: In a study, test subjects felt more removed from the consequences of a decision if they are ordered to carry it out.
lead_paragraph: Some people feel responsible for their actions even if they are forced to take them. But many do not, a new study suggests, finding in coercion a freedom from blame.

headline: Paul Simon Returning to Forest Hills Stadium After 46 Years
abstract: Paul Simon, who went to Forest Hills High in Queens, will play at Forest Hills Stadium for the first time since 1970.
lead_paragraph: Paul Simon spent his formative years at Forest Hills High School, playing music with a Forest Hills native named Arthur Garfunkel. So it’s only fitting that he will end his 2016 summer tour at Forest Hills Stadium on June 30 — his first appearance there in 46 years.

headline: An Animal-Based Diet?

headline: In Nevada, the Marco Rubio Entourage Is Lacking in Diversity

lead_paragraph: ELKO, Nev. — The diversity of Marco Rubio’s political team in South Carolina was so striking that his campaign boasted they were the face of the new conservative movement. Mr. Rubio, a Cuban-American, Gov. Nikki Haley, an Indian-American, and Senator Tim Scott, who is black, were like a Republican Benetton ad, as Ms. Haley joked at every event.

headline: The Case for Rubio-Kasich
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: Why a lazy pundit’s fantasy might actually be the best way to stop Trump.
lead_paragraph: Saturday’s Republican primary in South Carolina was not quite the train wreck for the not-Trump portion of the party that seemed likely after New Hampshire’s multi-candidate pileup. Boosted by Nikki Haley’s endorsement, Marco Rubio basically saved his campaign with a second-place finish, while Jeb Bush finished far enough back that dropping out became the only honorable option. That consolidation meant that notwithstanding Donald Trump’s victory, it wasn’t nearly as good a night for him as New Hampshire: The field narrowed, the party’s leadership accelerated its rally around Rubio, and the emerging three-way battle between Trump, Rubio and Ted Cruz, while still better for the Donald than a two-man race, isn’t the pure gift to him that the old Christie-Jeb-Rubio-Kasich combination offered.

headline: Kalamazoo Shooting Suspect Charged, but Motive Remains Mystery
abstract: Jason B. Dalton, a driver for Uber, was charged with six counts of murder in the shootings Saturday night.
lead_paragraph: KALAMAZOO, Mich. — An Uber driver admitted his involvement in a Saturday night shooting rampage that left six people dead and two others injured, the county prosecutor said on Monday as the driver was formally charged with murder. But the motive of the man, who had no criminal history, remained a mystery.

abstract: In August, the brand’s makeup counters will begin carrying a new shimmer dust, which was used generously on its fall/winter 2016 runway.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at Burberry’s fall/winter 2016 show, the makeup artist Wendy Rowe mirrored the “earthy opulence” of Christopher Bailey’s clothes with a trio of beauty looks: the nude (“some girls just look best completely natural, so we said let’s keep it like that”), the disheveled (essentially a dark eye, lined with Burberry’s Eye Colour Cream in charcoal with a glint of glittery sparkle — “as though they’ve tried to wipe it off”) and the all-out glitter-bombed.

abstract: 래리 페이지가 지적 호기심으로 가득한 실리콘 밸리의 첫 번째 CEO는 아니다. 하지만 다른 회사에서는 보기 드물게 구글 곳곳에는 CEO인 페이지가 개인적으로 매료됐던 것들이 반영되어 있다.
lead_paragraph: 3년 전, 무기 회사 록히드 마틴의 핵융합 프로그램을 관장하던 엔지니어 찰스 체이스는 구글이 주최한 “세상의 문제를 해결하자”는 뜻의 솔브포엑스(Solve for X) 콘퍼런스에서 하얀 가죽 소파에 앉아 있었다. 그때 전에 만난 적이 없었던 남자가 다가와 무릎까지 굽히고 앉으며 그에게 말을 걸었다.

abstract: Chef Grant Achatz breaks down his new seafood stew, designed for his three-week tasting menu at the Faena Hotel Miami Beach.
lead_paragraph: “We wanted to pay homage to the South American influence in Miami’s gastronomic culture,” said chef Grant Achatz, who is currently installed in the newly opened Faena Hotel Miami Beach for a three-week residency. The pop-up series, aptly named “Alinea In Residence,” brings Achatz and a staff of approximately 50 to Miami from Madrid (where the team had recently completed a similar short-term series), to execute an original multicourse menu in the Modernist style of his award-winning Chicago restaurant.

headline: Review: ‘The Secret Garden,’ a Concert Revival in Which Sadness Morphs Into Joy
abstract: Ghostly Freudian repression gives way to sunshine and fresh air in this concert revival of a musical based on Frances Hodgson Burnett’s children’s story.
lead_paragraph: The 1991 Broadway musical adaptation of Frances Hodgson Burnett’s classic children’s novel “The Secret Garden” is held by many in such esteem that the audience for its robust concert revival at David Geffen Hall arrived with rapturous expectations on Sunday evening. The performance, which was repeated on Monday, is the fourth installment in a series of such musical revivals by Manhattan Concert Productions.

headline: U.S.-Russia Deal on a Partial Truce in Syria Raises More Doubt Than Optimism
abstract: The cease-fire is to begin Saturday, but officials acknowledge that obstacles remain in getting the Syrian government and the armed opposition to comply.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and Russia announced an agreement on Monday for a partial truce in Syria, though the caveats and cautious words on all sides underscored the obstacles in the way of the latest diplomatic effort to end the five-year-old civil war.

lead_paragraph: The Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Lynn Nottage will need to make room on her shelf for another prestigious award: She is the 2016 winner of the Susan Smith Blackburn Prize for “Sweat,” her acclaimed drama about deindustrialization in a working-class city in Pennsylvania.

headline: Review: Nicolas Altstaedt and Alexander Lonquich, in a Stirring Concert at the Frick
abstract: The cello-piano duo used an intimate setting to their advantage in a program that included Debussy and Beethoven.
lead_paragraph: Late in his life, while battling rectal cancer, Debussy began a series of six sonatas for various instruments, starting with the Sonata for Cello and Piano in 1915. He ended up finishing only three before his death in 1918. Coming from such a pioneering composer, this sonata project seemed a throwback, a nod to the Neo-Classicism coming into vogue in Paris at the time.

headline: The Making of Mary Katrantzou’s Elaborate Tulle Skirts
abstract: T visited the designer in the lead up to her London Fashion Week show.
lead_paragraph: Less than two weeks before London Fashion Week, Mary Katrantzou was feeling good. “I like the collection so far,” the designer said, referring to her fall/winter 2016 offering, which was presented yesterday — though she acknowledged that she was preparing for an emotional roller coaster. “Now you like it, because you’re excited because a lot of the ideas are going to launch. Then you get stressed before the show, because the ideas haven’t come back launched and ready, so you’re just a bit concerned. And then you feel sick, because you don’t know how it will all feel when it comes together.” She continued, laughing: “So at the moment, you’re coming in just before the storm. Everything’s good now, and in seven days it won’t be.”

headline: Review: Inon Barnatan Soldiers Through Hallowed Works at 92nd Street Y

lead_paragraph: The fine Israeli pianist Inon Barnatan has served New York assiduously and well in recent years, especially through collaborative efforts with the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center and as the New York Philharmonic’s first artist-in-association. On Saturday evening he took the stage at the 92nd Street Y for a fascinating and rewarding solo recital.

headline: Trevor Nunn, British Shakespeare Master, Tries Something New: Directing Americans
abstract: With “Pericles,” Mr. Nunn is directing his 35th play out of 37 by Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: For more than half a century, Trevor Nunn has directed Elizabethan tragedies and contemporary comedies, heady literary adaptations and at least one roller-skating fantasia. He was the youngest-ever artistic director of the Royal Shakespeare Company and later ran London’s National Theater. He wrote the lyrics to “On My Own” from “Les Misérables.” He was integral in shaping “Cats.”

headline: Vaginal Ring With Drug Lowers H.I.V. Rates in African Women

abstract: A flexible ring that slowly releases an antiviral drug into the vagina helped protect African women against H.I.V. infection, two studies reported.
lead_paragraph: A flexible and inexpensive ring that is inserted into the vagina, where it slowly releases an antiviral drug, helped protect African women against contracting H.I.V. from their sexual partners, researchers said Monday in reports on two major studies that included more than 4,500 women.

The slender 29-year-old patient, dressed in a plaid shirt, jeans and a baseball cap, slouched into his chair and began pouring out a story of woe stretching back a dozen years.

headline: Rudy Giuliani, Although Friends With Donald Trump, Is Not Ready to Endorse Yet
abstract: The former mayor of New York said he had known Mr. Trump for decades, and was open to supporting John Kasich or Marco Rubio, but not Ted Cruz.
lead_paragraph: Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former mayor of New York, is an admirer of Donald J. Trump and has been friends with him for decades. His endorsement could be useful to Mr. Trump, both as an affirmation in national security terms and an appeal to transplanted New Yorkers in Florida and elsewhere.

headline: At New York City Ballet, Works That Tell Stories and Don’t
abstract: In a revival of Justin Peck’s “Paz de la Jolla,” the work looks fresher, deeper, more poetic than before.
lead_paragraph: The ballets of Justin Peck usually grow on renewed acquaintance. This hasn’t happened yet with his latest work, “The Most Incredible Thing,” which had its premiere at New York City Ballet on Feb. 2. After three viewings and two casts, I like it no better than before. On Saturday afternoon, though, the company revived Mr. Peck’s “Paz de la Jolla” (2014), a work not seen onstage since its initial season but the subject of the documentary “Ballet 422.” It looked fresher, deeper, more poetic than before.

headline: Hollywood’s Inclusion Problem Extends Beyond the Oscars, Study Says
abstract: The University of Southern California’s Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism finds that the film industry is still a “white, boy’s club.”
lead_paragraph: Men far outnumber women as directors, writers and industry executives. Minorities are drastically underrepresented in acting roles. Lesbian, gay and transgender characters are almost nonexistent. This is the portrait of an “epidemic of invisibility” in Hollywood described by researchers in a study released on Monday of more than 400 movies and scripted television series from 2014 and 2015.

headline: Joe Biden Argued for Delaying Supreme Court Picks in 1992

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As a senator more than two decades ago, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. argued that President George Bush should delay filling a Supreme Court vacancy, should one arise, until the presidential election was over, and that it was “essential” that the Senate refuse to confirm a nominee to the court until then.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Polls Show Bolivian Leader Losing Vote, but He Sees Tie
keywords: ['Referendums', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: President Evo Morales said that exit polls indicating the failure of a referendum to allow him to run for a fourth term in fact showed a statistical tie as a final count continued.
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — President Evo Morales of Bolivia said on Monday that he did not yet accept defeat in a contentious referendum to allow him to run for a fourth term, saying that despite the exit polls suggesting that it failed, the final vote count could still favor him.

headline: Leslie Ferraro, Disney’s Co-Chairwoman of Digital Media, Resigns
abstract: Ms. Ferraro’s resignation comes days after Paul Lee, the now-former president of ABC Entertainment, was fired. She took the role only nine months ago.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In the second major management shake-up at Disney in less than a week, Leslie Ferraro resigned under pressure on Monday as co-chairwoman of consumer products and digital media, a job she took only nine months ago.

headline: Truce, Cease-Fire and Armistice: The Legal Nuances
abstract: While the words evoke white flags and peace treaties, their definitions vary — and can be important to understanding ongoing conflicts.
lead_paragraph: Truce, cessation of hostilities, cease-fire, armistice — these terms are often used interchangeably these days, as if they were synonyms.

headline: F.D.A. Asks If Faulty Blood Monitor Tainted Xarelto Approval
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Blood Clots', 'Clinical Trials', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A legal brief says Johnson & Johnson has been asked whether Alere’s recalled INRatio blood-testing monitor compromised the anticlotting drug’s trial.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration is investigating whether a faulty blood-testing device may have compromised the results of a clinical trial that led to the approval of Xarelto, a blockbuster anticlotting drug that has been prescribed to millions of Americans since it arrived on the market in 2011.

headline: More Reason to Doubt Claim That Sanders Won Hispanic Vote in Nevada
abstract: New data from the entrance-exit poll gives additional reason to think Hillary Clinton might have captured the majority of the Latino vote.
lead_paragraph: The debate over who really won the Hispanic vote in Nevada, Hillary Clinton or Bernie Sanders, continues today. As I wrote Sunday, I think the balance of evidence points to Mrs. Clinton: Her strength in the heavily Hispanic areas of Las Vegas and among Hispanic voters in most national polls is, to my mind, much stronger evidence than an entrance/exit poll sample of 213 Hispanic respondents in 25 precincts.

headline: Legionnaires’ Outbreak in Flint Was Met With Silence
abstract: An examination of government emails and interviews shows a failure to act swiftly to address a dangerous health problem or warn the public.
lead_paragraph: FLINT, Mich. — It was the Fourth of July, a warm summer night in 2014, but Tim Monahan was shivering in a thick blanket as he watched fireworks from his front yard here. By the next afternoon his temperature had shot to 104.6, and doctors at the hospital he had checked into puzzled over what was wrong.

headline: Two Ranking Democrats to Offer Bill Aimed at Inversions
keywords: ['Corporate Taxes', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Tax Evasion']
abstract: Sander Levin and Chris Van Hollen’s bill would block a firm’s ability to use interest from debt payments by its American operations to its foreign parent company.
lead_paragraph: Two House Democrats plan to introduce a bill on Tuesday that would seek to curtail a strategy used by former American companies to cut their United States tax bills.

headline: Seeking iPhone Data, Through the Front Door
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'Privacy', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'iPhone', 'Computer Security', 'Cyberattacks and Hackers']
abstract: Apple argues that helping the F.B.I. gain entry to an iPhone will put customers’ privacy at risk. But they are undermining those customers’ safety.
lead_paragraph: THE government and Apple have chosen interesting ground on which to contest the limits of government access to data on mobile devices. The case involves an F.B.I. request for Apple’s assistance in opening a phone once carried by Syed Rizwan Farook, who with his wife was responsible for the terrorist attack in San Bernardino, Calif., that left 14 dead and 22 wounded.

headline: In Cairo, Alone Time With the Pharaohs
abstract: With a slump in tourism, you can enjoy the privilege of solitude at some of the world’s greatest historic sites in the chaotic metropolis of Cairo.
lead_paragraph: As I stood alone in the silent, darkened King’s Chamber of the Great Pyramid of Giza, staring into the sarcophagus that had been hollowed from red granite at least 4,500 years ago, my thoughts swirled.

headline: John E. Reinhardt, Ambassador and Head of U.S. Information Agency, Dies at 95
abstract: Dr. Reinhardt was the first black American ambassador to Nigeria, and the first career diplomat and first university educator to lead the information agency.
lead_paragraph: John E. Reinhardt, the first career diplomat to lead the United States Information Agency, died on Thursday in Silver Spring, Md. He was 95.

headline: The 911 Call After Mark Carson Was Shot
abstract: Shortly after midnight on May 18, 2013, Danny Robinson called 911 to report that his friend, Mark Carson, had been shot in the West Village.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after midnight on May 18, 2013, Danny Robinson called 911 to report that his friend, Mark Carson, had been shot in the West Village.

headline: Babysitter Questioned in Staten Island Boy’s Death
abstract: The grandmother of Anthony Delgado called 911 after a woman looking after him took the child, 16 months old, to his uncle, who found him unresponsive, the police said.
lead_paragraph: Investigators on Monday were questioning the babysitter of a 16-month-old boy who died on Staten Island over the weekend with visible signs of trauma on his body, the police said.

headline: Norwegian Air Flies in the Face of the Trans-Atlantic Establishment
keywords: ['AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Norwegian Air Shuttle has quietly established a beachhead in the trans-Atlantic market by offering low-fare, no-frills service on long-haul flights.
lead_paragraph: First there was Laker Airways. Then there was People Express. Both airlines shared a similar, if ultimately unsuccessful, goal: to bring low fares to the trans-Atlantic market.

headline: Atlantic City Officials Spurn Proposed Takeover by State
abstract: Mayor Donald Guardian called on lawmakers to reject legislation that would give the state control of the struggling city’s finances.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTIC CITY — Elected officials of this struggling gambling resort lashed out at Gov. Chris Christie and other New Jersey officials on Monday, calling their plan to take more control of the city fascist and hypocritical.

headline: United Technologies Declines Renewed Offer From Honeywell
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues']
abstract: The impasse between the two has halted, at least for now, the creation of what would be a nearly $150 billion industrial giant.
lead_paragraph: When the United Technologies Corporation approached Honeywell International about a merger late last spring, it appeared that a union of the two industrial giants could finally come to pass.

headline: Chief Justice Roberts Remembers Justice Scalia
abstract: The Supreme Court returned to the bench on Monday for the first time since the death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Feb. 13. Before hearing oral arguments on two cases, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. delivered this statement about his former colleague.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court returned to the bench on Monday for the first time since the death of Justice Antonin Scalia on Feb. 13. Before hearing oral arguments on two cases, Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. delivered this statement about his former colleague.

headline: Grief Gives Way to Division in First Court Arguments Since Scalia’s Death
abstract: While Justice Antonin Scalia’s eight colleagues were united in mourning last week, it took only hours for old divisions to re-emerge when the Supreme Court returned on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The day began with extended and sometimes wry reflections from Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. on the life and work of Justice Antonin Scalia, whose empty chair at the Supreme Court was draped in black. It ended with a liberal justice invoking events in Ferguson, Mo., and accusing a conservative colleague of being ignorant of facts in a case that could lead to “a police state.”

headline: Lee Stempniak, a Steady Veteran, Stabilizes the Devils
abstract: Entering Tuesday’s game against the Rangers, the Devils sit 3 points out of a playoff spot, and Stempniak, 33, is a key reason for their improvement.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — In a season of surprises for the Devils, Lee Stempniak may just be the biggest.

headline: Brock Nelson, a Prolific Scorer, Eases the Islanders’ Burden
abstract: Nelson has complemented the team’s perennial points leader, John Tavares, and taken some of the pressure off the team as it embarks on a tough stretch.
lead_paragraph: SYOSSET, N.Y. — The Islanders started their seven-game trip, the longest of their season, with a shutout of the Devils, but now the real road work begins.

headline: Donald Trump to Skip Panel Hosted by Megyn Kelly
abstract: Mr. Trump declined to participate in the Fox News panel, scheduled for Wednesday, the night before the next Republican debate, citing the last-minute invitation and prior commitments.
lead_paragraph: Megyn Kelly will host a two-hour “voters summit” broadcast special on Wednesday, but Donald J. Trump won’t be joining her.

headline: Voters Might Not Miss Jeb Bush, but Campaign Reporters Will
abstract: Jeb Bush was like a goofy dad, an awkward uncle. He spoke to children like adults and told jokes that made no sense. Jeb Bush ran a wildly imperfect campaign, but he remained impossibly human.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — By the time I was assigned to cover Jeb Bush, he was already becoming the exclamation point that couldn’t.

headline: Bubba Watson, a Candid and Sensitive Champion, Shows His Vulnerable Side
abstract: After winning the Northern Trust Open, Watson showed how much he continues to wrestle with the spotlight that comes with stardom, even as he shines in it.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Bubba Watson joked that when Jason Kokrak’s wife, Stephanie, sat across from Watson at breakfast in the Riviera clubhouse on Sunday, he told her: “You know, people don’t like me. You might not want to be seen near me.”

headline: Man Testifies How Night Out in the West Village Ended With Gay Slurs and a Friend’s Killing
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Danny Robinson testified that Elliot Morales pulled a gun on him and his friend, Mark Carson, on West Eighth Street and shot Mr. Carson.
lead_paragraph: The two gay men were walking along Sixth Avenue when a person passing by taunted them, calling them “gay wrestlers” and “faggots.”

headline: Mobs in Ukraine Attack Russian Banks in Burst of ‘Office Pogroms’
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Fires and Firefighters']
abstract: The branch offices of three Russian banks were firebombed or looted over the weekend, and some of the attacks by Ukrainian nationalists.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The branch offices of three Russian banks were firebombed or looted over the weekend, and some of the attacks were the work of Ukrainian nationalists.

headline: Consultant to Politicians in Brazil Faces Arrest
abstract: João Santana, a campaign strategist for the nation’s last two presidents, has been accused in the widening Petrobras corruption scandal.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Brazil’s huge corruption scandal involving the oil giant Petrobras widened on Monday after a federal judge issued arrest warrants for the country’s most influential campaign strategist who twice orchestrated the electoral triumphs of the country’s president, Dilma Rousseff.

headline: For Apple, a Search for a Moral High Ground in a Heated Debate
abstract: Is the company’s primary moral obligation to the help the government, protect its customers’ privacy or maximize profits for its shareholders?
lead_paragraph: What does it mean to be a good corporate citizen?

headline: Analysts Question Viability of Deep Tax Cuts Proposed by Republican Candidates
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Taxation', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'United States Economy']
abstract: The men running for president routinely denounce the current $14 trillion debt, but none has said how he would offset the revenues lost to his tax cuts.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The tax plans of the Republican presidential candidates would cut federal revenues as much as $12 trillion over a decade, a post-World War II record eclipsing the deep tax cuts of George W. Bush, Ronald Reagan and John F. Kennedy. And they would come just as America faces the costs of its aging baby-boom generation.

headline: Origin of Bullet That Struck New York Officer Remains Unclear, Police Say
abstract: Two officers shot during a gun battle in Brooklyn on Saturday survived, and investigators were looking at the possibility that one was hit by a bullet fired by a fellow officer.
lead_paragraph: Two police officers had stepped out of their car for a brief foot patrol in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, early Saturday when they heard the pop of a gunshot. A man drove by them with a gun in his hand, then made a U-turn and passed them again, police officials said.

headline: Woman’s Lawsuit Says DNA Proves Mt. Sinai Doctor Assaulted Her
abstract: The suit, filed in State Supreme Court, seeks monetary damages from the hospital and Dr. David H. Newman, whom she says sexual attacked her last month.
lead_paragraph: A woman who claimed last month that an emergency room doctor at Mount Sinai Hospital sexually assaulted her has filed a lawsuit stating there is DNA evidence to prove the assault.

headline: Russia Wants Closer Look From Above the U.S.
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: Russia has requested to upgrade the cameras it uses on sanctioned surveillance flights across the United States, which are part of a treaty.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia asked on Monday to fly surveillance planes equipped with high-powered digital cameras over the United States, fueling a long-simmering debate among Pentagon and intelligence officials over Russia’s intentions to use such flights to spy on American power plants, communications networks and other critical infrastructure.

headline: Shifting Game Plan: Think Small and Fire 3-Pointers
abstract: More conspicuously than in any previous year, small ball — loosely defined as a five-man lineup with just one big man — has taken over college basketball.
lead_paragraph: On a wintry afternoon in December, North Carolina, No. 11 at the time, took on a ranked U.C.L.A. team in Brooklyn without one of its two starting big men, Kennedy Meeks, who was laid up with a bruised knee. Making do, Coach Roy Williams started the 6-foot-11 backup Joel James in the frontcourt alongside Brice Johnson, a 6-10 senior.

headline: The Fizzling of Jeb Bush's Campaign
abstract: Ashley Parker, a Times political reporter, talks about covering Jeb Bush's 2016 presidential campaign, which ended Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Ashley Parker, a Times political reporter, talks about covering Jeb Bush's 2016 presidential campaign, which ended Saturday.

headline: Review: Eiko’s ‘Platform 2016,’ With a Class, a Film and More
abstract: A more dimensional portrait of the dancer and activist Eiko emerges when Danspace gives her license to add workshops and book clubs to her show.
lead_paragraph: One thing you might not know about Eiko, the veteran dancer, choreographer and activist at the center of Danspace Project’s “Platform 2016: A Body in Places”: She’s funny. Humor isn’t a quality I associate with her powerfully slow, often sorrowful work; if it’s there, it’s subtle. Last summer in Lower Manhattan, as part of a solo project also titled “A Body in Places,” she let her frail-looking body drift through the pedestrian traffic of Fulton Street Station in memory of the victims of Sept. 11. She looked like an angel, a ghost, a saint, certainly not one of us.

headline: A. J. Pierzynski, the Man They Love to Hate, Is Still Behind the Plate
abstract: Pierzynski, of the Braves, has a reputation for being abrasive but is now an elder statesman, approaching the top five on the career list for games caught.
lead_paragraph: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — He does not even bother knocking on the wooden frame of his locker stall at spring training. A. J. Pierzynski has made it this far, to the phase of his career when he plays strictly because he loves it. Of course he has been lucky. No need to ask for more.

headline: John Kasich Picks Up Another Billionaire Backer, Julian Robertson
abstract: The hedge fund titan Julian H. Robertson Jr., who founded Tiger Management, will help raise money for the campaign.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Va. — Gov. John Kasich’s campaign said on Monday that it had gained another billionaire supporter: the hedge fund titan Julian H. Robertson Jr.

headline: Off-Campus ‘Ghetto Party’ Condemned by Fairfield University
abstract: Posts on social media, claiming that students had worn brown makeup at the party, drew an angry response from the Connecticut university’s president.
lead_paragraph: FAIRFIELD, Conn. — A “ghetto”-themed party hosted off campus by students over the weekend set off a wave of discussion about race and a lack of diversity at Fairfield University, a mostly white Roman Catholic institution here.

headline: Joe Biden Speech From 1992 Gives G.O.P. Fodder in Court Fight
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Though remarks Mr. Biden made in 1992 are unlikely to stop the White House from submitting a nominee, Republicans appeared to gain an advantage in the looming battle.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans on Monday seized on a 1992 speech by Joseph R. Biden Jr., then a senator, in which he argued against any Supreme Court appointment during a presidential campaign, grabbing an early advantage in what is likely to be a protracted battle to replace Justice Antonin Scalia.

headline: Mets’ Rafael Montero, After Early Promise and Setbacks, Hopes to Regroup
abstract: Montero, who had cruised through the minors but essentially missed last season because of shoulder discomfort, is trying to regain the Mets’ trust.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Whenever the pitching coach Frank Viola gave Rafael Montero instructions during his time with the Las Vegas 51s in recent years, Montero would nod or acknowledge them in some nonverbal way. Montero was shy and not fluent in English, but Viola could tell by Montero’s body language and actions if he understood.

headline: The Magic Shop, a Venerable Recording Studio in SoHo, Will Close
abstract: After 28 years, a studio favored by Lou Reed and David Bowie, among many other famous musicians, will shut its doors next month.
lead_paragraph: The Magic Shop, a recording studio on Crosby Street in SoHo that was a favorite of Lou Reed, Norah Jones and David Bowie, who secretly recorded his last two albums there, will close next month after 28 years, a victim of a changed music business and a red-hot real-estate market.

headline: Yankees Willing to Hold Meeting With StubHub
abstract: The Yankees’ feud with StubHub over the team’s new ticket policies may have taken a turn toward cooling when StubHub’s president reached out to the Yankees’ president.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — The Yankees’ feud with StubHub over the team’s new ticket policies may have taken a turn toward cooling Monday, when StubHub’s president, Scott Cutler, reached out to the Yankees’ president, Randy Levine, who agreed to try to set up a meeting with Cutler.

headline: Review: In ‘Her Requiem,’ a Gifted Daughter and Her Two Warring Parents
abstract: In Greg Pierce’s new play at the Claire Tow Theater, a young composer’s great gift may come with costs for the entire family.
lead_paragraph: A precocious talent for musical composition proves to be as much a curse as a gift for the mostly unseen heroine of “Her Requiem,” a thoughtful, beautifully acted new play by Greg Pierce that opened at the Claire Tow Theater on Monday in an LCT3 production. As the title indicates, the composition in question is a requiem Mass – decidedly an ambitious undertaking for a woman of 17.

headline: Review: In ‘Angel Reapers,’ Torment and Bliss, Hand in Hand, Seek Connection
abstract: Martha Clarke and Alfred Uhry’s dance-theater piece follows a band of worshipers in stringent religion who are seeking refuge from worldly suffering.
lead_paragraph: Laughter breaks the meditative silence: Giggling that starts among the women leaps across the aisle to the men — black-suited, black-hatted, overcome with mirth.

headline: Often Said With a Smile
abstract: Elizabeth C. Gorski brings a bit of sweetness to our Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY PUZZLE — A delicious way to spend time on a Tuesday.

headline: PBS Is Creating a Channel Exclusively for Children
abstract: The 24-hour channel, PBS Kids, will be free and is expected to debut later this fall. It will also be available online with a live stream.
lead_paragraph: PBS is starting a new 24-hour channel dedicated solely to children’s programming.

headline: Review: ‘Smokefall,’ About Several Generations of an Eccentric Family
abstract: The characters’ lives in Noah Haidle’s comedy-drama are defined by their eccentricities and flights of odd lyricism.
lead_paragraph: Your appreciation of “Smokefall,” an enigmatic comedy-drama by Noah Haidle about several generations of an eccentric family, may boil down to your reaction to the dietary choices of the character Beauty, a 16-year-old girl who subsists on tree bark, newspapers, shoes, rocks and earth. All washed down with a nice big cup of paint. Oh, and for much of the play, she doesn’t speak a word.

headline: 24 Years Later, Joe Biden’s Words Haunt Democrats
keywords: ['Courts and the Judiciary', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Republicans pounced on a 1992 Senate speech that appeared to make the same argument against considering a Supreme Court nominee that they are making now.
lead_paragraph: When you are as voluble as Joseph R. Biden Jr. is, you are bound to say more than a few words that come back to haunt you. And some choice ones returned with a vengeance on Monday as the fight over the open Supreme Court seat began in the Senate.

headline: House Panel Confirms Inquiry Into Democrat
abstract: The House Committee on Ethics confirmed Monday for the first time that it was investigating Representative Alan Grayson, Democrat of Florida, who has been accused of violating House rules by operating a hedge fund while serving in Congress.
lead_paragraph: The House Committee on Ethics confirmed Monday for the first time that it was investigating Representative Alan Grayson, Democrat of Florida, who has been accused of violating House rules by operating a hedge fund while serving in Congress. The statement by the committee — which said it would continue to look into the matter until early April — also served as the first formal confirmation that the quasi-independent Office of Congressional Ethics had conducted a preliminary review and found reasonable grounds to conclude that Mr. Grayson had violated the rules. Mr. Grayson, who is a candidate for the Senate, set up the hedge fund in 2011, when he was not in Congress, and he has said he cashed out the outside investors in the last year. He has vehemently denied that he did anything wrong, but his own political aides urged him to close the hedge fund last year.

headline: Massachusetts: Cosby’s Wife Gives Deposition
abstract: Bill Cosby’s wife of 52 years, Camille, gave deposition testimony Monday in a civil case filed against him by seven women who say he defamed them, despite last-minute efforts by her lawyers to halt the deposition.
lead_paragraph: Bill Cosby’s wife of 52 years, Camille, gave deposition testimony Monday in a civil case filed against him by seven women who say he defamed them, despite last-minute efforts by her lawyers to halt the deposition. A lawyer for the women, Joseph Cammarata, said Mrs. Cosby had been questioned under oath for two and a half hours in a hotel in Springfield, Mass. Her deposition will continue March 14, Mr. Cammarata said. Mr. Cosby’s lawyers had sought to prevent Mrs. Cosby, 71, who was the entertainer’s business manager, from sitting for the deposition on a variety of grounds, and filed an emergency motion Saturday to delay it. But Judge Mark G. Mastroianni of United States District Court ruled Sunday that the deposition should go ahead, although Mrs. Cosby was not compelled to answer questions about her private conversations with her husband. Andrew Wyatt, a spokesman for Mr. Cosby, declined to comment. The civil case is separate from the criminal charges that Mr. Cosby, 78, faces in Pennsylvania, where a woman has accused him of sexually assaulting her in 2004.

headline: Knicks Summon Reinforcement but Fall Far Short of Raptors
abstract: Jimmer Fredette, who signed a 10-day contract with the Knicks, remained on the bench for much of the game. His only field-goal attempt cut Toronto’s lead to 21.
lead_paragraph: The Toronto Raptors arrived at Madison Square Garden on Monday night with two All-Stars in their starting lineup, a glowing record and an offense that was capable of creating shots from every conceivable angle.

headline: Jury Awards New York Firefighters $183 Million in 2005 Blaze
abstract: A State Supreme Court jury awarded the amount to five firefighters who battled a deadly Bronx fire and their families for damages from the city and the building’s owner.
lead_paragraph: It was a day in New York City that no firefighter could forget: Six of the department’s own, battling a blaze in a Bronx apartment building on a brutally cold Sunday in 2005, became trapped on the fourth floor, hemmed in by illegal drywall partitions and unable to find the fire escape.

headline: How Society Pays When Women’s Work Is Unpaid
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Families and Family Life', 'Working Hours']
abstract: Relative to women, men spend the most time doing chores in the Scandinavian countries, and the least time in India, Mexico, Turkey and Japan.
lead_paragraph: In countries around the world, the ways in which men and women spend their time are unbalanced. Men spend more time working for money. Women do the bulk of the unpaid work — cooking, cleaning and child care.

headline: ‘Better Call Saul’ Season 2, Episode 2: What’s Hoboken Got to Do With It?
abstract: Jimmy McGill has a permanent address in the realm of respectability but remains ready for piecework in the netherworld.
lead_paragraph: Let’s get straight to it: “Hoboken Squat Cobbler” is not a known, categorized sexual fetish. At least that was the case, according to the Internet, the day before the airing of this episode. No doubt the Urban Dictionary will fill this void soon.

headline: ‘The X-Files’ Season 10 Finale: Our Struggle
abstract: This short season ends on an incredibly disappointing note.
lead_paragraph: “This is the end,” read the title card, taking the place of “Trust No One” and “The Truth is Out There.” But can it actually be? We didn’t even get to see William. I know happy endings aren’t very X-ey, but come on!

headline: Donald Trump Says He’ll Release Tax Returns ‘at Some Point’
abstract: On the eve of Tuesday’s Republican caucuses in Nevada, where he is expected to do well, Donald J. Trump also criticized the caucus system, telling the radio host Hugh Hewitt, “I just think the caucus system throws wrinkles in it.”
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump said Monday that he would release his tax returns “at some point, probably,” after the radio host Hugh Hewitt pressed Mr. Trump about when he would make them available, warning that delaying in doing so had damaged Mitt Romney’s campaign in 2012.

headline: Chris Carter Expects More ‘X-Files,’ Definitely Reads Reviews
abstract: The creator of the show, which wrapped its revival on Monday with a surprise cliffhanger, says he expects the show to return, though no plans are set.
lead_paragraph: “I can tell you, almost without a doubt, we will come back.”

headline: Review: ‘For Claude Shannon’ Visualizes the Links Between Text and Movement
abstract: Liz Santoro and Pierre Godard’s dance, part of the Kitchen’s “From Minimalism Into Algorithm” series, looks like the output of a computer program .
lead_paragraph: When you walk into the Kitchen to watch “For Claude Shannon,” the work’s four dancers are already onstage, warming up. In addition to the usual limbering, though, they appear to be thinking especially hard, going over something in their heads. According to the program note, that’s exactly what they’re doing: preparing to perform a long and complicated dance they’ve only just learned.

headline: Review: In ‘Playing to the Edge,’ Michael V. Hayden, Bush-Era Spymaster, Defends His Record
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Mr. Hayden, a former director of the C.I.A., gives his opinions and settles some scores in his new book.
lead_paragraph: According to Michael V. Hayden, President George W. Bush personally intervened in 2005 to try to stop The New York Times from publishing an explosive scoop.

headline: Obama to Visit Florida Factory to Polish Stimulus’s Legacy
keywords: ['American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009)', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: President Obama will speak in Jacksonville at the Saft America battery plant, which opened in 2011 after a $95.5 million government investment.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Friday will visit a lithium-ion battery plant built with federal money from the economic stimulus package he pushed through Congress in 2009, part of a broad White House effort to highlight the measure’s success stories during his final year in office.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | zealot
abstract: This word has appeared in 10 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: zealot • \ˈze-lət\ • noun

headline: Google to Shut Down Its Comparison-Shopping Website
abstract: The move to shutter Google Compare marks a shift from a foray into selling financial products like insurance, according to people who work with the company.
lead_paragraph: Google is shutting down its Google Compare comparison-shopping site, marking a retrenchment from the search giant’s foray into selling financial products like insurance and credit cards, according to a spokeswoman and partners who work with the company.

headline: What to Watch Tuesday
abstract: Ridley Scott goes on “a blissed-out cosmic high” in “The Martian.” Sammy Hagar burns rubber with Dan Rather. And “Frontline” examines the country’s heroin epidemic.
lead_paragraph: Ridley Scott conjures what Manohla Dargis of The New York Times called “a blissed-out cosmic high” in his Oscar best-picture nominee, “The Martian.” Sammy Hagar takes Dan Rather for a spin in his LaFerrari. And “Frontline” examines the nation’s heroin epidemic.

headline: Corrections: February 23, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, February 23, 2016.
lead_paragraph: BUSINESS DAY

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, February 23, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “Accountability has to be laid on somebody’s lap. I want answers; I want to know why.”

headline: Donald Trump on Protester: ‘I’d Like to Punch Him in the Face’
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: On the eve of the Nevada caucuses and what could be Mr. Trump’s third consecutive victory in the Republican race, a demonstrator who Donald J. Trump said had thrown punches at security guards really got under the candidate’s skin.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed in real time the Republican Nevada caucuses.

headline: London Fashion Week: Coming to an End
abstract: The final day includes Marques’Almeida, Amanda Wakeley, Christopher Raeburn and Ashley Williams.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — London Fashion Week comes to an end on Tuesday, with the biggest buzz surrounding the noon show from Marques’Almeida, the 2015 winner of the LVMH Young Designer’s Prize. The Portuguese pair, who are based in East London, have been making waves with their radical reinventions of denim in recent seasons, so all eyes will be on the brand.

abstract: The Smithsonian’s Museum of African American History and Culture has acquired Bill Adler’s extensive archive of hip-hop photos.

headline: This Is What A Real Wall Street Shill Sounds Like

He wants to get rid of Dodd-Frank with no replacement, and wants to eliminate all taxes on capital income.
