headline: Photographing Hip-Hop’s Golden Era
abstract: The Smithsonian’s Museum of African American History and Culture has acquired Bill Adler’s extensive archive of hip-hop photos.
lead_paragraph: Before today’s corporate-sponsored arena concerts and big-money endorsement deals, there was a time in hip-hop when its stars were not far from the people and places that gave rise to the culture. LL Cool J could go to a high school in East Harlem and perform to an adoring crowd, or DMC could hang out in Hollis, Queens, and chill out by an ice cream truck.

headline: Three Views of Marriage
abstract: We make our decisions about matrimony by looking through several lenses: the psychological, the romantic and the moral.
lead_paragraph: Two years ago the Northwestern University psychologist Eli Finkel had an article in The Times describing how marriage is polarizing: The best marriages today are better than the best marriages of generations ago; the worst marriages now are worse; over all, the average marriage is weaker than the average marriage in days of yore.

headline: Relying Again on an Unreliable Mr. Putin
abstract: The Russian president, eager to restore glory to his nation, holds many of the cards in Syria but should not confuse that for respect for his power.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to imagine a conflict more in need of a cease-fire than the cruel violence that has ravaged Syria, killing almost half a million people and displacing millions. Though one sincerely hopes otherwise, it is equally hard to imagine that the truce negotiated by the United States and Russia has much chance of achieving more than a brief respite from the killing. One reason is the extraordinary web of conflicting interests and agendas involved in this struggle, and the warring parties have to buy in to make the truce work.

headline: The Plan to Shut Down Gitmo

headline: The Secret to School Integration

headline: Kenyans Reacquire an Old Taste: Eating Healthier
abstract: In colonial times, diets and agricultural work focused on corn and rice, alongside produce grown elsewhere. Health-consciousness is now restoring nutritious local fruits and vegetables to Kenyan tables.
lead_paragraph: In the 1950s and ’60s, governments in Africa and Asia started subsidizing the production of staple crops like rice and corn because it was the fastest way to fill bellies and reduce starvation in those regions. Today, needs have changed: The problem is no longer chronic hunger but malnutrition, and the solution is not more calories, but better calories.

headline: Notes From Psychiatry’s Battle Lines
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Psychiatry and Psychiatrists', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: I’m both a clinician and a historian of my field. It’s not as easy as it sounds.

As a clinical psychiatrist, I begin my day in a room filled with soothing art and soft leather chairs, where my pharmaceutical prescriptions and psychological interventions are intended to meet the pressing needs of my patients. Here, I’m supposed to have answers, or at least that’s the hope.

headline: 1916: An Eyewitness at Verdun
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A correspondent describes the scene of battle at Verdun in 1916.
lead_paragraph: One hundred years ago, on Feb. 21, 1916, the famous Battle of Verdun began, pitting French soldiers against the German army. It was one of the bloodiest battles of World War I: It lasted almost ten months, and caused an estimated 300,000 fatalities. In March 1916, the European edition of The New York Herald published an eyewitness account of Verdun, written by the correspondent Herbert A. Gibbons. Here are a few excerpts:

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Capitalism (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Campaign Finance', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Corporations']
abstract: Despite fierce anti-big-business sentiment among many Republican voters, no candidate has emerged to champion them.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, in the first draft of my book “A Capitalism for the People,” I had a section dedicated to how worrisome a Donald J. Trump presidential bid would be for America. I was not prescient. It’s just that having grown up in Italy, I knew how a real estate tycoon — in this case, Silvio Berlusconi — whose career exemplified crony capitalism could become the leader of supposed pro-market forces, and I knew what it meant for the country.

headline: A Young Ukrainian Designer Cheerfully at Home in Milan
abstract: The 25-year-old Marianna Senchina has emerged as one of the city’s names to watch.
lead_paragraph: It’s easy to feel rapturous about Milan at the Casa Galimberti, an Art Nouveau building richly painted with women posing under fruit trees. Sitting in the cafe on the ground floor on a recent afternoon, Marianna Senchina, a 25-year-old designer from Ukraine, is upbeat about the much-maligned city. “Milan is full of beauty, but it’s in the details,” she says, taking a quick sip of her espresso. “People here enjoy the minute aspects of daily life — eating, conversation, dressing — even elderly women love to dress impeccably, maybe more than anyone else in the city.”

headline: 1916: Massive Attacks Near Verdun
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: The French were holding off the German onslaught at Verdun in 1916.
lead_paragraph: Two things are evident from the French official communiqués issued yesterday: first, that the German offensive north of Verdun has developed into an important battle over a forty-kilomètre front; second, that French troops are holding their ground with magnificent courage and inflicting enormous losses upon the enemy’s very large effectives. Fighting of the most desperate and murderous description took place yesterday between Malancourt and Étain, and certain German units were killed to a man. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Feb. 24, 1916

headline: European Tech Scene Begins to Feel Silicon Valley’s Woes

The communal kitchen hums with 20-something developers. A gold-painted scooter, which the co-founder William Shu once used to make deliveries, stands in the center of the office as people bustle about.

headline: Landmark Status Is Urged for 30 New York City Properties
abstract: The Landmarks Preservation Commission voted not to seek the designation for dozens of others, in clearing a backlog that began to grow in the ’60s.

They are among 30 properties scattered across the five boroughs that the Landmarks Preservation Commission, at a marathon meeting on Tuesday, decided were worthy of protection.

headline: Little Pepper Packs More Than Heat in College Point
abstract: For diners seeking nuance as well as powerful flavors in Sichuan dishes, a trip to northern Queens is in order.
lead_paragraph: Little Pepper began life a dozen years ago in the competitive Chinese nucleus of downtown Flushing, Queens. Five years ago, Cheng Ying Wu and her husband, Gui Ping Huang, the owners, moved it northwest to College Point, where its nearest rival is a graffiti-scrawled storefront across the street selling takeout chop suey and chow mein. Little Pepper is not entirely free of American Chinese food, but its pork lo mein is not one of its chief attractions.

Putin, with the Kremlin strong-arming itself into a pivotal role in the Middle East, Ukraine floundering and the European Union developing cracks like a badly glazed pot.

headline: The Latest in Science Fiction and Fantasy
abstract: A family on the margins threatened by a comet, a prolific mother shot by Castro’s troops, civil war in a land of almonds and myrrh, and a city populated by insects.
lead_paragraph: In a typical young adult disaster novel, society col­lapses and survival depends on a young woman’s guts (and maybe her ability to pick a good love interest). Yet too often the world seems to end, and to exist, only for pleasantly middle-class communities, nuclear families and otherwise “normal” people by the standards of American media: white, straight, cisgender, abled and at least well-off enough that square meals aren’t rare. Everybody else is mysteriously gone long before the apocalypse comes.

headline: Old Hollywood Buildings Get Makeovers and Turn ‘Creative’

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The former prop house at 720 North Cahuenga Boulevard was once old Hollywood. Into the 1990s, it housed props from police shows like “Hill Street Blues.”

headline: ‘Until There Is Justice,’ by Jennifer Scanlon
abstract: Anna Arnold Hedgeman’s lifelong fight for civil rights.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Scanlon’s biography of the African-American activist Anna ­Arnold Hedgeman, who died in 1990, is long overdue. Over her career, Hedgeman pushed for civil rights legislation with Martin Luther King Jr.; pressured New York City politicians to make good on their promises for equal opportunity in housing, employment and education; and featured prominently in national politics, serving as the Democratic Party’s strategist for organizing the black vote in the 1948 election, and as an appointee in health and human services after World War II. Her feminism informed her decision to be a founding member of the National Organization for Women (NOW), yet she also sustained ties with the more moderate National Council of Churches. Nevertheless, despite her influence, Hedgeman remains relatively unknown.

headline: Ben Carson Says Obama Can’t Identify With Black Experience Because He Was ‘Raised White’

There’s the temptation to glorify the atmosphere, to overromanticize the drinking or the salt-of-the-earthiness of the patrons. There’s the idea that everything about drunks and drinking has ­already been written perfectly by Bukowski, so forget it.

headline: When in Bangkok, Consider a Thai Tattoo
abstract: The spa at the Siam Hotel now offers an unusual service: custom ink.
lead_paragraph: After years of shuttling guests to Buddhist temples to be inked by monks trained in an ancient style called sak yant, the Siam Hotel decided to invite a former monk named Ajahn Boo to set up a studio in its spa. According to sak yant tradition, the design and placement of these enduring souvenirs — believed to offer mystical powers, protection and luck — are mostly in the hands of the tattooer. The American tattoo artist Scott Campbell recently experimented with a similar concept, offering free tattoos to anyone willing to blindly put their arm through a hole in a wall and accept whatever he created.

headline: Estela Owners Branch Out With Café Altro Paradiso
abstract: Also, the Brooklyn Kitchen grows; Missy Robbins opens a cafe and takeout spot next to Lilia; Covina is coming from Tim and Nancy Cushman; and more.
lead_paragraph: Café Altro Paradiso The airy, generously windowed, high-ceilinged space for the new restaurant from Ignacio Mattos and Thomas Carter is a far cry from Estela, their railroad flat overlooking East Houston Street. Though thoroughly Italian, with 1930s modern light fixtures copied from the main post office in Palermo, Sicily, it also suggests a welcoming Parisian brasserie, all in keeping with its Art Deco-era building. Like the setting, Mr. Mattos’s cooking respects tradition (“It’s the foundation for the classics,” he said) but allows him to go lighter at many junctures. One example he cited is his amatriciana, which uses lardo in place of guanciale and spaghetti alla chitarra instead of bucatini. Also on the menu are a fennel salad with olives and provolone, mushroom and onion fritto misto with lemon; and grilled swordfish with artichokes, raisins and almonds. Mr. Mattos covers Italy from north to south, including the liver-and-onion classic fegato alla Veneziana: 234 Spring Street (Avenue of the Americas), 646-952-0828, altroparadiso.com.

headline: What Roles Get Black Actors to the Oscars?
abstract: Here’s a look at roles performed by black artists who have been nominated for a best actress or best actor Oscar — and what they have in common.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a look at roles performed by black artists who have been nominated for a best actress or best actor Oscar — and what they have in common.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Dark, Romantic — and Lacy
abstract: Preen by Thornton Bregazzi, Alexander McQueen and Erdem all showed sheer looks with a goth edge.
lead_paragraph: Goth was all over the runway in New York — and the trend popped up again in London, but with a romantic touch. At Preen by Thornton Bregazzi (left), the designers Justin Thornton and Thea Bregazzi showed a tulle and silk dress layered over a pair of sequin hot pants. at Alexander McQueen (right), Sarah Burton included a sweet sheer cocktail number with a Victorian collar and billowy sleeves. And at Erdem (center), a floor-sweeping look, made out of different panels of sheer fabrics, was stitched with embroidered flowers.

headline: In Court, Man Accused of Hate-Crime Killing Blames the Victim
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Hate Crimes', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Elliot Morales said in the second day of his trial in the murder of Mark Carson, a gay man, that Mr. Carson could have avoided his death.
lead_paragraph: Danny Robinson remained resolute as he sat in the witness box in a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday and fielded a barrage of questions from Elliot Morales.

headline: Race in America: Your Stories

lead_paragraph: A series of videos featuring personal stories that reflect the breadth of experiences in the United States.

headline: Review: Iggy Pop Salutes David Bowie at Tibet House Concert
abstract: He covered Mr. Bowie’s “The Jean Genie” and waxed reflective at a benefit that also featured Philip Glass, Sharon Jones, Basia Bulat and FKA twigs.
lead_paragraph: Iggy Pop turned the 26th annual Tibet House U.S. Benefit Concert into a full-fledged rock show at Carnegie Hall on Monday night. When the band started the blues shuffle of David Bowie’s “The Jean Genie,” the audience was eager to dance, clap, whoop and sing along, and soon there was a rush of fans down the aisles. For a Carnegie crowd, it was the equivalent of a riot.

headline: Judiciary Committee Letter Opposing Supreme Court Hearings
abstract: Republican senators on the Judiciary Committee sent this letter to the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, vowing not to hold hearings on a nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia.
lead_paragraph: Republican senators on the Judiciary Committee sent this letter to the Senate majority leader, Mitch McConnell, vowing not to hold hearings on a nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia.

headline: Seize the Morning: The Case for Breakfast
abstract: A little early effort in the kitchen can pay big dividends for the rest of the day.
lead_paragraph: I used to work nights. You can draw that card at a newspaper, same as you might in a hospital or police station, in a factory or a financial house doing business in markets that hum while the rest of America sleeps. I did not cook dinner much then. Night work makes cooking dinner more than a chore. Often, it makes it impossible.

lead_paragraph: Greece and Elsewhere — Pictures of the Day

headline: Nudges Aren’t Enough for Problems Like Retirement Savings
keywords: ['Economics (Theory and Philosophy)', 'Retirement', 'Savings', 'Poverty', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Ideas drawn from psychology are helping Americans make better economic choices, but they fail to address problems in areas like retirement savings.
lead_paragraph: Why don’t Americans save more for old age? Even when their employers promise to match their savings, workers often fail to salt away their earnings for the future, inexplicably leaving money on the table.

abstract: Photos from Greece, Russia, Spain and Italy.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Greece, Russia, Spain and Italy.

headline: 30 Years After Revolution, Some Filipinos Yearn for ‘Golden Age’ of Marcos
abstract: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., son of the former dictator, is leading his family’s political resurgence as the outrage that led to the 1986 “People Power” revolution fades.
lead_paragraph: MANILA — As Filipinos prepare for the 30th anniversary on Thursday of the “People Power” revolution that toppled Ferdinand E. Marcos, the Marcos family legacy is undergoing a political renaissance by those who claim it was a “golden age” of peace and prosperity.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Jason Stallman, Choe Sang-hun and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: Fernando Cardenal, Nicaraguan Priest Who Defied Pope, Dies at 82
abstract: Steeped in a movement committed to a Marxist agenda of promoting social justice and easing poverty, Father Cardenal joined the revolutionary Sandinista cabinet.
lead_paragraph: The Rev. Fernando Cardenal, a son of privilege who embraced Latin America’s poor as a revolutionary priest and brazenly defied Pope John Paul II’s order to quit Nicaragua’s leftist cabinet in the 1980s, died on Feb. 20 in Managua. He was 82.

headline: TodayTix Makes Inroads Into Broadway’s Ticketing Business
abstract: The company, which 26 months ago introduced a mobile app for selling discounted and full-price last-minute tickets, is poised to expand.
lead_paragraph: A theater industry start-up that is trying to corner a share of the byzantine Broadway ticketing business has raised nearly $16 million in venture capital and has expanded beyond New York to four other American cities and to London.

headline: Review: ‘The Lonely City,’ a Personal Study of Urban Isolation
abstract: This Olivia Laing book is partly a memoir, partly a critic’s look into visual artists whose productions speak to her heartsick sense of solitude.
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible to walk for long in New York City without passing someone who looks sad and alone and shrunken, like a snail that’s been salted. Some days, you suspect you are that snail.

headline: Viacom Says It Will Sell a Stake in Paramount
abstract: The identity of the investors and the value of the deal remain unclear.
lead_paragraph: Viacom announced on Tuesday that it was pursuing a deal to sell a minority stake in its Paramount Pictures film and television studio after being approached by several strategic investors.

headline: Review: Maria Hassabi’s ‘Plastic’ Sends Dancers Crawling Through MoMA
abstract: This super-slow work unfolds across the Marron Atrium and down two staircases as curious museumgoers look on.
lead_paragraph: It takes about 15 seconds, walking at a relaxed pace, to descend the stairs leading from the atrium of the Museum of Modern Art to the ground-floor lobby. On Sunday afternoon, the dancer Oisin Monaghan spent over an hour on that route, sliding down the steps through a glacial series of reclining, prone and seated poses. Visitors came and went, with some pausing to study his often-motionless body — was he sleeping? injured? — and others passing by unfazed. When he reached the bottom, he stood up and walked away. The next day, he would do it again.

headline: India’s Literary Festivals Multiply Amid Anxiety Over Free Expression
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Festivals', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: A festival in Jaipur drew 330,000 people, testifying to the popularity of what is proving to be a lightning rod for politics and emotions.
lead_paragraph: JAIPUR, India — Literary notables including Margaret Atwood, Aleksandar Hemon and Thomas Piketty came to this northern city toward the end of January, appearing before large crowds at the Diggi Palace, an 18th-century complex temporarily filled with tents, food kiosks and bookstores. Some 330,000 people showed up, breaking the attendance record and once again making the Jaipur Literature Festival the largest event of its kind in the world.

headline: A Composer and His Wife: Creativity Through Kink
abstract: Georg Friedrich Haas’s productivity has dramatically increased now that he’s the dominant figure in a dominant-submissive power dynamic.
lead_paragraph: The OkCupid message Mollena Williams received in December 2013 was, in some ways, standard. It was complimentary: “Wow — your profile is great.” It was confident: “I am an artist, very successful (probably member of the top 10 or 20 in my genre in the world).” It was polite, signing off with “warm wishes.”

headline: As News Media Changes, Bernie Sanders’s Critique Remains Constant
abstract: The candidate has for decades been critical of major outlets for what he calls their quest for profit and for not covering issues he deems important.
lead_paragraph: More than three decades before he became a familiar face on Sunday morning shows, cable television news and the late-night comedy circuit, Bernie Sanders made no secret of his contempt for commercial TV.

headline: The Rest of the World Gets a Breather as Republican Presidential Candidates Attack One Another
abstract: Ted Cruz, Donald Trump and Marco Rubio hurled insults at each other ahead of Tuesday’s Nevada caucus and Thursday’s debate.
lead_paragraph: Immigrants, Muslims, Syrian refugees and the poor got a relative pass this week as the Republican presidential front-runners instead attacked one another.

headline: Review: In ‘The Last Class: A Jazzercize Play,’ Clutching to the Past
abstract: This comedy by Megan Hill, a real-time dance class of sorts, delves into a fight against Zumba.
lead_paragraph: “My students are my success!” the Jazzercise instructor cries as they move to the music. “My students are my success!”

headline: The Model Whose Lips Spurred Racist Comments Speaks Out
keywords: ['Models (Professional)', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Discrimination', 'Social Media', 'New York Fashion Week']
abstract: A post on MAC’s Instagram feed, featuring a close-up of a black model’s full lips, caused a firestorm on social media.
lead_paragraph: By the time New York Fashion Week wrapped up late last week, the model Aamito Lagum, 23 years old and a native of Kampala, Uganda, had walked the runway for J. Mendel, Tadashi Shoji, Kanye West’s Yeezy line and Ohne Titel, even winning a coveted spot as the show closer for Zac Posen.

headline: JPMorgan Tries to Calm Investors on Its Outlook and Oil Defenses
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: The bank forecast another record profit this year and good tidings for the United States economy. But its stock still dropped 4 percent.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase executives painted a positive picture of the American economy and the bank’s business at their annual investor day, but they failed to beat back the pessimism that has battered bank shares and the broader stock market in recent months.

headline: Chinese Deals Feel the Chill From Washington
keywords: ['Foreign Investments', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: As Chinese companies look to get more currency out of China by buying American companies, the United States’ Committee on Foreign Investment’s review of those deals is coming under scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: As growth slows at home, more and more Chinese companies are looking to do deals in the United States. And they are increasingly running smack into the American national security apparatus.

headline: Fired M.T.A. Driver Rode Off in Bus After Being Told Not to Smoke, Police Say
abstract: Charita Headley, 34, climbed behind the wheel of the M101 bus she was riding when another bus came to take over the route in East Harlem, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: Charita Headley was fired months ago from her job as a bus driver in New York City. Still, it appears, she had not forgotten what to do when, the police said, she climbed behind the wheel of a bus on Tuesday and drove off.

headline: T.S.A. Lapses, Retaliation and Bonuses Are Investigated by House Panel
abstract: The inquiry began after employees who reported security problems were punished for reporting problems and managers that ignored the reports received bonuses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A congressional committee is investigating allegations that the agency in charge of airport security retaliated against employees who reported security lapses and awarded bonuses to supervisors who ignored their warnings.

headline: Anxious for Re-Election, Senator Richard Shelby Refuses to Act on Banking Nominations
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: A quest for a sixth term has stalled the work of the Senate banking committee, which has not approved any of President Obama’s 16 nominees.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As the Senate banking committee convened earlier this month to listen to testimony from Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, Senator Sherrod Brown of Ohio, the highest-ranking Democrat on the committee, all but dusted off the chairs and shook moths from the curtains.

headline: Against Barcelona, Arsenal Gives Up 2 Goals and Possibly All Hope
abstract: Away goals weigh heavily on every Champions League matchup, and Barcelona’s advantage may seem out of reach for a team that has failed to score against weak competition.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — More than 50 years ago, European soccer’s governing body instituted a quirky regulation designed to break ties in the two-game, home-and-home aggregate series that are so common in soccer. The away-goals rule, as it has become known, is, on the surface, quite simple: If two teams score the same number of goals over two games, the team that scores more away from home advances.

headline: Barbara M. Clark, New York Assemblywoman, Dies at 76
abstract: Ms. Clark, a Democrat and the Assembly’s deputy majority whip, made public education her signature issue over three decades in Albany.
lead_paragraph: Barbara M. Clark, a New York assemblywoman from Queens who made public education her signature issue over three decades in Albany, died on Monday in New Hyde Park, on Long Island. She was 76.

headline: The Devil in Ted Cruz
abstract: He makes angelic claims about his conduct and campaign. But he’s diabolically hypocritical.
lead_paragraph: When Ted Cruz announced this week that he was firing his campaign’s communications director for circulating a false insinuation that Marco Rubio had belittled the Bible, he told reporters, “Even if it was true, we are not a campaign that is going to question the faith of another candidate.”

headline: Centerview Partners Hires Jack Levy, Formerly of Goldman

abstract: Mr. Levy, an established mergers and acquisitions banker, will become a partner at Centerview, a boutique investment bank.
lead_paragraph: Centerview Partners, one of the most prominent boutique investment banks, has drawn another longtime deal maker to its ranks.

headline: Told to ‘Take the Gloves Off,’ John Kasich Says the Race Is Out of His Hands
abstract: “I don’t know if my purpose is to be president,” Gov. John Kasich of Ohio said, suggesting he is not sure he will win.
lead_paragraph: SANDY SPRINGS, Ga. — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio is adamant: He is finally getting the attention he craved in the presidential race, and he is not going anywhere. But he is also open about something else: He does not know if he is going to prevail.

headline: Where to Put Sewage Tank Snags Gowanus Canal Cleanup
abstract: Federal officials favor a location under the city-owned Thomas Greene Playground, but some angry park users are opposed.
lead_paragraph: The neighborhoods around the Gowanus Canal, widely considered the country’s dirtiest waterway, have been waiting decades for it to be cleaned up, and that seemed to be coming when the government designated the 1.8-mile canal a federal Superfund site in 2010.

abstract: The pop singer and her onetime mentor are fighting in court while their fans trade words on Twitter. What’s at stake, and what comes next?

lead_paragraph: As the Supreme Court faces the increasing prospect of having an eight-member bench for a year or more, Justice Samuel A. Alito Jr. said on Tuesday that “we will deal with it,” noting that the court has had an even number of members in the past.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department is demanding Apple’s help in unlocking at least nine iPhones nationwide in addition to the phone used by one of the San Bernardino, Calif., attackers.

headline: Phillies Count on Patience to Pay Off Before Long
abstract: After a 99-loss season, Philadelphia’s management is continuing to rebuild the club in the hopes that it can rejoin baseball’s elite teams, though not necessarily this year.
lead_paragraph: CLEARWATER, Fla. — The Philadelphia Phillies hold the first overall pick in the draft this June. The last time they had it, in 1998, they chose outfielder Pat Burrell. Ten years later, Burrell doubled to start the go-ahead rally on the night the Phillies won the World Series.

keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Confessions', 'News Sources, Confidential Status of']
abstract: The reporter, Frances Robles, has been subpoenaed to appear at a pretrial hearing for Conrado Juárez, who is accused of killing 4-year-old Anjélica Castillo in 1991.

lead_paragraph: A playlet in four acts, set in the Drama Book Shop, 250 West 40th Street, near Eighth Avenue, starring A BURST PIPE as the villain, and LIN-MANUEL MIRANDA, the creator of “Hamilton,” as one of many heroes.

lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — It has been less than a week since Aroldis Chapman arrived at spring training, but his indoctrination into what it means to be a prominent New York athlete under scrutiny has been swift and relentless.

headline: Babysitter Accused of Killing Staten Island Boy
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Gloria Fields, 31, was also charged with crimes including assault and sexual abuse against Anthony Delgado, who was 16 months old.
lead_paragraph: A babysitter has been charged with murder in the death of a 16-month-old boy she had been caring for on Staten Island over the weekend, the police said on Tuesday.

headline: Alabama Is Piling Up Victories, and No, It’s Not the Football Team
abstract: The Crimson Tide are 16-11 thanks to a multimillion-dollar investment and the hiring of Avery Johnson, who is pursuing athletes he might shape into the kind of player he was.
lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — The University of Alabama basketball program is on the other side of a high fence from the Alabama football program.

headline: Review: ‘The Body of an American’: Ties Created by War
abstract: Dan O’Brien’s play examines his friendship with the photojournalist Paul Watson after Mr. Watson won a Pulitzer for images of a dead American soldier.
lead_paragraph: Dan O’Brien’s “The Body of an American,” a lyrical, untidy and ultimately poignant work of theater is a ghost story. It is also a true story.

headline: Review: In ‘Dot,’ a Fading Matriarch Brings a Family Together
abstract: Colman Domingo wrote and Susan Stroman directs this comedy-drama about a woman with Alzheimer’s and how her family tries to adjust.
lead_paragraph: One minute, Dotty’s eyes are clear, and her mind is as steely sharp as her tongue. A minute later, clouds seem to shroud those big, bright peepers, and she has the bewildered look of a toddler who’s lost track of her mother at the mall. Dotty (Marjorie Johnson), the widowed matriarch of a black middle-class family from Philadelphia, is 65, and although she mostly avoids directly admitting it to anyone — sometimes even to herself — she has Alzheimer’s.

headline: Goes Underwater
abstract: Ruth Margolin’s Wednesday puzzle gives us a great opportunity to discuss how to crack a theme.
lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — I don’t know about you, but I knew this fun, midweek puzzle by Ruth Margolin was going to be trouble for me as soon as I had difficulty solving 1 Across. That kind of thing will shake the confidence of even a veteran solver, but we have a lot of new solvers joining us every day, so let’s talk about it.

abstract: Donald J. Trump was declared the winner of the Nevada G.O.P. caucuses on Tuesday night, according to The Associated Press.

headline: With Lawsuit Dropped, a Divisive Rodeo Season Is Expected
abstract: Elite Rodeo Athletes, a fledgling rodeo circuit that plans to start a season tour in March, dropped an antitrust suit against the Pro Rodeo Cowboys Association.
lead_paragraph: A fledgling rodeo circuit with many of the country’s top riders and ropers dropped its antitrust lawsuit against the Pro Rodeo Cowboys Association on Tuesday, a move that promises to leave the sport divided this season by competing factions.

headline: Bonnie Raitt on Time, Loss and Renewal on ‘Dig in Deep’
abstract: For every bittersweet ballad on her new soul-rattling album, there’s a steamrollering groove. Ms. Raitt took a break from rehearsing for a tour for an interview.
lead_paragraph: “The Ones We Couldn’t Be,” the final track on Bonnie Raitt’s soul-rattling new album, “Dig in Deep,” is a rueful hymn to what might have been. “My glass is raised for all the ways/We tried to get it right,” she sings, sifting through the remnants of a relationship that could be romantic or familial.

headline: Blind Chinese Man’s Guide Dog Is Returned
keywords: ['Dogs', 'Robberies and Thefts', 'Service Dogs and Other Animals']
abstract: Attached to the dog, Qiaoqiao, was a note asking for forgiveness.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A blind man’s guide dog that had been stolen in Beijing, drawing an unusual amount of police and media attention, was found Tuesday evening with a note attached asking for forgiveness, its owner said.

headline: Gabrielle Giffords Joins Hillary Clinton in South Carolina to Pay Tribute to Victims of Gun Violence
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Mrs. Clinton returned to South Carolina on Tuesday night for the first time since her victory in the Nevada caucuses and paid tribute to victims of gun violence and police misconduct as she campaigned before the state’s Democratic primary.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — A plainly confident Hillary Clinton returned to South Carolina on Tuesday night for the first time since her victory in the Nevada caucuses and paid tribute to victims of gun violence and police misconduct as she campaigned before the state’s Democratic primary.

headline: Bolivia’s President, Evo Morales, Faces Setback in Bid for Fourth Term
abstract: An official tally, with 97 percent of the ballots counted, showed that voters had rejected a bid by President Evo Morales to seek a fourth term.
lead_paragraph: LA PAZ, Bolivia — An official tally issued on Tuesday by Bolivian election officials showed that President Evo Morales had failed in his quest to run for a fourth term.

headline: Takata Faked Test Data a Year After Airbag Recalls, Report Says
keywords: ['Falsification of Data', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: A Senate report showed Takata officials presenting falsified test data about the design of a new component, illustrating what investigators called a pattern of deceit.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after defective Takata airbags led to recalls and at least two fatalities, company officials in Japan presented falsified test data about a new component’s design to Honda, their largest customer, according to internal documents.

headline: 'The People v. O.J. Simpson’ Episode 4: The Rise of Cochran
abstract: Robert Shapiro huffs and puffs, but can’t stand up against the other members of the “dream team.”
lead_paragraph: Didn’t O. J. Simpson have so much fun in the early ’90s? Dancing in formation to C+C Music Factory in a club, snorting lines of cocaine off women’s breasts, flooding the V.I.P. area with Robert Kardashian and all of their new club friends. It’s almost too bad a trial for double murder ruined all of his fun. At least, that’s what this flashback was meant to illustrate — the stark contrast between O.J.’s formerly opulent life and his currently bleak prison situation. Instead it has me asking: Who eats oysters in a dance club?

headline: Sergey Kalinin Helps the Devils Fortify Their Playoff Bid
abstract: Kalinin, who is in his first N.H.L. season, scored a goal, had an assist and got into a fight as the Devils crawled to within 1 point of the last Eastern Conference playoff berth.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Sergey Kalinin had a smile on his gnarled face and a bright red cut trailing down his nose after he scored a goal, had an assist and got into a fight in the Devils’ 5-2 victory on Tuesday over the Rangers at Prudential Center. He said he knew he had notched a “Gordie Howe Hat Trick.”

headline: Ukraine Sings Its Frustration With Russia
abstract: The Ukrainian entry in the 2016 Eurovision song contest is the latest example of popular protest music aimed at Russia.
lead_paragraph: War, revolution and resistance to Russian interference has inspired Ukrainian popular music for decades, creating a national soundtrack of proud anthems, but also lamentable pap.

headline: Ebola Drug Shows Signs of Efficacy in Small Clinical Trial
abstract: ZMapp, a potential treatment for Ebola, seemed to prevent death in its first rigorous trial, but researchers said the results were not conclusive.
lead_paragraph: The drug ZMapp, viewed as perhaps the most promising potential treatment for Ebola, seemed to prevent death from the disease in its first rigorous clinical trial, researchers reported on Tuesday.

headline: Hollywood Legal Battle Erupts Over Facial Animation Technology
keywords: ['Movies', 'Inventions and Patents', 'Copyrights and Copyright Violations', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Start-ups']

lead_paragraph: A technology used to animate the faces of digital superheroes in “Deadpool” and “Avengers: Age of Ultron” is at the center of a legal battle that may cause some superheadaches in Hollywood.

headline: Philip Knight of Nike to Give $400 Million to Stanford Scholars
keywords: ['Endowments', 'Colleges and Universities', 'Scholarships and Fellowships', 'Philanthropy', 'Graduate Schools and Students', 'Poverty', 'Global Warming']
abstract: The gift from Philip H. Knight, a co-founder of Nike, will make the new Knight-Hennessy program one of the largest fully funded scholarship endowments in the world.
lead_paragraph: Philip H. Knight, the co-founder and chairman of Nike Inc., said on Monday that he had pledged to give Stanford University $400 million to recruit graduate students around the globe to address society’s most intractable problems, including poverty and climate change.

headline: Word of the Day + Quiz | writ
abstract: This word has appeared in 108 New York Times articles in the past year.
lead_paragraph: writ • \ˈrit\ • noun

headline: Nepal: Plane Carrying 23 Is Missing
abstract: A passenger plane carrying 23 people lost contact minutes after takeoff and is missing in mountainous territory, officials here said.
lead_paragraph: A passenger plane carrying 23 people lost contact minutes after takeoff and is missing in mountainous territory, officials here said. The plane, a Tara Air flight from Pokhara to Jomsom, took off at 7:50 a.m. and vanished 11 minutes later, said Pavan Gautam, an air traffic controller at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu. Mr. Gautam said two helicopters had been deployed for search and rescue operations. Among the 23 people on board were two infants, he said.

headline: End an Unfair Restriction on College Aid

abstract: A draconian law denying government grants and loans to people with even a minor drug offense should be repealed.

headline: ‘Echo Echo,’ by Marilyn Singer
abstract: A new picture book presents ingenious poems about Greek mythology that can be read in both directions.
lead_paragraph: Marilyn Singer’s ingenious “reverso” poems are child-friendly feats of verbal pyrotechnics: They can be read from the top down or the bottom up, with just small changes of punctuation and capitalization. Reading in each direction yields a completely different meaning and point of view. Singer keeps the poems to a dozen or so mostly short lines, some just one word long, so they look spacious on the page and are easily accessible to younger child readers. Her first two collections, “Mirror Mirror” and “Follow Follow,” retold classic fairy tales. Now she’s plunging into Greek mythology with “Echo, Echo,” and the results are just as much fun, no matter the age of the reader. The economical summary of each myth at the bottom of the page is a special bonus for those of us who can never quite keep straight certain crucial details and plot lines. After spending time with this book, I may never again confuse Eurydice and Persephone.

Amid the keepers of the pit-masters’ flames are a few pioneers, like Atlanta’s Ben and Jennifer Johnson, who see the wave of revitalization as a chance to integrate newer dining trends and foreign flavors into their city.

headline: 1941: London Rehearses Gas Attack
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: London holds a mustard-gas attack drill in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — London had its first test alarm with real but non-lethal gas today [Feb. 24]. Air-raid precautions workers splashed a small quantity of diluted mustard gas in a roped-off section of Pimlico, and then went to work to demonstrate how the various units would function in case of a real gas alarm. For several hours the wrecked section of the street, from which the public was barred, was filled with grotesque masked figures clothed in anti-gas uniforms — rubber capes, trousers, boots and gloves, tin helmets and the all-important gas mask. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 25, 1941

headline: 1966: Wilson Bars ‘Spy’ Exchange
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Prime Minister Harold Wilson rejects a spy exchange with the Soviet Union in 1966.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Harold Wilson was reported today to have rejected a jailed Briton in exchange for Peter and Helen Kroger, two Americans serving 20 year sentences in Britain for spying for the Soviet Union. An authoritative source said the Russians made the suggestion for the exchange through diplomatic channels. Specifically they asked that a British lecturer, Gerald Brooke, detained for five years on charges of helping to distribute anti-Soviet propaganda, should be swapped for the Krogers, whose real names are Lona and Morris Cohen. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 25, 1966

headline: Inside “Tom House: Tom of Finland in Los Angeles”
abstract: The artist’s home is the subject of a new book out in early March from Rizzoli.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s home is the subject of a new book out in early March from Rizzoli.

headline: This Spring, All About Robert Mapplethorpe and Tom of Finland
abstract: A two-part retrospective, an HBO documentary and a new book celebrate the artists, who eventually became friends.
lead_paragraph: In her memoir “Just Kids,” Patti Smith recounts a day in the 1960s when she and her then-boyfriend Robert Mapplethorpe scoured the used-paperback stalls of Times Square, looking for inspiration. “Robert,” she writes, “found a few loose pages from a portfolio of sketches of Aryan boys in motorcycle caps by Tom of Finland.” Touko “Tom of Finland” Laaksonen’s work — stylized drawings of hypermasculine gay figures that turned postwar gay stereotypes on their head — would come to have a great impact on Mapplethorpe’s famously explicit photographs of male nudes, which were at the center of the culture war of the late ’80s and early ’90s. (Jesse Helms famously waved them on the Senate floor as an argument against public funding for the arts.)

headline: The Outcome of the Landmark Meeting
abstract: New York City’s Landmarks Preservation Commission took a step toward deciding the fates of 95 properties that have been stuck in limbo.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s Landmarks Preservation Commission took a step toward deciding the fates of 95 properties that have been stuck in limbo.

headline: A New Home for Pace Gallery in Palo Alto
abstract: The gallery will extend its reach in Silicon Valley with a new facility to open in April.
lead_paragraph: For the last two years, the Pace gallery has used a former Tesla showroom in Menlo Park, Calif., to showcase technology-driven or innovation-heavy installations in what they called a “pop-up gallery.” Exhibitions have featured work by Alexander Calder, Tara Donovan and the Japanese group teamLab.

headline: Make Breakfast.
abstract: A call to arms: Make your own yogurt, grind your own coffee, try a savory oatmeal bowl and more.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: Review: School of Seven Bells Has a Final Album With a Sad Back Story
abstract: “SVIIB” sets among its tones one of optimistic promise. Benjamin Curtis, the group’s producer, died in 2013.

headline: Aroldis Chapman Unlikely to Be Barred During Yankees’ Preseason
abstract: Any suspension of Yankees reliever Aroldis Chapman under baseball’s domestic violence policy is unlikely to begin before opening day, a baseball official said.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Any suspension of Yankees reliever Aroldis Chapman by Commissioner Rob Manfred under Major League Baseball’s domestic violence policy would be unlikely to begin before opening day, according to a baseball official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

headline: Bernie Sanders Ties Hillary Clinton to Poverty Caused by Welfare Reform
abstract: Senator Bernie Sanders began his day of campaigning by criticizing Hillary Clinton’s support of welfare reform in 1996, accusing her of backing legislation that ultimately increased poverty levels and led more Americans to face economic anxiety.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont began his day of campaigning Wednesday by criticizing Hillary Clinton’s support of welfare reform in 1996, accusing her of backing legislation that ultimately increased poverty levels and led more Americans to face economic anxiety.

abstract: The new festival, devoted to minority-group writers, will have its debut on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Bare Lit Festival, which is devoted to minority writers, will have its debut Friday in central London.

headline: Questlove Tries His Hand at Housewares
abstract: The musician designed the Lazy Strobe, his take on a Lazy Susan.
lead_paragraph: Ahmir “Questlove” Thompson knows a thing or two about tables that turn. It’s fitting, then, that the Roots frontman’s first non-music, non-sneaker-related design takes the form of a Lazy Susan. The idea came to him after the Les Ateliers Courbet founder Melanie Courbet brought a rotating tray to one of Thompson’s so-called “food salons”; they partnered on a set of handcrafted round, black-and-white inlaid Corian meant to resemble the strobe disks employed by D.J.s to ensure a perfect 33 and 1/3 r.p.m.

headline: Profile in Style: Questlove
abstract: The musical polymath talks about his (several) other passions, his unintentional signature look and what obscure music genre he’s collecting now.
lead_paragraph: The musical polymath talks about his (several) other passions, his unintentional signature look and what obscure music genre he’s collecting now.

headline: Questlove on His Signature Look — and What He’s Collecting

lead_paragraph: The musical polymath talks about his (several) other passions, his unintentional signature look and what obscure music genre he’s collecting now.

headline: U.S. Asks Tech and Entertainment Industries Help in Fighting Terrorism
abstract: The White House summoned executives from social media and entertainment to Washington for talks on countering recruiting efforts by extremists.
lead_paragraph: Obama administration officials met with executives of major technology and entertainment companies in Washington on Wednesday to discuss combating the activities of violent extremists online, according to industry and government officials.

headline: One Is Not Enough: 3 Fellows Named to Honor David Carr’s Legacy
abstract: Bill Brink, The Times’s media editor, discusses the search for the first recipients of the David Carr Fellowship, a new position in honor of The Times’s former media critic.
lead_paragraph: The applications, more than 600 of them, came from all over the world, and from every corner of journalism. A magazine writer in Nigeria who focused on the exploitation of women. A computer data specialist from Texas. A videographer in Colombia and a documentarian in Myanmar. Undergraduates from Duke, Temple and Iowa State.

headline: With E.U. Paralyzed, 10 Nations Try to Stem Migrant Flow
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'International Relations']
abstract: The moves came as Europe prepares for another surge in people fleeing war and poverty in the Middle East and beyond.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — Austria and nine Balkan states on Wednesday agreed on several measures to choke off the flow of refugees from Greece, effectively imposing their own response to the migrant crisis while the European Union has been paralyzed over what to do.

headline: ‘I’m Mad Today...’ Andrew Rosenthal on Gitmo and Trump. And the Good News.
abstract: The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, on the news: the good, the bad and what makes him mad.
lead_paragraph: “I’m mad today about the fact that the United States Senate and United States House of Representatives are about to miss an opportunity to close down the Guantánamo Bay prison camp,” says The Times’s editorial page editor, Andrew Rosenthal, in this short podcast on the news: the good, the bad and the most maddening.

headline: Texas Court Dismisses Criminal Case Against Rick Perry
abstract: The former governor was indicted by a grand jury in 2014 on two felony counts of coercing a public servant and abusing his power.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The highest criminal court in Texas dismissed a case against former Gov. Rick Perry on Wednesday, apparently ending the long-running abuse-of-power accusations that dogged Mr. Perry during his failed run for the Republican nomination for president. In its ruling, the court tossed the one remaining charge against Mr. Perry and upheld the previous dismissal of a second charge by a lower court.

headline: Treating Incontinence in Women with Osteoporosis
abstract: Incontinence can prevent women with osteoporosis from exercising. Now new research shows simple muscle exercises can significantly reduce leakage.
lead_paragraph: Many women with osteoporosis also suffer from incontinence. Now a Canadian clinical trial has found that simple pelvic floor muscle training can significantly reduce leakage episodes.

headline: Gucci’s 70 Shades of Renaissance
abstract: After lunch hosted by Italy’s prime minister, fashion week opened to Alessandro Michele’s signature smorgasbord: filling, but not entirely satisfying.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — It began with some boosterism and a success story; with lobster and lamb’s lettuce and lots of chiffon. Political power met economic power in a tag-team display of mutual appreciation as the big guns came out for the first day of Milan Fashion Week. Then Alessandro Michele, the creative director of Gucci, put some silk poppies on top.

headline: Lessons From Game Theory: What Keeps Kasich in the Race?
abstract: The two remaining mainstream candidates — Marco Rubio and Mr. Kasich — are living out a problem studied for decades in game theory.
lead_paragraph: The Republican establishment has a problem. It is headed for a car crash.

headline: Marco Rubio Gets Party’s Blessing, but Not Voters’
abstract: Mr. Rubio’s time is quickly running out, according to even his own supporters, who are offering increasingly candid assessments of his chances.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio has persuaded wealthy donors, Republican Party elders and his colleagues in Congress that he represents their best chance to overtake the seemingly invincible force that is Donald J. Trump.

headline: A Radical Idea to Rebuild a Shattered Libya: Restore the Monarchy
abstract: After years of turmoil and frustration with the United Nations peace process, some suggest that a king can rescue the country.
lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — The deserted royal palace here, hidden behind locked gates and an overgrown garden, stands as a monument to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s virulent rejection of Libya’s monarchy.

headline: Senate Republicans Lose Their Minds on a Supreme Court Seat
abstract: Republicans have parked themselves so far to the right for so many years that it’s not clear if they can hear how deranged they sound.
lead_paragraph: Following the death of Justice Antonin Scalia, Senate Republicans apparently believe they can profit by creating a political crisis that the nation has never seen before. On Tuesday, the leadership doubled down on its refusal to take any action on any nominee from President Obama to replace Justice Scalia.

lead_paragraph: Small overseas firms often feel helpless against American regulators, some of which render edicts after opaque and secretive processes.

headline: Israeli Soldiers Accidentally Kill Army Officer While Trying to Stop Attack
keywords: ['Palestinians', 'Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides']
abstract: The soldiers were aiming at a Palestinian assailant who was trying to stab the officer, who was shot in the chest, the Israeli military said.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Israeli soldiers accidentally shot an army officer in the West Bank on Wednesday while they were trying to thwart an attempted stabbing, the Israeli military said. The officer, who was hit in the chest, died of his wounds.

headline: Pennsylvania Governor, Tom Wolf, Says He Has Prostate Cancer
abstract: Gov. Tom Wolf announced that he had a treatable form of the cancer and that he would keep serving during several months of treatment to come.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tom Wolf of Pennsylvania has a treatable form of prostate cancer that was “thankfully detected early,” he announced on Wednesday. He will continue to serve as governor while undergoing treatment that will last several months.

headline: At Yosemite, a Waterfall Turns Into a Firefall
abstract: For at least a few more days, Horsetail Fall has a chance to glow like lava for 10 splendid minutes around sunset.
lead_paragraph: For a few weeks in February if the conditions are just right, for about 10 minutes around sunset, one waterfall in Yosemite National Park looks more like its opposite — a firefall.

headline: New York City Can Require Sodium Warnings, Judge Rules
abstract: The National Restaurant Association had sought to halt a measure requiring chain restaurants to warn customers about high salt levels in menu items.
lead_paragraph: Saying “information is power,” a judge on Wednesday upheld a measure in New York City requiring some restaurants to warn consumers about high levels of sodium in foods.

headline: Storms Batter the South
abstract: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida spoke in the aftermath of a severe weather system that tore through the South, spurring tornadoes in his state and in Louisiana. Storms continued to threaten the East Coast on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Scott of Florida spoke in the aftermath of a severe weather system that tore through the South, spurring tornadoes in his state and in Louisiana. Storms continued to threaten the East Coast on Wednesday.

headline: My Firsthand Encounter With Donald Trump’s Free Media Machine
keywords: ['Campaign Finance', 'News and News Media', 'Political Advertising', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Television']
abstract: A New York Times reporter who covers campaign finance offers a close-up take on how Donald J. Trump is able to get all that free attention. With this unusual campaign, it’s not so much where the money is, but where the money isn’t.
lead_paragraph: The other day, a host on MSNBC asked me if Donald J. Trump had a good enough campaign operation to win in Nevada. One thing Mr. Trump had going for him, I pointed out, was that he was very good at getting the news media to give him free airtime.

headline: Swedish Aid Group Seeks Inquiry Into Afghan Hospital Raid

abstract: The Swedish Committee for Afghanistan asked for an independent investigation into the raid in which, it said, three people were killed.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — A Swedish aid group has demanded an independent investigation of a raid on a hospital in Afghanistan last week in which it said that three people, including a boy, were summarily executed by Afghan forces who were accompanied by NATO troops.

headline: Dr. Robert Califf Wins Senate Confirmation to Run F.D.A.
keywords: ['Pain-Relieving Drugs', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic']
abstract: Dr. Califf’s nomination had been delayed at the request of a Democratic lawmaker unhappy with the agency’s oversight of painkiller drugs known as opioids.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s pick to run the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Robert M. Califf, was finally confirmed for the job by the Senate on Wednesday, in a vote of 89 to 4, after weeks of opposition from a handful of lawmakers who had blocked his nomination over what they said was the agency’s poor record on prescription painkillers.

headline: Getting YouTube Stars to Sell Your Product

lead_paragraph: YouTube influencers are a sought-after breed. One word from these connoisseurs of cool, these heralders of hipness, and traffic to a website or store soars, products fly off shelves and brands become blockbusters overnight.

headline: The Best Apps for Delivering Celebrity News
abstract: As the 88th Academy Awards fast approaches, here are a few ways to keep up with the latest news in the entertainment industry.
lead_paragraph: Everyone loves a bit of celebrity-watching, and the Oscars give us plenty of excuses to do so. One great way to keep on top of all the gossip is through an app, and there are plenty of them out there catering to our curiosity about the Academy Awards and the entertainment industry.

headline: Shadow of Human Rights Abuse Follows Contender in FIFA Vote
keywords: ['Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Torture', 'Soccer']
abstract: Critics want to know if Sheikh Salman bin Ebrahim al-Khalifa had any connection to the jailing and torture of Bahraini athletes who protested his family’s rule in 2011.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — Nothing has rocked international soccer quite like the waves of arrests made across several continents last year as the United States announced bribery and corruption charges against the men running the sport, the world’s biggest and richest. But as the organization that governs global soccer gathers this week to choose a new president, a leading contender risks stirring up another source of controversy for the sport: human rights.

lead_paragraph: The label’s latest collection.

headline: Classic English-Made Shoes for Men, Without the Heft
abstract: The designer Paula Gerbase is bringing new life to the beloved British shoemaker John Lobb, while retaining codes from its 150-year history.
lead_paragraph: As a woman who designs men’s wear, Paula Gerbase has grown accustomed to being perceived as a novelty ­— especially since her 2014 appointment as the first-ever artistic director of the beloved 150-year-old British shoemaker John Lobb. But Gerbase is no gimmick: She grew up fascinated by Savile Row’s legacy and the way men build their wardrobes, and spent the first six years of her career designing bespoke men’s suiting. At John Lobb, she’s brought a keen eye to the house’s archives. The lightweight, unlined suede shoes in her new spring collection reject the idea that English-made footwear must be hefty — but retain classic codes like buckles, hidden stitching and overlaid saddles.

headline: Looking On the Bright Side of Trump
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Tea Party Movement']
abstract: Why the G.O.P. (if not necessarily the country) might bounce back from Trumpism.
lead_paragraph: No, folks, I’m not retracting any of my “it won’t be Trump” predictions just yet, but in the interest of staying au courant with my fellow pundits in the wake of last night’s Nevada steamrolling let’s stroll for a moment in a world where Donald Trump actually wins the nomination. Michael Brendan Dougherty has a good column on all the ways that this would be a disaster for the conservative movement — how it would weaken the influence of conservatism’s major institutions (by exposing how “inessential” their ideas and imprimatur are to actually winning power in the G.O.P.), how it would turn the right’s personnel and policy minds against one another (some would throw in with Team Trump, others wouldn’t, and the recriminations would be vicious), and how it would create a particular crisis for the pro-life movement, because Trump’s “conversion on the issue is far less convincing than those of previous nominees like Mitt Romney or George H.W. Bush,” and one way or another his nomination would probably guarantee that genuinely anti-Roe justices would be “reduced to a tiny rump on a consolidated, progressive Supreme Court.”

headline: Sara Maino at Italian Vogue: ‘Highlighting’ Emerging Designers
abstract: As senior editor in charge of the magazine’s New Talents initiatives, she searches the world for fashion finds.
lead_paragraph: “You will rarely see me at the big shows, those blockbuster events with a starry front row. That is really not my scene,” Sara Maino, senior editor at Italian Vogue and scion of one of the most powerful families in Italian fashion, said on the eve of fashion week. Her aunt (and boss) is Franca Sozzani, the longtime editor in chief at Italian Vogue, and her mother is Carla Sozzani, founder of the Milan super-boutique 10 Corso Como.

headline: I Don’t Drink Coffee. Should I Start?
abstract: Though coffee has been linked to a variety of health benefits, experts stop short of recommending it for everyone.
lead_paragraph: As someone who doesn’t drink coffee, I’m sometimes forced to ponder whether I’ve escaped an unhealthy addiction or if I’ve just been asleep my whole life.

headline: Sedition Arrests in India Inflame Old Free-Speech Tensions
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Treason and Sedition', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Constitutions', 'Hinduism', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: As charges follow a student protest, a historic ambivalence about the right to unfettered expression collides with party politics and Hindu nationalist roots.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Over the years, the thousand-acre campus of Jawaharlal Nehru University has seen too many protests by its leftist student body to count, most of them petering out without incident. But one staged this month seems to have struck a raw nerve.

headline: British Panel Focuses on Tennis’s Self-Policing
abstract: Tennis officials answered questions from a British parliamentary committee on Wednesday about the sport’s ability to regulate itself amid concerns of match fixing.
lead_paragraph: Nigel Willerton, head of the Tennis Integrity Unit, told a British parliamentary committee Wednesday that he would recommend that tennis’s anticorruption program have greater independence from the sport’s governing bodies in the future.

headline: Obama’s Scotusblog Post: Reading Between the Lines
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Here are some translated highlights from the president’s summary of what he is seeking in a Supreme Court nominee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama’s Wednesday morning post on Scotusblog was more notable for the forum than for its message, which we have heard before as he considers a nominee to replace Justice Antonin Scalia. But it was nonetheless a valuable summary of what Mr. Obama is looking for in a justice as well as a glimpse of his view of the constitutional responsibilities of the president and the Senate.

headline: The FIFA Longshots: Prince Ali, Monsieur Champagne and Mr. Sexwale

But there are three other candidates in the race. Here is a look at where they stand, how they faltered and what might come next:

headline: Review: In ‘Prey,’ Rosie Cavaliero Takes Up a Pair of Pursuits

lead_paragraph: Rosie Cavaliero would seem to be the star of “Prey,” a fairly entertaining British crime series making its debut on BBC America on Thursday. Her picture is on the website, and she’s the only actor who appears in all six episodes. But she’s not, exactly — she receives second billing to two different men, John Simm (Episodes 1-3) and Philip Glenister (4-6).

headline: Donald Trump, Addressing Evangelicals, Questions John Kerry’s Familiarity With the Bible
abstract: Not only did the secretary of state “obviously” not read Mr. Trump’s 1987 best-seller on business, but he also “probably” hasn’t read the Bible either, the candidate said in an interview with Pat Robertson at an evangelical university.
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. — Donald J. Trump is certain that Secretary of State John Kerry has not read his 1987 best-seller on business.

headline: Forget President: The More Important FIFA Vote Is on Reforms
abstract: A new president alone won’t bring about much change in the current system, but the proposed reforms are exactly what the soccer organization needs to right itself.
lead_paragraph: FIFA will hold two important elections on Friday at its latest all-expenses-paid gathering in Zurich. Most of the attention will be on the second vote, to pick the organization’s new president. Fans, though, should pay closer attention to the first one.

lead_paragraph: GULFPORT, Miss. — Gov. John Kasich of Ohio vowed Wednesday to remain in the Republican race, declaring himself the party’s only hope of defeating Donald J. Trump.

abstract: We teamed up with The Wirecutter to determine the best methods for preventing your phone from going dark.
lead_paragraph: Ashlei Temeña’s family trip to Disneyland last Thanksgiving break turned into a nightmare when her smartphone battery hit empty.

keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']

lead_paragraph: SEMINOLE, Okla. — The plunging price of crude has inflicted pain in the Oklahoma oil patch, and now it is threatening to take out the smallest of the small operators, those that have survived decades of booms and busts.

headline: Donald Trump Keeps Winning. Here’s What Could Make Him Lose.
abstract: His path to the Republican presidential nomination appears wider than ever, but it could contain pitfalls and roadblocks.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has snatched three straight victories, built a powerful lead in national polls and knocked several opponents out of the 2016 presidential race. His path to the Republican nomination looks wider than ever. But it could still contain pitfalls and roadblocks. Here are some of the ways he could still stumble.

headline: Amazon Puts Spotlight on ‘The Fashion Fund’
abstract: Furla lets you get personal, Apiece Apart and Dieppa Restrepo are teaming up on a sample sale, and more.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Amazon Fashion will unveil a shopping destination featuring the spring collections of the 2015 CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund contenders just in time for “The Fashion Fund” Series 3 premiere on the Internet retailer’s streaming service. You’ll find sweet picks like a Jonathan Simkhai radial gingham dress ($445), Brother Vellies ankle-strap sandals ($435) and a Gypsy Sport mixed media cap ($132) from the three winners, and items from all of the remaining seven finalists. At amazon.com/FashionFundShop.

headline: John Gleeson, Prominent Judge, Said to Be Joining Debevoise & Plimpton
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: Judge Gleeson, who oversaw the government’s deferred-prosecution agreement with HSBC, is known for something of a maverick streak.
lead_paragraph: John Gleeson, a prominent federal judge and former prosecutor who handled one of Wall Street’s biggest criminal cases, is set to become a partner at Debevoise & Plimpton, according to people briefed on the matter.

headline: Review: Rita Wilson’s Peaceful Easy Feeling
abstract: Ms. Wilson, at Café Carlyle, sings original songs from her new album that evoke musicians like Joni Mitchell, Linda Ronstadt and the Eagles.
lead_paragraph: Some say it is never too late to be what you might have been. And if you’re a performer with the drive and resources of Rita Wilson, whose new show opened at Café Carlyle on Tuesday night, that hope is not just a fantasy but a real possibility. Many of us live, at least some of the time, in the musical dream world of our teenage years. And for Ms. Wilson, that place is the Southern California lotus land of the ’60s and ’70s distilled in songs heard on a car radio.

headline: Following a Punjabi Indian Family, a Missing Distinguished Novelist and More
abstract: New books by Sathnam Sanghera, Idra Novey, Tony Tulathimutte, Belinda McKeon, Hannah Tennant-Moore and Nicola Gardini.
lead_paragraph: By Sathnam Sanghera

headline: Jeb Bush Apologizes to Donors for Failure of His Campaign
abstract: A tired-sounding Jeb Bush apologized to his major financial backers in a brief conference call, saying he never expected his presidential campaign to end so early, and in such disappointment.
lead_paragraph: A tired-sounding Jeb Bush apologized to his major financial backers in a brief conference call on Wednesday afternoon, saying he never expected his presidential campaign to end so early, and in such disappointment.

lead_paragraph: Macedonia and More — Photos of the Day

lead_paragraph: As a young Pakistani-American Muslim girl growing up in Connecticut, Zareen Jaffery used to devour novels by Beverly Cleary and Judy Blume, hoping those stories would offer some clues for how to fit in.

abstract: Photos from Macedonia, Greece, Syria and Italy.
