headline: Crossing Borders, Confronting Boundaries
abstract: Azam Ahmed discusses some of the ethical quandaries he faced while reporting on migrants in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: There are different ways to cover a story about migrants. Sometimes you interview people about their experiences and talk to officials, then stitch together an article with composite perspectives and experiences told secondhand.

headline: Mitt Romney Says Donald Trump Should Release His Tax Data
abstract: Mitt Romney emerged from political hibernation on Wednesday and issued a challenge Donald J. Trump: Show us your taxes.
lead_paragraph: Mitt Romney emerged from political hibernation on Wednesday and issued a challenge to Donald J. Trump: Show us your taxes.

headline: Credit Unions Turn Borrowers Into Savers
abstract: The “Borrow and Save” concept, which ties small loans to savings accounts, is especially aimed at helping customers with low and moderate incomes.
lead_paragraph: Saving money by taking out a loan may sound counterintuitive, but a program offered by some credit unions is aimed at having consumers do just that.

headline: Senate Republicans and the Supreme Court: Where Is This Headed Exactly?
abstract: A conversation between Emily Bazelon of the magazine and John Fabian Witt of Yale Law School.
lead_paragraph: Hi, John,

headline: Escape to California in Style
abstract: Luckily, laid-back Cali-vibes can be secured without ever setting foot on a plane — not that any of the items here wouldn’t be best enjoyed if you did.
lead_paragraph: Luckily, laid-back Cali-vibes can be secured without ever setting foot on a plane — not that any of the items here wouldn’t be best enjoyed if you did.

headline: Review: BalletBoyz Get Ready to Rumble
abstract: The troupe, directed by Michael Nunn and William Trevitt, presents its very physical version of dance at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Few dance troupes are named more informatively than BalletBoyz. When the Royal Ballet principal dancers Michael Nunn and William Trevitt founded the company in 2000, they called it George Piper Dances, but the distinctive appeal indicated by the nickname they eventually adopted was already evident. They prefaced their performances with short, demystifying films in which they appeared as ordinary blokes with cheeky senses of humor. Then they danced with gorgeous, far-from-ordinary technique.

headline: Review: Animal Collective, in Joyful Pursuit of Sensory Overload
abstract: The long-running band performed Tuesday at Irving Plaza in support of “Painting With,” a slimmed-down album that differs from their live sound.
lead_paragraph: Build it up, take it apart. Fatten it up, slim it down. A long-running band develops a history and reacts against it — especially a band as self-conscious about sound as Animal Collective, which has just released its 11th full-length album since it emerged in 2000, “Painting With” (Domino).

headline: The Might-Have-Beens of Marijuana
abstract: Former Attorney General Eric Holder now says he supports reclassifying marijuana. But marijuana enthusiasts want to know why he didn’t push for the change while in office.
lead_paragraph: Former Attorney General Eric Holder, in a newly released interview conducted after he left office, said he was in favor of reclassifying marijuana as something less than a Schedule I controlled substance comparable to heroin. This was hailed as encouraging news by marijuana enthusiasts who immediately asked why Mr. Holder didn’t push for this change when he was running the Justice Department.

headline: Review: ‘Pandemic’ Explains How to Host the Perfect Pathogen Party
abstract: Sonia Shah’s book examines the assorted factors that contribute to the rapid spread of diseases, focusing in particular on cholera as an example.
lead_paragraph: Sometimes, the best approach to a book about deadly pathogens is to read it in a slightly dissociated state — it allows you to marvel at the cunning adaptability of microbial life, rather than contemplate the far creepier possibility of your own doom. In her introduction to “Pandemic: Tracking Contagions, From Cholera to Ebola and Beyond,” Sonia Shah, a science writer whose previous books include “The Fever” and “The Body Hunters,” does not seek shelter in euphemisms or shy away from scary numbers. Instead, she cites a study in which 90 percent of epidemiologists say they believe a global pandemic will sicken one billion and kill up to 165 million within the next two generations.

headline: How Mario Batali Does Breakfast
abstract: The chef’s first new restaurant in a decade, La Sirena, is also his first to offer all-day service.
lead_paragraph: Depending on who you ask, Chelsea’s Maritime Hotel could be seen as proof of the architect Albert C. Ledner’s inspired vision — or a monolithic monument to 1960s kitsch. Originally designed as a hiring hall for the National Maritime Union, the 11-story, porthole-adorned tower has since served as a shelter for runaways and as housing for the New York Service Center for Chinese Study Fellows, before opening as a fashionable hotel in 2003.

headline: Roberto Cavalli: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Peter Dundas shows his fall collection for Roberto Cavalli.
lead_paragraph: Peter Dundas shows his fall collection for Roberto Cavalli.

headline: Review: Mariinsky Ballet in ‘Raymonda,’ Searching About for a Perfect Suitor
abstract: The corps will perform eight programs in three cities in a week, highlighted by this Marius Petipa three-act ballet, at the Kennedy Center.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Is the Mariinsky Ballet of St. Petersburg breaking records this week? I hope so. Between Monday and this coming Sunday, it is to perform eight programs in four theaters, in three cities on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Mr. Purple, a Trendy Hotel Bar on the Lower East Side
abstract: It’s the kind of place where fashionable features like “reclaimed wood” and “small-bath spirits” feel warmed over.
lead_paragraph: Follow any trend to its exhausted end, and you may end up at Mr. Purple, a lounge on the 15th floor of the Hotel Indigo on the Lower East Side. It’s the kind of place where buzzwords like “reclaimed wood,” “small-batch spirits” and “regionally brewed craft beer” feel like PowerPoint concepts introduced in a focus group.

headline: Carla Hayden Nominated to Head Library of Congress
keywords: ['Libraries and Librarians', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Dr. Hayden, the head of Baltimore’s library system, would be the first woman and the first African-American to hold the position if she is approved by the Senate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Carla D. Hayden, the longtime head of Baltimore’s library system and an advocate for the privacy rights of library users, was nominated by President Obama on Wednesday to lead the Library of Congress.

headline: Governors Unite in the War Against Opioids
abstract: State leaders are working together to place sensible limits on the use of risky substances.
lead_paragraph: State governments are at the front lines of the country’s epidemic of drug overdose deaths. That’s why it is important that the National Governors Association says it will come up with  protocols for dispensing prescription painkillers that are among the biggest sources of addiction and abuse in the country.

headline: Macklemore & Ryan Lewis Return to the Hip-Hop Fray
abstract: As their new album,“This Unruly Mess I’ve Made,” is set to be released, the duo spoke on the impact and backlash of the success of their debut work.
lead_paragraph: To be Macklemore & Ryan Lewis is to be scrutinized ceaselessly. The most consequential white hip-hop act since Eminem, this Seattle duo became a pop sensation, hip-hop curio and sociocultural lightning rod in 2012 on the back of the quirky breakthrough “Thrift Shop.” The boisterous and off-kilter track turned out to be the first in a string of four Billboard top 15 hits, two of which went to No. 1.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Labor Unrest Stirs in Russia as an Economic Chill Sets In
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Railroads', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: In Nizhny Tagil, a city in the Ural Mountains, thousands of factory workers who once rallied behind Vladimir V. Putin in his campaign for the presidency now face idle assembly lines.
lead_paragraph: NIZHNY TAGIL, Russia — Workers in this city that calls itself the “birthplace of the trains” gained fame some years back for helping birth something far different: President Vladimir V. Putin’s drive to crush and marginalize a budding democracy movement. Recently, after a year with little or no work in the city’s giant train factory, they staged a protest of their own, aimed straight at Mr. Putin and his wealthy cronies in the industrial sector.

headline: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: Donald Trump, Republican Party, iPhone
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Q. and A.: Timothy Olyphant, a Tough Lawman, Goes Country Onstage
abstract: Mr. Olyphant, of “Justified” and “Deadwood,” discusses his role as a down-on-his-luck singer in Kenneth Lonergan’s new play, “Hold on to Me Darling.”
lead_paragraph: Countless words have been spilled on the subject of Timothy Olyphant and the Stare: that faint narrowing of those fathomless eyes, shorthand that one of his gunslinging lawmen — say, Raylan Givens of “Justified” or Seth Bullock of “Deadwood” — is about to blow a bad guy to smithereens.

headline: Doping Claims Involving Chinese Track Stars Re-emerge, Decades Later
abstract: The reprinting of a letter purportedly written by star athletes in 1995, alleging they were tricked into using drugs, has reignited a scandal.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Lunar New Year blessings in red and gold at the entrance to the Chinese Athletics Association wish visitors “Glorious Business Improving Year by Year” and “Splendid Future Reaching Up and Up.”

headline: Prosecutors Will Move to Dismiss Charges in Brownsville Rape Case
abstract: The effort to drop the case against five teenagers accused of attacking an 18-year-old woman came primarily as the victim’s credibility as a witness fell apart, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in Brooklyn plan on moving to dismiss first-degree rape charges against all five teenagers accused of attacking an 18-year-old woman on a playground in Brownsville, Brooklyn, in January, officials said on Wednesday.

headline: At Cavalli, Individual Beauty With a ’70s Vibe
abstract: “She’s very cool, very relaxed,” said the hairstylist Duffy of the look this season.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Roberto Cavalli show was set inside the 16th-century Palazzo Spinola in Milan, where giant chandeliers hung overhead and every cornice was covered in gold leaf. And the collection didn’t shy away from extravagance either: Clothes were dripping with beads, sequins and tiger prints, harking back to a 19th-century bohemian spirit. Backstage, the hairstylist Duffy explained the philosophy behind the hair look for the season. “It’s Peter’s girl,” he said, referring to the brand’s designer, Peter Dundas. “She’s very cool, very relaxed.” He turned to ’70s London — and, more specifically, the famous store Biba — as an inspiration for the free-spirited opulence of the collection.

headline: Review: ‘A Bronx Tale: The Musical’ Doo-Wops Down Mean Streets
abstract: The show, based on Chazz Palminteri’s one-man play and, later, a film, is directed by Jerry Zaks and Robert De Niro.
lead_paragraph: MILLBURN, N.J. — The tug of war for the soul of a young man on the mean streets of the Bronx may not sound like a subject that sings. But Chazz Palminteri’s “A Bronx Tale,” originally a solo show, later a movie, and after that a solo show once again on Broadway, has proved to be comfortably malleable material. Now it has been given a hefty infusion of music and dance and — presto! — the familiar-as-red-sauce story, with most of its rough edges intact, can be found finger-snapping and doo-wopping its way across the stage of the Paper Mill Playhouse here, with plans, no doubt, for a quick trip through the Lincoln Tunnel to the big time.

headline: Vanessa Moody Transforms at Cavalli
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.

headline: Oscars Too Boring? A Guide to Spicing Them Up
abstract: Maybe let the actors do away with stylists and wear whatever they want; or have a live vote for winners; or just do it ‘Idol’-style.
lead_paragraph: This is the last Carpetbagger column of the Oscar season, praise be, and there is absolutely nothing left to say. Well, maybe a couple of things. Final Oscar voting has closed, all that’s left to get through are a few parties, the red carpet and finally, on Sunday night, the ceremony.

headline: Struggle Over Supreme Court Pick Enters a New Level of ‘Hardball Politics’
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: After a year of confrontation, the conflict between Congress and President Obama entered a new phase with Republicans’ refusal to consider a nominee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Democrats were slightly surprised when Republicans told the White House budget director this month not to bother making the ritual presentation of a spending plan. They were absolutely astonished when Senate Republicans took the power struggle to an entirely new level by announcing that they would not even shake hands with a Supreme Court nominee selected by the duly elected president of the United States.

headline: Apple Is Said to Be Trying to Make It Harder to Hack iPhones
keywords: ['Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'iPhone', 'Software']
abstract: Concerned about the government’s insistence that it break into a terrorist’s phone, the company wants to take that power out of its own hands.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Apple engineers have begun developing new security measures that would make it impossible for the government to break into a locked iPhone using methods similar to those now at the center of a court fight in California, according to people close to the company and security experts.

headline: What Microsoft’s Xamarin Purchase Says About the Cloud Computing Fight
abstract: As it competes with Amazon and Google, the Windows maker is trying to make it easy for customers to migrate their technology to mobile and the cloud.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft announced on Wednesday that it was buying Xamarin, a company that helps software developers write applications for mobile devices. The price was not disclosed, but is believed to be more than $300 million.

headline: Kesha Speaks Out About Dr. Luke Case as Adele Voices Support
abstract: The pop singer wrote a statement on Facebook, the first time since her legal fight became the talk of the music industry.
lead_paragraph: The pop singer Kesha spoke out on Wednesday for the first time since her legal fight with the producer Dr. Luke became the talk of the music industry, earning the singer public encouragement from her brand-name peers, including Lady Gaga, Miley Cyrus and Taylor Swift.

headline: In an Improving Economy, Places in Distress
abstract: As the most prosperous communities in the United States have gotten richer since the end of the Great Recession in 2009, economic conditions in many distressed areas have deteriorated even further.
lead_paragraph: As the most prosperous communities in the United States have gotten richer since the end of the Great Recession in 2009, economic conditions in many distressed areas have deteriorated even further.

headline: Michael Skakel’s Lawyer Says Trial in Killing of Martha Moxley Wasn’t Fair
abstract: Connecticut prosecutors said Mr. Skakel did not deserve a new trial, while his defense pointed to another possible culprit in the 1975 death.
lead_paragraph: HARTFORD — More than 40 years after 15-year-old Martha Moxley was found beaten to death near her home in Greenwich, Conn., a lawyer for the man convicted in the killing laid out a litany of reasons that his client, Michael C. Skakel, “did not get a fair shake” during his 2002 trial.

headline: Commodities Agency Advised to Drop Plan to Limit Futures Contracts
keywords: ['Futures and Options Trading', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Derivatives (Financial Instruments)', 'Commodities']
abstract: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission is advised to abandon plans to limit contracts a trader can hold on commodities like oil and natural gas.
lead_paragraph: A long-running fight between regulators seeking to curb speculation in the commodities markets and traders is heading into its next round.

headline: Clinton, Sanders and Southern Voters
abstract: A regional preference creates a cultural barrier for one candidate and a built-in advantage for the other.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Sanders’s campaign is making incredible strides, but huge hurdles remain.

headline: Assessing the Shifting Military and Political Calculus in Libya
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'Targeted Killings', 'International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Terrorism']
abstract: A breakthrough in its tangled civil war, particularly in war-ravaged Benghazi, thrust Libya back into the headlines this week.
lead_paragraph: Fractured, chaotic Libya has leapt back into the headlines this week, with a breakthrough in its tangled civil war and a vicious display of Islamist extremism’s lengthening shadow.

headline: Proof Needed to Enroll in Health Plan Post-Deadline
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Federal Aid (US)']
abstract: A new policy requires people to submit documents like a birth or marriage certificate if they want to use special enrollment periods to sign up for coverage after the open enrollment deadline.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — People who want to buy health insurance in the federal marketplace outside the annual open enrollment period will now have to provide documents to show they are eligible, the Obama administration announced on Wednesday.

headline: Andrew Miller, Demoted After a Strong Season, Isn’t Fazed
abstract: Andrew Miller lost his closer’s job to Aroldis Chapman despite being named the American League relief pitcher of the year last season.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — Since Andrew Miller arrived in New York a year ago, he has been a model employee.

headline: Workers Who Reserve Parking Spots for Film Sets Denounce Conditions in Suit
keywords: ['Movies', 'Television', 'Minimum Wage', 'Overtime', 'Minorities', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Organized Labor', 'Discrimination', 'Parking', 'Working Hours']
abstract: The production assistants named several Hollywood studios in a lawsuit that described falsified time sheets, withheld wages and crude conditions.
lead_paragraph: For Christian Pellot, most weeks begin the same way, with a text from an unfamiliar number telling him to show up at a specific address. When he arrives, he is told to sign a wage form, with the hours and pay rate to be filled in at a later date. Then his work begins, sitting for days and nights in a parked vehicle to save street spots for any one of the scores of television, movie and commercial productions filmed around New York each year.

headline: Mets and Yoenis Cespedes Rev Up to Resume Title Quest
abstract: Yoenis Cespedes has a Lamborghini, and the Mets have a firm lineup, a deep bench, a strong bullpen and an enviable rotation as they prepare for a season that will begin with high expectations.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — Before he elevated the driver’s side door of his black Lamborghini Aventador and vroomed out of practice Wednesday, Yoenis Cespedes celebrated a pretend birthday.

headline: Treasury Plan for Puerto Rico Favors Pensions Over Bondholders
abstract: A plan from the Treasury Department to ease Puerto Rico’s debt crisis would put pension payments ahead of payments to bondholders, which may rattle the muni market.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If it’s up to the Treasury Department, public employees in Puerto Rico who were promised pensions could be better off than investors who bought the island’s bonds.

headline: At Harvard Dorms, ‘House Masters’ No More
abstract: The term to address residential administrators has come under fire for conjuring undertones of slavery.
lead_paragraph: The title “house master” as used by generations of Ivy League students to describe their residential administrators is fast becoming an anachronism. Harvard University announced Wednesday that, in a spirit of diversity and “an inclusive community,” the term was being replaced with “faculty dean.”

headline: Henry Diamond, Lawyer at Forefront of Conservation Movement, Dies at 83
abstract: Mr. Diamond hitched his political star to the Rockefellers and was New York State’s first conservation commissioner in 1970; he also served on presidential advisory committees.
lead_paragraph: Henry L. Diamond, a lawyer who went from the vanguard of a nascent environmental movement half a century ago to become New York State’s first environmental conservation commissioner, appointed by Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller on the inaugural Earth Day in 1970, died on Sunday in Washington. He was 83.

headline: U.N. Agency Hires Wife of Top Figure in Syrian War to Assist the Displaced
keywords: ['Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Shukria Mekdad’s appointment has led critics to question the World Health Organization’s impartiality, as her husband is a defender of the government’s war effort.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — When the World Health Organization wanted to know how the war in Syria was affecting the mental health of those forced to flee their homes, the agency hired someone known less for her expertise than for her connections: The consultant, Shukria Mekdad, is the wife of Faisal Mekdad, the deputy foreign minister of Syria and a powerful defender of the government’s war effort.

headline: Poorest Areas Have Missed Out on Boons of Recovery, Study Finds
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Poverty', 'Income Inequality', 'Urban Areas', 'Recession and Depression', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: A new research and advocacy group found that since the end of the recession, the divide between wealthy and poor communities had widened further.
lead_paragraph: The gap between the richest and poorest American communities has widened since the Great Recession ended, and distressed areas are faring worse just as the recovery is gaining traction across much of the country.

headline: Alisa Bellettini, Creator of MTV’s ‘House of Style,’ Dies at 61
abstract: “House of Style” was both glamorous and approachable, an attempt to mix the worlds of style and music in a way that would appeal to young viewers.
lead_paragraph: Alisa Marie Bellettini, a former television producer who created the popular MTV fashion show “House of Style,” naming the supermodel Cindy Crawford as its first host, died on Feb. 16 in Sacramento. She was 61.

headline: In Reversal, Egypt Says Terrorists Downed Russian Jet Over Sinai
keywords: ['Aviation Accidents, Safety and Disasters', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Bombs and Explosives', 'Terrorism']
abstract: After months of cautious silence, Egypt acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that terrorists had downed the Russian jet that broke up over its Sinai Peninsula in October.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — After months of cautious silence, Egypt acknowledged for the first time on Wednesday that terrorists had downed the Russian jetliner that broke up over the Sinai Peninsula in the fall.

headline: Elizabeth Eisenstein, Trailblazing Historian of Movable Type, Dies at 92
abstract: In “The Printing Press as an Agent of Change,” Professor Eisenstein argued that the proliferation of print shops had a seismic effect on civilization.
lead_paragraph: Elizabeth L. Eisenstein, a historian best known for her work on the seismic effect of printing on Western civilization — a novel contention when she began her research more than 40 years ago — died on Jan. 31 at her home in Washington. She was 92.

headline: CNN Seeing Dividend From Its Investment in Politics
abstract: CNN has turned the town hall-style genre into a powerful supplement — if not antidote — to the often-acrimonious presidential debates.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Jeff Zucker scowled over a laptop in a CNN truck here recently, scouring a new report by BuzzFeed: Donald J. Trump, contrary to his campaign trail boasts, initially supported the invasion of Iraq. A wall of monitors still showed Jeb Bush, but Mr. Trump would take the stage in CNN’s latest Republican town hall-style meeting in minutes.

headline: Networks Seek to Breathe Life Into FIFA Presidential Election
abstract: Much will depend on the quality of the in-studio storytelling and analysis by two networks during their coverage of the FIFA congress.
lead_paragraph: Bob Ley, who will anchor ESPN’s coverage of the FIFA presidential election on Friday, has a few delicious ways of describing what might happen.

headline: Democrats Press G.O.P. to Consider a Supreme Court Pick
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: One potential nominee’s name leaked out, Nevada’s Republican governor, Brian Sandoval, a candidate seemingly calculated to demonstrate the depths of Republican obstreperousness.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From the White House to the Capitol to the campaign trail, the entire Democratic power structure on Wednesday mobilized to break through Republican opposition and clear a path for President Obama to name a Supreme Court successor to Justice Antonin Scalia.

headline: American in Iran Jail With Son
abstract: The wife of Baquer Namazi, a former Unicef official, said she thought her husband had been sent to Evin Prison, where their son, Siamak Namazi is being held.
lead_paragraph: The 80-year-old father of an Iranian-American detained in Iran since last fall has himself been arrested in Tehran, his family said on Wednesday.

headline: Canadian Court Says Some Can Grow Marijuana at Home, With a Prescription
abstract: A Federal Court decision that prescription holders could grow their own supply for medical purposes adds to the confusion over the drug’s legal status.
lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau has not yet fulfilled his promise to legalize marijuana in Canada, but the country’s Federal Court ruled Wednesday that prescription holders could grow their own supply.

headline: 25 Plead Not Guilty in Standoff at the Oregon Wildlife Refuge
abstract: Bundy supporters have said they hoped to put a focus on government power at the occupation trial, but the judge made clear that she was in charge.
lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — Defendants charged with leading an armed occupation at a federal wildlife refuge in rural southeastern Oregon this year formally pleaded not guilty on Wednesday in a hearing here at Federal District Court, saying little and sitting obediently — a stark contrast to the days when they drew world attention by broadcasting their view that the United States government had illegally usurped lands across the West.

keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Sex Crimes', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Gloria Fields is accused of subjecting Anthony Delgado, a toddler, to hours of physical and sexual abuse while he was left in her care.
lead_paragraph: A babysitter charged with murdering a 16-month-old boy whose family lived in the same Staten Island building subjected him to hours of physical and sexual abuse while he was left in her care over the weekend, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

headline: New Ad Promotes John Kasich, and It Makes Him Uncomfortable

John Kasich of Ohio after an event in Massachusetts last weekend to offer some advice: His campaign should fashion a commercial out of the footage of an emotional moment Mr. Kasich had with a young supporter last week.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, February 25, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “This is the latest very serious attack on freedom of expression. During the Franco dictatorship, troublesome artists went to prison, but not in democratic Spain.”

headline: Phil Mickelson Never Met Harper Lee, but the Admiration Was Mutual
abstract: Phil Mickelson, who had read “To Kill a Mockingbird” in an English class, was hoping to meet its author, Harper Lee, after learning that years earlier she had rooted for him to win the 2004 Masters.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — Shushing down a mountain run of fresh snow never gets old for Phil Mickelson, but it is not his favorite part of skiing trips with his three children. What he likes best are the chairlift rides to the top, which facilitate conversations that can take wide and wondrous turns.

headline: Bolivian President Concedes Defeat in Term-Limit Referendum
abstract: The measure would have allowed President Evo Morales to run for a fourth term, but it lost narrowly in a vote held Sunday.
lead_paragraph: ORURO, Bolivia — President Evo Morales, facing mounting pressure to concede defeat in a referendum that would have allowed him to run for a fourth term, accepted the loss Wednesday but said he would use the remaining years of his presidency to advance his Socialist-inspired agenda.

headline: Carmelo Anthony’s Shot Hits Air, and Knicks’ Chances Evaporate

lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — A cold rain was falling outside Bankers Life Fieldhouse on Wednesday morning when the Knicks arrived for their shootaround. Carmelo Anthony opened a door, ducked his head inside the arena and then shuffled across the court in socks. Some teammates were quietly warming up. Anthony eventually retrieved his sneakers.

headline: Edward T. Foote, Who Led and Lifted University of Miami, Dies at 78

lead_paragraph: Edward T. Foote, who spent two decades as the president of the University of Miami lifting its academic standards, stabilizing its finances and helping dispel its reputation as Suntan U., died on Feb. 15 in Cutler Bay, Fla., near Miami. He was 78.

headline: Library of Congress Puts Rosa Parks Archive Online
abstract: Roughly 7,500 manuscript items and 2,500 photographs are available in the Library of Congress’s online offering of Rosa Parks’s archive.
lead_paragraph: The Library of Congress has digitized the papers of Rosa Parks, enabling free online access to everything from her first-hand recollections of the Montgomery bus boycott and personal correspondence with the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to family photographs, tax returns and a handwritten recipe for “featherlite pancakes.”

lead_paragraph: MILAN — Proceedings kick off bright and early on Thursday with the 9:30 a.m. show by Max Mara, an Italian label long known for its steadiness, reliability and sartorial conservatism, which, as of late, has been trying to move beyond that reputation. From there, it is on to Costume National and then to Fendi at 12:30 p.m., where Karl Lagerfeld will, no doubt, offer up lashings of leather and fur for its latest fall extravaganza.

headline: Cuba: Some Dissidents Will Be Allowed a Single Trip Overseas, an Activist Says
abstract: Officials contacted half a dozen former prisoners, who were incarcerated during a 2003 crackdown on dissidents, and told them that they could make one trip abroad.
lead_paragraph: Cuba has given some prominent dissidents one-time permission to travel overseas, weeks before President Obama is expected to visit and call for greater freedoms in Cuba. Officials contacted half a dozen dissidents who were imprisoned during a 2003 crackdown and  released as part of a deal brokered by the Roman Catholic Church in 2010 and told them they could make one trip abroad, said Hector Maseda Gutiérrez, one of the dissidents. He turned down the offer because it excluded four other former prisoners, including José Daniel Ferrer, leader of the Patriotic Union of Cuba.

lead_paragraph: TOKYO — For a few hours on Thursday, it looked as if Sharp, the ailing Japanese consumer electronics company, had secured a $5.5 billion takeover from Foxconn of Taiwan, the giant contract manufacturer that churns out products for Apple and other foreign brands.

keywords: ['Sex Crimes', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'International Relations']

headline: Finding Oscar Moments From the Red Carpet to Backstage

headline: Easy-Reading Road Signs Head to the Offramp
keywords: ['Traffic and Parking Signals and Signs', 'Typography', 'Elderly', 'Roads and Traffic']
abstract: The Federal Highway Administration is sending the Clearview typeface to the exit. I’ll miss it.
lead_paragraph: Durham, N.C. — STARTING this week, a familiar face will begin to disappear from America’s roadside signs. It's not particularly noticeable — certainly not as memorable as the goateed Colonel Sanders or smiling Big Boy or pigtailed Wendy pushing their fried chicken, hamburgers and French fries. Rather, it is a typeface named Clearview, which has graced many of our highway signs and directed us to our destinations since 2004, when it was granted interim approval by the Federal Highway Administration.

headline: A Bad Effort in Congress to Thwart States on Food Labels
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Food', 'Genetic Engineering', 'States (US)', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Biotechnology and Bioengineering', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)']
abstract: States should be free to require the labeling of genetically modified food if they want to.
lead_paragraph: The Senate could soon join the House to try to make it harder for consumers to know what is in their food by prohibiting state governments from requiring the labeling of genetically modified foods. This is a bad idea that lawmakers and the Obama administration should oppose.

headline: What Is Marco Rubio Waiting For?
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Maybe he has a strategy for making the not-Trump case, but time’s running out.
lead_paragraph: New Hampshire has fallen. South Carolina has been overwhelmed. Nevada has surrendered. And the Republican establishment, like the British Empire in the darkest days of 1940, finds its strength scattered on the beach at Dunkirk, desperately awaiting evacuation and hoping for a Churchill to rise to its defense.

headline: Private Prisons Are Cashing In on Refugees’ Desperation
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Outsourcing', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Government Contracts and Procurement']
abstract: From Australia to Austria to America, governments are relying on for-profit contractors to warehouse detainees. It’s bad policy.
lead_paragraph: Berlin — IMMIGRATION and Customs Enforcement calls the detention site in Dilley, Tex., a “family residential center.” But to the 2,000 migrant children and mothers who live there, it’s something else: “People who say this is not a prison are lying,” Yancy Maricela Mejia Guerra, a detainee from Central America, told Fusion last year. “It’s a prison for us and a prison for our children, but none of us are criminals.”

headline: ‘Playing to the Edge,’ by Michael V. Hayden
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Michael V. Hayden describes how he took over a dysfunctional C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: If Michael V. Hayden were a businessman, he might be called a turnaround artist. When he was named by President George W. Bush to take over the Central Intelligence Agency in mid-2006, it was in wide disrepute. It had failed to break up the 9/11 plot. It couldn’t find Osama bin Laden. It had rubber-stamped phony intelligence about Saddam Hussein’s nonexistent weapons of mass destruction, enabling the catastrophic war in Iraq. Revelations of waterboarding and other “enhanced interrogation techniques” carried out at C.I.A. “black sites” had provoked revulsion.

headline: Why Women Proposing Is Still Rare
abstract: Ireland’s leap year tradition has women asking, “Will you marry me?” But in general, men still propose.
lead_paragraph: When uttered by a man, the words “will you marry me” serve to signal a tradition that is both widely accepted and ages old. Having the same spoken by a woman however — except in a leap year like 2016, when an old Irish tradition of having the woman ask is known to emerge — are still surprisingly rare.

A suicide car bomb had ripped through the military bus, killing 28 and injuring more than 60.

lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Chinese economic policy makers tugged back the curtain a bit on Thursday on their plans to stabilize the country’s economy and financial markets, even as shares plunged more than 6 percent late in the day.

headline: Living With Cancer: A Farewell to Legs
abstract: After a fall on ice, I was about to discover what happens when cancer patients must deal with unrelated physical injuries.
lead_paragraph: On a bright, cold Sunday in mid-January, I returned home from visiting a frail member of my cancer support group and opened the garage to haul the recyclables up the steep driveway to the street. After a few steps, my feet started to slip and I fell with a thud on my bottom. The big bin toppled over me, scattering plastic containers and cardboard boxes, as my hands reached down to feel a sheet of ice that had been invisible on the asphalt.

headline: Big Health Benefits to Small Weight Loss
abstract: Losing as little as 5 percent of your body weight can improve health.
lead_paragraph: Obese individuals who lose as little as 5 percent of their body weight can improve their metabolic function and reduce the risk of developing Type 2 diabetes and heart disease, a new study has found.

abstract: Thursday: Where Mister Softee went, blustery weather, and the mystical ice cream man.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:48 a.m.

headline: The New Dream Jobs
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Youth', 'Millennial Generation', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: What a survey of millennials might tell us about the workplaces of the future.
lead_paragraph: When the National Society of High School Scholars asked 18,000 Americans, ages 15 to 29, to rank their ideal future employers, the results were curious. To nobody’s surprise, Google, Apple and Facebook appeared high on the list, but so did the Central Intelligence Agency, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the National Security Agency. The Build-A-Bear Workshop was No. 50, just a few spots behind Lockheed Martin and JPMorgan Chase. (The New York Times came in at No. 16.)

headline: Tracking a Parasite That Turns Bees Into Zombies
abstract: Parasitic flies are infesting honeybees across the country. If you see any, you can add them to the Zombee Watch database.
lead_paragraph: Call it “The Buzzing Dead.” Infestations of what scientists have dubbed “zombie bees” have spread across both the West and East coasts in recent years.

headline: The Post-Cubicle Office and Its Discontents
keywords: ['Workplace Environment', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE', 'Telecommuting', 'Executives and Management (Theory)', 'Desks']
abstract: Beige partitions have given way to napping lofts, lunch gazebos and lots of open space. But are employees any happier or more productive?
lead_paragraph: ‘I have known the inexorable sadness of pencils,’’ begins Theodore Roethke’s ‘‘Dolor,’’ the best poem in English about the grayness of the office. ‘‘All the misery of manila folders and mucilage,/Desolation in immaculate public places,/Lonely reception room, lavatory, switchboard.’’ For a century or more, office design has been our most useful metaphor for workers’ frustration. The color-sapped tedium of office life runs like a flickering current through the warrens of white-collar fiction — from Bartleby impassively facing his brick wall to Frank Wheeler caged in his dark cubicle in ‘‘Revolutionary Road.’’ The fluorescence, the screens, the fabric-wrapped plywood dividers: They’re demoralizing, humiliating.

headline: Managed by Q’s ‘Good Jobs’ Gamble
keywords: ['Cleaning Services', 'Wages and Salaries', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Income Inequality', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: Forgoing the gig-economy model, a start-up bets on a strategy that puts cleaning-service workers on a professional path.
lead_paragraph: ‘Baumol’s cost disease’’ is a phenomenon that economists sometimes cite when they want to underscore the unequal effects of technological change. William Baumol, the New York University economist for whom the concept is named, uses a classical string quartet as his paradigmatic example. As he points out, no matter how fast our computers become or how many people worldwide plug into broadband-Internet access, it will still take roughly 30 minutes for four human beings to play Mozart’s String Quartet No. 14. If your business is playing string quartets for live audiences, there’s a fundamental limit to how much more productive, in raw economic terms, your work can become.

headline: What Google Learned From Its Quest to Build the Perfect Team
abstract: New research reveals surprising truths about why some work groups thrive and others falter.
lead_paragraph: Like most 25-year-olds, Julia Rozovsky wasn’t sure what she wanted to do with her life. She had worked at a consulting firm, but it wasn’t a good match. Then she became a researcher for two professors at Harvard, which was interesting but lonely. Maybe a big corporation would be a better fit. Or perhaps a fast-growing start-up. All she knew for certain was that she wanted to find a job that was more social. ‘‘I wanted to be part of a community, part of something people were building together,’’ she told me. She thought about various opportunities — Internet companies, a Ph.D. program — but nothing seemed exactly right. So in 2009, she chose the path that allowed her to put off making a decision: She applied to business schools and was accepted by the Yale School of Management.

headline: Rethinking the Work-Life Equation
abstract: It takes more than just policies to make a workplace truly flexible. The whole office culture has to change.
lead_paragraph: Phyllis Moen, a sociologist who was widowed when her two children were young, has made a career studying the challenges of working full time while raising a family. She was an early voice calling for the government to provide paid maternity leave and offer benefits for part-time workers, but eventually, when she saw no signs of progress, she began considering instead the ways that corporations could reconfigure work to address the realities of the modern employee, who was more likely than ever to be a single parent or part of a dual-income couple. ‘‘We wanted to do a field experiment at a corporation that reduced its hours,’’ she said, ‘‘but realized nobody would let us do that. We thought they would be more willing to experiment with giving workers more control.’’

headline: Is Blind Hiring the Best Hiring?
keywords: ['Hiring and Promotion', 'Discrimination', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Minorities', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Most companies say they want to attract a diverse workforce, but few deliver. The only solution may be a radical one: anonymity.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Kedar Iyer, an entrepreneur in Silicon Valley, became acutely aware of a problem in his industry: A surfeit of talented coders were routinely overlooked by employers because they lacked elite pedigrees. Hiring managers, he thought, were too often swayed by the name of a fancy college on a résumé. To try to address the problem, he created a software company called GapJumpers, working with employers to create challenges for applicants that mimicked what people would do on the job. Companies using GapJumpers wouldn’t see candidates’ résumés, just their names, photographs and test results. In theory, this process would shift employers’ focus from résumés to skills. Then, two years ago, he came across an idea that caused him to rethink his business.

headline: Failure to Lunch
abstract: The lamentable rise of desktop dining.
lead_paragraph: For 11 years, June Jo Lee, an ethnographer, has been traveling the country, talking to Americans about how they eat. She has often been in offices, observing white-collar workers. In one interview, a 20-something administrative assistant at an architecture firm in Seattle told her, ‘‘I don’t think I ate at a table at all this week if you don’t include my desk at work.’’ In Chicago, Lee talked to an I.T. specialist who lunched in front of his computer and assiduously avoided the break room; anyone who ate in there was odd. Another guy said that each week he would bring in a crudité party platter from Costco and graze from it when he got hungry.

headline: The Robots Are Coming for Wall Street
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Software', 'Robots and Robotics', 'United States Economy']
abstract: Hundreds of financial analysts are being replaced with software. What office jobs are next?
lead_paragraph: When Daniel Nadler woke on Nov. 6, he had just enough time to pour himself a glass of orange juice and open his laptop before the Bureau of Labor Statistics released its monthly employment report at 8:30 a.m. He sat at the kitchen table in his one-bedroom apartment in Chelsea, nervously refreshing his web browser — Command-R, Command-R, Command-R — as the software of his company, Kensho, scraped the data from the bureau’s website. Within two minutes, an automated Kensho analysis popped up on his screen: a brief overview, followed by 13 exhibits predicting the performance of investments based on their past response to similar employment reports.

headline: Meet Is Murder
abstract: They’re boring. They’re useless. Everyone hates them. So why can’t we stop having meetings?
lead_paragraph: Early this year in the sun-streaked offices of Spring, a handsomely capitalized shopping start-up in Manhattan’s Flatiron district, Octavian Costache, the company’s chief technology officer and one of its founders, claimed a spot near the bright new kitchen to make a speech at a weekly all-hands meeting. For several months, I’d been working as a consultant to the company, and, though this was my last day, it was the first time I’d heard Costache address the team. I was excited. Costache, a 34-year-old Romanian with a dimpled, affable face, previously worked at Google, where he helped build Gmail’s multiple-inbox capability and various features of Google Maps. He commands rapt attention at Spring. But on this morning, Costache didn’t want to talk about software. He wanted to talk about meetings.

headline: How Prince Ali Could Win the Election to Be FIFA President
abstract: There is a possible path for Prince Ali bin al-Hussein of Jordan to leapfrog the favorites in the vote to lead soccer’s world governing body.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — Every candidate, in every election, tries to picture a path to victory. The  FIFA presidential election here on Friday is no different.

headline: Loretta Lynn Mines a Legacy of Heartaches and High Notes
abstract: “Full Circle,” Ms. Lynn’s first new album since “Van Lear Rose” in 2004, is part of a huge trove of recent recordings.
lead_paragraph: HURRICANE MILLS, Tenn. — “I really didn’t mean to knock his teeth out.” Over a lunchtime bowl of chicken noodle soup in the glass-walled dining room of her modern, hillside mansion here, Loretta Lynn was recounting a scuffle she had with her hard-drinking husband a few years before she started writing and singing the succinct, forthright songs that made her the undisputed queen of country music. Her eyes, a brilliant star-sapphire blue, still blazed at the memory.

headline: Think You Know the Movies? Take Our Oscars Quiz
abstract: You’re Leonardo DiCaprio. This quiz is a bear. Try to survive.
lead_paragraph: You’re Leonardo DiCaprio. This quiz is a bear. Try to survive.

headline: The Mississippians of Cahokia
abstract: John Hendrix illustrates Cahokia, the Native American “Manhattan” of early America and a collection of over 70 mounds and earthworks.
lead_paragraph: John Hendrix illustrates Cahokia, the Native American “Manhattan” of early America and a collection of over 70 mounds and earthworks.

headline: Debate Could Serve as Final Bulwark for Donald Trump’s Rivals
abstract: Donald J. Trump will take the stage Thursday night at the CNN-Telemundo debate in Texas with a new title: three-time winner. The stakes for many of the debates have been high, but none so high as this one.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump will take the stage Thursday night at the CNN-Telemundo debate in Texas with a new title: three-time winner. The stakes for many of the debates have been high, but none so high as this one. It represents one of the final chances for Senator Marco Rubio of Florida to produce a galvanizing, breakout moment. And it is the last chance for Senator Ted Cruz, whose home state of Texas votes on Super Tuesday next week, to try to fend off Mr. Trump there.

headline: Jimmy Savile Inquiry Accuses BBC of Failing to Report Sexual Abuse
abstract: A three-year investigation concluded that the TV personality had raped at least eight people during his time at the company, including an 8-year-old.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A culture of fear that persists to this day at the BBC and a permissive attitude toward stars allowed Jimmy Savile, the disgraced British television personality, to sexually abuse 72 victims, including children, according to a long-awaited report published on Thursday.

headline: China, Facing Land Shortages, Encourages Saving Space 6 Feet Under
abstract: A directive that encourages family members to be buried together or to have their remains disposed of in environmentally friendly ways has drawn criticism online.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Whether you are alive or dead, the Chinese authorities have made clear that there is just not that much room for you.

headline: Burundi Strife Is Turning More Sinister, Report Finds
keywords: ['Hutu Tribe', 'Tutsi Tribe', 'Kidnapping and Hostages', 'International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Human Rights Watch said it had found “an alarming new pattern of abductions and possible disappearances” in the Central African country.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Security forces and their allies in Burundi have beaten people with rocks, bricks, gun butts and iron bars; they have abducted suspects and extorted money for holding them; and they have buried victims in mass graves, a leading human rights group said on Thursday.

headline: The Iran Election: What’s at Stake
abstract: A look at the vote and its implications as Iranians move to select a new Parliament and membership in the Assembly of Experts, an influential panel.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, Iranians will go to the polls to elect members of Parliament and the Assembly of Experts. Here’s why this matters.

headline: Desktop Dining
abstract: Who has time for lunch breaks anymore?
lead_paragraph: Who has time for lunch breaks anymore?

headline: A Tall, Handsome Stranger’s Scarf
abstract: A diner thought she had found a way to meet the man of her dreams when he left his scarf at a nearby table.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: No question of authenticity here — this otherwise classic, logo-stamped tote from Gucci gets a cool edge with gold graffiti.

headline: Antonin Scalia Really Was A Character Out Of A Dan Brown Novel
abstract: It’s a very strange world.
lead_paragraph: Justice Scalia spent his last hours with members of this secretive society of elite hunters:

headline: The Daily Shoe: Gucci
keywords: ['Shoes and Boots', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Now that his Gucci fur slippers have managed to find their way into nearly every stylish girl’s closet, Alessandro Michele has taken a break from logo-mania (at least in shoes; the bags are different story) and introduced these vaguely ’40s-character shoes in zebra stripe.

headline: With Police Brutality Episode, ‘black-ish’ Shows How Sitcoms Can Still Matter
abstract: Wednesday’s remarkable episode, “Hope,” was funny but heartbreaking, nuanced but not mealy-mouthed, blunt but not despairing.
lead_paragraph: For “black-ish,” its characters and its audience, it was finally time to have The Talk.

headline: Coast Guard Vessel Capsizes During Fishing Boat Rescue Near Queens
abstract: Seven fishermen whose ship ran aground off Rockaway Beach were airlifted to safety early Thursday morning after a harrowing overnight rescue attempt.
lead_paragraph: The crew of a fishing boat whose ship ran aground off Rockaway Beach in Queens overnight was airlifted to safety early Thursday after a harrowing rescue by the Coast Guard.
