abstract: Karl Lagerfeld presents his fall collection for Fendi.
lead_paragraph: Karl Lagerfeld presents his fall collection for Fendi.

headline: Sharp’s Messy Milestone
abstract: The future of Sharp was expected to be a test of Japanese reform, but its deal with Foxconn of Taiwan has descended into farce.
lead_paragraph: The deal to put Sharp in Taiwanese hands would be a messy milestone.

headline: Printing Gmail Backup Codes
abstract: Generating a few backup codes ahead of time can come in handy when you are unable to get the text messages from Gmail’s two-step verification system.
lead_paragraph: Q. I use Google’s two-step authentication to protect my Gmail account, but I got temporarily locked out the other day when I was asked to re-enter my password, and the corresponding text code from Google didn’t arrive until hours later. Where do I get a set of those preprinted backup codes in case this happens again?

headline: South Dakota Bill on Transgender Students’ Bathroom Access Draws Ire
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Discrimination', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)', 'Law and Legislation', 'Gender']
abstract: The bill would make South Dakota the first state to bar transgender youth at public schools from using facilities in line with their gender identity.
lead_paragraph: SIOUX FALLS, S.D. — For Thomas Lewis, a high school senior who plays trumpet in the marching band and works evenings at a grocery store, South Dakota’s contentious debate over transgender rights is personal.

headline: Colonial Architecture Fades From Ho Chi Minh City, and Residents Mourn
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Demolition', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: As many historic buildings are razed to make way for the new, residents have started Facebook groups dedicated to celebrating and protecting them.
lead_paragraph: HO CHI MINH CITY, Vietnam — When Nguyen Viet moved back to Vietnam from Britain in 2014, he was hired to write design guidelines for a redevelopment project in downtown Ho Chi Minh City. He had just earned his master’s degree in urban design and planning, and was eager to make an impact.

headline: Transgender Students and ‘Bathroom Laws’ in South Dakota and Beyond
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Law and Legislation', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The Education Department has affirmed that the federal Title IX law protects transgender students, but schools in many states have challenged it.
lead_paragraph: The South Dakota Legislature approved a bill this month that would require public school students to use bathrooms and other facilities that correspond to their biological sex, defined in the bill as “a person’s chromosomes and anatomy as identified at birth.”

headline: 1941: ‘Final Plan’ for Siam Peace
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Japan expects Indo-China and Thailand to accept its peace proposals in 1941.
lead_paragraph: TOKIO — Japan has presented a ‘‘final mediation plan’’ for settlement of the border dispute between French Indo-China and Thailand (Siam), and expects representatives of both countries to accept the Japanese proposals without further delay, the Japanese press indicated today [Feb. 26]. A government spokesman said the Tokio plan, which was described as ‘‘based on full and serious considerations of the demands of both sides,’’ probably would be accepted and that an agreement might be reached today or tomorrow. Japan’s mediation of the conflict was hampered by the fact that Tokio was engaged in important trade negotiations with Indo-China and found it necessary to proceed tactfully. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 26, 1941

headline: 1966: New Regime in Syria
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: A new military regime in Syria names leaders after a coup in 1966.
lead_paragraph: DAMASCUS — Syria’s new military regime tonight [Feb. 25] named a new head of state and premier to replace former President Amin Hafez and ex-Premier Salah Bitar, ousted in Wednesday’s coup d’état. Damascus radio announced a decree naming Mr. Nureddin Atassi, 36, as new head of state and Mr. Youssef Zeayen as new premier. Mr. Zeayen, 35, is the youngest premier in Syria’s history. Mr. Atassi and Dr. Zeayen are both physicians and longtime doctrinaire Ba’athists. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 26, 1966

headline: When the Apple and F.B.I. Fight Really Began
abstract: In 2013, Edward J. Snowden revealed widespread government spying of American Internet activity. That’s when the tech industry got tougher on security.
lead_paragraph: In many ways, the current battle between Apple and the F.B.I. really began in June 2013, when the former defense contractor Edward J. Snowden revealed the scale of government spying on domestic Internet traffic.

headline: Girl Scouts Face Opposition From St. Louis Archbishop
abstract: The Archdiocese of St. Louis is scaling back ties with the Scouts because of the organization’s support for transgender rights, homosexuality and other issues.
lead_paragraph: The Archdiocese of St. Louis is encouraging Roman Catholics to scale back ties with the Girl Scouts, advising church members to think twice about membership and even about buying their cookies.

headline: Bronx Rabbi Who Had Sauna Chats Is Quitting
abstract: Rabbi Jonathan Rosenblatt fought to keep his job at Riverdale Jewish Center after drawing scrutiny for naked sauna sessions years ago with boys as young as 12.
lead_paragraph: The prominent senior rabbi of a Bronx synagogue who drew scrutiny for having naked sauna chats with boys as young as 12 is stepping down.

headline: Video Review: Restoring Diesel’s Good Name With a New Range Rover
abstract: With a powerful Td6 3-liter turbodiesel motor, the luxury vehicle combines opera house refinement and mountain goat ability.
lead_paragraph: Diesel is a dirty word these days thanks to the Volkswagen scandal.

headline: In Season of Upsets, No. 1 Perch Resembles an Ejection Seat
abstract: The No. 1 team in the Associated Press men’s basketball poll has now lost seven times this season, which may portend an interesting N.C.A.A. tournament.
lead_paragraph: Remember when a No. 1 team being upset was a cause for storming the court, television bulletins and front-page headlines? This season, a loss by the top team in men’s basketball seems to bring little more than a shrug.

headline: Post-Enron Accounting Rule Requires Companies to Report Leases
abstract: Starting in 2019, the most common type of lease must be included on a company’s balance sheet, giving investors a more accurate picture of its health.
lead_paragraph: The Enron accounting scandal happened nearly 15 years ago, but the announcement on Thursday of a new accounting rule shows that its impact is still being felt in corporate America.

headline: Amid Gloomy Rhetoric, John Kasich Sticks With Optimism
abstract: The slender hope for his White House bid rests on his ability to leverage that brand into a much larger share of the Republican audience.
lead_paragraph: The most valuable currency in politics is emotion. And the coin of the 2016 Republican presidential race has been anger and fear.

headline: More Overdose Deaths From Anxiety Drugs
abstract: Overdose deaths involving anti-anxiety drugs like Valium and Xanax are on the rise, with more than a fourfold increase between 1996 and 2013, a new study says.
lead_paragraph: Fatal prescription-drug overdoses in the United States have increased sharply in recent years. But while most of the deaths have involved opioid painkillers like oxycodone, a new study suggests that anti-anxiety medications now are playing an outsize role in overdose deaths.

headline: Jailed for Stealing Tools in 1980, ‘Prison Houdini’ Is Denied Release
abstract: Mark DeFriest, whose prison sentences snowballed after repeated escape attempts, was given an additional six months by a parole board on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: At 19, Mark DeFriest was sentenced to four years in prison after stealing some tools.

headline: The Baur au Lac and Me
abstract: Sam Borden has a special relationship with the Baur au Lac hotel in Zurich, which has become synonymous with the FIFA corruption scandal. He returned this week.
lead_paragraph: Sam Borden has a special relationship with the Baur au Lac hotel in Zurich, which has become synonymous with the FIFA corruption scandal. He returned this week.

headline: Spellbinding Treasures From Japan’s Kamakura Period at Asia Society
abstract: A new exhibition focuses on wonderfully vivid representations of Buddhist divinities.
lead_paragraph: In different times and places a combustive mix of realism and religion has given rise to some of the world’s greatest art. The European Renaissance was one such era. Another was the brief Kamakura period of Japan, from 1185 to 1333. “Kamakura: Realism and Spirituality in the Sculpture of Japan,” a spellbinding exhibition at Asia Society, features wonderfully vivid representations of Buddhist divinities.

headline: U.S. and China Agree on Proposal for Tougher North Korea Sanctions
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Nuclear Tests', 'International Relations']
abstract: The move, following a claim by Pyongyang that it had tested a hydrogen bomb, is a major policy shift for Beijing toward its longtime ally.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The United States and China reached an agreement to impose tougher sanctions against North Korea, in what appeared to be a diplomatic shift by Beijing regarding its intransigent ally.

headline: The Art of War (Elevator Edition)
keywords: ['Elevators and Escalators', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Touch that button one more time, kid, and you’ll be singing in the Gifted Children Angel Choir.
lead_paragraph: I’ve come across a lot of militaristic-sounding classes at the gym lately — Boot Camp Ballet, Older Adults Special Ops — but the course I want to take is Close Combat Elevator Warfare.

headline: Twin Sets, Subscription Vinyl and Laundry Room Melody
abstract: Michael Daves has taken distinctive approaches, Newvelle Records offers subscription vinyl, and Matmos samples sounds from a washing machine.
lead_paragraph: ORCHIDS AND VIOLENCE

headline: In Milan, Fendi and Cavalli Just Say No to Athleisure
abstract: Fausto Puglisi tones down the bling; MaxMara pairs hot pants and longline coats; and Alberta Ferretti embraces lingerie.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — It’s evening in Milan — or at least on the runways it is. Forget athleisure, wellness and wheat grass (though green juice is having a moment in the land of espresso); there are other things in life to dress for. Like dark, louche nights of the soul, a cabaret in Weimar Berlin or sunset dreams of swooning and spooning in a misty cityscape — to name a few of the scenarios that showed up in early shows. We can’t all be jogging all the time.

headline: The Minnesota Orchestra Rebounds From a ‘Near Death Experience’
abstract: Two years after a nearly devastating lockout, the musicians’ salaries are lower, but they have a greater hand in shaping their future.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Outside the office of Kevin Smith, the president and chief executive of the Minnesota Orchestra, a creed hangs on the wall: Enrich, Inspire, Serve. Elsewhere that mission statement — part management cliché, part heartfelt philosophy — might be cast on a plaque. Not here, at an organization where permanence has been shown to be an illusion. No, these guiding principles are drawn in block letters on three large, slightly crumpled pieces of paper, as if to say that, like the medium, the message is fragile and, once damaged, a challenge to repair.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Gucci, Alberta Ferretti and Roberto Cavalli in Pictures
abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Wednesday.

headline: Emilio Pucci: Fall 2016
abstract: The label’s fall show.
lead_paragraph: The label’s fall show.

headline: Americans Are Still Flying Blind on Drones
keywords: ['Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Targeted Killings', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: A new report gives President Obama shockingly poor ratings on critical aspects of drone policy.
lead_paragraph: One of the least understood aspects of American security policy is the use of armed drones for killing alleged terrorists overseas. These covert executions have long raised grave questions of morality, legality and secrecy. Yet President Obama is failing to adequately address them despite promises to make the program more transparent and accountable.

headline: Farruquito, Dance Career Interrupted, Makes His Return
abstract: The great Spanish flamenco dancer, who served three years in prison for manslaughter, performs in New York for the first time since 2003.
lead_paragraph: The dancer Farruquito is heir to one of the most renowned Gypsy flamenco dynasties in Spain, but when he performs at City Center on March 10, it will be his first New York appearance in 13 years. His dancing in the 2001 New York Flamenco Festival, when he was 18, inspired superlatives and heated comparisons: a charging bull, Heathcliff from “Wuthering Heights.” His return in 2003 was that year’s hottest ticket, and soon his brooding allure was hailed on People magazine’s “50 Most Beautiful” list. So why have his New York fans had to wait so long?

headline: Sound Bite: Dylan and Hopper Penn at Milan Fashion Week
abstract: The sister and brother acting pair found themselves with some spare time on the front row.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — After Gucci postponed its show on Wednesday for more than an hour over a late plane from London, the first day of Milan Fashion Week tipped into delay after delay with dominolike effect.

headline: Leche y Miel Restaurant
abstract: A quiet Latin spot in Kingsbridge, the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: A quiet Latin spot in Kingsbridge, the Bronx.

headline: Sweet Simplicity at Leche y Miel in the Bronx
abstract: Pungent island flavors from a couple with roots in the Dominican Republic.
lead_paragraph: To begin, mofonguitos: green plantains fried, mashed with garlic and olive oil, then popped into a lemon squeezer, making rough cups that look like craters. Into their maws go knots of hot, plump shrimp and a web, quickly melting, of Parmesan.

headline: Sepp Blatter, on Eve of FIFA Election, Is Exiting ‘a Happy Man’
abstract: In an interview a day before he is replaced as FIFA president, a sunny and reflective Blatter declared, “Every day is a fiesta.”
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — A day before he was to relinquish his title as the most powerful man in sports, Sepp Blatter already had his final morning as FIFA president planned. He said he would wake up and dance a little, as he always does (Frank Sinatra’s “My Way” is a favorite). He would monitor the election, he said. But he turned down several offers from friends, journalists and, he said, even a priest, to give him company while his FIFA career was to officially come to a close.

headline: The Whitney Will Be Alive With the Sounds of Sing Sing
abstract: Andrea Fraser’s site-specific audio installation starts a series of five short shows called “Open Plan.”
lead_paragraph: The fearless performance and video artist Andrea Fraser specializes in satirizing the rituals and myths of the high-art world, with withering attention on its political and social blind spots. “Down the River,” Ms. Fraser’s site-specific audio installation at the Whitney Museum of American Art, consists of ambient sounds recorded at Sing Sing Correctional Facility, which is 35 miles up the Hudson River from the museum’s new building. It’s meant to address the accelerated construction of museum buildings and prisons in the United States since the 1970s, parallel trends of cultural expression and incarceration. Running from February 26- March 13, it’s the first installment in “Open Plan,” a series of five short shows, each of which will occupy the whole of the museum’s 18,200-square-foot gallery, the largest unobstructed museum exhibition space in New York. After Ms. Fraser in “Open Plan” are renowned names in their genres: the painter Lucy Dodd, March 17-20; the sculptor Michael Heizer, March 25 to April 10; the musician Cecil Taylor, April 15-24; and the filmmaker Steve McQueen, April 29 to May 14. (whitney.org.)

headline: Hank Aaron’s Hard Road to Baseball Glory
abstract: He is the subject of a four-part series, “Major League Legends,” on the Smithsonian Channel.
lead_paragraph: Spring training has begun, and the sports channels are turning their thoughts to baseball, but so is the Smithsonian Channel. On Monday, it begins a four-part docu-series called “Major League Legends” with a moving episode on Hank Aaron. Every fan knows his triumphant trot around the bases when he broke Babe Ruth’s major league home run record in 1974, but this program traces the difficult road he traveled to get to that moment.

headline: Piotr Anderszewski’s Riddles of Bach and Schumann
abstract: This poetic pianist presents a solo recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday, March 3.
lead_paragraph: Piotr Anderszewski is an uncommonly poetic pianist, one with so awkward a stage presence that he can seem like a riddle. The program he presents for his solo recital at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday, March 3, is a riddle of sorts, too, a musical palindrome. After opening with one Bach Partita (No. 6), it moves on to early Schumann, pauses on the Impressionist-Symbolist reverie of Szymanowski’s “Metopes,” then reverses its steps through late Schumann and back to Bach (Partita No. 1). “Metopes,” based on three Classical friezes depicting stages of Homer’s “The Odyssey,” are lovely works that are too rarely played and that seem to look both forward and backward. The first is inspired by Odysseus’s encounter with the Sirens. It will be haunting to hear it followed by Schumann’s “Ghost Variations,” the last work he wrote before being confined to a mental institution; according to experts, Schumann tried to drown himself in the Rhine between the composition of the fourth and fifth variations. (7:30 p.m.; lcgreatperformers.org.)

headline: ‘The Crucible’ Returns to Broadway
abstract: Saoirse Ronan and Ben Whishaw lead a deep cast in this revival directed by Ivo van Hove at the Walter Kerr Theater.
lead_paragraph: It’s turning into the season of the witch. Earning the kind of raves for a horror movie not seen since “It Follows,” the period piece “The Witch” takes audiences back to the days when people thought covens were not just the stuff of spooky stories. The finest satire in Judd Apatow’s new Netflix show, “Love,” takes place on the studio lot of a tween-courting television series about witches with the spectacularly awful title “Wichita.” And there’s a new Broadway revival of Arthur Miller’s “The Crucible,” the most famous play about the anxiety of witchcraft this side of “Macbeth.” The last time this was on Broadway, in 2002, Richard Eyre directed a worthy production starring Laura Linney and Liam Neeson. Expect something more adventurous from the director Ivo van Hove, who staged the stripped-down revival of Mr. Miller’s “A View from the Bridge.” He has an equally impressive roster to work with, including Saoirse Ronan, Ben Whishaw and Ciaran Hinds. (Previews begin March 1 at Walter Kerr Theater; thecrucibleonbroadway.com.)

headline: A Dance and Music Pairing of Steps and Keys
abstract: Trio ConcertDance matches two dancers and a pianist in what could be called choreographic chamber music at the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: Chamber-music performances — say, by a fine string quartet or trio — can be magical in the way they combine intimacy of scale with emotional expansiveness. Two dancers and a pianist will offer what could be called choreographic chamber music in Trio ConcertDance. The participants — Alessandra Ferri, a former principal dancer of both American Ballet Theater and England’s Royal Ballet; Herman Cornejo, a principal dancer with A.B.T.; and Bruce Levingston, an American pianist — are known for their expressive range. The international group of choreographers for Trio includes the French-based Angelin Preljocaj; Demis Volpi, a resident choreographer of the Stuttgart Ballet; Russell Maliphant, associate artist of London’s Sadler’s Wells Theater; Stanton Welch of the Australian Ballet; and the Taiwanese choreographer Fang-Yi Sheu. All but one of their dances were commissioned for Trio. Mr. Levingston’s versatility will be on display as he cycles through Bach, Chopin, Philip Glass and more. (Wednesday, March 2, through March 6; Joyce Theater, joyce.org.)

headline: Vicente Amigo Plays Flamenco Guitar With a Personal Flair
abstract: Mr. Amigo, who often mixes other languages and techniques into his music, brings a traditional ensemble and dancer to a Carnegie Hall show.
lead_paragraph: The flamenco guitarist Vicente Amigo, from Seville, Spain, has called his engagement with his instrument “beloved torture.” You can imagine why when you hear him play: He reaches for depth of expression within ultimate precision, and sometimes at frightening speed. Now in his late 40s, he has worked with some of the great traditional flamenco singers of the last several decades — Camarón de la Isla, Enrique Morente, Diego el Cigala and Carmen Linares — but has also been part of the genre’s modernizing wave: He encompasses the tradition while trying other languages and techniques. (His last album, “Tierra,” combined flamenco with Celtic music.) He’s played in New York before, but his appearance this week, at Carnegie Hall’s Stern Auditorium, is part of his first major United States tour. It won’t be Celtic or any other kind of fusion: He’s bringing a traditional ensemble, as well as the dancer Antonio Molina, known as El Choro. (8 p.m., March 4; Carnegie Hall, carnegiehall.org.)

headline: Learning to Act, but Hungry for Roles to Practice
abstract: A new program at colleges and universities aims at cultivating female playwrights and the creation of more female characters in their work.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The playwright Kirsten Greenidge was in high demand. Over in the South End, her Obie-winning drama, “Milk Like Sugar,” was in previews at the Huntington Theater Company. A couple of miles west, at Boston University, her new play, “Baltimore,” was edging toward opening. In both places, there was work she needed to do.

headline: Bluffer’s Guide to the Oscars: Best Picture
abstract: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.
lead_paragraph: Everything you need to know about the contenders in one quick rundown.

headline: One Cocktail, Two Spirits: Bartenders Go for a Blend
abstract: That manhattan or old-fashioned may have more than one type of bourbon or rye.
lead_paragraph: When you’re ordering an old-fashioned, the first and main question facing you is this: bourbon or rye? At Valkyrie, a bar in Tulsa, Okla., you don’t have to make that decision. You get both.

headline: A Family Adds Five Children, Special Needs and All
abstract: In November, this family adopted five young children from foster care.
lead_paragraph: Diane Stanley has seven children in her home: her biological son, Cooper, 18; her foster son, David, 22, who is intellectually disabled; and five younger children whom she and her husband adopted in November 2015. Those five include the biological siblings Demetries, 8; Caleb, 4; and Maya, 2; as well as the biological sisters Julianna, 7, and Juliette, 6. She is also the mother of two adult children and the stepmother to two adult children, and she has one stepdaughter, 14, who lives with her mother.

headline: Setback for Picasso’s Daughter in Battle Over Sculpture
abstract: A French court rejects a request by Maya Widmaier-Picasso in a battle over a sculpture by her father.
lead_paragraph: A French court has rejected a plea by the daughter of Pablo Picasso to void a seizure order for a valuable sculpture at the center of a dispute over ownership between the New York dealer Larry Gagosian and an agent for the Qatari royal family.

headline: Donald Trump Leads in Florida, While Ted Cruz Has Edge in Texas, Polls Show
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Having won three consecutive states, Donald J. Trump could deal a decisive blow to his two leading rivals if he manages to beat them, Senator Ted Cruz of Texas and Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, in their home state primaries in March.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump holds a wide lead over Senator Marco Rubio in his home state of Florida, but trails Senator Ted Cruz on his turf in Texas, according to two new polls of coming primary contests that could ultimately determine the Republican presidential nomination.

headline: Sinn Fein Gains Popularity in Ireland Through a Desire for Change
abstract: The party linked to the Irish Republican Army is poised to gain more seats in Parliament, riding a wave of dissatisfaction with austerity measures.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Sean Crowe, a member of the Irish Parliament, has been around long enough to remember just how tough it was to attract votes when his party, Sinn Fein, was known only as the political arm of the Irish Republican Army as it waged a guerrilla campaign against Britain in Northern Ireland, only an hour’s drive from his Dublin constituency.

headline: Ted Cruz Fights in Texas, Hoping It Won’t Be His Alamo
abstract: The Super Tuesday voting states have always been at the center of Mr. Cruz’s campaign strategy, and now Texas is at the forefront of that plan.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Senator Ted Cruz cannot stop talking about the Alamo.

headline: New Baseball Rules Take On Rolling Slides and ‘Neighborhood Plays’
abstract: Under Major League Baseball rules changes announced on Thursday, block slides will be outlawed and neighborhood plays will be subject to video review.
lead_paragraph: When Chase Utley’s slide broke Ruben Tejada’s right leg in Game 2 of a National League division series between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the Mets, the relatively common tactic of trying to break up a double play was put under a microscope, with many assuming that a change in baseball’s rules would result.

headline: Jeremy McQueen’s Ballet Collective to Foster Black Works
abstract: Starting in May, Jeremy McQueen’s new ballet collective, Black Iris Project, will present new works about black lives and history.
lead_paragraph: The Black Iris Project, a new ballet collective aiming to foster and present new works about black lives and history, takes its name from a Georgia O’Keeffe painting, “Black Iris III” (1926).

headline: Technology Problems Top a List of Car Complaints
abstract: The results of J.D. Power’s latest survey on vehicle dependability suggest there is a long way to go before self-driving cars become practical.
lead_paragraph: Craig Sakowitz could be considered a technologically adept driver. As an e-commerce project manager for the Gap in San Francisco, he often rents cars and relies on hands-free technologies to get work done.

headline: Some Calais ‘Jungle’ Camp Migrants Get Eviction Reprieve
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons', 'Volunteers and Community Service']
abstract: The French government got permission to relocate some of the migrants, but for now, anyway, the camp cannot be leveled, a court ruled.
lead_paragraph: CALAIS, France — Somewhere between the Good Chance Theater and the One Spirit Ashram Kitchen sits the School of Arts and Trades, not to mention the Hamid Karzai Restaurant and Arts in the Village.

headline: Science in the National Interest
abstract: Lamar Smith, chairman of the House Committee on Science, Space and Technology, takes issue with an editorial that is critical of his legislation.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Leaving Las Vegas for Natural Beauty and More
abstract: Lesser-known Vegas day trips: a Martian landscape, a snowy peak and red rocks, all to be savored on scenic drives or hikes.
lead_paragraph: Las Vegas is not only about gambling, partying and making certain that everything that you do there stays there: it’s just mostly about those things. If you’re feeling a little grimy from the previous night or need to soothe your hurt pride from losses incurred at the blackjack table, take solace in the knowledge there’s a wealth of natural beauty and interesting side trips at your disposal. Last week I discussed the underappreciated gems off the Strip — but if you’re willing to travel a bit farther, the rewards become a lot more beautiful. The Hoover Dam, Lake Mead and the Grand Canyon are among the most popular — but here are a few more options that are both less obvious and, in some cases, a lot closer.

headline: On Assisted Dying
abstract: A psychiatrist says a psychiatric evaluation should be required before a decision to end one’s life occurs because of a false sense of hopelessness.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Swedish Girl Who Ran Away to Iraq Says She Had Not Heard of ISIS
abstract: In a video interview with Kurdish TV, Marilyn Nevalainen, 16, said she knew nothing about the Islamic State before she ran away to Iraq with her boyfriend.
lead_paragraph: A Swedish teenager rescued from the Islamic State said she had never heard of the militant group known as ISIS before running away with her boyfriend to join the extremists at their base in Iraq.

headline: A Ski Trip, but Work
keywords: ['Customs, Etiquette and Manners', 'Skiing', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Indecency, Obscenity and Profanity', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Also, racial interaction tips; the book on colleague swearing; and clues to handling disappointments.
lead_paragraph: My mother recently ended a long-term relationship. She and her ex-boyfriend loved skiing together, and she really misses it. Last week, my boyfriend’s firm invited us to a ski retreat in Park City, Utah. It is a work event with significant others only. It is also the first time my boyfriend qualified to attend. (It’s a prestigious invitation; all expenses are paid by the company.) My mother asked if she could come along. We explained the context to her, but she keeps pushing to join us. What should we do?

headline: What Binds a Marriage
abstract: Readers share their views of successful marriage.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Why Tech Degrees Are Not Putting More Blacks and Hispanics Into Tech Jobs
keywords: ['Engineering and Engineers', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Careers and Professions']
abstract: There are many more black and Hispanic students majoring in computer science and engineering than work in tech jobs. So why aren’t they being hired?
lead_paragraph: Technology companies employ strikingly few black and Hispanic workers. They blame the recruitment pipeline, saying there aren’t enough of them graduating with relevant degrees and applying for tech jobs.

headline: Pop Art International: Far Beyond Warhol and Lichtenstein
abstract: An exhibition reveals how Pop Art shook up Eastern Europe, Latin America and Asia.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — “Remember how insane the 1960s felt, every day?” someone asked me at a preview of the traveling exhibition “International Pop,” which is making its final stop here at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. Absolutely I remember, and the show — brash, manic and acid-tinged — took me right back there.

headline: Will Shortz: Everything You Want To Know About Crossword Puzzles
abstract: What rhymes with orange? Times crossword puzzle editor and self-described “puzzlehead,” Will Shortz answers readers’ questions.
lead_paragraph: What rhymes with orange? Times crossword puzzle editor and self-described “puzzlehead,” Will Shortz answers readers’ questions.

headline: New Movie House in Manhattan: Metrograph Theater
abstract: As part of its opening, the theater will show 16 films involving the movie-going experience.
lead_paragraph: Quietly, New York City is adding movie theaters. True, the Ziegfeld has closed, but last month, Brooklyn gained the Syndicated; this week, the Lower East Side welcomes the Metrograph Theater. To mark the occasion, the Metrograph begins its life with “Surrender to the Screen,” 16 films whose plot lines feature the film-going experience.

headline: Rachel Weisz to Star in ‘Plenty’ at the Public Theater
abstract: The revival of David Hare’s “Plenty” is set for the Public Theater this fall, the theater announced on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Rachel Weisz will star in a revival of David Hare’s “Plenty” at the Public Theater this fall, the Off Broadway nonprofit announced Thursday.

headline: Met Opera Names Ennead Architects to Redesign Lobby
abstract: The opera house has chosen the firm to lead the renovation of its cramped lobby.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera has selected Ennead Architects to design the renovation and expansion of its lobby, the opera house said on Thursday.

headline: Program Offers Free E-Books to Low-Income Children
abstract: Under the Open eBooks program thousands of best-selling books are available free to low-income children.
lead_paragraph: Open eBooks, a program making thousands of best-selling books available for free to low-income children, signed up roughly 50,000 users on its first day, according a report by the project’s partner organizations.

headline: Luxurious Italian Pajamas, Inspired by Literature
abstract: The designer Francesca Ruffini, who showed her collection for F.R.S. today in Milan, takes T on a tour of her Lake Como library.
lead_paragraph: Sitting on a long velvet sofa and looking out over Lake Como, Francesca Ruffini calls this her “place of serenity.” Her villa, perched on a steep mountainside that plunges into the lake’s eastern edge, is an oasis in the grand Como style: tiled with large slabs of black-and-white marble, neatly lined with paintings, statues and books. A row of indoor palms behind arched glass doors opens to a topiary garden with sweeping views of the water and snow-capped mountains.

headline: Francesca Ruffini, at Home on Lake Como
abstract: T visited the designer before her F.R.S presentation, which showed today in Milan, to learn about the influences for her fall collection.
lead_paragraph: T visited the designer before her F.R.S presentation, which showed today in Milan, to learn about the influences for her fall collection.

headline: Breanna Stewart Completes Her Run of Dominance
abstract: Breanna Stewart’s four-year record with UConn was 151-5, and every victory but one was by 10 or more points.
lead_paragraph: Breanna Stewart’s four-year record with UConn was 151-5, and every victory but one was by 10 or more points.

headline: Street Style: Milan
abstract: The chic set around the Italian city during fashion week.
lead_paragraph: The chic set around the Italian city during fashion week.

headline: ^: Off With the Circumflex!
abstract: A reader and her French colleagues say it’s hard to find it on the keyboard.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Once a Coup, Pipeline Company Deal Becomes a Nightmare
abstract: Shares of Energy Transfer Equity and the Williams Companies have plummeted, partly because of numerous concerns about their complicated merger.
lead_paragraph: Over the last decade, Kelcy Warren became one of the great beneficiaries of America’s energy boom. The son of a Texas oil-field worker, Mr. Warren built a multibillion-dollar fortune amassing a 71,000-mile network of pipelines across the United States.

headline: 36 Hours in Palm Springs, California
abstract: The city's midcentury modern architecture, which effortlessly blends desert and design, is all the rage.
lead_paragraph: The city's midcentury modern architecture, which effortlessly blends desert and design, is all the rage.

headline: SeaWorld Admits Employees Posed as Animal Rights Activists
abstract: People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, or PETA, accused the company of infiltrating its ranks and joining protests against the amusement park.
lead_paragraph: SeaWorld acknowledged on Thursday that it had sent company employees to pose as animal rights activists to protect the company “from credible threats.”

headline: Bill Clinton Defends Welfare Law From Bernie Sanders’s Attacks
abstract: A day after Bernie Sanders criticized Hillary Clinton for supporting a welfare overhaul bill in 1996, Bill Clinton mounted a defense of the law without attacking the Vermont senator directly.
lead_paragraph: ROCK HILL, S.C. – A day after Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont sharply criticized Hillary Clinton for supporting a welfare overhaul bill in 1996, former President Bill Clinton mounted a detailed defense of the law on Thursday while restraining himself from attacking his wife’s opponent.

headline: How One Contemporary Artist Got Addicted to Finger Painting
abstract: Some of the 6-by-12-foot pieces in Mark Wallinger’s “ID,” on view at Hauser & Wirth, functioned therapeutically for the artist.
lead_paragraph: The works in Mark Wallinger’s new exhibition at Hauser & Wirth in London, “ID,” span a range of methods, from the prehistoric to the very recent. For an evocative series of huge, black-and-white finger-painted “iD” works, Wallinger cites precedent as far back as the earliest rock art. On the newer end of the technological spectrum, several films and photographs in the show were shot on an iPhone, a tool that appeals to the artist for its ubiquity and the texture of its footage: for conveying contemporary experience, he says, “it’s the most appropriate tool.”

headline: Italian Senate Approves Civil Unions for Gay Couples, but Not Adoptions
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'ADOPTIONS', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Legislatures and Parliaments', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The bill passed handily once a provision allowing same-sex couples to adopt stepchildren was cut; gay rights advocates condemned the move.
lead_paragraph: ROME — After months of political infighting and decades of battles by gay people for civil rights, Italy’s Senate on Thursday approved the country’s first law granting legal recognition to civil unions, but stopped short of giving same-sex couples the right to stepchild adoption.

headline: We Should Probably Have a Conversation About ‘Damn, Daniel’
abstract: An examination by “The Ellen DeGeneres Show” and participation by major brands may mark the end of the lifespan of Internet sensations like this one.
lead_paragraph: Every once in a while, a meme rises up from the wondrous bog of entertaining nonsense that is the Internet.

headline: Nonbillionaire Candidates
abstract: The group Every Voice writes that another billionaire candidacy “isn’t a serious solution to the money-in-politics problem.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Do U.S. Drones Really Make Us Safer?
abstract: “In 2012, drones attacked the wedding celebration of my eldest son,” a Yemeni reader writes. Two other readers also criticize U.S. drone policy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Suffolk County Police Release Video of 2014 Shooting of Long Island Developer
abstract: Two years after a masked gunman ambushed Gary Melius and shot him in the head, the police have asked the Federal Bureau of Investigation for assistance in the unsolved case.
lead_paragraph: The assassination attempt has proved as baffling as it was brazen.

headline: Review: ‘Prodigals’ by Greg Jackson Skewers the Elite
abstract: This collection of stories satirizes the lives of characters who are filmmakers, architects and tennis pros.
lead_paragraph: The writing in Greg Jackson’s first book of stories, “Prodigals,” is so bold and perceptive that it delivers a contact high. You know from the first pages that, intellectually, you’ve climbed into a high-performance sports car. Only one question remains: Will the author smash it into a tree?

headline: U.N. Envoy Prepares to Set Date for Syria Talks to Resume
abstract: The envoy, Staffan de Mistura, said that he been encouraged by “serious changes” after peace talks were suspended, but that obstacles remained.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — Staffan de Mistura, the United Nations special envoy for the Syrian conflict, said on Thursday that he was preparing to set a date for peace negotiations to resume in Geneva, three weeks after breaking off talks between the warring parties. Mr. de Mistura said he had been encouraged by what he called “serious changes” on the ground.

headline: At Prada, Romantic Beauty That’s Just a Little Off-Kilter
abstract: The hairstylist Guido Palau created a beauty look for the fall/winter 2016 show that he described as “powerful, and slightly kinky in a way.”
lead_paragraph: “For Miuccia Prada, the men’s show was a preview to what she was feeling for women’s wear,” said the hairstylist Guido Palau backstage in the hours before Prada’s women’s collection. “And Miuccia wanted to continue the same look we created for the women in January’s show.”

headline: ‘Falsettos’ Is Returning to Broadway
abstract: Lincoln Center Theater will stage a revival of “Falsettos” on Broadway in the fall.
lead_paragraph: Marvin and Whizzer are coming back to Broadway, to a neighborhood and a society that has changed dramatically since they last visited.

headline: As Bombs Hit Syrian Hospitals, Medical Workers Fear They Are the Target
abstract: Many medical workers and rights groups believe facilities are not just being hit by stray airstrikes, but have long been deliberately targeted by the Syrian government and its Russian allies.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The hospital in the northern Syrian town of Maarat al-Noaman was not just grazed, or damaged, by the airstrikes last week. It was destroyed, taking a direct hit that pancaked its three stories into one, entombing and killing 25 people, including nine staff members.

headline: Artful and Stunning Cabinets of Curiosities, Decoded
abstract: Mark Dion discusses major works in his new show, which displays live birds, puzzle pieces and old trash.
lead_paragraph: This past weekend, the artist Mark Dion was standing in the midst of his apartment in Upper Manhattan, looking very relaxed after having just dispatched boxes upon boxes — which were filled with countless smaller boxes — from his living room down to Chelsea for his latest gallery showing. “When I say this room was full,” he said genially with a sweep of both arms, “I mean it was full. It was mayhem. But now it’s calmed down again.”

headline: An Artist and a Poet on Coupling
abstract: The Swiss performance artist, painter and sculptor John Armleder created a response to a poem by Jericho Brown, 2015 winner of the Ainsfield-Wolf Book Award for Poetry.
lead_paragraph: For T’s ongoing series, the Swiss performance artist, painter and sculptor John Armleder created a response to a poem by Jericho Brown, 2015 winner of the Ainsfield-Wolf Book Award for Poetry.

headline: Off-Season Setback Frustrates Mets’ Brandon Nimmo
abstract: Nimmo, a first-round pick in 2013, arrived for spring training this week with two to three weeks of rehab remaining, wiping out a chance to impress Mets coaches.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — At first, Brandon Nimmo did not notice that anything was wrong. It was mid-January, and he was training for the season with purpose after the Mets had added him to the 40-man roster. He ran through his conditioning drills, lifted weights, hit for a little while and ate lunch. Only later did he notice the pain in his left foot.

headline: Prada: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Miuccia Prada shows her fall 2016 collection.
lead_paragraph: Miuccia Prada shows her fall 2016 collection.

headline: Netflix Aims for Family-Friendly Nostalgia With New Slate
keywords: ['Web-Original Programming', 'Families and Family Life', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Television']
abstract: Starting with “Fuller House” on Friday, the streaming service has lined up shows harking back to the ’80s and ’90s, meant for family watching.
lead_paragraph: Over the last couple of years, as Netflix has crashed the gates of the television industry, the service has aimed to attract all age groups. It created adult-oriented dramas like “Narcos” and “Orange Is the New Black,” developed more than two dozen original series for children and started a comedy, “Grace and Frankie,” starring four actors in their 70s.

headline: How To Read Primary Results
abstract: Nate Silver makes it all clear.
lead_paragraph: When Nate Silver is good, he’s very good. This “swingometer” from FiveThirtyEight is exactly what we all need to make sense of Democratic primary results. Oh, and hold the Hillary-hatred and all that, OK? Whoever you support, this is a great tool for tracking your favorite’s progress or lack thereof.

headline: Apple Goes to Court, and F.B.I. Presses Congress to Settle iPhone Privacy Fight
keywords: ['San Bernardino, Calif, Shooting (2015)', 'iPhone', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: In a court filing, Apple said the order had broad implications that would “inflict significant harm — to civil liberties, society and national security.”
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The legal wrangling over a federal court order requiring Apple to help law enforcement break into an iPhone intensified Thursday, with the company filing its formal response and asking the court to drop its demand.

headline: Egypt Sentences Coptic Teenagers to Prison for Insulting Islam
abstract: A court sentenced the four teenagers to up to five years for making a video in which they mocked Muslim prayer.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — An Egyptian court sentenced four Coptic Christian teenagers to up to five years in prison on Thursday after finding them guilty of insulting Islam, the latest of a series of high-profile blasphemy convictions that have drawn sharp criticism of Egypt’s judicial system.

headline: Review: Lili Reynaud-Dewar Summons Walt Whitman in Brooklyn
abstract: The French artist titles her first commercial gallery exhibition in New York “I Sing the Body Electric.”
lead_paragraph: Lili Reynaud-Dewar dancing is an amazing sight to see. Trim, androgynous and in the buff, this enormously talented French artist makes videos that show her improvising, alone, lost in private fantasies in empty public spaces. Almost always on her toes, she leaps and prances, evoking a good swath of modern dance or movement: Isadora Duncan, Nijinsky’s faun, Josephine Baker, George Balanchine and Merce Cunningham, but also folk dance, yoga and colloquial gestures.

headline: A Strange Day With Bolivia’s Evo Morales
keywords: ['Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Exercise', 'Referendums', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Bolivian voters were right to decide that the president’s third term in office will be his last.
lead_paragraph: Last week, I was invited to spend a day with President Evo Morales of Bolivia.

headline: Prada’s Fall/Winter 2016 Set
abstract: The Rem Koolhaas-led architecture firm OMA team takes T behind the scenes.
lead_paragraph: The Rem Koolhaas-led architecture firm OMA team takes T behind the scenes.

headline: Review: Amy Sillman Returns to Figurative Motifs
abstract: Her new exhibition, “Stuff Change” at Sikkema Jenkins, features works that are defined yet remain ambiguous.
lead_paragraph: Artists sometimes move too fast, abandoning parts of a personal style that deserve development. And so, in some of the best paintings of her career, Amy Sillman steps back from abstraction to reassert the ambiguous figurative motifs from her earlier paintings, which conjure cartoons, modernist abbreviation and a persistent eroticism. “Stuff Change,” the show’s title, bluntly suggests artistic growth, but is also a literal translation of “stoffwechsel,” the German word for metabolism.

headline: The Making of Prada’s Understated, Architectural Set
abstract: Rem Koolhaas’s OMA team breaks down the latest set in its 15-year long collaboration with the fashion house.
lead_paragraph: Each season, after the fashion masses pile into a Milanese venue or (these days) load a live-stream, the designer Miuccia Prada displays not only her latest vision, but one of the industry’s strongest, and innovative, alliances — the partnership between her house and the Rem Koolhaas-led architecture firm OMA. For 15 years, they’ve partnered on boutiques, branding studies, films, digital products, projects for Fondazione Prada and, of course, runway shows.

headline: Scott Kelly’s Year in Space
abstract: On Tuesday, Scott J. Kelly is scheduled to return from the International Space Station, completing the longest stay in space for a NASA astronaut. Here are some ways to measure his mission.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Scott J. Kelly is scheduled to return from the International Space Station, completing the longest stay in space for a NASA astronaut. Here are some ways to measure his mission.

headline: Readers Respond: Do Armed Guards Make Hospitals Feel Safer?
keywords: ['Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Gun Control', 'Hospitals', 'Emergency Medical Treatment']
abstract: New York Times readers, including patients and people who work in hospitals and in law enforcement, shared their thoughts and experiences.
lead_paragraph: Does equipping security guards with Tasers and guns make hospitals safer for staff members, visitors and patients — and under what circumstances? That was the issue raised by my article about Alan Pean, a college student with bipolar illness, who was shot in his hospital room — after a scuffle with an off-duty police officer who was moonlighting as a hospital security officer. My article was accompanied by a podcast produced by “This American Life,” our first such collaboration.

headline: Dilone Transforms at Fendi
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.

headline: Apple’s Motion Opposing the iPhone Order
abstract: The company filed its formal opposition to the federal court order requiring it to help law enforcement officials break into an iPhone connected to the San Bernardino shootings.
lead_paragraph: The company filed its formal opposition to the federal court order requiring it to help law enforcement officials break into an iPhone connected to the San Bernardino shootings.

headline: Supreme Court Fight Won’t Die, No Matter How Hard Republicans Try
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']
abstract: Democrats continued their battle to fill the vacant court seat in the Senate on Thursday as Republicans held firm against doing so.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senate Republicans, facing fierce criticism from Democrats on Capitol Hill, insisted Thursday that they would face no political retribution from their decision to shun any Supreme Court nomination made by President Obama, expressing confidence that they would not be hurt at the polls in November.

headline: F.B.I. Chief Presses Congress to Act on Data Privacy
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Privacy', 'Computer Security', 'Software', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: “The larger question isn’t going to be answered in the courts, and shouldn’t be,” said James B. Comey Jr., who is fighting Apple to unlock a mass killer’s iPhone.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The head of the F.B.I., battling Apple over unlocking an iPhone used by one of the killers in a December rampage in San Bernardino, Calif., called on Congress on Thursday to settle the question of when law enforcement officials should get access to citizens’ private data.

headline: University of Missouri Fires Melissa Click, Who Tried to Block Journalist at Protest
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Colleges and Universities', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press']
abstract: An assistant professor who called for “some muscle” as she tried to remove journalists from a campus protest last year was dismissed.
lead_paragraph: A University of Missouri professor whose shout of “I need some muscle over here,” to remove a student journalist from a demonstration sparked an international debate over the limits of protest and a free press, has been fired, the university announced Thursday.

headline: Breanna Stewart, UConn’s Wow Factor, Always Had a Sweep in Mind
abstract: No college basketball player has won four consecutive N.C.A.A. Division I titles, but Breanna Stewart, the two-time player of the year, and her classmates are close.
lead_paragraph: Breanna Stewart remembered the play, and how could she not? It was one of those flashes of athletic entitlement she has been lectured on during her four-year course study at Connecticut in advanced basketball dramatic arts.

headline: Mrs. Clinton, Show Voters Those Transcripts
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Voters are entitled to know what Mrs. Clinton said in paid speeches to industry groups, and stonewalling on this will only damage her.
lead_paragraph: “Everybody does it,” is an excuse expected from a mischievous child, not a presidential candidate. But that is Hillary Clinton’s latest defense for making closed-door, richly paid speeches to big banks, which many middle-class Americans still blame for their economic pain, and then refusing to release the transcripts.

headline: The Archbishop Is Troubled By The Girl Scout Ethos, Not the Cookies
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Cookies', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Archbishop Robert Carlson of St. Louis accused the Girl Scouts of associating with organizations “in conflict with Catholic values,” like Oxfam.
lead_paragraph: So far, the Trefoils and Samoas have not been interdicted. Nor have the Thin Mints and Tagalongs. Catholics in St. Louis began asking about the fate of the Girl Scout cookie sale soon after Archbishop Robert Carlson called on parishes to consider alternatives to the scouts because of “a troubling pattern of behavior” he finds “incompatible” with church teachings on such issues as contraception and abortion.

headline: Global Finance Leaders Meet as Economic Skies Darken
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Renminbi (Currency)']
abstract: Government and central bank officials are gathering in Shanghai with few easy answers to sluggishness in Europe, China and Japan.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — The global economy looks shaky. Markets for things as diverse as oil and European bank shares have plumbed new lows. The tried-and-true cures no longer seem to work.

headline: Merger Plans Fall Apart for Oi, Troubled Brazilian Telecom
abstract: Telecom Italia’s Brazilian operator said it was ending talks with Oi on a merger proposed by a Russian oligarch.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Shares of the Brazilian telecommunications company Oi plunged on Thursday after TIM Participações, the Brazil operator of Telecom Italia, rebuffed an offer made by the Russian oligarch Mikhail Fridman to merge the two companies.

headline: Vicente Fox and Felipe Calderón, 2 Ex-Presidents of Mexico, Say No Way Country Is Paying for Donald Trump’s Wall
abstract: Vicente Fox and Felipe Calderón have a message for Mr. Trump: You want a wall on the border? You pay for it.
lead_paragraph: At almost all of his campaign rallies, Donald J. Trump leads a familiar refrain as he details his plan to build a giant wall along the border with Mexico.

headline: Sarah Huckabee, Mike’s Daughter, Joins Donald Trump Campaign
abstract: Ms. Huckabee’s addition gives the Trump campaign a toehold in Arkansas, one of 12 states that vote on Super Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Huckabee, the daughter of Mike Huckabee — the former governor of Arkansas and two-time presidential candidate — joined Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign this week as a senior adviser, giving Mr. Trump a toehold in Arkansas, one of 12 states that are holding nominating contests on Super Tuesday.

headline: Yogurt-Making Tips From Readers
abstract: Everyone, it seems, has an opinion on the best way to make yogurt.
lead_paragraph: Everyone, it seems, has an opinion on the best way to make yogurt.

headline: Bill Gates Explains How to Make Climate Progress in a World Eating Meat and Guzzling Gas

headline: Unpaid Bills Bedevil Harlem Church Known for Its Outspoken Pastor
abstract: The views of James L. Manning, the pastor of the Atlah Worldwide Church, have long provoked neighbors and others, many of whom have staged protests.
lead_paragraph: Ask James L. Manning, the pastor of the Atlah Worldwide Church, why he is involved in a legal battle to save his redbrick building in Harlem from foreclosure, and he gives the same answer he employs when talking about many of the world’s problems. “It’s primarily about my very vigorous opposition to the sodomy activity going on in this community,” he said.

headline: Dwight Eschliman’s “Ingredients”
abstract: For his new book, the photographer isolated and took pictures of 75 common food additives, plus the ingredients of 25 grocery-store staples.
lead_paragraph: For his new book, the photographer isolated and took pictures of 75 common food additives, plus the ingredients of 25 grocery-store staples.

headline: ‘Friday File’: The Whitney’s 1966 Debut (Now the Met Breuer)
abstract: The Whitney has moved on to its fancy new digs, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art is moving in. The Met Breuer’s building will be largely unchanged.
lead_paragraph: The Whitney has moved on to its fancy new digs. It has left the old place — shuttered for two years — to renters. Don’t worry, the tenant won’t trash the building. It’s the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and it has a healthy respect for history. When the Met Breuer is unveiled next week, the building, inside and out, will be largely unchanged from when it opened in 1966.

headline: Nets Waive Johnson; Curry Scores 51 Points
abstract: Johnson, 34, who averaged 11.8 points and 4.1 assists this season, will be able to join a new team, perhaps a playoff contender, if he clears waivers on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The Nets requested waivers Thursday on Joe Johnson, a seven-time All-Star shooting guard whose likeness still dominates team promotional materials.

headline: A Word With: Neal Brennan
abstract: Mr. Brennan, 42, has a show, “3 Mics,” opening at the Lynn Redgrave Theater, that balances one-liners, “emotional stuff” and stand-up.
lead_paragraph: The set design for Neal Brennan’s new one-man comedy show, “3 Mics,” is just as the title suggests — three microphones on one stage. The first is devoted to one-liners, which he reads from sheets of paper; the second is billed as being for “emotional stuff,” monologues exploring issues like his relationship with his alcoholic father and his own struggles with depression; the third is for stand-up.

headline: Photos That Show What (Really) Goes Into the Food We Eat
abstract: For his “Ingredients” project, Dwight Eschliman documents ubiquitous additives, from yeast and caffeine to propylene glycol.
lead_paragraph: Deconstruction has long been a theme in the photographer Dwight Eschliman’s work. So when a chef proposed that he examine the composition of food, Eschliman decided to begin with that fabled American standby — the Twinkie. Around 37 ingredients later, Eschliman became fascinated by what exactly goes into the food we eat — particularly highly processed foods, with intimidatingly long ingredient lists. For his most recent project, Eschliman selected 75 of the most ubiquitous additives — or “functional ingredients,” as they’re called in the industry — to photograph individually, from yeast and caffeine to disodium inosinate and propylene glycol. He also photographed the separate ingredients of 25 grocery-store staples: Amy’s Burritos, Cool Whip, Red Bull and more. The result is the book “Ingredients,” created in collaboration with Steve Ettlinger, a pop-science writer who has also made a mission of demystifying the Twinkie.

headline: Philadelphia Museum of Art Finally Gets a Hopper
abstract: Also, the Art Dealers Association of America’s art show, which begins on Wednesday, will feature works by Kirchner and early selfies by Gillian Wearing.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe that the Philadelphia Museum of Art has never had a Hopper.

headline: Review: Heidi Hahn at the Jack Hanley Gallery
abstract: The works in the artist’s first New York solo show, “Bent Idle,” portray young women in the age of emojis and social media.
lead_paragraph: The clock reads 12:30 in “Everything Left Is Plain” (2016), a pink-red painting in Heidi Hahn’s first New York solo show, “Bent Idle,” at Jack Hanley. It’s impossible to tell, however, whether this means afternoon or just after midnight. The same ambiguity runs throughout Ms. Hahn’s other paintings, which depict young women laughing and crying — or perhaps laughing and crying at the same time — in groups and pairs, or alone with a cat or a candle.

lead_paragraph: Paris is entering another culinary golden age, only this time with influences as diverse as its people.

abstract: The Mariinsky Orchestra and five soloists, including the young superstar Daniil Trifonov, played a complete survey of this composer’s piano concertos at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: It’s not every day that a young superstar like Daniil Trifonov, the sensational Russian pianist, agrees to be just one of five soloists in a marathon concerto concert. But clearly he could not resist taking part in “Folk, Form, and Fire,” a complete survey of Prokofiev’s five piano concertos, performed in order on Wednesday at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by Valery Gergiev and the Mariinsky Orchestra, who are in residency there.

headline: Paula Modersohn-Becker and Her Thwarted Ambitions
abstract: This artist recognized her talent early on. She died young in 1907, leaving behind an intriguing body of work.
lead_paragraph: An exhibition of Paula Modersohn-Becker’s art is almost by definition a bittersweet event. It’s thrilling to watch this pioneering German painter restlessly experiment with color and surface in the form of portraits, landscapes, still lifes and scenes of peasant women and children she made during her short time on earth. It’s sad to wonder what she might have done had she lived longer. So it is with “Paula Modersohn-Becker: Art and Life,” a riveting exhibition at Galerie St. Etienne, the keeper of her flame in this country.

headline: A Quirky Board Game With Versions Spanning 400 Years
abstract: The Grolier Club is exhibiting around 70 antique variations of the Game of the Goose, illustrated with images ranging from cannibals to breath-mint ads.
lead_paragraph: Adrian Seville has bought hundreds of board games, but he has hardly any interest in playing them. A retired university administrator living outside London, Dr. Seville has focused on collecting variants of the Game of the Goose, which was invented in the 15th century and remains in production. While its rules may be too simplistic for his tastes — players roll dice and try to beat one another to the 63rd square — he nonetheless described the collecting process as “highly addictive.”

headline: New York International Children’s Film Festival Gives Young Heroes Their Stage
abstract: The festival, which runs through March 20, is well stocked with hair-raising tales (all with generally happy resolutions, of course).
lead_paragraph: A film festival for children might sound, on the surface, like a safe and festive zone — sunshine, puppies, hugs and happy families. But any young reader or moviegoer knows better. From the Brothers Grimm to “The Wizard of Oz” to Harry Potter, some of our darkest stories are the ones we conjure up for and about children.

headline: Review: Rhiannon Giddens Sings of Oppression
abstract: Ms. Giddens was joined by Leyla McCalla and Bhi Bhiman in an exploration of black history as part of Lincoln Center’s American Songbook series.
lead_paragraph: Somber, contemplative, quietly impassioned: “Swimming in Dark Waters — Other Voices of the American Experience” brought a concert of protest songs to the Appel Room on Wednesday evening. The 90-minute performance, a scholarly exploration of black history in folk songs and spirituals both traditional and contemporary, was a pinnacle of this season’s American Songbook series at Lincoln Center.

lead_paragraph: Pacific Northwest Ballet, by opening its return visit to New York on Wednesday night with a triple bill of three Balanchine ballets well known here, ran the risk of overfamiliarity — yet the opposite proved true. Works we thought we knew looked and felt novel, peculiar, arresting. More than that, the basic connection between music, space and dancers acquired a shocking immediacy and fullness.

headline: ‘Orchidelirium’ Explodes With Color at New York Botanical Garden
abstract: This year’s orchid show at the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory offers a tropical tour that evokes the heady time of orchid fever in Victorian England.
lead_paragraph: The orchid trail at the New York Botanical Garden burns with color like a slow fuse. Along a greenhouse walkway in the Enid A. Haupt Conservatory, refitted for “Orchidelirium,” this year’s edition of the annual orchid show, clustered plantings clamor, each more brilliant and extravagantly shaped than its neighbor. Tiny blazing-yellow Colombian buttercup orchids jostle with frilly, purply-red Pacific Sun Spots, which compete with hybrid Phalaenopsis, their petals decorated with pink stripes as fine as a hair.

headline: Review: In ‘Gods of Egypt,’ That Doughnut Beast Is Stepping on My Sandal
abstract: Alex Proyas’s special-effects extravaganza, set in antiquity, is an embarrassment of kitsch riches with intermittent moments of wit.
lead_paragraph: Bosomy damsels and brawny slabs; cheering digital crowds; a lachrymose sphinx; a bedazzled Geoffrey Rush; a galactic cruise ship; an Egyptian god played by the Dane Nikolaj Coster-Waldau; the sword-and-sandals enabler Gerard Butler; a smoky monster that from one angle looks like a fanged doughnut and from another an alarmingly enraged anus — “Gods of Egypt” attests that they do make them like they used to, or at least like the King of the Bs, Roger Corman, once did, except with far more money. If “Gods of Egypt” were any worse, it might be a masterpiece.

headline: Review: In ‘Triple 9,’ an Appealing Cast Can’t Rise Above the Violence
abstract: The film is one of those productions in which much of the creative energy has been funneled into gaudily inventive displays of brutality.
lead_paragraph: With its lurid red and brooding villains, the thriller “Triple 9” comes dressed to kill. Directed by John Hillcoat, it purrs to a start with men plotting in near dark, a hook-y start that establishes the look and mood. Within minutes, the men are robbing an Atlanta bank in a scene filled with gunfire and rattling, visceral specifics, like the wet stains spreading under the weeping, prostrate employees. The men’s camaraderie and choreography announce their professionalism while the guns and money telegraph the stakes. And all of this is gone with the wind the moment Kate Winslet swaggers in, wearing a doo-wop bouffant and flashing a blingy Star of David as big as a bagel.
