headline: Florida: Bill to Regulate Fracking Fails to Advance
keywords: ['Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Water', 'Water Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'State Legislatures', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: A bill to regulate fracking, an oil and gas extraction technique relatively new to Florida and vigorously opposed across the state, was voted down on Thursday by a state Senate committee.
lead_paragraph: A bill to regulate fracking, an oil and gas extraction technique that is relatively new to Florida and vigorously opposed across the state, was voted down on Thursday by a pivotal State Senate committee. The Senate Appropriations Committee rejected the measure in a 10-to-9 bipartisan vote. Florida’s extremely porous geology raised fears among environmentalists and Florida residents that well stimulation could more easily lead to contamination of underground aquifers, the source of drinking water for almost all Floridians. The bill, which had passed the House, proposed regulating only two forms of well stimulation in the state but left out a third method, matrix acidizing, that is conducted with low pressure. It also would not require oil and gas companies to reveal all of the chemicals they would put into the ground because some are protected by federal law. The legislation called for a study on the potential effect of well stimulation, but matrix acidizing would not be part of the study. Local governments objected to the legislation because it would prohibit them from banning well stimulation. Nearly 80 counties and cities have passed resolutions or ordinances that banned or opposed fracking. The bill can be called up again in the Senate committee. Well stimulation is not regulated in Florida and does not require a separate permit.

headline: Review: ‘Marguerite & Julien,’ a Tale of Siblings in Love
abstract: Valérie Donzelli’s film transposes the factually based, centuries-old story of incestuous French lovers to a not-quite-modern setting.
lead_paragraph: This distressing film, directed by Valérie Donzelli from a script by Ms. Donzelli and Jérémie Elkaïm, has an admirable pedigree. Its roots are in an unrealized project that the screenwriter Jean Gruault had hoped to make with François Truffaut, and the movie is dedicated to Mr. Gruault, who died last year. “Marguerite & Julien” transposes the factually based, centuries-old tale of incestuous French lovers to a not-quite-modern setting (much nostalgia is expended depicting one of its characters developing photographs in a darkroom) that could be called “Wes Anderson and Sofia Coppola Land,” only it isn’t as attractive as that sounds.

headline: Spare Times for Children Listings for Feb. 26-March 3
abstract: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has drawn sharp criticism for its failure to embrace diversity. But on this Oscars weekend, another academy, with a smaller audience — and, for this occasion, much smaller audience members — has dedicated itself to a “pursuit of equity” in movies.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has drawn sharp criticism for its failure to embrace diversity. But on this Oscars weekend, another academy, with a smaller audience — and, for this occasion, much smaller audience members — has dedicated itself to a “pursuit of equity” in movies.

headline: Analyzing Apple’s Argument That First Amendment Applies to Its Code
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Privacy', 'Software', 'iPhone', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Computer Security', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The company, in its fight with the F.B.I., is defending its phones on grounds that its code represents free speech, and there is some precedent.
lead_paragraph: Computer code is incomprehensible to anyone without programming skills, but Apple argued in a court filing on Thursday that code is a form of speech. So, the company contends, the government’s order to crack a locked iPhone used by one of the San Bernardino killers would violate Apple’s First Amendment rights.

headline: What You Missed in the Debate
abstract: With less than a week to go before Super Tuesday, the remaining Republican presidential candidates gathered to debate in Houston.
lead_paragraph: Here’s how we analyzed the Republican debate, and fact checked.

headline: Maodo Lo, an ‘Artist With a Basketball’ at Columbia
abstract: Lo is a star basketball player at Columbia attracting the attention of the N.B.A. He visits art galleries in his spare time, which is no surprise since his mother is Elvira Bach, a renowned German painter and sculptor.
lead_paragraph: Maodo Lo, the lissome Columbia senior attracting N.B.A. attention this season, snatched a brochure as he walked into the Susan Eley Fine Art gallery on the Upper West Side one recent afternoon.

headline: With No Unified Refugee Strategy, Europeans Fall Back on Old Alliances
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'International Relations']
abstract: Without an effective Europe-wide policy response, and facing growing public anger in many countries, Europe’s national leaders have splintered, searching for allies.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Roughly five weeks ago, Donald Tusk, one of the European Union’s most powerful political figures, issued a blunt warning to its 28 countries: Come up with a coherent plan to tackle the refugee crisis within two months, or risk chaos.

headline: Review: ‘Paul Verhoeven’s Tricked,’ a Documentary and a Farce
abstract: A film about a corporate bigwig whose former mistress shows up with a baby bump at his birthday party is preceded by a documentary about its making.
lead_paragraph: It’s unlikely that Paul Verhoeven, the Dutch filmmaker behind “Basic Instinct,” “Showgirls” and “Hollow Man,” ever directs his movies with a completely straight face. “Paul Verhoeven’s Tricked” — which consists of two parts, “Tricked,” a farce built from crowd-sourced suggestions, and “Tricked: Paul’s Experience,” a documentary about how that film was made — qualifies merely as a more overt prank than usual.

headline: Yolande Betbeze Fox, Miss America Who Defied Convention, Dies at 87
abstract: Ms. Fox helped set new standards for beauty pageants by refusing to tour the country in revealing bathing suits as Miss America of 1951.
lead_paragraph: Yolande Betbeze Fox, a convent-educated Alabamian who defied convention, and set new standards, by refusing to tour the country as Miss America of 1951 in revealing bathing suits, died on Monday in Washington. She was 87.

headline: Review: ‘A Strange Course of Events’
abstract: A clerical worker at a hospital in Israel decides, on impulse, to visit his estranged father in Haifa.They haven’t see each other in five years.
lead_paragraph: The unexamined life is not worth living, but “A Strange Course of Events” reminds us that the inspected one is not always worth watching.

headline: Review: ‘Virus of Fear,’ a Kiss Touches Off Child Abuse Accusations
abstract: A swimming instructor is accused of inappropriately touching a child, and battle lines are drawn among his colleagues and parents.
lead_paragraph: Ventura Pons’s stagy drama “Virus of Fear” tries to walk a thin line about its volatile subject — child sexual abuse — as it weighs a man’s possible innocence against a mob’s rage. But its attempts at ambiguity work against it. Fortunately, the film, adapted from Josep Maria Miró’s play “Archimedes’ Principle,” falls on the right side of its issue, if barely.

headline: Benjamin Netanyahu Rebukes David Cameron for Criticizing Israel
abstract: Israel’s prime minister responded sharply to his British counterpart’s assertion that he found Israel’s “effective encirclement” of East Jerusalem and its construction in that territory “genuinely shocking.”
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has long counted his British counterpart, David Cameron, as a staunch friend in a shrinking world of dependable allies.

headline: Spare Times for Feb. 26-March 3
abstract: A listing of discussions, film screenings, cultural activities and walking tours in New York City.
lead_paragraph: American Museum of Natural History: ‘Countdown to Zero’ (through early 2017) Smallpox is the only human disease to have been eradicated, but what about Guinea worm, polio, malaria and others? This exhibition, presented in collaboration with the Carter Center, examines international efforts to control and wipe out infection. Daily from 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m., Central Park West and 79th Street, 212-769-5200, amnh.org.

headline: Suit Alleges Persistent Sexual Abuse of Female Inmates in New York State Prisons
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Women and Girls', 'Sex Crimes', 'Prison Guards and Corrections Officers', 'Sexual Harassment']
abstract: The suit, replete with claims of forcible intercourse, harassment and voyeurism, seeks to end what it calls the “pattern of sexual misconduct” at the state’s all-female correctional facilities.
lead_paragraph: Sexual abuse of female inmates is persistent in New York State prisons, six female prisoners claim in a lawsuit filed Thursday.

headline: Anaheim Ducks Rediscover Goal and Turn Their Season Around
abstract: The Ducks are 20-4-2 in their last 26 games, and have 46 goals in 12 February games, a surge sparked perhaps by separating the team’s two best offensive players.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — The N.H.L.’s Ducks hosted Orange County’s biggest field trip on Tuesday when they welcomed roughly 16,000 elementary school students to Honda Center. Anaheim players enjoyed the task of using hockey to educate children on some basic tenets of science. But they also admitted that the event, now in its 16th year, is considerably more fun when the team is winning.

headline: Gunman Kills 3 at Kansas Factory Before Dying in Shootout
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Factories and Manufacturing']
abstract: The man drove through at least two towns firing a gun out his car window before attacking the plant in Hesston, Kan., where he worked, officials said.
lead_paragraph: NEWTON, Kan. — Three people were killed at a manufacturing plant in Hesston, Kan., on Thursday by a man who had driven through at least two towns shooting a gun out of his car window, the police said.

headline: Review: ‘A Room of My Own’ Recalls a Greenwich Village of 1979
abstract: This Charles Messina play features Ralph Macchio and Mario Cantone as part of a brash Italian-American family unconcerned with political correctness.
lead_paragraph: Before we see Jackie, we hear him: a screaming voice in the hallway, threatening to attack a neighbor whose punk rock kept him up all night. He’s still clutching his weapon, a hammer, when he strides into his sister’s apartment, where he paces the floor like a feral cat before he lets her calm him down.

headline: Eviction Notification Turns Deadly as Man Fires at Police Officers in Colorado
keywords: ['Evictions', 'Attacks on Police', 'Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Foreclosures', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: On Wednesday, when seven Park County sheriff’s officers arrived to serve what they called a “high-risk” eviction notice, a man opened fire on them, killing a corporal and injuring two other officers.
lead_paragraph: BAILEY, Colo. — Martin Wirth was angry with the system. As a grass-roots activist with the Occupy Denver protests and a long-shot Green Party candidate for a conservative-held seat in Colorado’s Senate, he denounced social injustice and police brutality.

headline: Treasury Official Urges Solution for Puerto Rico
keywords: ['Credit and Debt', 'Bankruptcies', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Some lawmakers worry that a bankruptcylike debt restructuring for the island could have broad implications for states’ debt.
lead_paragraph: A senior Treasury official urged Congress on Thursday to help Puerto Rico restructure its debt quickly, warning that failing to do so would lead to a decade of financial decline.

headline: A Player Struggles, Then Vaults Into Contention
abstract: Sam Saunders, a grandson of Arnold Palmer, kept his composure and stayed in contention at the Honda Classic, another step in his road back from a “brain bleed” in September.
lead_paragraph: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla. — After four holes at the Honda Classic, Sam Saunders was at even par. Two holes later, he was four over. For Saunders, a player not known for his patience who was battling gusty winds and dark thoughts blown in by five consecutive missed cuts, the bolt into black numbers seemed to forecast a disaster.

headline: U.S. Plans to Put Advisers on Front Lines of Nigeria’s War on Boko Haram
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The deployment of dozens of Special Operations advisers would push American troops hundreds of miles closer to the battle that Nigerian forces are waging against the militants.
lead_paragraph: DAKAR, Senegal — The Pentagon is poised to send dozens of Special Operations advisers to the front lines of Nigeria’s fight against the West African militant group Boko Haram, according to military officials, the latest deployment in conflicts with the Islamic State and its allies.

headline: Appeals Court Upholds Law Restricting Louisiana Abortion Doctors
abstract: The Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals voted to allow a 2014 state law requiring abortion doctors to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals go into effect, reducing the number of remaining clinics to two.
lead_paragraph: BATON ROUGE, La. — A large blue sign stood at the entrance to the Delta Clinic, a low brick building amid the ranch houses in a neighborhood here in the Louisiana capital.

headline: Debating in Texas With Super Tuesday in Sight
abstract: The Republican presidential candidates conducted a feisty final debate before the Super Tuesday voting next week.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates conducted a feisty final debate before the Super Tuesday voting next week.

headline: President Weighs In on Data From Genes
abstract: President Obama said the success of his initiative to collect genetic data so scientists can develop drugs and personalized treatments hinged partly on “understanding who owns the data.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama on Thursday waded into the complex and high-stakes debate over whether patients own their genetic information, saying that he believes that his tissues and any discoveries that stem from his DNA belong to him.

headline: Closely Watched Fight Over California Teacher Tenure Moves to Appeals Court
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Teachers and School Employees', 'Tenure', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Organized Labor']
abstract: The plaintiffs argued that too often, incompetent teachers end up in classrooms with disadvantaged children, with the law making it impossible to remove them.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A fierce battle over the future of teacher tenure in California moved to an appeals court here on Thursday. Lawyers for student plaintiffs argued that the state’s ironclad job protections for teachers deprived students of a quality education, while teachers unions and the state said the system helped recruit and retain teachers.

headline: Swings, Slides and the Lingering Memory of a Brownsville Rape Case
abstract: A day after prosecutors said they would drop the charges against five men in the case, a quiet calm set in at the playground where a woman reported being attacked.
lead_paragraph: Overhead, the clang of metal on metal. The snap hook securing an American flag to its halyard struck the flagpole, sounding a toll in the crisp wind.

headline: Hillary Clinton Makes Appeals to Black Voters in South Carolina
abstract: Mrs. Clinton began a whirlwind day by taking questions from some 400 African-Americans in a Kingstree, S.C., church that had been burned down by Ku Klux Klan members.
lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, S.C. — Hillary Clinton began a whirlwind day in South Carolina on Thursday by taking questions from some 400 African-Americans in Kingstree, where in 1996 President Bill Clinton attended a dedication for a newly rebuilt church that had been burned by members of the Ku Klux Klan.

headline: Hey, Sport! ​Know Your Old New York Slang?
abstract: Lingo of the 1920s is back on Broadway. Test your knowledge, with help from Forest Whitaker.
lead_paragraph: Lingo of the 1920s is back on Broadway. Test your knowledge, with help from Forest Whitaker.

headline: Review: In ‘Hughie,’ With Forest Whitaker, Two Desolate Lost Souls
abstract: The actor makes his Broadway debut in this one-act play by Eugene O’Neill.
lead_paragraph: The dim and cavernous hotel lobby is, as one of its two inhabitants puts it, “about as homey as the morgue.” But for Erie Smith, the fidgety man who comes up with that desolate description, this morgue is the only place to be.

headline: Review: ‘Women Without Men,’ a Learning Experience of Sorts
abstract: The minutiae of the pressures and games among female teachers living in close quarters at a boarding school are revealed in this Irish play from 1938.
lead_paragraph: The staff sitting room at the Malyn Park Private School looks snug enough. Yes, the fire is less than blazing and a few of the cushions are threadbare, but the chairs are covered in a cheerful green, the rug looks soft underfoot and the lamps cast a warm glow. You wouldn’t think so much malice could lurk somewhere quite so cozy.

headline: Review: Tetzlaff Trio: Music That’s Off Kilter, Even Boozy
abstract: The fiery ensemble performed works by Dvorak, Schumann and Brahms at Zankel Hall on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: Rarely is an encore so well chosen as it was at Zankel Hall on Wednesday night. The fiery ensemble made up of the star violinist Christian Tetzlaff, the cellist Tanja Tetzlaff (his sister) and the pianist Lars Vogt had burned through Dvorak’s E-minor trio (“Dumky”) before intermission, so after a warm ovation at the end of the concert they returned to that composer with the Scherzo from his earlier F-minor trio.

headline: Spooking Spelunkers
abstract: This one by Paula Gamache will hurt, but you’ll feel better if you indulge in your favorite puzzle-solving reward system. Mine’s chocolate. What’s yours?
lead_paragraph: Administrivial Will Shortz Sighting Alert! Will Shortz sat down to answer readers’s questions about the crossword on the Times Insider podcast. Non-members can listen too! Click here to listen in.

headline: Review: In ‘Pericles,’ Much Ado About a Lot of Things
abstract: Trevor Nunn directs “Pericles,” one of Shakespeare’s tumultuous late romances, in a Theater for a New Audience Production.
lead_paragraph: “What shall be next,” says Gower, the sorely taxed narrator of Shakespeare’s complicated romance “Pericles,” preparing to introduce the next knot in the yarn. Well, you might reasonably think, what shall not be next?

headline: Donald Trump Is Focus of Attacks in the Republican Debate
abstract: The other candidates in Texas were overshadowed as Trump, Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz sparred over immigration, health care and tax returns.
lead_paragraph: This Republican debate is a make-or-break moment for all candidates but Donald Trump. Among the political experts I speak to, the debate is between those who are betting on Trump and those who think that someone else (usually Rubio) still has a strong chance. The betting markets on the eve of the debate showed Trump with a 74 percent chance of becoming the Republican nominee, and Rubio with a 24 percent chance. Of course Ben Carson and John Kasich are also part of the debate, but the focus is on Trump, Cruz and Rubio as the front-runners. Here’s my play-by-play from the debate, in the form not of a column but simply an assortment of my tweets during the debate. It’s journalism on the fly — and here goes!

headline: Mayor De Blasio Proposes Retirement Savings Plan for Private-Sector Workers
abstract: The proposal would create a way for New York City’s estimated 1.4 million private-sector workers who do not have employer-sponsored retirement plans to set aside money in a city-organized program.
lead_paragraph: Amid visions of a new Brooklyn-Queens streetcar line and a repurposed Governors Island, one progressive aspect of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s State of the City address this month was obscured.

headline: FIFA Presidential Election: Analysis
abstract: Times journalists followed the twists and turns of the Extraordinary FIFA Congress (their words, not ours), where a new president of the world’s governing soccer body, Gianni Infantino, was elected to replace Sepp Blatter. We provided updates and commentary throughout the long, tedious (and sometimes hilarious) voting process.

headline: John Gagnon, Who Linked Sexuality to Social Influences, Dies at 84
abstract: Professor Gagnon shifted the ground in sex research, proposing that sexuality is shaped in the world, not in the psyche.
lead_paragraph: John Gagnon, a sociologist who shifted the ground in sex research by proposing that sexual behavior could better be understood by looking at social forces rather than biology or psychology, died on Feb. 11 at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 84.

headline: In Republican Debate, a Feisty Marco Rubio Lays Into Donald Trump
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio, alarmed by Donald Trump’s ascendancy and worried that his presidential chances were slipping away, delivered the onslaught that Republican leaders had desperately awaited.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio, alarmed by Donald J. Trump’s ascendancy and worried that his presidential chances were slipping away, unleashed a barrage of attacks on the real estate mogul’s business ethics, hiring practices and financial achievements in Thursday’s debate, forcefully delivering the onslaught that Republican leaders had desperately awaited.

headline: Massachusetts Poll Shows Clinton and Sanders in Tight Race
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: Days before Massachusetts votes on Super Tuesday, a poll there shows Hillary Clinton with a slight edge over Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont but one that is within the margin of error.

headline: Ted Cruz Says Rubio Would Be ‘a Much Better President’ Than Trump

headline: New York Police Captain Is Put on Modified Duty for Not Helping After Shootout
abstract: A supervisor requested that Capt. Scott J. Forster, 31, stay past his shift to help coordinate the response to a gunfight that wounded two officers.
lead_paragraph: A New York City police captain has been placed on administrative duty for declining to stay after his shift to help when two officers were injured in a shootout in Brooklyn, the police said on Thursday.

headline: Donald Trump Has New Reason for Not Releasing Tax Returns: I.R.S. Is Picking on Him
abstract: Donald J. Trump, under pressure from Mitt Romney and others to release his tax returns, now says he may not be able to because of a curious number of audits.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from the last Republican presidential nominee to release his tax returns, Donald J. Trump used the debate stage Thursday night to debut a new reason for why he can’t do so right now, and might not even be able to release them at all during the campaign: He’s been the target of curious audits for many years.

headline: Who Won the Debate? Attacks on Donald Trump Help Marco Rubio More
abstract: Mr. Trump faced a barrage of attacks from Senator Ted Cruz and Mr. Rubio in Houston and many critics thought Mr. Rubio had a newfound toughness.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump faced a barrage of attacks from his Republican rivals during their debate Thursday night, the last face-off before Super Tuesday next week. Senator Marco Rubio assailed Mr. Trump’s record as a businessman and his knowledge of policy. Senator Ted Cruz called him a closet liberal in a multitude of ways. Mr. Trump responded forcefully and with a torrent of schoolyard taunts. Many critics and commentators thought that Mr. Rubio was the clear winner on Thursday night, but said that his newfound toughness may have come too late.

headline: What to Watch Friday
abstract: “Fuller House” returns to the Tanner family’s old stomping ground. And Ray Charles and Fats Domino get the PBS treatment.
lead_paragraph: Feeling nostalgic? It’s déjà vu all over again when “Fuller House” returns to the Tanner family’s old stomping ground. Ray Charles and Fats Domino get the PBS treatment. And some Oscar nominees remember the times of their lives.

headline: Peering Through the Haze of China’s Economic Data
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Gross Domestic Product', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Censorship']
abstract: Economists and academics comment on the quality and official control of economic data coming out of China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — With economic growth slowing and China’s stock markets in turmoil, the Communist Party and central government are starting to restrict the flow of economic information and data to control the narrative. That runs counter to the needs of global investors and economists, who had been hoping that China would continue becoming more transparent with such information.

headline: A Unified Theory of Trump
abstract: Here’s an explanation for the behavior of the man who may soon represent the Party of Lincoln: sleep deprivation.
lead_paragraph: In trying to explain Donald Trump and his hostile takeover of the Republican Party, people have trotted out a host of character disorders. Narcissist. Racist. Bully. Buffoon. Tyrant. Liar. Celebrity obsessive. Fact-denier. You’ve heard them all, and they all apply, in varying degrees.

headline: The Governing Cancer of Our Time
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Donald Trump’s candidacy is the culmination of 30 years of antipolitics.
lead_paragraph: We live in a big, diverse society. There are essentially two ways to maintain order and get things done in such a society — politics or some form of dictatorship. Either through compromise or brute force. Our founding fathers chose politics.

headline: Helping Women in Africa Avoid H.I.V.
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Women and Girls', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: A promising new device lowered infection rates for some women, but more work and research is needed.
lead_paragraph: Every day, nearly 1,000 young women around the world become infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS. More than half of the 37 million people worldwide infected with H.I.V. are women, and most of them live in sub-Saharan Africa. These women too often lack the awareness, the financial means and the power over their own lives to protect themselves from the virus. Tragically, more women of reproductive age around the world die from AIDS than from any other cause.

headline: Veto South Dakota’s Transgender Restroom Law
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Bathrooms and Toilets', 'Education (K-12)', 'Discrimination', 'Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Title IX (Gender Discrimination Legislation)']

lead_paragraph: Gov. Dennis Daugaard of South Dakota must decide by Tuesday whether his state will become the first to designate some public restrooms at schools off limits to transgender students.

headline: Twilight of the Apparatchiks
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Discrimination', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Social Security (US)']
abstract: The Republican establishment’s “wingnut welfare” made Trump possible.
lead_paragraph: Lack of self-awareness can be fatal. The haplessness of the Republican establishment in the face of Trumpism is a case in point.

headline: How to Reduce Crime: Stop Charging Children as Adults
keywords: ['Juvenile Delinquency', 'Courts and the Judiciary', 'Family Courts', 'Age, Chronological', 'Sentences (Criminal)']
abstract: States that have raised the family court age to 18 have seen their young prison populations decline and rearrest rates fall.
lead_paragraph: FOR the second year in a row, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York has proposed raising the age of the state’s Family Court jurisdiction to 18 from 16. If that legislation fails again this year, it will leave New York and North Carolina as the only states where people age 16 and older can be tried as an adult and, if incarcerated, locked up in adult prisons and jails. (In New York, children as young as 13 must be tried in adult court for certain charges, like murder.)

headline: Sarah Palin’s Mustache
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Beards and Mustaches', 'Discrimination']
abstract: When unwanted facial hair brings unfair scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: IT’S hard to know exactly what impact Sarah Palin’s endorsement of Donald J. Trump has had on his campaign. We do know, however, that the sparkly Milly beaded silk bolero jacket she wore while giving her speech sold out soon after, despite its $695 price tag. But several style experts slammed her choice as inappropriate, and on Twitter a marketing executive likened her to a “disco ball hedgehog.”

headline: Bruni and Douthat Agree: #OscarsSoPolitical
keywords: ['Academy Awards (Oscars)', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Movies']

(It won’t be Trump it won’t be Trump la la la la la la I can’t heaaar you.)

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Royal Bank of Scotland reported on Friday a multibillion-dollar loss in the fourth quarter that was worse than analyst expectations, driven by 2.21 billion pounds, or about $3 billion, in additional provisions for legal and regulatory matters.

headline: Eni, Hit by Falling Oil Prices, Reports $9.4 Billion Loss
abstract: The Italian oil giant is the latest energy company to be hit by sharply lower crude prices, which have slashed revenue and led to asset write-downs.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Italian oil giant Eni reported on Friday a loss of 8.5 billion euros, or about $9.4 billion, in the fourth quarter of 2015, becoming the latest energy company to be hit by sharply lower crude prices that have slashed revenue and led to asset write-downs.

headline: In Rare Appearance, China’s Central Bank Chief Says All Is Well
keywords: ['Renminbi (Currency)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Stocks and Bonds']

headline: Shedding Skins at the Zoo
abstract: A young woman learns about love and bravery from snakes, gorillas and cockroaches.
lead_paragraph: My first serious relationship ended a week before I started my summer job at the zoo. Every morning as I drove my parents’ Toyota to work, I’d put on a Dar Williams CD and cry. I felt as tragic as it was possible to feel while wearing an oversize blue T-shirt with gorillas printed on the front.

There were planes to catch, seminars, grant proposals, a book to write, classes to teach, a whirlwind that rarely stopped. Rebecca MacKinnon and Bennett Freeman had known each other professionally for years, had sat in the same room for meetings, but cannot recall having a single conversation outside of work.

headline: The National Park Service, at 100, Gets Its Own Film
keywords: ['Movies', 'Travel and Vacations', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores']
abstract: A conversation with Greg MacGillivray, one of the producers of “National Parks Adventure,” a 43-minute movie narrated by Robert Redford.
lead_paragraph: America’s first national park, Yellowstone, was designated in 1872, but it wasn’t until 1916 that the government established the National Park Service to manage the growing number of parks; there are 409 across the states as well as territories like American Samoa. The agency is turning a 100 years old in August, and in commemoration Brand USA, the national marketing organization for the United States, has produced “National Parks Adventure” in partnership with MacGillivray Freeman Films and its co-founder Greg MacGillivray.

headline: Musangwe Fight Club: A Vicious Venda Tradition
abstract: No gloves, no headgear, no time limits. Only when one fighter submits can the fight can come to an end. Also, no gambling. Just fighting.
lead_paragraph: TSHIFUDI, South Africa — As the sun reached its highest point of the day, men started to trickle onto a green field where cows gather. Quickly, they formed a circle, which grew to include excited 9-year-old boys and wrinkly old men. All of them were clapping, pumping one another up, preparing to fight.

headline: ‘On This Day in Poetry History,’ by Amy Newman
abstract: Amy Newman’s latest poems begin with small episodes in the lives of a pivotal generation of American poets.
lead_paragraph: The artist’s job is “a continual extinction of personality,” T. S. Eliot said. Try telling that to John Berryman, Elizabeth Bishop, Robert Lowell, Sylvia Plath, Theodore Roethke, Delmore Schwartz and Anne Sexton, the subjects of Amy Newman’s dazzling new collection of poems, “On This Day in Poetry History.” Speculating on his generation’s colossal ambitions and eventual place in literary history, in a letter that Newman quotes as an epigraph, Lowell wrote Roethke that “there must be a kind of glory to it all that people coming later will wonder at. I can see us all being written up in some huge book of the age. But under what title?”

headline: ‘The Right Wrong Man,’ by Lawrence Douglas
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: The trials of John Demjanjuk, a death-camp guard disguised as an American autoworker.
lead_paragraph: Not once but twice, in the period 1987-2012, the Ukrainian-American John Demjanjuk was tried and convicted of of­fenses committed as a World War II death camp guard. Following each trial, one in Israel, the other in Germany, he appealed. The first appeal was successful: The Israeli prosecutors had charged the wrong man. The second appeal was not heard: The 91-year-old Demjanjuk died before the court could be convened, though the German prosecutors were confident his appeal would fail.

headline: Should Democrats Fear Trump?
abstract: Last night’s debate offered one reason to think that he can’t beat Hillary.
lead_paragraph: My insta-take on last night’s debate isn’t particularly original: Marco Rubio’s shrinking violet act this week turned out to be a head fake, he battered and — above all — mocked Donald Trump in ways that Republicans should have been battering him and mocking him all along, and Trump’s counterpunches were weak and Rubio did what poor Jeb Bush never managed and talked over him, denying him the chance to let his punchlines land. Between Rubio and Ted Cruz, who was also on offense, there was still probably too much talk about how Trump is not a real conservative, and too little in the way of efforts to actually co-opt the valid parts of Trump’s critiques of organized conservatism and the Republican Party. And if Trump somehow wins that will be the deep story — that his rivals just couldn’t grasp how disaffected their voters were from the Bush-and-after record and the present party line. But what we saw last night was at least, and at last, the obvious way of taking down Trump, the way that I’ve assumed will work all along. Now we’ll find out if it’s too late.

headline: Letters: Love and Death
abstract: Readers respond to a recent review by Andrew Solomon and an essay by Vivian Gornick.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Three Talents Changing the Red Carpet Glamour Game
abstract: A former model who styles Alicia Vikander, a makeup artist who works with Lupita Nyong’o and a Hollywood insider are changing the typical notion of celebrity allure.
lead_paragraph: A former model who styles Alicia Vikander, a makeup artist who works with Lupita Nyong’o and a Hollywood insider are changing the typical notion of celebrity allure.

headline: Reimagining the Record
abstract: A look back at novels that took their characters from real life.
lead_paragraph: In 1974, Gore Vidal told The Paris Review: “By and large, history tends to be rather poor fiction — except at its best. The ‘Peloponnesian War’ is a great novel about people who actually lived.” Yet Vidal turned to history as the source for his own fiction time after time. (In this week’s Shortlist, Maxwell Carter reviews three new novels based on the real lives of artists, including Michelangelo and Georgia O’Keeffe.)

headline: 1941: Bulgaria Denies Nazi Rumors
keywords: ['Holocaust and the Nazi Era', 'World War II (1939-45)']
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: Bulgaria denies rumored entry of Nazi troops in 1941.
lead_paragraph: SOFIA — Tension in Sofia reached the  highest point in a month of crisis as unconfirmed but alarming and persistent  rumors flew wildly from mouth to mouth  today [Feb. 26]. These rumors, which  were flatly denied in government circles,  described the entry into Bulgaria of trainloads of German soldiers, followed by  hundreds of tanks. According to one version circulating in Sofia tonight, crossings had been made into Bulgaria at the  Danube River points of Vidia, near the  Yugoslav frontier, and Nicopol, across the  river from Turnu Magurele, Rumania.  However, when the reporter tried to  check the reports by telephoning to these  towns, he was told that no troops had arrived on the Bulgarian side of the river.  At both places, however, ‘‘movements’’  had been observed on the Rumanian side  and on the river itself, he was informed. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Feb. 27, 1941

headline: Judge in Dewey & LeBoeuf Fraud Case Whittles Down Charges
abstract: A New York State Supreme Court judge tossed out the grand larceny charges against the two remaining defendants stemming from law firm’s collapse.
lead_paragraph: An accounting fraud case at a once-prominent New York law firm that captured front-page headlines in 2014 is now looking more ordinary.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Sheer Silhouettes, With a Bit of Fantasy
abstract: Alberta Ferretti, Gucci and Alexander McQueen have all shown dresses with whimsical, other-worldly designs.
lead_paragraph: A few runways in New York and London have featured black lace dresses with a goth feel — while others have shown light, romantic versions covered in otherworldly designs. At Alberta Ferretti (left), a sheer dress came embroidered with flowers growing up the sides; at Gucci (center), motifs included swans covered in marabou feathers. And at Alexander McQueen (right), several fantastical references converged in a single garment: flowers, unicorns — even a sun.

headline: Recipes for the Weekend
abstract: Fantasizing about better weather and facing reality with a comforting beef stew.
lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: ‘Wreck and Order,’ by Hannah Tennant-Moore
abstract: Cliché be damned, a young American woman revisits Sri Lanka in this novel of self-discovery.
lead_paragraph: “If you count drinking a bottle of wine by yourself and crying in public parks as going to school in Paris, then yes, I definitely went to school in Paris,” the narrator of Hannah Tennant-Moore’s debut novel, “Wreck and Order,” notes by way of describing her education. And Paris is only the beginning of her travels. Once this would have been called the “I’ve been to Europe” story, but the current trend seems to be the “I’ve been to the developing world” novel, and Tennant-Moore’s book is exactly that.

headline: Doubts in Asia Over Whether New Sanctions Against North Korea Can Work
abstract: Analysts say a draft resolution circulating at the United Nations has too many loopholes for it to induce the isolated nation to denuclearize.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As a new set of sanctions against North Korea circulated at the United Nations Security Council, analysts in South Korea and China expressed doubts on Friday that the measures would be tough enough to force the pariah state to give up its nuclear weapons.

headline: Turning Polluted Properties Into Profits
keywords: ['Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Water Pollution']
abstract: Companies with backing from wealthy investors buy tainted properties, return them to productive use and sometimes reap rich rewards.
lead_paragraph: Decades ago, Ideal Uniform Rental operated a dry cleaner in Garden Grove, Calif., and some of the solvents it used leaked into the ground and the water supply.

headline: 1916: French Retake Douaumont
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: French forces retake Douaumont in 1916.
lead_paragraph: The battle in the region to the north of Verdun continued yesterday without respite. The slow, regular withdrawal of the French forces has apparently ceased, the French troops driving back the Germans, from the position round the fort of Douaumont, which after several costly attempts, they had carried.

headline: Fed’s 3 Mandates: Price Stability, Jobs and ... Wall Street?
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Interest Rates', 'United States Economy', 'Recession and Depression']
abstract: For three decades, the financial world has believed that the Fed will always intervene to stabilize the market. Will Janet Yellen go along?
lead_paragraph: Suppose a visitor from the future comes and tells you these facts about the financial markets in the year 2030: The stock market has fallen sharply, as have the price of oil and investors’ expectations for interest rate increases over the next couple of years.

lead_paragraph: Paperback books of particular interest.

headline: James Burke, Ex-Suffolk County Police Chief, Pleads Guilty
abstract: Mr. Burke was facing federal civil rights charges stemming from accusations that he beat a suspect in police custody and coerced his fellow officers into covering up the episode.
lead_paragraph: CENTRAL ISLIP, N.Y. — The former police chief of Suffolk County pleaded guilty on Friday to federal charges stemming from accusations that he beat a suspect in custody, threatened to kill him and then coerced his fellow officers into covering up the misconduct.

headline: Germany Chooses New Eurovision Singer After Outcry
abstract: The singer Jamie-Lee Kriewitz will represent Germany at Eurovision, replacing Xavier Naidoo, whose selection was rescinded after an outcry over his apparent right-wing sympathies.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The 17-year-old singer Jamie-Lee Kriewitz will represent Germany at this year’s Eurovision song contest with her song “Ghost.”  She was elected on Thursday night by public vote.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.

headline: ‘Be Frank With Me,’ by Julia Claiborne Johnson
abstract: A child obsessed with old films is at the center of this novel.
lead_paragraph: Early on in Julia Claiborne Johnson’s first novel, the wise reader — or, perhaps, the forgiving reader — will find a clue that will suggest how best to read this book. Mimi Banning, the reclusive writer at the center of its plot, explains to her new assistant, Alice Whitley, that her 9-year-old son, Frank, was once obsessed with gangster epics but has “moved on” to screwball comedies.

headline: ‘The Book of Memory,’ by Petina Gappah
abstract: An African inmate struggles for clarity about her early years.
lead_paragraph: With the advent of social media, forgetting can seem like an obsolete danger: Facebook timelines and chat logs have externalized the burden of remembering. But a different and more pernicious kind of forgetfulness looms in Petina Gappah’s first novel, “The Book of Memory,” whose narrator grapples with the threat of ­erasure.

headline: ‘The Slave’s Cause: A History of Abolition,’ by Manisha Sinha
abstract: Manisha Sinha has produced an encyclopedic study of the abolitionist movement...
lead_paragraph: Without question, the most important liberation movement in American ­history — from Jacksonian democracy to gay rights — was the long struggle against slavery. Abolition established the principles and rhetoric, while setting the strategies and tactics, that have guided all subsequent reform movements — even those that have stood opposed to one another like prohibitionism and antiprohibitionism, or pro- and anti-abortion rights. Recently, historians have been taking a new look at the struggle against slavery as a way of examining contemporary movements for securing human rights, expanding democracy, liberating colonials and criticizing capitalism.

headline: ‘Ways to Disappear,’ by Idra Novey
abstract: A novelist vanishes, prompting a revelatory search by family, friends and the not so friendly.
lead_paragraph: A novel starring a novelist can often seem a little pleased with itself, as if the author is looking over her shoulder, eager to make a great drama from a greatly uneventful thing. So it was with some trepidation that I picked up “Ways to Disappear,” the first novel by the poet and translator Idra Novey. The protagonist, Emma Neufeld, is a Portuguese-to-English translator devoted to the work of a cult-classic Brazilian writer. Novey herself translates from Portuguese to English, most recently the work of Clarice Lispector, the cult-classic Brazilian writer.

headline: ‘Weatherland,’ by Alexandra Harris
abstract: The English obsession with weather is reflected in all manner of creative expression across the centuries.
lead_paragraph: In Virginia Woolf’s novel “Orlando,” every century of the title character’s long life is marked by distinctively different weather and changes in the air. The days and seasons of the Elizabethan age are full of sharp contrasts (it’s either hot or cold, bright or dark), while for the Victorians the light and sun of the 18th century turn damp, moist and shadowy. “All was darkness,” Orlando observes at the stroke of midnight on the last day of 1799, “the 19th century had begun.”

headline: My 10 Favorite Books: Marcus Samuelsson
abstract: The chef shares the titles he’d most want with him on a desert island.
lead_paragraph: For his bookshop and website One Grand Books, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books they’d take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is Marcus Samuelsson, the chef behind Red Rooster in Harlem and Kitchen & Table, a concept restaurant with Clarion Hotels in Sweden and Norway. He shares his list exclusively with T.

headline: Could the Internet Do What the Euro Couldn’t?
abstract: A plan to connect the Continent online could help its moribund economy.
lead_paragraph: ROME — WHEREVER you look in Europe, the 60-year project to unite the Continent is starting to show its age.

headline: Review: ‘Full House’ Sequel Is a Forced March Down Memory Lane
abstract: Your view of Netflix’s “Fuller House” probably depends on how you remember its predecessor.
lead_paragraph: Netflix’s “Fuller House” is not good, but that’s arguably the best thing the show has going for it. To make a “Full House” sequel “good” — less formulaic, more innovative — would be like baking an artisanal, organic Hostess CupCake: You could do it, it might be delicious, but it would be a betrayal of the product. This is, after all, a franchise whose theme song begins, “Whatever happened to predictability?”

abstract: New novels about Leonardo, Michelangelo, Dora Maar and Georgia O’Keeffe.
lead_paragraph: OIL AND MARBLEA Novel of Leonardo and MichelangeloBy Stephanie Storey345 pp. Arcade, $24.99.

headline: Metropolitan Museum of Art Reaches Settlement on Admissions Policy
abstract: The Metropolitan Museum of Art will go back to saying $25 is a “suggested” admission fee, not “recommended.”
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art reached a settlement Friday in part of a long-running legal challenge to its admissions policy, conceding a semantic point and agreeing to change the wording on its signs to say that its $25 dollar full-admission charge is “suggested” instead of “recommended.”

headline: San Francisco Wants Homeless to Leave Tent Camp, but Some Vow to Fight
abstract: The city, which has sought gentler methods to deal with homelessness, is struggling for answers to what many describe as a worsening problem.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — An order by the San Francisco authorities to vacate a sidewalk tent camp in a commercial district has rekindled passions over the city’s longstanding homeless problem, which residents say has reached crisis levels.

headline: At Etro, Practical Beauty for a Night on the Town
abstract: For the label’s ’90s-inspired fall/winter 2016 show, models’ sultry beauty looks were accomplished using everyday techniques.
lead_paragraph: For fall/winter 2016, Veronica Etro was inspired by ’90s London — and memories of growing up and going out. Backstage, where models flitted about in robes printed with the designer’s signature paisley patterns, the hairstylist James Pecis created a look he described as “’90s grunge” — “but with clean hair, and a bit of ‘Rayanne’ from the show ‘My So-Called Life’,” he added.

headline: Fresh Pasta Comes in Different Shades
abstract: Once you get the hang of making the dough, a mix of paprika, cayenne and pimentón turns it rusty red.
lead_paragraph: Please never make me choose between dried pasta and fresh pasta. There’s a time and a place for each of them, and I confess to loving both equally.

headline: A Side Table With Character
abstract: The Red Hook, Brooklyn design company Uhuru’s steel console is meant to weather and gain a pretty patina over time.
lead_paragraph: This blackened metal console has something of the hulking monumentality and elegance of a Richard Serra installation, albeit on a domestic scale. Fashioned by the design firm Uhuru in its Red Hook, Brooklyn, studio, the 250-pound table is meant to weather over time, acquiring a warmth and patina, and the dings that accompany real life. As its name — the Tack — suggests, the piece is tack-welded (soldered with small beads instead of thick strips), a technique that lends it a surprising delicacy, while also conjuring an aging freighter gliding gracefully, even despite its heft, across roiling seas.

headline: Sarah Kershaw, Former Times Reporter, Dies at 49
abstract: Ms. Kershaw joined The New York Times in 1995 as a news clerk. She became known for her ability to spot trends and write offbeat feature articles.
lead_paragraph: Sarah Kershaw, a former reporter for The New York Times who covered real estate, the Pacific Northwest and New York City schools, died on Monday at her home in Sosúa, a beach town in the Dominican Republic. She was 49.

abstract: Speaking at the Saft America battery plant, opened with a federal grant, the president said that subsidies had bolstered the economy.

Stajic, 66, filed a lawsuit against the city, claiming she had been forced into retirement last year in part because of a disagreement with her superiors over the accuracy of certain DNA tests.

You — the readers — provide the advice: How have you made this work better in your family? I invite an expert to add to the discussion.

abstract: “It is, potentially, a historic junction,” the United Nations mediator, Staffan de Mistura, said of the cease-fire negotiated by the United States and Russia.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — Against the backdrop of relentless airstrikes on rebel-held positions inside Syria, the United Nations Security Council on Friday unanimously endorsed a deal negotiated between the United States and Russia for a “cessation of hostilities.”

headline: At Essence Lunch, a Lesson in Diversity Off-Camera
abstract: A powerful entertainment lawyer at the starry event urges minority performers to hire representatives who are not white men.
lead_paragraph: The annual Essence Black Women in Hollywood lunch, held in Beverly Hills days before the Oscars, is always a show of spirit, talent, glamour and grit. This year’s event was something more: a how-to manual on wresting control of Hollywood away from white men.

headline: $28.5 Million, a Record Sale in NoLIta
abstract: The developer Jared Kushner sells the second of six loft-style apartments at Puck Penthouses, setting a per-square-foot record for NoLIta.
lead_paragraph: The developer Jared Kushner, son-in-law of the presidential hopeful Donald J. Trump, sold the second of six loft-style apartments at Puck Penthouses, a luxury condominium his firm assembled atop the landmark Puck Building in NoLIta. At $28,511,000, the transaction was the most expensive closed sale of the week, according to city records, as well as a neighborhood record.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: William Shatner’s new book about his 50-year relationship with Leonard Nimoy is No. 11 on the hardcover nonfiction list. Readers looking for gossip about Kirk and Spock won’t be disappointed.
lead_paragraph: O Captain: William Shatner’s new book, “Leonard,” about his 50-year relationship with his “Star Trek” co-star and occasional frenemy Leonard Nimoy, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 11. Readers looking for gossip about Kirk and Spock won’t be disappointed — there’s plenty here about contract disputes, on-set rivalries and substance abuse, along with the revelation that Nimoy, who died in 2015 at the age of 83, essentially stopped speaking to Shatner for the last several years of his life because Shatner had filmed him without permission for a documentary about the Starship Enterprise. But Shatner also devotes generous space to his friend’s sensitive artistic side, taking note of Nimoy’s photographic pursuits and seven volumes of poetry — including, in 1973, the surprisingly successful debut “You & I,” which went through five print runs in hardcover and had an initial paperback printing of 250,000 copies. “What helped sell the book, of course, was the fact that Leonard was willing to promote it by doing bookstore signings,” Shatner writes. “It may have been Leonard’s poetry — but fans were getting Spock’s autograph.” What did Shatner think of the work? “Trying to understand poets through their poetry requires higher degrees than I have,” he writes, “but it is obvious reading his work that from the beginning to the end Leonard was intent on emotionally defining grand themes like love, compassion, loss and the endless search for roots. For the man who became famous playing the ultimate dispassionate character, his poems successfully bring out the range of important emotions.”

headline: Big Ticket | 293 Lafayette Street

headline: ‘Strange Gods,’ by Susan Jacoby
abstract: Susan Jacoby examines the motives for religious conversion.
lead_paragraph: By the time she was 14, the writer Susan Jacoby realized that there is no God, and ever after, she has been working to share that insight. Her new book studies the phenomenon of conversion, since she is upset that people still find ways to accept “goofy religious myths.” Sometimes she writes as if it is a personal insult to her for people to have any religion. She resents the fact that a nun of the Dominican order, singing a tribute to the order’s founder, St. Dominic, did so with a “mind-numbing refrain that still pounds in my cortex as ‘Dominiqua-niqua-niqua.’ ” She writes to prove that the so-called religious experience of conversion often has a secular explanation — then she offers a broad range to choose from.

headline: Top Lobbyist for Drug Makers Threads a Thicket of Outrage
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care']
abstract: Stephen Ubl, who became head of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America late last year, is facing rising criticism of the industry.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few lobbyists have walked into the kind of political inferno that greeted Stephen J. Ubl when he became the top pitchman for the pharmaceutical industry.

headline: Chris Christie Endorses Donald Trump and Calls Marco Rubio ‘Desperate’
abstract: The endorsement from Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey, who bowed out of the presidential race on Feb. 10 after a disappointing sixth-place finish in New Hampshire, comes a day after Donald J. Trump came under withering attacks from his rivals at the latest Republican debate.
lead_paragraph: In a rollicking day of spectacle, spite and scorn, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey declared his allegiance to Donald J. Trump and war on Marco Rubio, describing the senator on Friday as desperate and unfit for the presidency.

headline: Marco Rubio Does a Withering Takedown of Donald Trump
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio, the day after a raucous Republican presidential debate, mocked Donald J. Trump’s misspellings on Twitter. He made fun of his flop sweat. He even said Mr. Trump might have wet his pants.
lead_paragraph: Senator Marco Rubio on Friday leveled the same kind of taunting, ridiculing insults against Donald J. Trump that Mr. Trump is so well-known for throwing at his rivals, reprising his feisty debate performance.

headline: ‘War Music,’ by Christopher Logue
abstract: The poet Christopher Logue layers a variety of times, places and sensibilities over the framework of the ‘Iliad.’
lead_paragraph: On Mount Olympus the gods are at it again. Bickering, back-stabbing. Thetis implores Zeus, on behalf of her son, the Greek hero Achilles. Hera, the wife and sister of Zeus (you know how families can be), demands that he back her favorites. Far below, on the plains stretching from Troy to the sea, mere mortals fight and suffer in a war that has gone on far too long and will be sung forever. But for now, all-powerful Zeus has had enough. And he lets Hera and the others know it with a threat that shuts them up and silences the world. Then, we read:

headline: Marco de Vincenzo: Fall 2016 RTW

lead_paragraph: Marco de Vincenzo presents his fall 2016 collection.

headline: Things to Do in Connecticut, Feb. 27 to March 6

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: Some Kids Sell Lemonade. He Starts a Chain.
abstract: A Colorado organization is teaching financial literacy to those under 22, and thousands have participated in its entrepreneurship programs.
lead_paragraph: Two summers ago, Jack Bonneau started a lemonade stand to earn some cash. Instead of setting it up on a street corner in his Broomfield, Colo., neighborhood, he and his father, Steve, came up with a more ambitious plan. Jack, then 8, would peddle cups of lemonade at the local farmers’ market throughout the summer.

headline: Palestinian Fugitive Found Dead Outside Embassy in Bulgaria
abstract: Omar Zayed, 52, had been living in Bulgaria after he escaped in 1990 from custody in Israel, where he was convicted of killing a yeshiva student.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A Palestinian man who escaped from prison in Israel more than 20 years ago was found dead Friday outside the Palestinian Embassy in Bulgaria, his family and Palestinian officials said.

headline: Home Sales Around the New York Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Review: At Campagna, Glamour and Grace Notes in the Countryside
abstract: A modern Italian restaurant on Richard Gere’s Bedford Post Inn complex walks a fine line between flash and understatement.
lead_paragraph: On a recent visit to Campagna I looked over and saw Richard Gere, the owner of the Bedford Post Inn complex in which the restaurant is located, happily dining with two others a couple of tables down. No one was bothering him: A man and woman nearby had eyes only for each other, a group of six friends were laughing over appetizers and others were moving between tables to say hello to neighbors they had just noticed. But as Mr. Gere made his way out, a quiet buzz stirred through the room.

headline: Raf Simons
abstract: In his studio in Antwerp, the men’s wear designer ponders a future as an artist — or a farmer.
lead_paragraph: In his studio in Antwerp, the men’s wear designer ponders a future as an artist — or a farmer.

abstract: Learn to make dulce de leche from a can of condensed milk for this Latin American dessert.
lead_paragraph: Learn to make dulce de leche from a can of condensed milk for this Latin American dessert.

headline: Alfajores, a Sweet Excuse for Making Dulce de Leche
abstract: Dulce de leche stars in the Latin American sandwich cookies called alfajores. (Article plus video.)
lead_paragraph: I ate alfajores daily when I was in Argentina, grabbing a packet of the foil-wrapped confection whenever I saw one: at cafes, markets, gas stations, the concession stand at the zoo.

headline: The New Republic Is Sold
abstract: Its owner, Chris Hughes, said he had sold the magazine to Win McCormack, who planned to name a former Nation publisher to lead it.
lead_paragraph: Chris Hughes, the owner of The New Republic, said on Friday that he had sold the magazine to Win McCormack, a publisher and editor based in New York and Portland, Ore., who founded the literary quarterly Tin House.

headline: Review: Thai West Puts French Accent on an Asian Cuisine
abstract: Thai West restaurant in Westwood is run by the Premon family, who have experience at both Thai and French restaurants.
lead_paragraph: At its best, fusion cuisine can be novel and refreshing; at its worst, a hard-to-decipher mash-up.

headline: Review: Xarello Takes Inspiration From a Michelin Favorite
abstract: The owners of the restaurant and its chef worked together at Manhattan’s Picholine, a Michelin-starred restaurant that closed in 2015.
lead_paragraph: Look close enough at Xarello, a Mediterranean restaurant that opened late last year in Williston Park, and you will see a place where nearly every detail is perfect. The dining room is sleek and romantic, with radiant cherry-red banquettes that hark back to the Russian Tea Room. Glasses, tableware and cutlery are all four-star quality. And the service, which embraces a more formal style, is outstanding. Water glasses barely reach the halfway mark before they are refilled, and plates of food land unfailingly in front of the person who ordered them. You will not find much better service this side of the Lincoln Tunnel.

headline: Raf Simons: A Look Back
abstract: Fresh off his departure from Dior, the influential designer pauses to consider the future of men’s fashion.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off his departure from Dior, the influential designer pauses to consider the future of men’s fashion.

headline: The World (and Future) of Raf Simons
abstract: The influential designer has irrevocably changed the face of men’s wear. And he’s only getting started.
lead_paragraph: The Belgian fashion designer Raf Simons lives, at least part of the year, above a flower shop in one of the fancier arrondissements of Paris. His apartment is one of those expected parquet-floored affairs with carved boiseries painted chalk-white, filled with contemporary art. There’s a George Condo painting that makes the sitter look like Beaker from ‘‘The Muppet Show,’’ hung in a space once occupied, perhaps, by a 19th-century academic oil. There are good Picasso ceramics on a gray marble mantelpiece.

headline: Tod’s: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Fall 2016 looks from Tod’s.
lead_paragraph: Fall 2016 looks from Tod’s.

headline: Review: At Abigail’s in Simsbury, a Ghost, at No Extra Charge
abstract: Colonial elegance in a building that dates to 1803 offers a warm atmosphere in two dining rooms spread over two floors.
lead_paragraph: When a building has been around for a couple of hundred years, it is not uncommon to hear tales of ghosts inhabiting the premises. Such is the case with Abigail’s Grille and Wine Bar in Simsbury, in a former tavern that dates to 1803, atop the foundation of a stagecoach stop built in 1780.

headline: Tony Burton, Apollo Creed’s Trainer in ‘Rocky’ Movies, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Burton, who played Duke in six Rocky films, was a former boxing champion himself.
lead_paragraph: Tony Burton, who played a tough-talking boxing trainer in six of the “Rocky” movies with Sylvester Stallone, died on Thursday in a California hospital, his family said. He was 78.

headline: Perry Hill Delivers a Simple Message for a Complex Task
abstract: The old-school infield coach, who is known as Bone, simplifies his message while teaching a series of complex moves.
lead_paragraph: JUPITER, Fla. — Baseball is awash in data, and the game is better for it. Numbers reveal truths that broaden fans’ understanding. Executives make better-informed decisions. Players with subtly valuable skills are appreciated more, and paid accordingly.

headline: Artist’s Greatest Subject Was the Panama Canal
abstract: The Hudson River Museum is displaying the works of a painter who spent three months documenting the project to link the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.
lead_paragraph: Not everyone sees the artistic potential in the current construction of a new Tappan Zee Bridge. But Bartholomew F. Bland does.

headline: Amid Iraqi Chaos, Moktada al-Sadr, an Old Provocateur, Returns
abstract: Mr. Sadr, a cleric whose command of the Iraqi Shiite street is unmatched, is ostensibly lending support to Prime Minister Haider al-Abadi.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — They came from the slums of this city’s underclass, the alleyways and the simple halls of the seminary in the Shiite holy city of Najaf, and the outer reaches of the rural south.

headline: Sculptures That Find Emotion in Geology
abstract: The inspiration for Liz Larner’s meticulously painted clay pieces is rooted deep in the earth — and deep in the subconscious.
lead_paragraph: “This one is a ‘caesura,’” the artist Liz Larner says while running her fingertips along a long piece of fired clay in her studio in the Highland Park neighborhood of Los Angeles. The piece is the approximate oblong shape of a world map, painted with yellow and black pigment and coated with a mucilaginous resin. A fracture runs down the middle of the sculpture. The caesura, or poetic line break, becomes a literal break, geologic in form, rising from the piece like a mountain range from a fault line. “It’s linguistic,” says Larner, who this week presents nearly 30 of these wall-hung sculptures as a body of work at the Aspen Art Museum, “but it’s also physical.”

headline: Review: Comic Drama in ‘Sister Play’ in Summit
abstract: Two siblings, one highhanded and the other free-spirited, form the core of Dreamcatcher theater’s staging of John Kolvenbach’s work.
lead_paragraph: There are some promises of intriguing interactions in “Sister Play,” a dramatic comedy at the Dreamcatcher Repertory Theater at the Oakes Center in Summit. But those promises have been largely left unfulfilled.

headline: Cut Compensation at Investment Banks, Then Take Cover
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Stocks and Bonds']
abstract: What Wall Street leaders need to do to get their stocks moving is to cut compensation. They should reverse-engineer their income statements to increase their profits.
lead_paragraph: Long gone are the days on Wall Street when our leading investment banks were stock-market highfliers.

lead_paragraph: It would be impossible to try to find one voice for the estimated 25,000 Latinos on Long Island’s East End. Some are wealthy, some are struggling; some are undocumented, and others are American citizens.

abstract: Continuing care offers retirees independent living with assistance when needed, but prospective residents need to evaluate communities carefully.
lead_paragraph: Is it possible to have it all in retirement? That’s what so-called continuing care retirement communities promise.

headline: The Tomb Is Never Far Away in This Gray ‘Romeo’
abstract: Life merely plays on the stones of death in this tale of the star-crossed lovers, with a pit of pebbles like a grave at their feet.
lead_paragraph: Those Capulets and Montagues, hurling insults and spittle at each other and inspiring even their servants to curl fists and brandish knives, have made Verona a bad enough environment for raising kids. Now Hartford Stage has gone further, putting Romeo Montague and Juliet Capulet at odds with the universe: Their world is backed by a stage-spanning gray wall of mausoleum vaults, and at their feet lies a rectangular pit of pebbles akin to a grave.

headline: For Black Women in South Carolina, It’s Clinton’s Turn

lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Jackie DeBose woke up early on Sunday, well before sunrise, grabbed her rhinestone-bedazzled Obama hat and her vintage “Hillary for President” button, loaded her suitcase in the trunk of her Lexus and headed to pick up three friends for a road trip to South Carolina.

headline: Shabab Militants Claim Deadly Attack on Hotel in Somalia
abstract: At least 10 people were killed and dozens were wounded in an attack on a hotel and public garden in Mogadishu. Security forces managed to stop militants from storming the building, officials said.
lead_paragraph: MOGADISHU, Somalia — Somali militants on Friday attacked a popular hotel and a nearby public garden in Mogadishu, the capital, killing at least 10 people and wounding more than 25, witnesses and officials said.

headline: Donald Trump and Chris Christie Weren’t Always So Friendly
abstract: Chris Christie and Donald Trump may be warm to each other now, but during the presidential campaign they frequently went after each other.
lead_paragraph: The love-fest between Donald J. Trump and Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey could hardly have been more effusive on Friday. Unveiling Mr. Christie’s endorsement, Mr. Trump called him a “spectacular governor” and a close friend whose support he coveted deeply. Mr. Christie said Mr. Trump was by far the best leader to take America forward and a true fighter.

lead_paragraph: One day during the past few weeks you may have noticed, on the subway home from work, an ad that wasn’t like the others, in part because it didn’t promote an app that could deliver a grain bowl, or a dog groomer, or a pack of C batteries and a gallon of Tide to your door in 19 minutes, and in part because it might have nudged you toward your essential prudishness.

headline: When Did the Red Carpet Become Prom?
abstract: In the hands of a self-appointed group of commentators, the pre-awards show has turned into a contest with strict rules and limited ideas of fashion.
lead_paragraph: In a literal sense, the red carpet has been part of the Oscars since 1961. But the red carpet as we know it today dates from the 1995 ceremony, when Joan Rivers and her daughter, Melissa, stood along the scarlet walkway and asked attendees the indelible question: “Who are you wearing?”

headline: How to Forge Your Own Path in Hollywood
