lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, looking to shore up his credentials on foreign policy, is seeking advice from a patchwork of experts, including Lawrence Wilkerson, who was chief of staff to Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and who has speculated that Israel might have carried out chemical attacks in Syria.

headline: Trump University’s Checkered Past Haunting Candidate
abstract: The now-defunct Trump University, subject of a Marco Rubio attack at the Republican debate, is embroiled in lawsuits accusing it of misrepresentation.
lead_paragraph: The now-defunct Trump University, the subject of one of Marco Rubio’s attacks on Donald J. Trump at the Republican presidential debate on Thursday night, was not a real university at all but a series of seminars held in hotels across the country that promised to share Mr. Trump’s real estate investing acumen with students. It is still embroiled in lawsuits accusing it of misrepresentation.

headline: The Alliance of Chris Christie and Donald Trump: What Each Side Gets
abstract: Every political marriage involves a bit of calculation, and in the case of the Christie-Trump endorsement, both men have much to gain.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie’s announcement on Friday that he was endorsing Donald J. Trump startled the political world. But every political marriage involves a bit of calculation, and in this case, each man has much to gain from the alliance.

headline: Melissa Harris-Perry Walks Off Her MSNBC Show After Pre-emptions
abstract: She said that her show had effectively been taken away from her and that she felt “worthless” in the eyes of NBC News executives.
lead_paragraph: In an unusually public flare-up, one of MSNBC’s television personalities clashed with the network on Friday in a dispute about airtime and editorial freedom and said she was refusing to host the show that bears her name this weekend.

headline: Ted Cruz Moves Aggressively to Court Younger Voters
abstract: Mr. Cruz’s presidential campaign has invested heavily in building a youth army of sorts, with 30 millennial state directors and 4,000 members.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ted Cruz quotes “Scarface” and boasts of his beer pong prowess.

headline: Wallflower Bunny Finds a Home and a Companion
abstract: Tonya, the furry subject of a column on speed dating for rabbits at a city shelter, was finally adopted, along with a new friend, Kenny.
lead_paragraph: Tonya, always the bridesmaid rabbit, is finally a bride.

headline: Jazzercise Lives On in the Age of Zumba
abstract: The exercise regime, which combines dance, cardio and strength training, continues to draw a loyal following decades after its peak popularity.
lead_paragraph: If you have an ear to the ground, you can still hear the commands — “Grapevine!” “Step-ball-change!” — in New York, where Zumba and Tracy Anderson-inspired dance cardio classes long ago trumped Jazzercise as the choreographed workout of choice.

headline: How Clinton and Sanders Are Courting Black Votes
abstract: The Democratic candidates don’t want to be seen as “pandering” in South Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Charleston, S.C. — ON Thursday night, a few blocks from Mother Emanuel A.M.E. Church, Charlie Wilson, in a shimmery white blazer, was trying to get out the vote for Hillary Clinton. And trying to get the former secretary of state to do some shoulder shrugs. She bopped her head along gamely, smiling wide.

headline: The Arbiter of Invention
abstract: Robert Quintero helps his clients get their ideas licensed, manufactured and marketed. But first, he gives them the long odds for success.
lead_paragraph: Robert Quintero works out of a tiny office overlooking West 34th Street that is filled with big ideas, and bigger dreams.

headline: Apple Shareholders Show Their Support for Tim Cook
abstract: Apple’s chief received a standing ovation on Friday for opposing a court order requiring Apple to help law enforcement officials break into an iPhone.
lead_paragraph: CUPERTINO, Calif. — Even before Timothy D. Cook, Apple’s chief executive, began his speech on Friday at the company’s annual shareholder meeting, he got a standing ovation.

headline: The History of the Archbishop Who’s Concerned About Girl Scouts
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Priests', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Archbishop Robert Carlson’s criticism of the Girl Scouts has stirred recollections of his past role in managing sexual-abuse allegations against priests.
lead_paragraph: Archbishop Robert Carlson’s recent caution to his parishes in St. Louis about the “troubling pattern of behavior” of the Girl Scouts is stirring stark recollections of the prelate’s past role in managing accusations against priests for sexually abusing children. In a deposition two years ago, he insisted that he was not certain sexual abuse of a child by a priest constituted a criminal act in 1984, when he was auxiliary bishop for St. Paul and Minneapolis handling sex scandal cases.

headline: Japan Lost Nearly a Million People in 5 Years, Census Says
abstract: A downward trend had been indicated for years, but a national count made it official. The population total in 2015 was lower, by almost a million, than that of the census in 2010.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s population shrank by nearly a million during the last half-decade, official census figures confirmed on Friday, an unprecedented drop for a society not ravaged by war or other deadly crisis, and one that helps explain the country’s persistent economic woes.

headline: Justice Scalia’s Death Prompts Dow Chemical to Settle Lawsuit
abstract: Dow to pay $835 million after deciding that the absence of the conservative judge changed the balance of a suit that was heading to the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Antonin Scalia’s empty Supreme Court seat has cost Dow Chemical $835 million.

headline: Golfers Say Trump Reneged on Deal
abstract: Members of Trump National Jupiter say that Donald J. Trump basically stiffed them out of their refundable deposits, causing them to negotiate settlements or sue.
lead_paragraph: When last we left Donald J. Trump, at least here on the sports page, we were recalling the time he owned the New Jersey Generals in the short-lived United States Football League. Trump bought the Generals in 1983, after their first season, and immediately began pushing the league to move its season from the spring to the fall and take on the mighty N.F.L. His campaign generated a tremendous amount of publicity for Trump, but produced nothing but misery for the other owners. After a Trump-orchestrated antitrust suit against the N.F.L. backfired spectacularly, the once-promising U.S.F.L. went kaput.

headline: Better Care or Onerous Restrictions? Texas Abortion Law Going Before Supreme Court
abstract: Health groups, including the American Medical Association and the Texas Hospital Association, argue stringent rules the measure would impose are unnecessary.
lead_paragraph: For all the furious debate over constitutional rights rekindled by the first Supreme Court  abortion case in nearly a decade, the stated goal of the law at issue is a medical one: ensuring patient safety.

headline: Family Says Death of Black Woman in South Carolina Jail Was Easily Preventable
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: Court documents showed the chain of events leading up to Joyce Curnell’s death in July while in police custody.
lead_paragraph: The chain of events that led to the death of a black woman in a South Carolina jail last July began with a desperate bid to save her life from alcoholism.

headline: How Mark Norell, a Paleontologist, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Art, music and decompression at a local bar are part of the weekend ritual for Dr. Norell, a division chief at the American Museum of Natural History.
lead_paragraph: The titanosaur recently unveiled at the American Museum of Natural History was nearly as long and heavy as two subway cars when it roamed the earth, making it one of the biggest dinosaurs ever discovered. But Mark A. Norell, 58, the curator and chief of the museum’s paleontology division, is just as excited about an exhibition opening March 21, “Dinosaurs Among Us,” which he curated and which explores how one group of dinosaurs evolved into birds. Dr. Norell says technology has brought paleontology closer to biology, allowing scientists to examine topics like the evolution of dinosaur brains, and, yes, dinosaur feathers. He lives in the NoMad neighborhood with his wife, Vivian Pan, a partner in a capital management firm. Their daughter, Inga, 20, is a student at Barnard College.

headline: An Easy Fix for Vertigo
abstract: The most common form of vertigo can be quickly treated by repositioning the head, but many doctors remain unfamiliar with the maneuver.
lead_paragraph: The first time it happened, in 2011, Bob Amberger thought he might be having a stroke.

headline: Sora Choi Transforms at Versace
abstract: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: The photographer Greg Kessler captures behind-the-scenes beauty transformations during Fall/Winter 2016 Fashion Week in Milan.

headline: The Myth of the Hero Teacher
abstract: In his new memoir, Ed Boland tells of trying, and failing, to make a difference at a public school in Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: Maybe you have had the fantasy: Chuck your day job to teach in a public school in a blighted neighborhood. The money is lousy, of course, but that’s part of the fantasy — no one wants to turn around the lives of poor children just for a paycheck. Then you decide that maybe today is not the day, and go back to your life. Sound familiar?

headline: Paul L. Whalen, Architect, at Home in Greenwich Village
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Interior Design and Furnishings', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Mr. Whalen, a partner in Robert M. Stern Architects, lives in a building with a distinguished pedigree.
lead_paragraph: Living in a Greenwich Village apartment with a distinguished pedigree is something Paul L. Whalen savors. “I am very aware of being in a Bing & Bing building,” he said, referring to the developers who built numerous apartment buildings in Manhattan during the early 20th century. “Bing & Bing buildings offer the formal qualities of grand Upper East Side apartments on a practical scale. They were designed for single people or young couples. They have classic layouts, often with fireplaces and rooms large enough to furnish nicely.”

headline: Apple Art Supplies in Brooklyn Is Hub for Matte Knives and Gossip

headline: A Top N.H.L. Rookie Skates In From the Heat
abstract: Shayne Gostisbehere, whose 15-game point streak for the Philadelphia Flyers ended recently, is believed to be one of only eight Florida-born players to reach the N.H.L.
lead_paragraph: Shayne Gostisbehere’s unusual journey from South Florida to the N.H.L. actually started in Montreal in the 1950s when a woman named Cleo Brodeur went to the doctor seeking a treatment for severe asthma.
