lead_paragraph: The freaked-out entrance line of the first song of the first Black Sabbath album, sung by Ozzy Osbourne over the guitarist Tony Iommi’s creepy-crawly interval of a tritone, is: “What is this that stands before me?”

headline: Washington Streetcar Stumbles Could Benefit de Blasio’s Plan
keywords: ['Cable Cars and Trams', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Transit Systems']
abstract: The efforts to create a line on H Street in the nation’s capital offer a cautionary tale for those planning the Brooklyn Queens Connector.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The empty streetcars started their test runs down H Street more than a year ago, a slow-rolling taunt for a fast-changing neighborhood left to wonder when the line might finally open.

headline: Margin of Victory Will Matter as Clinton Counts on Black Voters in South Carolina
abstract: Black women seem to hold the key, but a less impressive win would give the Sanders campaign hope in other primaries.
lead_paragraph: After three contests, Hillary Clinton leads Bernie Sanders by the slimmest of margins in the Democratic primary, 51 to 50 in delegates.

headline: The T Takes on Four Oscar-Nominated Writer/Directors
abstract: Ahead of Sunday night’s ceremony, a guide to some of the Academy Award-nominated talent we’ve met along the way.
lead_paragraph: Household names and newcomers alike have made it onto the 2016 Academy Awards ballot — and into the pages of T. Ahead of Sunday night’s ceremony, a guide to the some of the talent we’ve met along the way.

headline: Jersey City Warehouse Converted to Rental Lofts
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)']
abstract: A century-old Jersey City warehouse is being reimagined as 366 residential lofts available for rent.
lead_paragraph: When the Butler Brothers building rose near the Jersey City waterfront 111 years ago, the immense brick structure was a testament to the city’s manufacturing prowess. Shaped like the letter E, the eight-story warehouse spanned a square city block and was a distribution center for the Chicago-based company’s catalog business and its Ben Franklin five-and-dime stores and Federated stores.

headline: Modera Lofts, Jersey City
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites']
abstract: The 1905 Butler Brothers Building at 350 Warren Street in Jersey City is being converted to 366 residential lofts.
lead_paragraph: The 1905 Butler Brothers Building at 350 Warren Street in Jersey City is being converted to 366 residential lofts.

headline: Before There Was Trump, There Was Gingrich
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Presidential Election of 2012', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Sidewalks']
abstract: Mr. Trump’s comment that he did not want people “dying on the sidewalks” was not without precedent in Republican circles.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times columnist Gail Collins recently wrote a takedown of Donald Trump. Her focus was Mr. Trump’s rationale for his professed support of Obamacare. “I don’t want people dying on the streets,” he said.

headline: What’s the Point of Moral Outrage?
keywords: ['Evolution (Biology)', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Research', 'Emotions', 'ADVERTISING AND MARKETING']
abstract: It may seem noble and selfless, but it’s also about improving your reputation.
lead_paragraph: HUMAN beings have an appetite for moral outrage. You see this in public life — in the condemnation of Donald J. Trump for vowing to bar Muslims from the United States, or of Hillary Clinton for her close involvement with Wall Street, to pick two ready examples — and you see this in personal life, where we criticize friends, colleagues and neighbors who behave badly.

headline: Feb. 26, 2016 — Pictures of the Day
abstract: Photos from Syria, Iran, Macedonia and Germany.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Syria, Iran, Macedonia and Germany.

headline: Photos of the Day: Syria and Elsewhere
abstract: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day
lead_paragraph: Syria and More — Pictures of the Day

headline: At Max Mara, A Bauhaus-Inspired Twist
abstract: The fall/winter 2016 collection included stripes, sweaters — and lots of bold color.
lead_paragraph: The fall/winter 2016 collection included stripes, sweaters — and lots of bold color.

headline: Betting Markets Weigh the Odds of Vice President Christie
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Endorsements', 'Vice Presidents and Vice Presidency (US)']
abstract: After endorsing Donald Trump, Chris Christie is now the market favorite for the No. 2 spot.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie’s surprise endorsement of Donald Trump on Friday immediately set tongues wagging about what’s in it for him. After all, Mr. Trump has said of Mr. Christie that “there could certainly be a place for him” as his running mate.

headline: Questions Nag in Sweden 30 Years After Leader’s Assassination
abstract: The unsolved shooting of Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986 was a watershed moment in history that continues to fascinate and haunt the country.
lead_paragraph: GOTEBORG, Sweden — Three decades after Prime Minister Olof Palme was gunned down on a Stockholm street, his unsolved killing continues to reverberate through Swedish politics and society.

headline: Soprano Gets Two More Turns at Met “Butterfly”
abstract: Ana María Martínez will sing the role on Feb. 27 and March 5.
lead_paragraph: Ana María Martínez, who received rave reviews earlier this month when she filled in for an ailing soprano in the title role of Puccini’s “Madama Butterfly” at the Metropolitan Opera, will extend her run and sing the role two more times, the company announced on Friday.

headline: What We’re Reading
abstract: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. Today, great reads from Randy Archibold, Jack Healy and others.
lead_paragraph: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What We’re Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up »

headline: These Days, John Baldessari Cribs From the Masters
abstract: Now 84, the conceptual artist is grappling with the history of painting by focusing on Goya and Giotto.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Having taught many generations of Los Angeles artists, John Baldessari proudly displays a few of their creations on the walls of his large studio in Venice. One piece, by Analia Saban, consists of white paper cleverly made to look like a stained gym towel.

headline: Friday Night Music: White Rabbit
abstract: Logic and proportion have indeed fallen sloppy dead.
lead_paragraph: Definitely a good week to start dropping acid, although it might be hard to tell the difference.

headline: Review: Baiba Skride Wrestles Bartok’s Art of Darkness
abstract: The violinist and the New York Philharmonic perform the composer’s dark-hued Violin Concerto No. 2 and two sunny works by Dvorak.
lead_paragraph: Young musicians are often told they should wait to perform certain works that require technical or psychological maturity, like late Beethoven or Schubert. The piece the Latvian violinist Baiba Skride, 34, yearned to play as a student was Bartok’s Violin Concerto No. 2, but her teachers deemed it too emotionally taxing.

headline: English National Opera’s Chorus Votes to Strike
abstract: Members of the chorus will stage a strike during the first act of the March 18 performance of Philip Glass’s “Akhnaten.”
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Chorus members at the English National Opera here voted on Friday to strike over proposed layoffs and salary cuts.

headline: Review: Jason Isbell, Slowing Down to Feel the Americana
abstract: Mr. Isbell, working with his band, the 400 Unit, has emerged over the last few years as the prevailing bard of the Americana genre.
lead_paragraph: It’s standard practice for a band to play its songs a little faster in concert than on record, as a matter of courting excitement or surrendering to it. Jason Isbell and the 400 Unit tacked the other way on Thursday at the Beacon Theater, in his first of two consecutive nights there: digging deep furrows and hunkering down.

headline: Allergic to Dogs on a Flight? What Travelers Need to Know
abstract: An airline recently asked a family whose son developed an allergic reaction to a dog on board to leave the plane. Here is what fliers can do in a similar situation.
lead_paragraph: A 7-year-old boy and his parents were asked to leave their Allegiant Air flight from Bellingham, Wash., to Phoenix last week after the boy developed an allergic reaction to a dog, a service animal, on the plane, according to several news reports. The flight was delayed about 90 minutes and some passengers were said to have applauded when the child was leaving.

headline: Review: Mariinsky Celebrates a Prima Ballerina
abstract: In the first of four programs at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the ballet company performed “A Tribute to Maya Plisetskaya” on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The Mariinsky Ballet has been variously known as the wellspring of ballet classicism and the finest home of ballet romanticism. On Thursday, however, it became the celebrant of sensationalist kitsch in the triple bill that opened its four-program season, “A Tribute to Maya Plisetskaya,” at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. The evening was bizarre in several ways.

headline: Versace: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Donatella Versace’s vision for fall 2016.
lead_paragraph: Donatella Versace’s vision for fall 2016.

headline: Donald Trump and Chris Christie Start a Bully Bromance
abstract: Chris Christie’s endorsement of Donald Trump feeds the New Jersey governor’s twin desires: for national recognition and political revenge.
lead_paragraph: Those who have witnessed Gov. Chris Christie’s performance both in New Jersey and in the national arena over the past couple of years almost could have seen Friday’s sweaty embrace of Donald Trump coming. Almost.

headline: Review: The New@Graham Series Is Helped by an App
abstract: The troupe hosted a virtual tour of its new technology, as well as live performances of three Martha Graham works.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that the Martha Graham Center for Contemporary Dance has a free downloadable mobile app? I didn’t until Thursday night, when the Graham company hosted a virtual tour of its latest technological endeavors, in particular its new partnership with the Google Cultural Institute.

headline: Rauschenberg Foundation Eases Copyright Restrictions on Art
abstract: The foundation has adopted a policy of making images of the artist’s work much more widely available for free.
lead_paragraph: Museumgoers tend to be unaware of the vast network of copyright protections that underlie images of much of Modern and contemporary art, until they try to shoot a cellphone picture of a favorite painting and receive an embarrassing tut-tut from a guard.

headline: Review: ‘I’ll Never Love Again,’ From a Teenage Girl’s Diary
abstract: Clare Barron’s play at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn recalls the anguishing mysteries of sex and love during adolescence.
lead_paragraph: Should it choose to adopt the Broadway business model for self-promoting souvenirs, the Bushwick Starr could surely do a brisk trade in “I Am Clare” buttons. These artifacts might be sold, along with the usual choices of bottled beer, from the bar in what passes for a lobby in this tiny walk-up theater in Brooklyn.

headline: Evening Hours | The Orchid Dinner, the Viennese Opera Ball and More
abstract: Plus: the Purim Ball and the annual winter ball hosted by the Museum of the City of New York.
lead_paragraph: Plus: the Purim Ball and the annual winter ball hosted by the Museum of the City of New York.

headline: Success Academy Loses in Pre-K Battle With de Blasio Administration
abstract: The state education commissioner ruled that New York City could require the charter school operator to sign a prekindergarten contract it had refused to sign.
lead_paragraph: Success Academy suffered a defeat in a high-profile skirmish with New York City on Friday, when the state education commissioner ruled that the city could require the charter school network to sign a contract to receive funding for its prekindergarten program.

headline: Review: ‘City of Glass,’ Down a Rabbit Hole of Meta-Noir
abstract: Untitled Theater Company No. 61 presents an adaptation of the first novel in Paul Auster’s enigmatic “New York Trilogy.”
lead_paragraph: In “City of Glass,” an adaptation of Paul Auster’s 1985 novel by Untitled Theater Company No. 61, a wrong number plunges a thriller writer into a mystery of his own. When a man first telephones Daniel Quinn (Robert Honeywell), asking to speak to “the detective, Paul Auster,” Quinn informs the caller of his mistake. But the next time the phone rings, Quinn pretends to be Auster and soon finds himself embroiled in the tale of a monstrous father, a damaged son and an alluring wife.

headline: Prada’s Wistful Tough Girls
abstract: The label’s fall/winter show incorporated iconic markers of femininity like brocade, roses and pearls — but the effect was still unsettling.
lead_paragraph: The label’s fall/winter show incorporated iconic markers of femininity like brocade, roses and pearls — but the effect was still unsettling.

headline: Review: You See ‘The Encounter’ With Your Ears
abstract: In the play, by Simon McBurney at the Barbican Theater in London, audience members are asked to put on headphones and listen closely.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Someone is blowing in your ear, and it isn’t anybody in your immediate vicinity. You can feel this distant person’s breath (hot) and his urgency (hotter), and the sound of him is all over the place — behind you, before you, to either side of you, close and distant, shouting and whispering, sometimes in several voices at once.

headline: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Sepp Blatter, Academy Awards, Syria
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
lead_paragraph: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

headline: Review: Mozart, a Little Bit Symphony, a Little Bit Opera
abstract: The Freiburg Baroque Orchestra’s Mozart program at Alice Tully Hall was a chance to hear Mozart as performed in the late-18th century.
lead_paragraph: You would think that a Mozart symphony should be heard as an entity, a single composition in four parts. But at concerts in that composer’s day, it was fairly common for movements of a symphony to be interspersed with opera arias, orchestral dances and whatnot.

headline: The Young Minimalist Designer Being Compared to Armani
abstract: Lucio Vanotti will hold his second runway show in Milan this week.
lead_paragraph: All weather reports indicated spring on a recent Saturday in Milan, but February’s gloomy cloud cover said otherwise. Still, Lucio Vanotti, the 40-year-old minimalist clothing designer, appeared for a stroll in Parco Sempione with his perpetual sidekick, a tiny taupe-colored, bowlegged Italian greyhound named — in true minimalist fashion — Clean. Both man and dog were dressed rigorously in black, but color was all around — it was Carnival week, and brightly costumed children threw thick trails of rainbow confetti on the park’s walkways.

headline: Donald Trump Might Not Keep Paying for His Campaign Himself, Chris Christie Suggests
abstract: The New Jersey governor said he expects Mr. Trump, whom he endorsed earlier on Friday, to start seeking campaign contributions in a general election despite his primary-season boasts that he is funding his own campaign.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey told his finance team late Friday that he anticipates that Donald J. Trump, who often boasts that he is funding his own campaign, will begin to solicit campaign contributions as the race heads into a general election if Mr. Trump becomes the nominee.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Shaggy Streets
keywords: ['Fur', 'Coats and Jackets', 'New York Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: The fur (faux and natural) was flying on the runways and on the guests at the recent New York collections, despite anti-fur sentiments
lead_paragraph: The fur (faux and natural) was flying on the runways and on the guests at the recent New York collections, despite anti-fur sentiments. There were patchworks of fur everywhere, and at Marc Jacobs, three or four different furs were combined into single coats. Zero-degree weather during fashion week only encouraged the fur-bearing.

headline: Ted Cruz, Running a Distant Third in Friday’s Insult-a-Thon, Still Takes His Shots
abstract: With Marco Rubio and Donald J. Trump (with help from Gov. Chris Christie) dominating the news cycle, Ted Cruz soldiered on.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Donald J. Trump plucked a mega-endorsement from across the Hudson River. Senator Marco Rubio established himself as the front-runner’s new chief tormentor, insulting Mr. Trump’s spelling and questioning his bladder control.

headline: Baseball’s First Threshold
abstract: The game has changed, but some things never do: The first day of spring training is the only day you will feel 100 percent.
lead_paragraph: The first day of spring training is often linked with the smell of fresh-cut grass. Cut grass means well-manicured baseball fields. Well-manicured baseball fields mean we are about to get serious.

headline: Marines Toast Iwo Jima Veterans on Anniversary of Flag Raising
keywords: ['World War II (1939-45)', 'Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Retired and active-duty Marines gathered to honor Angelo Ciotta and Jack Seiferth, two Queens natives who fought in the battle for Iwo Jima in 1945.
lead_paragraph: Angelo Ciotta, 90, leaned against the bar inside a restaurant in Queens as fellow Marines offered a series of taut salutes and a bottle of red wine — a Marine Corps-themed vintage called Jarhead Red.

headline: A Better Way to Control the Banks
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Defending and building on Dodd-Frank makes the most sense at this time.
lead_paragraph: Nearly eight years after the financial crisis, behemoth banks still dominate the global economy. They are still immensely complex, highly leveraged and politically powerful. They are still difficult, if not impossible, to manage and supervise. For those reasons, they remain a threat to the economy, and the notion of breaking them up appeals to many voters, policy makers and politicians.

headline: Rejected Proposals for Penn Station
abstract: As the city considers overhauling the station, it seems like a good time to review ideas that didn't make the cut last time.
lead_paragraph: As the city considers overhauling the station, it seems like a good time to review ideas that didn't make the cut last time.

headline: A Georgia Bill Shields Discrimination Against Gays
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships']
abstract: The state is one of eight that are considering blanket legal protection for discrimination on religious grounds. Its bill is one of the most alarming.
lead_paragraph: After Indiana’s disastrous attempt last year to enact a religious-freedom law protecting business owners and others who refuse to serve same-sex couples for religious or moral reasons, one might reasonably have assumed that other states contemplating similar legislation would be chastened into dropping it.

headline: Two Deaths, One Overlooked, Remain Unsolved After J’ouvert Festival
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Parades', 'West Indian-American Day']
abstract: A Bronx man was killed the same night as an aide to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, but their cases received different levels of public scrutiny. Both their killers remain at large.
lead_paragraph: It was a little after midnight when Denentro Josiah peeked into his parents’ bedroom in their Bronx home and told his mother he was heading to Brooklyn for the street party taking place before the West Indian American Day Parade, she recalled.

headline: Fed’s Transparency May Give Investors False Confidence, Economists Say
abstract: A paper by a group of economists argues that the Federal Reserve’s efforts to speak more clearly about its plans for monetary policy set up markets for disappointments.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve may be guilty of sharing too much information.

headline: Mets’ Zack Wheeler, Recovering From Surgery, Practices Patience
abstract: Wheeler, who continues to recover from Tommy John surgery, is not expected to rejoin the rotation until around July 1, leaving his teammates to prepare for the start of the season without him.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As Matt Harvey threw a routine bullpen session this week, Zack Wheeler stood 10 feet behind him, holding a clipboard. With each pitch Harvey threw, Wheeler marked a box on a sheet of paper, indicating where it was. Coaches typically fill out the form, but Wheeler figured that if he was just standing around, why not help?

headline: Officials Report 9 New Cases of Zika Virus Among Pregnant Women Tested in U.S.
abstract: One of the women gave birth to a baby with microcephaly, a defect that has been associated with the Zika virus, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
lead_paragraph: Nine pregnant women in the United States have tested positive for the Zika virus, American health authorities reported Friday. One of the women gave birth to a baby with microcephaly, a defect that has been associated with the virus, and at least one other had an abortion after severe brain atrophy was detected in the fetus.

headline: Retired Police Sergeant Pleads Guilty to Tapping Into Confidential Databases for Money
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Detectives (Private)', 'Bribery and Kickbacks', 'Police']
abstract: Ronald G. Buell, 49, admitted to providing restricted information to an investigator for criminal defense lawyers.
lead_paragraph: A former New York City police sergeant pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiracy, admitting that he had accepted money to tap into restricted law enforcement databases to furnish information to a former officer who was working as an investigator for criminal defense lawyers.

headline: For a Yankees Prospect, Training Camp Involves Part Healing, Part Hope
abstract: For Greg Bird, a first-base prospect who will miss the 2016 season because of a shoulder injury, spring training means recovery.
lead_paragraph: TAMPA, Fla. — While the Yankees were on the baseball fields on Friday, throwing, catching, running and hitting, Greg Bird was doing none of those.

headline: George C. Nichopoulos, Elvis’s Last Doctor, Dies at 88
abstract: Dr. Nichopoulos, who lost his medical license for overprescribing addictive drugs, was the singer’s personal physician in the decade before his death.
lead_paragraph: Dr. George C. Nichopoulos, Elvis Presley’s personal physician in the decade before his death in 1977, who lost his medical license for overprescribing addictive drugs for years to numerous patients, died on Wednesday in Memphis. He was 88.

headline: Apple’s Privacy Fight Tests Relationship With White House
abstract: The encryption debate and the government’s legal action against Apple have created more tension between the company and the Obama administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Timothy D. Cook, the chief executive of Apple, was relentless during a private meeting of tech giants and President Obama’s top national security officials last month. Encrypted devices like the iPhone are here to stay, he insisted. Law enforcement needs to find a way to do its job in a new world.

headline: Unclassified Clinton Emails May Have Consequences for a Key Deputy
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'E-Mail', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: Much of the correspondence American diplomats had with Hillary Clinton when she was secretary of state went through an aide who routinely sent emails to her that should have been secret.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In May, 2011, John Kerry wrapped up a trip to Pakistan intended to calm tensions over the secret raid that had killed Osama bin Laden just weeks before. But as he took off to fly to Dubai, the Central Intelligence Agency carried out a pair of drone attacks in North Waziristan.

headline: Buy Local? South Bronx’s New Councilman Makes It a Habit
abstract: Rafael Salamanca Jr., a Democrat who won a special election this week, likes his money to stay with businesses in his troubled corner of New York City.
lead_paragraph: The newest member of the New York City Council, Rafael Salamanca Jr., will be sworn into office in a new blue suit. Like most everything in his life, it has a South Bronx connection.

headline: Syria Truce Comes With Price, but Not for Assad
abstract: European and Israeli intelligence officials believe the pause in fighting may consolidate President Bashar al-Assad’s hold on power.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the temporary cease-fire in Syria begins to take hold on Saturday, despite the low expectations of the American and Russian officials who negotiated the agreement, it will be a landmark event. For the first time, diplomacy will have succeeded in abating the killing and misery that have already led to more than 250,000 deaths and millions of refugees pouring out of the shattered country.

headline: Emails Show Michigan Aides Worried About Flint’s Water a Year Before Acting
abstract: Newly released emails show that aides to Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan were concerned about the quality of Flint’s water a year before he told residents to stop drinking it.
lead_paragraph: A full year before the state took significant action, some top aides to Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan were alarmed at the quality of Flint’s water, with a lawyer for the governor calling the notion of drinking it “downright scary,” newly released emails show.

headline: Trump Meets the Mean Boys
abstract: The key to a successful debate: Avoid discussions of actual policy and concentrate on inflicting death by insult.
lead_paragraph: Chris Christie has endorsed Donald Trump! Well, really, what did you expect? He’s a sworn enemy of Marco Rubio, and we have long since established that nobody likes Ted Cruz.

headline: Andy Bathgate, Standout on Dismal 1950s Rangers, Dies at 83
abstract: Bathgate set a team record for goals and was elected to the Hockey Hall of Fame, but he won the Stanley Cup only after being traded to Toronto.
lead_paragraph: Andy Bathgate, the hockey Hall of Famer whose scoring touch gave Ranger fans something to cheer about while watching usually lackluster teams in the 1950s and early ’60s, died on Friday in Brampton, Ontario. He was 83.

headline: B&H Electronics Store Sued for Discrimination of Hispanic Workers
keywords: ['Hispanic-Americans', 'Hiring and Promotion', 'Discrimination', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The suit, filed by the federal Labor Department, said the workers were also subjected to harassment and unsanitary conditions.
lead_paragraph: For the second time in nine years, the owners of B&H Photo Video, a popular electronics store in Manhattan, have been sued by the federal government for discriminating against Hispanic workers.

headline: Alfred E. Mann, Pioneer in Medical Devices, Dies at 90
abstract: Mr. Mann’s companies developed products ranging from pacemakers with rechargeable batteries to the first “artificial retina.”
lead_paragraph: Alfred E. Mann, who started medical device companies that pioneered in the development of pacemakers for erratic hearts, insulin pumps for diabetics, cochlear implants for the deaf and retinal implants for the blind, died on Thursday in Las Vegas. He was 90.

headline: Buna Ziua and Mad Props
abstract: How to become a Saturday solver and why you should develop Saturday-level solving skills.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There is only one way that I know of to gain a toehold in a Saturday crossword, and that is to scan and re-scan the clue list for an entry that you definitely know. Sometimes, you might have to perform this exercise two or three times before you find a single entry to write into the grid.

headline: Elias Demetracopoulos, 87, Dies; Journalist Linked Greek Junta to Nixon
abstract: The enigmatic Mr. Demetracopoulos often exasperated the State Department, once sued the C.I.A. and was honored in his homeland as a champion of freedom.
lead_paragraph: Elias Demetracopoulos, an enigmatic journalist who fled Greece after a military coup in 1967 and accused the ruling right-wing junta of illegally funneling a half-million dollars into Richard M. Nixon’s 1968 presidential campaign, died on Feb. 16 at a nursing home in Athens. He was 87.

headline: John Kasich Says He’s Surprised but Unfazed by Chris Christie’s Endorsement of Donald Trump
abstract: Mr. Kasich, the only governor remaining in the Republican presidential field, said Mr. Christie’s decision would not affect his campaign.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — John Kasich, the only governor remaining in the Republican presidential field, said on Friday that he was “a little bit surprised” that Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey decided to endorse Donald J. Trump.

headline: ‘The Revenant’ Author Michael Punke Has a Day Job
abstract: Michael Punke is the United States ambassador to the World Trade Organization, a role that is seriously limiting his celebrity.
lead_paragraph: There are five literary adaptations in the Oscar race for best picture this year, including movies based on Emma Donoghue’s “Room” and Colm Tóibín’s “Brooklyn.” But among the hopeful novelists who will be closely watching Sunday’s Academy Awards ceremony, only one has negotiated a $1.3 trillion global trade deal.

headline: Knicks Find Balance and Break Free Fall
abstract: The Knicks easily handled the Magic with a balanced attack that was led by Carmelo Anthony and Kristaps Porzingis.
lead_paragraph: When Kurt Rambis took over as interim coach of the Knicks this month, he set a lofty goal of steering the team with a 23-31 record to the playoffs.

headline: Dean at University of Texas Resigns in Part Over Handgun Law
abstract: The decision by the School of Architecture’s dean in Austin underscores concerns over a new law allowing people to carry concealed firearms in campus buildings.
lead_paragraph: A highly regarded dean at the flagship campus of the University of Texas announced this week that he was leaving the school in part because of his concerns over a new state law allowing people to carry concealed firearms in classrooms and other buildings on public college campuses.

headline: Quotation of the Day
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: “A new era has been started as we speak. You will be proud of FIFA. You will be proud of what FIFA will do for football.”

headline: Corrections: February 27, 2016
abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Saturday, February 27, 2016.
lead_paragraph: WEEKEND ARTS

headline: Eddie Einhorn, a Creator of College Basketball on TV, Dies at 80
abstract: Mr. Einhorn, who created a sports network that propelled national interest in college basketball, was also an owner and team president of the Chicago White Sox.
lead_paragraph: Eddie Einhorn, who created a sports network that propelled national interest in college basketball, laying a foundation for the immense popularity of the annual tournament known as March Madness, died on Wednesday in Norwood, N.J. He was 80.

headline: What to Watch Saturday
abstract: Adam McKay takes a thrill-ride through the 2008 financial crisis in “The Big Short.” And Bertrand Bonello imagines Yves Saint Laurent in his prime.
lead_paragraph: Our best-picture Oscar catch-up concludes with “The Big Short,” Adam McKay’s thrill ride through the 2008 financial crisis. And Essence magazine honors black women in Hollywood.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: The Weekend
abstract: From Bottega Veneta to Missoni, the schedule as the week winds down is a busy one.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — Saturday starts in a highly civilized fashion at 9:30 a.m. with a show by Bottega Veneta, one of Kering’s star performing brands, which happens to have some of the best baristas in the business at its sleek headquarters on the Via Privata Ercole Marelli here.

headline: Suicide Bombings in Afghanistan Kill at Least 26
abstract: The two attacks, in Kabul and Kunar Province, also wounded nearly 50 people days ahead of expected talks between the government and the Taliban.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Two separate suicide bombings in Afghanistan on Saturday left at least 26 people dead and nearly 50 injured, officials said, days ahead of expected talks between the government and the Taliban.

headline: Our Best Comments of the Week
abstract: “I want someone who can dismantle the establishment.” Readers react to Donald Trump, the battle over the Supreme Court and more.
lead_paragraph: In this new feature, we’ll list the top 10 comments of the week on our digital platforms, as selected by our readers and the journalists who moderate nearly every comment.

headline: For Some Men, Mark Zuckerberg Is a Lifestyle Guru
abstract: Each year the Facebook chief executive announces a self-improvement project. And now a number of “brogrammers” follow his lead.
lead_paragraph: Anyone who has ever taken to social media to announce a self-improvement project knows that your “friends” cannot be relied upon to hold you accountable. Almost as soon as you proclaim your intention to learn French or cut out carbs, the world moves on, leaving you with only your empty promises and scone crumbs on your shirt.

headline: Lupita Nyong’o and Trevor Noah, and Their Meaningful Roles
abstract: The actress and the “Daily Show” host talk about the challenges of diversity, childhoods lived under oppressive governments and #OscarsSoWhite.
lead_paragraph: The most intriguing stars seem to appear from out of nowhere.

headline: Poll Watch: Trump Tries to Court Hispanic Voters
abstract: Donald Trump’s history of making disparaging comments about Mexican immigrants is well known, and he faces an uphill battle in building trust among the Hispanic electorate.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump bragged during Thursday night’s Republican debate that he had won almost half the Hispanic vote in the Nevada caucuses on Tuesday. “Nobody else was close,” he said. Looking forward, he said, “I will do really well with Hispanics.”

headline: Bottega Veneta: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Designs for fall 2016 from the mind of Tomas Maier.
lead_paragraph: Designs for fall 2016 from the mind of Tomas Maier.

headline: The Week on Instagram
keywords: ['Photography', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'ALPINE SKIING', 'Grapefruit']
abstract: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took our followers from Yosemite National Park to fashion week in Milan.
lead_paragraph: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took our followers from Yosemite National Park to fashion week in Milan.

headline: Inside the Republican Party’s Desperate Mission to Stop Donald Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Despite all the forces arrayed against Mr. Trump, a paralytic sense of indecision and despair has prevailed.
lead_paragraph: Get live updates about the Florida primary.

headline: Antonio Marras: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: The latest collection from Antonio Marras.
lead_paragraph: The latest collection from Antonio Marras.

headline: Hillary Clinton Wins South Carolina Primary
abstract: Drawing overwhelming support from African-American voters, Mrs. Clinton won her first resounding victory of the 2016 campaign.
lead_paragraph: COLUMBIA, S.C. — Drawing overwhelming support from the African-American voters who deserted her here eight years ago, Hillary Clinton won her first resounding victory of the 2016 campaign in South Carolina on Saturday, delivering a blow to Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont as their fight turns to the 11 states where Democrats vote on Tuesday.

headline: The Daily Shoe: Versace
abstract: T plucks the best shoes right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Donatella Versace and a kitten heel aren’t exactly synonymous. And yet these zip-up ankle boots are just as sexy as one of her many vertiginous designs.

headline: A Little Variety
abstract: Discuss your experiences solving the “A Little Variety Suite” of puzzles here.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE VARIETY PUZZLES — This week’s puzzles include:

headline: Farhad and Mike Hash Out the Week’s Big Topic: Apple
abstract: The Apple-F.B.I. fray, in a terrorism case no less, is reverberating throughout the digital world, with some East Coast-West Coast divergences.
lead_paragraph: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

headline: G-20, Rejecting Major Policy Shifts, Plays Up Basic Strengths
keywords: ['International Trade and World Market', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Renminbi (Currency)', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: The finance ministers from the world’s 20 largest economies wrapped up a day and a half of meetings with a message that the markets worry too much.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Through the winter, world financial markets have tumbled and churned with a succession of worries. The Chinese economy seemed to be faltering. Commodity exporters like Russia and Brazil suffered sharp slowdowns. And with oil prices falling, banks that have lent heavily to energy companies could be hurt.

headline: Dropping the Curtain on a Singing Neighbor
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Cooperatives', 'Building Service Employees', 'Balconies and Terraces', 'Noise', 'Opera', 'Plumbing']
abstract: This week’s topics include quieting a songstress, installing a dishwasher, and paying for balcony repairs.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

headline: Equality in Marriages Grows, and So Does Class Divide
keywords: ['Marriages', 'Income Inequality', 'Women and Girls', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Sociology', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The nature of marriage is changing, and that is contributing to income inequality, research shows.
lead_paragraph: The Don Drapers of the world used to marry their secretaries. Now they marry fellow executives, who could very well earn more than they do.

headline: The Daily Bag: Tod’s
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: We love the classic Tod’s satchel’s fall look: stitched up and strung with tassels.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Multicolored Oversize Knits
abstract: The once-frumpy combination of volume and clashing hues has gone from geek to chic.
lead_paragraph: This season, oversize multicolored knits — historically the opposite of cool — have caught our attention. In London, where we first saw the trend take shape at Joseph, the designer Louise Trotter showed sweaters in baggy proportions — including this childlike alphabet version that felt more thrift-store cool than designer. At Prada, a classic mosaic knit was made luxurious with the addition of fur cuffs. And at Etro, horizontal stripes and frayed edges recalled the grunge heyday — to great effect.

headline: The Daily Jewel: Sportmax
keywords: ['Fashion and Apparel', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Jewels and Jewelry']
abstract: T plucks the best jewels right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: These metal crescent earrings perfectly complemented Sportmax’s sculptural fall collection — as they would almost any outfit.

headline: Boston Suburb Bars Filming at Site of Post-Marathon Shootout
abstract: Watertown, Mass., won’t let “Patriot’s Day” be filmed at the scene of a blistering shootout between the police and the bombers.
lead_paragraph: The makers of a movie about the Boston Marathon bombing have scrapped plans to film the traumatic shootout scenes on location in Watertown, Mass., because the town has decided not to cooperate.

headline: The Cases for Public Investment
abstract: It should be a no-brainer.
lead_paragraph: One of the annoying aspects of the Sanders/Friedman flap was the assumption of many Sanders supporters that anyone who doesn’t accept extravagant economic projections is against a big program of public investment. Actually, it was destructive as well as annoying; aside from being an insult to progressive economists who believe in infrastructure but also believe in arithmetic, it created at least the possibility that other people would take the crash-and-burn of a particular piece of analysis as evidence that the whole case for spending more is wrong.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Marco de Vincenzo, Etro and Versace in Pictures
abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Friday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Friday.

headline: In ‘Good Old Days,’ Donald Trump Says,  Campaign Protesters Got More Than Just an Escort Out
abstract: Donald J. Trump again assailed political correctness, saying it limits what law enforcement can do to people protesting at his events.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The crowd at Donald J. Trump’s rally here Friday night quickly began booing the young protester clad in the “KKK supports Trump” T-shirt, who was escorted from the event.

headline: Jil Sander: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Jil Sander’s take on fall 2016.
lead_paragraph: Jil Sander’s take on fall 2016.

headline: Violence in Syria Abates on Day 1 of Cease-Fire
abstract: Fighting decreased significantly in the country following a truce brokered by the United States and Russia, though there were reports of scattered violations.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Violence significantly decreased in much of northern and western Syria on Saturday, the first day of a truce brokered by the United States and Russia, even amid reports of scattered violations, including incidents of bombing, shelling and at least one aerial attack.

headline: Variety: Diagramless Puzzle
abstract: Fred Piscop returns with a Diagramless puzzle.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — Are you one of those D.I.Y.ers, someone who would rather build something yourself than be content with a mass-produced object? Have we got a variety puzzle for you.

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines in Sports.
lead_paragraph: Curtain Call Remembered Fondly

headline: Warren Buffett, in Annual Letter, Rejects Candidates’ Message of U.S. Decline
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Company Reports', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Economy']
abstract: In his annual letter to shareholders, the billionaire investor dismissed the view, popular on the campaign trail, that children in America would not live as well as their parents.
lead_paragraph: Warren E. Buffett took aim on Saturday at the “negative drumbeat” of this year’s presidential campaign, saying that the view that children today would not live as well as their parents was “dead wrong.”

headline: FIFA, Knowing Prosecutors Are Watching, Makes Some Changes
abstract: Through its elections on Friday, FIFA likely wanted to show United States and Swiss prosecutors that it is willing to undertake reforms on its own.
lead_paragraph: ZURICH — Soccer’s governing body used an election on Friday to try to break with the past. FIFA chose a new president, the Swiss administrator Gianni Infantino, while approving reforms intended to overhaul the multibillion-dollar organization that the American authorities said last year was overrun with criminals.

headline: Early Results Show Reformists and Moderates Drawing Votes in Iran Elections
abstract: Preliminary results released Saturday showed that reformist and moderate candidates were leading in one of the two elections just held by Iran, state news media quoted the Interior Ministry as saying.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — Preliminary results released Saturday in Iran indicated that reformist and moderate candidates were set to expand their influence after two important elections, state news media quoted the Interior Ministry as saying.

headline: Warren Buffett Vows to Stick to Friendly Strategy, Rebuffing Activism
keywords: ['Shareholder Rights and Activism', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Letters']
abstract: Berkshire Hathaway will not engage in hostile takeovers, despite the rise of activist investors, its chief wrote in his annual letter to shareholders.
lead_paragraph: Activist investors may be on the rise and takeover efforts may have become more aggressive, but Warren E. Buffett is committed to a strategy he has pursued for the better part of 51 years.

headline: What It’s Really Like to Risk It All in Silicon Valley
keywords: ['Venture Capital', 'Women and Girls', 'Start-ups', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Entrepreneurship']
abstract: An entrepreneur tries to start a company and raise venture capital in Silicon Valley — and then finds out she is pregnant.
lead_paragraph: Before Nathalie Miller decided to walk away from Instacart, the grocery delivery start-up now worth more than $2 billion, she made a spreadsheet to analyze how much money she was leaving on the table.

headline: Disney Introduces Demand-Based Pricing at Theme Parks
keywords: ['AMUSEMENT AND THEME PARKS', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: Starting on Sunday, Disney’s theme park resorts in California and Florida will charge different ticket prices based on the calendar.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — For the first time, tickets to Walt Disney World in Florida and Disneyland in California will cost more during holidays and some weekends — up to 20 percent more — than during slower periods, as the bursting-at-the-seams parks seek to spread out demand.

headline: Ensconced in Family, Top Prospect Tries to Grow Into a Man, and a Met
abstract: With his family as his support system, Dominic Smith worked his way up through the minors and was drawing nearer to making his debut in the major leagues.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — In the fall of 2013, after the Mets selected Dominic Smith out of high school with the 11th overall pick in the first round and gave him a $2.6 million contract, one of his first big purchases was a new six-bedroom, five-bathroom home in a gated community here. It was about 10 minutes from the Mets’ spring training facility, and it was big enough that his mother, two siblings and a young nephew could live with him. Smith was only 18, after all.

headline: I.R.S. Calling to Demand Cash? Don’t Pay Up. Hang Up.
abstract: About 900,000 people have reported getting a call from I.R.S. phone scammers, and not all of these people hung up unscathed.
lead_paragraph: A tax adviser in Orlando, Fla., named Craig Smalley received a call about 10 months ago from a panicked client. Someone from the I.R.S. had just phoned, she said, to say a warrant for her arrest had been issued for failure to pay back taxes.

headline: Lindsey Vonn Suffers Hairline Fracture to Knee
abstract: Vonn, who has a history of knee injuries, crashed during a World Cup super-G race in Andorra but did not rule out a swift return to competition.
lead_paragraph: Lindsey Vonn, the American skier who is leading the overall World Cup standings as part of a spectacular comeback season, sustained a hairline fracture of her left knee Saturday during a high-speed crash in a super-G race at Soldeu-el Tarter, Andorra.

headline: Republican Candidates Deeply Entrenched Against Gun Controls
abstract: Clearly, facing up to the gun mayhem is a nonstarter for these contenders. All the more reason for the Democrats to keep driving the point home.
lead_paragraph: Realistically, no one studying politics should have expected the remaining Republican presidential contenders to speak up at their latest debate about the nation’s harrowing problem of mass shootings.

headline: The Sad Demise of the Summer Job
abstract: A program proposed by President Obama for getting young people into jobs deserves support.
lead_paragraph: President Obama touched on a national crisis last week when he called on business leaders to help connect young people with summer jobs that give them not just money, but also valuable work experience. Private companies can help. But they are hesitant to hire inexperienced applicants at a time when seasoned, middle-aged workers who lost good jobs during the recession are desperate for any work. The only solution to youth unemployment is for Congress to reinstate some version of the summer jobs program it abandoned in the late 1990s.

headline: Abdifatah Mohamud: Captain of the Call Center
abstract: As a customer care supervisor, Abdifatah Mohamud mentors employees at Alliance Data Systems, which manages companies’ credit card and loyalty programs.
lead_paragraph: Abdifatah Mohamud, 30, is a supervisor for Alliance Data Systems in Columbus, Ohio.

headline: That Coke Can Is Back
abstract: Anita, Clarence and O.J. are once more center-stage — but what have we learned?
lead_paragraph: HOLLYWOOD — THEY were dramas that drilled into the most sensitive parts of the national psyche, searing and dividing us with lurid sexual images and racial grievances as old as the nation.

headline: If Donald Trump Changed Genders
abstract: The Republican front-runner illuminates as much about sexism and double standards as the Democratic one.
lead_paragraph: IMAGINE, for a moment, the presidential candidacy of a rich, brash real estate magnate and reality TV star named Donna Trump.

headline: Showdown on Abortion at the Supreme Court
abstract: The justices should see that a Texas law has nothing to do with women’s health or free choice.
lead_paragraph: The decades-long crusade to end legal abortion in America after Roe v. Wade has again reached the Supreme Court.

headline: From Obama to Trump
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Although Donald Trump is immediately the Republicans’ problem, the Obama era contributed to his rise.
lead_paragraph: THE spectacle of the Republican Party’s Trumpian meltdown has inspired a mix of glee and fear among liberals — glee over their rivals’ self-immolation, and fear that what arises from the destruction will be worse.

headline: Who Are the Gay Evangelicals?
abstract: Some have found themselves turning to Catholic theology and queer theory.
lead_paragraph: THE anti-gay ideology that has long held sway in American evangelicalism seems to be crumbling. Conservatives’ insistence that the Bible proscribes homosexual acts and their claim that protecting gay rights infringes on their own religious liberty have depended on another assumption not found in Scripture: that homosexuality is not a biologically rooted identity but a sinful temptation, an addiction that one must control.

headline: Why Courts Shouldn’t Ignore the Facts About Abortion Rights
keywords: ['ABORTION', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: How far can states go in setting rules that restrict the procedure?
lead_paragraph: At the core of the most important Supreme Court abortion case in a generation is a series of questions about facts. In deciding the constitutionality of a law that would shut down most abortion clinics in a state in the name of protecting women’s health, which facts about the law’s rationale and its impact may a court consider? Which facts must a court consider? Are there facts a court must ignore entirely?

headline: The Killing Field
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Humanitarian Aid', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Crimes against humanity are being committed in South Sudan, which the U.S. helped midwife.
lead_paragraph: LEER, South Sudan — THE killing field on the edge of town is marked by skulls and bones littering the ground, attracting vultures and hyenas.

headline: Deniz Gamze Erguven
abstract: An Academy Award-nominated filmmaker on jealousy, Turkish politics and wearing a watch again.
lead_paragraph: Deniz Gamze Erguven is a Turkish-French filmmaker whose debut film, “Mustang,” has been nominated for an Academy Award for best foreign language film.

headline: Trigger Warnings
abstract: The stories told of gun accidents echo far beyond each isolated shot.
lead_paragraph: ACCIDENTAL gun deaths are not all that common, but stories about them are.

headline: What Prodigies Could Teach Us About Autism
abstract: Passionate interests, extreme working memories and family ties are among the intriguing connections.
lead_paragraph: MANY parents remember a moment when their toddler astounded them. Maybe he outpaced his playgroup at mastering a song. Maybe she knew an esoteric fact about outer space. They might quietly wonder: Is my child a prodigy?

headline: Even When Shots Miss, Intentionally Fouling May Not Pay Off
abstract: Intentional fouls against a poor free-throw shooter is a strategy with apparently inconclusive results, and there is a growing sentiment that the rules regarding the tactic should be changed.
lead_paragraph: Every time a poor free-throw shooter is fouled intentionally, it seems to reopen the debate about whether the N.B.A. should take action against the strategy.

headline: What Women Find in Friends That They May Not Get From Love
abstract: Not marrying right away doesn’t mean you’re alone.
lead_paragraph: SARA and I met as office drones in 1999. We became friends in a period of our lives when the demands of our jobs were just heating up, when the roots we were putting down in the city were just getting deep. In each other, we found respite, recognition, a shared eagerness to relax, take stock and talk about it all.

headline: Early Tallies Show Irish Voters Rejecting Government
abstract: The governing coalition will lose too many seats in Parliament to retain power, but it is unclear if any party will have enough seats to form a government.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Early results in Ireland’s general election indicated Saturday that voters had firmly rejected the center-right government, but it remained unclear if any party will have enough seats in Parliament to form a government.

headline: Davis Cup Returns to a Scene of Its Grassy Past
abstract: Kooyong Stadium, the site of memorable Davis Cup finals and the home of the Australian Open from 1972 to 1987, will host a first-round match between Australia and the United States.
lead_paragraph: MELBOURNE, Australia — It will be the United States versus Australia in the first round of Davis Cup this week at Kooyong Stadium.

headline: The Wrong Way to Teach Math
abstract: Think about numbers as a language; we need to learn to be fluent in it.
lead_paragraph: HERE’S an apparent paradox: Most Americans have taken high school mathematics, including geometry and algebra, yet a national survey found that 82 percent of adults could not compute the cost of a carpet when told its dimensions and square-yard price. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development recently tested adults in 24 countries on basic “numeracy” skills. Typical questions involved odometer readings and produce sell-by tags. The United States ended an embarrassing 22nd, behind Estonia and Cyprus. We should be doing better. Is more mathematics the answer?

headline: Don’t Call Me the ‘Black Seth Rogen’
abstract: Beyond the Oscars, what aiming for diversity in Hollywood can really feel like.
lead_paragraph: Los Angeles — YEARS ago, I was in a cast in what’s called a “network showcase.” Hollywood does tons of these types of showcase shows. The networks bring in young actors to create material and perform for agents, managers and casting directors. The goal is to get actors signed or brought in for auditions for pilots and eventually to create a star.

headline: Fixing the Iraq Mess
abstract: Readers discuss a letter from a retired Marine colonel about the need to pursue a “managed breakup” of Iraq and what America’s role should be.
lead_paragraph: Readers discuss a letter from a retired Marine colonel about the need to pursue a “managed breakup” of Iraq and what America’s role should be.

headline: Marco Rubio on Day 3 of Trump Offensive: ‘He Should Sue Whoever Did That to His Face’
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio of Florida said he would not let up on his attacks on Donald J. Trump because there was no other way to stop him.
lead_paragraph: KENNESAW, Ga. – Senator Marco Rubio of Florida, his momentum seemingly stunted by Gov. Chris Christie’s endorsement of Donald J. Trump, said Saturday that he would not stop ridiculing Mr. Trump as he tries to capitalize on  fears among Republicans about the businessman’s candidacy.

headline: Ask Your Doctor if This Ad Is Right for You
keywords: ['ADVERTISING AND MARKETING', 'Hospitals', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicine and Health', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: How advertising promotes expensive drugs and treatments you may not need.
lead_paragraph: A LITTLE more than a decade ago, most health care advertising was confined to mass-market drugs, and hospitals and doctors generally considered the practice tacky or ethically dubious. More often than not, the ads appeared in unassuming places like cheaper women’s magazines or the New York subway — for decades New Yorkers sat beneath ubiquitous rainbow posters for Dr. Jonathan Zizmor that promised to conquer blemishes: 212-594-SKIN!

headline: Talk Grows About Who Will Succeed Palestinians’ Fading Mahmoud Abbas
abstract: The aging Palestinian president, likened to a tree with leaves blowing off, rules ineffectively over a divided people and failing institutions.
lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — The past five months of Palestinian attacks on Israeli Jews have undermined the already weak political position of Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, who rules ineffectively over a divided people and failing institutions.

headline: John Kasich Says If He Doesn’t Win Ohio, He’s Going Home
abstract: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio, facing some pressure to leave the race, said that he would win his home state, but that if he did not, he would return to his day job.
lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — Facing pressure to leave the presidential race, Gov. John Kasich on Saturday singled out next month’s primary in his home state of Ohio as a make-or-break moment for his campaign.

headline: Sam Beall, Farm-to-Table Restaurateur Right on His Farm, Dies at 39
abstract: Mr. Beall turned Blackberry Farm, his parents’ country inn in eastern Tennessee, into a national destination and was a leader in the farm-to-table movement.
lead_paragraph: Sam Beall, who turned Blackberry Farm, his parents’ country inn in Walland, Tenn., into a national destination for fine dining and a leader in the farm-to-table culinary movement, died on Thursday in Vail, Colo. He was 39.

headline: Wesley A. Clark, Who Designed First Personal Computer, Dies at 88
keywords: ['Deaths (Obituaries)', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Laboratories and Scientific Equipment']
abstract: Mr. Clark’s designs built a bridge from the era of mainframe systems that were programmed with stacks of punch cards to personal computers that respond interactively to a user.
lead_paragraph: Wesley A. Clark, a physicist who designed the first modern personal computer, died on Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 88.

headline: Baffling the Yankees: A Select Group
abstract: Dallas Keuchel of the Houston Astros dominated the Yankees last year, defeating them three times. We take a closer look at those games as well as a list of other pitchers who have managed to confound the Yankees.
lead_paragraph: Dallas Keuchel of the Houston Astros dominated the Yankees last year, defeating them three times. We take a closer look at those games as well as a list of other pitchers who have managed to confound the Yankees.

headline: Guile Sharpens Perpetual Thorn in Yankees’ Side
abstract: It almost seems as if Dallas Keuchel, the Houston Astros’ bearded left-handed pitcher, can will himself to humble the Yankees and their city.
lead_paragraph: KISSIMMEE, Fla. — He stifled the Yankees in the summer, eliminated them in the fall, haunted them in the winter and looms over them in the spring. Even when he visited New York in January, the city stood still for Dallas Keuchel.

headline: Zack Wheeler’s Warm-Up Commands a Stage
abstract: As they did with Matt Harvey last season, the Mets are taking it slow with Zack Wheeler, who is recovering from Tommy John surgery.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — As the other Mets pitchers scattered to take part in various drills Saturday morning, Zack Wheeler reported to a relatively empty bullpen area. Standing on the slope of the mound, not even on the rubber, he made about 10 throws, as if simply warming up.

headline: No Trouble Seen in Brooklyn Home Where Fire Killed Girl, 2
keywords: ['Fires and Firefighters', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: Anonymous calls prompted child welfare caseworkers to visit Leila Aquino several times before her daughter, Kalenah, died in a house fire on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The anonymous calls to the New York State child abuse hotline claimed that Kalenah Muldrow’s mother was not taking care of her young daughter: Their home was squalid, the callers said, and lacking adequate food. In the most recent call, on Feb. 15, the caller raised concerns that Kalenah was being left with people other than her mother for extended periods of time.

headline: Strangers Extend a Helping Hand to Struggling New Yorkers
abstract: The latest Neediest Cases Fund campaign raised $5,664,202 for New Yorkers facing difficulties, and readers chipped in boxing lessons and pet supplies.
lead_paragraph: For Margaret Macaluso, driving her sons to and from their college classes and part-time jobs requires patience and compromise. The family has only one vehicle. Fortunately, she does not mind being a chauffeur. Ever since Ms. Macaluso learned in August that she had Stage 3 ovarian cancer, she has viewed every car ride as extra time with her sons.

headline: Smiles Come, and Smiles Go. Soon, Carmelo Anthony Might Follow.
abstract: Anthony was upbeat after the Knicks again looked like a team with a path forward, but ultimately nobody knows what is in his head, or heart.
lead_paragraph: Carmelo Anthony was back to being the last Knick out of the shower Friday night, as opposed to being the first one through the Madison Square Garden exit, as was the case earlier in the week. Normalcy was restored. He had returned to his standard postgame speaking slot as the resident star.

headline: Neediest Cases Fund: How to Give
abstract: A guide for how readers can contribute to the Neediest Cases Fund.
lead_paragraph: For more than 100 years, The New York Times has asked readers for contributions to its Neediest Cases Fund, to give direct assistance to troubled children, families and elders. The first year’s contributions totaled $3,630.88. The total now is about $6 million a year, and over the years the Fund has raised more than $282 million.

headline: The Strip
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: Court Jesters
abstract: Timothy Polin drags us onto the court.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today, Timothy Polin merges wacky definitions and sports in a crossword puzzle. Some of you might find this easier than others (and by that I mean me), especially if you are a basketball fan.

headline: Donald Trump Has Big Lead in Massachusetts, and Marco Rubio Is Distant Second, New Poll Shows
abstract: Donald J. Trump is doing well in Massachusetts, in small part, perhaps, because of his support of Tom Brady during the scandal over deflated footballs.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Donald J. Trump is the clear favorite among likely Republican voters in the Massachusetts primary on Tuesday, according to a poll released on Saturday by Suffolk University.

headline: With Fewer Members, a Diminished Political Role for Wisconsin Unions
keywords: ['Organized Labor', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Government Employees', 'Collective Bargaining', 'Presidential Election of 2012']
abstract: Wisconsin, once a labor stronghold, has lost tens of thousands of union members, and the shift has shaken the order of election-year politics.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Gov. Scott Walker’s foray into the Republican presidential field ended months ago, but he may yet have sway over the outcome.

headline: South Carolina Primary: Highlights
abstract: Hillary Clinton won her first resounding victory of the race in the South Carolina primary, dealing a blow to Bernie Sanders ahead of Super Tuesday.

headline: Donald Trump, Despite Impieties, Wins Hearts of Evangelical Voters
abstract: The candidate, who has boasted about adulteries, praised Planned Parenthood and admitted to never asking for God’s forgiveness, is the favorite of the Christian right.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — It is one of the prime paradoxes of the 2016 election: A twice-divorced candidate who has flaunted his adultery, praised Planned Parenthood and admitted to never asking for God’s forgiveness is the favorite of the Christian right.

headline: Female Pilot Unit Gains Support in Congress for Right to Arlington Burials
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Women and Girls', 'World War II (1939-45)', 'Veterans']
abstract: A lack of active-duty status keeps World War II veterans of the Women Airforce Service Pilots, known as the WASPs, out of the cemetery, but a House bill would change that.
lead_paragraph: SILVER SPRING, Md. — Shortly after Elaine D. Harmon died last April at the age of 95, her family found a letter in a fireproof box with explicit instructions: She wanted her ashes placed at Arlington National Cemetery.

headline: Assassination of Putin Critic Remembered in Moscow
keywords: ['Assassinations and Attempted Assassinations', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Tens of thousands of people joined a solemn march on Saturday to commemorate the first anniversary of the assassination of Boris Y. Nemtsov, a Russian opposition leader.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Tens of thousands of people flooded the streets of central Moscow on Saturday, joining a solemn march to commemorate the anniversary of the assassination of Boris Y. Nemtsov, a Russian opposition leader.

headline: C.D.C. Urges Pregnant Women to Avoid Travel to Olympics Over Zika Fears
abstract: Fears of the Zika virus have prompted the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to issue strict travel advisories for the upcoming Summer Games in Brazil.
lead_paragraph: Health officials in the United States have advised pregnant women who are scheduled to attend the Olympic Games in Brazil to reconsider their plans because of the Zika virus epidemic.

headline: Scientists Protest Cuts and Commercialization at Australian Climate Center
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Oceans and Seas', 'Research', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: A decision by Australia’s science agency to lay off researchers and focus more on commerce threatens climate studies around the globe.
lead_paragraph: SYDNEY, Australia — Perched on a wild, windy promontory on the rugged tip of northwestern Tasmania, the tiny Cape Grim research station has been measuring airborne greenhouse gases since 1976.

headline: Monarch Butterfly Migration Rebounds, Easing Some Fears
keywords: ['Butterflies and Moths', 'Endangered and Extinct Species', 'Global Warming']
abstract: Monarch butterflies, which fly each year to Mexico from Canada and the United States, covered about 10 acres this winter, an area more than three times as large as last year.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — After years of being ravaged by severe weather and shrinking habitats, the monarch butterflies hibernating in the Mexican mountains rebounded last year, kindling cautious hope that one of the insect world’s most captivating migrations may yet survive.

headline: South Carolina Exit Polls
abstract: Surveys of Democratic voters exiting voting locations throughout South Carolina on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Surveys of Democratic voters exiting voting locations throughout South Carolina on Saturday.

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Winning Numbers in South Carolina Suggest Sweep in South
abstract: Based on exit polls, her margin of victory with black voters was larger than Barack Obama’s against her in 2008.
lead_paragraph: After winning South Carolina’s Democratic primary eight years ago, Senator Barack Obama declared that “after four great contests, we have the most votes, the most delegates, and have the broadest coalition for change.” Tonight it is his former opponent, Hillary Clinton, who can now make the same claim.

headline: Italy Growers Wary of Olive Oil Fraud as New Law Is Weighed
keywords: ['Olive Oil', 'Counterfeit Merchandise', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Olives', 'Frauds and Swindling', 'Law and Legislation', 'Labeling and Labels (Product)', 'Consumer Protection']
abstract: Olive oil producers in the nation are troubled by draft legislation that would tinker with penalties for passing off counterfeit olive oil and its origin.
lead_paragraph: BLERA, Italy — For some of the 300 olive growers who toil here in the rolling hills of the Lazio region, making olive oil is a year-round labor of love.

headline: Ex-Official Calls for Malaysian Prime Minister to Step Down
abstract: A Malaysian official who has been removed from a top party job said he had seen proof that Prime Minister Najib Razak committed a crime related to the country’s sovereign wealth fund.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A prominent member of the governing coalition in Malaysia who has been removed from a top party job lashed back on Saturday with a strongly worded Facebook post saying he had seen “proof” that Prime Minister Najib Razak committed a crime in his dealings with the country’s sovereign wealth fund.

headline: Yemeni Civilians Killed by Airstrike on Market, Witnesses Say
abstract: At least 30 people were reported dead after a bombing by the Arab coalition that could add to calls for an international arms embargo on Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — A United States-backed Arab military coalition bombed a busy market north of Yemen’s capital early Saturday, killing at least 30 people, witnesses said.

keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Elections', 'Social Conditions and Trends']

headline: A Famous Voice Praises Hillary Clinton as a Voice for Blacks
abstract: With narration by the actor Morgan Freeman, an ad presents Mrs. Clinton as defender, protector and champion of African-Americans.
lead_paragraph: It is a choir of two, singing for millions. “She says their names,” Morgan Freeman intones, and Hillary Clinton’s voice, clipped from the campaign trail, seems to blend in with his: “Trayvon Martin,” they both say. “Shot to death,” says Mrs. Clinton, as pictures of victims of police brutality, and their grieving mourners, flash on screen. Dontre Hamilton: “Unarmed,” she says. “Sandra Bland did nothing wrong,” she says. Mr. Freeman drives home the point: Mrs. Clinton “makes their mothers’ fight for justice her own.”

headline: Hillary Clinton’s Legacy in Libya
abstract: As the secretary of state in 2011, Hillary Clinton pressed the Obama administration to intervene militarily in Libya, with consequences that have gone far beyond the fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

headline: Hillary Clinton, ‘Smart Power’ and a Dictator’s Fall
keywords: ['Series', 'United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The president was wary. The secretary of state was persuasive. But the ouster of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi left Libya a failed state and a terrorist haven.
lead_paragraph: By the time Mahmoud Jibril cleared customs at Le Bourget airport and sped into Paris, the American secretary of state had been waiting for hours. But this was not a meeting Hillary Clinton could cancel. Their encounter could decide whether America was again going to war.

headline: A New Libya, With ‘Very Little Time Left’
keywords: ['Series', 'United States International Relations', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The fall of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi seemed to vindicate Hillary Clinton. Then militias refused to disarm, neighbors fanned a civil war, and the Islamic State found refuge.
lead_paragraph: It was a grisly start to the new era for Libya, broadcast around the world. The dictator was dragged from the sewer pipe where he was hiding, tossed around by frenzied rebel soldiers, beaten bloody and sodomized with a bayonet. A shaky cellphone video showed the pocked face of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, “the Leader” who had terrified Libyans for four decades, looking frightened and bewildered. He would soon be dead.

headline: 1941: British Planes Set off 150 Fires in Cologne
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: British raiders heavily bomb Cologne in 1941.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the fifty-sixth raid on Cologne since the war started Royal Air Force bombers concentrated their fire on that important German manufacturing city for two and a half hours last night, dropping hundreds of high explosive and incendiary bombs. Pilots reported that 150 fires were set, and the Air Ministry termed it ‘‘a heavy and successful attack.’’

headline: At Bottega Veneta and Versace, the Soft Power Suit Also Rises
abstract: Marni, Jil Sander and Tod’s also proposed offerings fit for the new C-suite.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — On and on they came, the Versace hordes, striding out in pencil skirts and lace-up bootees and then circling left and right, tracing their way between rows, swarming the room. Donatella Versace set her show in the round, and paced it accordingly, so that at any given point wherever you looked was a streamlined silhouette, moving purposefully forward. The effect was to invert the usual runway equation: Instead of the audience surrounding the clothes, the clothes surrounded the audience. There was no escaping the import.

headline: The Daily Bag: Jil Sander
abstract: T plucks the best bags right off the runway.
lead_paragraph: Jil Sander’s designer gets the modern working woman: This season’s practical purses in drab neutrals — especially this one little black bag, with a twist — seem made for the ever-on-the-go minimalist.

lead_paragraph: When almost all the models in Bottega Veneta’s fall show have long scarves wrapped around their necks, it’s nearly impossible not be pulled in by this multistrand necklace worn by only two. It was styled for daytime, but looks just right for evening wear — and spring, summer and winter too.

headline: Marni’s Old Hollywood Beauty
keywords: ['Cosmetics and Toiletries', 'Milan Fashion Week', 'Fashion and Apparel']
abstract: In the house’s fall/winter 2016 show, shellacked waves of hair and black-and-white film inspired makeup felt classic, dramatic — and a little bit off balance.
lead_paragraph: “Amazing” is how the makeup artist Tom Pecheux, laughing just a bit, described the look he created for Marni’s fall show today. The designer Consuelo Castiglioni pointed to the 1940 black-and-white film “Rebecca” as a spark for the new collection, and the movie’s dramatic lighting and silver-screen glamour were translated into a classic Hollywood look: pale skin, intense lips, waves of hair set about the face — all thrown a little off-balance.

headline: A Former Calvin Klein Underwear Model Ages, if Only in a Leap Year
abstract: Antonio Sabato Jr. had celebrated six leap-year birthdays in 1996, when he appeared on a Times Square billboard advertising Calvin Klein underwear.
lead_paragraph: Antonio Sabato Jr. remembers unveiling the huge photograph on a billboard in Times Square in 1996 — the 90-foot-tall image of him with a defiantly seductive look in his eyes and almost no clothes on, only black bikini briefs. He was Calvin Klein’s newest underwear model, and the world took him for a 20-something heartthrob.

headline: Stephen Curry Can’t Be Stopped, by Any Generation

headline: Berlin’s Museum Tours in Arabic Forge a Bridge to Refugees
abstract: The Culture Ministry is introducing migrants from Iraq and Syria to a cultural heritage that happens to include rare treasures from the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Pergamon Museum is home to the famous Ishtar Gate, a monument of blue and white tile decorated with golden lions and daisies that was once the entrance to ancient Babylon. When Kamal Alramadhani, a 25-year-old Iraqi economics student, saw it for the first time this month, “I got goose bumps,” he said, pointing to his arm.
