lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel said on Sunday that he welcomed the efforts to achieve a long-term cease-fire in Syria but warned that Israel would continue to defend its own interests there.

headline: ‘Gods of Egypt’ and ‘Eddie the Eagle’ Struggle at Box Office
abstract: A third release, “Triple 9,” was also licking its wounds. “Gods of Egypt” came in at No. 2, though, and “Deadpool” remained at No. 1.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — As Hollywood prepared to celebrate its artistic accomplishments at the Academy Awards on Sunday, three movie studios were licking box-office wounds. Arriving in wide release over the weekend and struggling were Lionsgate’s big-budget “Gods of Egypt,” 20th Century Fox’s “Eddie the Eagle” and Open Road’s “Triple 9.”

headline: Trying to Revive H.M.O.s, but Without Those Scarlet Letters
abstract: The plans are making a comeback, but they are so tainted by their poor reputation that insurers and companies try to avoid calling them H.M.O.s.
lead_paragraph: An H.M.O. by any other name is still an H.M.O.

headline: Academy Awards 2016: Highlights and Analysis
abstract: Chris Rock hosted the 88th Academy Awards in Hollywood. “Spotlight” won best picture and Leonardo DiCaprio finally secured an Oscar for his performance in “The Revenant.”

headline: Rangers Trade for Eric Staal, Hurricanes’ Captain
abstract: Staal, a veteran center who joins his brother Marc in New York, cost the Rangers Aleksi Saarela — a third-round draft pick last year — as well as two future draft picks.
lead_paragraph: Five months after signing a seven-year, $57.75 million contract extension, center Eric Staal beat Martin Brodeur with a wrist shot with 31.7 seconds remaining in regulation to lift the Carolina Hurricanes over the stunned Devils in Game 7 of a first-round playoff series in 2009.

headline: Report Cites Dangers of Autonomous Weapons
abstract: A former Pentagon official who helped establish United States policy on such weapons says they could be uncontrollable in real-world situations.
lead_paragraph: A new report written by a former Pentagon official who helped establish United States policy on autonomous weapons argues that such weapons could be uncontrollable in real-world environments where they are subject to design failure as well as hacking, spoofing and manipulation by adversaries.

headline: Missoni: Fall 2016 RTW
abstract: Angela Missoni’s vision for fall 2016.
lead_paragraph: Angela Missoni’s vision for fall 2016.

headline: Oscars 2016: Chris Rock Scores and ‘Spotlight’ Takes Center Stage
abstract: The newspaper drama about the Catholic Church cover-up of sexual abuse by priests snatched top honors over “The Revenant,” considered the favorite by many.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In a ceremony that became a raucous diversity lesson under the guidance of its host, Chris Rock, “Spotlight,” a newspaper drama about the Roman Catholic Church cover-up of sexual abuse by priests, snatched top honors at the 88th Academy Awards on Sunday. It beat out “The Revenant,” which had been widely viewed as the favorite, but which nevertheless earned a best actor prize for Leonardo DiCaprio, his first Oscar, and a best director award for Alejandro G. Iñárritu.

headline: Review: ‘Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny,’ a Fight-Ridden Sequel
abstract: This sequel, directed by Yuen Wo Ping, mostly uses different actors as it tries to recapture the feel and success of the 2000 original.
lead_paragraph: When “Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon” opened in 2000, it carried surprises: that Ang Lee, a director known for high-minded literary adaptations, could make such a vibrant and exciting martial-arts movie, and that a Chinese-language film could be a box-office hit in America.

headline: Review: ‘Battle for the Airwaves,’ a Rock ’n’ Roll History
abstract: The show, part of the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series, was hosted by James Naughton.
lead_paragraph: Several rows of empty seats at Saturday evening’s opening performance of the 92nd Street Y’s Lyrics & Lyricists series suggested the lingering hostility of older patrons toward rock ’n’ roll. Some cultural conflicts never end. And the program, “Battle for the Airwaves,” hosted by the actor and singer James Naughton, rekindled memories of a time when the ascent of Elvis Presley was regarded by popular music’s old guard as a nothing less than a barbarian invasion.

headline: Review: ‘The Heart’ Offers Portraits in the Race to an Organ Transplant
abstract: In Maylis de Kerangal’s novel, translated from the French, we peer inside the lives of those affected by a fatal car crash.
lead_paragraph: Why are hospitals so rarely the settings for works of serious contemporary fiction? There are exceptions to this rule — Abraham Verghese’s “Cutting for Stone” comes to mind — but not many, which is strange, given that we’re at our most vulnerably human once we’ve burst through those automated doors, either wretched from grief or ecstatic from relief, release, new life.

headline: 3 Killed and 2 Injured in Hit-and-Run Crashes Across New York City
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Hit-and-Run Drivers']
abstract: No arrests have been made in a series of collisions that occurred after midnight on Saturday in which pedestrians and a cyclist were hit by motorists.
lead_paragraph: Three people were killed and two were injured on Sunday in separate collisions across New York City in which pedestrians and a cyclist were hit by motorists who fled the scene, the police said. No arrests had been made, and each of the five episodes remained under investigation.

headline: Only Separation Can Lead to a Two-State Solution
abstract: The leader of Israel’s opposition puts forward his vision for security and a long-term resolution to the conflict with the Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: Jerusalem — The Israeli-Palestinian conflict in its post-1967 incarnation has been raging for nearly 49 years, with no solution in sight. Several Israeli prime ministers, including Ehud Barak and Ehud Olmert, made great efforts to reach a permanent agreement, only for the Palestinians to decline, while Ariel Sharon’s unilateral withdrawal from Gaza was met not by peace and quiet, but by rockets and terror tunnels. The terror wave of recent months, in which Israeli civilians have been victims of stabbings, shootings and car attacks, has further eroded the faith of Israeli moderates in the prospects of attaining peace.

headline: Donald Trump Elicits Shock and Biting Satire in European Media
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'News and News Media', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Once dismissive of Mr. Trump’s presidential candidacy, European news media are adjusting to the prospect of a seemingly unstoppable Trump juggernaut.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — He has been depicted as a snarling demagogue in France, equated with Donald Duck in Spain, and described as worse than Lord Voldemort in Britain.

headline: See That Billboard? It May See You, Too
keywords: ['Smartphones', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing', 'Outdoor Advertising', 'Privacy', 'Cellular Telephones', 'Consumer Behavior']

lead_paragraph: Pass a billboard while driving in the next few months, and there is a good chance the company that owns it will know you were there and what you did afterward.

headline: Review: In ‘Pow,’ Keely Garfield Combines Tough and Awkward
abstract: This restless work, part of the Harkness Dance Festival, has intimate moments and includes renditions of Prince and Kate Bush songs.
lead_paragraph: After 30 years of making dances, Keely Garfield has found a way to wake herself up. The trigger was a Zen koan, a kind of riddle: “How is it when the tree withers and the leaves fall?” the student asks. The master replies, “Body exposed in the golden wind.”

headline: Lil Yachty, Lil Uzi Vert and Playboi Carti, Oddball Rap’s Children, at Play
abstract: Lil Yachty brought his meandering rhymes to Webster Hall’s Marlin Room; Lil Uzi Vert and Playboi Carti shared a bill at S.O.B.’s.
lead_paragraph: In the way that the Internet has scrambled pretty much everything, it has remade the textbook of oddball rap. For this generation, the tree of influence is short and irregularly shaped: Soulja Boy for self-started, Internet-driven fame; ASAP Rocky and the rest of the ASAP Mob for flamboyance and for eradicating regional loyalty; Chief Keef for the disassembly of traditional ideas about verse structure; Young Thug for radiant weirdness and genuine indifference.

headline: Review: Pacific Northwest Ballet Plays With Limits and Dystopia at City Center
abstract: Pacific Northwest Ballet delivered two New York premieres on Friday, David Dawson’s “A Million Kisses to My Skin” and Crystal Pite’s “Emergence.”
lead_paragraph: During intermission at City Center on Friday, some fragments of distressed conversation floated my way. “Where’s the danger?” one audience member asked another. After watching David Dawson’s “A Million Kisses to My Skin,” the first work on Pacific Northwest Ballet’s “Contemporary Innovators” program, I was wondering the same.

headline: Viceland, a New Cable Channel, Aims to Stand Out
abstract: Vice Media’s march toward world domination of news and lifestyle coverage for the 18-to-34 demographic now includes the shows “Noisey” and “Weediquette.”
lead_paragraph: Vice Media’s march toward world domination of news and lifestyle coverage for the 18-to-34 demographic continues at 6 a.m. Monday with the introduction of Viceland, a new cable channel inhabiting the slot formerly occupied by H2 (in the 70 million homes where H2 had a slot). It further expands Vice’s already-substantial efforts in video programming, joining the company’s highly popular online library and a documentary series, “Vice,” on HBO.

headline: Finding Beauty in Georg Friedrich Haas’s Darkness
abstract: The Talea Ensemble and the JACK Quartet performed works by this composer, who has been in the news recently because of his personal life.
lead_paragraph: Was that a frisson of tension that ran through the audience at the start of Friday’s concert at the Bohemian National Hall when the composer Georg Friedrich Haas took the microphone and said he had an “uncomfortable announcement” to make? After all, Mr. Haas had jolted some readers earlier that week when he spoke openly to The New York Times about “devilish desires,” his interest in playing with pain and the happiness he has found in his fourth marriage, which is based on a dominant-submissive power exchange.

headline: Obama’s Tangled History With Supreme Court Sets Stage for Nominee Fight

The president, a onetime constitutional law teacher, was in his element, a “legal nerd,” as one aide called him, putting theory into practice.

headline: ‘Vinyl’ Season 1, Episode 3: Rock Star Karaoke
abstract: When “Vinyl” incorporates historical figures into its world, they often seem slightly off.
lead_paragraph: “Vinyl” isn’t the first TV show to fill out its cast of characters with a parade of real-life music stars from the past: “American Dreams,” for example, which ran on NBC from 2002 to 2005, was centered on the 1960s era of Dick Clark’s music program “American Bandstand,” and included modern singers impersonating older ones (John Legend as Stevie Wonder, Usher as Marvin Gaye, Jennifer Love Hewitt as Nancy Sinatra). When a show pulls off this stunt, it can bring the past and the present into a dialogue — when it fails, it can feel like one long Halloween episode. “Vinyl” hasn’t carved any pumpkins yet, but I worry that the show has a jumbo bag of fun-size Nestle Crunch stashed in the pantry.

Its students in third through eighth grades scored in only the 14th percentile in reading on national achievement tests last year and in the eighth percentile in math.

headline: Fears About Water Supply Grip Village That Made Teflon Products
abstract: The discovery of a toxic chemical in the Hoosick Falls, N.Y., water supply has alarmed residents, some of whom are critical of officials’ response.
lead_paragraph: HOOSICK FALLS, N.Y. — One resident called 911 asking whether the village’s water would burn his skin off. Families have lined up to have their blood drawn and their wells tested. Banks stopped giving out mortgages, and some local residents stopped washing their dishes, their clothes and themselves. Erin Brockovich has been to town.

keywords: ['Relocation of Business', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Rock Music', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)']

lead_paragraph: At Trash and Vaudeville, the rock ’n’ roll clothing store in the East Village, punk rock music played as usual. Fliers for defunct bands peeled off the wall. Shoppers ambled through the cavernous space, plucking leather jackets from pipe racks.

headline: Hillary Clinton Gets Help From Bill, in Spirit, at Least
abstract: In the final event in the South before the string of contests on Super Tuesday, Mrs. Clinton referenced her husband, Bill Clinton, by his first name only, in his home state, repeatedly.
lead_paragraph: PINE BLUFF, Ark.— It was Hillary Clinton’s final event in the South before the string of contests on Super Tuesday that could set her on a surer path to the Democratic presidential nomination. But there was someone else on stage helping her here on Sunday night, in spirit, at least.

headline: Cuomo-de Blasio Feud Threatens New York City’s Plans for Affordable Housing
abstract: Developers predict projects could be choked off by the rivalry between the mayor and governor, who has outlined a bigger state role in affordable housing.
lead_paragraph: For most of the last two decades, financing affordable housing in New York City has been a predictable process, instrumental in adding tens of thousands of apartments for lower-income households in a city where rents continue to soar out of reach for more people every year.

headline: Once Upon a Greek Island, Migrants and Tourists
abstract: Lesbos is a popular vacation destination, but when migrants began streaming there, Marieke van der Velden and her partner, Philip Brink, paired them with tourists for conversations about their journeys.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine enjoying a holiday getaway in an area rife with suffering. But it happens all the time, and not just in the developing world where verdant, gated resorts exist not far from impoverished shantytowns. Consider the Greek island of Lesbos, where sunbathers laze by azure waters while not too far away boats arrive daily full of families fleeing violence in Syria and other hot spots.

headline: Planet on the Ballot
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Carbon Caps and Emissions Trading Programs', 'United States Economy', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: It appears that the goal of drastically reducing emissions is within reach, but the wrong leader could still get in the way of saving the planet.
lead_paragraph: We now have a pretty good idea who will be on the ballot in November: Hillary Clinton, almost surely (after the South Carolina blowout, prediction markets give her a 96 percent probability of securing her party’s nomination), and Donald Trump, with high likelihood (currently 80 percent probability on the markets). But even if there’s a stunning upset in what’s left of the primaries, we already know very well what will be at stake — namely, the fate of the planet.

headline: H.I.V.’s Toll on Black and Latino Men
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome']
abstract: Infection rates can be curbed even among these disproportionately affected groups.
lead_paragraph: There is encouraging news in the fight against H.I.V in the United States: Over all, fewer people are contracting the virus, which causes AIDS. But H.I.V. continues to take a devastating toll on men who have sex with men, particularly among African-Americans and Latinos. If current rates persist, one in every six men who has sex with men will become infected with H.I.V., the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said last week in its first lifetime risk analysis. One out of every two black men and one out of every four Latino men in this segment of the population is projected to become infected.

headline: Reducing Funding for the Humanities
abstract: Readers say a good education embraces both the sciences and the liberal arts. “Learning and studying the humanities is what makes us human,” one writes.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: ‘I’m Not a Super Predator’
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Crime and Criminals', 'Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Youth']
abstract: A graduate student’s bold confrontation of Hillary Clinton raised an issue that needed to be raised.
lead_paragraph: Days before Hillary Clinton thundered to an overwhelming victory over rival Bernie Sanders in South Carolina — largely on the strength of black voters who supported her by an even higher percentage than they supported Barack Obama with in 2008 — a young, proudly queer, black activist, Ashley Williams, was in Charlotte, N.C., plotting an action that would make a statement of its own.

headline: From ‘Je Suis Charlie’ to Attacks on Free Speech
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Terrorism', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression']
abstract: Laws intended to combat terrorism in Western nations too often restrict the very freedoms that terrorists wish to curtail.
lead_paragraph: After the murderous attack on the offices of the satirical French magazine Charlie Hebdo in January 2015, “Je suis Charlie” became a rallying cry in France and across much of Europe in support of free speech and freedom of expression. It is a sad and depressing sequel to that display of solidarity that so many European nations seem willing today to curtail those same freedoms in the name of fighting terrorism.

headline: Clinton, Sanders and the Fight Over Obama’s Legacy
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: A call for ‘revolution’ can read as a rebuke of the president.
lead_paragraph: Picture a largely unknown, black first-term senator with a surname that rhymes with “Osama,” who spent part of his childhood living in a Muslim country, crisscrossing the country calling for “revolution,” perhaps with a guy called Killer Mike in tow. Now imagine that person becoming president of the United States.

headline: The Broken System of Classifying Government Documents
keywords: ['Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: The case of Hillary Clinton’s emails shows we need a saner policy about marking information secret.
lead_paragraph: EVERY few years, a news event demonstrates how dysfunctional, arbitrary and counterproductive the country’s system of classifying information really is. Sometimes it’s an article or book about government conduct that causes hand-wringing among intelligence officials. Sometimes it’s a prosecution under the nearly 100-year-old Espionage Act for mishandling classified information, instead of for actual spying. Now we have calls for prosecuting Hillary Clinton because, when she was secretary of state, she had documents on her private email server that have since been declared top secret.

headline: A Better, Not Bigger, Military Budget
keywords: ['Editorials', 'Federal Budget (US)', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Giving the Pentagon a blank check does not ensure security.
lead_paragraph: Given recent history, the next president can expect to face an even more unpredictable world than the one President Obama is dealing with. Russia, China, Syria, Iran, North Korea, the Islamic State — the list of security challenges is daunting. It will require smart policy choices backed by a powerful military to protect American interests.

headline: A Conversation With Latinos on Race

lead_paragraph: In this short documentary, Latinos grapple with defining their ethnic and racial identities.

headline: ‘A Conversation With Latinos on Race’
abstract: In this short documentary, Latinos grapple with defining their ethnic and racial identities.
lead_paragraph: Last year we set out to make a series of short documentaries that we hoped would foster a discussion about race relations in the United States. To date the series has focused on the personal nuances of systemic racism as reflected in the relationship between blacks and whites. And while that dynamic is a significant part of the American story of race, it does not fully reflect the country’s varied history and rapidly changing demographics. So for our next installment of our “Conversation on Race” series, we decided to go broader, and hear from Latinos on their experiences here.

headline: Student Question | Should Displays of Art Be Welcome in All Public Spaces?
abstract: What qualities make a public space appropriate for displays of art?
lead_paragraph: Many public spaces such as parks are home to art such as sculpture or site-specific installations. Finding a way to bring art appreciation to the “drudgery” of commuting, for example, is behind a collaboration presented in a German subway. There are even degree programs in social practice devoted to creating and presenting communal art.

headline: Eyes on Kennedy, Women Tell Supreme Court Why Abortion Was Right for Them
abstract: Hoping to humanize their decisions, more than 100 women filed briefs directed largely at Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who holds the crucial vote in an abortion case to be argued Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Amy Brenneman, an actress, wants Justice Anthony M. Kennedy to know about the abortion she had when she was a 21-year-old college junior.

headline: As Detroit Starts to Mend, Its Schools Lurch Toward Fiscal Crisis
abstract: Battered by declining enrollment and large debts, the system could run out of money by April and may be forced to default or declare bankruptcy.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Since this city emerged from bankruptcy at the end of 2014, it has eked out a tentative recovery, tearing down thousands of abandoned houses, restoring streetlights and luring new businesses.

headline: Identidad y Raza: Una Conversación Entre Latinos
abstract: En este breve documental, los latinos tratan de definir su identidad étnica y racial.
lead_paragraph: El año pasado nos propusimos hacer una serie de documentales cortos con la esperanza de fomentar una discusión acerca de las relaciones raciales en los Estados Unidos. Hasta la fecha, la serie se ha enfocado en los pormenores personales del racismo sistemático que se refleja en las relaciones entre personas blancas y negras. Mientras que esa dinámica es una parte significativa de la historia racial estadounidense, no refleja del todo la diversidad histórica y la configuración cambiante de nuestra nación. Así que para nuestra siguiente entrega de la serie “Conversaciones en torno a la raza”, decidimos ir más allá y escuchar las experiencias de los latinos de este país.

headline: E.L.L. Practice + Prompt | The Life of a Refugee

lead_paragraph: Note: We invite any English Language Learner student 13 years or older to post comments in response to the writing prompts in this post.

headline: ‘The Civil Wars of Julia Ward Howe,’ by Elaine Showalter
abstract: In a riveting new biography, Elaine Showalter argues that Julia Ward Howe was much more than the writer of the lyrics to the “Battle Hymn of the Republic.”
lead_paragraph: “It needed a very serene or a very powerful mind to resist the temptation to anger,” Virginia Woolf wrote in 1929 in an essay about 19th-century women writers. A woman might start out writing about one thing or another but, before she knew it, she’d find herself “resenting the treatment of her sex and pleading for its rights.” This was a pity, Woolf thought, and a trap she hoped women were on the verge of escaping.

headline: ‘Constance Fenimore Woolson’ and ‘Miss Grief and Other Stories’
abstract: A new biography resurrects Constance Fenimore Woolson as a pioneering author who chose a literary career over marriage and motherhood, and another new book collects her stories.
lead_paragraph: If the American writer Constance Fenimore Woolson is remembered at all, it’s mostly for her dresses. And these weren’t just any ­dresses. These were the dark silk ones that, after her sudden death, Henry James presumably tried to drown in a Venetian lagoon, hurling them from his gondola and jabbing them with a pole to keep them from rising. But he failed, and to Woolson’s admirers his failure is symbolic: You can’t keep this good writer down.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Feb. 29, 2016
abstract: On Mondays, we publish a Times photo without a caption, headline or other information about its origins. Join the conversation by commenting on what you see and why. A live discussion is offered that day from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m. Eastern.
lead_paragraph: Updated: March 4, 2016

headline: Trump’s Il Duce Routine
abstract: Europe knows that democracies can collapse. It watches Trump with memories of when the sky darkened.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Europe, the soil on which Fascism took root, is watching the rise of Donald Trump with dismay. Contempt for the excesses of America is a European reflex, but when the United States seems tempted by a latter-day Mussolini, smugness in London, Paris and Berlin gives way to alarm. Europe knows that democracies can collapse.

headline: Justices to Announce Appeals They Will Hear Without Antonin Scalia
abstract: On Monday morning, the Supreme Court will announce which appeals it will hear, the result of a meeting they held on Friday, the first such meeting since Justice Antonin Scalia’s death.
lead_paragraph: Most Fridays during the Supreme Court term, the justices gather in a private conference to decide which appeals they will hear. The odds have always been long: About one in 100 requests for review are granted. With Justice Antonin Scalia’s death, the odds just got longer.

headline: Violence Erupts in Greece as Migrants Try to Cross Into Macedonia
keywords: ['Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Refugees and Displaced Persons']
abstract: Less than a week after a meeting to discuss stemming the flow of people toward Germany, thousands were stuck in Greece after the Macedonian authorities sealed the border.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — It was a scene of a type that could become all too common in coming months: Thousands of increasingly desperate people backed up at the frontier between Greece and Macedonia on Monday, stymied in their efforts to reach Germany. A group of angry asylum seekers busted through a razor-wire fence. Armed police officers fired tear gas as frenzied crowds chanted, “Open the border!”

abstract: A single paragraph in the sweeping legislation could shield the company from costly liability for making the now-banned chemicals known as PCBs.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing hundreds of millions of dollars in lawsuits, the giant biotechnology company Monsanto last year received a legislative gift from the House of Representatives, a one-paragraph addition to a sweeping chemical safety bill that could help shield it from legal liability for a toxic chemical only it made.

headline: Hong Kong Bookseller Confesses on TV to Evading Rules on Shipping to Mainland
keywords: ['Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Ships and Shipping']
abstract: Gui Minhai was shown on Sunday night saying that he had circumvented China’s strict rules on importing books, in part by placing shipments in bags that could not be X-rayed.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A co-owner of a Hong Kong publishing house who disappeared from his home in Thailand only to emerge in police custody in China has given a televised confession, saying that his company circumvented customs regulations to ship politically sensitive books from Hong Kong to the mainland.

headline: Arthur Arbesser: Fall 2016 RTW

headline: CNN Poll Points to a Donald Trump-Hillary Clinton Matchup in November
keywords: ['Polls and Public Opinion', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses']
abstract: While only four states have held primary contests so far, most Republicans and Democrats expect Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton to face off in the general election. Of likely voters in both parties, 70 percent predict that they will get the nominations of their parties.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and Hillary Clinton are racing toward a general election matchup, according to a new poll that shows the presidential candidates with dominant national leads atop their parties.

headline: Once I Saw Light in Iran. Now It’s Mostly Shadows.
abstract: What has really changed from the 2001 elections to today?
lead_paragraph: I REMEMBER vividly the first time I ever voted in an Iranian election. It was a balmy summer day in June 2001, in the election that won the reformist president Mohammad Khatami a second term. The blue stamp was the first on the voting page of my identification card, and I felt a sharp, exhilarating pride.

headline: Democrats, Looking to South, Face Balance Between Core and Younger Voters
abstract: While demographics seem to be changing in their favor, attracting a growing population of younger, urban white voters may help the party become competitive more quickly.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — For years, voting as a Deep South Democrat in a presidential general election has been like shouting at the television set: It may feel good, but it will not make much of a difference.

headline: Japan Indicts 3 Former Executives Over Fukushima Nuclear Disaster
keywords: ['Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (Japan)', 'Japan Earthquake and Tsunami (2011)', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: The indictments were the first stemming from the event, which spread radiation across a wide area in the country’s northeast and led to evacuations that left more than 100,000 homeless.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japanese prosecutors indicted three former executives of the Tokyo Electric Power Company, the owner of the ruined Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, on Monday, charging them with criminal negligence for their role in reactor meltdowns after an earthquake and tsunami five years ago.

headline: Icahn Makes Bid for Federal-Mogul, an Auto-Parts Supplier

lead_paragraph: Two months after winning a bidding war for the car-parts retailer Pep Boys, Carl C. Icahn has his sights on acquiring another company in the auto industry: the Federal-Mogul Holdings Corporation.

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Mahathir Mohamad, who long dominated Malaysian politics as prime minister and leader of its governing party, said on Monday that he was quitting the organization because he was embarrassed by its role in protecting Prime Minister Najib Razak from accusations of corruption.

keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'Polls and Public Opinion']

headline: Daughter of Abe Vigoda Is Upset About Oscars ‘Memoriam’ Snub
abstract: The Academy said it was “unfortunately unable to feature” the actor, who died at 94 earlier this year, but did list him on its website.
lead_paragraph: The daughter of Abe Vigoda, the sad-face actor who died last month at 94 and was known for his roles in “The Godfather” and the television show “Barney Miller,” said on Monday it was wrong for her father to have been left out of the “In Memoriam” segment of the Academy Awards on Sunday night.

headline: Woman Waving Child’s Severed Head Is Arrested in Moscow
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Mental Health and Disorders']
abstract: Witnesses said a woman waved the severed head of a small child outside a Moscow subway station on Monday.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A visibly disturbed woman was arrested on Monday after witnesses said they saw her waving the severed head of a small child outside a Moscow subway station. A Russian television network, REN TV, posted images from video that appeared to show the woman dressed in black and shouting incoherently. The Interfax news agency identified her as Gulchekhra Bobokulova, 38, a native of Uzbekistan, and said she was the child’s nanny. The child’s body was found near the subway station in an apartment that had been set on fire, the news agency said. Investigators issued a statement saying the woman had been charged with killing the child, who was 3 or 4, and that she appeared to be mentally unstable.

headline: Deepwater Horizon and Dewey & Leboeuf Cases Share Challenges
abstract: Both cases highlight just how hard it is to convict those involved in complex corporate decisions where there is diffuse responsibility.
lead_paragraph: The explosion of the Deepwater Horizon drilling rig in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010 and the demise of venerable New York law firm Dewey & Leboeuf in 2012 could not be more different. One causing widespread pollution along with 11 deaths, while the other involved questionable accounting to keep the firm afloat as it struggled to deal with a changing marketplace.

headline: Bernie Sanders Collects $36 Million in February as Fund-Raising Successes Continue
abstract: The amount — a huge sum for a candidate who has virtually no donors giving the largest contributions legally permitted — suggests that Senator Bernie Sanders successfully capitalized on his close finish in the Iowa caucuses behind Hillary Clinton and his victory in the New Hampshire primary.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont raised more than $36 million in February and was hoping to hit the $40 million mark by the end of the day on Monday, his campaign announced.

headline: Souq, Online Retailer in Middle East, Gets a $275 Million Boost
abstract: The company, based in the United Arab Emirates, is a rare e-commerce success story in a region that has been hit by logistical, political and economic hurdles.
lead_paragraph: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates — Souq.com, an online retailer based in the United Arab Emirates, said on Monday that it had raised $275 million from international investors. It was a vote of confidence for digital commerce in the Middle East, which has made little headway compared with elsewhere.

headline: Beyond the Red Carpet, at Giorgio Armani and Missoni

lead_paragraph: MILAN — It was probably always going to be anticlimactic. Stuck between the Oscars (rock) and Super Tuesday (hard place), not to mention the news that the unthinkable was happening and Starbucks was coming to Italy, there wasn’t much the final Milanese shows could do to claim people’s attention.

headline: 1916: Kaiser’s Goal Is Verdun
abstract: From the International Herald Tribune archives: German newspaper reports that the Kaiser’s goal is Verdun in 1916.
lead_paragraph: Despite the instructions which have been issued to the German press to diminish the importance of the attack upon Verdun and even to deny that the capture of this stronghold has been the German high command’s objective; despite also the semi-official statement published in the ‘‘Norddeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung’’ that the ‘‘object of the attack has been attained’’ and that ‘‘the present attack is not of exceptional importance’’; the Kaiser has just admitted in a telegram that his hopes, now doomed to disappointment, were centred in the capture of Verdun. — The New York Herald, European Edition, March 1, 1916

headline: Make a Plan on How to Handle Risk, Then Stick to It
abstract: Many investors plan in advance on how they will handle risk, but when they face the real thing they tend to react differently.
lead_paragraph: I ski the backcountry a lot, so I pay close attention to reports of avalanches. In particular, I pay attention when a skier is caught and killed by one. This year alone there have been 20 avalanche fatalities in the United States. In January, there were nine fatalities in nine days.

lead_paragraph: Argentina has agreed to pay $4.65 billion to four hedge funds in a deal that could put an end to more than a decade of mudslinging and legal attacks that had cut the country off from global financial markets.

lead_paragraph: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

headline: The Pocket Watch, a Gentleman’s Best Friend
abstract: Baume & Mercier’s men’s watch tells time in the dark — 18th-century style.
lead_paragraph: In the early 18th century, when a handmade pocket watch was the ultimate luxury for a gentleman, master clockmakers engineered one that could tell time at night, even after the candles had been extinguished. With the touch of a button, the divinely complex mechanism would chime a mellifluous pattern counting off the hour, and then, in increments of five, the minutes. Baume & Mercier’s new Clifton 1830 pocket watch is an updated version of that marvel, showcasing the five-minute repeater, a ‘‘complication’’ long vaunted by aficionados. The Swiss house has made just 30, set in 18-karat red gold. It makes telling time by the glaring face of a smartphone seem strangely passé.

headline: Oscar Ratings Fell, but All Eyes Are on the Academy
abstract: After several years of climbing ratings, the genre of awards shows has been showing signs of viewer fatigue.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences survived, just barely, Sunday’s tumultuous Oscar telecast. Overall ratings tumbled to near record lows but did not completely implode, as some movie executives had feared.

headline: At Giorgio Armani, the Romantic Side of Fall
abstract: Hair and beauty at the show today was kept soft — to match the collection’s floral motifs.
lead_paragraph: When he first envisioned the beauty look for his flower-filled fall collection, Giorgio Armani drew a woman with an upswept pouf of hair and handed the sketch to the Aldo Coppola hairstylist Roberta Bellazzi. To create the look, she loaded hair with product: Elnett spray, mousse, and — she admitted sheepishly — sugar water, which turned out to be the key ingredient for what she called a “cotton candy effect.” The back of the head was pulled into a tight, upswept twist and held in place with copious amounts of micro bobby pins, while on top, hair was shaped into spirals with a curling iron and sculpted into its final fluffy form, delicately falling to one side of models’ faces.

abstract: The prime minister’s pledge to revitalize the economy and create a deluge of jobs has become subsumed in political turmoil.
lead_paragraph: MUMBAI, India — A flash fire sent the star-studded audience at Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s “Make in India” convention fleeing into Mumbai’s streets last month. But that was minor compared with the political firestorm caused by his government’s arrest that same weekend of a student leader accused of participating in a university rally in support of a man put to death for a terrorist attack in India years ago.

lead_paragraph: This week’s puzzle was suggested by Fred Gluck, a math educator who works mainly with grade-school children. I really enjoy Fred’s challenge because there’s more than one way to crack it. How many can we come up with? Let’s find out by trying on —

headline: ‘Fight the Power’ Roars Back to Relevance at the Oscars
abstract: Public Enemy’s anti-establishment anthem proved its timeless quality in serving as a kind of theme music for Chris Rock’s criticism of Hollywood on its biggest night.
lead_paragraph: As Chris Rock strolled onto the Dolby Theater stage Sunday night and prepared to lay waste to the Academy Awards, there was a hint of what was to come in the music playing in the background: Public Enemy’s “Fight the Power.”

headline: On New York’s Bustling Streets, a Soccer Megastar Roams Freely
abstract: Andrea Pirlo may be one of Manhattan’s most famous faces — if you can pick him out of a crowd.
lead_paragraph: To many people around the world, Andrea Pirlo is a god. As a soccer player for some of the planet’s biggest clubs, he has two Champions League trophies and six league titles. In 2006, he won the World Cup with Italy, where he has three times been player of the year, and where his nicknames include ‘‘Mozart’’ and ‘‘The Professor.’’ His 2013 autobiography, ‘‘I Think Therefore I Play,’’ was a best seller in Italy. There are social media accounts devoted entirely to his beard. A quick Google search of his name returns results like ‘‘37 Reasons Why Andrea Pirlo Is the World’s Greatest Living Human Man.’’ He has met two popes.

headline: Antico Noè Panini From Florence Now Sold in New York
abstract: Also, a Vermont cheesemaker is selling pork; a new whiskey from South Africa; a large griddle from Colombia; and more.
lead_paragraph: The logo and the name of the panini shop Antico Noè, off Piazza San Pier Maggiore in Florence, Italy, came from an old mirror on the wall. It advertised an Italian vermouth, Antico Noè. Michael Grant and Vinny Dautaj, who lived in Florence and became devotees of the 71-year-old shop, have opened a New York branch with the blessing of the original’s owners. They offer 10 of the shop’s 25 panini, made on sub-style breads, white and seven grain, pressed and crisped in a press. “Finding someone to bake the bread was not easy,” Mr. Grant said. “It has very little salt and is light enough to press flat”: Antico Noè, 220 East 53rd Street, 212-750-0802, anticonoe.com.

headline: For Bronson Arroyo, a Comeback at 39 Would Be Pure Gravy
abstract: Arroyo, who has not pitched since June 2014, before Tommy John surgery, hopes to make the Nationals, but regardless, he has eclipsed his career goals.
lead_paragraph: VIERA, Fla. — Bronson Arroyo dresses next to Lucas Giolito in the Washington Nationals’ clubhouse at spring training. Both pitchers are tall right-handers, but that is where the similarities end. Giolito was born in 1994, in the summer before Arroyo’s senior year in high school. He has not yet pitched in the major leagues. Arroyo has logged 15 seasons.

headline: Partisan Classiness
abstract: Marx, class, and The Donald.
lead_paragraph: Many people in the commentariat are utterly committed to the view that the two major parties are mirror images of each other, despite vast evidence to the contrary. But until Harry Enten directed me to this interesting paper by Grossman and Hopkins, I hadn’t really registered the extent to which the same assumption of symmetry is often made by political scientists. What Grossman and Hopkins do is try to document the very real differences in the two parties’ structure — not in terms of value judgments, but in terms of how they work:

headline: Clubbed Thumb’s Summerworks Festival Announces Lineup

Julia Jarcho, Ethan Lipton and Eric Dufault will join an impressive list of playwrights who have worked with this festival, which emphasizes the discovery and showcasing of rising writers.

headline: In Zimbabwe, Mugabe’s Birthday Is Rife With Political Jockeying

lead_paragraph: MASVINGO, Zimbabwe — The lavish annual birthday parties for President Robert G. Mugabe of Zimbabwe, who has been in power since the country gained independence in 1980, have been a stage from which he has swatted away challengers and secured his larger-than-life hold on his nation.

headline: Three’s a Trend: Vibrant Graphic Prints
abstract: Emilio Pucci, Marni and Salvatore Ferragamo featured zigzags of every color and stripe.
lead_paragraph: Despite rain in Milan this week, bright, kaleidoscopic patterns have dominated the runways. Massimo Giorgetti’s second outing for Emilio Pucci (left) offered a colorful collection that took cues from ski wear, including this boxy jacket and pencil skirt in blue and yellow stripes. Marni (center), another brand fond of graphic motifs, showed a knee-length tunic in a pattern that recalled abstract art. And at Salvatore Ferragamo (right), Massimiliano Giornetti presented a vibrant, zigzag cape and skirt that were just as colorful as the runway.

headline: How to Pick a Wine Store
abstract: The best way to drink better bottles is to cultivate a relationship with a good shop.
lead_paragraph: If you care about wine and want to drink better and more confidently, the best thing you can do is cultivate a close relationship with a good wine shop. I have been making this case for years without ever addressing the obvious question: How do you know if a wine shop is good?

abstract: Fred Kaplan tackles a subject that, as the current controversy over Apple’s standoff with the Justice Department confirms, attracts fierce partisans.
lead_paragraph: Fred Kaplan has written a consistently eye-opening history of our government’s efforts to effectively manage our national security in the face of the largely open global communications network established by the World Wide Web.

headline: Derek Hough to Play Gene Kelly Role in ‘Singin’ in the Rain’ on Broadway
abstract: The two-time Emmy winner will make a splash on Broadway next January as the lead in the Théâtre du Châtelet’s production.
lead_paragraph: Derek Hough will make a splash on Broadway next January: He has been cast as the lead in the Théâtre du Châtelet’s production of “Singin’ in the Rain.” Mr. Hough, a two-time Emmy winner (for “Dancing with the Stars”), has stage experience from the 2006 West End production of “Footloose.” Here, he’ll step into the role of Don Lockwood, which Gene Kelly made famous in the 1952 film.

headline: In ‘Half Earth,’ E.O. Wilson Calls for a Grand Retreat
keywords: ['Biodiversity', 'Conservation of Resources', 'Books and Literature', 'Wildlife Sanctuaries and Nature Reserves']
abstract: In a new book, the renowned biologist argues that it is time for humans to abandon much of the planet to other species.
lead_paragraph: This week, the biologist Edward O. Wilson, professor emeritus at Harvard University and recipient of two Pulitzer Prizes, will publish his 32nd book, a personal exhortation to conserve biodiversity titled “Half Earth: Our Planet’s Fight for Life.”

headline: Free the Tampons
abstract: A growing number of advocates are talking about menstruation publicly, and calling for free tampons in every public restroom.
lead_paragraph: Call it the period paradox. Everyone knows most girls and women menstruate, but even in the age of oversharing, periods are treated like a dirty little secret.

headline: By Disclosing Tax Data, Rivals Pressure Donald Trump to Do the Same
abstract: Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz made public details of their taxes, hoping to strike a comparison with Donald J. Trump, who has said he cannot release tax forms yet because of continuing I.R.S. audits.
lead_paragraph: Putting heft behind their calls for Donald J. Trump to release his income tax filings, Marco Rubio and Ted Cruz have now made public some details of their own taxes.

headline: Woman, 77, Fatally Struck by Livery Cab in Midtown
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Car Services and Livery Cabs', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Carol Dauplaise, a jewelry designer who was crossing the street at Madison Avenue and 36th Street, was the fourth pedestrian killed by a motor vehicle in New York City in the past three days.
lead_paragraph: Carol Dauplaise was crossing Madison Avenue at 36th Street just after 8:30 a.m. on Monday, a few blocks from her apartment and the costume jewelry company that she started more than 35 years ago, when a black livery cab turned and struck her, pinning her under the car.

headline: Another Trip Cut Short on Anthem of the Seas
abstract: The Royal Caribbean ship again sailed to port early because of weather, the second time in a month a cruise ended prematurely.
lead_paragraph: It happened again: Less than a month after Royal Caribbean’s Anthem of the Seas vessel returned earlier than scheduled to its port of origin in Cape Liberty, N.J.,  after facing 120 m.p.h. winds off Cape Hatteras, N.C., the ship ended another cruise early in anticipation of a severe storm expected in the same location.

headline: Donald Trump Carries Big Leads in Alabama and Oklahoma, Polls Show
abstract: Mr. Trump has a comfortable lead in Alabama and a smaller one in Oklahoma, two of the 12 states holding nominating contests on Tuesday, according to a polls that show him with strong support from evangelicals.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump is in position to sweep to victories in the Alabama and Oklahoma primaries on Tuesday, according to a new polls that show strong support from evangelical Christians potentially helping him win a big haul of delegates.

headline: Curtis Granderson’s Eye Malady Underscores Mets’ Outfield Depth
abstract: The Mets, who signed Alejandro De Aza in the off-season, worried Granderson might have pinkeye and sent him away, which served as a reminder they have options should an injury occur.
lead_paragraph: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — When Curtis Granderson arrived at the Mets’ complex Monday morning, he was wearing glasses because he was worried about redness around his eye. The Mets worried it might be pinkeye, and given how contagious that can be, they sent him away and asked him to skip his normal drills for the day.

headline: Green-Wood Cemetery Luminaries
abstract: Leonard Bernstein and Boss Tweed are among the famous and infamous buried at a Brooklyn cemetery recognized by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: A preservationist mourned an important building of the Harlem Renaissance and other sites that he said would surely have been preserved in another neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: It is hard to go almost anywhere in Harlem with Michael Henry Adams, at least not in a hurry.

headline: ‘Female Viagra’ Only Modestly Increases Sexual Satisfaction, Study Finds
abstract: Half of one satisfying sexual encounter a month: That is the average benefit a woman gets from the new female libido drug, researchers said on Monday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Half of one satisfying sexual encounter a month. That is the average benefit a woman gets when she takes the new female libido drug, sometimes called the “female Viagra,” researchers reported Monday.

abstract: The Governors Ball and other post-Oscars events were upbeat affairs even for contenders who didn’t take home trophies.
lead_paragraph: Everyone loves an underdog story, especially a surprise one, and ripples of delight over “Spotlight’s” win for best picture spread out from the Dolby Theater on Sunday night into the after-party beyond.

headline: A Men’s Store for the Everyguy
abstract: The proprietor of Palmer Trading Company, Willy Chavarria, talks about how he arrived at his no-frills sense of style.
lead_paragraph: Willy Chavarria, 48, the tattooed owner of Palmer Trading Company, at 137 Sullivan Street in Manhattan, set up shop in 2010. “When we started, it was all vintage,” Mr. Chavarria said.

headline: France Faces Protests as It Dismantles ‘Jungle’ Migrant Camp
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis', 'Evictions', 'Police']
abstract: Some migrants lit shacks on fire to protest their evictions as workers tore down tents and disassembled huts at the camp near Calais.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French authorities faced angry protesters on Monday as they began to dismantle part of a vast migrant camp near the northern city of Calais after a court order last week that at least partially allowed the government to move forward with its plans to vacate the settlement, known as “the Jungle.”

headline: A Decade Later, Clarence Thomas Speaks Again
abstract: On Monday, Justice Clarence Thomas asked his first question during oral arguments in ten years. Why now?
lead_paragraph: Ten years and one week after it began without warning or explanation, Justice Clarence Thomas’s unofficial vow of silence has ended.

headline: Argentina’s Debt Settlement Ends 15-Year Battle
abstract: Four hedge funds refused to accept a steep discount in two restructurings over the years. Here’s a look at some crucial moments of the fight.
lead_paragraph: The announcement of a $4.65 billion agreement between the Argentine government and four “holdout” hedge funds promises to end a 15-year battle that started when the government defaulted on $100 billion in debt in 2001.

headline: Hillary Clinton Rallies Large Crowd in Boston Before the Primary
abstract: A buoyant Hillary Clinton plunged into the crowd here after a barnstorming speech on the eve of what she hopes will be a pivotal victory in Massachusetts, one of 11 states holding Democratic nominating contests on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — A buoyant Hillary Clinton plunged into the crowd here after a barnstorming speech, posing for selfies and shaking hands on the eve of what she hopes will be a pivotal victory in the 11 states, including Massachusetts, that hold Democratic nominating contests on Tuesday.

headline: Invasive Species Aren’t Always Unwanted
abstract: A growing number of scientists argue that not all non-native species are bad, and some may actually be beneficial.
lead_paragraph: Invasive species are bad news, or so goes the conventional wisdom, encouraged by persistent warnings from biologists about the dangers of foreign animals and plants moving into new territories.

headline: Does This Species Belong Here?
abstract: Many common animals, plants and insects are not native to the environments in which they are now found. Take this quiz and learn more about the living things that surround you.
lead_paragraph: Many common animals, plants and insects are not native to the environments in which they are now found. Take this quiz and learn more about the living things that surround you.

headline: The Birth of Postwar Italian Style
abstract: A museum exhibition in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., showcases the country’s fashion during a period when a distinctive design sensibility emerged.
lead_paragraph: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — Bonnie Clearwater cast a covetous eye on a pair of wool coats. “I’d love to own one,” she said. “Wear it and you won’t end up looking like a box.”

headline: Parents of American Held in North Korea Unable to Speak With Him
abstract: In their first comment on the arrest, the parents of Otto F. Warmbier said they hoped North Korea would free him after he admitted stealing a political banner.
lead_paragraph: The parents of an American college student who tearfully apologized on North Korean state television on Monday for having plotted to steal a political banner said they had been unable to speak with their son since the North Korean police seized him two months ago.

lead_paragraph: American women are having their first babies at increasingly older ages.

lead_paragraph: A financial adviser who was recently highlighted in an article in The New York Times as the only Goldman Sachs employee to contribute to Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign has been placed on administrative leave, according to people familiar with the matter.

headline: Bernie Sanders Tells Minnesotans They Can ‘Make History’
abstract: On the eve of voting in 11 Democratic contests, Bernie Sanders told hundreds of supporters here that he was counting on them to defeat Hillary Clinton and start a political revolution.
lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — On the eve of voting in 11 Democratic contests, Bernie Sanders told hundreds of supporters here on Monday that he was counting on them to defeat Hillary Clinton and start a political revolution.

headline: Sikh Soldier Sues Defense Dept., Citing Religious Discrimination
keywords: ['Sikhs and Sikhism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Beards and Mustaches', 'Discrimination', 'Freedom of Religion']
abstract: Capt. Simratpal Singh, a decorated West Point graduate, said the Army had singled him out for special tests because of his beard and turban.
lead_paragraph: A combat soldier who is Sikh sued the Defense Department on Monday, saying his beard and turban had made him the subject of religious discrimination because the Army was putting him through arduous helmet and gas mask testing that no other soldier goes through.

abstract: Since 2000, only five albums have spent 10 weeks at the top of the albums chart — and four of them are by Adele or Taylor Swift.

lead_paragraph: Amid generally positive reviews of his jabs at Hollywood and #OscarsSoWhite, the host of Sunday’s Oscar ceremony, Chris Rock, is being taken to task for some of his material involving Asian-Americans.

headline: Ad Tars John McCain’s Pledge to Back the Republican Nominee
abstract: Representative Ann Kirkpatrick, the Arizona Democratic who is challenging Senator John McCain, is offering a prime example of why Republicans should be worried that a Trump nomination would damage the party down the ballot in November.
lead_paragraph: If Republicans are worried about a Donald J. Trump presidential nomination damaging the party down the ballot in November, Representative Ann Kirkpatrick, the Arizona Democratic who is challenging Senator John McCain, is offering a prime example of why they should be.

headline: Eric Staal Opens His Rangers Career With a Victory
abstract: Staal, who agreed to join the Rangers not because of the presence of his brother Marc but because he could end a long personal playoff drought, won nine of 17 face-offs in a win over Columbus.
lead_paragraph: After Eric Staal told his family he had been traded to the Rangers, Levi Staal, who is 4 years old and is the second of Eric and Tanya Staal’s three sons, told Eric time after time that he did not want his father to move away. Eric assured Levi that he would not be leaving North Carolina without him.

headline: Catalog Interview With Gloria Steinem Has Lands’ End on Its Heels
abstract: The company apologized for the interview with Ms. Steinem that prompted criticism from parents at Christian schools and anti-abortion activists.
lead_paragraph: The retailer Lands’ End was scrambling to disentangle itself from the feminist icon Gloria Steinem after an interview printed in a recent catalog prompted criticism from parents at Christian schools and anti-abortion activists.

headline: Judge Grants Delay of Sodium Warnings for New York City Restaurants
abstract: The law, which would require chain restaurants to label high-sodium items, was to go into effect on Tuesday, but will be delayed while it remains under judicial review.
lead_paragraph: An appeals court on Monday ordered a temporary halt to New York City’s enforcement of a measure requiring some chain restaurants to post warnings on menu items with high levels of sodium.

headline: SEAL Who Wrestled Gunman and Shielded Hostage Is Awarded Medal of Honor
keywords: ['Medal of Honor (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001-14)', 'Kidnapping and Hostages']
abstract: At the White House, the president gave the highest military honor to Senior Chief Special Warfare Operator Edward Byers for bravery in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Edward C. Byers Jr., a senior chief special warfare operator, was the second Navy SEAL team member to enter a Taliban compound on a frigid night in December 2012, part of a mission to rescue an American doctor being held hostage in eastern Afghanistan. The first, Petty Officer First Class Nicolas Checque, was shot in the head after he burst through the door.

keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Bedbugs', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Social Media']
abstract: A survey found that a single recent review that mentions bedbugs lowers hotel room values by $38 for business travelers and $23 for leisure travelers.
lead_paragraph: The worst hotel experiences can be caused by an insect smaller than a fingernail clipping.

abstract: Readers discuss efforts to stop Donald Trump and bemoan the nature of some of the campaign attacks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: Dana Spiotta’s ‘Innocents and Others’ Explores the Dynamics Between Life and Art
abstract: Dana Spiotta’s novel features a heroine obsessed with the movies, and a collagelike structure that jump-cuts between her story and those of two others.
lead_paragraph: In her stunning 2001 debut novel, “Lightning Field,” Dana Spiotta wrote of her film-obsessed heroine Mina: “She sometimes thought that if someone saw all the movies she had seen, the number of times she had seen them and in the order she had seen them, that person might know exactly who she was.” It’s an observation that could serve as a keystone for every one of Ms. Spiotta’s strobe-lit novels — all of which concern the search for identity, and the mysterious dynamics between life and art.

headline: Milan Fashion Week: Salvatore Ferragamo and Missoni in Pictures
abstract: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Sunday.
lead_paragraph: A photo diary of the fall/winter 2016 collections that were presented Sunday.

headline: Oscars’ Best Dressed Men? Common, Eddie Redmayne and Jacob Tremblay
abstract: The guys have it easy on a night like this.
lead_paragraph: According to the tacit protocols of gala dressing, women, and not men, are meant to shine. Thus — whether by instinct or because that is what their Svengali stylists taught them — the best-dressed men at the 88th annual Academy Awards ceremony evinced faith in the simplicity of proper evening clothes, with the result that this was among the most stylish Oscars ceremonies in recent years.

headline: The Inseparable Sisters Bringing Bright, Graphic Designs to London
abstract: Nikita and Tina Sutradhar of the brand Miuniku discuss their latest collection, dubbed “The Explorer,” exclusively with T.
lead_paragraph: Interviewing Nikita and Tina Sutradhar feels less like a formal assignment and more like being welcomed into their family. The sisters, 25 and 27, trade off the retelling of childhood anecdotes, reminiscing about their local Mumbai bookshop in the ’90s that sold American Teen Vogue and watching Miss World as middle schoolers, enraptured by the parade of outfits. They describe how they crafted a dress from newspapers in their teens. “Our father came home and we showed it to him,” Tina says, “and he was like, ‘That’s it. You have to go to design school.’”

headline: Review: In the Met’s ‘Figaro,’ a Scene Stealer in Her Element
abstract: As the lusty page Cherubino, Isabel Leonard has plenty of opportunities to command the stage in Richard Eyre’s production.
lead_paragraph: Few operatic characters are better equipped to steal scenes than the adolescent page Cherubino in Mozart’s “Le Nozze di Figaro”: a young man ridden by hormones and given gorgeous arias pulsing with sensuality. That the role is allotted to a grown woman only increases the opportunities for sophisticated humor and low farce.

headline: Brandee Younger, a Harpist Finding Her Way to Jazz
abstract: Ms. Younger took a circuitous route through classical music to become a musician building on the achievements of Dorothy Ashby and Alice Coltrane.
lead_paragraph: Brandee Younger was a teenager — an aspiring classical harpist, growing up on Long Island — when she came across an eye-opening issue of Harp Column magazine. A trade bimonthly with a loyal constituency (motto: “practical news, for practical harpists”) had published a readers poll celebrating the instrument’s most influential figures of the 20th century.

headline: Anna Netrebko, a Towering Soprano, in Her New York Recital Debut
abstract: The vast Metropolitan Opera House isn’t suited to intimate songs. But Ms. Netrebko was in her element.
lead_paragraph: As she began Rachmaninoff’s “Lilacs” during her program of Russian songs at the Metropolitan Opera on Sunday afternoon, Anna Netrebko stepped away from her accompanist and walked to one side of the stage, where two enormous vases of flowers stood. Caressing some blossoms in her hands, she tenderly sang the lyrics, the thoughts of a sorrowful young woman comforted by the happiness that “lives in the lilacs.”

headline: Valeant Pharmaceuticals Is Under S.E.C. Investigation
abstract: The beleaguered drug maker, already under scrutiny for its steep price increases, earlier canceled its fourth-quarter earnings report.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International said on Monday that it was being investigated by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the latest turn of events for the Canadian drug maker, which has come under recent scrutiny for its sky-high drug prices and a once-secret relationship with a mail-order pharmacy.

headline: Eiko, Koma and Soloists Perform in Sacred Space
abstract: Eight dancers performed solos that explored the architecture of St. Mark’s Church as part of Danspace Project’s “Platform 2016: A Body in Places” series.
lead_paragraph: Even if you frequent St. Mark’s Church in the East Village, you’ve probably never been inside the Priest’s Room or walked around the second-floor balcony. You’ve passed the lion statue guarding the entrance, but have you ever really looked at it?

headline: City Ballet’s Season of Renewal
abstract: Dancers and choreographers asserted themselves and George Balanchine’s influence was obvious during the company’s winter season, and will continue to be.
lead_paragraph: Who is Miriam Miller? She became a member of the New York City Ballet corps only in January — so recently, in fact, that her brief biography on the company’s website has no photo attached. This is odd for two reasons. One: From the auditorium of the David H. Koch Theater, where the company finished its six-week winter season on Sunday, she appears to have the perfect, theatrically legible features of a model. Two: It’s been apparent since June that she’s going places.

headline: Apple Wins Ruling in New York iPhone Hacking Order
abstract: A federal judge denied the use of the All Writs Act, a law that federal authorities have cited in insisting on Apple’s help breaking into iPhones.
lead_paragraph: A federal magistrate judge on Monday denied the United States government’s request that Apple extract data from an iPhone in a drug case in New York, giving the company’s pro-privacy stance a boost as it battles law enforcement officials over opening up the device in other cases.

headline: George Pell, Aide to Pope, Is Put on Defensive in Abuse Inquiry
abstract: Cardinal Pell, chosen by Francis to spearhead Vatican financial reform, is testifying voluntarily before a Royal Commission looking into child sexual abuse.
lead_paragraph: ROME — When Pope Francis was chosen to lead the world’s 1.2 billion Catholics three years ago, he pledged to reform antiquated and troubled Vatican institutions.

lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — A crowd gathered here on Monday to denounce the killing of a black man shot earlier in the day after a foot chase with a police officer.

headline: Young Lawyers Ready to Argue a Major Abortion Case Before the Supreme Court
abstract: Two lawyers who will appear before the Supreme Court to argue Texas’ abortion restrictions are described by colleagues as masters of the law and unflappable under pressure.
lead_paragraph: Facing off before the Supreme Court on Wednesday, in what could be the most momentous abortion case in a quarter-century, will be two lawyers who are still in their thirties and are described by colleagues as whip-smart masters of the law and unflappable under pressure.

headline: Review Agency Faults New York Police Department on Unlawful Searches
keywords: ['Search and Seizure', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Cameras', 'Fourth Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: A report by the Civilian Complaint Review Board found 180 instances from 2010 to October 2015 in which the police carried out improper home entries and searches.
lead_paragraph: A team of plainclothes New York City police officers, tracking the signal of a stolen cellphone, pushed past a man who denied the officers permission to enter his home and searched it floor by floor. A sergeant forced the man to wait outside in his underwear in the rain.

headline: Quiz: How Much Grit Do You Have?
abstract: Here’s a sample of the Grit Scale, developed to identify traits that might predict success.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a sample of the Grit Scale, developed to identify traits that might predict success.

headline: Ideas Help No One on a Shelf. Take Them to the World.
abstract: Distributing, promoting and lending continuing support to good ideas for fixing the world’s woes is as critical a task as thinking them up in the first place.
lead_paragraph: Have you thought of a clever product to mitigate climate change? Did you invent an ingenious gadget to light African villages at night? Have you come up with a new kind of school, or new ideas for lowering the rate of urban shootings?

headline: Magistrate Judge James Orenstein’s Order
abstract: A federal judge has denied the United States government’s request to open up an Apple iPhone in a drug case in New York.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge has denied the United States government’s request to open up an Apple iPhone in a drug case in New York.

headline: Jets Are Said to Be Planning on Franchise Tag for Muhammad Wilkerson
abstract: By tagging the standout defensive lineman before Tuesday’s deadline, the Jets would have until July 15 to reach a multiyear contract with Wilkerson, 26.
lead_paragraph: The Jets’ contract impasse with the standout defensive lineman Muhammad Wilkerson, spanning years and regimes, will reach an expected stage Tuesday. The Jets intend to designate Wilkerson as their franchise player before the 4 p.m. deadline, according to a person in football with knowledge of their plans, in a maneuver that allows them to retain his rights while extending the window for brokering a long-term contract.

headline: George Kennedy Dies at 91; Versatile Actor Won Oscar for ‘Cool Hand Luke’
abstract: With the exception of his Academy Award performance in 1967 and his work in about a dozen other films, Mr. Kennedy was most often a peripheral player.
lead_paragraph: George Kennedy, who played tough guys, oafs, G.I.’s and a bonanza of cowboys as one of Hollywood’s most versatile and durable character actors, and who won an Oscar as the best supporting actor of 1967 for his performance in the Paul Newman film “Cool Hand Luke,” died on Sunday in Boise, Idaho. He was 91.

headline: New Study Links Zika Virus to Temporary Paralysis
abstract: Mosquito-borne Zika virus may lead to increased risk of Guillain-Barré syndrome, which leaves patients unable to move and in some cases requires life support.
lead_paragraph: A new study of 42 cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome in French Polynesia offers the strongest evidence to date that the Zika virus can trigger temporary paralysis, researchers reported on Monday. But experts cautioned that more evidence from other locations was needed to be conclusive.

headline: It’s Stephen Curry’s Game Now
abstract: The Warriors’ butterfly with a jump shot, Curry is changing how we understand basketball.
lead_paragraph: If you have somehow missed watching the Golden State Warriors this season, you might have a quaint notion of how basketball is played.

headline: Auto Safety Agency Resists Broader Recall of Takata Airbags
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said that such a recall would not improve public safety, and might exceed its authority.
lead_paragraph: Under pressure from some lawmakers to recall all Takata airbags, the nation’s top auto safety regulator responded that such a recall would not improve public safety, and might exceed the agency’s authority.

headline: Artists’ Children, Depicted By Their Parents
abstract: Inspired by the paintings of Vigée Le Brun, 13 contemporary artists portray their own kids.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the paintings of Vigée Le Brun, 13 contemporary artists portray their own kids.
